Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are pattern recognition receptors that recognize conserved structures on pathogens and are involved in the recognition of microbial pathogens and in the induction of innate immune responses. So far, 1 3TLR members have been identified in mammals and TLR1-TLR1 3 are encoded in the human genome. TLR1-TLR6 and TLR1 0 are expressed on the cell surface, while TLR2, TLR4, TLR5, and TLR6 are expressed in intracellular compartments such as the plasma membrane and the endosome. TLR2 forms heterodimers with either TLR1 or TLR6 to recognize triacyl or diacyl lipopeptides derived from Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, respectively. TLR4 recognizes lipopolysaccharide (LPS), a component of Gram-negative bacteria. TLR3, TLR7, and TLR9 are localized in intracellular compartments and recognize nucleic acids derived from viruses or bacteria. TLR4 is also activated by the endogenous ligands, heat shock proteins and high-mobility group box 1 protein. Upon ligand recognition, TLRs recruit the adaptor proteins to transduce signals. MyD8 8 is the common adaptor protein for all TLRs except for TLR3. TRIF is the adaptor protein for TLR3 and TLR4. RIP1 and TRAF6 are also involved in the signaling of MyD8 8-dependent TLRs. TRIF is the adaptor protein for TLR3 and TLR4.

Endocytosis is a key mechanism for regulating the abundance of cell-surface proteins and lipids. Endocytosis can be constitutive or ligand-induced. Constitutive endocytosis occurs when proteins are delivered to the cell surface directly from the biosynthetic pathway or via recycling endosomes. Ligand-induced endocytosis is initiated by ligand binding to its receptor and the formation of clathrin-coated pits. The receptor-ligand complex is then internalized via clathrin-dependent endocytosis (CDE) or clathrin-independent endocytosis (CIE). CDE is mediated by lipid rafts, caveolae, or clathrin-independent mechanisms. The majority of internalized receptors are either recycled back to the cell surface or sorted to late endosomes and lysosomes for degradation.

The calcium-release channel of the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR), also known as the ryanodine receptor (RyR), is a large homotetrameric protein complex that is expressed in the junctional membrane of the SR (JSR). Each RyR channel is a macromolecular complex composed of four subunits, each of which has a 60-kDa pore-forming subunit and a regulatory or channel-associated subunit. The primary regulator of the RyR channel is the calcium-release channel modulator (or calsequestrin), which binds 4 mol of Ca2 + per mol of calsequestrin. The release of Ca2 + from the SR is triggered by the binding of Ca2 + to the RyR channel, which results in a conformational change of the channel and its subsequent opening. The Ca2 + that is released from the SR is transported to the myofilaments by the Ca2 + -ATPase of the SR (SERCA), which is also a homotetrameric protein complex. The SERCA pump is regulated by phospholamban, which binds to each of the SERCA subunits. The Ca2 + that is transported back into the SR is pumped back into the lumen by the uphill transport of protons by the mitochondrial Ca2 + -ATPase (or F1F0-ATPase).

IL-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that inhibits the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-1, TNF-alpha, IL-6 and IL-8. IL-10 also induces the production of the anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-1RA. The IL-10 receptor is a heterodimer of IL-10R1 and IL-10R2. The IL-10R1 subunit is shared with the IL-6 receptor and is responsible for ligand binding and signal transduction. The IL-10R2 subunit is required for ligand binding and receptor internalization but is not required for signal transduction. The IL-10R1 subunit is also found in the IL-6 receptor and is responsible for the specificity of the IL-10 and IL-6 receptors. Binding of IL-10 to the IL-10R1 / IL-10R2 receptor complex activates the JAK / STAT pathway and induces the expression of anti-inflammatory genes such as heme oxygenase-1. The anti-inflammatory properties of IL-10 make it an attractive therapeutic agent for the treatment of inflammatory diseases such as arthritis.

The cell cycle is a series of events that a cell goes through in order to prepare for and prosecute its duplication and division. The cell cycle is divided into four phases: G1, S, G2 and M. The G1 phase is the gap phase between the synthesis (S) and duplication (M) phases. The G1 to S phase transition is regulated by the cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs). The CDKs are a family of serine / threonine kinases that are activated by association with cyclins. The CDKs are activated by the removal of inhibitory phosphorylation and the addition of a phosphate group by the CDK-activating kinase (CAK). The CDKs in turn phosphorylate targets that regulate the cell cycle. The G1 to S phase transition is regulated by the phosphorylation of the RB protein by the cyclin D-CDK4 / 6 kinases. The phosphorylation of RB causes the release of the E2F transcription factor, which activates the transcription of genes required for S phase. The activation of the cyclin E-CDK2 kinase at the G1 to S phase transition further phosphorylates RB, and other targets, that are required for the progression through S phase and into G2. The G2 to M phase transition is regulated by the activation of the cyclin B-CDK1 kinase. The activity of the cyclin B-CDK1 kinase is regulated by the destruction of cyclin B and the phosphorylation of CDK1 by the Wee1 and Myt1 kinases. The completion of DNA replication in S phase triggers the activation of the G2 to M phase transition by the activation of the cyclin A-CDK1 kinase. The activation of the cyclin B-CDK1 kinase at the G2 to M phase transition is inhibited by the protein kinase Myt1. The completion of mitosis triggers the destruction of cyclin B by the anaphase-promoting complex (APC), and the inactivation of the cyclin A-CDK1 kinase by the phosphatase Cdc2 5C. The completion of mitosis is signaled by the activation of the spindle assembly checkpoint, which inhibits the cyclin B-CDK1 kinase and the APC until all of the chromosomes are properly aligned on the metaphase plate. The spindle assembly checkpoint inhibits the APC to prevent the destruction of cyclin B and the activation of the cyclin A-CDK1 kinase until all of the chromosomes are aligned on the metaphase plate. The activation of the spindle assembly checkpoint also inhibits the APC to prevent the destruction of cyclin B and the activation of the cyclin A-CDK1 kinase until all of the chromosomes are aligned on the metaphase plate.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease, with a wide range of clinical outcomes. Some patients are cured with current therapies, while others have a poor prognosis. The molecular basis of AML is complex and heterogeneous, with a large number of genetic alterations identified to date. Some of these alterations are associated with favorable prognosis, such as the t (8; 2 1) translocation, which generates the AML1-ETO fusion protein. Other alterations are associated with a poor prognosis, such as the inv, which generates the CBFB-MYH1 1 fusion protein. The t (9; 2 2) translocation, which generates the BCR-ABL fusion protein, is associated with a particularly poor prognosis. The molecular mechanisms by which these fusion proteins contribute to leukemogenesis are not yet clear.

Hypoxia is a common feature of solid tumors and is associated with increased angiogenesis, invasion and metastasis. The transcription factor HIF-1 is a key mediator of the cellular response to hypoxia. Under normoxic conditions, HIF-1 is rapidly degraded by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. Oxygen-dependent prolyl hydroxylases (PHDs) hydroxylate HIF-1 on two conserved prolyl residues. This leads to the binding of von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor protein (pVHL), an E3 ubiquitin ligase component, and subsequent degradation of HIF-1 by the proteasome. Under hypoxic conditions, HIF-1 is stabilized and activates the transcription of genes involved in many aspects of tumor progression, including angiogenesis, glycolysis, erythropoiesis, and cell survival. Another oxygen-sensitive factor is the ribosomal protein S6 kinase, 4EBP-1, which is phosphorylated by the mTOR kinase under hypoxic conditions, leading to the dissociation of eIF-4E and eIF-4G and the activation of protein translation.

The immune system consists of a variety of cells that respond to different stimuli. Macrophages, B cells, and T cells are all involved in the immune response. Macrophages are the cells of the innate immune system that respond to non-specific stimuli like bacterial products like LPS. B cells produce antibodies that are specific for a particular antigen. T cells are the cells of the adaptive immune system that respond to specific antigens and provide a more long-lasting response. Macrophages and B cells respond to bacterial stimuli by producing cytokines that stimulate other immune cells. Macrophages also present antigen to T cells in the adaptive immune response. B cells produce antibodies that bind specific antigens and are transported to the B cell receptor (BCR) on the surface of T cells. The BCR binds antigen and the T cell receptor (TCR) binds to the MHC protein associated with the antigen. The interaction of the BCR and TCR activates T cells and stimulates T cell proliferation and cytokine production. Macrophages and T cells also communicate with each other through cytokines. Macrophages produce cytokines that stimulate T cell proliferation and activation. T cells produce cytokines that stimulate macrophage activation and proliferation.

Homologous recombination (HR) is a mechanism for the error-free repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs). HR is initiated by the resection of DNA ends to generate 3 'single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) tails. The 3' ssDNA tails are first coated by the ssDNA-binding protein RPA, which is then replaced by the recombinase Rad5 1. The Rad5 1-ssDNA filament then searches for a homologous sequence and searches for and invades a homologous duplex, forming a joint molecule with the single-stranded DNA, followed by DNA synthesis and then DNA ligation. The Holliday junction is an intermediate of HR and can be resolved by either of two different pathways, by structure-specific endonucleases or by DNA helicases and topoisomerases.

The transcription factor NF-kB is a key regulator of genes involved in the immune response, apoptosis, and cellular transformation. Normally sequestered in the cytoplasm by an inhibitor protein, IkB, activation of NF-kB occurs through phosphorylation of IkB, its subsequent ubiquitination and degradation in the proteosome. The kinase that phosphorylates IkB is activated by a variety of stimuli, including tumor necrosis factor, interleukin-1, bacterial lipopolysaccharide, and viral infection. Once phosphorylated, IkB is ubiquitinated and degraded, releasing NF-kB to translocate to the nucleus and bind to DNA and activate transcription. The kinase that phosphorylates IkB is NIK (NF-kB-inducing kinase), a member of the map kinase family. The NIK gene was identified as a potential oncogene in a study of a chromosomal translocation found in a subset of Hodgkin's lymphomas. The translocation fuses the NIK gene to the Ig heavy-chain locus, resulting in constitutive expression of NIK. The kinase activity of NIK is required for NF-kB activation, as a kinase-inactive mutant of NIK does not activate NF-kB. The kinase activity of NIK is also required for activation of the transcription factor ATF2, another substrate of NIK. The map kinase kinase MEKK1 also activates NF-kB, but MEKK1 does not activate NIK, indicating that MEKK1 and NIK act in parallel pathways to activate NF-kB. The p53 tumor suppressor gene also activates NF-kB, but does so through a p53-dependent pathway that does not involve NF-kB activation.

The innate immune response is triggered by the presence of microbial products, such as lipopolysaccharide (LPS), in the extracellular environment. The LPS receptor is a member of the Toll-like receptor (TLR) gene family. The TLR family is found in both the innate and adaptive immune systems. In the innate immune system, TLR signaling activates the expression of cytokines and other genes that stimulate the inflammatory response. In adaptive immunity, TLR signaling stimulates the activation and proliferation of antigen-specific lymphocytes. In addition to the TLR family, the innate immune system contains a variety of intracellular signaling molecules, including the adaptor protein MyD8 8, the kinase IRAK, and the transcription factor NF-kB. The activation of innate immunity by LPS is a complex process. LPS is a complex molecule, consisting of a lipid A portion that is responsible for the toxicity of the molecule, and a core oligosaccharide portion that is required for the biological activity of the molecule. The lipid A portion of LPS interacts with the TLR4 / MD2 receptor complex, activating signaling through the MyD8 8-dependent pathway. The core oligosaccharide portion of LPS interacts with the TLR4 / MD2 receptor complex, activating signaling through the MyD8 8-independent pathway. The activation of innate immunity by LPS is a key component of the response to infection by Gram-negative bacteria. The activation of innate immunity by LPS also has important therapeutic implications. The inappropriate activation of innate immunity by LPS can lead to septic shock, a condition involving multiple organ failure and death that is associated with the inappropriate activation of the innate immune system. The inappropriate activation of innate immunity by LPS may also play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma and other inflammatory conditions.

The complement system is a major component of the humoral immune response. It is activated by three different pathways, the classical pathway, the lectin pathway, and the alternative pathway. The first two pathways are triggered by antibody-antigen complexes or by interaction with microbial carbohydrates, respectively. The alternative pathway is initiated spontaneously by C3 convertase formation. The three initiating pathways converge in the formation of C3 convertase, which cleaves the third complement component (C3) into C3a and C3b. The opsonin C3b is involved in phagocytosis of the infectious agent and in the formation of the C5 convertase. The C5 convertase cleaves C5 into the anaphylatoxin C5a and C5b. C5b associates with C6, C7, and C9 to form the membrane attack complex (MAC). The MAC causes osmotic lysis of cells that are not protected by CD5 9. The anaphylatoxin C5a is involved in the recruitment and activation of inflammatory cells. C5b-9 induces the expression of adhesion molecules on endothelial cells and stimulates the release of vasoactive mediators from these cells.

The liver is the major site of heme synthesis and degradation. Heme is an essential cofactor for many proteins, but it is also toxic in excess. Heme oxygenase (HO) catalyzes the first and rate-limiting step in heme degradation, converting heme to carbon monoxide (CO), free iron, and the by-product biliverdin. HO-1 is an inducible stress protein that is induced by a variety of stimuli including heme, metals, oxidative stress, and cytokines. HO-1 expression is also induced by the transcription factor Nrf2. HO-1 induction results in the production of CO, which has been implicated in the regulation of vascular tone, inflammation, and apoptosis. Biliverdin is subsequently converted to bilirubin by the enzyme biliverdin reductase. The antioxidant properties of bilirubin have been proposed to be responsible for the anti-inflammatory and antiapoptotic properties of HO-1. The production of free iron by HO-1 is also important in iron homeostasis. The release of iron from heme can be utilized by the body to synthesize heme and also stored in ferritin. In addition to its role in heme metabolism, HO-1 has been implicated in the regulation of apoptosis, inflammation, and angiogenesis.

The Hedgehog (Hh) family of secreted proteins plays a key role in development of many different tissues and organs. In the developing central nervous system, Hh signaling is required for the proliferation of neuronal precursor cells and for the survival of neurons. Hh signaling also plays a key role in the development of the skin, regulating the proliferation of epidermal cells. Mutations in components of the Hh signaling pathway have been associated with several types of cancer, including basal cell carcinoma of the skin, and some forms of lung, pancreatic, and colon cancer. Hh signaling is mediated by the transcription factors Gli1, Gli2, and Gli3. In the absence of Hh ligand, the Patched (Ptc) protein inhibits the activity of the signaling pathway by an as yet unknown mechanism. Binding of Hh to Ptc relieves inhibition of the pathway, allowing activation of the pathway by the Gli proteins. Activation of the pathway results in the nuclear translocation of Gli1, which activates transcription of target genes.

The cell cycle is a highly coordinated sequence of events that includes DNA replication, chromosome segregation, and cell division. Mitosis is the phase of the cell cycle during which the cell's genome is divided into two daughter cells. Mitosis is also the phase during which the cell's chromosomes are condensed. Mitosis is triggered by the activation of a cyclin-dependent kinase (Cdk1), also known as maturation promoting factor (MPF). The activation of MPF is regulated by the cyclin subunit and the phosphorylation state of Cdk1. The activation of MPF triggers the entry into mitosis and the initiation of chromosome condensation. The activation of MPF is opposed by the protein tyrosine phosphatase Cdc2 5. The activation of MPF is also opposed by the protein kinase Wee1. The activation of Wee1 is opposed by the kinase Myt1. The activation of Wee1 and Myt1 is opposed by the protein kinase Chk1. The checkpoint kinase Chk1 is activated by the DNA damage checkpoint. The activation of Chk1 by DNA damage inhibits the activation of MPF by Cdc2 5, Wee1, and Myt1. The DNA replication checkpoint also inhibits the activation of MPF by blocking the activation of Cdc2 5. The DNA replication checkpoint also inhibits the activation of MPF by blocking the degradation of cyclin B. The DNA damage checkpoint inhibits the activation of MPF by blocking the degradation of cyclin B.

The ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS) is a major pathway for protein degradation in cells. Proteins are tagged with ubiquitin before they are degraded by the proteasome. The addition of ubiquitin to proteins is a multistep process involving three enzymes: a ubiquitin activating enzyme (E1), a ubiquitin conjugating enzyme (E2), and a ubiquitin ligase (E3). The specificity of the UPS pathway is determined by the E3 enzymes. The alpha-synuclein protein is a major component of Lewy bodies, the hallmark pathological lesions of Parkinson's disease. The presence of alpha-synuclein in Lewy bodies suggests that the protein may be involved in the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease. The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a receptor tyrosine kinase that is widely expressed in epithelial tissues and is involved in the regulation of cell proliferation, differentiation and migration. Overexpression of EGFR has been observed in many human cancers and is associated with a more aggressive tumor phenotype and a poor prognosis. Binding of EGF or TGF-alpha to EGFR induces receptor dimerization, activation of the intrinsic protein kinase activity of the receptor, and autophosphorylation of the receptor on specific tyrosine residues. These phosphorylated residues serve as binding sites for proteins containing src homology 2 (SH2) or phosphotyrosine binding (PTB) domains. These downstream signaling molecules include the GRB2-SOS-RAS-RAF-MEK-ERK pathway and the PI3 kinase-AKT pathway. EGFR activation also leads to the activation of NF-kB through the PI3 kinase-AKT pathway and the p38 kinase pathway. The activation of NF-kB by EGFR contributes to cell survival and anti-apoptosis.

The fibrinolytic system is a proteolytic cascade that degrades fibrin clots and plays a key role in the maintenance of hemostasis. The key components of the fibrinolytic system are the serine proteases tissue-type plasminogen activator (tPA) and urokinase-type plasminogen activator (uPA), their inhibitors (PAIs), and the fibrin clot itself. The fibrinolytic system is activated by the binding of tPA and uPA to fibrin clots, releasing the catalytic serine proteases, tPA and uPA, from their respective proenzyme forms. The tPA-plasminogen activator inhibitor 1 (PAI1) complex is the most active fibrinolytic complex, and is responsible for the degradation of fibrin clots. The uPA-plasminogen activator inhibitor 1 (PAI1) complex is less active than the tPA-PAI1 complex, but is also involved in the degradation of fibrin clots. The balance between the activators and inhibitors of the fibrinolytic system is critical for the proper functioning of the fibrinolytic system. Deficiencies in the components of the fibrinolytic system can lead to excessive fibrin formation and the formation of thrombi, which can result in heart attacks and strokes. The fibrinolytic system is also involved in other processes, including the migration of cells, the release of growth factors, and the activation of complement. The components of the fibrinolytic system are found in a variety of tissues and cells, including the lungs, kidneys, brain, and heart. The tPA and uPA genes are located on different chromosomes and are regulated by different mechanisms. The tPA gene is regulated by the binding of the transcription factor Egr-1 to the tPA promoter. The uPA gene is regulated by the transcription factors AP-1 and PEA3. The PAIs are a family of proteins that bind to and inhibit tPA and uPA. The PAIs are regulated by the protease plasmin, which cleaves and inactivates tPA and uPA. The PAIs are also regulated by the protease inhibitor PAI-2. The formation of a fibrin clot is initiated by the activation of the clotting factors thrombin and factor XII. The clot is then degraded by the fibrinolytic system, activated by the binding of tPA and uPA to fibrin clots. The components of the fibrinolytic system are potential therapeutic targets for the treatment of thrombosis and other conditions involving excessive fibrin formation.

Taste perception is triggered by the detection of a wide variety of compounds by taste receptors. These receptors are localized in the taste bud cells and are grouped into five classes: the bitter, sweet, umami, amino acid and salt receptors. Bitter, sweet and umami compounds are detected by specific receptors, the T2Rs, T1Rs and mGluRs, respectively. Bitter and sweet compounds are detected by two distinct families of GPCRs, the T1R and T2R families, respectively. The T1Rs and T2Rs form heterodimers that are activated by tastants. The umami receptor is a heterodimer formed by T1Rs and a metabotropic glutamate receptor, mGluR4. The amino acid receptor is a heterodimer formed by a cationic amino acid transporter and a vomeronasal receptor, V1R. Salty compounds are detected by a heterodimer formed by a sodium channel and a TRP channel, such as TRPM5. Food compounds such as lipids, proteins and nucleotides are detected by a variety of mechanisms.

T cell activation is initiated by the interaction of the T cell receptor (TCR) with antigen-bound MHC on the surface of an antigen-presenting cell (APC). This interaction leads to the activation of the T cell receptor complex (TCR) -associated protein tyrosine kinases Lck and Fyn, which phosphorylate several proteins in the TCR complex, including the CD3 subunits. The phosphorylation of the TCR complex creates binding sites for other proteins, including the adaptor protein LAT. LAT also becomes phosphorylated, creating binding sites for other signaling proteins. One of the first events following TCR engagement is the activation of the small G-protein Ras. Ras activates a kinase cascade that includes the kinases Raf, Mek and Erk, which ultimately leads to the activation of transcription factors such as NFAT and AP-1. The protein kinase C (PKC) family of proteins also plays an important role in T cell activation. The activation of PKC is dependent on the second messenger diacylglycerol (DAG), which is produced by the cleavage of phosphatidylinositol-4, 5-bisphosphate by phospholipase C (PLC). DAG activates the kinase PKC, which in turn activates the transcription factor NF-AT. DAG also activates the kinase Raf, which activates the kinase Mek, which activates Erk. The activation of PKC and the kinase cascade downstream of Ras are all dependent on the presence of calcium. The activation of NF-AT and AP-1 by the Ras pathway and the activation of NF-kB by the PKC pathway are important for the activation of T cells. The activation of T cells is also regulated by the phosphatase calcineurin, which is activated by calcium and dephosphorylates NFAT and other transcription factors.

Inflammation is a protective response to infection, but chronic inflammation can damage tissues. The first step in inflammation is the activation of the complement system, a cascade of plasma proteins that is activated by the presence of foreign cells or foreign molecules. The activated complement proteins recruit and activate leukocytes to the site of inflammation, causing the release of inflammatory factors that help clear the infection. The activated complement proteins also cause lysis of the cells that activate the complement system, helping to remove infected or damaged cells. The membrane attack complex (MAC) formed by the complement system causes lysis of cells and is a part of the immune system that kills bacteria. The membrane attack complex also causes lysis of red blood cells, leading to anemia. The activated complement proteins also attract and activate other cells in the immune response, including macrophages and mast cells. Macrophages phagocytose cells that have been killed by the complement system, and release inflammatory factors to help fight infection. Mast cells release inflammatory factors in response to the complement system, and are involved in allergic reactions. Macrophages and mast cells also express adhesion molecules that help recruit other cells to the site of inflammation. Adhesion molecules on the surface of cells bind to receptors on other cells, helping to keep cells in the proper location and facilitating communication between cells. The complement system, macrophages, and mast cells all play an important role in the immune response, but can also cause inflammation in response to infection when they are activated inappropriately.

The T cell receptor (TCR) is a multi-subunit complex that is expressed on the surface of T cells and is responsible for the recognition of specific peptide antigens in the context of MHC molecules. The TCR is composed of six different polypeptide chains, alpha and beta chains that form the variable region of the receptor, and three chains, gamma, delta, and epsilon that form the constant region. The TCR complex is associated with a multi-subunit complex of proteins that includes the CD3 subunits and the CD4 and CD8 co-receptors. The CD3 subunits are responsible for the association of the TCR with the signaling machinery in the T cell. The activation of the T cell is initiated by the binding of the TCR to peptide-MHC complex on an antigen-presenting cell. This binding causes a conformational change in the TCR complex that leads to the activation of the T cell. The activation of the T cell is accompanied by the activation of a number of different signaling pathways that lead to T cell activation.

The insulin receptor is a key component of the insulin signaling pathway. The binding of insulin to the receptor leads to the activation of the Ras / Raf / MAPK pathway and the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI 3-kinase) pathway. The Ras / Raf / MAPK pathway leads to the phosphorylation of transcription factors such as ELK-1 and p38, resulting in the activation of genes such as c-fos and c-jun. The PI 3-kinase pathway leads to the phosphorylation of AKT and GSK-3, and the activation of transcription factors such as c-myc and FKHRL1. The activation of these transcription factors leads to the regulation of genes involved in metabolism, growth and differentiation.

The mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) cascade is a highly conserved signal transduction module that is involved in the regulation of a variety of cellular processes, including differentiation, proliferation, motility, survival and apoptosis. The MAPK cascade is typically organized into kinase cascades, in which a MAPK kinase kinase (MAPKKK) phosphorylates and thereby activates a MAPK kinase (MAPKK), which in turn phosphorylates and thereby activates a MAPK. The MAPKs are Erk1 / 2, JNK, and p38. Each of these MAPKs is activated by a different MAPKK, and each MAPKK is activated by a different MAPKKK. The MAPKKKs include the Raf, Mek, and p38 kinases. The upstream activators of the MAPKKKs are the growth factor receptors, G-protein-coupled receptors, and cytokines. The activation of the MAPK cascade is initiated by the binding of a growth factor to its receptor, followed by the activation of Ras. The activation of Ras leads to the recruitment of the adaptor proteins Shc and Grb2, which together with the exchange factor Sos-1 activate the Mek1 / 2-Erk1 / 2 cascade. The activation of the p38 cascade is initiated by the cytokines, followed by the activation of the NF-kB pathway.

Splicing is a key step in gene expression that removes introns from precursor mRNA (pre-mRNA) and ligates the exons to form a mature mRNA that can be translated into a protein. Splicing takes place in a macromolecular complex called the spliceosome, which consists of five small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNPs), U1, U2, U4, U5, and U6 snRNPs, and many other proteins. Spliceosomes assemble on the conserved sequences at the 5 'and 3' splice sites and the branch point, a highly conserved sequence of introns, in a stepwise manner. The first step of splicing, termed the recognition of the splice sites, is a dynamic process that involves the exchange of some proteins for other ones. After recognition, the spliceosome is activated and the spliceosome is converted to the first catalytic step. The second step of splicing involves the ligation of exons and the release of the intron lariat.

Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) is a serious complication of bone marrow transplantation (BMT). GVHD is caused by the attack of donor T cells on host tissues. In addition to the direct attack of cytotoxic T cells (CTLs) on host cells, cytokines produced by activated T cells are also involved in the pathogenesis of GVHD. The interaction of donor T cells with host cells leads to the activation of nuclear factor-kappaB (NF-kappaB) and the expression of cytokines, such as TNF-alpha and IL-1. These cytokines can induce apoptosis in host cells, which may contribute to the pathogenesis of GVHD.

Hypertrophy is a complex pathological growth of the heart that can lead to heart failure. Cardiac hypertrophy is induced by various stimuli, including pressure overload, volume overload, and genetic defects. Cardiac hypertrophy is initially an adaptive response to increased hemodynamic load, in which the heart enlarges in an attempt to normalize wall stress and maintain cardiac function. However, prolonged cardiac hypertrophy is a risk factor for cardiovascular disease and is associated with an increased risk of heart failure and sudden death. Cardiac hypertrophy is initially characterized by an increase in the size of cardiomyocytes without an increase in their number. This is followed by re-expression of fetal genes, such as atrial natriuretic factor (ANF) and beta-myosin heavy chain (beta-MHC), which are normally expressed only in fetal hearts. The fetal gene program is associated with a decrease in the expression of contractile proteins, such as myosin heavy chain (MHC) and actin, and an increase in the expression of natriuretic peptides, which are involved in the regulation of blood pressure and volume. The reactivation of the fetal gene program is associated with a decrease in the activity of the transcription factor, myocyte enhancer factor-2 (MEF-2). The activity of MEF-2 is regulated by various signaling pathways, including the calcineurin / nuclear factor of activated T cells (NFAT) pathway, the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway, and the calcium / calmodulin-dependent protein kinase (CaMK) pathway. The calcineurin / NFAT pathway is involved in the development of cardiac hypertrophy. Calcineurin is a calcium-activated phosphatase that dephosphorylates NFAT, leading to its nuclear localization and activation of gene expression. Calcineurin is activated by an increase in intracellular calcium concentration, which is induced by various stimuli, including pressure overload. Calcineurin activation leads to the nuclear localization of NFAT and the subsequent activation of fetal genes. The MAPK pathway is also involved in the development of cardiac hypertrophy. The expression of ANF and beta-MHC is increased by the activation of extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK), c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK), and p3 8 MAPK. Calcineurin dephosphorylates and activates MAPK kinase (MAPKK), which in turn activates ERK, JNK, and p3 8 MAPK. Calcineurin also activates MEF-2, which is involved in the reactivation of the fetal gene program. The calcium / calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II (CaMK) pathway is also involved in the development of cardiac hypertrophy. CaMK activates NFAT, which is also activated by calcineurin. The reactivation of the fetal gene program is also involved in the development of cardiac hypertrophy. The inhibition of CaMK by KN6 2 or KN9 3 inhibits the reactivation of the fetal gene program and the development of cardiac hypertrophy.

Interleukin 4 (IL-4) is a cytokine that is produced by activated Th2 cells and is involved in the differentiation of B cells into antibody-secreting cells. IL-4 also plays a role in the differentiation of monocytes into macrophages and the activation of eosinophils. The IL-4 receptor is a member of the hematopoietin receptor family and is composed of two chains, a ligand-specific alpha chain and a common gamma chain that is shared with other cytokines in the IL-2 family. The alpha chain is required for high affinity binding and is not itself a signaling protein. The gamma chain is also shared by other cytokines in the IL-2 family. Binding of IL-4 to the alpha / gamma receptor complex activates JAK kinases and the STAT proteins, STAT6 being the major STAT activated by IL-4. The JAK / STAT pathway is also activated by other cytokines in the hematopoeitic growth factor family, and the IL-4 receptor is a member of this family. The JAK / STAT pathway is a point of convergence for multiple signaling pathways and is involved in many cellular responses. The JAK / STAT pathway is also involved in the differentiation of B cells into antibody-secreting cells. The JAK / STAT pathway is also involved in other cellular responses to IL-4, such as the activation of monocytes and the differentiation of eosinophils. The JAK / STAT pathway is also involved in other cellular responses to cytokines, such as the induction of the anti-apoptotic gene bcl-xL. The JAK / STAT pathway is also involved in other cellular responses to cytokines, such as the induction of the acute phase response.

Base excision repair (BER) is the predominant pathway for the repair of small base lesions in DNA, such as uracil, thymine, 5mUra, 3meA, 8oxoG, and other modified bases. BER is initiated by the excision of the damaged base by a specific DNA glycosylase, followed by incision of the DNA backbone at the resulting apurinic / apyrimidinic (AP) site by an AP endonuclease. In mammalian cells, BER is accomplished by a series of steps. (i) Glycosylase removes the damaged base. (ii) AP endonuclease incises the DNA 5 'to the AP site. (iii) DNA polymerase (pol) fills in the single nucleotide gap, and then (iv) DNA ligase (Lig) seals the remaining nick.

The ubiquitin-proteasome pathway (UPP) is the major non-lysosomal proteolytic system in eukaryotes. It is responsible for the degradation of most intracellular proteins, including regulatory proteins involved in cell cycle control, signal transduction, antigen processing, apoptosis, and stress response. The proteasome is a large multiprotein complex that degrades ubiquitinated proteins. The proteolytic activity of the proteasome is carried out by three distinct activities: trypsin-like (T-L), chymotrypsin-like (C-L), and peptidylglutamyl peptide-hydrolyzing (PGPH). The proteasome is a 26S proteasome in which one or both of the regulatory particles PA70 0 (PA70 0) and PA28 (PA28) are required. PA28 is also called PA300. PA28 binds to PA70 0 and is responsible for the binding of the proteasome to ubiquitinated proteins. PA28 is a ring-shaped structure with a 20S core. PA28 is composed of 20S subunits alpha 10beta 10beta 

The TNF receptor superfamily contains several members that induce apoptosis or programmed cell death when activated by their cognate ligands. One of the receptors in this family, TNFR1, can also induce the activation of the transcription factor NF-kB. The activation of NF-kB by TNFR1 requires the receptor to be in a complex with the adaptor protein TRADD. TRADD interacts with the kinase RIP and also with the kinase NIK. RIP and NIK activate the I-kB kinases, which phosphorylate and thereby activate the NF-kB transcription factors. The activation of NF-kB by TNFR1 also requires the kinase activity of the receptor. The activation of NF-kB by TNFR1 requires the receptor to be in a complex with TRADD, but does not require RIP. The activation of NF-kB by TNFR1 also requires the kinase activity of the receptor. The activation of NF-kB by TNFR1 requires the receptor to be in a complex with TRADD, but does not require RIP. The activation of NF-kB by TNFR1 requires the receptor to be in a complex with TRADD, but does not require RIP. The activation of NF-kB by TNFR1 also requires the kinase activity of the receptor. The activation of NF-kB by TNFR1 requires the receptor to be in a complex with TRADD, but does not require RIP. The activation of NF-kB by TNFR1 also requires the kinase activity of the receptor.

Granzyme B is a serine protease released from cytotoxic T cells and natural killer cells that induces apoptosis in target cells. Granzyme B enters the target cell and is transported to the nucleus, where it cleaves nuclear proteins, including DNA-dependent protein kinase (DNA-PK), topoisomerase II, and NuMA. The cleavage of these proteins by granzyme B leads to the nuclear changes associated with apoptosis. The cleavage of DNA-PK and topoisomerase II by granzyme B also activates the DNA-damage response pathway, which may amplify the apoptotic signal. The cleavage of NuMA by granzyme B may be involved in the reorganization of the cytoskeleton that occurs during apoptosis. Granzyme B also activates caspase-3, a protease that is responsible for most of the proteolytic events during apoptosis. Granzyme B activates caspase-3 by cleaving the caspase-3 inhibitor, XIAP. The cleavage of XIAP by granzyme B relieves inhibition of caspase-3, allowing caspase-3 to cleave other cellular targets and induce apoptosis. Granzyme B also activates caspase-independent pathways of apoptosis. The cleavage of the anti-apoptotic protein Bid by granzyme B induces the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria, which then activates caspase-9 and caspase-3. Granzyme B also activates a caspase-independent apoptotic pathway that does not require caspase activation. Granzyme B activates apoptosis by multiple pathways, and the relative importance of each pathway may depend on the cell type and the environment of the cell.

The chemokine (C-C motif) ligand 2 1 (CCL2 1) is a ligand for the chemokine receptor CCR7. CCR7 is expressed on the surface of immature DCs and mature DCs. CCR7 expression is induced by inflammatory stimuli such as LPS and TNF-alpha. CCL2 1 is expressed in high levels in the secondary lymphoid tissues, including the spleen, thymus, and lymph nodes. CCL2 1 binds to CCR7 and induces chemotaxis of immature and mature DCs. DCs that have migrated to the secondary lymphoid tissues respond to CCL2 1 by migrating to the T cell zone of the lymph nodes. DCs that have not migrated to the T cell zone of the lymph nodes respond to CCL2 1 by migrating to the B cell zone of the lymph nodes. DCs that have migrated to the B cell zone of the lymph nodes respond to CCL2 1 by migrating to the T cell zone of the lymph nodes. DCs that have migrated to the T cell zone of the lymph nodes respond to CCL2 1 by migrating to the B cell zone of the lymph nodes. DCs that have migrated to the B cell zone of the lymph nodes respond to CCL2 1 by migrating to the T cell zone of the lymph nodes. DCs that have migrated to the T cell zone of the lymph nodes respond to CCL2 1 by migrating to the B cell zone of the lymph nodes. DCs that have not migrated to the lymph nodes respond to CCL2 1 by migrating to the spleen.

The cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA) is a serine / threonine kinase that is activated by the second messenger cAMP. The PKA holoenzyme is a tetramer consisting of two regulatory subunits and two catalytic subunits. The regulatory subunits bind to four molecules of cAMP and are released upon binding of cAMP to the catalytic subunits. The PKA regulatory subunit 100is encoded by the PRKAR1A gene. Loss of function mutations in PRKAR1A lead to the cAMP-independent activation of PKA and the Carney complex, a multiple neoplasia syndrome. The PKA catalytic subunit 110is encoded by the PRKACA gene. Mutations in PRKACA lead to constitutive activation of PKA and are associated with the development of cortisol-secreting adrenal adenomas. The PKA holoenzyme is also regulated by the cAMP-regulated guanine nucleotide exchange factor (Epac). Epac1 and Epac2 are guanine nucleotide exchange factors for the Ras-like GTPases Rap-1 and Ral-B. The cAMP-activated exchange factor Epac is encoded by the RAPGEF3 gene. The Rap-1 and Ral-B GTPases are involved in the regulation of cell adhesion and motility. The cAMP-dependent protein kinase is also regulated by the p300 protein kinase. The p300 protein kinase is activated by the phosphorylation of a threonine residue by the phosphoinositide-3-kinase-related kinases. The p300 protein kinase is encoded by the gene PRKCZ. The p300protein kinase is also called the casein kinase 2 (CK-2) family of protein kinases. The p30 protein kinase is involved in the regulation of cell cycle progression and apoptosis.

ADP-ribosylation factors (ARFs) are 2 0-kDa guanine nucleotide binding proteins that are members of the Ras GTPase superfamily. ARFs are essential for the activation of cholera toxin and are involved in the intracellular vesicle trafficking. There are at least four ARF genes in mammals, and they are grouped into three classes based on their sequence similarities. Class I ARFs (ARF1, ARF2, and ARF3) are 2 0-kDa proteins that are highly conserved in sequence and structure. Class II ARFs (ARF4 and ARF5) are 2 1-kDa proteins that are 8 5% identical in amino acid sequence. ARF4 and ARF5 are closely related and are not clearly distinguished in this study. ARF6 is a 2 6-kDa protein that is most similar in sequence to ARF3. ARFs cycle between active GTP-bound and inactive GDP-bound states. The inactive form is found in the cytosol and is associated with the Golgi complex. Activation of ARF requires a specific nucleotide exchange factor (GEF), which catalyzes the release of bound GDP and the binding of a new GTP molecule. The intrinsic GTPase activity of ARF is very low, but stimulated by GAPs, which stimulate the low intrinsic GTPase activity of ARF. GAPs are a diverse group of proteins that share a conserved ~ 13 0 amino acid domain, the GAP domain. GAPs stimulate the GTPase activity of ARF proteins by several orders of magnitude and are critical for the regulation of ARF activity. GAPs also stimulate the intrinsic nucleotide exchange activity of ARFs. The GAPs for ARFs include GcA1, GcA2, and Glo3 in yeast, and ASAP1, ASAP2, ASAP3, and GIT2 in mammals. GAPs also include GIT2-related proteins, which lack the ARF GAP domain, and ASAP-related proteins, which contain the ARF GAP domain. The GAPs for ARFs are classified into two groups based on their sequence similarities and functions. The first group includes GcA1, GcA2, and Glo3, which are essential for yeast cell growth. The second group includes ASAP1, ASAP2, and GIT2. ASAP proteins are expressed in a variety of tissues and are localized to focal adhesions, actin cytoskeleton, and endosomes. ASAP proteins bind to paxillin and Crk and are involved in cell migration and cytoskeletal reorganization.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that leads to dementia. AD is characterized by the presence of senile plaques (SPs) and neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs). SPs are composed of amyloid-beta (Abeta) peptides, which are derived from the sequential cleavage of amyloid precursor protein (APP) by beta- and gamma-secretases. NFTs are composed of hyperphosphorylated tau. The pathogenesis of AD is believed to be closely associated with the accumulation of Abeta peptides and tau pathology. Recent studies suggest that Abeta may exert its toxicity through a variety of mechanisms, including oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, and calcium homeostasis disruption.

Chemokine receptors are G-protein coupled receptors that bind chemokines and activate signaling pathways to direct cell migration. The chemokine receptors CXCR4 and CCR7 are expressed on lymphocytes and are activated by their ligands, SDF-1 and CCL2 1, to direct lymphocyte homing and trafficking. The chemokine receptors CXCR4 and CCR7 are also expressed on some cancer cells and are activated by their ligands to direct cancer cell migration and metastasis. The activation of the chemokine receptor CXCR4 by its ligand SDF-1 activates a signaling pathway that includes the Gi protein, the small G protein Rac, the serine-threonine kinase AKT, and the transcription factor NF-kB. The chemokine receptor CCR7 also activates Rac and AKT, but does not activate NF-kB. The chemokine receptor CCR7 also activates the MAPK pathway, including activation of the kinases MEKK1, MEK1, and ERK2. The chemokine receptor CCR7 also activates the phospholipase C pathway, leading to calcium flux and activation of protein kinase C. The chemokine receptor CCR7 also activates the focal adhesion kinase, FAK, and paxillin, and the actin cytoskeleton is reorganized to direct cell migration. The activation of CCR7 also activates the kinase Src, which may contribute to CCR7 signaling. The signaling pathways activated by CCR7 are similar to those activated by the chemokine receptor CXCR4, and may contribute to cancer metastasis.

The formation of neuromuscular junctions (NMJs) is a multistep process. Axons of motor neurons contact skeletal muscle cells and release agrin, a large proteoglycan, which binds to the dystroglycan complex on the muscle cell surface. Agrin induces clustering of acetylcholine receptors (AChRs), the key component of the postsynaptic apparatus at the NMJ. Agrin also induces clustering of utrophin, a dystrophin-related protein. Clustering of AChRs and utrophin is mediated by the intracellular protein rapsyn. Agrin-induced clustering of AChRs is also dependent on muscle-specific kinase (MuSK), a receptor tyrosine kinase that is activated by the neurotrophin erb-b2. Clustering of AChRs by agrin is followed by the formation of the secondary synaptic folds, which are thought to increase the surface area for the neuromuscular transmission. Agrin is also involved in the maintenance of NMJs. Disruption of the agrin gene in mice results in the absence of NMJs at birth and death within a few days after birth. Agrin is also involved in the formation of synapses between neurons and non-skeletal muscle cells.

The kallikrein-kinin system is a hormonal cascade that includes plasma kallikrein, tissue kallikrein, and bradykinin. Kinin peptides are released from kininogen precursors by plasma kallikrein or tissue kallikrein. Tissue kallikrein is released from kininogen by urokinase-type plasminogen activator (uPA) or tissue-type plasminogen activator (tPA). Bradykinin is a potent vasodilator and is involved in inflammatory responses. Kinin peptides also stimulate cardiac contractility and renal function. Kinin peptides are released during tissue injury and inflammation. Tissue kallikrein is overexpressed in prostate cancer and is a prognostic indicator of disease recurrence. The mitogenic activity of tissue kallikrein is mediated by the protease-activated EGF receptor (EGFR). Tissue kallikrein also activates PAR-2, a G-protein coupled receptor. PAR-2 activation stimulates proliferation of prostate cancer cells and PAR-2 activation also stimulates the release of the angiogenic factor VEGF. PAR-2 activation also stimulates the release of the neuropeptide substance P, which may contribute to the pain associated with prostate cancer. The mitogenic and angiogenic activities of tissue kallikrein are mediated by the activation of the MAP kinase pathway and the transcription factor ELK-1. Kinin peptides also activate PAR-2 to stimulate calcium release and activate protein kinase C. The mitogenic activity of tissue kallikrein is blocked by the protease inhibitors aprotinin and alpha-2-antiplasmin. The mitogenic activity of tissue kallikrein is also blocked by the protease inhibitor alpha-1-antichymotrypsin. The kallikrein-kinin system may play a role in the development of prostate cancer. The kallikrein-kinin system may also play a role in the development of pain associated with prostate cancer.

The T cell receptor (TCR) is a multi-subunit complex that is expressed on the surface of T cells and plays a critical role in the recognition of foreign antigens by the T cell. The TCR is a heterodimer consisting of an alpha and beta chain that noncovalently associate with the heterodimer to form the TCR complex. The zeta chain is a component of the TCR that is expressed in low copy number and is required for efficient surface expression of the TCR. The CD3 complex is associated with the zeta chain and is required for the efficient expression of the TCR. The CD3 complex is associated with several other proteins that play a role in the function of the TCR complex. The p21 protein is associated with the TCR and plays a role in the phosphorylation of the TCR and the activation of downstream signaling pathways. The zeta chain is associated with the SH2 domain of ZAP-7 0, a protein tyrosine kinase that is activated by phosphorylation by the TCR and that plays a critical role in the initiation of TCR signaling. The CD24 protein is associated with beta1 and beta2 chains of the TCR and plays a role in the regulation of the TCR. The CD3 complex is also associated with several other proteins that play a role in the function of the TCR. The LAT protein is phosphorylated following TCR ligation and plays a role in the activation of downstream signaling pathways. The SLP-7 6 protein is also phosphorylated following TCR ligation and plays a role in the activation of downstream signaling pathways. The CD4 and CD8 proteins are associated with the TCR complex and play a role in the regulation of the TCR.

Nucleotide excision repair (NER) is a mechanism for the recognition and removal of bulky, helix-distorting lesions, including those caused by UV light, bulky chemical adducts, and cross-links. NER is a multistep process that involves more than 3 0 polypeptides and three distinct pathways of repair: transcription-coupled repair (TCR), global genome repair (GGR), and an NER-independent pathway for the repair of ICLs. In GGR, the XPC-HR2 3B-UV-DDB complex detects DNA damage, recruiting the basal transcription factor IIH (TFIIH) and XPE to the site of damage. The XPB and XPD helicases in TFIIH unwind the damaged DNA, recruiting the XPG and ERCC1-XPF endonucleases. The resulting single-stranded region is repaired by DNA replication and ligation.

The T cell receptor (TCR) complex is a multi-subunit complex that is expressed on the surface of T cells and is responsible for the recognition of specific antigen bound to the MHC-II molecule on the surface of antigen-presenting cells. The TCR complex is composed of six different polypeptide chains, two each from the alpha and beta chains, and two each from the gamma and delta chains. The CD3 complex is associated with the TCR complex and is responsible for signal transduction following antigen recognition. The zeta chain is associated with the TCR complex and is responsible for the signal transduction function of the TCR complex. The zeta chain contains three immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motifs (ITAMs) that are phosphorylated by the protein tyrosine kinase Lck. The Lck-dependent phosphorylation of the ITAMs in the zeta chain leads to the recruitment of additional Lck and other signaling molecules to the TCR complex and the activation of downstream signaling pathways. The activation of Lck is positively regulated by the protein tyrosine phosphatase CD4 5 and negatively regulated by the Csk kinase. The Csk kinase phosphorylates Lck on a conserved tyrosine residue in the kinase domain (Y3 9 4 in human Lck) that is inhibitory to Lck activity. The Csk gene is localized to the same region of chromosome 1 as the gene for the Src family member Fyn, suggesting that Csk may regulate Fyn as well. The Csk kinase is regulated by the binding of Csk to the phosphoprotein adaptor 14@-@ 3-3 in a phosphorylation-dependent manner. The Csk-14@-@ 3-3 interaction is regulated by the kinase PKA, which phosphorylates Csk on a serine residue (S2 9 in human Csk). The Csk-14@-@ 3-3 interaction is also regulated by the tyrosine kinase Lck, which phosphorylates Csk on a tyrosine residue (Y5 0 5 in human Csk). The phosphorylation of Csk by Lck dissociates Csk from 14@-@ 3-3, activating Csk and dephosphorylating Lck. The Csk-dependent regulation of Lck activity may be involved in the regulation of T cell activation.

The FPR is a G-protein coupled receptor that is activated by peptides derived from bacterial proteins known as formylated peptides. The FPR is expressed by neutrophils and is involved in the inflammatory response to bacterial infection. The FPR is also expressed by microglia, the resident immune cells of the central nervous system. Activation of the FPR in microglia leads to the release of reactive oxygen species and the release of cytokines that may contribute to the progression of neurodegenerative diseases. The FPR is also expressed by some types of tumor cells and may contribute to their proliferation. The FPR is coupled to multiple G-proteins and signaling pathways. The FPR couples to Gi, Gq, and G1 2 / 1 3 to activate different signaling pathways. Gi activates the MAP kinase pathway and inhibits adenylyl cyclase. Gq activates phospholipase C and the release of calcium. G1 2 / 1 3 activates Rho and the MAP kinase pathway. The FPR also couples to Gs, activating adenylyl cyclase and increasing cAMP levels. The FPR is phosphorylated by GRKs and binds arrestins, targeting it for internalization. The FPR is also regulated by protein phosphatases. Protein phosphatase 2A dephosphorylates the FPR and desensitizes the receptor, while protein phosphatase 1Deg dephosphorylates FPR and resensitizes the receptor.

The MET receptor tyrosine kinase is a cell surface receptor for hepatocyte growth factor / scatter factor (HGF / SF). HGF / SF is a mitogen for epithelial cells and a motogen for epithelial cells and melanocytes. HGF / SF is also angiogenic and stimulates the growth of tumor cells of epithelial origin. The ligand for the MET receptor is HGF / SF, which is produced by mesenchymal cells. The MET receptor is widely expressed in epithelial tissues and is essential for normal development of muscle and neuronal tissues. The MET receptor is activated by HGF / SF, which induces receptor dimerization and autophosphorylation of tyrosine residues in the cytoplasmic domain. Downstream signaling by the MET receptor includes activation of the ras pathway, PI3 kinase, and PLC gamma pathways. The Cbl protein binds to the phosphorylated tyrosine residue 1 2 3 4 in the MET receptor and is involved in down-regulation of the MET receptor. The endophilin proteins are involved in membrane trafficking and may be involved in receptor internalization. The association of the MET receptor with the Grb-2 family of adaptor proteins may be involved in the down-regulation of the MET receptor and in the mitogenic signaling of the MET receptor. The association of the MET receptor with the protein kinase C alpha and beta isoforms may be involved in the mitogenic signaling of the MET receptor. The association of the MET receptor with the Cbl protein may be involved in down-regulation of the MET receptor.

The immune system is composed of two distinct arms: the innate immune system, which provides immediate protection against invading pathogens, and the adaptive immune system, which is comprised of B cells, T cells, and antigen-presenting cells (APCs) and is responsible for the long-term memory and memory responses. B cells produce antibodies that are responsible for the humoral immune response, while T cells provide cellular immunity by recognizing and destroying foreign cells. APCs, such as macrophages and dendritic cells, are responsible for the processing and presentation of antigens to B and T cells. The presentation of antigen in the context of MHC molecules by APCs is required for T cell activation. Macrophages phagocytose foreign pathogens and present antigens in the context of MHC class II molecules to B cells and T cells. Dendritic cells are potent APCs and are found in many tissues, including the skin, where they are responsible for the processing of antigens and the activation of T cells. The complement system is an important component of the innate immune system that is activated when complement proteins are cleaved by the C3 convertase. The cleavage products of complement proteins, including the anaphylatoxin C3a and the membrane attack complex C5b, are responsible for the inflammatory response to infection. The opsonization of pathogens by complement proteins and the lysis of pathogens by the membrane attack complex are important components of the innate immune response.

ADP-ribosylation factors (ARFs) are a family of small GTPases that are involved in vesicle trafficking between different cellular compartments. ARFs are activated by guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs) and are deactivated by GTPase activating proteins (GAPs). The ARFs are grouped into three classes based on sequence homology. Class I includes yeast Arf1 and human ARF1--3. class II includes yeast Arf4p and human ARF4--5 and class III includes yeast Arf6--7. The yeast Arf proteins are essential for cell viability and are involved in secretion and vesicular transport. The mammalian ARFs are less essential and have been implicated in a variety of cellular processes including secretion, endocytosis, intracellular membrane traffic, and intracellular lipid metabolism. The mammalian ARFs are also involved in vesicular transport, but their functions are not as well defined. The yeast ARFs are activated by a single Arf GEF, Sec7 1p, and the mammalian ARFs are activated by a family of GEFs known as cytohesins. The yeast Sec7 1p and the cytohesins are large multidomain proteins that share a common structural core of a Dbl homology (DH) domain and a pleckstrin homology (PH) domain. The DH domain is responsible for guanine nucleotide exchange and the PH domain is involved in the regulation of Arf GEF activity and membrane association. The Sec7 1p / cytohesin GEFs also contain a coiled-coil domain that mediates protein-protein interactions. The yeast Arf GAPs include Sys1p and Gcs1p. Sys1p is specific for Arf1 and is involved in vesicular transport between the Golgi and the endoplasmic reticulum. Gcs1p is specific for Arl1p and is involved in the transport of vesicles from the trans-Golgi network to the plasma membrane.

Fc gamma receptors (FcgammaR) are a family of cell-surface receptors that bind the Fc portion of IgG and are expressed on the surface of a variety of cells, including leukocytes, macrophages, mast cells, NK cells, and neutrophils. FcgammaR are involved in a variety of immune responses, including phagocytosis of antibody-coated particles, activation of inflammatory cells, and development of antibody responses. FcgammaR are comprised of an FcRgamma chain associated with a heavy chain of different molecular weights. The FcRgamma chain is required for FcgammaR expression and is necessary for the activation of most FcgammaR signaling pathways. The cytoplasmic domains of FcgammaR contain the tyrosine-based activation motifs (ITAM) that are required for downstream signaling. Upon receptor ligation, the FcRgamma chain is phosphorylated by src family kinases and serves as a scaffold for the recruitment of additional signaling molecules. The activation of src kinases leads to the phosphorylation of the ITAMs and the subsequent recruitment and activation of the tyrosine kinase Syk. The activation of Syk leads to the activation of multiple downstream pathways, including the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway, the phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway, and the p21GTPase pathway.

Retinoids are vitamin A derivatives that regulate cellular proliferation and differentiation in a variety of tissues. In the epidermis, the major retinoid-responsive tissue, retinoids are critical for the maintenance of the normal differentiation process and for the prevention of skin cancer. The biologically active form of vitamin A, all-trans retinoic acid (tRA), binds to two classes of nuclear receptors, the retinoic acid receptors (RARs) and retinoid X receptors (RXRs). The RXR / RAR heterodimer binds to DNA at a consensus DNA sequence called the retinoic acid response element (RARE). In the absence of ligand, the heterodimer complex binds to transcriptional corepressors such as N-Cor and SMRT, which actively repress transcription. Binding of tRA to the RXR / RAR heterodimer causes a conformational change in the receptors, which leads to the release of the corepressors and the binding of transcriptional coactivators such as pCIP, CBP and CBP-associated factors. Transcriptional coactivators are involved in the modification of chromatin structure and the recruitment of the basal transcription machinery. The net effect of retinoid signaling is the activation of genes containing an RARE and the repression of genes lacking an RARE. The activation of genes containing an RARE leads to growth arrest and differentiation, while genes lacking an RARE are involved in growth arrest alone. The balance between the actions of these two groups of genes is critical for the maintenance of normal homeostasis in the epidermis. The ability of retinoids to induce growth arrest and differentiation in keratinocytes is thought to be responsible for the ability of these compounds to prevent skin cancer. The importance of retinoids in the maintenance of normal epidermal homeostasis and the prevention of skin cancer has led to the development of synthetic retinoids as potential therapeutic agents for the treatment of hyperproliferative skin disorders and skin cancer.

The immune system is a complex network of cells and molecules that defend against foreign pathogens and eliminate infected cells. The immune system is composed of two major parts, the innate and the adaptive immune systems. The innate immune system consists of a variety of cells, including natural killer (NK) cells, macrophages, and neutrophils, that do not require previous exposure to antigen or the expression of specific antigen receptors and are able to respond immediately to infection. Innate immune cells recognize foreign pathogens through pattern recognition receptors, such as Toll-like receptors (TLRs), and produce inflammatory cytokines and chemokines. Macrophages phagocytose and degrade pathogens. The adaptive immune response requires the activation of a specific immune response against a particular antigen in the context of self-MHC molecules and is mediated by antigen-specific T cells and B cells. Naive T cells are activated by antigen-presenting cells (APCs), such as dendritic cells (DCs), that present antigen-derived peptides bound to MHC-I or MHC-II molecules on the cell surface. The interaction of T-cell receptor (TCR) with the MHC-peptide complex triggers T-cell activation. Naive B cells do not produce a functional antigen-specific TCR unless they are activated by APCs that present antigen-derived peptides bound to MHC-II molecules. The activation of B cells also requires the help of T cells.

The protease-activated receptor-2 (PAR-2) is activated by trypsin and the peptide SFLLRN. PAR-2 is coupled to multiple signaling pathways including the mobilization of intracellular calcium, activation of the G (q) family of G proteins, and the Rho-dependent activation of the serine / threonine kinase, Rho kinase. The activation of PAR-2 by trypsin or synthetic peptides also leads to the activation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway. The PAR-2-induced activation of MAPK is mediated by both the G (i) and G (q) families of G proteins. The PAR-2-induced activation of MAPK is inhibited by pretreatment of cells with pertussis toxin, indicating that the PAR-2-induced activation of MAPK is mediated by the G (i) family of G proteins. The PAR-2-induced activation of MAPK is also inhibited by the Rho kinase inhibitor, Y-2 7 6 3 2, indicating that the PAR-2-induced activation of MAPK is Rho-dependent. The PAR-2-induced activation of MAPK is also inhibited by the protein kinase C (PKC) inhibitor, GF1 0 9 2 0 3X, indicating that the PAR-2-induced activation of MAPK is also PKC-dependent. The PAR-2-induced activation of MAPK is also inhibited by the MEK inhibitor, PD9 8 0 5 9, indicating that the PAR-2-induced activation of MAPK is mediated by the upstream kinase, MEK. The activation of PAR-2 also leads to the activation of the transcription factor, NF-AT, through the Rho-dependent kinase, ROCK. The activation of NF-AT by PAR-2 is inhibited by the MEK inhibitor, PD9 8 0 5 9, indicating that the PAR-2-induced activation of NF-AT is also mediated by the upstream kinase, MEK.

Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are generated by a variety of mechanisms, including aerobic metabolism, exposure to environmental toxins, and inflammatory responses. ROS are highly reactive molecules that include the superoxide anion (O2 -), hydroxyl radicals (OH), and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). ROS can damage cellular components such as lipids, proteins, and DNA. Cells have evolved complex antioxidant systems to counter the effects of ROS. Glutathione (GSH) is a major cellular antioxidant that neutralizes ROS and protects cellular components from oxidative damage. Glutathione peroxidase (GPx) is a key enzyme in the glutathione antioxidant system that catalyzes the reduction of H2O2 and other peroxides using glutathione as a reducing agent. Glutathione reductase (GR) catalyzes the reduction of oxidized glutathione (GSSG) back to reduced glutathione (GSH) using NADPH as a cofactor. NADPH is an important reducing agent in the cell and is generated by the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP). NADPH is also used by glutathione reductase to regenerate glutathione. The transcription factor NF-kB is activated by oxidative stress and regulates the expression of genes involved in inflammation, apoptosis, and cellular proliferation. The activation of NF-kB by ROS is mediated by the IkappaB kinase (IKK) complex. ROS activate NF-kB by inducing the phosphorylation and subsequent degradation of the inhibitor protein IkB. The activation of NF-kB by ROS leads to the induction of genes involved in inflammation, apoptosis, and cellular proliferation.

The cAMP response element (CRE) is a DNA regulatory sequence that mediates transcriptional activation by a diverse group of transcription factors, including CREB, AP-1, and NF-kappaB. The CRE is a TGACGTCA sequence that binds a basic-region leucine zipper (bZIP) protein dimer. The bZIP proteins include CREB, c-Fos, c-Jun, and NF-kappaB. The bZIP domain mediates DNA binding and dimerization. The transcriptional activity of the bZIP proteins is regulated by a variety of mechanisms, including phosphorylation by several kinases, dimerization with bZIP proteins, and interaction with coactivators and corepressors. The coactivator CBP interacts with the bZIP domain and the amino-terminal region of CREB. The interaction with CBP is regulated by phosphorylation of CREB at Ser119 by the cAMP-dependent protein kinase A (PKA). The interaction of CBP with CREB is also regulated by the phosphorylation of the bZIP domain of CREB by the p300 protein kinase. The p300 protein kinase is activated by the MAP kinase pathway. The interaction of CBP with the bZIP domain of CREB is inhibited by the binding of the adenovirus E1a oncoprotein to the KID domain of CREB. The bZIP domain of CREB also interacts with the p160 protein, which is a coactivator of the vitamin D receptor. The interaction of p160 with CREB is inhibited by the binding of E1a. The interaction of p160 with CREB also stimulates the interaction of p160 with CBP. The interaction of CBP with the bZIP domain of CREB is also inhibited by the binding of the ETO protein to the bZIP domain of CREB. The ETO protein is fused to CBP by the (8; 2 1) translocation associated with acute myeloid leukemia.

The Fas / FasL system is a key regulator of apoptosis in the immune system and other tissues. The Fas receptor is activated by its ligand, FasL, expressed on the surface of other cells. Binding of FasL to Fas results in the formation of the death-inducing signaling complex (DISC), which includes the adaptor protein FADD and caspase-8. Caspase-8 activation leads to the proteolytic activation of caspase-3 and other caspases, and cleavage of cellular targets that results in the execution of apoptosis.

The mTOR pathway is a key regulator of cell growth and proliferation. It is activated by growth factors, nutrients, and cellular energy status. The mTOR pathway is negatively regulated by the TSC complex, which consists of hamartin (TSC1), tuberin (TSC2) and the TBC1D7 protein. The mTOR protein kinase is the catalytic component of two distinct protein complexes, mTOR complex 1 (mTORC1) and mTOR complex 2 (mTORC2). In the presence of nutrients and growth factors, mTORC1 is activated and phosphorylates downstream targets such as the ribosomal S6 kinase (S6K) and the eukaryotic initiation factor 4E binding protein (4EBP). 4EBP is a repressor of the initiation of translation, and phosphorylation of 4EBP by mTOR relieves this repression, leading to increased translation of mRNAs with a 5 'terminal oligopolypyrimidine tract. S6K is a kinase that phosphorylates the 4EBP repressor, releasing it from its inhibitory effect on translation. In addition to 4EBP and S6K, mTOR also phosphorylates other substrates that regulate translation and other cellular processes. Rapamycin and its analogs (CCI-7 7 9, RAD0 0 1, AP2 3 5 7 3) inhibit mTOR and are being tested as anti-cancer agents.

The immune system is a complex network of cells that defends against infectious agents and tumors. The immune system is composed of two major parts, the innate and the adaptive immune systems. The innate immune system is the first line of defense against invading pathogens and includes cells such as macrophages, natural killer (NK) cells, and dendritic cells (DCs). The adaptive immune system is a more specific system that requires time to develop and is comprised of B cells and T cells. B cells produce antibodies and T cells are responsible for cellular immunity. Naive T cells are activated by antigen-presenting cells (APCs), such as macrophages and DCs. The interaction between T cells and APCs leads to the activation of T cells and the proliferation of T cells. The activation of T cells requires two signals. The first signal is the interaction between the T cell receptor (TCR) and the antigen-MHC complex. The second signal is provided by the interaction of costimulatory molecules on APCs with their receptors on T cells. The interaction between B7 and CD2 8 provides the costimulatory signal for T cell activation. The interaction of CD4 0 and CD1 5 4 provides the second costimulatory signal for T cell activation. The activation of T cells leads to the production of cytokines and the proliferation of T cells. Activated T cells provide help to B cells and macrophages to produce antibodies. Naive B cells are activated by antigen and cytokines (IL-4 and IL-5) to become antibody-secreting plasma cells. The interaction between B cell receptor (BCR) and antigen-MHC complex leads to the proliferation and differentiation of B cells. The interaction between T cell-B cell receptor (TCR-BCR) provides the second signal for B cell activation. The differentiation of B cells into memory B cells and plasma cells requires the interaction of T cells with APCs.

Erythropoietin (Epo) is a cytokine that regulates the growth and differentiation of red blood cells. Epo binds to its receptor (EpoR) in the plasma membrane of erythroid cells and activates several signaling pathways. The JAK / Stat pathway is one pathway activated by EpoR that leads to the expression of genes involved in red blood cell differentiation. The MAPK pathway is also activated by Epo and leads to the expression of genes involved in red blood cell differentiation. The PI3 kinase pathway is also activated by Epo and leads to the activation of Akt and other kinases. The activation of these signaling pathways leads to the expression of genes involved in red blood cell differentiation.

The protease-activated receptors (PARs) are a family of G-protein coupled receptors that are activated by proteolytic cleavage of their amino-terminus by the coagulation proteases thrombin and trypsin. The tethered peptide ligand that is unmasked by proteolytic cleavage binds to the body of the receptor and acts as a ligand to activate the receptor. The PAR family currently consists of four members, PAR1, PAR2, PAR3 and PAR4. PARs are expressed by a variety of cell types and are involved in a number of physiological and pathological processes including platelet activation, inflammation, and possibly cancer. PARs are activated by the coagulation proteases thrombin and trypsin, but can also be activated by the coagulation protease factor VIIa in the presence of the cofactor tissue factor. Synthetic peptides that mimic the tethered ligand can also activate the PARs. The tethered ligand is a peptide that is not present in the intact receptor and is revealed by receptor cleavage. The synthetic PAR-activating peptides are useful tools for studying the signaling properties of PARs and are often used in place of the protease agonist. PAR1 is activated by thrombin and trypsin, PAR2 by trypsin, and PAR4 by trypsin and the PAR4-activating peptide SFLLRN. PAR2 can also be activated by factor VIIa in the presence of tissue factor. PAR3 does not appear to function as a PAR and does not appear to be activated by any of the known PAR-activating proteases. The PAR-activating peptides are useful for studying the signaling properties of PARs and are often used in place of the protease agonist. The cleavage of PARs by coagulation proteases leads to the activation of G-protein signaling pathways including Gq, Gi and G1 2 / 1 3. G-protein activation leads to the release of intracellular calcium and the activation of downstream signaling pathways including the MAP kinase pathways. The activation of PARs also leads to the activation of Rho and the formation of stress fibers and focal adhesions. PARs are involved in a number of physiological and pathological processes including platelet activation, inflammation, and possibly cancer. The PAR-activating peptides are useful for studying the signaling properties of PARs and are often used in place of the protease agonist. The PAR-activating peptides are useful for studying the signaling properties of PARs and are often used in place of the protease agonist. The PAR-activating peptides are useful for studying the signaling properties of PARs and are often used in place of the protease agonist. The PAR-activating peptides are useful for studying the signaling properties of PARs and are often used in place of the protease agonist. The PAR-activating peptides are useful for studying the signaling properties of PARs and are often used in place of the protease agonist. The PAR-activating peptides are useful for studying the signaling properties of PARs and are often used in place of the protease agonist. The PAR-activating peptides are useful for studying the signaling properties of PARs and are often used in place of the protease agonist. The PAR-activating peptides are useful for studying the signaling properties of PARs and are often used in place of the protease agonist. The PAR-activating peptides are useful for studying the signaling properties of PARs and are often used in place of the protease agonist. The PAR-activating peptides are useful for studying the signaling properties of PARs and are often used in place of the protease agonist.

ErbB receptors are activated by the binding of their ligands, the EGF-like growth factors. The four members of the ErbB receptor family, EGFR / HER1, HER2 / neu, HER3 and HER4, share a common structure with an extracellular ligand-binding domain, a single transmembrane domain and an intracellular tyrosine kinase domain. The binding of ligands to the extracellular domain leads to the formation of receptor homo- or heterodimers and the activation of the intrinsic kinase domain. The phosphorylated tyrosine residues provide binding sites for the recruitment of signaling molecules containing Src homology 2 (SH2) or phosphotyrosine binding (PTB) domains. The activation of ErbB receptors results in the stimulation of several signaling pathways, including the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) cascade, the phosphatidylinositol-3 kinase (PI3K) pathway and the protein kinase C (PKC) pathway. These pathways mediate a variety of cellular responses, such as proliferation, differentiation, migration and apoptosis.

Presenilin is the catalytic component of gamma-secretase, an intramembrane protease that cleaves transmembrane proteins. Gamma-secretase cleaves amyloid precursor protein (APP) to generate the amyloid beta-peptide (Abeta), a major component of senile plaques in Alzheimer's disease (AD). Presenilin is also involved in the processing of other transmembrane proteins, including Notch. Presenilin is required for gamma-secretase activity and its function is essential for development. Presenilin is a polytopic membrane protein with six transmembrane domains. The N-terminus of presenilin is oriented toward the cytoplasm, and the C-terminus is oriented toward the lumen of the ER or the secretory pathway. The N-terminal fragment of presenilin is generated by the action of signal peptidase and is further cleaved by an unknown protease to generate the N-terminal fragment of presenilin (NTF) and the C-terminal fragment of presenilin (CTF).
