The NTF and CTF form a stable complex, which is transported to the plasma membrane or the early secretory compartments. The CTF is subsequently cleaved within the membrane-spanning domain by an unknown protease to release the cytoplasmic domain of presenilin (PSH). The cytoplasmic domain of presenilin is involved in the gamma-secretase activity. The Notch signaling pathway is one of the best-characterized signaling systems in animals. Notch is a single-pass transmembrane receptor that is activated by binding to Delta or Jagged on the surface of a neighboring cell. The Delta / Jagged ligand is proteolytically removed in the signal-sending cell, and the Notch intracellular domain (NICD) is released and translocates to the nucleus. In the nucleus, the NICD interacts with CSL (CBF1 / Su (H) / Lag-1) family transcription factors and coactivators to activate transcription of target genes.

The development of cancer is a multi-step process that involves the accumulation of genetic alterations in genes that control cell proliferation, cell death, angiogenesis, differentiation, senescence, and migration. The majority of human cancers are believed to result from the constitutive activation of signaling pathways involved in cell proliferation and survival. The most commonly altered genes in human cancer encode proteins that regulate the mitogenic signaling pathways RAS / p53 and p60. These include receptor tyrosine kinases (EGFR, ERBB2, PDGFR), adaptor proteins (GRB2, IRS1), and the serine-threonine kinases (PI3K, AKT, p53).

The mitochondrial respiratory chain is the main source of cellular energy in aerobic organisms. It is composed of four multiprotein enzyme complexes embedded in the mitochondrial inner membrane. NADH dehydrogenase (complex I) is the entry point of electrons into the respiratory chain. It oxidizes NADH to transfer four protons across the mitochondrial inner membrane per NADH oxidized. The protons are pumped back into the intermembrane space by the respiratory chain complexes III and IV, creating an electrochemical gradient that is used by complex V to drive ATP synthesis. Complex I is a large protein complex with a total mass of about 1MDa. It is composed of at least 4 5 different subunits in mammals. The NADH dehydrogenase (complex I) is the most complicated of the four enzyme complexes of the respiratory chain. It is composed of a peripheral arm that receives electrons from NADH and transfers them to ubiquinone, and a membrane arm that pumps protons. The peripheral arm contains the NADH dehydrogenase activity and is made up of at least four different segments. The membrane arm contains the ubiquinone reductase activity and is made up of at least three different segments. The NADH dehydrogenase (or flavin-containing) segment transfers electrons from NADH to ubiquinone. The iron-sulfur cluster (Nf) is the third segment. The fourth segment is the ubiquinone reductase (or iron-sulfur protein). The structure of the NADH dehydrogenase has been determined at the atomic level. The membrane arm is much simpler. The proton channel is formed by a single protein, the subunit ND1. The ND1 subunit is encoded by the mitochondrial DNA. The assembly of the NADH dehydrogenase complex is a complicated process involving the coordinated expression of the mitochondrial and nuclear genomes. Defects in this system can lead to severe human disease.

The development of the heart is a complex process that requires precise spatial and temporal regulation of gene expression. The heart is derived from the embryonic mesoderm, and the formation of a heart tube from the cardiac crescent is a critical step in heart development. The cardiac tube is then remodeled into a four-chambered heart through the septation of the cardiac ventricles and the formation of the valves. The formation of the endocardial cushion is essential for proper heart development. Defects in this process can lead to congenital heart defects, which are the most common human birth defects. The formation of the endocardial cushion requires the coordinated proliferation and migration of endothelial cells, as well as the differentiation of these cells into smooth muscle cells. The proliferation and migration of the endocardial cells are regulated by a variety of growth factors, including FGFs, EGF, TGFs, BMPs, and PDGFs. The differentiation of the endocardial cells into smooth muscle cells is regulated by the transcription factors Nkx-2. 5, GATA4, and MEF2.

Chondroitin sulfate is a linear polysaccharide composed of repeating disaccharide units composed of N-acetylgalactosamine and glucuronic acid. Chondroitin sulfate is found in proteoglycans such as cartilage and in a variety of other tissues. Chondroitin sulfate chains are modified by sulfation at various positions, including the 4-position of the N-acetylgalactosamine and the 2-position of the glucuronic acid. The sulfation pattern of chondroitin sulfate chains is tissue-specific and changes during development. Chondroitin sulfate chains are also the linkage region of chondroitin sulfate in proteoglycans. The polymerization of chondroitin sulfate chains is catalyzed by a bifunctional enzyme, chondroitin polymerizing factor (ChPF), which also acts as a bifunctional enzyme in the polymerization of heparan sulfate. The polymerization of chondroitin sulfate chains is also regulated by chondroitin synthase-1 and chondroitin synthase-2. The transfer of N-acetylgalactosamine to the linkage region is catalyzed by chondroitin synthase-1. The transfer of glucuronic acid to the linkage region is catalyzed by chondroitin synthase-2. The transfer of both N-acetylgalactosamine and glucuronic acid to the linkage region is catalyzed by chondroitin polymerizing factor.

Apoptosis is a form of cell death that is distinct from necrosis in that it results in the rapid and selective degradation of cellular structures and the subsequent formation of apoptotic bodies that are phagocytosed by neighboring cells or inflammatory cells. The Bcl-2 family of proteins plays a key role in regulating apoptosis. Bcl-2 is an oncogene that inhibits apoptosis and blocks the action of several proteins in the Bcl-2 family that induce apoptosis. Bax is another Bcl-2 family member that induces apoptosis and antagonizes the anti-apoptotic activity of Bcl-2. Other Bcl-2 family members such as Bak and Bad induce apoptosis and oppose the action of Bcl-2. Bcl-2 and Bax localize to the mitochondrial membrane and oppose each other's activity by regulating the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria. Cytochrome c activates Apaf-1, a protease that activates caspases involved in apoptosis. Caspases are a family of cysteine proteases that are involved in apoptosis and are produced as inactive precursors that are activated by cleavage. Caspases are separated into two groups: the caspases that are involved in the execution of apoptosis (caspases-1, -2, -3, -4, and -5) and the inflammatory caspases (caspase-1, -4, and -5). Caspases are activated by two different mechanisms. The first mechanism involves the death receptors of the TNF family, such as Fas, that activate caspase-8. Caspase-8 activates caspase-3, -6, and -7, which are the effector caspases involved in apoptosis. Caspase-8 also cleaves Bid, a Bcl-2 family member, which translocates to the mitochondria and activates cytochrome c release. The second mechanism of caspase activation involves the mitochondria. Cytochrome c released from mitochondria activates caspase-9, which in turn activates caspase-3. Caspases are inhibited by inhibitor of apoptosis proteins (IAP), such as XIAP. The tumor suppressor protein p53 also plays a role in apoptosis, as well as in other cellular processes such as cell cycle regulation and DNA repair.

Hypoxia (low oxygen tension) is a common feature of many physiological and pathological processes. Cells respond to hypoxia by activating genes that allow them to survive and grow under low oxygen conditions. One of the genes activated by hypoxia is vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). VEGF is a secreted growth factor that induces angiogenesis in response to hypoxia and plays an important role in tumor growth and metastasis. VEGF expression is induced by hypoxia through the transcription factor HIF-1. HIF-1 is a heterodimer of HIF-1alpha and HIF-1beta (ARNT). HIF-1 is induced by hypoxia and activates transcription of many genes including VEGF. HIF-1 is a member of a basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) transcription factor family that also includes ARNT, USF1, USF2 and TFE3. HIF-1 is induced by hypoxia and activates transcription of many genes by binding to a core HRE (5 '-RCGTG-3') in their promoters. Genes activated by HIF-1 include those involved in erythropoiesis (e.g., EPO), in anaerobic metabolism (e.g., LDH-A), and in cell survival (e.g., Bcl2). Genes repressed by HIF-1 include those involved in angiogenesis (e.g., TSP2). HIF-1 is a key regulator of oxygen homeostasis and is induced by hypoxia to allow cells to survive and grow under low oxygen conditions. HIF-1 is a key target for developing cancer drugs that block tumor angiogenesis.

Inflammation is a complex series of responses by the body to harmful stimuli, such as bacteria, viruses, or irritants. Inflammation is initiated by the activation of macrophages and other cells in response to irritants. Activated macrophages produce cytokines such as IL-1 and TNF-alpha that activate endothelial cells and other cells. Activated endothelial cells express adhesion molecules that interact with leukocytes and platelets. The interaction of leukocytes with endothelial cells is mediated by adhesion molecules. The interaction of platelets with endothelial cells is mediated by selectins. The interaction of leukocytes and platelets is mediated by integrins. The interaction of leukocytes and endothelial cells is essential for the immune response and inflammation.

Receptor-stimulated phosphoinositide hydrolysis by phospholipase C generates two second messengers, inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). IP3 mobilizes intracellular calcium stores and DAG activates protein kinase C (PKC). The other product, cADPR, activates a calcium release channel, the ryanodine receptor (RyR), in a calcium-induced calcium release (CICR) mechanism. The activation of PKC by DAG leads to the down-regulation of the receptors through phosphorylation. The activation of the tyrosine kinase Src by the angiotensin II receptor leads to the tyrosine phosphorylation and activation of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), which is coupled to the phospholipase C-gamma (PLC-gamma) pathway. The activation of the tyrosine kinase Src by the angiotensin II receptor leads to the tyrosine phosphorylation and activation of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), which is coupled to the phospholipase C-delta (PLC-delta) pathway. The activation of the tyrosine kinase Ras by the angiotensin II receptor leads to the activation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway. The activation of the tyrosine kinase Src by the angiotensin II receptor leads to the tyrosine phosphorylation and activation of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), which is coupled to the phospholipase C-gamma (PLC-gamma) pathway.

The immune system is comprised of cells that respond to specific antigens. The immune system can be separated into two categories, the innate immune system and the acquired immune system. The innate immune system is comprised of macrophages, natural killer cells, and other cells that respond to non-specific antigens. The acquired immune system is comprised of B cells and T cells that respond to specific antigens. B cells produce antibodies that bind specific antigens. T cells respond to specific antigens by either the helper T cell pathway or the cytotoxic T cell pathway. The helper T cell pathway involves the activation of B cells and the production of specific antibodies. The cytotoxic T cell pathway involves the activation of cytotoxic T cells and the killing of specific cells. The helper T cell pathway is required for the activation of cytotoxic T cells. The activation of helper T cells also leads to the activation of B cells and the production of antibodies. The helper T cell pathway is stimulated by antigens that are presented by MHC-II molecules on antigen presenting cells. Cytotoxic T cells are stimulated by antigens that are presented by MHC-I molecules. The cytotoxic T cell pathway is stimulated by antigens that are presented by MHC-I molecules. The CD40-CD40L interaction is required for the activation of helper T cells. CD40 is a cell surface molecule that is expressed on activated B cells and macrophages. CD40L is a soluble protein that is secreted by activated T cells. CD40-CD40L interaction is required for the activation of B cells and the proliferation of T cells. Cytotoxic T cells are stimulated by antigens that are presented by MHC-I molecules. CD40-CD40L interaction is required for the activation of cytotoxic T cells.

The IGF-1R is a tyrosine kinase receptor that is activated by its ligand, IGF-1. IGF-1R activation stimulates proliferation and inhibits apoptosis. IGF-1R activation also stimulates protein synthesis and cell growth through the mTOR pathway. The mTOR pathway is involved in the mitogenic effects of IGF-1 and is activated by IGF-1 through the PI3 kinase pathway. The mTOR pathway stimulates protein synthesis through phosphorylation of the ribosomal protein S6 kinase and the initiation factor elF4E binding protein. The mTOR pathway also stimulates cell growth through inhibition of glycogen synthase kinase-3 (GSK-3) and inhibition of the forkhead transcription factor FKHRL1. The GSK-3 pathway inhibits cell cycle progression and is inhibited by IGF-1 through the PI3 kinase pathway. The mTOR pathway also stimulates proliferation and inhibits apoptosis through phosphorylation of the Bcl-2 family protein BAD.

Growth hormone (GH) is a peptide hormone that regulates growth and metabolism. The GH receptor (GHR) is a member of the cytokine receptor gene family. Binding of GH to the GHR activates several signaling pathways, including the JAK / STAT pathway, the MAPK pathway, and the PI3 kinase pathway. These pathways are involved in regulation of gene expression, proliferation, and apoptosis.

Natural killer (NK) cells are lymphocytes of the innate immune system that play an important role in the early defense against viral infections and in the regulation of hematopoiesis. NK cells do not express antigen-specific receptors but express activating receptors that recognize specific ligands on target cells and inhibitory receptors that recognize MHC molecules. Upon recognition of target cells, NK cells release perforin and granzyme to induce apoptosis and also secrete cytokines that can modulate the function of other immune cells. The activating receptors include NKG2D, NKp4 6, NKp4 4, 2B4, and LFA-1. The inhibitory receptors include MHC-I-specific receptors, such as KIR and NKG2A, and the Ig-like receptors, such as LMIR. The balance of signals from these receptors determines the activation state of the NK cell.

Sonic hedgehog (Shh) is a secreted morphogen that plays a critical role in development. In the developing nervous system, Shh acts as a mitogen for neuronal precursor cells in the developing cerebellum and spinal cord. In addition, Shh plays a role in the proliferation of granule cell precursors in the developing cerebellum. The mitogenic effect of Shh is mediated by the transcription factor Gli1, which activates the transcription of cell cycle genes such as cyclin D and c-myc. The activation of Gli1 by Shh is inhibited by the protein kinase Patched (Ptc), which is a receptor for Shh. Ptc is a tumor suppressor gene, and mutations in Ptc that lead to constitutive activation of Shh signaling have been identified in several types of cancer including basal cell carcinoma and medulloblastoma. The activation of Gli1 by Shh is inhibited by the protein kinase PKA, which is activated by cAMP. The inhibition of Gli1 by PKA requires the phosphorylation of Gli1 by PKA at several sites. The activation of Gli1 by Shh leads to the transcription of cyclin D and c-myc, which in turn activate the cell cycle and contribute to the mitogenic effect of Shh. The role of Shh signaling in the proliferation of neuronal precursor cells may provide insights into the development of brain tumors and the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases.

The actions of progesterone are mediated by two receptors, PR-A and PR-B. PR-A is a 9 4kDa protein that contains the DNA binding domain and the ligand binding domain of the PR-B receptor, but lacks the N-terminal AF1 domain. PR-B is 1 2 0kDa and contains an additional activation function domain, AF3, in its N-terminal region. PR-B is the only receptor that is able to activate gene transcription. PR-A functions as a dominant negative inhibitor of PR-B when the two receptors are coexpressed. The ratio of PR-B to PR-A can be altered by the presence of estrogen, which induces the expression of PR-B and decreases the expression of PR-A. In the absence of progesterone, PR-B is found in a multiprotein complex with heat shock proteins, immunophilins and other factors. Binding of progesterone to the PR causes a conformational change in the receptor, dissociation of the heat shock proteins, translocation of the receptor to the nucleus and dimerization of the receptor. PR dimers bind to specific progesterone response elements (PRE) in the promoter region of progesterone responsive genes. The interaction of PR with the PRE is stabilized by the interaction of the receptor with the general transcription factors, TATA-binding protein (TBP) and TFIIB. The interaction of the PR with TBP and TFIIB is mediated by the N-terminal domain of the PR. The interaction of the PR with other transcription factors such as c-jun, c-fos and CREB is mediated by the central and C-terminal domains of the PR. The interaction of the PR with the transcription coactivators CREB-binding protein (CBP) and p160 is mediated by the N-terminal domain of the PR. The interaction of the PR with the corepressors NCoR and SMRT is mediated by the central and C-terminal domains of the PR. The coactivators CBP and p160 increase the transcriptional activity of the PR by increasing the interaction of the receptor with the basal transcription factors and by histone acetylation. The corepressors NCoR and SMRT decrease the transcriptional activity of the PR by recruiting histone deacetylases to the promoter region of the progesterone responsive genes. The interaction of the PR with other signaling pathways is mediated by the interaction of the PR with other transcription factors. The interaction of the PR with the transcription factor CREB is mediated by the interaction of the N-terminal domain of the PR with the N-terminal domain of CREB. The interaction of the PR with the transcription factor c-jun is mediated by the interaction of the central and C-terminal domains of the PR with the leucine zipper region of c-jun. The interaction of the PR with the transcription factor Stat5 is mediated by the interaction of the N-terminal domain of the PR with the N-terminal domain of Stat5. The interaction of the PR with the transcription factor Sp1 is mediated by the interaction of the N-terminal domain of the PR with the DNA binding domain of Sp1. The interaction of the PR with the transcription factor p300 is mediated by the interaction of the central and C-terminal domains of the PR with the p300 transcription factor.

The colony stimulating factor-1 receptor (CSF-1R) is a member of the tyrosine kinase receptor gene family and is activated by its ligand, colony stimulating factor-1 (CSF-1). CSF-1 is a cytokine that stimulates the proliferation and differentiation of cells of the monocyte-macrophage lineage. The CSF-1R is also involved in the proliferation and survival of tumor cells in some leukemias. The CSF-1R is a heterodimer with a transmembrane subunit of 9 0kDa and a tyrosine kinase subunit of 1 80kDa. Binding of CSF-1 to the receptor induces receptor dimerization, activation of the tyrosine kinase domain, autophosphorylation of the receptor, and binding of signaling molecules to the phosphorylated tyrosine residues. The major signaling pathways activated by the CSF-1R include the ras-map kinase pathway, PI3 kinase, and the p38 map kinase pathway. Activation of these pathways leads to changes in gene expression that result in cellular proliferation and differentiation.

The cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA) is a key mediator of the actions of the second messenger cAMP. The PKA holoenzyme is a tetramer consisting of two regulatory (R) subunits and two catalytic (C) subunits. In the absence of cAMP, the C subunits are inhibited by the R subunits. Binding of cAMP to the R subunits causes the C subunits to dissociate and become active. The PKA regulatory subunits are encoded by four genes, prkar1a, prkar1b, prkar2a and prkar2b, which give rise to multiple isoforms through alternative splicing. The four PKA regulatory subunit genes are expressed in a tissue-specific manner, and the different isoforms have distinct expression patterns. The cAMP responsive element binding protein (CREB) is a key transcription factor that is regulated by PKA. Phosphorylation of CREB at serine 1 3 3 by PKA leads to transcriptional activation of CREB-responsive genes. PKA also regulates other transcription factors such as EGR-1, ELK-1, STAT-1 and STAT-3. PKA can also regulate gene expression through phosphorylation of other transcription factors such as c-jun and c-fos. The activity of PKA is also regulated by the A-kinase anchoring proteins (AKAPs). AKAPs are a family of structurally diverse proteins that coordinate the localization and the specificity of the cAMP-dependent signaling pathway. AKAPs bind to the regulatory subunits of PKA and localize the kinase in discrete subcellular locations. The subcellular localization of PKA is important for the specificity of PKA signaling. AKAPs also bind to other signaling molecules, such as the cAMP-dependent phosphodiesterase 4D3 (PDE4D3), the phosphatase calcineurin, and the lipid kinase phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K). The interaction of AKAPs with PDE4D3 and calcineurin regulates the hydrolysis of cAMP and the dephosphorylation of CREB. The interaction of AKAPs with PI3K is important for the regulation of the PI3K / AKT pathway by PKA.

The clathrin-mediated endocytosis of neurotransmitter-filled vesicles at the synapse is a key mechanism for the rapid release of neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft. The assembly of clathrin with adaptor proteins AP2 and clathrin to form a clathrin-coated pit is a key step in endocytosis. The GTPase dynamin is required for the fission of the vesicle from the clathrin-coated pit. The dephosphorylation of dynamin by calcineurin is required for the completion of endocytosis. Calcineurin is activated by calmodulin, which is released from the calcium sensor protein calpacitin by the calcium-binding protein calmodulin kinase II (CamKII). The dephosphorylation of dynamin by calcineurin is required for the completion of endocytosis. The dephosphorylation of dynamin by calcineurin is also required for the recycling of the vesicle membrane and the reformation of the clathrin-coated pit. The dephosphorylation of dynamin by calcineurin is also required for the recycling of the membrane in non-neuronal cells. The dephosphorylation of dynamin by calcineurin is also required for the formation of clathrin-independent carriers (CLICs). Calcineurin is activated by calmodulin, which is released from the calcium sensor calpacitin by the calcium-binding protein CaM kinase II. Calmodulin kinase II is activated by the calcium-binding protein calmodulin. The formation of CLICs is stimulated by the activation of the EGF receptor and the subsequent activation of phospholipase Cgamma. The activation of phospholipase Cgamma by EGF leads to the production of diacylglycerol and inositol triphosphate, which activates PKC and Calmodulin kinase II, respectively. The activation of PKC and Calmodulin kinase II leads to the activation of calcineurin. Calcineurin dephosphorylates dynamin, stimulating the formation of CLICs and the endocytosis of clathrin-coated pits.

The peptide hormone endothelin-1 (ET-1) is a potent vasoconstrictor that also stimulates cell proliferation and migration in a variety of cell types. ET-1 is secreted by vascular endothelial cells and acts on ET (A) and ET (B) receptors on adjacent cells. ET-1 is a key mediator of cardiac hypertrophy and remodeling in response to hypertension and heart failure. ET-1 also stimulates proliferation of prostate cancer cells and may play a role in the development of renal and other cancers. ET-1 is also a potent mitogen for cultured astrocytes and may play a role in the reactive gliosis that accompanies brain injury. ET-1 is secreted by many different cell types and is present in the circulation in a prohormone form (big ET-1) that is cleaved by the protease endothelin converting enzyme (ECE1) to produce ET-1. ECE1 is also known as ADAM-1 2. The ET-1 peptide is cleaved from big ET-1 by the protease ACE to produce the mature peptide. ET-1 is rapidly degraded by neutral endopeptidases and is not detected in the circulation. ET-1 is a 2 1-amino acid peptide that is secreted by many different cell types. Big ET-1 is cleaved by the protease furin to produce ET-1, which is then secreted. ET-1 is a 2 1-amino acid peptide that is secreted and cleaved by the protease ACE to produce the mature peptide. ET-1 is a potent vasoconstrictor that acts on ET (A) and ET (B) G-protein coupled receptors to stimulate increases in intracellular calcium and activation of phospholipase C. ET-1 also activates phospholipase D and stimulates the formation of inositol phosphates. ET-1 also activates a number of other signaling pathways including activation of protein kinase C, the MAP kinase pathway, and the JAK / STAT pathway. ET-1 stimulates the proliferation of many different cell types including vascular smooth muscle cells, prostate cancer cells, and astrocytes. ET-1 stimulates proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells and prostate cancer cells through activation of the MAP kinase pathway and the transcription factor AP-1. ET-1 also stimulates the proliferation of astrocytes through activation of the transcription factor NF-kB. The peptide stimulates the proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells and prostate cancer cells through activation of AP-1 and NF-kB. The ET-1 receptor is a GPCR and is coupled to Gq / 1 1, Gs, and Gi. ET-1 stimulates proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells through activation of AP-1 and NF-kB through activation of Gq and Gs. Activation of Gi is not required for proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells. ET-1 stimulates proliferation of prostate cancer cells through activation of Gq and Gi. Activation of Gs is not required for proliferation of prostate cancer cells. ET-1 also stimulates proliferation of astrocytes through activation of Gq and G1 2 / 1 3. The ET-1 receptor is a GPCR and is coupled to Gq / 1 1, Gs, and Gi. ET-1 stimulates proliferation of astrocytes through activation of Gq and G1 2 / 1 3.

The chemokine receptors are a family of GPCRs that are expressed on leukocytes and are activated by small chemoattractant peptides called chemokines. The chemokines are a family of cytokines that are involved in the regulation of leukocyte trafficking and activation. The chemokine receptors CCR1, CCR2, CCR3, CCR5, and CXCR4 are activated by the chemokines MCP-1, MCP-3, MIP-1alpha, MIP-1beta, and SDF-1, respectively. The chemokine receptors CCR1, CCR2, CCR3, and CCR5 are expressed on monocytes and macrophages, while CXCR4 is expressed on lymphocytes. The binding of chemokines to their receptors activates a variety of signaling pathways in leukocytes including the activation of G proteins, the MAP kinase pathway, and the JAK / STAT pathway. The activation of these signaling pathways leads to changes in gene expression and cellular responses.

Neutrophils respond to inflammatory stimuli by increasing their expression of the chemokine receptor FPR1. This response is mediated by the transcription factor NF-kB, which binds to a site in the FPR1 promoter. The FPR1 promoter also contains a binding site for NFAT, which is involved in the regulation of other immune cell functions. The binding of NF-kB and NFAT to the FPR1 promoter is activated by the calcium flux that occurs when neutrophils are stimulated by inflammatory stimuli. The calcium flux activates calcineurin, which dephosphorylates and activates NFAT, and also activates the kinase MEKK1, which activates NF-kB. The activation of NF-kB and NFAT by the calcium flux is required for the induction of FPR1 expression by inflammatory stimuli. The activation of NF-kB and NFAT by the calcium flux is similar to the activation of these transcription factors by T cell receptor stimulation in lymphocytes. The similarity of the mechanisms involved in the regulation of FPR1 expression in neutrophils and lymphocytes suggests that the regulation of FPR1 expression may be a more general feature of immune cell activation.

The release of Ca2 + from intracellular stores is a key mechanism in the control of many physiological processes. The release of Ca2 + is triggered by the binding of a variety of extracellular messengers to specific receptors coupled to second messenger pathways. The receptors coupled to inositol 1, 4,5-trisphosphate (InsP3) production are the InsP3 receptors (InsP3Rs), whereas the metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) are coupled to the production of InsP3 through the activation of phospholipase C (PLC). The ryanodine receptors (RyRs) are another intracellular Ca2 + release channel that is activated by the second messenger Ca2 + itself. The Ca2 + release through InsP3Rs and RyRs is a highly coordinated process that is regulated by various Ca2 + -sensing proteins. The Ca2 + sensor responsible for the activation of InsP3Rs is InsP3, whereas that for RyanRs is calsequestrin. The Ca2 + sensor responsible for the inhibition of InsP3Rs and RyanRs is calmodulin.

The translocation of proteins across the membrane of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and the mitochondrial inner membrane (IM) is mediated by signal recognition particles (SRPs) and the Sec-dependent protein translocation pathway. The targeting of proteins to the ER and the mitochondrial IM is accomplished by distinct signal recognition particles (SRPs). In bacteria, the SRP pathway is used to target membrane proteins that are synthesized in the cytosol. In contrast, in eukaryotes, the SRP is not involved in the targeting of cytosolic proteins to the ER membrane but rather recognizes the signal sequence of proteins that are translocated into the ER. The targeting of proteins to the mitochondrial IM is mediated by the twin-arginine translocase (Tat) pathway. This pathway is distinct from the general secretory (Sec) pathway in that it transports folded proteins and does not require ATP hydrolysis.

The chemokine receptor CXCR4 is expressed on the surface of hematopoietic cells and is involved in the homing of hematopoietic stem cells to the bone marrow. CXCR4 also plays a role in HIV infection, as the chemokine receptor CCR5 is used by macrophage-tropic strains of HIV to infect macrophages. The ligand for CXCR4 is stromal cell-derived factor-1 (SDF-1), also known as CXCL1 2. SDF-1 is a chemokine that is constitutively expressed in the bone marrow. Binding of SDF-1 to CXCR4 on the surface of hematopoietic cells activates a signaling pathway that includes the G-protein subunits Galphai, Galphaq, and phospholipase C-gamma 1. Downstream of this pathway are the kinases protein kinase C and map kinase, and the transcription factor NF-kB. The activation of this pathway by SDF-1 leads to chemotaxis of hematopoietic cells in vitro and may play a role in the homing of hematopoietic cells to the bone marrow.

The thyroid hormone receptor (TR) is a ligand-dependent transcription factor that mediates the biological effects of thyroid hormone. The TR exists in two major isoforms, TRalpha and TRbeta, which are encoded by separate genes. The TR binds to specific DNA sequences, TREs, in the promoter region of target genes and regulates their transcription in response to thyroid hormone. The transcriptional activity of the TR is regulated by a variety of corepressors in the absence of ligand and by corepressors in the presence of ligand. The corepressors include N-CoR and SMRT. The binding of ligand to the TR causes a conformational change in the receptor that results in the release of the corepressors and the association of a coactivator complex. The coactivators include SRC-1, pCIP, CBP, and pCAF. The binding of coactivators to the TR is dependent upon histone acetylase activity provided by CBP and pCAF. The binding of corepressors to the TR is dependent upon the action of a group of proteins including the mSin3 complex and the enzyme histone deacetylase. The corepressors and coactivators are recruited to the TR by a number of different proteins that interact with the TR in a ligand-dependent fashion. The corepressors dissociate from the TR in the presence of ligand and the coactivators are recruited. The binding of corepressors to the TR in the absence of ligand represses transcription, but the binding of coactivators to the TR in the presence of ligand activates transcription. The binding of corepressors to the TR in the absence of ligand represses transcription in a dominant negative fashion. The binding of corepressors to the TR in the absence of ligand represses transcription by two different mechanisms. One mechanism is that the binding of corepressors to the TR causes the formation of a transcriptionally inactive complex between the TR and the basal transcriptional machinery. The second mechanism is that the binding of corepressors to the TR causes the condensation of the chromatin structure in the promoter region of the target gene. The binding of coactivators to the TR in the presence of ligand causes an open chromatin structure and allows the binding of transcriptional activators and the basal transcriptional machinery to the promoter region of the target gene.

The cell cycle is a highly coordinated series of events that lead to the duplication and segregation of chromosomes and the formation of two daughter cells. The progression through the cell cycle is governed by the coordinated action of cyclins (G1-S-G2-M) and cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) (M-G1-S-G2-M.). CDKs are regulated positively by binding to cyclins and negatively by binding to CDK inhibitors (CDKIs). The activity of CDKs is also regulated positively by CDK-activating kinases (CAK) and negatively by CDK inhibitors (CDKIs). The checkpoint kinase ATM (ataxia telangiectasia-mutated) is a member of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase-like kinase family and is activated by DNA damage. ATM phosphorylates the tumor suppressor protein p5 3, which in turn binds to the promoters of the CDKI genes CDKN1A (also known as p15) and CDKN1B (also known as p16). This results in the transcriptional activation of these genes, thereby inhibiting CDK activity and halting the cell cycle. CDKs are negatively regulated by CDKIs. CDKN2A (also known as p16) encodes two different proteins, p14ARF and p16. p14ARF inhibits the activity of the E3 ubiquitin ligase MDM2, which targets CDKs for degradation. p16is a CDK inhibitor that directly binds to and inhibits CDK2 and CDK1. CDKN1B (also known as p15) encodes p15, which inhibits the activities of CDK2 and CDK1. CDKN1B is transcriptionally activated by p53. The CDK inhibitor WEE1 (also known as p13) inhibits CDK1 and CDK2.

Patched 1 (Ptc1) is a tumor suppressor gene that is mutated in the nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome (Gorlin syndrome). Ptc1 is a receptor for Sonic hedgehog (Shh), a secreted protein that is expressed in the developing CNS. Ptc1 is a receptor for Shh, and binding of Shh to Ptc1 relieves Ptc1-mediated inhibition of the 7transmembrane protein Smoothened (Smo). Smo activation leads to activation of the Gli family of transcription factors, which regulate the expression of genes involved in proliferation and differentiation. Ptc1 is also a transcriptional target of Gli, creating a feedback loop that regulates Shh signaling. The role of Shh signaling in development of the CNS has been well documented, and the role of Shh signaling in the development of basal cell carcinoma has been recently reviewed.

The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a member of a family of genes that encode receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs). These RTKs are involved in the regulation of cellular processes such as proliferation, differentiation, and migration. Overexpression or mutation of EGFR has been implicated in the development and progression of a variety of human cancers. Overexpression of EGFR has been observed in up to 8 0% of glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) tumors. This overexpression may be caused by gene amplification or increased protein stability. Amplification of the EGFR gene is also observed in a subset of non-small cell lung cancers (NSCLC), head and neck cancers, and breast cancers. Point mutations in the EGFR gene have been identified in NSCLC and these mutations lead to constitutive activation of the receptor. The most common mutation in NSCLC is a deletion in exon 2-7, which results in a truncated, ligand-independent receptor. The presence of this mutation in NSCLC patients correlates with a clinical response to the EGFR-specific tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib (Iressa).

The maturation of Xenopus oocytes into eggs is triggered by the steroid hormone progesterone. This process is accompanied by a dramatic increase in the synthesis of a specific group of mRNAs, the Mos-related mRNAs. The Mos protein kinase activates the MAP kinase pathway, which is essential for the resumption of the cell cycle. The polyadenylation of Mos-related mRNAs is stimulated by the CSF-Mos pathway and the poly (A) -binding protein.

Allergy is a condition in which the immune system reacts to normally harmless antigens, such as pollen, dust, and food, by producing antibodies and other inflammatory mediators. The condition can be triggered by environmental factors, such as dust mites, cockroaches, and molds, and by certain foods. The condition is characterized by an increase in the number and activation of mast cells and eosinophils. The condition can also be triggered by infection with certain viruses, such as the common cold virus. The condition is treated with anti-inflammatory drugs, such as steroids. The mast cells and eosinophils release a variety of inflammatory mediators, including histamine, leukotrienes, and cytokines. The activation of mast cells and eosinophils also causes damage to the airway epithelium. The airway epithelium secretes a variety of inflammatory mediators, including the cytokines IL-13 and IL-4. The cytokines stimulate mucus production and increase vascular permeability, allowing more inflammatory cells to enter the airway. The airway epithelium also secretes the anti-microbial protein eosinophil peroxidase, which kills bacteria. The activation of mast cells and eosinophils also causes damage to the airway epithelium. The activation of mast cells and eosinophils also causes damage to the airway epithelium. The airway epithelium secretes a variety of anti-microbial proteins, including the anti-viral protein interferon-gamma. The airway epithelium also secretes the anti-microbial protein eosinophil peroxidase, which kills bacteria.

Wnt proteins are secreted glycoproteins that act as extracellular signals in a variety of developmental processes. Wnt proteins bind to Frizzled (Fz) receptors and low-density lipoprotein-related protein 5 (LRP5) or LRP6 coreceptors to transduce signals. Wnt proteins bind to Frizzled receptors to activate two pathways, the canonical pathway and the planar cell polarity (PCP) pathway. In the canonical pathway, Wnt-Fz binding activates disheveled (Dsh), which inhibits the degradation of beta-catenin by glycogen synthase kinase-3 (GSK-3) and leads to beta-catenin accumulation in the cytoplasm. Beta-catenin then enters the nucleus and activates transcription by binding to TCF / LEF family transcription factors. In the PCP pathway, Wnt-Fz binding activates small GTPases RhoA and Rac, which activate the kinase JNK. JNK activation leads to phosphorylation of the myosin light chain and changes in cell shape and motility.

The heat shock protein Hsp40 is a molecular chaperone that is induced by a variety of stresses, including heat, heavy metals, and oxidative stress. Hsp40 also plays a role in the immune response, acting as a co-stimulator of the T cell receptor. In addition to its role as a molecular chaperone, Hsp40 interacts with a variety of signaling molecules, including the transcription factor p53 and the protein kinase ASK1. Hsp40 interacts with p53 through a conserved domain, the TPR domain, which is also found in a number of other proteins involved in the stress response and in cell cycle control. Hsp40 interacts with the p53 DNA binding domain and inhibits p53-mediated transcriptional activation. The interaction of Hsp40 with p53 is disrupted by phosphorylation of p53 on serine 2 0 by the stress-activated protein kinase, map kinase. ASK1 is a MAPKKK that activates p53 in response to oxidative stress. The interaction of Hsp40 with ASK1 is disrupted by Hsp40, preventing the activation of p53 by ASK1. The interaction of Hsp40 with ASK1 and p53 may play a role in the regulation of apoptosis in response to stress. The interaction of Hsp40 with p53 may also play a role in the regulation of the heat shock response. The interaction of Hsp40 with ASK1 may play a role in the regulation of apoptosis in response to stress, while the interaction of Hsp40 with p53 may play a role in the regulation of the heat shock response.

Spliceosomes are large ribonucleoprotein complexes that catalyze the excision of introns from precursor mRNA (pre-mRNA) and the ligation of exons. Spliceosomes are composed of five small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNPs), U1, U2, U4, U5 and U6, and many other proteins. Spliceosomes assemble on the 5 'splice site, the branch site, and the 3' splice site of the intron and catalyze two transesterification reactions.

The attachment of proteins to the cell surface via a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor is a widespread feature of eukaryotic evolution. In mammals, more than 1 5 0 different proteins are attached to the cell surface via a GPI anchor. The GPI biosynthetic pathway is conserved from yeast to man and is essential in eukaryotes. The GPI anchor is attached to proteins in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) by the sequential addition of monosaccharides to the C-terminus of the protein. The GPI precursor is synthesized in the ER membrane and then transported to the Golgi. In the Golgi, the GPI precursor is remodeled by the addition of phosphoethanolamine (EtNP) residues and by side-chain modifications before it is attached to proteins.

Insulin resistance is a key feature of type 2 diabetes. It is associated with impaired insulin signaling in liver, skeletal muscle and adipose tissue. The molecular basis of insulin resistance is complex and includes genetic and environmental factors. Genetic factors include mutations in the genes of the insulin receptor and the insulin receptor substrate-1. Environmental factors include increased levels of circulating free fatty acids, increased levels of circulating inflammatory cytokines (tumor necrosis factor-alpha, interleukin-6, and others), and increased levels of circulating glucocorticoids. These factors interfere with insulin signaling at several levels. They inhibit the expression of the insulin receptor and the insulin receptor substrate-1. They also activate stress-activated protein kinases, such as c-jun N-terminal kinase and inhibitor of nuclear factor-kappaB kinase. These kinases phosphorylate IRS-1 and IRS-2, thereby inhibiting the recruitment and activation of PI 3-kinase. They also activate the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR), which leads to serine phosphorylation of IRS-1 and IRS-2 and thereby to inhibition of insulin signaling.

Tight junctions (TJs) are essential for the formation and maintenance of cell polarity and tissue integrity. TJs are formed by a specialized belt-like structure, the tight junction (zonula occludens), which occludes the intercellular space between adjacent cells. TJs are composed of a complex of integral membrane proteins, occludins, claudins and junctional adhesion molecules (JAMs), and of cytoplasmic plaque proteins, including the MAGUKs (membrane-associated guanylate kinases), CRB3 (crumbs), PATJ (PAR-3) and PATJ-associated proteins. The cytoplasmic plaque proteins are involved in the regulation of the actin cytoskeleton and in the assembly of the TJs.

The olfactory receptor (OR) gene family is the largest known family of genes in the genome, with more than 1 0 0 0 members in the human genome. The function of the OR gene family is unknown, but it is hypothesized that they may be involved in olfaction. The OR family is divided into two broad classes, class I and class II, based on sequence similarity and tissue distribution. Class I genes are expressed in the olfactory epithelium and class II genes are expressed in the testes. The OR genes are organized in a cluster in the genome, with each gene containing a coding region, a putative promoter region, and a downstream region containing a putative terminator. The coding region is separated from the putative promoter region by a cluster of simple sequence repeats (SSRs). The SSRs are thought to be involved in the regulation of the expression of the OR genes. The putative promoter region contains a MORE (MOdified Repetitive Elements) box, a sequence that is found in many promoters and enhancers. The MORE box is thought to be involved in the tissue-specific expression of the OR genes. The putative terminator region contains a polyadenylation signal and a cluster of CA repeats. The presence of the polyadenylation signal suggests that the OR genes are not polycistronically transcribed. The SSRs are thought to be involved in the regulation of the expression of the OR genes. The OR proteins are predicted to have seven membrane-spanning helices and are thought to be G-protein coupled receptors. The regulation of the expression of the OR genes is not known, but it is thought that the SSRs are involved in this regulation. The OR proteins are proposed to be involved in the detection of odorants. The regulation of the expression of the OR genes is not known, but it is thought that the SSRs are involved in this regulation. The OR proteins are proposed to be involved in the detection of odorants. The regulation of the expression of the OR genes is not known, but it is thought that the SSRs are involved in this regulation. The OR proteins are proposed to be involved in the detection of odorants.

The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a receptor tyrosine kinase that is activated by binding of its ligand, epidermal growth factor (EGF). The EGFR is a member of the ErbB family of receptor tyrosine kinases, which also includes ErbB-2 (HER2 / neu), ErbB-3 (HER3), and ErbB-4 (HER4). Binding of EGF or other ligands to the extracellular domain of the EGFR results in receptor dimerization and activation of the intracellular tyrosine kinase domain. The phosphorylated tyrosine residues provide docking sites for a variety of signaling proteins, including the adaptor protein Shc, the docking protein Grb2, the protein tyrosine phosphatase Shp-2, and the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3-kinase) pathway. The downstream signaling pathways activated by the EGFR include the Ras-Raf-mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway, the PI3-kinase pathway, and the phospholipase C-gamma pathway. These pathways regulate a variety of cellular functions, including proliferation, differentiation, migration, and apoptosis.

Hypoxia is a common feature of growing tumors and is associated with resistance to radiation and chemotherapy. Hypoxia-inducible factor-1 (HIF-1) is a transcription factor that plays a key role in cellular and systemic responses to hypoxia. HIF-1 is a heterodimer consisting of HIF-1alpha and HIF-1beta subunits. HIF-1beta is constitutively expressed, whereas HIF-1alpha is induced by hypoxia. The induction of HIF-1 by hypoxia is mediated by the von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor suppressor protein. Inactivation of VHL in renal carcinoma cells leads to constitutive expression of HIF-1 and activation of HIF-1-responsive genes. HIF-1 induces expression of genes involved in erythropoiesis, glycolysis, vascular development, and cell survival. HIF-1 also induces expression of the gene encoding the angiogenic factor, VEGF. The induction of VEGF by HIF-1 is a key component of the angiogenic response to hypoxia. HIF-1 also induces expression of the glucose transporter gene, Glut-1. Glut-1 increases the uptake of glucose by cells and provides a mechanism for cells to survive under hypoxic conditions. HIF-1 also induces expression of genes that inhibit apoptosis, including Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL. HIF-1 is induced by hypoxia through a post-translational mechanism. The induction of HIF-1 by hypoxia is independent of new protein synthesis, but is blocked by agents that inhibit cellular respiration, such as cyanide and hypoxia mimetics such as CoCl. The induction of HIF-1 by hypoxia is also blocked by inhibitors of the mitochondrial electron transport chain, suggesting that mitochondrial function is required for HIF-1 induction by hypoxia. The induction of HIF-1 by hypoxia is blocked by antioxidants, suggesting that reactive oxygen species (ROS) are involved in the hypoxia-induced activation of HIF-1. The induction of HIF-1 by hypoxia is also blocked by inhibitors of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) and by inhibitors of the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway, suggesting that these signaling pathways are involved in the hypoxia-induced activation of HIF-1. The induction of HIF-1 by hypoxia is reversed by reoxygenation, suggesting that the cellular response to hypoxia is dynamic and that reoxygenation may lead to a decrease in HIF-1 activity. The reversal of the induction of HIF-1 by hypoxia by reoxygenation may be due to the rapid degradation of HIF-1alpha protein by reoxygenation. The induction of HIF-1 by hypoxia is also blocked by the heat shock protein 90 (Hsp9 0) inhibitor geldanamycin, suggesting that Hsp9 0 is involved in the regulation of HIF-1 by hypoxia. The molecular mechanisms that regulate HIF-1 activity are complex and involve multiple signaling pathways.

Mucins are heavily glycosylated proteins that are the major component of mucus. Mucin expression is often altered in cancer, and mucins can act as tumor suppressors in some cases. Mucin expression is also altered in inflammatory conditions, and mucins can act as anti-inflammatory agents. The MUC genes are clustered on chromosome 1q2 2-2 3, and are regulated by a large number of factors, including growth factors, cytokines, and hormones. Growth factors and cytokines can alter mucin expression both transcriptionally and post-transcriptionally. Inflammatory agents can alter mucin expression transcriptionally, and can alter mucin glycosylation. Inflammatory agents can also alter mucin glycosylation, and this can alter the interaction of mucins with other factors. Growth factors and cytokines can alter mucin expression both transcriptionally and post-transcriptionally. Cytokines can alter mucin expression both transcriptionally and post-transcriptionally. Growth factors can alter mucin expression both transcriptionally and post-transcriptionally. Inflammatory agents can alter mucin expression both transcriptionally and post-transcriptionally. Inflammatory agents can alter mucin glycosylation, and this can alter the interaction of mucins with other factors. Alterations in mucin expression can alter many different aspects of cell behavior, including cell adhesion, cell signaling, and apoptosis.

The multifunctional calcium / calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II (CaM kinase II) is a key enzyme in the regulation of neuronal activity. CaM kinase II is activated by calcium influx through voltage-dependent calcium channels and NMDA receptors. The activation of CaM kinase II is mediated by calmodulin, which binds to the regulatory domain of CaM kinase II and induces a conformational change that exposes the catalytic domain. Autophosphorylation of CaM kinase II at Thr2 8 6 and Thr3 0 5 increases the calcium / calmodulin-independent activity of CaM kinase II. CaM kinase II phosphorylates a variety of substrates including other CaM kinases, ion channels, neuromodulin, and synapsin I. The activation of CaM kinase II by glutamate and calcium may play a role in long-term potentiation and learning and memory.

The tachykinin NK1 receptor is activated by the neuropeptides substance P and neurokinin B. The NK1 receptor is coupled to G-proteins of the Gq family, which activate phospholipase C, generating IP3 and diacylglycerol. The IP3 released by the phospholipase C activates IP3 receptors in the endoplasmic reticulum, causing release of calcium from this store. The increase in intracellular calcium activates a number of calcium-dependent signalling pathways. The diacylglycerol released by the phospholipase C activates the protein kinase C family of proteins. The activation of protein kinase C can activate ion channels and stimulate the MAP kinase cascade. The NK1 receptor can also activate the MAP kinase cascade through a G-protein independent mechanism involving the tyrosine kinase Src. The NK1 receptor is widely expressed in the central and peripheral nervous systems and is involved in a variety of physiological processes including pain, emesis, and inflammation. The NK1 receptor is also expressed in a number of tumour cells where it may play a role in proliferation. The NK1 receptor is activated by substance P and the related peptide neurokinin B. The structure of the NK1 receptor has been determined by molecular biology techniques. The NK1 receptor is a rhodopsin-like GPCR with an extracellular N-terminus and an intracellular C-terminus. The NK1 receptor is coupled to Gq proteins, activating phospholipase C, and also to Gi / o proteins, inhibiting adenylyl cyclase. The NK1 receptor is also coupled to the activation of MAP kinase cascades, activating ras and raf, and also the MAP kinase kinase MEK. The NK1 receptor is subject to homologous and heterologous desensitization, a process involving phosphorylation of the receptor by a number of kinases including PKC, PKA and GRKs. Receptor phosphorylation uncouples the NK1 receptor from G-proteins, and also leads to receptor internalization. The internalization of the NK1 receptor may play a role in the desensitization of the receptor. The NK1 receptor is also subject to heterologous desensitization, being activated by a variety of other GPCRs. The NK1 receptor is also activated by the endogenous peptide agonist substance P (SP), but is also activated by the related peptide neurokinin B (NKB). SP is produced by the preprotachykinin A gene, and is cleaved to release SP as a biologically active peptide. The NKB gene encodes two peptides, neurokinin B and NKB-2 9. NKB is a product of the preprotachykinin B gene, and is cleaved to release NKB-2 9. SP and NKB are both potent neurotransmitters and neurotransmitters involved in a variety of physiological processes including pain, emesis, and inflammation. The NK1 receptor is also a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of pain, emesis, and inflammatory disorders. The NK1 receptor has been cloned from a number of species including human, rat, and guinea pig. The amino acid sequence of the NK1 receptor is highly conserved across these species, with the greatest sequence difference between the human and rat receptors being at position 2 0 0, where the rat receptor has a threonine and the human receptor a methionine. The NK1 receptor has been expressed in a number of different cell types and the response to SP and NKB has been found to be similar in all cases. The NK1 receptor is also activated by the endogenous peptides NKA and NKB, but with lower potency than SP and NKB. The peptides NKA and NKB are produced by the preprotachykinin C gene, and are cleaved to release NKA and NKB as well as NKB-2 9. NKA and NKB are also called neurokinins A and B, and are involved in a variety of physiological processes including pain, emesis, and inflammation. The NK1 receptor is also activated by a number of other peptides including septide, GR6arebacyte, and GR6arebacyte-2 9. The NK1 receptor is also activated by a number of other peptides including neuropeptide Y, bradykinin, and angiotensin II. The peptide ligands for the NK1 receptor are classified into two groups, the SP-like peptides and the NKB-like peptides. The SP-like peptides include substance P, neurokinin A, and neurokinin B. The NKB-like peptides include neurokinin B, neuropeptide gamma, and neuropeptide gamma-2 9. The NK1 receptor is also activated by a number of other peptides including neuropeptide Y, bradykinin, and angiotensin II. The peptide ligands for the NK2 and NK3 receptors are different from those of the NK1 receptor, and are classified as the tachykinins NK3, Neurokinin-4, and Neurokinin-4-related peptides.

The multifunctional calcium / calmodulin-dependent protein kinase (CaMK) II is a key enzyme in the regulation of cellular calcium homeostasis and is involved in a variety of cellular processes including gene expression, muscle contraction, and neuronal plasticity. The CaMK cascade is initiated by the activation of membrane receptors coupled to phospholipase C, which cleaves phosphatidylinositol 4, 5-bisphosphate to generate the second messengers diacylglycerol and inositol 1, 4, 5-trisphosphate (IP3). IP3 mobilizes intracellular calcium stores and diacylglycerol activates protein kinase C (PKC). The multifunctional CaMK-II is a decameric protein kinase that is activated by calcium and calmodulin. CaMK-II is a key enzyme in the regulation of cellular calcium homeostasis and is involved in a variety of cellular processes including gene expression, muscle contraction, and neuronal plasticity. The CaMK cascade is initiated by the activation of membrane receptors coupled to phospholipase C, which cleaves phosphatidylinositol 4, 5-bisphosphate to generate the second messengers diacylglycerol and IP3. IP3 releases calcium from intracellular stores and activates the multifunctional CaMK-II. The multifunctional CaMK-II is a key enzyme in the regulation of cellular calcium homeostasis and is involved in a variety of cellular processes including gene expression, muscle contraction, and neuronal plasticity. IP3 mobilizes intracellular calcium stores and activates the multifunctional CaMK-II. The multifunctional CaMK-II is a key enzyme in the regulation of cellular calcium homeostasis and is involved in a variety of cellular processes. IP3 releases calcium from intracellular stores and activates the multifunctional CaMK-II. The multifunctional CaMK-II is a key enzyme in the regulation of cellular calcium homeostasis and is involved in a variety of cellular processes. IP3 mobilizes intracellular calcium and activates the multifunctional CaMK-II. The multifunctional CaMK-II is a key enzyme in the regulation of cellular calcium homeostasis and is involved in a variety of cellular processes.

The Na + / K-ATPase is an ion transporter that uses the energy of ATP hydrolysis to drive the transport of Na + and K + across cell membranes. It is an alpha beta heterodimer with each subunit having a different role. The alpha subunit is the ion-transporting subunit and is a member of the P-type ATPase gene family. The beta subunit is required for the proper expression and function of the alpha subunit. The gamma subunit is expressed in the kidney and may be involved in the regulation of the enzyme in this tissue. The beta subunit is required for the apical localization of the enzyme in the renal collecting duct. The FXYD protein family is a group of small single-span membrane proteins that modulate the activity of the Na + / K-ATPase. The gamma subunit is expressed in the kidney and may be involved in the regulation of the enzyme in this tissue. The FXYD proteins are related to the gamma subunit in that they have a conserved tyrosine residue in the center of a transmembrane segment. The other members of the family have a conserved aspartate residue in this position. The aspartate-containing members of the family (FXYD2, 3, 4, 5, 6) are Na + -K + -ATPase inhibitors, whereas the tyrosine-containing members (FXYD1, 3, 7, 8) are activators. The aspartate-containing FXYDs are expressed in tissues where the Na + / K-ATPase is not expressed, suggesting that they have other functions. The gamma subunit is expressed in the kidney and may be involved in the regulation of the enzyme in this tissue. The beta-adrenergic receptor kinase 1 (betaARK1) is involved in the regulation of the Na + / K-ATPase by G-protein coupled receptors. The Na + / K-ATPase is inhibited by phosphorylation of the alpha subunit by protein kinase A (PKA). The inhibition is reversed by protein phosphatase 1 (PP1) or PP2A-dependent dephosphorylation. The PKA phosphorylation site is located in the cytoplasmic domain of the alpha subunit. The betaARK1 is a G-protein coupled receptor kinase that phosphorylates the beta-adrenergic receptor in response to agonist binding. The phosphorylated receptor is a better substrate for PKA than the Na + / K-ATPase. The betaARK1 is also a substrate for PKA. The betaARK1 is inhibited by PKA-dependent phosphorylation. The inhibition of betaARK1 by PKA may serve to keep the Na + / K-ATPase active during conditions that stimulate the G-protein coupled receptor signaling pathway.

The innate immune response is triggered by the recognition of conserved microbial structures by host pattern recognition receptors (PRRs). The two major classes of PRRs are the Toll-like receptors (TLRs) and the RIG-I-like receptors (RLRs). TLRs are expressed on the cell surface or in endosomal compartments and recognize microbial membrane components, such as lipopolysaccharides (LPS), lipoproteins, peptidoglycans, and flagellin. RLRs are expressed in the cytosol and recognize viral RNA. Upon recognition of viral RNA, RLRs trigger signaling cascades that lead to the production of type I interferon and proinflammatory cytokines. The RLR family includes RIG-I, MDA5, and LGP2. RIG-I and MDA5 contain two N-terminal caspase recruitment domains (CARDs), a DExD / H box helicase domain, and a C-terminal regulatory domain (CTD). LGP2 lacks a CARD but contains a helicase domain and a CTD. Upon recognition of viral RNA, RIG-I and MDA5 interact with the mitochondrial antiviral-signaling protein (MAVS), also known as IPS-1, Cardif, or VISA. MAVS then activates the transcription factors IRF-3 and NF-kB, which induce the expression of type I interferon and other inflammatory cytokines.

Cholesterol is a precursor of steroid hormones, bile acids, vitamin D and vitamin E. The biosynthesis of cholesterol starts with acetyl-CoA, which is converted to 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA (HMG-CoA) by 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA synthase (HMGS). HMG-CoA is converted to mevalonate by the subsequent enzymes of the mevalonate pathway. The first committed step in the biosynthesis of isopentenyl diphosphate (IPP) and its isomer dimethylallyl diphosphate (DMAPP), the universal precursors of isoprenoids, is the conversion of acetyl-CoA to acetoacetyl-CoA by the enzyme acetyl-CoA carboxylase (ACAT). Acetyl-CoA is also the source of the activated two-carbon unit, which is transferred to the 4-carbon IPP by the enzyme of the mevalonate pathway. IPP and DMAPP are then condensed to form the five-carbon prenyl diphosphate compound geranyl diphosphate (GPP). The next step in the pathway is the formation of the 1 0-carbon IPP unit, isopentenyl pyrophosphate (IPP), from DMAPP by IPP isomerase. The next step in the pathway is the condensation of IPP with another DMAPP to form the 1 5-carbon farnesyl diphosphate (FPP). The next steps in the biosynthesis of sterols and nonsterol isoprenoids are catalyzed by a family of enzymes known as terpene synthases. The cyclization of FPP to squalene is the first committed step in the biosynthesis of sterols. Squalene is cyclized to form the pentacyclic triterpenoid squalene oxide by squalene cyclase. Squalene oxide is cyclized to form the tetracyclic compound cycloartenol by the enzyme oxidosqualene cyclase. The oxidosqualene cyclase also catalyzes the cyclization of oxidosqualene to form the pentacyclic triterpenoid hopene. The oxidosqualene cyclase also catalyzes the conversion of squalene to 2, 3-oxidosqualene, the precursor of the triterpenoid precursor of carotenoids. The conversion of 2, 3-oxidosqualene to the tetracyclic compound lupeol is the first committed step in the biosynthesis of the pentacyclic triterpenoid oleanolic acid. The cyclization of lupeol to betulinic acid is catalyzed by oxidosqualene cyclase. The oxidosqualene cyclase also catalyzes the formation of the hopane family of triterpenoids. The cyclization of 2, 3-oxidosqualene to cycloartenol is the first committed step in the biosynthesis of the benzoquinone ansamycin antibiotics. The cyclization of 2, 3-oxidosqualene to the tetracyclic compound uvaol is the first committed step in the biosynthesis of the macrolide antibiotic erythromycin. The tetracyclic compound abafungin is the precursor of the antifungal agent acarbose.

Sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) is a sphingolipid metabolite with diverse and sometimes opposing biological actions. S1P is produced by the sphingosine kinase-catalyzed phosphorylation of sphingosine, and is degraded by S1P phosphatases and lyase. S1P is a ligand for a family of G-protein coupled receptors, termed S1P1-5. S1P is a potent mitogen for a variety of cell types, and S1P signaling through its receptors regulates cell migration, proliferation, and survival. S1P signaling is involved in angiogenesis and vascular maturation, and may also play a role in inflammatory responses and asthma. S1P signaling is also involved in lymphocyte trafficking, and may play a role in lymphocyte homing and cancer. S1P signaling may also play a role in heart disease through its effects on heart cells. The S1P2 receptor is coupled to Gi, Gq, and G1 2 / 1 3, and couples to inhibition of adenylate cyclase and stimulation of phospholipase C, Rho activation, and stimulation of the serum response factor. Gi-mediated inhibition of adenylate cyclase may also be involved. Rho activation and serum response factor activation may lead to changes in cytoskeletal structure and cell motility. Gi-mediated stimulation of phospholipase C may lead to calcium release and changes in heart rate and rhythm. Rho activation may lead to changes in cell shape and motility. S1P2 couples to G1 2 / 1 3 and stimulates the Rho-dependent kinase, p1 6 0ROCK. This pathway may lead to changes in cell shape and motility. Rho activation may also lead to changes in cell motility through changes in actin stress fiber formation. The S1P3 receptor couples to Gi, but also couples to Gq and G1 2 / 1 3. Rho activation by S1P3 may lead to changes in cell shape and motility through changes in the actin cytoskeleton. The S1P4 receptor couples to Gi, but also couples to G1 2 / 1 3. The S1P5 receptor couples to Gi and G1 2 / 1 3. The S1P6 receptor couples to Gi and Gq.

The coagulation cascade is a series of reactions that lead to the formation of a clot at the site of vascular injury. The first step is the activation of prothrombin by the tissue factor (TF) / factor VII complex. This reaction is called the initiation step. The next steps are the activation of factors V and X by the TF / factor VIIa complex, the formation of the prothrombinase complex, the cleavage of prothrombin by the prothrombinase complex, and the activation of factors XI and XII. The final step is the clot formation by thrombin, which converts soluble fibrinogen into a clot that is stable in the blood. The coagulation cascade is negatively regulated by several factors. Tissue factor (TF) is the main trigger of the coagulation cascade. It is expressed by cells in the vascular wall and by cells in the extravascular space. TF is released from the cell membrane into the blood in response to tissue damage or inflammation. The TF / factor VIIa complex activates factors X and V, initiating the coagulation cascade. The TF / factor VIIa complex is short-lived and is inhibited by tissue factor pathway inhibitor (TFPI). The TF / factor VIIa complex is also inhibited by antithrombin (AT) and by the zymogen protein C (PC). Protein C is activated by the thrombin-activated factor V (Va). The activated protein C (APC) in the presence of protein S (PS) inhibits factors Va and VIIIa, thus inhibiting the further activation of factors X and IX. The inhibition of factors Va and VIIIa by APC also leads to the degradation of the fibrinogen by thrombin. Antithrombin is a plasma protein that inhibits thrombin. Antithrombin deficiency is associated with a severe bleeding disorder.

Prion diseases are a group of fatal neurodegenerative disorders that affect humans and other mammals. The etiology of these diseases is linked to the conversion of the cellular prion protein (PrP C) into a protease-resistant, beta-sheet-rich isoform (PrP Sc). PrP Sc is the major component of the infectious agent responsible for prion diseases, or prions. The conversion of PrP C into PrP Sc is believed to occur post-translationally, and is thought to occur by a seeded polymerization mechanism. The conversion of PrP C into PrP Sc is accompanied by a conformational change that results in the acquisition of partial resistance to proteolysis and a strong tendency to aggregate. The accumulation of PrP Sc in the brain may lead to neuronal death through a gain-of-function mechanism, or through a loss-of-function mechanism. The conversion of PrP C into PrP Sc may also trigger a cascade of events that lead to neuronal death. The conversion of PrP C into PrP Sc may also affect the function of the normal cellular prion protein. The normal cellular prion protein is involved in copper metabolism, synaptic plasticity, signal transduction, and cell survival. The conversion of PrP C into PrP Sc may affect the function of the cellular prion protein. The conversion of PrP C into PrP Sc may also affect the function of the normal cellular prion protein. The conversion of PrP C into PrP Sc may also affect the function of the normal cellular prion protein.

The Fas-mediated apoptotic pathway is activated by the binding of Fas ligand to Fas. This interaction leads to the recruitment of Fas-associated death domain (FADD) to the cytoplasmic domain of Fas. FADD in turn recruits pro-caspase 8 through a homophilic interaction between the death domains of each protein. Pro-caspase 8 is then cleaved and activated, and in turn activates other caspases that lead to apoptosis.

Calmodulin (CaM) is a small acidic protein that binds calcium with high affinity. It is involved in many cellular processes, including calcium signaling, muscle contraction, and gene expression. The binding of calcium to CaM causes a conformational change that exposes a binding site for other proteins. One of the CaM-binding proteins is calcineurin, a protein phosphatase that is involved in calcium-mediated signal transduction. Calcineurin is activated by CaM binding, and CaM binding is inhibited by the immunosuppressive drugs cyclosporin A and FK5 0 6. The binding of CaM to calcineurin causes a conformational change that exposes a catalytic site that dephosphorylates p38IkappaBalpha, releasing the transcription factor NF-AT to move into the nucleus and activate transcription. The binding of CaM to calcineurin is inhibited by the immunosuppressive drugs cyclosporin A and FK5 0 6, which bind to immunophilins that also bind CaM. Another CaM-binding protein is CaM-dependent protein kinase II (CaM kinase II). CaM kinase II is a protein kinase that is activated by calcium and CaM. CaM kinase II is involved in many cellular processes, including neurotransmitter release and long-term potentiation. The binding of CaM to CaM kinase II causes a conformational change that exposes a catalytic site that phosphorylates other proteins. The binding of CaM to CaM kinase II is inhibited by the CaM kinase inhibitor peptide, KKALRRQEQIVA. The binding of CaM to calcineurin is inhibited by the autoinhibitory domain, a region near the amino terminus of the enzyme that inhibits the activity of the enzyme until CaM binds. The binding of CaM to CaM kinase II is inhibited by the protein kinase inhibitor peptide, which is a peptide derived from the CaM kinase II autoinhibitory domain.

T cells are lymphocytes that recognize specific antigens in the form of peptides bound to MHC-1 molecules on the surface of other cells. T cells can be subdivided into two major classes, T helper cells and T cytotoxic cells. T helper cells are involved in the cellular immune response and produce cytokines that stimulate the proliferation and activation of other immune cells. T cytotoxic cells are involved in the humoral immune response and kill cells that display specific antigens on their surface. The T cell receptor (TCR) complex on the surface of T cells recognizes the peptide-MHC-1 complex on the surface of other cells and this interaction is required for T cell activation. T cell activation also requires the presence of costimulatory signals provided by cells that interact with the T cell receptor complex. The interaction of the T cell receptor with the peptide-MHC-1 complex causes the T cell to be activated and to proliferate. T cell activation also requires the interaction of the costimulatory receptor CD2 8 with its ligand B7 on the surface of other cells. T cell activation is a complex process that requires the integration of signals from the TCR, costimulatory receptors, and cytokines.

The cholinergic anti-inflammatory pathway (CAP) is an endogenous mechanism that helps to keep the body from overreacting to injury or infection. The CAP is activated by the neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh) released from the vagus nerve. The CAP inhibits the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines by macrophages and other cells in response to infection or injury. The anti-inflammatory signal is transmitted by the alpha7 nicotinic ACh receptor (alpha7nAChR), which is expressed on macrophages and other cells. The alpha7nAChR is coupled to the inhibitory G protein Gi, which inhibits the activity of the downstream kinase AKT. The inhibition of AKT leads to the activation of the transcription factor FOXO3a, which in turn induces the expression of the death receptor Fas ligand (FasL) on macrophages. FasL binds to the Fas receptor on other cells, activating the apoptotic pathway. The CAP may help to keep the body from overreacting to infection or injury.

Skeletal muscle contraction is triggered by the release of Ca2 + from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) into the cytosol of the muscle fiber. The release of Ca2 + is triggered by the binding of Ca2 + to the ryanodine receptor (RYR), a large transmembrane protein of the SR. The binding of Ca2 + to RYR causes the channel to open and release Ca2 + into the cytosol. The amount of Ca2 + released by RYR is determined by the amount of Ca2 + in the SR. The amount of Ca2 + in the SR is determined by the balance of Ca2 + uptake into the SR by the sarco (endo) plasmic reticulum Ca2 + -ATPase (SERCA) and Ca2 + efflux from the SR by the RYR. The release of Ca2 + from the SR is stimulated by the binding of calmodulin (CaM) to the RYR. The binding of CaM to RYR is stimulated by the binding of Ca2 + to CaM. The binding of Ca2 + to CaM also activates the Ca2 + release channel. The binding of Ca2 + to CaM also inhibits the reuptake of Ca2 + into the SR by the SERCA pump. The binding of Ca2 + to CaM also activates the protein kinase A (PKA) and protein kinase C (PKC) pathways. The binding of acetylcholine (ACh) to the nicotinic ACh receptor (nAChR) on the surface of skeletal muscle causes the opening of a cation channel in the receptor. The influx of cations through the nAChR depolarizes the cell membrane and activates voltage-gated L-type Ca2 + channels in the plasma membrane. The influx of Ca2 + through the L-type channels in turn activates the release of Ca2 + from the SR. The influx of Ca2 + through the nAChR also activates the protein kinase C (PKC) pathway. The activation of the PKC pathway may also contribute to the release of Ca2 + from the SR.

The paired box transcription factors are a family of developmental control genes that play a key role in the development of the midbrain and limb buds in vertebrates. The Pax gene family contains nine members in mammals, Pax-1 through Pax-9. Pax-3, a member of the Pax gene family, is expressed in the developing central nervous system and is essential for normal brain and midbrain development. Pax-3 is also expressed in the developing limb buds and is required for normal development of the forelimb and hindlimb. The paired domain is a DNA binding domain found in many transcription factors and is found in paired-box containing genes. The paired domain of Pax-3 binds to a consensus sequence of TCAG (N) 6GAG. The paired domain of Pax-3 also binds to the sequence GTACGGAT, which is similar to the consensus sequence, but with a T in place of the G or A in the middle position. The paired domain of Pax-3 binds to this site with a higher affinity than to the consensus sequence. The paired domain of Pax-3 also binds to the sequence GTACGGAT with a higher affinity than the consensus sequence. The binding of the paired domain of Pax-3 to the GTACGGAT sequence is inhibited by the presence of a G in the middle position. The presence of a G in the middle position of the consensus sequence does not inhibit binding of the paired domain of Pax-3 to the consensus sequence. The presence of a G in the middle position of the consensus sequence does not inhibit binding of the paired domain of Pax-3 to the consensus sequence. The presence of a G in the middle position of the consensus sequence does not inhibit binding of the paired domain of Pax-3 to the consensus sequence.

Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is an inherited heart muscle disease that may lead to sudden cardiac death. The hallmark of ARVC is the replacement of cardiac myocytes with adipose and fibrous tissue. The pathological hallmark of ARVC is the presence of intramyocardial fat and / or extensive myocyte loss. The prevalence of ARVC is estimated to be 1 in 1 0, 0 0 0. The disease is caused by mutations in genes that encode proteins that are involved in the structure and function of the cardiac desmosome. The desmosome is a protein complex that holds together adjacent cells in the heart and plays a crucial role in maintaining the structural integrity of the heart. Disruption of desmosome function may lead to myocyte death and fibrofatty replacement of cardiac tissue. The purpose of this review is to provide an overview of the molecular basis of ARVC.
