The complement system is an important part of the immune system. It is part of the humoral response to infection and injury. It is activated by three different pathways. The classical pathway is activated by the presence of foreign antigen, antibody, and complement proteins. The first step is the binding of antigen-antibody complexes to the Fc region of the antibody. This binding causes the activation of the C1 complex, which consists of three proteins: C1q, C1r, and C1s. The C1 complex is a protease complex that cleaves C4 and C2 to form the C4b2a complex. This complex is a protease that cleaves and activates C3. The C3 convertase cleaves and activates additional C3 molecules, forming the membrane attack complex (MAC). The MAC causes lysis of foreign cells and is the final step in the complement cascade. The alternative pathway is activated by foreign cell membranes or aggregates of proteins. In this pathway, the first step is the spontaneous activation of C3. This results in the formation of C3 (H2O). C3 (H2O) is a cleavage product of C3 that has not yet been cleaved by C3 convertase. C3 (H2O) can form a C3 convertase with factor B and factor D. The C3 convertase cleaves additional C3, forming the amplification loop. The alternative complement pathway is important in the early stages of infection and is also activated by ischemia and reperfusion injury. The complement cascade results in the formation of several different proteins that can act as opsonins, activate inflammatory cells, and lyse foreign cells. The complement cascade is regulated by a group of proteins called complement regulatory proteins. Inappropriate regulation of the complement system can lead to tissue damage and disease.

Granzyme A and granzyme B are serine proteases that are released from cytotoxic T cells and NK cells and enter the target cell to induce apoptosis. Granzyme A cleaves the nuclear protein SET, releasing the histone chaperone NAP-1 and inducing apoptosis. SET is also a substrate for protein kinase CK2, which phosphorylates SET and blocks its cleavage by Granzyme A. The SET protein is involved in the regulation of chromatin structure and apoptosis. The DNA repair enzyme APE-1 is also a substrate for Granzyme A and is also cleaved to induce apoptosis. Granzyme A also cleaves the transcription factor CREB to block transcription of anti-apoptotic genes. Granzyme B cleaves Bid to induce apoptosis.

Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) are a family of ligand-activated transcription factors that are involved in lipid metabolism and glucose homeostasis. Three PPAR subtypes (PPARalpha, beta / delta, and gamma) have been identified in vertebrates. Each PPAR subtype has distinct tissue distribution and regulates the expression of different genes involved in lipid metabolism. PPARalpha is highly expressed in the liver and plays a key role in the regulation of lipid metabolism by activating genes involved in fatty acid oxidation. PPARbeta / delta is ubiquitously expressed and plays a role in lipid metabolism in many tissues. PPARgamma is highly expressed in adipose tissue and plays a key role in adipocyte differentiation. The activation of PPARgamma by its ligands stimulates adipocyte differentiation and insulin sensitivity.

Interleukin-1 (IL-1) is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that plays a key role in the immune response. IL-1 is produced by a variety of cells in response to infection or tissue injury. IL-1 is a key mediator of fever, pain, and other responses to infection. IL-1 is a member of a family of cytokines that also includes IL-1 8 and IL-1F2. IL-1 is produced as an inactive precursor that is cleaved by a protease called IL-1converting enzyme (ICE) to produce the active form. ICE is also involved in the activation of other cytokines involved in the immune response. IL-1 is a key mediator of the inflammatory response and is a key component of arthritis. IL-1 plays a key role in the response to infection and is a key component of arthritis. IL-1 is a key mediator of the inflammatory response and is a key component of arthritis. IL-1 is a key mediator of the response to infection and is a key component of arthritis. IL-1 is a key component of arthritis. IL-1 is a key regulator of the immune response. IL-1 is a key regulator of the immune response. IL-1 is a key regulator of the immune response. IL-1 is a key mediator of the immune response. IL-1 is a key regulator of the immune response. IL-1 is a key component of septic shock and arthritis. IL-1 is a key regulator of the inflammatory response. IL-1 is a key regulator of the inflammatory response. IL-1 is a key regulator of the inflammatory response. IL-1 is a key mediator of septic shock and arthritis.

Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) and the structurally related peptide pituitary adenylate cyclase-activating polypeptide (PACAP) are neurotransmitters and hormones that are widely distributed in the central nervous system and peripheral tissues. They exert their actions through three G-protein coupled receptors, VPAC and VPAC, coupled to the AC / cAMP / PKA and PLC / PKC second messenger pathways. They exert their actions through the activation of several transcription factors, including CREB, NF-AT, and NF-kB.

Hypoxia is a reduction in tissue pO tension below the level of oxygen delivery, which occurs in many physiologic and pathologic processes including development, wound healing, and ischemia. Cells respond to hypoxia by increasing the expression of genes involved in oxygen delivery and decreasing the expression of genes involved in oxygen consumption. The transcription factor hypoxia-inducible factor-1 (HIF-1) plays a key role in the cellular response to hypoxia. In the presence of oxygen, HIF-1 is rapidly degraded by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. Oxygen-dependent hydroxylation of HIF-1alpha by a family of prolyl hydroxylases targets HIF-1 for ubiquitination and degradation. HIF-1 activation by hypoxia leads to increased expression of genes involved in oxygen delivery, such as erythropoietin, and decreased expression of genes involved in oxygen consumption, such as the vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). Decreased oxygen consumption in response to hypoxia leads to a reduction in the intracellular pO, which in turn activates a pathway involving the tumor suppressor VHL, elongin B, elongin C, and cullin-2 that targets the transcription factor HIF-1 for ubiquitination and degradation by the proteasome. VHL is a tumor suppressor gene that is mutated in patients with von Hippel-Lindau disease. Binding of the VHL protein to HIF-1 blocks the interaction between HIF-1 and the ubiquitin ligase complex, preventing ubiquitination and degradation of HIF-1. Nonhypoxic signals that increase the level of intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) also activate HIF-1. ROS activate the HIF-1 pathway by inhibiting the degradation of HIF-1, increasing the half-life of HIF-1. ROS also activate the MAPK pathway, which can stimulate HIF-1 activity by a mechanism independent of HIF-1 stabilization. HIF-1 is also activated by hypoxia-independent mechanisms. For example, HIF-1 is activated by the oncogene HER-2 / neu, which activates the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway. HIF-1 activation by hypoxia and by other stimuli such as growth factors and oncogenes may play a role in the development and progression of cancer.

Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) and the structurally related peptide pituitary adenylate cyclase-activating polypeptide (PACAP) are widely distributed neuropeptides with potent effects on many different cell types. They are involved in a variety of physiological processes such as regulation of endocrine and exocrine secretion, neuronal transmission, and smooth muscle contraction. The biological effects of VIP and PACAP are mediated by two different G-protein coupled receptors, VPAC and VPAC. Both peptides are able to activate adenylate cyclase through the G (s) -protein coupled receptor, but they also can activate phospholipase C through the G (i) -protein coupled receptor. The activation of these second messenger systems leads to the activation of protein kinase A and protein kinase C, which in turn can activate a variety of transcription factors. The activation of nuclear factor-kB (NF-kB) by VIP and PACAP has been shown to be involved in the regulation of the expression of several genes. The activation of the transcription factor AP-1 by VIP and PACAP has been shown to be involved in the regulation of the expression of the genes encoding the immediate early genes c-fos and c-jun. The activation of the transcription factor CREB by VIP and PACAP has been shown to be involved in the regulation of the expression of the gene encoding the neuropeptide VIP itself.

Chemokines are small chemoattractant cytokines that are classified into four groups, the CC, CXC, C and CX3C chemokines, based on their N-terminal amino acid sequence similarity. The chemokine family is large and includes more than 5 0 members in humans. Chemokines are small proteins (8-1 0 kDa) that are secreted by a variety of cells and act as chemoattractants for leukocytes, lymphocytes, and other cell types. Chemokines are involved in many physiological and pathological processes, such as immune responses, inflammation, angiogenesis, and development of the hematopoietic system. Chemokines exert their biological functions by binding to their receptors on the cell surface. Most chemokine receptors belong to the rhodopsin-like 7TM receptor family. The chemokine receptors are classified into four groups, CXC receptors (CXCR1-4), CC receptors (CCR1-5, CCR2B, CCR3L1-3, and CCR5), CX3C receptors (CX3CR1), and the atypical chemokine receptor.

The immune system consists of two major parts, the innate and the adaptive immune systems. The innate immune system is present in all organisms and provides immediate protection against invading pathogens. The adaptive immune system is generated only in higher organisms and provides a more specific response to pathogens. The innate immune system consists of natural killer (NK) cells, macrophages, and neutrophils. Macrophages and neutrophils are the first line of defense against invading pathogens. Macrophages phagocytose and destroy invading pathogens, and neutrophils release reactive oxygen species and proteases to kill and digest pathogens. Macrophages and neutrophils also secrete cytokines that stimulate the immune system. NK cells are lymphocytes that provide a rapid response to infection and malignancy. NK cells are also involved in the regulation of other immune cells, such as T cells. Macrophages and neutrophils secrete cytokines that stimulate the adaptive immune system. Macrophages and neutrophils also present antigens to T cells, stimulating the proliferation and activation of T cells. T cells are a key component of the adaptive immune system, as they are responsible for the specificity of the immune response. T cells are classified into two groups, helper T cells and cytotoxic T cells. Helper T cells, such as those in mice that express the CD40 receptor, stimulate B cells to proliferate and produce antibodies that bind to and inactivate specific pathogens. Cytotoxic T cells, such as those in mice that express CD80, are cytotoxic cells that kill cells that express the same antigen. Cytotoxic T cells are stimulated by antigen-presenting cells (APCs), such as macrophages and dendritic cells, to proliferate and secrete cytokines that stimulate the immune response. APCs present antigen to T cells in the form of peptides bound to MHC molecules on the surface of the APC. The CD40 receptor is required for T cell activation. The CD40 ligand is CD28, which is expressed on the surface of activated B cells and some T cells. The CD40 ligand is expressed on activated macrophages and is upregulated by inflammatory cytokines.

The meiotic maturation of oocytes is triggered by the maturation-inducing steroid (MIS), progesterone in vertebrates. The signal transduction pathway activated by the MIS is similar to that activated by growth factors. The tyrosine kinase activity of the epidermal growth factor (EGF) receptor is activated by binding of MIS, and the activated EGF receptor phosphorylates and activates the tyrosine kinase, c-Src. The activity of the small G protein Ras is increased by the action of growth factor receptors and MIS receptors. The activity of the G protein, Gqalpha, is also increased by the action of growth factor receptors and MIS receptors. The activation of Ras and Gqalpha leads to the activation of the MAP kinase cascade, which includes Raf, MEK and MAPK. The activation of the MAP kinase cascade is essential for the resumption of meiosis. The activation of MPF, the cyclin B-Cdc2 kinase, is also essential for the resumption of meiosis.

Leukocyte adhesion is a key step in the inflammatory response. During an inflammatory response, circulating leukocytes roll along the endothelium of the blood vessel wall, then adhere to the endothelium and migrate into the underlying tissue. This process is mediated by a family of cell surface adhesion molecules called integrins. Integrins are a family of cell surface receptors that mediate cell-cell and cell-extracellular matrix interactions. Members of the integrin family include the leukocyte integrins LFA-1 (lymphocyte function-associated antigen 1), Mac-1 (macrophage antigen 1), and VLA-4 (very late antigen 4), which are involved in the adhesion of leukocytes to other cells. The selectins are a family of cell surface glycoproteins that mediate the initial attachment of leukocytes to the vascular endothelium during inflammation. Selectins are expressed on the surface of activated endothelial cells and mediate the initial attachment of leukocytes. The interaction of selectins with their ligands is calcium-dependent. The interaction of selectins with their ligands is also reversible, allowing leukocytes to roll along the endothelium and then be arrested by integrin-mediated interactions.

Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death that is essential for normal development and tissue homeostasis. Caspases are a family of cysteine proteases that are central to the apoptotic signaling pathways. Caspases are synthesized as inactive proenzymes that are activated through proteolytic cleavage. Once activated, caspases cleave a variety of cellular targets, leading to the morphological changes associated with apoptosis. Caspase-3 is a key effector caspase that is activated by a variety of apoptotic stimuli and cleaves a variety of cellular targets. One of the cellular targets of caspase-3 is DFF4 0 / CAD, a caspase-3 substrate that normally functions to maintain genomic stability by cleaving chromosomal DNA. Caspase-3 cleavage of DFF4 0 / CAD results in the activation of DFF4 0 and the subsequent degradation of chromosomal DNA. Another caspase-3 substrate is PARP, an abundant nuclear enzyme that is involved in DNA repair. Caspase-3 cleavage of PARP results in the depletion of cellular NAD + and ATP, which can lead to cell death by necrosis. Another caspase-3 substrate is golgi-associated apoptosis related protein (GARP). GARP is localized to the Golgi apparatus and is involved in vesicular transport. Caspase-3 cleavage of GARP may lead to the fragmentation of the Golgi apparatus that is observed during apoptosis.

TNF is a cytokine that induces a variety of cellular responses including apoptosis, cell proliferation, and inflammation. The biological activities of TNF are mediated by two cell surface receptors, TNFR1 and TNFR2. TNFR1 contains a cytoplasmic death domain that is essential for TNF-induced apoptosis. TNFR2 does not have a cytoplasmic death domain and transmits signals through TRAF proteins to activate NF-kB and other signaling pathways.

The immune system is composed of a variety of cells and proteins that work together to protect the body from harmful pathogens. T cells are a key component of the immune system and are essential for the response to infection. Naive T cells recognize antigens presented by antigen-presenting cells (APCs) in the context of MHC molecules. Naive T cells are classified into two types, CD4 + and CD8 + T cells. Naive CD4 + T cells are further classified into two subsets, Th1 and Th2 cells, based on the cytokines they produce. Th1 cells produce interferon-gamma (IFNgamma) and interleukin-2 (IL-2), which stimulate macrophage activation and promote cell-mediated immune responses. Th2 cells produce IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, and IL-10, which stimulate B cell activation and eosinophil proliferation and activation. In addition to these cytokines, naive CD4 + T cells can differentiate into regulatory T cells (Treg) that suppress the activation of other T cells. The differentiation of naive CD4 + T cells into Th1 and Th2 cells is influenced by the cytokines in the local environment. Treg cells are induced by TGF-beta and IL-1 0 and suppress the activation of other T cells.

Epithelial cell polarization is a fundamental feature of tissues and organs. It is essential for the formation of specific cell-cell contacts, the formation of tight junctions (TJs) and the establishment of cell-cell asymmetry. The TJs form a selective diffusion barrier between the apical and basolateral plasma membrane domains and are involved in the control of cell proliferation and apoptosis. The establishment of cell-cell asymmetry is achieved by the segregation of membrane proteins into apical and basolateral membrane domains. The basolateral membrane is in contact with the extracellular matrix, the apical membrane is in contact with the environment. The formation of cell-cell contacts and the establishment of cell polarity are under the control of cell adhesion molecules and of cell-cell adhesion molecules. Cell adhesion molecules are involved in the initial step of cell-cell adhesion. They interact with the extracellular matrix and with other cells. Cell-cell adhesion molecules interact with each other and with the cytoskeleton. The formation of cell-cell contacts and the establishment of cell polarity are under the control of cell adhesion molecules.

Hypertrophy is a compensatory response to increased hemodynamic load that is accompanied by an increase in the size of the cardiac myocytes. The increase in cell size is brought about by an increase in the size of the individual proteins (i.e., protein synthesis) with no change in the number of cells (i.e., cell proliferation is not involved). The increase in cell size is brought about by an increase in the amount of protein that is being synthesized without a change in the rate of protein degradation. The increase in protein synthesis is brought about by an increase in the translation of existing mRNAs into protein. The increase in protein synthesis is brought about by an increase in the activity of the translation initiation factor eIF-2. The increase in eIF-2 activity is brought about by a decrease in the activity of the eIF-2 inhibitor, eIF-2B. The increase in eIF-2B activity is brought about by a decrease in the activity of the eIF-2B inhibitor, GSK-3. The increase in eIF-2 activity is brought about by the phosphorylation of eIF-2 by a protein kinase called CaM Kinase III. The increase in eIF-2 activity is also brought about by the phosphorylation of the ribosomal protein S6 by a protein kinase called RSK. The increase in eIF-2 and ribosomal protein S6 activity is brought about by the phosphorylation of the initiation factor 4E by the kinase called MNK1. The increase in eIF-2 and ribosomal protein S6 activity is brought about by the phosphorylation of the initiation factor 4E by the kinase called MNK1.

The heme group is an essential cofactor in many proteins. The heme group is synthesized from glycine and succinyl CoA by a series of enzymatic steps. The first step is the condensation of glycine and succinyl CoA to form porphobilinogen. This is followed by four enzymatic steps to form uroporphyrinogen III. This is converted to coproporphyrinogen III by two enzymatic steps. Coproporphyrinogen III is converted to protoporphyrinogen by the addition of a fourth ring. The heme group is attached to a protein carrier by a covalent bond. The final step in the synthesis of heme is the insertion of iron into protoporphyrin IX to form heme. The iron is inserted by ferrochelatase. The first step in the synthesis of heme is the activation of glycine by the enzyme ALA synthase. There are two forms of the enzyme in mammals, ALAS1 and ALAS2. ALAS1 is the housekeeping form and is expressed in all tissues. ALAS2 is a product of a specific erythroid gene and is expressed only in erythroid cells. The activity of ALAS is regulated by heme and succinyl CoA. Heme feedback inhibits the activity of ALAS. The activity of ALAS is also regulated by the level of succinyl CoA. When the level of succinyl CoA is high, the activity of the enzyme is increased. The activity of ferrochelatase is also regulated by heme. When the level of heme is high, the activity of ferrochelatase is increased.

Rho family GTPases are molecular switches that cycle between an inactive GDP-bound state and an active GTP-bound state. In their active state, Rho GTPases interact with downstream effectors to regulate a variety of cellular processes including cytoskeletal reorganization, gene transcription, and cell cycle progression. Guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs) activate Rho proteins by stimulating the exchange of GDP for GTP, whereas GTPase-activating proteins (GAPs) inactivate Rho by stimulating the hydrolysis of bound GTP to GDP. The Dbl family of GEFs is one group of proteins that activate Rho GTPases by stimulating the exchange of GDP for GTP. The Dbl family of Rho GEFs includes Lbc, Vav, and Tiam1. The Dbl family also includes Dbl, P-Rex, Vav-2, and TrioD1. The Dbl homology (DH) domain is responsible for the catalytic activity of Dbl family GEFs, and the pleckstrin homology (PH) domain is involved in the localization of Dbl family proteins to the plasma membrane and in the regulation of the exchange activity of the DH domain. The DBL-homology (DH) domain is also found in the Bcr protein, which is involved in the development of chronic myelogenous leukemia. The Dbl family also includes the Dbs and Vav proteins. The Dbs protein is involved in the development of multiple myeloma. The Vav protein is involved in T cell activation and is involved in the development of lymphoma and leukemia. The DBL protein is involved in the development of Wilms' tumors. The TrioD1 protein is involved in the development of the heart. The Lbc protein is involved in the development of a variety of tissues. The Dbl protein is involved in the development of leukemia. The P-Rex protein is involved in the development of myeloproliferative disorders. The Vav protein is involved in the development of lymphoma and leukemia. The Bcr protein is involved in the development of chronic myelogenous leukemia. The Dia proteins are involved in the development of brain and skeletal abnormalities. The Dia-1 protein is involved in the regulation of the actin cytoskeleton and cell morphology. The Dia-2 protein is involved in the regulation of gene transcription.

Interleukin 4 (IL-4) is a cytokine that is involved in the differentiation of B cells and T cells. The IL-4 receptor is a heterodimer, with the IL-4Ralpha chain being the ligand binding subunit and the IL-2Rgamma chain being the common gamma chain for the IL-2, IL-4, IL-7, IL-9, IL-13 and IL-15 receptors. The IL-4Ralpha chain is also the site of recruitment of JAK kinases for activation of the JAK / STAT pathway. The JAK kinases are a family of tyrosine kinases that are activated by cytokine receptors and are involved in the JAK / STAT signaling pathway. The JAK kinases phosphorylate the IL-4Ralpha chain and the IL-2Rgamma chain, creating binding sites for the STAT transcription factors. The STAT factors are activated by phosphorylation by the JAK kinases, and then translocate to the nucleus to activate transcription. The JAK / STAT pathway is involved in a variety of cellular responses, including differentiation of cells, proliferation and apoptosis.

The GPI-anchor is a post-translational modification that anchors a diverse class of proteins to the cell surface. The GPI anchor is synthesized in the ER membrane from a phosphatidylinositol (PI) -tailed protein, a process termed GPI-anchor biosynthesis. The GPI-anchor precursor is first assembled on the ER membrane by the GPI-anchor biosynthetic pathway on the lipid-modified glycan, GlcN-acyl-1'phosphatidylinositol (GlcNAc-PI). After its attachment to the protein, the GPI-anchor precursor is transferred en bloc to the phosphatidylinositol-glycan (PI-G), the second GPI intermediate, by the GPI-transamidase complex. The GPI-anchor precursor is then deacetylated by an inositol-specific phospholipase C (PI-PLC) in the lumen of the ER, releasing the GPI-anchored protein from the membrane. The mature GPI-anchor precursor is then transferred to the target proteins in the lumen of the ER by an as yet unidentified glycolipid transporter. Defects in GPI-anchor biosynthesis cause a group of inherited disorders, the 'PIGA-related disorders'.

Sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) is a bioactive sphingolipid metabolite produced by sphingosine kinase 1 (SPHK1). S1P is a ligand for five GPCRs, Edg-1, Edg-5, SPP-1R, SPP-2R and LPAR-3. S1P has been implicated in a variety of biological processes, including cell proliferation, survival, migration, and angiogenesis. In addition, S1P has been shown to play an important role in inflammation. S1P is produced in the plasma membrane from sphingomyelin by the action of acid sphingomyelinase. S1P is exported out of cells and is taken back up by cells through specific transporters. S1P is degraded to phosphoethanolamine and hexadecenal by S1P lyase.

The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a transmembrane glycoprotein with an extracellular ligand-binding domain, a single transmembrane domain, and an intracellular tyrosine kinase domain. The binding of ligand to the extracellular domain results in receptor dimerization and activation of the tyrosine kinase domain. The downstream signaling pathways activated by EGFR activation include the ras / raf / mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway, the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway, and the Janus kinase / signal transducers and activators of transcription (JAK / STAT) pathway. These pathways ultimately result in enhanced cell proliferation, survival, and motility. Mutations in the EGFR gene have been identified in a subset of non-small-cell lung cancers (NSCLC). These mutations lead to constitutive activation of the receptor and are associated with a more favorable response to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) such as gefitinib and erlotinib. EGFR gene amplification and protein overexpression are also associated with a more favorable response to EGFR TKIs. The presence of EGFR gene mutations, EGFR gene amplification, and EGFR protein overexpression may be used to select patients with NSCLC who are most likely to respond to EGFR TKIs. Mutations in the EGFR kinase domain are associated with a higher response rate to EGFR TKIs. Mutations in the K-ras gene are associated with primary resistance to EGFR TKIs. The presence of EGFR mutations may also be used to select patients with NSCLC who are most likely to respond to EGFR TKIs.

The inflammatory response is a complex process involving the recruitment of leukocytes to the site of inflammation, the release of inflammatory mediators, and the clearance of infectious agents. The inflammatory response is initiated by the recognition of foreign pathogens by pattern recognition receptors, such as the Toll-like receptors (TLRs). TLR activation leads to the production of proinflammatory cytokines, including IL-12, IL-15, IL-6, IL-8, and TNF-alpha, and the induction of interferon-beta (IFN-beta). The production of these cytokines is regulated by the transcription factor NF-kappaB, which is activated by TLR signaling. The recruitment of neutrophils, macrophages, and lymphocytes to the site of inflammation is regulated by chemokines, small chemoattractant cytokines that are induced by the inflammatory cytokines. The chemokines IL-8 and MIP-1 are potent chemoattractants for neutrophils and macrophages, respectively. The inflammatory response is terminated by the production of anti-inflammatory cytokines, including IL-10, IL-1RA, and IL-13. The anti-inflammatory actions of IL-10 and IL-1RA are mediated in part by the inhibition of the production of inflammatory cytokines by activated macrophages. The balance of pro- and anti-inflammatory cytokines produced during an inflammatory response is an important determinant of the severity of an inflammatory response. Aberrant production of inflammatory cytokines has been implicated in the pathogenesis of a number of human diseases, including septic shock, rheumatoid arthritis, and asthma.

Apoptosis is a genetically controlled cell suicide mechanism that plays a critical role in development and tissue homeostasis. Caspases are a family of cysteine proteases that are responsible for the execution phase of apoptosis. Caspases are synthesized as inactive precursors and are activated by proteolytic cleavage. Caspase-8 and caspase-9 are the two apical caspases that respond to apoptotic stimuli. Caspase-8 is activated by the Fas receptor and the cytochrome c / Apaf-1 / caspase-9 pathway. Caspase-9 is activated by the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria. Once activated, caspase-3, -6 and-7 are the downstream effector caspases that cleave cellular targets that are essential for cell survival. The Bcl-2 family of proteins regulates apoptosis through their interactions with the caspases. Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL inhibit apoptosis by blocking the activation of caspases, whereas Bax and Bid promote apoptosis by a similar mechanism.

Hypoxia is a reduction in tissue oxygen tension that can occur in a number of settings, including ischemia, high altitude, and cancer. Cells respond to hypoxia by increasing the expression of genes that increase oxygen delivery, such as erythropoietins, and decrease the expression of genes that reduce oxygen delivery, such as erythropoietins and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). The erythropoietin gene is activated by hypoxia through the coordinate action of a hypoxia-inducible enhancer (HRE) and a cyclic AMP-responsive element (CRE). The HRE binds the transcription factor HIF1, which is a heterodimer of HIF-1alpha and ARNT. The HIF-1alpha subunit is regulated by oxygen tension in cells, and is rapidly degraded under normoxic conditions, but is stabilized and activated in hypoxia. The von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor protein (VHL) binds to HIF-1alpha in an oxygen-dependent manner, targeting it for ubiquitination and proteosomal degradation. The binding of VHL to HIF-1alpha is inhibited by the interaction of the elongin complex with HIF-1alpha, allowing HIF-1alpha to accumulate under hypoxic conditions. The binding of HIF-1alpha to ARNT also requires oxygen, and is inhibited by the interaction of HIF-1alpha with the p300 protein. The CRE in the erythropoietin gene binds CREB and ATF family members, and is required for full hypoxia responsiveness. The interaction of HIF-1alpha with CBP / p300 is also required for full erythropoietin induction by hypoxia. The interaction of HIF-1alpha with the elongin complex may also be involved in the inhibition of transcription by hypoxia. The interaction of HIF-1alpha with the p300 protein may also play a role in the transcriptional activation of other genes by HIF-1, such as VEGF. The inhibition of p300 by HIF-1alpha may also play a role in other HIF-1-dependent processes, such as apoptosis.

The Notch signaling pathway is an evolutionarily conserved mechanism for cell-fate specification. It is involved in a variety of developmental processes, including neurogenesis, myogenesis, and hematopoiesis. The Notch receptor is activated by Delta or Jagged ligands on the surface of an adjacent cell. Upon ligand binding, the Notch receptor is cleaved and the Notch intracellular domain (NICD) is released. The NICD translocates to the nucleus and forms a transcriptional activation complex with the DNA-binding protein CSL (CBF1 / Su (H) / Lag-1) and the coactivator Mastermind (MAM). This complex activates the transcription of Notch target genes, including those involved in cell fate specification. The Notch pathway is also involved in oncogenesis. The Notch pathway is constitutively activated in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) by mutation of the Notch receptor or of the proteins involved in the Notch signaling cascade.

Protein ubiquitination plays a key role in a variety of cellular processes, including protein degradation, endocytosis, cell cycle control, transcriptional regulation, DNA repair, and stress signaling. E3 ubiquitin ligases determine the substrate specificity of ubiquitination. There are two major types of E3 ligases: HECT-type and RING-finger-type E3s. HECT-type E3s have a catalytic cysteine residue that accepts ubiquitin from the ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme (E2) and transfers it to the substrate. The RING-finger-type E3s do not have a catalytic cysteine residue but bind both the ubiquitin-charged E2 and the substrate.

Apoptosis is a genetically controlled cell death mechanism that is essential for proper embryonic development and tissue homeostasis in adult organisms. Caspases are a family of cysteine proteases that are essential for apoptosis. Caspases are activated through two main pathways, the extrinsic (receptor-mediated) and the intrinsic (mitochondria-mediated) pathways. The extrinsic pathway is triggered by the binding of extracellular death ligands to cell surface receptors. The intrinsic pathway is triggered by a variety of stimuli, including DNA damage, growth factor withdrawal, and ligation of cell surface receptors. Both pathways result in the activation of caspase-9, which in turn activates downstream caspases, including caspase-3. The cleavage of cellular substrates by caspases results in the morphological and biochemical changes associated with apoptosis.

Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) are ligand-gated ion channels that mediate fast synaptic transmission at the neuromuscular junction and in the brain. They are also expressed in a variety of non-neuronal tissues, where their function is less well understood. The neuromuscular junction is a model system for the study of synapse formation and plasticity. At the neuromuscular junction, the motor neuron releases the neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh), which binds to nicotinic receptors on the muscle fiber. The binding of ACh opens a channel in the receptor, allowing influx of Na + and Ca2 + into the muscle fiber. The influx of cations depolarizes the muscle fiber and activates voltage-dependent calcium channels. The influx of calcium activates signaling pathways that lead to the formation of new acetylcholine receptors and other proteins at the neuromuscular junction. Nicotinic receptors are also expressed in the brain, where they modulate the release of dopamine, serotonin, and glutamate. Nicotinic receptors are also expressed in non-neuronal tissues, where their function is less well understood. The alpha7 nicotinic receptor is expressed in the thymus and may modulate the immune system. The alpha4beta2 nicotinic receptor is expressed in the lung and is the target of the drug nicotine used to treat tobacco dependence.

Cytokines are soluble factors that are secreted by cells in the body and that act on other cells. Cytokines are involved in a variety of activities including the immune response, inflammation, hematopoiesis, and development of the nervous system. The cytokines are produced by many different cell types and act in an autocrine, paracrine, or endocrine manner. The cytokines are classified into different groups based on their structure and function. The hematopoietic cytokines are a group of cytokines that stimulate the growth and differentiation of hematopoietic cells. The hematopoietic cytokines include the interleukins, colony stimulating factors, and the pentraxins.

Tight junctions (TJs) are specialized cell-cell adhesion structures that regulate the passage of solutes and particles through the paracellular space between epithelial cells. TJs are formed by the association of transmembrane proteins with cytoplasmic plaque proteins. The transmembrane proteins occludin and claudins are the principal components of TJs. The cytoplasmic plaque contains several proteins that are involved in the regulation of TJ assembly and function. These include the zonula occludens proteins ZO-1, ZO-2 and ZO-3, which are involved in the organization of the membrane proteins into a stable complex, and the multi-PDZ protein MUPP1, which may serve as a scaffold for the assembly of other proteins. Other cytoplasmic plaque proteins are cingulin, 73kDa protein, and AF-6. Cingulin and AF-6 are involved in the regulation of the assembly of TJs. 73kDa protein is involved in the regulation of the actin cytoskeleton.

T cells are activated by the T cell receptor (TCR) -major histocompatibility complex (MHC) interaction and by costimulatory molecules. Engagement of the TCR by antigen-bound MHC molecules on the surface of antigen-presenting cells (APCs) leads to T cell activation. The costimulatory signal is provided by interaction of the T cell receptor with costimulatory molecules on the APC. Engagement of the TCR and costimulatory molecules induces a signaling cascade that results in T cell proliferation and differentiation into effector cells. The strength and duration of the signal are critical for T cell activation. T cell activation is regulated by a delicate balance between positive and negative signals. T cell activation requires a positive signal provided by the TCR and costimulatory molecules. T cell activation is also regulated by a negative signal provided by various mechanisms, including coinhibitory molecules. Coinhibitory molecules are expressed on T cells and bind to their ligands on APCs. T cell activation is also regulated by the cytokine environment. T helper (Th) cells are classified into two subsets based on their cytokine profiles and functions. Th1 cells produce interleukin (IL) -2, interferon-gamma (IFNgamma), and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNFalpha) and are involved in cellular immunity. Th2 cells produce IL-4, IL-5, and IL-10 and are involved in humoral immunity. CD4 0 ligand (CD40L) is a costimulatory molecule that is expressed on activated T cells and that is required for Th2 cell differentiation.

Macrophages are cells of the immune system that respond to infection and injury by ingesting and destroying foreign cells and tissues. Macrophages secrete a variety of factors that stimulate the immune response, including the cytokines that stimulate the growth and differentiation of other cells of the immune system. Macrophages also secrete reactive oxygen species that are toxic to cells and tissues. Cytokines are proteins or glycoproteins secreted by macrophages that act on other cells to elicit a response. Macrophages are activated by different factors to produce different cytokines. Interferon-gamma activates macrophages to secrete interleukin-1, tumor necrosis factor-alpha, and other cytokines. Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) activates macrophages to secrete interleukin-1, tumor necrosis factor-alpha, and other cytokines. IL-1 is a protein secreted by macrophages that stimulates the inflammatory response and fever. IL-1 is produced by macrophages in response to LPS and other bacterial factors. IL-1 is secreted by macrophages in response to LPS and other bacterial factors. IL-1 is a key cytokine in the inflammatory response. IL-1 is a key cytokine in the inflammatory response. IL-1 is a key cytokine in the inflammatory response. IL-1 is a key cytokine in the inflammatory response. It is produced by macrophages in response to LPS and other bacterial factors. IL-1 is a key cytokine in the inflammatory response. IL-1 is a cytokine that stimulates fever and other responses to infection. IL-1 is also a key regulator of the immune response. IL-1 activates T cells and B cells to proliferate and produce antibodies. IL-1 also stimulates the proliferation of fibroblasts and other cells. IL-1 is a key regulator of the immune response.

Cell-cell adherens junctions (AJs) and tight junctions (TJs) are important structures that regulate cell-cell adhesion and cell polarity. At AJs, homophilic interactions between the extracellular domains of E-cadherins lead to the formation of a zipper-like structure between cells. At TJs, occludin, claudins, and junction adhesion molecules (JAMs) interact with the cytoplasmic proteins ZO-1, -2, and -2, which in turn bind to the cytoplasmic domain of occludin and claudin. These interactions are thought to be important for the formation and maintenance of TJs. The formation of AJs and TJs is regulated by tyrosine phosphorylation. Several protein tyrosine kinases (PTKs) and protein tyrosine phosphatases (PTPs) have been implicated in the regulation of AJs and TJs. The PTK c-Src is a key regulator of both AJs and TJs. Overexpression of c-Src in epithelial cells disrupts AJs and TJs, whereas inhibition of c-Src activity has the opposite effect. The disruption of AJs and TJs by Src is mediated by the tyrosine phosphorylation of E-cadherin, occludin, and ZO-1. The phosphorylation of these proteins by Src disrupts their interactions and their localization at AJs and TJs. The activity of c-Src is regulated by several mechanisms. The activity of c-Src is negatively regulated by phosphorylation of a tyrosine residue, Y5 2 7, in the kinase domain of c-Src. Dephosphorylation of Y5 2 7 by PTPs such as PTP-1B and PTP-LAR is required for the activation of c-Src. The activity of c-Src is also regulated by its interaction with other proteins. The interaction of c-Src with FAK is required for the activation of c-Src by integrin-mediated cell adhesion. The interaction of c-Src with cortactin also positively regulates the activity of c-Src. The disruption of AJs and TJs by Src is also mediated by the phosphorylation of cortactin. The tyrosine phosphorylation of cortactin by Src disrupts the interaction of cortactin with ZO-1 and ZO-2, which leads to the disruption of TJs.

Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a heart muscle disease characterised by dilatation and impaired contractility of the left or both ventricles, with a clinical presentation of heart failure. The incidence of DCM is approximately one in 25 0 0, and the prevalence is approximately 1 in 10 0 0. The clinical course is usually progressive, with a high mortality rate in the absence of heart transplantation. The cause of DCM is heterogeneous, with genetic factors being the most important. The genetic causes of DCM are heterogeneous, with mutations in at least 1 0 genes identified to date. These genes encode proteins that are involved in the maintenance of cytoskeletal structure, force-generating systems, and force transmission. The diagnosis of DCM is based on clinical, electrocardiographic, and echocardiographic findings. The prognosis of patients with DCM is poor, with a high mortality rate in the absence of heart transplantation. The treatment of patients with DCM is challenging, and the optimal approach is still under debate. Key issues include the identification of high-risk patients, the use of implantable cardioverter-defibrillators, and the role of heart transplantation.

The T cell receptor (TCR) complex is a multimeric receptor complex expressed on the surface of T cells that plays a central role in the immune system by recognizing specific peptide antigens associated with major histocompatibility complex (MHC) proteins. The TCR complex is composed of two polypeptide chains, the clonotypic alpha and beta chains that noncovalently associate with the invariant gamma and delta chains. The CD3 complex is associated with the TCR complex and is required for signal transduction. Engagement of the TCR by antigen induces a complex series of signaling events that result in T cell activation. The CD3 complex contains the invariant gamma and delta chains and two variable chains, alpha and beta, that associate with the gamma and beta chains to form a complex that is noncovalently associated with the TCR. The CD3 complex is responsible for transducing the TCR-derived activation signal. The TCR-CD3 complex is associated with tyrosine kinases of the Src and Syk families that are activated by TCR engagement and phosphorylate immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motifs (ITAMs) in the cytoplasmic domains of the TCR-associated CD3 and TCR-zeta chains. The phosphorylation of ITAMs creates binding sites for the Syk / ZAP-7 0 family of proteins that are also associated with the TCR-CD3 complex. The activation of these kinases results in the phosphorylation of downstream targets, including phospholipase C-gamma (PLC-gamma), LAT, Vav, and other proteins, that are required for T cell activation.

The mitotic spindle is a macromolecular machine that segregates chromosomes during cell division. The mitotic spindle is composed of microtubules and associated proteins. The activity of the mitotic spindle is regulated by the cell cycle, and by the cell's environment. The cell cycle regulates the activity of the mitotic spindle by controlling the assembly and disassembly of microtubules, and by regulating the activity of microtubule associated proteins. The cell's environment regulates the activity of the mitotic spindle by controlling the concentration of free tubulin dimers. The concentration of free tubulin dimers is regulated by the levels of free tubulin monomers, which are in turn regulated by the opposing activities of polymerization and depolymerization. The activity of microtubule associated proteins is regulated by phosphorylation, and by the concentration of free tubulin monomers.

Mitochondria play a central role in the apoptotic pathway. The release of mitochondrial proteins into the cytoplasm triggers the caspase cascade and the downstream destruction of the cell. The release of mitochondrial proteins is regulated by the Bcl-2 family of proteins. The Bcl-2 family can be divided into three groups. The anti-apoptotic proteins include Bcl-2, Bcl-xL, Bcl-w, A1, and Mcl-1. The pro-apoptotic proteins can be further divided into two groups. The first group includes Bax and Bak, which are required for apoptosis induced by a variety of stimuli, including the release of mitochondrial proteins. The second group includes Bid, Bim, Bad, Bik, Puma, Noxa, and Htra2. These proteins share homology in one region, the BH3 domain. When activated, these BH3-containing proteins can interact with Bcl-2 family members to either promote apoptosis or sensitize cells to apoptosis. The anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 proteins block apoptosis by binding to the pro-apoptotic Bcl-2 proteins and preventing them from inducing apoptosis. The Bcl-2 family members are localized to the mitochondrial membrane, the only known site at which they exert their effects. The release of mitochondrial proteins is regulated by the Bcl-2 family. The anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 proteins like Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL maintain the mitochondrial membrane potential and prevent the release of mitochondrial proteins. The pro-apoptotic Bcl-2 proteins like Bax and Bak induce the release of mitochondrial proteins by forming pores in the mitochondrial membrane. The release of mitochondrial proteins into the cytoplasm activates caspases, a family of cysteine proteases that are required for apoptosis. Caspases are produced as inactive zymogens and are activated by cleavage. Caspases cleave cellular targets in a defined sequence and the destruction of these targets contributes to the morphological changes associated with apoptosis. Caspases include caspase-8, -9, and -3. Caspase-8 is activated by the Fas receptor and the adaptor protein FADD. Caspase-9 is activated by the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria. Caspase-9 cleaves and activates caspase-3. IAP proteins block apoptosis by binding to caspases and preventing them from being activated. IAP proteins are antagonized by Smac / Diablo, a mitochondrial protein released into the cytoplasm during apoptosis.

The development of cancer is a multistep process that involves the accumulation of multiple genetic alterations. The activation of oncogenes and inactivation of tumor suppressor genes contribute to the development of cancer. The retinoblastoma (Rb) tumor suppressor gene is one of the most frequently mutated genes in human cancer. The Rb protein is involved in cell cycle control and apoptosis. The Rb protein binds to the transcription factor E2F and regulates the expression of genes involved in cell cycle progression and apoptosis. Inactivation of the Rb gene leads to the loss of Rb protein and the release of free E2F. The free E2F then activates genes involved in cell cycle progression and apoptosis. The activation of oncogenes such as c-MYC also contributes to the development of cancer by deregulating the cell cycle and apoptosis. The activation of oncogenes and inactivation of tumor suppressor genes contribute to the development of cancer.

TrkA is a receptor tyrosine kinase for NGF. The binding of NGF to TrkA activates several signaling pathways, including the Ras / Map kinase pathway and the phosphoinositide 3-kinase pathway. The activation of these pathways leads to neuronal survival and neurite outgrowth.

Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVD) is a heart muscle disease that predominantly affects young adults. It is characterized by progressive loss of ventricular myocytes, replacement by fat and fibrous tissue, and is the most common cause of SCD in young adults in industrialized countries. The disease is genetically heterogeneous, with autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive and X-linked recessive modes of inheritance. Mutations in the desmosomal genes (DSP, JUP, PKP) have been identified in patients with ARVD. Desmosomes are intercellular junctions that provide strong mechanical coupling between adjacent cardiomyocytes. The desmosomal proteins include plakoglobin (PG), plakophilin (PKP), desmoplakin (DSP), desmocolin (DSC), and desmoglein (DSG). Desmosomes are also important in maintaining cell-cell adhesion and cytoskeletal organization. Mutations in these genes may lead to a loss of cell-cell adhesion and cytoskeletal disorganization, which may be responsible for the myocyte loss and fibrofatty replacement. The identification of mutations in the desmosomal genes in patients with ARVD provides strong support for the desmosome hypothesis of ARVD pathogenesis.

Interleukin-1 2 (IL-1 2) is a heterodimeric cytokine that is produced by activated macrophages and dendritic cells and stimulates the proliferation and activation of T cells. The IL-1 2 heterodimer is composed of p3 5 and p4 0 chains that are encoded by separate genes. The IL-1 2 receptor is a heterodimer and is composed of two chains, a ligand-binding chain (IL-1 2Rbeta1) and a signal-transducing chain (IL-1 2Rbeta2). IL-1 2 stimulates T cells to proliferate and produce cytokines such as IFN-gamma and IL-2. The IL-1 2 receptor is expressed on T cells, NK cells, and some B cells. IL-1 2 stimulates T cells and NK cells to proliferate and produce IFN-gamma and IL-2. The IL-1 2 receptor is also expressed on some B cells and is required for IL-1 2-induced B cell proliferation and the differentiation of B cells into immunoglobulin-secreting plasma cells. Mice lacking IL-1 2 or IL-1 2 receptor are impaired in their ability to generate Th1 cells and are susceptible to intracellular infections. The IL-1 2 receptor is also required for the development of protective Th1 cells in humans. The IL-1 2 receptor is a member of the JAK-STAT receptor family and signals through the JAK kinases and STAT transcription factors. Binding of IL-1 2 to the receptor causes the tyrosine phosphorylation and activation of JAK2 and Tyk2 and the tyrosine phosphorylation and activation of STAT1 and STAT4. The IL-1 2 receptor is not down-regulated by IL-1 2 and is not down-regulated by IFN-gamma, but the response of cells to IL-1 2 is sustained by IL-1 2. The IL-1 2 receptor is induced on T cells by activation and is maintained on activated T cells.

NK cells are lymphocytes that are distinct from B and T cells in their origin, receptors, and function. NK cells are involved in innate immunity through the secretion of cytokines and lysis of virus-infected and tumor cells. NK cells are also involved in the regulation of adaptive immune responses through the regulation of T cells. NK cells express a variety of activating and inhibitory receptors that regulate their activation and cytotoxicity. Inhibitory receptors include killer cell lectin-like receptors (KLR) that bind to MHC-I molecules on target cells. Activating receptors include natural cytotoxicity receptors (NCR) that bind to ligands such as MICA and MICB. The balance of activating and inhibitory signals determines the activation state of the NK cell. The protein tyrosine kinase SYK is an essential component of the NK cell activation pathway. The tyrosine kinase ZAP7 0 is also involved in NK cell activation, but is not essential for NK cell cytotoxicity. The LAT adaptor protein is involved in NK cell activation and is phosphorylated by SYK and ZAP7 0. The small GTPase RAC is also involved in NK cell activation. The integrin LFA-1 is involved in NK cell cytotoxicity and may play a role in the formation of an NK cell immunological synapse.

Phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) is a lipid kinase that phosphorylates the D3 position of inositol ring of phosphoinositides. PI3K is activated by a variety of growth factors and regulates a variety of cellular responses, including cell growth, survival, and motility. The activation of PI3K is negatively regulated by PTEN (phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 1 0), a tumor suppressor gene. The activation of PI3K leads to the activation of AKT, also known as protein kinase B. AKT is a serine / threonine kinase that regulates a variety of cellular processes through phosphorylation of downstream targets. AKT inhibits apoptosis through phosphorylation and inactivation of the caspase-9 and BAD proteins. AKT also phosphorylates and inactivates the forkhead transcription factor FKHRL1, leading to the inhibition of apoptosis through the upregulation of the survival gene products like manganese superoxide dismutase (MnSOD). AKT also phosphorylates and activates the mTOR (mammalian target of rapamcyin) kinase, leading to an increase in translation. AKT activation also leads to the phosphorylation and inactivation of GSK-3, a kinase that phosphorylates and regulates the phosphorylation of beta-catenin. Beta-catenin is a component of the Wnt signaling pathway that regulates cell proliferation and differentiation. The phosphorylation of beta-catenin by GSK-3 leads to its ubiquitination and degradation by the proteosome. The inhibition of GSK-3 by AKT leads to the accumulation of beta-catenin in the nucleus, where it forms complexes with the transcription factors of the TCF / LEF family to activate transcription of genes involved in cell survival and proliferation.

Blood coagulation is a series of reactions that leads to the formation of a clot at the site of injury. The clotting cascade can be divided into three phases: the extrinsic activation phase, the intrinsic activation phase and the clot formation phase. The extrinsic phase begins with damage to the vascular wall or exposure of blood to a foreign surface. This causes the release of tissue factor (TF), a membrane protein expressed on the surface of cells, which activates the clotting cascade by binding to factor VII and activating factor X. Once activated, factor X is rapidly converted to factor Xa, which cleaves prothrombin to thrombin. Thrombin cleaves fibrinogen to fibrin, which is the main component of the clot. The clot is then stabilized by factor XIII, which cross-links the fibrin monomers. The intrinsic activation phase is triggered by contact of blood with the vascular wall or with a foreign surface. This phase is activated by the intrinsic pathway, which is triggered by the presence of negatively charged phospholipids in the membrane of activated platelets. The intrinsic pathway is also activated by thrombin, which cleaves factor VIII and releases the activation peptide from factor VIIIa. Activated factor VIIIa binds to factor IXa to form the Xase complex, which activates factor X in the presence of calcium. The extrinsic and intrinsic pathways are closely linked and interact to form a balanced system. The clot formation phase is triggered by thrombin, which cleaves fibrinogen to fibrin. The fibrin monomers are cross-linked by factor XIII.

Sonic hedgehog (Shh) is a secreted signaling protein that plays a key role in development of the central nervous system and other tissues. In the developing cerebellum, Shh secreted by the Purkinje cells acts on the granule cell precursor (GCP) cells in the external granule layer (EGL) to stimulate their proliferation. In the absence of Shh, the GCP cells continue to proliferate and migrate into the internal granule layer (IGL). The proliferation of the GCP cells is regulated by Shh through the activation of the Shh receptor Patched (Ptc). Binding of Shh to Ptc relieves inhibition of the Shh receptor Smoothened (Smo), which in turn activates a signaling pathway that includes the transcription factor Gli. The downstream targets of Shh signaling include cyclin D and N-myc. The regulation of GCP proliferation by Shh is essential for proper development of the cerebellum. Shh signaling also plays a role in the proliferation of other cell types, including some types of cancer. Inhibition of Shh signaling may provide a strategy for the treatment of some cancers.

Insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) is a mitogen that stimulates proliferation of skeletal muscle cells. IGF-1 binds to its receptor, activating the receptor tyrosine kinase and initiating a signaling cascade that includes the ras / MAPK pathway and the PI3 kinase pathway. The ras / MAPK pathway is involved in the stimulation of proliferation by IGF-1, while the PI3 kinase pathway is involved in the stimulation of differentiation. The transcription factor NFAT is activated by IGF-1 and is involved in the stimulation of differentiation by IGF-1. The activity of NFAT is regulated by phosphorylation, with phosphorylation resulting in inhibition of NFAT activity. Protein phosphatase calcineurin dephosphorylates NFAT, activating it and allowing it to translocate into the nucleus and regulate gene expression. Calcineurin is activated by calcium and calmodulin, and is inhibited by the immunophilin FKBP1 2. Rapamycin inhibits the activation of NFAT by IGF-1, indicating that the activation of NFAT by IGF-1 is mediated by the PI3 kinase pathway. The inhibition of NFAT activation by rapamycin indicates that another target of the PI3 kinase pathway is involved in the activation of NFAT by IGF-1.

Rho family GTPases are molecular switches that cycle between GTP- and GDP-bound states. In their active GTP-bound state, Rho proteins interact with a variety of downstream effectors to regulate a variety of cellular processes including actin cytoskeletal organization, gene transcription, cell cycle progression, and membrane trafficking. Rho GTPases are activated by guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs) and are deactivated by GTPase activating proteins (GAPs). Guanine nucleotide dissociation inhibitors (GDIs) maintain Rho proteins in their inactive GDP-bound state. Guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs) activate Rho proteins by catalyzing the release of GDP and the binding of GTP. GAPs inactivate Rho proteins by stimulating their intrinsic GTPase activity, which promotes their dissociation from the membrane and their subsequent degradation in the cytosol. Guanine nucleotide dissociation inhibitors (GDIs) maintain Rho proteins in their inactive, membrane-associated state. Phosphatidylinositol-4, 5-bisphosphate (PIP2) is required for the dissociation of Rho from the GDI and for the subsequent activation of Rho by GEFs. Phosphatidylinositol-4-phosphate 5-kinase (PIP5K) is a Rho effector that phosphorylates PIP2 to generate phosphatidylinositol-4, 5-bisphosphate (PIP2). Rho effectors include the Rho-associated coiled-coil forming protein kinase (ROCK), the Diaphanous-related formins (Dia), and the protein kinase N (PKN). ROCK and Dia regulate the actin cytoskeleton and membrane blebbing, while PKN regulates gene transcription. Talin binds to the cytoplasmic domain of integrin and regulates cell adhesion. Talin also binds to vinculin, which also binds to actin and regulates cell adhesion. The interaction of these three proteins (Rho, Talin, and Vinculin) is required for the formation of focal adhesions. Talin binds to the cytoplasmic domain of integrin and activates signaling through Rho and ROCK. Vinculin binds to talin and also binds to actin, bringing them together to form a complex that regulates cell adhesion.

The HTLV-1 virus causes adult T-cell leukemia (ATL), an aggressive CD4 + T-cell malignancy. The viral protein Tax plays a central role in cellular transformation by HTLV-1. Tax interacts with a variety of cellular factors and alters their function. One of the most important of these is the p53 tumor suppressor protein. Tax interacts with p53 and increases its stability. Tax also increases the transcriptional activity of p53. The p53 protein is a transcription factor that can both activate and repress transcription. Tax interaction with p53 alters the cellular functions of p53. One of the genes activated by p53 is the gene for the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor, p15. Tax activation of p53 causes a G2 cell cycle arrest and a subsequent increase in apoptosis. Another target of p53 is the gene for the tumor suppressor gene p16. Tax activation of p53 also represses the expression of the Fas cell surface receptor. Tax activation of p53 also activates NFkB, a transcription factor that plays a key role in inflammation and immune responses. Tax activation of NFkB causes resistance to apoptosis induced by TNF.

Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) and Natural Killer (NK) cells are part of the immune system and play a key role in the defense against viral infections and tumor cells. CTLs and NK cells release perforin and granzyme proteins into the target cell to induce apoptosis. Perforin forms pores in the cell membrane allowing the granzyme proteins to enter the cell and activate caspases and nucleases. The caspases and nucleases cleave cellular components, leading to the breakdown of the cell and the death of the cell. The granzyme proteins are a family of proteases that enter the cell through the perforin pore and activate caspases and nucleases. The caspases are a class of cysteine proteases that are activated during apoptosis and cleave cellular targets to induce cell death. The caspases include caspase-1 (also known as IL-1beta convertase), caspase-2, caspase-3, caspase-4, caspase-5, caspase-6, and caspase-8 (also known as FLICE). The granzyme proteases activate caspases directly or indirectly. The caspases cleave and activate other caspases to amplify the apoptotic signal. The nucleases involved in apoptosis include DNA fragmentation factor (DFF) and endonuclease G (EndoG). DFF is activated by caspase-3 and caspase-7 and translocates to the nucleus to induce DNA fragmentation. EndoG is a nuclease that is released from the mitochondria during apoptosis and translocates to the nucleus to induce DNA fragmentation.

Taste perception is mediated by taste receptors, which are expressed on the apical surface of taste cells. Five distinct families of taste receptors have been identified: T1R (umami), T2R (bitter), T4R (sweet), T6P (amino acids), and T6S (sour). Each of these families is represented by a large number of genes. Each family of receptors has a distinct structure and mechanism of activation. The T1R family is composed of metabotropic receptors, which are coupled to G proteins. The T1R family is composed of two subunits, T1R1 and T1R2, which form a heterodimer. T1R1 has been suggested to be the umami taste receptor, while T1R2 is involved in umami and sweet tasting. The T2R family is composed of metabotropic receptors, which are coupled to gustducin. The T2R family is composed of bitter taste receptors, which are divided into two subfamilies, TAS1R and TAS2R. The T2R family of receptors is also divided into two subfamilies, TAS1Rs and TAS2Rs. The T2R family of receptors is coupled to gustducin, while the T1R family is coupled to the G protein gustducin. The T4R family is composed of receptors for amino acids. The T6P family is composed of receptors for amino acids and is coupled to the G protein subunit GNAT3. The T6S family is composed of a receptor for protons.

The calcium / calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II (CaM KII) is a multifunctional protein kinase that is expressed in all eukaryotic cells. It is activated by calcium and calmodulin. CaM KII is involved in a variety of cellular functions including learning and memory, muscle contraction, and gene expression. CaM KII is a tetramer composed of two subunits, each containing a catalytic domain, a regulatory domain, and a calmodulin binding domain. The CaM KII holoenzyme is inactive in the absence of calcium and calmodulin. Calcium binding to calmodulin causes a conformational change in the enzyme, releasing the catalytic and regulatory domains to interact and phosphorylate substrates. CaM KII is autophosphorylated at three sites in the regulatory domain, which increases the activity of the kinase. The autophosphorylation of CaM KII is a calcium-dependent process. Autophosphorylation of CaM KII at the Thr-3 0 5 site causes a 1 0-fold increase in activity, while autophosphorylation at the CaM KII sites in the alpha and beta subunits causes a further 2-3-fold increase in activity. The autophosphorylation of CaM KII at Thr-3 0 5 is reversed by a protein phosphatase, calcineurin. The CaM KII alpha subunit is the predominant isoform in the brain. A closely related kinase, CaM KIV, is also regulated by calcium and calmodulin. CaM KIV is activated by the protein kinase CaMK-2, which is activated by CaM KII. CaM KIV is involved in the regulation of gene expression by calcium.

The small G-protein RhoA is a molecular switch that regulates a variety of cellular functions, including cytoskeletal structure, gene expression, cell cycle progression, and membrane trafficking. RhoA is activated by guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs), which stimulate the release of GDP and its replacement with GTP. The intrinsic GTPase activity of RhoA is stimulated by GAPs, which increase the rate of GTP hydrolysis. The downstream effectors of RhoA are serine / threonine kinases, including PKN, Rho-kinase, and mDia1, and the transcription factor serum response factor (SRF). RhoA regulates SRF through the p0 0 7 1 family of transcriptional cofactors. The p0 0 7 1 family members are transcriptional coactivators that interact with the MADS-box transcription factors serum response factor (SRF) and MEF2A. The transcriptional activity of p0 0 7 1 is regulated by phosphorylation. RhoA activates PKN, which phosphorylates p0 0 7 1 and induces its dissociation from SRF. PKN also phosphorylates and activates the transcriptional cofactor MAL, which translocates to the nucleus and activates SRF and MEF2A. The p0 0 7 1 family members include p0 0 1, p0 0 3, and p0 0 2. The transcriptional activity of p0 0 7 1 is inhibited by its interaction with the promyelocytic leukemia (PML) tumor suppressor. The interaction of p0 0 7 1 with PML is disrupted by phosphorylation of p0 0 7 1 by PKN. The p0 0 7 1-PML interaction is also disrupted by phosphorylation of p0 0 7 1 by the MAPK pathway. The interaction of p0 0 7 1 with PML is required for the localization of p0 0 7 1 to nuclear bodies. The p0 0 7 1-PML interaction is disrupted by phosphorylation of p0 0 7 1 by the MAPK pathway. The interaction of p0 0 7 1 with PML is also disrupted by phosphorylation of PML by the p38 stress-activated protein kinase (SAPK). The p38 SAPK is activated by stress signals, including osmotic shock, UV irradiation, and inflammatory cytokines. The disruption of the p0 0 7 1-PML interaction by phosphorylation of p0 0 7 1 and PML by p38 SAPK may allow p0 0 7 1 to activate SRF and MEF2A in response to stress signals.

The ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporters are a large superfamily of membrane proteins that actively transport a wide variety of substrates across extra- and intra-cellular membranes using the energy of ATP hydrolysis. The human genome contains 4 8 genes that encode ABC transporters, which are classified into seven subfamilies (A-G) on the basis of their sequence similarities and phylogenetic relationships. The human erythrocyte membrane contains two major ABC transporters, the multidrug resistance protein (MRP) and the band 3 protein (AE1, SLC4A1). The MRP is encoded by the ABCC1 gene and is responsible for the transport of a broad spectrum of organic anions, including conjugated metabolites, GSH conjugates, and drugs and toxins. The band 3 protein is encoded by the SLC4A1 gene and is the major anion exchanger in erythrocytes. The structure of the band 3 protein is shown in Fig. 1. The structure of the MRP is shown in Fig. 2. The MRP is a multi-specific transporter that transports a broad spectrum of anionic compounds, including anionic drugs, toxins, and carcinogens, out of cells. The structure of the band 3 protein is shown in Fig. 3.

The cell cycle is a highly coordinated sequence of events that results in the replication and segregation of chromosomes. The G1 phase of the cell cycle is the growth phase in which cells prepare for DNA replication. The restriction point controls the transition from G1 to S phase. The G1 to S phase transition is regulated by the interplay of several proteins, including the cyclins, cyclin-dependent kinases (cdks), and cdk inhibitors. The cyclins are regulatory subunits of the cdks, and the cdks are a family of serine-threonine kinases. The cyclins are expressed in a cell cycle dependent manner and activate the cdks at specific times in the cell cycle. The cdk inhibitors oppose the action of the cyclins and cdks to regulate the cell cycle. The cdk inhibitors include p16INK4a, p15INK4b, p15INK4c, and p27KIP1. The p16INK4a gene is a tumor suppressor gene that is frequently mutated in human cancer. The cdk inhibitors oppose the action of the cyclins and cdks to regulate the cell cycle. The cdk inhibitors are expressed in a cell cycle dependent manner and inhibit the transition from G1 to S phase. The cdk-cyclin complexes phosphorylate the tumor suppressor Rb, releasing the transcription factor E2F. E2F activates genes involved in DNA synthesis. The TGF-beta signaling pathway also regulates the G1 to S phase transition. The TGF-beta receptor phosphorylates and activates smad 2 and 3, which form a complex with E2F and p53 to repress transcription of genes involved in DNA synthesis.

The Raf / Mek / Erk kinase cascade is a key mediator of growth factor signaling. Growth factor receptors activate the small G protein Ras, which recruits Raf to the membrane where it is activated by phosphorylation. Raf phosphorylates and activates Mek1, which in turn phosphorylates and activates Erk1 and Erk2. Erk1 and Erk2 phosphorylate transcription factors such as ELK-1 and fos, which regulate genes involved in cell proliferation. The p38 Map kinase cascade is also activated by growth factors and is involved in cell survival and proliferation. Mek1 and Mek2 are activated by the small G protein Raf1, which is activated by growth factor receptors and by the small G protein Rac. Mek1 and Mek2 phosphorylate and activate Erk1 and Erk2, which phosphorylate transcription factors such as ELK-1 and fos. The p38 Map kinase cascade is also involved in cell survival and proliferation. The importance of this pathway in cellular responses to growth factors has been demonstrated by the finding that mice lacking Mek1 are embryonic lethal and that mice lacking Erk1 or Erk2 die at mid-gestation. The Raf / Mek / Erk cascade is also involved in cellular responses to cytokines. The Jak / Stat pathway is activated by cytokines such as IL-2 and activates genes involved in cell survival and proliferation. The Stat proteins are phosphorylated by Jak kinases, which are activated by cytokine receptors. The Map kinase pathway is also involved in cellular responses to cytokines. The p38 Map kinase cascade is activated by the IL-2 receptor and activates transcription factors such as NF-AT and AP-1.

TNF is a potent inflammatory cytokine that induces the expression of adhesion molecules and the production of cytokines, chemokines and other inflammatory mediators. The biological effects of TNF are mediated by two receptors, TNFR1 and TNFR2. TNFR1 is expressed on most cells and mediates the cytotoxic and apoptotic effects of TNF. TNFR2 is primarily expressed on cells of the hematopoietic lineage and mediates the inflammatory and immunoregulatory effects of TNF. Binding of TNF to TNFR1 or TNFR2 induces the recruitment of TRADD, TRAF2, RIP and the TAK1 / TAB1 kinase complex to the receptor. The E3 ubiquitin ligase activity of RIP is required for TNF-induced NF-kB activation. The TAK1 / TAB1 kinase complex phosphorylates and activates the IKK complex, which phosphorylates the NF-kB inhibitor IkB and leads to its degradation. NF-kB is then free to translocate into the nucleus and activate transcription of target genes.

The mu opioid receptor (MOP-r) is a GPCR that is activated by the endogenous peptide ligand, enkephalins, and the synthetic opiate drugs morphine and fentanyl. The MOP-r is widely expressed in the nervous system and is involved in the regulation of pain, reward, and respiration. The receptor is a member of the rhodopsin-like GPCR family and couples to the Gi / o family of G proteins. The receptor is rapidly desensitized and down-regulated following activation by agonist. The receptor is phosphorylated by GPCR kinases (GRKs), which recruit beta-arrestins to the receptor, uncoupling the receptor from G protein and targeting it for internalization. The receptor is then dephosphorylated by an as yet unidentified phosphatase and is targeted to clathrin-coated pits for internalization. The receptor is then either recycled to the cell surface or targeted for degradation. The receptor is also regulated by other signaling pathways. The receptor is phosphorylated by protein kinase A (PKA) and protein kinase C (PKC), and activation of these kinases desensitizes the receptor. The receptor is also regulated by other GPCRs. The delta opioid receptor (DOP-r) is activated by the endogenous peptide ligand, deltorphin, and is also regulated by the MOP-r. The kappa opioid receptor (KOP-r) is activated by the endogenous peptide ligand, dynorphin, and is also regulated by the MOP-r. The regulation of the MOP-r by other GPCRs may be important in the development of tolerance to opiate drugs. The DOP-r is also regulated by the KOP-r, and the activation of the KOP-r may contribute to the development of tolerance to opiates.

The zona pellucida (ZP) is a glycoprotein matrix surrounding the oocyte that is required for sperm to bind to the egg and undergo the acrosome reaction. The mouse egg contains three major glycoproteins (ZP1, ZP2, and ZP3) that form the zona pellucida. The genes for these proteins are closely linked on mouse chromosome 1E2. The ZP1 and ZP2 genes are separated by 1kb and the ZP3 gene is 1kb downstream of the ZP2 gene. The ZP3 gene is alternatively spliced to produce two different forms of ZP3, a secreted form and a membrane-bound form. The secreted form of ZP3 is the sperm receptor that triggers the acrosome reaction. The membrane-bound form of ZP3 is involved in egg-sperm adhesion. The mouse ZP3 gene is expressed in growing oocytes and its expression is regulated by the transcription factor Obox. The Obox binding site is also the binding site for the transcription factor Foxl2. Foxl2 is also expressed in growing oocytes and is required for ZP3 expression. The ZP3 gene is also activated by the transcription factors Nobox and Bmp1 5. The protein kinase C (PKC) pathway is involved in the regulation of ZP3 expression. The PKC activator PMA increases ZP3 expression, while the PKC inhibitor calphostin C reduces ZP3 expression. The PKC pathway also regulates the expression of other oocyte-specific genes. The transcription factor Nobox activates ZP3 expression, while Bmp1 5 represses ZP3 expression. The transcription factor AP-1 is involved in the regulation of other oocyte-specific genes. The AP-1 family member c-Fos represses ZP3 expression, while c-Jun activates ZP3 expression. The transcription factor Bmp1 5 also activates ZP3 expression. The PKC pathway may regulate the activity of AP-1.

The AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) is a heterotrimeric enzyme complex that is highly conserved from yeast to man. It is activated by increases in the ratio of AMP to ATP within the cell, and so acts as an intracellular monitor of energy status. It is also activated by phosphorylation by an upstream kinase, which in mammals is a complex of three subunits, each of which is a member of a gene family. The AMPK kinase complex is activated by phosphorylation of a single threonine residue (Thr1 7 2 in the rat alpha2 subunit) within the catalytic subunit by an upstream kinase, which has been identified as a member of the protein kinase gene family, LKB1. Once activated, AMPK phosphorylates and regulates several metabolic enzymes to increase glucose uptake and lipid oxidation, while switching off biosynthetic pathways, such as lipid and protein synthesis. Other effects of AMPK include inhibition of cholesterol synthesis and stimulation of insulin secretion by pancreatic beta-cells.

TNF is a cytokine that induces apoptosis in some cells. The cytotoxic effects of TNF are mediated by two receptors, TNFR1 and TNFR2. Binding of TNF to TNFR1 leads to the activation of NF-kB and apoptosis. Binding of TNF to TNFR2 does not activate NF-kB but can activate apoptosis. The cytotoxic effects of TNF are mediated by the activation of caspases. TNF can also activate the ASK1 kinase to activate the JNK kinase pathway and apoptosis. TNF can also activate the neutral sphingomyelinase to generate ceramide, which can activate apoptosis. TNF can activate the ASK1 kinase to activate the JNK kinase pathway and apoptosis. TNF can also activate the mitochondrial apoptotic pathway through the induction of reactive oxygen species.

Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the second leading cause of cancer death in the United States. The majority of colorectal cancers (CRCs) arise from benign adenomatous polyps through the accumulation of mutations in a variety of genes. Mutations in the APC gene occur early in tumor development and are found in the vast majority of colorectal adenomas and carcinomas. APC is a multifunctional protein that regulates cell proliferation and apoptosis through its interaction with beta-catenin, a key mediator of Wnt signaling. Mutations in the APC gene also result in stabilization of beta-catenin, which leads to constitutive activation of the beta-catenin / T-cell factor (TCF) pathway.
