Mutations in the K-ras gene occur early in tumor development and are found in approximately 5 0% of colorectal cancers. The transforming activity of mutant K-ras is mediated through multiple effectors, including the Raf / MEK / ERK kinase cascade and the PI3K / AKT pathway. Mutations in the p53 gene are late events in colorectal tumorigenesis and are found in approximately 3 0% of colorectal cancers. The p53 gene product transcriptionally activates genes that induce cell cycle arrest and apoptosis, such as p16 and BTG.

The Rho family of GTPases (RhoA, Rac1, and Cdc4 2) are molecular switches that cycle between an inactive GDP-bound state and an active GTP-bound state. In their inactive state, GTPases are bound to GDP and are sequestered in the cytosol by guanine-nucleotide-dissociation inhibitors (GDIs). Activation occurs when extracellular signals lead to the dissociation of the GTPase-GDI complex, membrane localization of the GTPase, and interaction with a specific set of downstream effectors. The downstream effectors transduce the signal to regulate cytoskeletal structure, gene transcription, and other cellular processes. The activity of Rho GTPases is regulated by a variety of factors, including guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs), GTPase-activating proteins (GAPs), and guanine nucleotide-dissociation inhibitors (GDIs). GEFs activate Rho proteins by facilitating the exchange of GDP for GTP, GAPs inactivate Rho proteins by stimulating their intrinsic GTPase activity, and GDIs inhibit the exchange of GDP for GTP and keep Rho proteins in their inactive state in the cytosol. The Dbl family of GEFs is characterized by the presence of a conserved Dbl homology (DH) domain and a less-conserved pleckstrin homology (PH) domain. The DH domain is responsible for the GEF activity, and the PH domain may regulate the activity of the DH domain or may serve as a membrane-targeting module. The Dbl family includes several members that are specific for RhoA (Lbc, Lfc, Net1, and Net2), several that are specific for Rac1 (Tiam1, Vav1, and Vav3), and several that act on both RhoA and Rac1 (Dbl, Trio, and Kalirin). The Dbl family GEFs are regulated by a variety of mechanisms, including the presence of upstream activators, interaction with other proteins, and phosphorylation. The Dbl family GEFs are also negatively regulated by several factors, including RhoGDIs, and the RhoGAP proteins. The downstream effectors of Rho GTPases include several kinases, such as the p145 and p21 isoforms of the 38-kDa subunit of the initiation factor complex, p160 of the Arp2 / 3 complex, and Rho-associated coiled-coil containing protein kinase (ROCK). The p145 and p21 subunits of the initiation factor complex bind to the active form of Rho GTPases and stimulate their interaction with downstream effectors. The p160 of the Arp2 / 3 complex binds to the inactive form of Rho and is released when the GTPases are activated. ROCK is a serine / threonine kinase that phosphorylates several targets, including myosin light chain kinase (MLCK) and LIM kinase. The phosphorylation of myosin light chain by MLCK increases myosin-based contractility, while the phosphorylation of LIM kinase by ROCK inhibits the activity of cofilin, a protein that severs actin filaments and promotes their polymerization. Cofilin promotes actin depolymerization by increasing the availability of monomers for polymerization. The balance between actin polymerization and depolymerization is critical for many cellular processes, including cell motility, cytokinesis, and cell adhesion.

DNA damage checkpoints are signaling pathways that respond to DNA damage to halt cell cycle progression and allow time for DNA repair to occur. The ATM protein kinase is a key component of the DNA damage checkpoint pathway that responds to double-strand breaks in DNA. ATM phosphorylates downstream targets including the checkpoint kinase chk1 and the tumor suppressor p53. The checkpoint function of ATM is important for maintaining genomic stability and preventing cancer. The ATR kinase also plays a key role in the DNA damage checkpoint pathway. ATR is activated by single-stranded DNA that arises from DNA damage or during DNA replication. ATR phosphorylates chk1 and p53 in response to DNA damage and is required for the G2 / M checkpoint. The ATR-dependent phosphorylation of chk1 and p53 is required for the G2 / M checkpoint. The ATR-dependent phosphorylation of chk1 and p53 is also required for the intra-S phase checkpoint in response to DNA damage. The ATR-dependent phosphorylation of chk1 and p53 is also required for resistance to DNA damaging agents such as ionizing radiation. The checkpoint function of ATR is important for maintaining genomic stability and preventing cancer. The ATR-dependent phosphorylation of chk1 and p53 is also required for resistance to DNA damaging agents such as ionizing radiation. The ATR-dependent phosphorylation of chk1 and p53 is also required for resistance to DNA damaging agents such as mitomycin C and cisplatin. The ATR-dependent phosphorylation of chk1 and p53 is also required for resistance to DNA crosslinking agents such as mitomycin C and cisplatin. The ATR-dependent phosphorylation of chk1 and p53 is also required for resistance to DNA methylating agents such as N-methyl-N-nitro-N-nitrosoguanidine (MNNG) and methyl methanesulfonate (MMS). ATR is also required for resistance to ultraviolet light (UV). ATR is mutated in the cancer-prone disorder, Seckel syndrome. Cells from patients with Seckel syndrome are sensitive to DNA damaging agents, including ionizing radiation, mitomycin C, cisplatin, MNNG and UV. The sensitivity of Seckel cells to DNA damaging agents may be caused by the role of ATR in maintaining genomic stability. The breast cancer susceptibility gene BRCA1 is also required for resistance to DNA damaging agents. BRCA1 is required for the ATR-dependent phosphorylation of chk1 and p53 in response to DNA damage. The phosphorylation of chk1 and p53 by ATR is required for resistance to DNA damaging agents. The breast cancer susceptibility gene BRCA2 is also required for resistance to DNA damaging agents. BRCA2 interacts with chk1 and p53 in response to DNA damage. The interaction of BRCA2 with chk1 and p53 may be required for resistance to DNA damaging agents.

Angiogenesis, the formation of new blood vessels from the pre-existing vasculature, is a complex, multi-step process that is essential for both the development and the repair of tissues. It is also a key factor in a number of pathological conditions including cancer, arthritis, and psoriasis. The process of angiogenesis is regulated by a balance of angiogenic and anti-angiogenic factors. The balance is altered in favor of angiogenesis in the presence of a tumor. The angiogenic switch is activated by a variety of factors, including growth factors such as vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), fibroblast growth factor (FGF), epidermal growth factor (EGF), platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF), hypoxia, and inflammatory cytokines. These factors activate several signaling pathways that converge on the transcription factor hypoxia-inducible factor-1 (HIF-1). HIF-1 is a master regulator of angiogenesis that induces the expression of a number of genes involved in angiogenesis and vascular permeability. These genes include VEGF, FGF, PDGF, and ET-1. These factors stimulate endothelial cell proliferation, migration, and vascular permeability. The activation of endothelial cells also leads to the expression of adhesion molecules and extracellular matrix proteases, which are required for the invasion and migration of endothelial cells. The formation of new blood vessels allows the tumor to grow beyond a few millimeters in diameter without a vascular supply. The inhibition of angiogenesis has been shown to be an effective strategy for the treatment of cancer.

Peroxisomes are essential for the metabolism of a wide variety of substrates, including fatty acids, fatty alcohols, and fatty acid derivatives. The oxidation of fatty acids is the most important function of peroxisomes. The first step of fatty acid oxidation is the conversion of acyl-CoA to acyl-carnitine by carnitine O-octanoyltransferase (COT). Acyl-carnitine is then transported to the mitochondria for beta-oxidation. Peroxisomes are also involved in the biosynthesis of ether phospholipids, which are essential for the function of human lungs, heart, and blood clotting. The biosynthesis of ether phospholipids is initiated by the conversion of dihydroxyacetonephosphate to alkylglycerol phosphate by dihydroxyacetonephosphate acyltransferase (DHAPAT). The next steps are the conversion of alkylglycerol phosphate to plasmenylethanolamine by ethanolamine phosphotransferase (EPT) and the conversion of plasmenylethanolamine to ethanolamine phosphate by vinyl ether transferase (VCT). The final product, platelet-activating factor, is then released from the membrane and plays an important role in blood clotting.

Insulin binding to its receptor activates the receptor tyrosine kinase and leads to the activation of two major signaling pathways: the PI 3-kinase pathway and the MAPK pathway. The PI 3-kinase pathway leads to the activation of protein kinase B (also known as AKT) and its downstream effectors, including the mTOR (also known as RAFT or FRAP) pathway. The mTOR pathway regulates protein translation by phosphorylating the initiation factor 4E-BP1 and the ribosomal protein S6 kinase. The MAPK pathway leads to the activation of the ternary complex factor (TCF) and ELK-1. The TCF / ELK-1 pathway regulates genes involved in cell growth and proliferation.

Krebs cycle or citric acid cycle is a series of eight reactions that takes place in the mitochondria and results in the production of NADH and FADH2 that are used in the electron transport chain to produce energy in the form of a high-energy phosphate bond. The Krebs cycle is also a major source of carbon skeletons for the biosynthesis of amino acids, fatty acids, and other important metabolites. The cycle begins with the carboxylation of pyruvate to form oxaloacetate. This reaction is catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase. The next four reactions of the cycle are the condensation of two molecules of acetyl-CoA to form citrate. This reaction is catalyzed by citrate synthase. The next four reactions are the same as those in the first reaction of the glyoxylate cycle. The fifth reaction of the Krebs cycle is the oxidative decarboxylation of citrate to produce alpha-ketoglutarate. This reaction is catalyzed by isocitrate dehydrogenase. The sixth reaction of the Krebs cycle is the condensation of two molecules of alpha-ketoglutarate to form succinyl-CoA. This reaction is catalyzed by alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. The last reaction of the Krebs cycle is the oxidative decarboxylation of succinyl-CoA to form fumarate and CO2. This reaction is catalyzed by fumarate hydratase. The electrons from the Krebs cycle are transferred to the electron transport chain to produce energy in the form of a high-energy phosphate bond. The transfer of electrons from the Krebs cycle to the electron transport chain occurs via a series of redox reactions. The first reaction of the Krebs cycle is the oxidative decarboxylation of isocitrate to form alpha-ketoglutarate. This reaction is catalyzed by isocitrate dehydrogenase. The next reactions of the cycle are the transfer of electrons to form NADH and FADH2. NADH is used in the electron transport chain to produce energy in the form of a high-energy phosphate bond. FADH2 is also an important electron carrier in the electron transport chain. The transfer of electrons from the Krebs cycle to the electron transport chain is accomplished by a series of redox reactions. The transfer of electrons from succinate to the electron transport chain is accomplished by the oxidation of succinate to fumarate. This reaction is catalyzed by fumarate reductase. The transfer of electrons from the electron transport chain to the Krebs cycle is accomplished by succinate dehydrogenase. The transfer of electrons from the Krebs cycle to oxygen is accomplished by the cytochrome pathway. The transfer of electrons from oxygen to the electron transport chain is accomplished by the terminal oxidase of the electron transport chain. The transfer of electrons from the electron transport chain to oxygen is catalyzed by cytochrome c oxidase. The transfer of electrons from oxygen to the Krebs cycle is catalyzed by succinate-CoA ligase. The transfer of electrons from the Krebs cycle to the electron transport chain is catalyzed by alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. The transfer of electrons from the electron transport chain to oxygen is catalyzed by cytochrome oxidase.

The T cell receptor (TCR) is a multimeric complex composed of alpha and beta chains noncovalently associated with the CD3 complex. The CD28 protein is a member of the immunoglobulin gene superfamily and is expressed on the surface of activated T cells. CD28 is a costimulatory molecule that is required for full T cell activation. CD28 is a ligand for CD80 and CD86. CD80 is expressed on the surface of B cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells. CD86 is expressed on the surface of macrophages, dendritic cells, and activated B cells. CD86 is also expressed on activated B cells. CD80 and CD86 are members of the immunoglobulin gene superfamily and share 4 0% amino acid identity. The CD80 and CD86 proteins are non-covalently associated with the Ig-like domains 1 and 2 of the CD28 protein. The CD28 protein is required for efficient T cell activation. The CD86 protein is required for the development of a normal intestinal intraepithelial lymphocyte (IEL) population.

S-Adenosylmethionine (SAM) is the methyl group donor for most biological methylations. The methyl group is transferred from SAM to the -nitrogen of a substrate to form S-adenosylhomocysteine (SAH). SAH is then hydrolyzed to homocysteine and adenosine by the enzyme SAH hydrolase. Homocysteine is either remethylated to methionine or reduced to cysteine, which is used to synthesize glutathione. DNA, RNA, proteins, and lipids are modified by methylation. DNA methylation is an important mechanism for regulating gene expression. Proteins can be modified by methylation of their lysine or arginine residues. Cysteine is the limiting amino acid in food. Cysteine is synthesized from serine by the enzyme serine transhydroxymethylase (SHMT). Cysteine is also derived from methionine. Methionine synthase transfers a methyl group from 5-methyltetrahydrofolate (CH3-THF) to homocysteine to regenerate methionine. Methionine synthase is an important methyl group donor in remethylation of homocysteine to methionine. The remethylation of homocysteine to methionine is an important process to maintain a constant level of methionine in cells. DNA methylation is an important mechanism for regulating gene expression.

Interleukin-6 (IL-6) is a cytokine that signals through a receptor complex that includes the alpha chain gp8 0 and the beta chain gp1 3 0. IL-6 activates several signaling pathways including the Jak / Stat pathway, the Map kinase pathway and the PI3 kinase pathway. The Jak / Stat pathway is activated by phosphorylation of Stat3 and Stat5 by the Jak kinases in response to IL-6. The Map kinase pathway is activated by phosphorylation of Shc and activation of the Erks. The PI3 kinase pathway is activated by phosphorylation of Akt by the PI3 kinase. The activation of these pathways by IL-6 contributes to the anti-apoptotic activity of IL-6 and also contributes to the proliferative activity of IL-6.

The central nervous system (CNS) is separated from the rest of the body by the blood-brain barrier (BBB), a specialized endothelial cell-cell tight junction (TJ) structure that restricts the free movement of solutes and macromolecules between the circulating blood and the brain. The presence of TJs restricts the paracellular diffusion of solutes and restricts the movement of solutes between the circulating blood and the brain parenchyma. TJs are composed of a number of integral membrane proteins and associated proteins, such as occludins, claudins, and junctional adhesion molecules (JAMs). These integral membrane proteins and associated proteins form a complex network that seals the intercellular space. TJs are also involved in the regulation of cell polarity and cell signaling. Disruption of TJs is believed to be one of the initial steps in the pathogenesis of a number of CNS diseases, including brain edema, meningitis, and brain tumors.

Eukaryotic initiation factor 2 (eIF2) is a guanine nucleotide-binding protein that binds GTP and GDP and is required for the formation of a ternary complex with methionyl-tRNA and the initiation of translation. Phosphorylation of eIF2 at Ser5 1 by a variety of kinases inhibits the formation of the ternary complex and thus protein synthesis. The heme-regulated inhibitor (HRI), the double-stranded RNA-activated protein kinase (PKR), the general amino acid control kinase (GCN2), and the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) kinase (PERK) are all activated by different forms of stress and phosphorylate the alpha subunit of eIF2. The phosphorylation of eIF2 by PKR and PERK is involved in the cellular response to viral infection and the unfolded protein response, respectively. GCN2 is activated by amino acid deprivation and inhibits translation of mRNAs encoding amino acid biosynthetic enzymes. The HRI kinase is activated by heme deficiency and is involved in translational regulation by heme.

The adrenergic receptor / cAMP signaling pathway is a key regulator of cardiac function. Increased adrenergic signaling is a key component of heart failure. The downstream effects of cAMP signaling are mediated by the cAMP-dependent protein kinase A (PKA) and the exchange protein activated by cAMP (EPAC). EPAC is a guanine nucleotide exchange factor (GEF) for the small G protein Rap1. EPAC is activated by the second messenger cAMP and couples cAMP signaling to the regulation of Rap1. Rap1 is a member of the Ras family of small GTPases that regulates a variety of cellular processes including cell adhesion, migration, proliferation and differentiation. The EPAC / Rap1 pathway is involved in the regulation of cardiac hypertrophy. The EPAC / Rap1 pathway is also involved in the regulation of calcium channels and calcium handling in the heart. The EPAC / Rap1 pathway is also involved in the regulation of calcium handling in the heart through the sodium / calcium exchanger (NCX). Calcium handling is an important regulator of cardiac contractility and calcium handling is impaired in heart failure. The EPAC / Rap1 pathway is involved in the regulation of calcium handling in the heart through the regulation of NCX. The regulation of calcium handling by the EPAC / Rap1 pathway may be involved in the regulation of cardiac hypertrophy.

The innate immune response is triggered by the recognition of conserved molecular patterns associated with pathogens. Lipopolysaccharide (LPS), a component of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, is a potent activator of the innate immune response. LPS is recognized by Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4), which is expressed on the cell surface of immune cells and in the cytoplasm. LPS recognition by TLR4 initiates a signaling cascade that leads to the activation of NF-kB and the production of proinflammatory cytokines such as TNF and IL-1. The activation of NF-kB by LPS is mediated by the adaptor protein MyD8 8, which is also involved in signaling by IL-1 and IL-18. MyD8 8 interacts with IL-1R1 and IL-18R via the adaptor protein IRAK-1, which in turn interacts with TRAF6. TRAF6 activates the IKK complex, which phosphorylates I-kB, releasing NF-kB to translocate to the nucleus and activate transcription of inflammatory genes. The activation of NF-kB by LPS and IL-1 is negatively regulated by the I-kB kinase complex member RIP. The activation of NF-kB by LPS and IL-1 is also negatively regulated by the SOCS family of proteins, which are induced by these cytokines and which interact with the IL-1R1 and TLR4 signaling complexes to inhibit further activation of NF-kB and the production of inflammatory cytokines. The activation of NF-kB by LPS and IL-1 is also negatively regulated by the TNF receptor associated factor family member TRAF6. TRAF-6 interacts with RIP and activates NF-kB signaling, but also interacts with SOCS-1 to inhibit further activation of NF-kB and the production of inflammatory cytokines.

The insulin-like growth factor 1 receptor (IGF-1R) is a receptor tyrosine kinase that is structurally similar to the insulin receptor. It binds IGF-1 and IGF-2 and mediates the proliferative and metabolic actions of these growth factors. IGF-1R is widely expressed in many tissues and its expression is regulated by many factors. Binding of IGF-1 to IGF-1R activates several signaling pathways including ras / map kinase, PI 3-kinase and STAT5.

The chemokine receptor CXCR4 is expressed on cells of the hematopoietic system and is involved in the homing of hematopoietic stem cells to the bone marrow. CXCR4 is also expressed on many tumor cells, including breast, prostate, and brain tumors. The ligand for CXCR4 is SDF-1, also known as CXCL1 2. Binding of SDF-1 to CXCR4 activates a signaling pathway that includes activation of the MAPK pathway, calcium mobilization, and activation of the small G protein Rac. The activation of Rac is mediated by the guanine nucleotide exchange factor Vav1. The activation of Rac leads to the formation of membrane ruffles and lamellipodia, which are involved in cell motility. The activation of the MAPK pathway is mediated by the small G protein Rho, which activates the Rho-associated coiled-coil containing protein kinase (ROCK). The activation of the calcium pathway is mediated by phospholipase C, which is activated by the alpha subunit of Gq. The activation of the MAPK pathway and calcium signaling are required for SDF-1 induced cell migration. The activation of Rac and the resulting membrane ruffling and lamellipodia formation are required for cell polarization and directional migration. The activation of the MAPK pathway and calcium signaling are not required for cell polarization and directional migration, but are required for cell proliferation and cell survival.

The calcium / calmodulin-dependent protein kinases (CaMKs) are a family of serine / threonine kinases that are activated by calcium and calmodulin. CaMKI, II and IV are all activated by the CaMKK. CaMKK is activated by CaM kinase kinase (CaMKKK). The CaMKs regulate a variety of cellular processes including gene transcription, cell cycle progression, apoptosis, and neuronal function. The CaMKs are activated by a complex mechanism involving the binding of calcium and calmodulin, and the autophosphorylation of the kinases. The CaMKs are regulated by a variety of mechanisms including phosphorylation, CaM-kinase kinase (CaMKK), CaM-kinase phosphatase (CaMKP), and CaM-kinase inhibitor (CaMKI inhibitor). The CaMKs are also regulated by the binding of CaM-kinase kinase (CaMKKK) and CaM-kinase inhibitor (CKI). The CaMKs are regulated by a variety of mechanisms including the binding of CaM-kinase kinase (CaMKKK) and CaM-kinase inhibitor (CKI). The CaMKs are regulated by a variety of mechanisms including the binding of CaM-kinase kinase (CaMKKK) and CaM-kinase inhibitor (CKI). The CaMKs are regulated by a variety of mechanisms including the binding of CaM-kinase inhibitor (CKI) and CaM-kinase inhibitor (CKI). The CaMKs are regulated by a variety of mechanisms including the binding of CaM-kinase kinase (CaMKKK) and CaM-kinase inhibitor (CKI). The CaMKs are regulated by a variety of mechanisms including the binding of CaM-kinase inhibitor (CKI) and CaM-kinase inhibitor (CKI). The CaMKs are also regulated by CaM-kinase inhibitor (CKI) by a mechanism that does not involve the phosphorylation of the CaMKs.

Eosinophils are leukocytes that are part of the innate immune system. They respond to infection by parasites and secrete cytokines that cause inflammation. Eosinophils are also involved in some allergic reactions. Eosinophils express a cell-surface receptor called CD58 that binds to a protein called CD24 7. CD24 7 is expressed on the surface of activated T cells and binds to CD58 on eosinophils. The interaction of CD24 7 with CD58 activates the JAK / STAT signaling pathway in eosinophils, causing them to secrete cytokines that cause inflammation.

The complement system is a group of plasma proteins that are part of the immune system. The complement system is activated by three different pathways. The classical pathway is activated by antigen-antibody complexes, the alternative pathway is activated by bacterial infection, and the lectin pathway is activated by bacterial cell wall carbohydrates. Each of these pathways culminates in the formation of a C3 convertase that cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b. The C3a fragment is a potent anaphylatoxin that stimulates inflammation, and the C3b fragment is a key component of the C3 convertase that activates the complement membrane attack complex (MAC). The MAC causes osmotic lysis of cells and is also involved in opsonization of bacteria. The three pathways converge at the formation of the C3 convertase, which cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b. The alternative pathway is an amplification loop that is initiated by C3 convertase formation. The lectin pathway is activated by mannan binding lectin (MBL) or ficolins, which bind carbohydrates on the surface of bacteria. The binding of MBL or ficolins to bacteria activates the lectin pathway. The MBL-associated serine proteases (MASP) -1 and MASP-2 are part of the lectin pathway. MASP-1 is a protease that is part of the C1 complex of the classical complement pathway. MASP-2 is a protease that is part of the alternative complement pathway. Once activated, MASP-2 cleaves complement factors C2 and C4. The cleavage of C2 by MASP-2 forms the C3 convertase of the lectin pathway. The cleavage of C4 by MASP-2 forms the C4b2a convertase of the lectin pathway. The classical complement pathway is activated by antigen-antibody complexes. The antibody in the complex binds to C1q in the C1 complex. The binding of the antigen-antibody complex to C1q activates the C1 complex. The activation of the C1 complex cleaves C4 and C2, forming the C3 convertase of the classical complement pathway. The alternative complement pathway is initiated by spontaneous activation of C3 convertase. The C3 convertase cleaves additional C3 to amplify the alternative pathway.

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a common B cell malignancy in the Western hemisphere. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of small mature-appearing B cells in the bone marrow and lymphoid tissues. The disease is generally an indolent course, but some patients may progress to a more aggressive form of the disease. The etiology of CLL is unknown, but genetic factors appear to play a role in the development of the disease. The immunoglobulin heavy chain variable region (IgVH) gene mutational status is the most important prognostic factor in CLL. Patients with mutated IgVH genes have a more favorable prognosis than patients with unmutated IgVH genes. The expression of zeta-chain-associated protein kinase 7 0 (ZAP-7 0) is associated with unmutated IgVH genes and a poor prognosis. ZAP-7 0 is a tyrosine kinase that is expressed in T cells and in some B cells. ZAP-7 0 is involved in signal transduction downstream of the T cell receptor and the B cell receptor. The expression of ZAP-7 0 in B cells may contribute to the pathogenesis of CLL by interfering with normal B cell receptor signaling.

Interleukin 2 (IL-2) is a cytokine that stimulates the growth and differentiation of T cells. The IL-2 receptor is composed of three chains, alpha, beta and gamma. The IL-2 receptor is expressed on activated T cells and some T regulatory cells. Binding of IL-2 to its receptor activates the JAK / STAT pathway. JAK kinases are activated by the IL-2 receptor and phosphorylate STAT transcription factors. Phosphorylated STAT factors dimerize and translocate to the nucleus and activate transcription of target genes. The JAK / STAT pathway is negatively regulated by SOCS proteins. The PI3K / Akt pathway is also activated by the IL-2 receptor and contributes to T cell growth and survival.

Sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) is a sphingolipid metabolite that regulates diverse cellular functions including cell proliferation, survival, migration, and angiogenesis. S1P is produced by the phosphorylation of sphingosine by sphingosine kinase (SPHK). S1P is exported from cells and binds to five different G-protein coupled receptors (S1PR1-5). S1P has been implicated in a variety of disease processes including cancer, autoimmune disease, and heart disease. The S1PR1 receptor is involved in lymphocyte trafficking and lymphocyte homing to the spleen. The S1PR2 receptor is involved in the development of the heart and the regulation of vascular tone. The S1PR3 receptor is involved in platelet activation and inflammation. The S1PR4 receptor is involved in the inhibition of platelet aggregation and the inhibition of inflammatory cell migration. The S1PR5 receptor is involved in lymphocyte trafficking. The production of S1P is regulated by the enzyme neutral sphingomyelinase (N-SMase). N-SMase is activated by a variety of factors including tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha), Fas, and reactive oxygen species. N-SMase activation results in the production of ceramide and the activation of sphingosine kinase. S1P is degraded by the S1P phosphatases (Sgpp1 and Sgpp2) and by the S1P lyase. The S1P phosphatases hydrolyze S1P to sphingosine and the inorganic phosphate. The S1P lyase cleaves S1P to phosphoethanolamine and hexadecenal.

The transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) superfamily consists of multifunctional cytokines that include TGF-betas, bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) and growth and differentiation factors (GDFs). These factors regulate a broad spectrum of cellular processes including proliferation, differentiation, apoptosis, migration and angiogenesis. TGF-beta superfamily members signal through type II and type I serine / threonine kinase receptors. Type II receptors are constitutively associated with type I receptors and ligand binding to the type II receptor recruits type I receptors to form heterotetrameric complexes. Ligand binding to type II receptors results in the phosphorylation and activation of type I receptors by the type II receptor kinase. Activated type I receptors phosphorylate receptor-regulated SMADs (R-SMADs), including SMADs 1, 2, 3, 5 and 8. Phosphorylated R-SMADs associate with the co-SMAD, SMAD4, and the heteromeric complexes translocate to the nucleus, where they regulate transcription of target genes in association with other transcription factors and coactivators. Inhibitory SMADs (I-SMADs) such as SMAD7 act as negative regulators of signaling by preventing phosphorylation and activation of R-SMADs. TGF-beta signaling is negatively regulated by several inhibitory factors, including SMAD7.

The cell cycle is a tightly regulated series of events that leads to the duplication of cellular components and the division of cells. The G1 to S phase transition is a key regulatory checkpoint in the cell cycle. Cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) are a family of kinases that control the cell cycle. The CDKs are activated by association with cyclins and inhibited by CDK inhibitors. The activity of CDKs is regulated by phosphorylation and dephosphorylation and by association with CDK inhibitors. The E2F family of transcription factors regulates the expression of genes required for progression through the S phase and into the G2 phase of the cell cycle. The activity of E2F-1 is regulated by the cell cycle, by the tumor suppressor protein p53, and by the CDK inhibitors p16 and p19. The activity of p53 is regulated by p95, which binds to p53 and inhibits its transcriptional activity. The p53 tumor suppressor protein is a transcription factor that is activated by DNA damage. The p53 tumor suppressor induces growth arrest and apoptosis in response to DNA damage.

Serine is a non-essential amino acid derived from glycine. It is a component of several amino acids including methionine, cysteine, threonine, and tryptophan. Serine is synthesized from 3-phosphoglycerate by three different pathways in bacteria, plants, and animals. The phosphorylated pathway is found in bacteria, plants, and some protozoa. The glycine cleavage system is found in bacteria, plants, and animals. The third pathway is found in bacteria, plants, and animals.

The LPA1 receptor is coupled to Gi / o and inhibits adenylyl cyclase. The LPA2 receptor is coupled to Gq / 1 1 and activates the phospholipase C / protein kinase C pathway. The LPA3 receptor is coupled to G1 2 / 1 3 and activates the Rho / Rho-kinase pathway. The LPA4 receptor is coupled to Gs and activates adenylyl cyclase. The LPA5 receptor is coupled to Gs and inhibits adenylyl cyclase. The LPA6 receptor is coupled to Gi and inhibits adenylyl cyclase.

Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) are nuclear hormone receptors that are activated by fatty acids and their derivatives. PPAR subtypes alpha, gamma and delta are involved in lipid homeostasis and glucose metabolism. PPAR-alpha is activated by fatty acids and their metabolites and plays a key role in lipid oxidation in liver and skeletal muscle. PPAR-gamma is activated by thiazolidinedione (TZD) drugs and plays a key role in adipocyte differentiation and glucose homeostasis. PPAR-delta is involved in lipid oxidation in skeletal muscle. PPAR-gamma and PPAR-delta are also involved in the regulation of inflammation. The activation of PPAR-gamma by TZD drugs is responsible for the insulin-sensitizing effects of these drugs. The activation of PPAR-delta by fibrates is responsible for the lipid-lowering effects of these drugs.

Endocytosis is the process by which extracellular material and plasma membrane constituents are delivered to the lysosome for degradation. It is a fundamental mechanism for nutrient uptake and for the regulation of plasma membrane composition and receptor-mediated signalling. Endocytosis is also involved in the uptake of pathogens and toxins from the extracellular environment. Endocytosis can be subdivided into two major pathways: clathrin-dependent endocytosis (CDE) and clathrin-independent endocytosis (CIE). CDE is the best characterized pathway and is characterized by the formation of clathrin-coated pits, which pinch off from the plasma membrane to form clathrin-coated vesicles (CCVs). In contrast, the mechanisms of CIE are less well characterized. In addition to clathrin, CIE pathways include caveolae, GPI-anchored proteins, lipid rafts, and macropinocytosis.

The immune system is made up of a variety of cells, each with its own set of proteins called markers. T cells are a type of white blood cell that help other cells in the immune system defend against infection. They are activated when they receive a signal from a cell called the antigen-presenting cell (APC), which takes up and presents antigen on its surface and then presents it to other cells in the immune system. The APC then expresses a protein called CD4 0 ligand, which binds to a protein called CD4 on the T cell surface. This interaction activates the T cell, allowing it to respond to the antigen. The T cell also expresses a protein called CD80, which binds to a protein called CD8l to help it stay in the resting state. When the T cell is activated, it also expresses a protein called Fas ligand, which binds to a protein called Fas on the surface of other cells. This interaction triggers the cell to die, causing the other cells in the immune system to die as well. This process of cell death is called apoptosis.

The opioid receptors are members of the G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) gene family. The opioid receptors are activated by endogenous opioid peptides and are therapeutic targets for pain relief and treatment of addiction. The kappa opioid receptor (KOR) is activated by the endogenous peptide dynorphin, and is involved in analgesia, while the mu opioid receptor (MOR) is activated by the endogenous peptide enkephalin and is involved in the euphoric effects of opiates. The delta opioid receptor (DOR) is activated by the endogenous peptide enkephalin, and is involved in analgesia and the rewarding effects of drugs of abuse. The opioid receptors are coupled to G-proteins of the Gi / o family, and activation of the opioid receptors inhibits adenylyl cyclase and the cAMP response element (CRE) -mediated gene transcription. Gi / o-mediated inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and cAMP formation leads to activation of the protein kinase A (PKA) pathway and the subsequent activation of the transcription factor CREB. The activation of CREB by the opioid receptors may be involved in the development of tolerance to the analgesic effects of opioids. The opioid receptors are also coupled to G-proteins of the Gq / 1 1 family, and activation of these G-proteins leads to the activation of the MAP kinase pathway and the serum response factor (SRF). The activation of SRF by the opioid receptors may be involved in the regulation of genes involved in neuronal development and differentiation.

The forkhead family of transcription factors are involved in the regulation of a variety of cellular processes including cell cycle progression, apoptosis, oxidative stress, and metabolism. FKHR-L1 is a member of the forkhead family that is regulated by AKT. AKT phosphorylates FKHR-L1 at three conserved residues, resulting in cytoplasmic retention and inhibition of FKHR-L1 transcriptional activity. Growth factors activate AKT, which phosphorylates FKHR-L1, resulting in its inactivation and allowing for the transcriptional activation of genes involved in cell cycle progression and cell survival.

Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death that is characterized by a number of morphological changes, including cell shrinkage, chromatin condensation, membrane blebbing, and the formation of apoptotic bodies. The morphological changes are caused by a family of cysteine proteases called caspases that are activated by apoptotic stimuli. Caspases are synthesized as inactive proenzymes that are activated by proteolytic cleavage. Caspase activation can be induced by two different pathways. The extrinsic pathway is triggered by the binding of death receptors on the cell surface, such as Fas, to their ligands. The binding of Fas ligand to Fas-receptor recruits the adapter protein FADD and the initiator caspase-8. The activated caspase-8 then activates caspase-3 and other caspases, leading to apoptosis. The intrinsic pathway is triggered by cellular stress, such as DNA damage, and is mediated by mitochondria. The release of cytochrome c from mitochondria into the cytosol triggers the formation of a caspase-activating complex called the apoptosome. The apoptosome activates caspase-9, which activates caspase-3. Caspase-3 cleaves cellular proteins, including the DNA repair enzyme PARP, that are important for maintaining cellular structure and function.

The immune system is comprised of a variety of cells that communicate with one another through secreted cytokines and other signaling molecules. The immune system is constantly responding to the presence of foreign pathogens through the activation of innate immune cells and the subsequent production of inflammatory cytokines. The adaptive immune response is initiated by the recognition of foreign antigens by B cells and T cells, which proliferate and differentiate to produce antigen-specific effector cells. The activation of innate immune cells and the differentiation of antigen-specific effector cells are regulated by a variety of cytokines. Macrophages and other innate immune cells respond to a variety of stimuli, including lipopolysaccharide (LPS) from Gram-negative bacteria, extracellular parasites, and fungi, and produce inflammatory cytokines such as IL-12, IL-6, and TNF-alpha. Macrophages also produce IL-18, a chemokine that recruits and activates NK cells and T cells. B cells and T cells respond to a variety of stimuli, including antigen, T cell costimulatory signals, and cytokines, to differentiate into antigen-specific effector cells. T helper cells differentiate into Th1 cells that produce the cytokines IL-2, IFN-gamma, and TNF-alpha, or Th2 cells that produce IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, and IL-10. Th1 cells are involved in cellular immunity and activate macrophages and other cells to fight intracellular pathogens, while Th2 cells are involved in humoral immunity and allergies. The differentiation of Th1 and Th2 cells is regulated by the cytokines IL-12 and IL-4, respectively. IL-12 induces Th1 differentiation and the production of IFN-gamma and TNF-alpha, while IL-4 induces Th2 differentiation and the production of IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, and IL-10. The differentiation of Th1 and Th2 cells is also regulated by the cytokines IL-18 and IL-18 receptor. IL-18 induces Th1 differentiation and the production of IFN-gamma by activating the transcription factor STAT4. IL-18 also induces the production of IL-10, an anti-inflammatory cytokine that inhibits Th1 differentiation and the production of IFN-gamma by Th1 cells. IL-18 receptor is expressed on Th1 cells and is required for IL-18 to induce Th1 differentiation and the production of IFN-gamma. IL-18 is produced by macrophages and other cells in response to LPS and other stimuli, and IL-18 receptor is expressed on Th1 cells. IL-18 receptor is also expressed on Th2 cells, but IL-18 does not induce Th2 differentiation. The differentiation of Th1 and Th2 cells is also regulated by the cytokines IL-12p7 0 and IL-10. IL-12p7 0 induces Th1 differentiation and the production of IFN-gamma and TNF-alpha, while IL-10 induces Th2 differentiation and the production of IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, and IL-10. The differentiation of Th1 and Th2 cells is also regulated by the costimulatory molecules CD8 0 and CD8 6 on antigen-presenting cells that bind to the CD2 8 and CTLA-4 costimulatory receptors on T cells. The binding of CD8 0 and CD8 6 to CD2 8 and CTLA-4 induces the activation of T cells and the production of IL-2 and other cytokines. The differentiation of Th1 and Th2 cells is also regulated by the transcription factors T-bet and GATA-3. T-bet induces Th1 differentiation and the production of IFN-gamma and TNF-alpha, while GATA-3 induces Th2 differentiation and the production of IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, and IL-10.

Cell migration is a fundamental process in development, wound healing, and metastasis of cancer cells. Cell migration is regulated by many factors, including growth factors, extracellular matrix, and cell-cell interactions. Cell migration is initiated by integrin-mediated cell adhesion to the extracellular matrix, and is followed by the formation of lamellipodia and filopodia, which are driven by actin polymerization. The formation of lamellipodia and filopodia is regulated by the small G protein Rac1 and the Arp2 / 3 complex, which nucleates actin polymerization. The formation of lamellipodia and filopodia is followed by the formation of focal adhesions, which are formed by the clustering of integrins and the recruitment of signaling molecules. The formation of focal adhesions is required for cell migration. Cell migration is also regulated by the small G protein RhoA, which induces the formation of stress fibers and focal adhesions. Rho-associated coiled-coil containing protein kinase (ROCK) is a downstream target of RhoA and regulates the formation of stress fibers and focal adhesions through the phosphorylation of myosin light chain (MLC). Cell migration is also regulated by the lipid kinase phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K). PI3K is activated by growth factors and is required for cell migration. PI3K produces phosphatidylinositol-3, 4, 5-trisphosphate (PIP3), which activates Rac1 and Cdc4 2. PIP3 also activates the serine / threonine kinase Akt, which regulates cell migration through the phosphorylation of several targets.

Angiotensinogen is the precursor of the vasoconstrictor peptide angiotensin II (AngII). The renin-angiotensin system (RAS) is a hormonal cascade that regulates blood pressure and sodium balance. AngII is the effector peptide of the RAS. It is produced from angiotensinogen by the proteolytic action of renin and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE). ACE is a dipeptidyl carboxypeptidase that cleaves off the C-terminal dipeptides from both angiotensin I and bradykinin. ACE is a key regulatory enzyme of the RAS. ACE is also known as dipeptidyl carboxypeptidase-1 (DCP1). Bradykinin is a vasodilator peptide that is produced from its precursor kininogen by the action of kallikrein. Bradykinin is degraded by the enzyme ACE to produce the inactive metabolite angiotensin 1-8. ACE is also known as kininase II. The RAS is a key regulator of blood pressure and sodium balance. ACE inhibitors are a class of drugs used to treat hypertension. ACE inhibitors block the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, thus blocking the action of angiotensin II at its receptor. ACE inhibitors are also used to treat heart failure and diabetic nephropathy. ACE inhibitors do not increase the levels of bradykinin, but increase the levels of the ACE substrate angiotensin 1-9. This peptide is an agonist of the bradykinin receptor. ACE inhibitors also increase the levels of the ACE substrate angiotensin 1-7. Angiotensin 1-7 is a vasodilator peptide that acts through the G-protein coupled receptor MAS. The RAS also includes the angiotensin II receptor type 2 (AGTR2). The RAS is a key regulator of cardiac growth and remodeling. ACE inhibitors block the action of angiotensin II at its receptor, blocking the growth of cardiac tissue. ACE inhibitors block the growth of cardiac tissue, preventing cardiac hypertrophy and dilation. ACE inhibitors block the growth of cardiac tissue, preventing cardiac hypertrophy and dilation. ACE inhibitors block the growth of cardiac tissue, preventing cardiac hypertrophy and dilation.

Nerve growth factor (NGF) is a member of the neurotrophin family of growth factors that includes brain derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) and neurotrophin 3 (NT-3). Neurotrophins are involved in the development and maintenance of the peripheral and central nervous systems. NGF is required for the survival and maintenance of the cholinergic neurons of the basal forebrain. NGF also plays a role in the development of sensory neurons and in the survival of developing motor neurons. NGF is also involved in learning and memory. NGF binds to TrkA, a receptor tyrosine kinase, to initiate a signaling cascade that results in the activation of the ras-MAP kinase pathway and the ELK-1 transcription factor. NGF also binds to the p7 5 neurotrophin receptor, a member of the TNF receptor gene family. Binding of NGF to the p7 5 receptor can activate apoptosis through the activation of caspase-3. NGF also activates NF-kB through a pathway that does not involve the ras-MAP kinase pathway.

Notch signaling is a conserved mechanism of cell-cell communication that is essential for proper embryonic development in all metazoan organisms. The Notch family of receptors and their ligands are both highly conserved throughout evolution. In addition to its role in development, Notch signaling is also involved in a number of pathological conditions, including cancer. Presenilin is the protease that cleaves the Notch receptor to release the Notch intracellular domain (NICD). NICD translocates to the nucleus and forms a transcriptional activation complex with the DNA-binding protein CSL (CBF1, Su (H), Lag-1) and the coactivator Mastermind. CSL is a DNA-binding protein that represses transcription in the absence of NICD. In the absence of NICD, corepressors such as histone deacetylases and the histone methyltransferase MAML1 are associated with CSL. NICD displaces corepressors and recruits coactivators to convert CSL from a transcriptional repressor to an activator. Notch signaling regulates the expression of a number of genes involved in a variety of cellular processes.

The intercalated disc (ID) is a specialized region of cardiac myocyte plasma membrane that provides a critical link between the extracellular matrix (ECM) and the cytoskeleton. The ID is a highly organized structure with distinct junctional complexes that transmit mechanical and electrical signals between the plasma membrane and the cytoplasm. The ID is composed of two major junctional complexes: the desmosome, which provides strong intercellular adhesion, and the fascia adherens junction (FAJ), which provides a structural bridge between the plasma membrane and the actin cytoskeleton. Desmosomes are composed of transmembrane proteins of the cadherin family (desmoglein and desmocollin) that interact with the cytoplasmic armadillo protein plakoglobin. Plakoglobin interacts with desmoplakin, which in turn binds to the intermediate filament protein desmin. The FAJ is composed of two major components: the fascia adherens junction (FAZ) and the gap junction (GJP). The FAZ is composed of the transmembrane proteins N-cadherin and beta-catenin, which interact with the cytoplasmic proteins alpha-catenin and plakoglobin. The GJP is composed of the integral membrane proteins connexin-4 3 (Cx4 3) and plakoglobin. The integrity of the ID is essential for normal cardiac function. Mutations in genes encoding proteins of the desmosome and the gap junction have been associated with inherited cardiac disorders including arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC), dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) and sudden cardiac death.

Cell migration is a fundamental cellular function that is involved in a variety of biological processes including embryonic development, inflammation, wound healing, and cancer metastasis. Cell migration is a complex process that requires the coordinated regulation of the cytoskeleton, membrane protrusion, adhesion, and membrane trafficking. Rho family GTPases are molecular switches that regulate many aspects of cell behavior, including cell migration. Rho regulates the formation of actin stress fibers and focal adhesions, which are involved in the formation of cell adhesions and cell motility. Rac and Cdc-4 2 regulate membrane ruffling and lamellipodia formation, respectively, which are involved in cell migration. Rho also regulates membrane trafficking through the formation of membrane ruffles and vesicles. The regulation of membrane trafficking by Rho is mediated by the Rho effector protein kinase N (PKN). The regulation of membrane trafficking by Rho is also involved in the invasive migration of cancer cells.

The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a member of the ErbB family of receptor tyrosine kinases. The EGFR is activated by a variety of ligands including EGF, transforming growth factor-alpha (TGFA), heparin-binding EGF-like growth factor (HBEGF), amphiregulin (AREG), betacellulin (BTC), epiregulin (EREG), and epigen (EPGN). These ligands are synthesized as transmembrane precursors that are proteolytically cleaved to release soluble growth factors. The soluble ligands bind to the extracellular domain of the EGFR and induce receptor dimerization and activation. The intracellular domain of the EGFR contains a tyrosine kinase domain that is activated by ligand-induced dimerization. Receptor activation leads to the phosphorylation of tyrosine residues in the cytoplasmic domain that serve as docking sites for signaling molecules. The adaptor protein Shc binds to phosphorylated tyrosine residues in the EGFR and couples to the Ras / Raf / MEK / MAPK pathway. The Grb2-Sos complex is recruited to the receptor via binding to phosphorylated tyrosine residues in the EGFR and couples to the Ras / Raf / MEK / MAPK pathway. Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) and phospholipase C-gamma (PLC-gamma) are also recruited to the activated EGFR and contribute to the activation of the Ras / Raf / MEK / MAPK pathway. Growth factor receptor bound protein 2 (GRB2) is an adaptor protein that couples to the EGFR and couples to the Ras / Raf / MEK / MAPK pathway. Grb2 also couples to the adaptor protein Gab1 and couples to the Ras / Map kinase pathway as well as the PI3K pathway. The adaptor protein Shc couples to the EGFR and couples to the Grb2-Sos complex. Grb2-associated binder 1 (Gab1) is a docking protein that couples to the Ras / Raf / MEK / MAPK pathway as well as the PI3K pathway. Gab1 also couples to the Crk-associated substrate (CAS) / Crk pathway. The Crk adaptor protein couples to the Crk / DOCK1 8 0 pathway.

Apoptosis is a genetically programmed cell death that is characterized by a series of morphological changes including cell shrinkage, chromatin condensation, and nuclear fragmentation. Caspases are a class of cysteine proteases that play a central role in apoptosis. Caspases are synthesized as inactive precursors that are activated by cleavage or other mechanisms. Caspases are grouped into initiator and executioner caspases. Caspases-2, -8, -9, and -1 0 are initiator caspases that activate the downstream executioner caspases-3, -6, and -7. The caspase cascade is initiated by the activation of initiator caspases, which in turn activate the downstream executioner caspases. Caspases are activated by two main pathways, the extrinsic pathway and the intrinsic pathway. The extrinsic pathway is triggered by the binding of death receptors of the TNF receptor gene family to their ligands. Caspases-8 and -1 0 are activated by the death-inducing signaling complex (DISC), which is formed on the cell surface by the ligation of the receptor and its adaptor protein FADD. The intrinsic pathway is triggered by various apoptotic stimuli, such as DNA damage, ER stress, and hypoxia. The release of cytochrome c from mitochondria into the cytosol is a key event in the intrinsic pathway. Cytochrome c activates Apaf-1, which in turn activates caspase-9. Caspases-3, -6, and -7 are the main executioner caspases. Granzyme-B is a protease released from cytotoxic T cells and natural killer cells to induce apoptosis in virus-infected or transformed cells. Granzyme-B activates caspases directly and also activates the caspase-independent pathway.

The G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) superfamily is the largest gene family in the human genome. GPCRs respond to a wide variety of stimuli, including light, odorants, neurotransmitters, lipids, and peptides, and are the target of many drugs. The GPCRs are coupled to intracellular heterotrimeric G proteins, which are composed of alpha, beta, and gamma subunits. The alpha subunits of G proteins are classified into four families (Gs, Gi, Gq / 1 1, and G1 2 / 1 3), and each family is coupled to a different set of effectors. The Gs family is coupled to the activation of adenylyl cyclase and an increase in cAMP levels, the Gi family is coupled to the inhibition of adenylyl cyclase, and the Gq / 1 1 family is coupled to the activation of phospholipase C and the release of intracellular calcium. The G1 2 / 1 3 family is coupled to the activation of Rho and the inhibition of adenylyl cyclase. The beta-adrenergic receptor kinase (betaARK1) and the regulator of G-protein signaling (RGS) proteins are two important regulators of GPCR signaling. The betaARK1 phosphorylates agonist-occupied GPCRs and targets them for desensitization and internalization. The RGS proteins are GTPase-activating proteins (GAPs) for the alpha subunits of G proteins and act as negative regulators of GPCR signaling. The Gs-adenylyl cyclase-cAMP pathway is involved in learning and memory, and is also involved in heart failure and asthma. The Gi-adenylyl cyclase-cAMP pathway is involved in heart rate control and is also involved in heart failure and asthma. The Gq-phospholipase C-IP3 pathway is involved in vasoconstriction and platelet activation. The G1 2 / 1 3-Rho pathway is involved in cell proliferation and is also involved in heart failure and asthma.

The chemokine receptor CXCR4 is activated by the chemokine ligand SDF-1 (stromal cell-derived factor-1). SDF-1 is expressed in the bone marrow and recruits leukocytes to the bone marrow during immune responses. The CXCR4 receptor is also expressed on the surface of lymphocytes and is involved in lymphocyte homing to the bone marrow. Binding of SDF-1 to CXCR4 activates a G-protein coupled signaling pathway that includes activation of phospholipase C, release of intracellular calcium, activation of protein kinase C, and activation of the MAP kinase pathway. The MAP kinase pathway includes activation of the small G-protein Rac, which activates the MAP kinase kinase kinase MEKK1, which activates the MAP kinase kinase kinase Raf, and ultimately activates MAP kinase ERK1 and ERK2. The activation of the MAP kinase pathway by SDF-1 through CXCR4 is distinct from the pathway activated by the growth factor receptor CXCR4 that includes PI3 kinase and Akt. The activation of the MAP kinase pathway by SDF-1 through CXCR4 may play a role in lymphocyte homing to the bone marrow.

The regulation of the cell cycle is a complex process that involves the coordinated activation of a variety of proteins. The cell cycle is regulated by the interaction of cyclins with cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs). The activity of CDKs is regulated by phosphorylation and dephosphorylation and by the presence of CDK inhibitors. The activity of cyclins is also regulated by the ubiquitin-dependent proteolytic pathway. The transition from G1 to S phase is regulated by the interaction of cyclin D with CDK4 or CDK6 and the phosphorylation of the retinoblastoma protein (Rb). The transition from G1 to S phase is also regulated by the interaction of cyclin E with CDK2 and the phosphorylation of the Rb and the protein encoded by the p61c- gene. The transition from G2 to M phase is regulated by the interaction of cyclin A with CDK2. The progression through the cell cycle is also regulated by the interaction of checkpoint control proteins with cyclins and CDKs. The checkpoint control proteins include the protein kinases ATM and ATR, which are activated by DNA damage and phosphorylate the checkpoint proteins chk1 and chk2. These proteins then phosphorylate cdc2 5, a phosphatase that activates cdc2 (CDK1), and phosphorylate the CDK inhibitors, p27 and p19, that inhibit the activity of cdc2. The checkpoint control proteins also regulate the interaction of cyclins with CDKs. The interaction of cyclin A with CDK2 is inhibited by the checkpoint control protein p21. The interaction of cyclin B with CDK1 is inhibited by the checkpoint control protein p19.

Apoptosis or programmed cell death is a genetically regulated mechanism of cell death that is essential for the maintenance of tissue homeostasis. Apoptosis can be triggered by a variety of stimuli, including cytokines, growth factor withdrawal, radiation, chemotherapeutic drugs, and viral infection. The Bcl-2 family of proteins plays a key role in regulating apoptosis. Bcl-2 is an anti-apoptotic protein that inhibits apoptosis induced by a variety of stimuli, including growth factor withdrawal, cytotoxic drugs, and radiation. Bcl-2 functions by interacting with other Bcl-2 family members to regulate the release of mitochondrial factors that induce apoptosis. Bcl-2 interacts with Bax, another Bcl-2 family member that promotes apoptosis. Bcl-2 and Bax interact to form a heterodimer that inhibits apoptosis. Other Bcl-2 family members, such as Bcl-xL and Bcl-w, promote cell survival, interacting with Bax to inhibit apoptosis. Bax promotes apoptosis by inducing cytochrome c release from mitochondria, which activates caspases and other apoptotic factors. Bad is another Bcl-2 family member that promotes apoptosis by interacting with Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL to release cytochrome c. Bid is a Bcl-2 family member that promotes apoptosis by interacting with Bax. Bad is phosphorylated by protein kinase C (PKC) in response to growth factor signaling, which inhibits its interaction with Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL to promote cell survival. Bcl-xL is a Bcl-2 family member that promotes cell survival by interacting with Bax to inhibit apoptosis. Bad is also a Bcl-2 family member that promotes apoptosis by interacting with Bcl-xL to inhibit apoptosis. Bax is a Bcl-2 family member that promotes apoptosis. Interaction of Bax with Bcl-2 or Bcl-xL inhibits their anti-apoptotic activity. Other Bcl-2 family members, such as Bak and Bik, do not interact with Bcl-2 or Bcl-xL to promote apoptosis. Bad and Bax are also regulated by phosphorylation. Other factors involved in regulating apoptosis include the inhibitor of apoptosis proteins (IAP) that inhibit caspase activation, and the inhibitor of caspase-activated DNase (ICAD) that inhibits caspase activation by caspase-activated DNase (CAD). IAP proteins interact with caspases to inhibit their activity. ICAD is cleaved by caspase-3 to release CAD, which induces apoptosis.

The Tax protein encoded by HTLV-1 is a transcriptional activator that plays a key role in the transformation of T cells by HTLV-1. Tax interacts with cellular transcription factors and coactivators to alter their activities. Tax interacts with the CREB transcription factor to increase the affinity of CREB for the HTLV-1 2 1 bp repeat promoter element. Tax also interacts with the CBP / p300 transcriptional coactivators to increase the transcriptional activity of CREB and other transcription factors. Tax interacts with the tumor suppressor p53 to alter its activity. Tax interacts with the I-kB inhibitor of NFkB to alter its activity. Tax interacts with the heat shock protein Hsp70 to alter its activity. Tax interacts with the heat shock protein Hsp40 to alter its activity. Tax interacts with the ubiquitin ligase E6-AP to alter its activity. Tax interacts with the tumor suppressor gene p53 to alter its activity. Tax interacts with the tumor suppressor gene lin-7 to alter its activity. Tax alters the activity of the tumor suppressor gene VHL.

Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) is a cardiac hormone secreted by the atrial cardiocytes in response to atrial stretch. ANP is a 2 8-amino acid peptide with a ring structure formed by the oxidation of a cysteine residue and a C-terminal amino acid. ANP is a potent natriuretic and diuretic agent. The biological effects of ANP are mediated by binding to its receptor, natriuretic peptide receptor-A (NPR-A). The binding of ANP to NPR-A activates the receptor-coupled guanylate cyclase, increasing intracellular cGMP levels. The cGMP then activates cGMP-dependent protein kinase, cGMP-regulated PDE3, and cGMP-inhibited cAMP phosphodiesterase, leading to the inhibition of Na + / Ca + exchanger and the activation of the Na + / K + ATPase. The inhibition of the Na + / Ca + exchanger and the activation of the Na + / K + ATPase by ANP reduce intracellular Na + and Ca + + levels, leading to water and salt excretion. The activation of cGMP-dependent protein kinase by ANP also leads to the phosphorylation of phospholamban, which relieves its inhibition on the sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca + -ATPase, increasing the reuptake of Ca + + into the sarcoplasmic reticulum and leading to increased relaxation of cardiac myocytes. The activation of cGMP-dependent protein kinase by ANP also leads to the phosphorylation of the heat shock protein 2 7, which may contribute to the anti-hypertrophic action of ANP. The anti-hypertrophic action of ANP may also be mediated by the inhibition of the nuclear factor-kB (NF-kB) pathway. The activation of NF-kB by hypertrophic stimuli such as angiotensin II leads to the induction of hypertrophic genes. ANP inhibits the activation of NF-kB by blocking the degradation of I-kB, the inhibitor of NF-kB.

The Rho family of small GTPases (Rho, Rac and Cdc-4 2) are molecular switches that cycle between an inactive GDP-bound state and an active GTP-bound state. The cycling between the GDP- and GTP-bound states is regulated by three classes of proteins: Guanine nucleotide Exchange Factors (GEFs), GTPase Activating Proteins (GAPs) and Guanine Nucleotide Dissociation Inhibitors (GDIs). GEFs promote the exchange of GDP for GTP, GAPs stimulate the intrinsic GTP-ase activity of GTPases, and GDIs inhibit the release of GTPases from the membrane and keep them in the inactive state in the cytosol. The Rho GTPases regulate a variety of cellular functions including cytoskeletal dynamics, cell motility, gene expression, cell cycle progression and membrane trafficking. The best characterized downstream effectors of Rho are the ROCK kinases (ROCK I and II), which are involved in cytoskeletal reorganization and cell motility. ROCK kinases also phosphorylate LIM kinase, which phosphorylates cofilin, an actin-binding protein that stimulates actin depolymerization. ROCK also phosphorylates and inhibits myosin phosphatase, increasing actin-myosin interactions and stimulating contraction. ROCK is involved in the regulation of neurite retraction and neuronal cell migration. Other Rho effectors include the PKN kinase, which phosphorylates and activates the ERM (Ezrin, Radixin, Moesin) family of proteins, which link the actin cytoskeleton to the plasma membrane. PKN also phosphorylates and activates the Map kinase pathway, which regulates cell proliferation and survival.

The regulation of skeletal muscle growth and development is a complex process involving the coordinated expression of multiple genes. The insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) plays a key role in skeletal muscle growth and development. IGF-1 is a potent mitogen for many cell types, including skeletal muscle cells. IGF-1 stimulates muscle cell proliferation and differentiation. IGF-1 exerts its effects through the IGF-1 receptor, a member of the tyrosine kinase receptor family. The IGF-1 receptor is expressed in skeletal muscle and its expression increases during muscle development. The IGF-1 receptor activates several signaling pathways, including the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway, the phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway, and the protein kinase C (PKC) pathway. The activation of these pathways leads to the expression of immediate early genes, such as c-fos and Egr-1, and late response genes, such as myogenin and myosin light chain. The coordinated expression of these genes leads to the differentiation of skeletal muscle cells.

Heart development is a complex process that requires the integration of multiple signaling pathways. The Wnt pathway is one of several signaling pathways that are involved in cardiogenesis. Wnt signaling is involved in the formation of the first heart field, which gives rise to the left and right ventricles and parts of the atria. Wnt signaling is also involved in the second heart field, which gives rise to the outflow tract and parts of the atria. Wnt signaling is also involved in the development of the cardiac conduction system. The transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) family of secreted factors also plays a role in cardiogenesis. Members of this family include bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs), growth and differentiation factors (GDFs), activins and inhibins. TGF-beta family members signal through serine-threonine kinase receptors and SMAD family members. TGF-beta family members are involved in the formation of the cardiac cushions, septation of the heart, and the development of the cardiac valves.

Tight junctions (TJs) are cell-cell contacts that restrict the movement of solutes and lipids between the apical and basolateral surfaces of epithelial cells. They are formed by the association of transmembrane proteins, occludin, claudins and junctional adhesion molecules (JAMs), with cytoplasmic proteins. The cytoplasmic proteins include the MAGuK protein ZO-1, which interacts with occludin, ZO-2, ZO-3, and the myosin-binding protein cingulin. ZO-1 also binds to the actin cytoskeleton through its association with ZO-2 and actin. The PAR complex, consisting of PAR-3, PAR-6 and aPKC, is localized at the apical region of epithelial cells and is involved in the establishment and maintenance of cell polarity. The PAR complex is also involved in the organization of tight junctions. The PAR complex is localized at the apical region of epithelial cells and is involved in the organization of tight junctions.

The growth and development of hematopoietic cells is regulated by a variety of cytokines. The actions of these cytokines are mediated through specific cell surface receptors. The binding of cytokines to their receptors results in the activation of a variety of signaling pathways, including the JAK / STAT, MAPK, and PI3 kinase pathways. The net effect of these pathways is to regulate cellular survival, proliferation, and differentiation.

Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) and natural killer (NK) cells are a major component of the immune system and play a key role in the defense against viral infection and tumor cells. CTLs and NK cells are activated by the interaction of antigen-presenting cells (APCs) with specific antigens on the surface of tumor cells or virus-infected cells. Activated CTLs and NK cells induce apoptosis in target cells through two major pathways, the perforin / granzyme pathway and the Fas / Fas ligand (FasL) pathway. Perforin is released by CTLs and NK cells and forms pores in the membrane of target cells, allowing the entry of granzyme proteases into the cytosol of the target cell. Granzyme A and granzyme B are the most abundant granzyme proteases in CTLs and NK cells and are the major proteases that induce apoptosis in target cells. Once in the cytosol, granzyme B activates caspase-3, -7 and-6, which are key proteases in apoptosis. Perforin also induces apoptosis in target cells through a caspase-independent pathway. The interaction of Fas on the surface of target cells with Fas ligand on the surface of CTLs induces apoptosis in target cells. The interaction of perforin and granzyme with the target cell membrane and the interaction of Fas with its ligand induce the release of mitochondrial proteins such as cytochrome c and AIF into the cytosol. Cytochrome c interacts with Apaf-1 and caspase-9 to form an apoptosome that activates caspase-3, -7 and-6. AIF induces apoptosis independently of caspase activation.

The transcription factor NFAT is a key regulator of cytokine expression in T cells. In resting T cells, NFAT is sequestered in the cytoplasm by association with the proteins 14-3-3 and 19kDa-AKAP. T cell activation leads to the activation of phospholipase C, the production of IP3 and release of calcium from intracellular stores. The increase in intracellular calcium activates calcineurin, a calcium-dependent phosphatase. Calcineurin dephosphorylates NFAT, causing it to translocate to the nucleus. In the nucleus, NFAT binds to the IL-2 promoter and other NFAT-dependent promoters and activates transcription. The activity of NFAT is regulated by phosphorylation. The kinases GSK-3 and cdk9 phosphorylate NFAT and cause it to be retained in the cytoplasm. Dephosphorylation by calcineurin causes NFAT to translocate to the nucleus and activate transcription. The activity of NFAT is also regulated by binding of 14-3-3 and 19kDa-AKAP. 14-3-3 binds to NFAT when it is dephosphorylated by calcineurin and prevents it from translocating to the nucleus. 19kDa-AKAP binds to NFAT and anchors it in the cytoplasm. Binding of cAMP to PKA causes the regulatory subunit of PKA to dissociate from the catalytic subunits, allowing them to phosphorylate NFAT and cause it to be retained in the cytoplasm. The activity of NFAT is also regulated by the kinase PKC. PKC activates calcineurin, causing NFAT to be dephosphorylated and translocate to the nucleus. The kinase PKA can also inhibit NFAT by phosphorylating it and causing it to be retained in the cytoplasm.

Cyclin B is a regulatory subunit of the cyclin-dependent kinase CDK1. It is required for the transition from the G2 to the M phase of the cell cycle. The activity of cyclin B / CDK1 is regulated by the phosphorylation of CDK1 and the phosphorylation of the cyclin B. The phosphorylation of CDK1 is regulated by the balance of the activities of the kinases and phosphatases. The phosphatase PP2A dephosphorylates CDK1 and inactivates CDK1. The phosphatase CDC2 5 activates CDK1 by dephosphorylating CDK1 and activating cyclin B / CDK1. The activity of CDC2 5 is regulated by the phosphorylation of CDC2 5 by the kinase p38 and the phosphatase PP2A. The kinase p38 activates CDC2 5 and inactivates PP2A. The phosphatase PP2A dephosphorylates CDC2 5 and inactivates CDK1. The activity of PP2A is regulated by the phosphorylation of the PP2A catalytic subunit by PKC and the dephosphorylation of the PP2A catalytic subunit by the p21 kinase. The kinase p38 is activated by the EGF receptor and PKC and inhibited by the kinase p21.

The interferon gamma receptor is a heterodimer of two subunits, IFNGR1 and IFNGR2. The ligand for the receptor is interferon gamma, a cytokine secreted by activated T cells that is involved in the immune response. Interferon gamma binds to the extracellular domain of the receptor and signals through the JAK / STAT pathway to activate transcription of interferon-stimulated genes. The receptor is also involved in other cellular processes such as cell adhesion and apoptosis. The receptor is found on the surface of cells of the immune system, including macrophages, natural killer cells, and T cells. The receptor is also found on some epithelial cells. The IFNGR1 subunit is a 70000Dalton protein that is associated with the IFNGR2 subunit in the plasma membrane. The cytoplasmic domain of IFNGR1 is involved in signaling and contains several tyrosine residues that are phosphorylated by JAK kinases in response to ligand binding. The JAK kinases phosphorylate and activate STAT transcription factors that move into the nucleus and activate transcription of interferon-stimulated genes. The IFNGR2 subunit is a transmembrane protein that is associated with JAK2 in the plasma membrane. The activation of JAK kinases by the receptor is believed to be mediated by the cytoplasmic domain of IFNGR2. The role of the receptor in other cellular processes is not yet clear.

Type I diabetes mellitus (T1DM) is an autoimmune disease resulting from the autoimmune destruction of the insulin-producing beta-cells in the pancreatic islets of Langerhans. The autoimmune destruction of beta-cells leads to a deficiency in insulin secretion and the clinical symptoms of diabetes. The disease is caused by the interaction of genetic and environmental factors. Environmental factors include viral infections, dietary factors, and chemicals. The genetic factors include mutations in immune regulatory genes such as the cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) gene and the protein tyrosine phosphatase, non-receptor type 2 2 (PTPN2 2) gene. The CTLA-4 gene is involved in the regulation of T cell activation and tolerance. The PTPN2 2 gene is involved in the regulation of T cell activation and the control of T cell receptor signaling. The mutations in these genes may lead to an imbalance in the immune system and an increased susceptibility to autoimmune diabetes. The genetic factors also include the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) and non-MHC genes. The MHC is the most polymorphic region of the genome and is responsible for presenting foreign antigens to T cells. Non-MHC genes include those involved in insulin production (insulin gene), beta-cell function (PDX1), and immune regulation (cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4), protein tyrosine phosphatase non-receptor type 2 2 (PTPN2 2), and protein tyrosine phosphatase receptor type 6 (PTPRD)). Environmental factors may trigger the autoimmune process in genetically predisposed individuals by altering the immune system, leading to the production of autoantibodies and T cells that are reactive to beta-cell antigens. The autoantibodies are used as markers to identify individuals at risk for developing T1DM. T cells that are specific for beta-cell antigens are found in the peripheral blood of individuals at risk for T1DM. The beta-cell-specific autoantibodies are produced by autoreactive B cells. The presence of these autoantibodies and autoreactive T cells in the blood of individuals at risk for T1DM indicates that the autoimmune process leading to T1DM begins before the onset of clinical diabetes. The autoimmune response is characterized by the production of autoantibodies against insulin, glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD), and islet antigen-2 (IA-2). The autoantibodies are used as markers to identify individuals at risk for T1DM.
