The interaction of T cells with APCs is also regulated by other costimulatory molecules. The inducible T cell costimulatory molecule (ICOS) is a member of the CD2 8 family that shares many of the same functions as CD2 8. The interaction of ICOS with its ligand B7x provides a second signal that is required for T-cell activation. The interaction of ICOS with B7x is involved in the regulation of T-cell responses. The Programmed death-1 (PD-1) molecule is another member of the CD2 8 family that is involved in the regulation of T-cell responses. The interaction of PD-1 with its ligand PD-L1 or PD-L2 provides a second signal that down-regulates T-cell responses.

The protease-activated GPCRs are a family of GPCRs that are activated by proteases rather than peptide hormones. The protease-activated receptors (PARs) are a family of four GPCRs that are activated by proteolytic cleavage of their N-terminus to reveal a new N-terminal sequence that functions as a tethered ligand. This new N-terminus functions as a peptide ligand that activates the receptor and is subsequently removed by an aminopeptidase. The tethered ligand can be unmasked by synthetic peptides corresponding to the newly created N-terminus. Synthetic peptides corresponding to the new N-terminus of PAR1, PAR2, and PAR4 can activate the PARs in the absence of cleavage. Synthetic peptides corresponding to the new N-terminus of PAR1 and PAR2 can also activate the protease-activated receptors in the absence of cleavage. The tethered ligand can also be unmasked by peptides corresponding to the newly created N-terminus of PAR3. The PAR receptors are widely expressed in the cardiovascular, central nervous, and immune systems. Activation of the PARs by thrombin and other proteases can lead to cellular responses that can be either beneficial or detrimental depending on the cellular and disease context.

The immune system consists of two major components, the lymphoid cells and the nonlymphoid cells. The lymphoid cells are formed from hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) through a series of differentiation steps, called hematopoiesis, in the bone marrow. The HSCs differentiate into common lymphoid progenitors (CLPs), which give rise to T cells, B cells, and NK cells. The common myeloid progenitors (CMPs) differentiate into granulocyte-macrophage progenitors (GMPs), which produce the myeloid cells, including monocytes, macrophages, and neutrophils. The megakaryocyte-erythrocyte progenitors (MEPs) differentiate into the common erythrocyte-granulocyte-macrophage progenitors (EGPs), which produce megakaryocytes and erythrocytes.

The 5HTR is a receptor for serotonin (5HT) that is expressed in the central nervous system and in the gastrointestinal tract. The 5HTR is coupled to the Gq / 1 1 family of G proteins. Activation of the 5HTR stimulates phospholipase C, which cleaves phosphatidylinositol bisphosphate to form inositol trisphosphate and diacylglycerol. Inositol trisphosphate causes release of intracellular calcium, and diacylglycerol activates protein kinase C. Activation of the 5HTR also stimulates the MAP kinase pathway through a G protein-independent mechanism involving transactivation of the EGF receptor. The 5HTR is involved in the regulation of a variety of physiological functions including learning and memory, feeding behavior, and gastrointestinal motility.

The protease-activated receptors (PARs) are a unique family of GPCRs activated by proteolytic cleavage of their extracellular N-termini to reveal a tethered peptide ligand that binds and activates the receptor. The tethered ligand sequences of the four PARs are SFLLRN (PAR1), GYPGQV (PAR2), GYPGQV (PAR4), and SLIGKV (PAR4). Synthetic peptides corresponding to these sequences can activate the receptor and are referred to as PAR-APs. The tethered ligand peptides are not present in the intact receptor and are not found in plasma or extracellular matrix. The PAR-APs are generated by the limited proteolysis of extracellular proteins by a family of proteases that includes trypsin, tryptase, and coagulation factors VIIa and Xa. The PAR-APs are the first known examples of cellular ligands that are activated by proteolysis. The PAR-APs are trypsin-like proteases and are trypsin-like in that they cleave the PAR at a specific site to expose a tethered ligand that activates the receptor. The PAR-APs are trypsin-like in that they cleave the PAR at the same specific site as trypsin. The PAR-APs are trypsin-like in that they are trypsin-like in that they cleave the PAR at the same specific site as trypsin. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are activated by proteolysis. PAR-1 is activated by trypsin, tryptase, and factor Xa. PAR-2 is activated by trypsin, tryptase, factor Xa, and cathepsin G. PAR-3 is activated by factor Xa and cathepsin G, and PAR-4 is activated by trypsin and factor Xa. PAR-1 and PAR-2 are cleaved and activated by low concentrations of trypsin (1-1 0 nM), but PAR-3 and PAR-4 are not cleaved by trypsin at concentrations as high as 1uM. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are activated by proteolysis. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are activated by proteolysis. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are activated by proteolysis. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are activated by a proteolytic mechanism. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are irreversibly activated. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are irreversibly activated. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are irreversibly activated. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are irreversibly activated by proteolysis. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are irreversibly activated by proteolysis. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are irreversibly activated. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are irreversibly activated. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are irreversibly activated. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are irreversibly activated. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are irreversibly activated. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are irreversibly activated. The PAR-APs are the first known cellular ligands that are irreversibly activated.

Neurotransmitters such as dopamine, glutamate, acetylcholine and 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) are released from presynaptic nerve terminals and bind to specific receptors on the surface of postsynaptic neurons. These receptors are coupled to a variety of signal transduction pathways, including the Gs, Gi, Gq and Gi / o families of heterotrimeric G proteins. The activation of Gs-coupled receptors leads to the stimulation of adenylate cyclase and the production of the intracellular second messenger cAMP, which activates protein kinase A (PKA). The activation of Gi-coupled receptors leads to the inhibition of adenylate cyclase and a reduction in cAMP levels. The activation of Gq-coupled receptors leads to the activation of phospholipase C and the production of inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). IP3 binds to the intracellular receptor, resulting in the release of Ca2 + from intracellular stores. DAG activates protein kinase C (PKC). The activation of Gs-coupled receptors also leads to the activation of the MAPK pathway. The activation of Gi-coupled receptors leads to the inhibition of adenylate cyclase and a reduction in cAMP levels. The activation of Gq-coupled receptors leads to the activation of phospholipase C and the production of IP3 and DAG. IP3 binds to the intracellular receptor, resulting in the release of Ca2 + from intracellular stores. DAG activates protein kinase C (PKC). The activation of Gs-coupled receptors also leads to the activation of the MAPK pathway.

The extracellular matrix (ECM) is a complex network of structural and functional macromolecules that provides a structural framework for cells and tissues. The ECM also plays a critical role in cell signaling and in the regulation of cell proliferation and differentiation. The major components of the ECM are collagen, proteoglycans, and glycoproteins. The collagens form a family of fibril-forming proteins that provide tensile strength to tissues. Proteoglycans consist of a core protein with covalently attached glycosaminoglycan chains. Proteoglycans interact with collagen and other ECM components to provide structural support and regulate cell proliferation and migration. Glycoproteins include laminin, fibronectin, and tenascin. The laminin family of glycoproteins provides structural support for tissues and regulates cell adhesion. The extracellular matrix is synthesized and secreted by cells and is continuously remodeled by the combined action of proteolytic enzymes and the action of tissue-derived and secreted metalloproteinases (MMPs). The balance between the synthesis and degradation of ECM components is critical for the maintenance of tissue structure and function. Disruption of this balance can lead to tissue destruction and is associated with a number of pathological conditions. The collagen family of proteins is synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) as precursors that are cleaved in the Golgi to produce the mature proteins. The propeptide domains of the collagen propeptides inhibit the assembly of collagen monomers into higher order structures. The propeptides are removed from the procollagens in the trans-Golgi network by the action of the enzyme C-proteinase. The removal of the propeptide domains is required for the assembly of collagen monomers into fibrils and fibers. The removal of the propeptide domains is also required for the activation of the collagen-degrading MMPs. The removal of the propeptide domains is regulated by the interaction of the propeptides with the chaperone protein HSP4 7. The collagen-degrading MMPs are secreted as inactive zymogens. The conversion of the inactive zymogen to the active enzyme is regulated by a family of secreted proteins called tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMPs). The activity of the MMPs is also regulated by the action of a family of ECM-associated proteinase inhibitors (cystatins).

Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a heart muscle disease associated with dilation and impaired function of the left or both ventricles. Familial forms of DCM are caused by mutations in genes encoding cytoskeletal, contractile, or regulatory proteins of the cardiac sarcomere. The most common form of DCM is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion and is associated with mutations in the genes encoding the sarcomeric proteins beta-myosin heavy chain (beta-MHC), cardiac troponin T (cTnT), and alpha-tropomyosin (alpha-TM). In addition, mutations in the genes encoding the cytoskeletal protein desmin (DES) and the Z-disk protein Cypher (CSRP3) have been identified in rare families with autosomal dominant DCM. Mutations in the genes encoding the Z-disk protein Titin (TTN) and the sarcolemmal proteins dystrophin (DMD) and laminin (LAMA2) have been identified in families with an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. The Titin gene encodes a protein that spans the half-sarcomere from the Z disk to the M-band. Mutations in this gene are thought to cause DCM by altering the elasticity of the sarcomere and / or by disrupting signaling pathways that are important for cardiac development and / or homeostasis.

The E2A-HLF fusion gene is generated by the t (1 7; 1 9) (q2 3; p1 3) chromosomal translocation in pre-B-cell ALL. The E2A gene on chromosome 1 9 is fused to the HLF gene on chromosome 1 7. The E2A-HLF chimeric protein consists of the DNA-binding and dimerization domains of E2A and the basic leucine zipper domain of HLF. The chimeric protein functions as a transcriptional activator that is able to induce leukemia in mice. E2A-HLF induces leukemia by activating the expression of a set of genes involved in cell proliferation and survival.

p53 is a tumor suppressor that plays a key role in cell cycle regulation, apoptosis, DNA repair and transcriptional regulation. The p53 gene is mutated in a variety of human cancers. The p53 protein is activated by DNA damage and other stress signals, and in turn activates the expression of genes that mediate these responses. The p53 protein is a short-lived protein that is regulated by Mdm2-mediated ubiquitination and proteasome-dependent degradation. Mdm2 binds to p53 through a p53-p53 interaction domain (p53PD) and targets p53 for ubiquitination and degradation. The p53 protein is also regulated by phosphorylation. The p53 tumor suppressor is activated by DNA damage and other stress signals, and in turn activates the expression of genes that mediate these responses. The p53 protein is activated by DNA damage and other stress signals, and in turn activates the expression of genes that mediate these responses. The p53 protein is also regulated by phosphorylation. The p53 tumor suppressor is activated by DNA damage and other stress signals, and in turn activates the expression of genes that mediate these responses. The p53 protein is also regulated by phosphorylation. The p53 tumor suppressor is activated by phosphorylation. The p53 tumor suppressor is also regulated by acetylation. The p53 tumor suppressor is activated by phosphorylation. The p53 tumor suppressor is also activated by acetylation.

The neutrophil NADPH oxidase is a multi-subunit enzyme that catalyzes the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in response to inflammatory stimuli. The enzyme is activated by the small G-protein Rac-1 and inhibited by the cytosolic factor GDI. The enzyme is also inhibited by the cytoskeletal component actin. The phosphorylation of p4 7phox by protein kinase C is required for NADPH oxidase activation. The phosphorylation of p4 7phox is inhibited by the action of protein phosphatases. The neutrophil NADPH oxidase is also inhibited by the bacterial protein factor H, which cleaves the electron transport chain.

The RAB proteins are a highly conserved gene family that are involved in intracellular vesicle transport and secretion. The RAB proteins are involved in the movement of vesicles from the Golgi to the plasma membrane and back. The movement of vesicles from the Golgi to the plasma membrane is also involved in the release of secretory products such as neurotransmitters. The movement of vesicles from the plasma membrane back to the Golgi is involved in the endocytosis of membrane components and nutrients. The movement of vesicles from the Golgi to the plasma membrane is also involved in the endocytosis of cell surface receptors and ligands. The movement of vesicles from the plasma membrane back to the Golgi is also involved in the recycling of membrane components and nutrients. The movement of vesicles from the Golgi to the plasma membrane and back is also involved in the exocytosis of secretory vesicles. The movement of vesicles from the plasma membrane back to the Golgi is also involved in the endocytosis of cell surface receptors and ligands. The movement of vesicles from the Golgi to the plasma membrane and back is also involved in the exocytosis of secretory vesicles.

Cytokines are secreted proteins that are involved in a variety of biological responses, including the activation and differentiation of immune cells and the regulation of metabolic homeostasis. Cytokines are grouped into different families based on their structural and functional properties. The interleukin (IL) family includes IL-1 through IL-13. The IL-1 receptor (IL-1R) family includes the type I IL-1Rs (IL-1R1, IL-1R2) and the type II IL-1Rs (IL-1R3). The IL-1R1 and IL-1R3 are the receptor for IL-1 and IL-1RA. The type II IL-1Rs are also the receptors for IL-1RA and IL-1RN. The TNF receptor (TNFR) family includes the TNF receptor type I (TNF-RI) and type II (TNF-RII). The IL-1 receptor family includes IL-1R1 and IL-1R2. The TNF receptor family includes TNF-RI and TNF-RII.

Inflammasomes are large protein complexes that assemble in response to cellular stress and damage and serve to activate inflammatory caspases and induce the secretion of proinflammatory cytokines. The best characterized inflammasome is the one formed by the Nod-like receptor protein 3 (NLRP3), also known as NALP3 or Pypa1R, and the adaptor protein ASC. The assembly of the NLRP3 inflammasome leads to the activation of caspase-1 and the maturation of proinflammatory cytokines interleukin-1beta (IL-1beta) and IL-1 8. The NLRP3 inflammasome is activated by a variety of stimuli, including bacterial and viral components, extracellular ATP, and the environmental irritants silica and asbestos. The activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome requires two signals. The first signal is provided by microbial components or stress signals that activate the transcription of the inflammasome components. The second signal is provided by a variety of agents that activate the inflammasome. The identification of the molecular mechanisms that regulate inflammasome activation will provide important insights into the pathogenesis of inflammatory and autoimmune diseases and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is a specialized extracellular matrix (ECM) that lines the inner surface of the glomerular capillaries and is essential for the permselective properties of the kidney glomerular filter. The GBM is a highly specialized ECM that is composed primarily of type IV collagen, laminin, and proteoglycans. The size, charge, and shape of the proteins in the GBM are precisely regulated to maintain the size and shape of the glomerular filtration barrier, while allowing for the selective permeability of the filter. The size of the proteins in the GBM is regulated by the proteolytic degradation of large proteins by the serine protease plasmin, which is activated by the plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 (PAI1). The charge of the proteins in the GBM is regulated by the heparan sulfate (HS) side chains of the heparan sulfate proteoglycan (HSPG) agrin. The size and charge of the proteins in the GBM are also regulated by the post-translational hydroxylation of proline residues in the collagen chains. The collagen IV molecules in the GBM are heterotrimers, with each molecule consisting of two alpha 1 chains, two alpha 2 chains, and one alpha 3 chain. The alpha 1 and alpha 2 chains are encoded by the COL4A1 and COL4A2 genes, and the alpha 3 chain is encoded by the COL4A3 gene. Mutations in the COL4A3 and COL4A4 genes cause Alport syndrome, a progressive kidney disease characterized by hematuria, proteinuria, and eventual renal failure. Mutations in the COL4A5 gene cause thin basement membrane disease, a disorder characterized by persistent microscopic hematuria. Mutations in the COL4A3 and COL4A4 genes cause autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive thin basement membrane disease. Mutations in the COL4A5 gene also cause the more severe disease Alport syndrome. Mutations in the COL4A3 and COL4A4 genes cause Alport syndrome by a dominant negative effect, in which the mutant alpha 3 and alpha 4 chains are incorporated into the GBM, but do not participate in the formation of heterotrimers. The mutant alpha 3 and alpha 4 chains are incorporated into the GBM, and disrupt the normal structure and function of the GBM. The disruption of the GBM leads to the thickening and splitting of the basement membrane, the loss of the normal filtration properties of the GBM, and the development of proteinuria and renal failure.

Fas-mediated apoptosis is triggered by the Fas ligand (FasL), a member of the TNF family of cytokines. Fas is a 4 0kDa type I transmembrane protein that is expressed on the cell surface. Binding of FasL to Fas triggers a signaling cascade that results in apoptosis. The signaling cascade begins with the aggregation of Fas by the binding of FasL, which leads to the recruitment of the adaptor protein FADD (Fas-associated death domain protein). FADD in turn recruits caspase-8 to the membrane through the death effector domains (DED) of each protein. Caspase-8 is then activated by self-cleavage and this active caspase-8 proteolytically activates downstream caspases, including caspase-3. The cleavage of caspase-3 leads to the degradation of cellular proteins and the morphological and biochemical changes associated with apoptosis. The cleavage of Bid by caspase-8 leads to the activation of the mitochondrial apoptotic pathway.

TNF is a cytokine that can induce a variety of cellular responses including inflammation, apoptosis, and cellular proliferation. The TNF receptor family contains five members, TNFR1 through 5. TNFR1 and TNFR2 are expressed on most cells, and can induce both apoptotic and proliferative signals. The proliferative signal is activated by the TRAF family of proteins recruited to the TNF receptor complex by the death domain of the receptor. The apoptotic signal is activated by the recruitment of RIP and FAN to the receptor complex. Both of these pathways activate the transcription factor NF-kB, but the mechanism of activation is different. The proliferative signal is activated by the TRAF family of proteins recruiting the protein kinase NIK to the receptor complex. NIK activates the IkappaB kinase complex, which phosphorylates IkB, causing it to dissociate from NF-kB and move into the nucleus to activate transcription. The apoptotic signal is activated by the recruitment of RIP and FAN to the receptor complex. RIP activates the kinase RIP-associated ICH-1 to phosphorylate FADD and activate caspase-8. FAN activates caspase-1 through a still unknown mechanism. Caspase-1 activates caspase-3, which cleaves ICAD, releasing the CAD to enter the nucleus and activate the apoptotic program.

The progression of melanoma is associated with the loss of the cell cycle checkpoint control and the activation of cellular proliferation. The activation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway is a key event in the transformation of normal melanocytes to melanoma. The activation of the MAPK pathway is achieved by the mutation of the NRAS, BRAF, and HRAS genes. The NRAS mutation leads to the constitutive activation of the MAPK pathway, which is not dependent on growth factor stimulation. The BRAF mutation is found in approximately half of all melanomas and is associated with the constitutive activation of the MAPK pathway. The HRAS mutation is found in a small subset of melanomas and is associated with the constitutive activation of the MAPK pathway in the absence of growth factor stimulation.

Protein phosphorylation plays an important role in the regulation of protein synthesis. Eukaryotic initiation factor-2 (eIF-2) is a key regulator of translation and is regulated by phosphorylation of its alpha subunit. One eIF-2 kinase activated by double-stranded RNA is the PKR protein kinase. PKR is also activated by the endoplasmic reticulum stress-activated kinase PERK. Activation of PKR and PERK leads to phosphorylation of eIF-2 and inhibition of translation. Another eIF-2 kinase activated by interferon is the PKR-like ER kinase (PERK). PERK is activated by the accumulation of unfolded proteins in the ER and phosphorylates the eIF-2 alpha subunit. The phosphorylation of eIF-2 alpha by PKR, PERK and other eIF-2 kinases leads to inhibition of translation and a reduction in protein synthesis that can lead to the formation of stress granules. Stress granules are cytoplasmic aggregates of mRNA, translation initiation factors and other proteins that are induced by stress. The formation of stress granules may play a role in the translational control and the stress response.

Leptin is an adipocyte-derived hormone that signals the status of energy stores to the brain and other tissues. Leptin acts on its receptor in the hypothalamus to reduce food intake and increase energy expenditure. Leptin receptors are also expressed in other tissues, including skeletal muscle, liver, and the heart. In skeletal muscle, leptin stimulates fatty acid oxidation and energy expenditure. The mechanism by which leptin stimulates fatty acid oxidation in skeletal muscle is not known, but may involve inhibition of ACC. Leptin also stimulates glucose uptake and oxidation in skeletal muscle, and this may contribute to the ability of leptin to reduce body weight. Leptin does not appear to alter glucose homeostasis in humans, but may improve glucose tolerance in diabetic animal models. The ability of leptin to stimulate fatty acid oxidation and energy expenditure may be useful in the treatment of obesity and other conditions in which energy storage is increased, such as type II diabetes.

GABA is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain. GABA is released from presynaptic terminals and binds to postsynaptic GABA-A receptors to produce an inhibitory response. GABA-A receptors are ligand-gated chloride channels that are inhibited by benzodiazepines. GABA-A receptors are heteropentamers, typically composed of two alpha, two beta, and two delta subunits. The alpha subunits determine the pharmacological properties of the receptor, and the delta subunit is required for the formation of receptors on the dendrites. The subcellular localization of GABA-A receptors is an important determinant of the response to GABA. Receptors on the cell surface are rapidly internalized by clathrin-mediated endocytosis. The receptors are then either rapidly recycled back to the cell surface or transported to the lysosome for degradation. Gephyrin is a brain specific protein that binds to the intracellular domain of the beta subunit of the GABA-A receptor. Gephyrin is required for the clustering of GABA-A receptors at synapses. The clustering of GABA-A receptors at synapses may also be regulated by phosphorylation of the receptor.

The renin-angiotensin system (RAS) is a key regulator of blood pressure and volume homeostasis. Angiotensinogen is cleaved by renin to form angiotensin I, which is further cleaved by ACE to form the potent vasoconstrictor angiotensin II. Angiotensinogen is also cleaved by the serine protease cathepsin G to form angiotensin I, which is the same length as angiotensin I formed by ACE. Angiotensinogen is found in plasma and is filtered through the kidney glomerulus, where it is cleaved by cathepsin G in the tubular lumen. Angiotensin II is a potent vasoconstrictor that also has proliferative effects on vascular smooth muscle cells. ACE is found in the lungs, kidneys, and blood vessels. Angiotensinogen is also found in the lungs and is cleaved by renin in the circulation. Angiotensinogen is also found in the kidneys and is filtered through the kidney glomerulus, where it is cleaved by cathepsin G in the tubular lumen. Angiotensinogen is also found in the brain, where it is cleaved by cathepsin G in the cerebrospinal fluid. The ACE inhibitor captopril is used to treat hypertension and heart failure. ACE cleaves angiotensin I to form angiotensin II, which increases blood pressure by constricting blood vessels and increasing the cardiac output. ACE inhibitors block the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, reducing blood pressure. The renin inhibitor aliskiren is also being developed as a treatment for hypertension. Angiotensinogen is also cleaved by the protease chymase, which is found in high concentrations in the heart and blood vessels. Chymase cleaves angiotensin I to form the peptide angiotensin II (4-8), which is a more potent vasoconstrictor than angiotensin II. The cleavage of angiotensin I by chymase also releases angiotensin II (1-7), which is a vasodilator. The inhibition of chymase may be a new way to treat heart disease.

T cell activation is a complex process that requires the interaction of the T cell receptor with antigen-MHC complex on an antigen-presenting cell. The T cell receptor complex is associated with the CD3 complex, which is responsible for the signal-transducing function of the receptor. The activation of T cells requires two signals, one provided by the T cell receptor and the other provided by the interaction of the costimulatory molecule CD2 8 with B7 on the antigen-presenting cell. The interaction of the T cell receptor with antigen-MHC complex induces a series of signaling events, including the activation of protein tyrosine kinases of the src and Syk families, the activation of phospholipase C, and the production of second messengers such as IP3 and diacylglycerol. The activation of protein tyrosine kinases leads to the tyrosine phosphorylation of several cellular substrates, including the adaptor protein LAT. LAT phosphorylation creates binding sites for the recruitment of other signaling molecules, including phospholipase C-gamma1, which is required for the production of the second messengers. The activation of protein kinase C and the production of IP3 and diacylglycerol lead to the activation of the transcription factors NF-AT and NF-kB, which are required for the activation of T cells. The interaction of the costimulatory molecule CD2 8 with its ligands on the antigen-presenting cell further enhances T cell activation. The activation of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase pathway by the costimulatory molecule provides an additional source of metabolic energy that is required for T cell activation.

The Wnt family of secreted glycoproteins are secreted factors that bind to cell surface receptors of the Frizzled family. Wnt signaling is involved in many developmental processes and is also involved in the development of cancer. Wnt signaling is involved in the development of cancer in a variety of tissues. Wnt signaling can lead to either activation or repression of transcription. In the absence of Wnt signaling, beta-catenin is phosphorylated by glycogen synthase kinase-3 (GSK-3) and is targeted for proteosomal degradation. Binding of Wnt to Frizzled leads to inhibition of GSK-3 and the accumulation of beta-catenin. Beta-catenin is then free to move into the nucleus and activate transcription. Wnt signaling can also lead to activation of the Map kinase pathway and the transcription factor NF-kB. Wnt signaling can also lead to the activation of the PI3 kinase pathway. Wnt signaling can also lead to the activation of the transcription factor NFAT. Wnt signaling can also lead to the activation of the transcription factor NFAT. Wnt signaling can also lead to the activation of the transcription factor DREAM.

Interleukin-6 (IL-6) is a cytokine that signals through a receptor complex that includes the beta-subunit of the IL-6 receptor and gp1 3 0. The gp1 3 0 receptor is a shared receptor with the receptor for IL-11and the LIF receptor. The JAK kinases are associated with the cytoplasmic domain of gp1 3 0 and are activated by ligand binding to gp1 3 0. The JAKs phosphorylate the receptor on tyrosine, creating binding sites for src homology 2 (SH2) containing proteins like STAT transcription factors. STAT factors are phosphorylated by JAK and dimerize in the nucleus to activate transcription. The ras / raf / MEK / MAP kinase pathway is also activated by IL-6 and leads to activation of transcription factors like AP-1. The JAK / STAT and ras / raf / MEK / MAP kinase pathways are activated by IL-6 in a coordinated fashion to activate transcription of genes like C-reactive protein.

The NFAT family of transcription factors plays a key role in the regulation of genes involved in the immune response. The NFAT proteins are regulated by a calcium-dependent signaling pathway that is activated by the antigen receptor on T cells and by other cell surface receptors. The NFAT proteins are retained in the cytoplasm of resting cells by interacting with the chaperone protein 1-4-3. Activation of the calcium signaling pathway leads to the activation of the phosphatase calcineurin, which dephosphorylates the NFAT proteins, causing them to migrate from 1-4-3 to the nucleus. In addition to regulating the subcellular localization of the NFAT proteins, calcium signaling also regulates the transcriptional activity of the NFAT proteins. The transcriptional activity of NFAT proteins is regulated by a variety of kinases, including the protein kinase C family members, the CaM kinase family members, and the casein kinase I family members. The activity of the NFAT proteins is also regulated by the binding of other transcription factors. The NFAT proteins interact with other transcription factors such as AP-1 and NF-AT family members to regulate genes involved in cytokine gene expression and the immune response.

The cell cycle is driven by the coordinated activity of cyclin dependent kinases (CDKs) and their cyclin regulatory subunits. The activity of CDKs is regulated by the phosphorylation of a conserved threonine residue in the catalytic domain and by the association of CDK inhibitors. The transition from G1 to S phase of the cell cycle is regulated by the activity of the cyclin D-CDK4 / 6 complex, which phosphorylates the Rb protein and related proteins, releasing the inhibition of E2F transcription factors. The activation of E2F transcription factors induces the expression of cyclin E, which forms a complex with CDK2 and phosphorylates Rb and related proteins, further releasing E2F. The activity of the cyclin E-CDK2 complex is also regulated by the CDK inhibitor p2 7Kip1. The ubiquitin-dependent proteolytic pathway plays an important role in regulating cell cycle progression. The addition of ubiquitin to proteins targets them for rapid degradation by the proteosome. The addition of ubiquitin is catalyzed by a multi-subunit enzyme known as the ubiquitin-activating enzyme (E1), which activates ubiquitin in an ATP-dependent reaction. Ubiquitin is transferred to a ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme (E2), and is then transferred to a substrate protein, usually with the participation of a ubiquitin protein ligase (E3). The transfer of ubiquitin to a protein is a three-step reaction. E1 first forms a high energy thioester bond with ubiquitin. E2 then interacts with E3, bringing it into close proximity with the substrate protein, and transfers ubiquitin to the substrate protein. Proteins that are tagged with ubiquitin are recognized by a multi-subunit protein complex known as the proteosome, and are degraded rapidly. The activity of the proteosome is itself regulated by the ubiquitin-like protein NEDD8. The addition of NEDD8 to a protein is analogous to the addition of ubiquitin, but the enzymes that catalyze the addition of NEDD8 and the substrates modified by NEDD8 are different from those involved in the addition of ubiquitin. NEDD8 is added to the cullin subunits of the SCF complex, a ubiquitin ligase complex that regulates cell cycle progression. The addition of NEDD8 to cullin increases the activity of the SCF complex, and may also increase the ability of the complex to recognize specific substrates.

The innate immune system is the first line of defense against invading pathogens. Pathogen recognition receptors (PRRs) are expressed by innate immune cells and recognize conserved microbial structures called pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs). The Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are a class of PRRs that recognize bacterial cell wall components such as lipopolysaccharide (LPS), peptidoglycan (PGN), and lipoproteins. Upon recognition of PAMPs, TLRs activate signaling pathways that culminate in the production of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines. The adaptor protein MyD8 8 is required for signaling by all TLRs with the exception of TLR3. TRIF is required for signaling by TLR3 and TLR4. TRIF-related adaptor molecule (TRAM) is required for signaling by TLR4, but not for signaling by TLR2 or TLR3. TRIF-related adaptor molecule (TIRAP) is required for signaling by TLR2 and TLR4, but not for signaling by TLR3. TRAF3 is required for signaling by all TLRs with the exception of TLR3. TRAF6 is required for signaling by all TLRs with the exception of TLR3. TRAF3 and TRAF6 activate the kinase map kinase (MKK) and the transcription factors NF-kB and AP-1. The production of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines is essential for the clearance of bacterial infection. Chronic activation of innate immune signaling can, however, result in tissue damage and inflammatory disease.

The chemokine receptor CCR5 and CCR2 are expressed on macrophages and T cells and act as coreceptors for macrophage-tropic HIV strains. The ligands for these receptors are the beta-chemokines RANTES, MIP-1alphaand MIP-1beta. beta-chemokines are chemotactic cytokines that direct the migration of leukocytes to sites of inflammation. The CCR5 and CCR2 genes are genetically associated with the rate of disease progression in HIV-infected individuals. The CCR5Delta3 2 mutation that results in a truncated, non-functional receptor is found in approximately 3% of Caucasians. Individuals homozygous for the CCR5Delta3 2 mutation are highly resistant to HIV infection. The CCR2-64I mutation that results in a non-conservative amino acid change in the CCR2 receptor is also associated with delayed progression to AIDS. The CCR5Delta3 2 and CCR2-64I mutations are in strong linkage disequilibrium with each other. The protective effect of these mutations is due to the absence of the CCR5 and CCR2 receptors on the surfaces of cells expressing these mutant genes. The CCR5Delta3 2 mutation is found in approximately 1% of Caucasians and is found at a higher frequency in individuals of European and American descent. The CCR2-64I mutation is found at a higher frequency in individuals of Asian descent.

The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a member of the ErbB family of receptor tyrosine kinases. The binding of EGF or other ligands to the extracellular domain of the receptor induces receptor dimerization and activation of the cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase domain. The activation of the receptor tyrosine kinase leads to the recruitment of signaling molecules to the receptor and the activation of downstream signaling pathways. The Ras-Map kinase pathway and the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI-3K) pathway are two major signaling pathways that are activated by the EGFR. Ras activates the Raf-1 kinase, which in turn activates the MAP kinase cascade. The activated Map kinases phosphorylate and activate transcription factors such as ELK-1 and SRF. The PI-3K pathway leads to the activation of AKT and other kinases. The Crk adaptor proteins are substrates of the EGFR and may link the EGFR to other signaling pathways.

Fc epsilon RI is a multi-subunit receptor that plays a key role in allergic responses. The crosslinking of Fc epsilon RI by antigen-antibody complexes on the surface of mast cells leads to the release of inflammatory mediators. This process is known as mast cell activation. The activation of mast cells is also important in host defense mechanisms such as the response to parasites. The activation of mast cells is initiated by the aggregation of Fc epsilon RI and the subsequent activation of signaling pathways. The activation of mast cells is also affected by other signaling pathways. In this chapter we will discuss the role of signaling pathways in mast cell activation. We will first discuss the activation of Fc epsilon RI and the role of this receptor in mast cell activation. We will then discuss the role of signaling pathways downstream of Fc epsilon RI in mast cell activation. We will discuss the role of calcium in mast cell activation and the role of calcium in signaling pathways. We will also discuss the role of the tyrosine kinases Lyn and Syk in mast cell activation. We will discuss the role of the MAP kinase pathway in mast cell activation and the role of the transcription factor AP-1 in mast cell activation. We will also discuss the role of the lipid second messenger IP3 in mast cell activation and the role of the lipid kinase PI3 kinase in mast cell activation.

TNF is a cytokine that induces apoptosis in some cells and is involved in inflammatory signaling. TNF binds to two receptors, TNFR1 and TNFR2, which are members of the TNF receptor gene family. Binding of TNF to TNFR1 activates two signaling pathways, one that leads to apoptosis and one that activates transcription factors that induce inflammatory signaling. The apoptotic pathway is activated by TNFR1-associated death domain protein (TRADD) and receptor interacting protein (RIP). TRADD and RIP recruit the protein kinases RIP and TNF receptor-associated factor 2 (TRAF-2). RIP and TRAF-2 activate the caspase 8 pathway that leads to apoptosis. Activation of NF-kB by TNF is blocked by the I-kappa kinase complex, which contains the kinases RIP, TRAF-2, and the I-kappa kinase subunit I-kappa kinase-associated protein (IKAP). The I-kappa kinase phosphorylates I-kappa B, causing I-kappa B to dissociate from NF-kB and allow NF-kB to translocate to the nucleus to activate transcription. The TRAF-2 component of the I-kappa kinase also activates Map kinases that activate transcription factors such as c-Jun.

The peptide hormone angiotensin II (Ang II) is a key regulator of blood pressure and fluid homeostasis. Ang II is generated by the proteolytic cleavage of the precursor angiotensinogen by the protease renin. Ang II exerts its actions through two different G-protein coupled receptors, AT1 and AT2. The AT1 receptor couples to Gq / 1 1 to activate phospholipase C, which cleaves phosphatidylinositol 4, 5-bisphosphate to produce inositol 1, 4, 5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol. IP3 causes release of intracellular calcium, and diacylglycerol activates protein kinase C (PKC). PKC activation and calcium influx stimulate the activity of the Na + / H + exchanger, leading to an increase in intracellular sodium and a subsequent increase in blood pressure. DAG activates the Ras / Raf-1 / MEK / ERK pathway, leading to activation of the transcription factor AP-1 and subsequent regulation of gene expression. The AT2 receptor is coupled to the G protein Gi, which inhibits adenylyl cyclase and leads to a decrease in cAMP. The activation of the AT2 receptor also leads to activation of the Src family of tyrosine kinases and subsequent activation of the Ras / Raf-1 / MEK / ERK pathway.

Sprouty proteins are a family of proteins that act as inhibitors of signaling by growth factor receptors. Sprouty proteins inhibit signaling by growth factor receptors such as the fibroblast growth factor (FGF), epidermal growth factor (EGF), and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) receptors. Sprouty proteins inhibit signaling by blocking the activation of the Ras / MAP kinase pathway by growth factor receptors. Sprouty proteins do not inhibit the binding of growth factor to its receptor, but inhibit the tyrosine phosphorylation of the adaptor protein GRB2 and the subsequent activation of Ras by the Grb2 / Sos-1 complex. Sprouty proteins interact with the GRB2-associated binding protein (Gab1) and inhibit the association of Gab1 with the tyrosine kinase MET. Sprouty proteins also interact with Cbl, an E3 ubiquitin ligase that interacts with the tyrosine kinase receptors to target them for degradation. Sprouty proteins interact with Cbl through a tyrosine-phosphorylated tyrosine residue in the amino terminus of Sprouty. Interaction of Sprouty with Cbl increases the stability of Cbl and increases its ability to ubiquitinate and down-regulate the growth factor receptors. Sprouty proteins also interact with the protein kinase Raf-1 and inhibit the activation of Raf-1. The interaction of Sprouty with Raf-1 appears to be indirect and may involve an adaptor protein. Sprouty proteins also interact with the lipid kinase PI3 kinase and inhibit the activation of PI3 kinase by growth factor receptors. The interaction of Sprouty with PI3 kinase may be important in the inhibition of the MAP kinase pathway by Sprouty.

Vasoconstrictor agents acting on GPCRs in the vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) cause the release of Ca2 + from intracellular stores and entry of Ca2 + from the extracellular space. The increase in intracellular Ca2 + concentration ([Ca2 +] i) is a major signal for activation of contractile proteins, leading to contraction. The initial Ca2 + release is due to the activation of the inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate receptor (InsP3R) by the second messenger IP3. The subsequent Ca2 + entry is mediated by voltage-operated Ca2 + channels (VOCs) and receptor-operated Ca2 + channels (ROCs). The VOCs are activated by membrane depolarization, which is caused by inhibition of the large conductance Ca2 + -activated K + channels (BK channels) and / or activation of non-selective cation channels (NSCCs). The NSCCs are activated by depletion of intracellular Ca2 + stores and / or by a direct interaction of the Ca2 + -sensing receptor (CaR) with the ryanodine receptor (RyR). The CaR is also involved in the activation of phospholipase A2 (PLA2) and subsequent production of arachidonic acid (AA), which is metabolized to the vasoconstrictor eicosanoids. The RhoA / Rho kinase pathway is involved in the regulation of the Ca2 + sensitivity of contractile proteins. The Ca2 + sensitivity is determined by the ratio of GTP-bound active form of RhoA to GDP-bound inactive form of RhoA. The Ca2 + sensitivity is increased by the activation of the RhoA / Rho kinase pathway, which phosphorylates myosin phosphatase (MLCP) and its regulatory subunit myosin light chain (MLC) kinase (MLCK). The Ca2 + sensitization induced by the RhoA / Rho kinase pathway is inhibited by the cAMP / protein kinase A (PKA) pathway. The cAMP / PKA pathway inhibits the Ca2 + sensitization by phosphorylating the InsP3R and / or the RhoA / Rho kinase pathway.

The G2 / M DNA damage checkpoint prevents cells with damaged DNA from entering mitosis. This checkpoint is activated by DNA damage and results in inhibition of the Cdc2-cyclin B complex, which is required for entry into mitosis. The protein kinase Chk1 is activated by the DNA damage checkpoint and phosphorylates and inhibits the Cdc2 5C phosphatase, which dephosphorylates and activates Cdc2. The protein kinase Chk2 is also activated by DNA damage and phosphorylates Cdc2 5C, but it is not required for the DNA damage checkpoint. Instead, Chk2 activates the transcriptional program of genes that includes the cell cycle inhibitor p53, which in turn inhibits the Cdc2-cyclin B complex. The DNA damage checkpoint also inhibits the degradation of p53, which is required for the activation of the Cdc2-cyclin B complex. The DNA damage checkpoint also inhibits the transcription of genes that promote the progression of mitosis. The p53 gene product inhibits the transcription of these genes by preventing the activation of the transcription factor E2F. The DNA damage checkpoint also inhibits the transcription of the Cdc2 gene itself, which is required for the activation of the Cdc2-cyclin B complex.

Thrombin is a serine protease that plays a key role in blood coagulation. It cleaves fibrinogen to form fibrin, which is then degraded to release platelets. Thrombin also has a number of other effects in cells, including activation of platelets, proliferation of cells, and regulation of gene expression. The effects of thrombin are mediated by protease-activated receptors (PARs). Four PARs have been identified, PAR1, PAR2, PAR3, and PAR4. Each of these PARs has an extracellular N-terminus that is cleaved by thrombin to reveal a new N-terminus that acts as a ligand for a second receptor. PAR1 and PAR4 are cleaved by thrombin, but PAR3 is not. The tethered ligand sequence for PAR1 is SFLLRN, and the tethered ligand sequence for PAR4 is GYPGQV. Synthetic peptides with these sequences activate the receptors and can also be used to study the actions of the tethered ligands in the intact protein. PAR1 and PAR4 are cleaved and activated at similar rates by thrombin, but PAR4 has a higher affinity for the tethered ligand than does PAR1. The tethered ligand for PAR2 is SLIGRL, and cleavage of PAR3 does not activate G proteins. The tethered ligands for PAR1 and PAR4 are stable for many hours in the absence of protease inhibitors, but the peptide ligands are rapidly cleaved and inactivated by the protease inhibitor antithrombin III and alpha-macroglobulin. The continued presence of the tethered ligands can activate PAR signaling, so that the proteases can act in an autocrine or paracrine manner. The tethered ligands for PAR1 and PAR4 activate G protein-coupled signaling pathways, but PAR4 also signals through a G-protein-independent pathway involving beta-arrestin and the tyrosine kinase Pyk2. The G protein-independent pathway requires tyrosine phosphorylation of beta-arrestin by the Src kinase, recruitment of Pyk2, and activation of the small G protein Rac1. Rac1 activation leads to reorganization of the actin cytoskeleton and formation of lamellipodia, which are involved in cell motility and migration. The G protein-dependent pathway leads to activation of the protein kinase C (PKC) isoforms alpha, beta, and gamma, which are involved in platelet activation and proliferation of cells. The role of PAR4 in platelet activation is not clear, but it is thought to play a role in the initial activation of platelets by low concentrations of thrombin.

Angiotensin II (Ang II) is a key regulator of blood pressure and volume homeostasis. Ang II exerts its effects through two receptors, AT1 and AT2. The AT1 receptor is coupled to Gq / 1 1 proteins and activation of phospholipase C, inositol phosphate formation and intracellular calcium release. Ang II also activates the MAP kinase pathway through Gi / o proteins and ras. Ang II also activates the tyrosine kinase pathway through the AT1 receptor. The tyrosine kinase pathway leads to the activation of the MAP kinase pathway and the stimulation of immediate early genes such as c-fos. The activation of these genes leads to long term effects such as cell proliferation and differentiation. The AT1 receptor also couples to Gi / o proteins and activates the MAP kinase pathway through this pathway. This pathway is independent of Gi / o proteins and is mediated by tyrosine phosphorylation of the EGF receptor. The activation of the tyrosine kinase pathway by Ang II is mediated by the formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS). Ang II also activates the c-fos gene through the AT1 receptor through a pathway involving protein kinase C and the EGF receptor. The activation of the c-fos gene by Ang II through this pathway leads to the formation of AP-1 transcription factor complexes and the stimulation of genes containing AP-1 binding sites. The activation of AP-1 by Ang II through this pathway may play a role in the long term effects of Ang II such as cell proliferation and differentiation.

TGF-beta signaling is involved in a variety of cellular processes including proliferation, differentiation, apoptosis, and migration. TGF-beta signaling is initiated by ligand binding to TGF-beta receptors, which in turn phosphorylate the receptor-activated SMAD (R-SMAD) proteins, SMAD2 and SMAD3. SMAD2 and SMAD3 are phosphorylated by the TGF-beta type I receptor ALK5, while SMAD1, SMAD5, and SMAD8 are phosphorylated by the TGF-beta type II receptor. The phosphorylated SMADs form a complex with the co-SMAD, SMAD4, and this complex then translocates to the nucleus to regulate transcription. SMAD-independent signaling by TGF-beta also occurs, including activation of the MAPK pathways.

Wnt proteins are secreted glycoproteins that bind to cell surface receptors of the Frizzled family. Wnt signaling is involved in a variety of developmental processes including axis formation, cell fate specification, and tissue patterning. Wnt signaling is also involved in the regulation of cell proliferation and apoptosis. Wnt signaling is activated by binding of Wnt to Frizzled, which leads to the stabilization of beta-catenin. In the absence of Wnt signaling, beta-catenin is phosphorylated by glycogen synthase kinase-3 (GSK-3) and is targeted for degradation by the ubiquitin-dependent proteasome pathway. Binding of Wnt to Frizzled leads to inhibition of GSK-3, resulting in stabilization of beta-catenin. Beta-catenin is then able to complex with members of the LEF / TCF family of transcription factors and activate transcription of Wnt-responsive genes. Wnt signaling is inhibited by members of the Dkk family of secreted proteins. Wnt signaling is also inhibited by members of the Fz family of receptors. Wnt signaling is also inhibited by the APC tumor suppressor protein. Mutations in APC lead to constitutive activation of beta-catenin and constitutive activation of Wnt-regulated genes. Mutations in beta-catenin that prevent its phosphorylation and degradation by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway also lead to constitutive activation of Wnt-regulated genes. Wnt signaling leads to the stabilization of beta-catenin, which is able to complex with LEF / TCF transcription factors and activate transcription of Wnt-regulated genes. Wnt signaling is also regulated by the TCF family member LEF1. LEF1 is expressed in the developing central nervous system, but is not expressed in the developing intestine. Wnt signaling in the developing intestine leads to the activation of cdx-2 and msx-4, which activate expression of the homeobox gene PDX-1. PDX-1 is a transcription factor that is required for expression of insulin and other pancreatic hormones.

Homologous recombination (HR) is a mechanism for the accurate repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs). HR requires the generation of a single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) molecule at the site of the DSB, followed by the search for a homologous DNA sequence and the formation of a joint molecule (Holliday junction), which is resolved either by a synthesis-dependent strand-annealing mechanism or by a Holliday junction-specific branch migration mechanism. The strand exchange protein Rad5 1 plays a central role in HR by catalyzing the formation of a nucleoprotein filament on ssDNA that searches for and invades a homologous double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) sequence, forming a stable synaptic complex that can then be extended by DNA synthesis. The strand exchange protein Rad5 4 and the Swi2 / Snf2-like ATPase Rad5 4B stimulate the activity of Rad5 1 in vitro. The Holliday junction is then resolved by structure-specific endonucleases or by branch migration of the junction, followed by either of the two resolution mechanisms.

The formation of metastases by cancer cells is a multi-step process involving local invasion, intravasation, transport through the vasculature, extravasation, and growth at a distant site. The epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT) is a key step in the process of metastasis. During EMT, epithelial cells lose their polarity and cell-cell adhesions, and gain a mesenchymal phenotype. The transcription factors Snail, Slug, and Twist are key regulators of EMT. They repress the expression of E-cadherin, a key cell adhesion molecule, and other epithelial genes, and induce the expression of mesenchymal genes. The induction of EMT by these transcription factors is associated with increased motility and invasiveness. The expression of Snail and Twist is regulated by the extracellular signals TGF-beta and EGF, and by the intracellular signaling pathways PI3K / Akt, MAPK, and GSK-3. The induction of EMT by these transcription factors is associated with the development of cancer stem cells. The induction of EMT by these transcription factors is also associated with the resistance of cancer cells to chemotherapy and radiation. The induction of EMT by these transcription factors also contributes to the development of therapeutic resistance. The induction of EMT by these transcription factors also contributes to the development of cancer stem cells. The induction of EMT by these transcription factors also contributes to the development of therapeutic resistance. The induction of EMT by these transcription factors contributes to the development of therapeutic resistance. The induction of EMT by these transcription factors also contributes to the development of cancer stem cells. The induction of EMT by these transcription factors also contributes to the development of therapeutic resistance.

Cutaneous melanoma is a highly aggressive malignancy that arises from the transformation of normal melanocytes. The incidence of melanoma has increased dramatically in the past several decades, with a corresponding increase in mortality. The risk of developing melanoma is increased by exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation, and the prognosis is poor once metastases have occurred. The pathogenesis of melanoma is complex and is influenced by both genetic and environmental factors. The identification of genes that are involved in the development of melanoma has provided important insights into the molecular mechanisms of melanoma. The CDKN2A gene encodes two distinct tumor suppressor proteins, p16INK4A and p19ARF, that are involved in cell cycle regulation and apoptosis, respectively. Germline mutations in CDKN2A are found in a high percentage of families with a high incidence of melanoma. The CDK4 gene encodes a protein that binds to and inhibits the function of p16INK4A. The activating mutations in the NRAS and BRAF genes are found in a high percentage of melanomas. The MITF gene encodes a basic helix-loop-helix-leucine zipper transcription factor that is involved in the regulation of cell cycle progression and differentiation of melanocytes. The identification of the genes involved in the development of melanoma has provided important insights into the molecular mechanisms of melanoma. The identification of genes that are involved in the development of melanoma has provided important insights into the molecular mechanisms of melanoma. The identification of genes that are involved in the development of melanoma has provided important insights into the molecular mechanisms of melanoma. The identification of genes that are involved in the development of melanoma has provided important insights into the molecular mechanisms of melanoma. The CDKN2A gene encodes two distinct tumor suppressor proteins, p16INK4A and p19ARF, that are involved in cell cycle regulation and apoptosis, respectively. The CDK4 gene encodes a protein that binds to and inhibits the function of p16INK4A. The activating mutations in the NRAS and BRAF genes are involved in the MAPK pathway. The MITF gene encodes a basic helix-loop-helix-leucine zipper transcription factor that is involved in the regulation of cell cycle progression and differentiation of melanocytes.

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is a heterogeneous group of neoplasms originating from the renal epithelium. The two most common histologic subtypes of RCC are conventional (clear cell) RCC (CCRCC) and papillary RCC (pRCC). Approximately 5% of RCC are chromophobe RCC, and collecting duct carcinoma is rare. Approximately 1 0% of RCC are unclassified. The molecular pathogenesis of RCC is complex and heterogeneous. The VHL tumor suppressor gene is inactivated in the majority of patients with CCRCC. Hereditary papillary RCC (HPRC) is associated with germline mutations of the MET oncogene. Loss of the p163 VHL gene product leads to accumulation of the hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs), which activate genes involved in angiogenesis and glycolysis. Activating mutations of the MET oncogene lead to constitutive activation of the HGF / SF receptor tyrosine kinase and the downstream signaling pathways. Activation of the MET oncogene also leads to loss of p163 VHL, resulting in increased HIF levels. The VHL and MET pathways converge on the hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) pathway, which plays a central role in the pathogenesis of CCRCC and HPRC. The molecular pathogenesis of pRCC is less well characterized. Activating mutations of the beta-catenin gene have been identified in a small subset of patients with pRCC. Loss of p163 VHL may also contribute to the pathogenesis of pRCC.

The renin-angiotensin system (RAS) is a hormonal cascade that plays a key role in the regulation of blood pressure and fluid homeostasis. Angiotensis II (Ang II) is the final product of this system and is a potent vasoconstrictor. It is also a growth factor and a mitogen. The RAS is comprised of two major components, renin, the enzyme that cleaves prorenin to form Ang I, and the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) that cleaves Ang I to form the active peptide Ang II. ACE is also known as kininase II and cleaves bradykinin, a vasodilator peptide, to inactive peptide bradykinin. ACE is a zinc metallopeptidase that cleaves a dipeptide from the N-terminus of several peptides, including Ang I and bradykinin. The RAS is a classic endocrine system, with the plasma RAS acting as a circulating hormone. However, the components of the RAS are also found in many tissues, where they act as local hormones. Ang II is also formed from the nonapeptide angiotensin I (AngI) by the action of thelarge protease cathepsin D. AngI is formed in tissues by the action of tissue-specific aspartyl proteases, thelarge proteases. The formation of Ang II in tissues is regulated by the balance between the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), which converts AngI to Ang II, and the thelarge protease cathepsin D, which degrades AngI to form the ACE-resistant heptapeptide angiotensin (1-7) (Ang- (1-7)). Ang- (1-7) is a biologically active peptide that is formed from AngI by the action of ACE-independent pathway. The actions of Ang II are mediated by two types of receptors, AT1 and AT2. AT1 receptors are coupled to Gq / 1 1 proteins and activate phospholipase C, resulting in the release of intracellular calcium and the activation of protein kinase C. The AT2 receptor is a G-protein-coupled receptor that is coupled to Gi / o proteins. The AT2 receptor is widely expressed in the developing heart and vasculature, and its expression is upregulated in pathological conditions such as heart failure and atherosclerosis. Ang II also stimulates reactive oxygen species (ROS) production through the activation of NADPH oxidase. Ang II also stimulates the tyrosine phosphorylation of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and the subsequent activation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway. Ang II-induced cardiac hypertrophy is mediated by the AT1 receptor and involves the activation of the extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) and c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) pathways. Ang II also stimulates the expression of c-fos and egr-1, which are involved in the regulation of gene expression. Ang II also stimulates the tyrosine phosphorylation of the EGF receptor and the subsequent activation of the MAPK pathway. The activation of the EGF receptor and the subsequent stimulation of the MAPK pathway by Ang II may be involved in the development of atherosclerosis.

The T cell receptor (TCR) is a complex of polypeptides that is expressed on the surface of T cells and is responsible for recognizing foreign antigens presented by MHC-1 molecules on the surface of other cells. The TCR is composed of two subunits, the clonotypic alpha beta heterodimer and the invariant CD3 polypeptides gamma delta epsilon zeta that noncovalently associate to form the TCR / CD3 complex. The CD3 polypeptides are transmembrane proteins that associate with the TCR complex in the membrane and are responsible for the signal transduction events that result in T cell activation. The clonotypic alpha beta heterodimer is responsible for recognizing specific antigens and is expressed on the surface of T cells only when associated with the CD3 polypeptides. The CD3 polypeptides do not have intrinsic enzymatic activity but associate with protein kinases that are involved in the transduction of the antigen-induced T cell activation signal. The activation of T cells by antigen is dependent on the interaction of the clonotypic alpha beta heterodimer with MHC-1 molecules on the surface of antigen-presenting cells. The interaction of the TCR with MHC-1 and the interaction of the TCR with antigen results in the aggregation of the TCR and the recruitment of the CD3 polypeptides to the TCR complex. The aggregation of the TCR and the recruitment of the CD3 polypeptides leads to the activation of the protein tyrosine kinases Lck and Fyn and the subsequent phosphorylation of the CD3 polypeptides and the TCR. The activation of Lck and Fyn leads to the phosphorylation of other proteins involved in T cell activation, including the tyrosine kinase ZAP-7 0. The phosphorylation of the TCR and the CD3 polypeptides creates binding sites for other signaling molecules and leads to the activation of downstream signaling pathways that result in T cell activation.

Mast cells are specialized cells of hematopoietic origin that play a key role in the immune response by releasing a variety of preformed and newly synthesized lipid-derived mediators, such as leukotrienes and prostaglandins, and cytokines, such as histamine and TNF-alpha, upon activation. The activation of mast cells by allergens, such as pollen, or by specific antigens (allergens) is responsible for the development of allergic diseases, such as asthma, rhinitis, and food allergy. The activation of mast cells by cross-linking of the high affinity IgE receptor (FcepsilonRI) by allergens leads to the release of preformed mediators by degranulation. The de novo synthesis of lipid mediators is triggered by the activation of phospholipase A2 (PLA2) and the subsequent release of membrane phospholipids, which are mainly phosphatidylcholine (PC) and sphingomyelin (SM). The activation of the lipid kinase phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) and the subsequent activation of the serine-threonine kinase AKT (also known as protein kinase B) are also involved in this process. The activation of PLA2 liberates arachidonic acid (AA), the first and rate-limiting step in the synthesis of eicosanoids. The subsequent metabolism of AA by the 5-lipoxygenase (5-LO) pathway leads to the synthesis of the leukotrienes (LTC4, LTD4, and LTE4), which are potent inflammatory mediators. The metabolism of AA by the cyclooxygenase (COX) pathway leads to the synthesis of prostaglandins (PGD2, PGE2, PGF2, and PGI2), which are involved in many physiological processes, including the regulation of the cardiovascular system and the immune response.

Fanconi anemia (FA) is a genetically heterogeneous disorder characterized by congenital abnormalities, progressive bone marrow failure, and predisposition to cancer. Cells from FA patients are highly sensitive to DNA crosslinking agents such as mitomycin C (MMC) and exhibit chromosomal instability. At the cellular level, FA cells are characterized by a defect in the G2 / M cell cycle checkpoint and a high frequency of spontaneous chromosomal aberrations. FA is genetically heterogeneous and at least eight complementation groups have been identified (A through H). The genes for the complementation groups A, C, E, F, G, and L have been cloned and characterized. These genes encode proteins that are involved in the cellular response to DNA damage. In response to DNA damage, the FA proteins FANC-A, -C, -E, and -G form a nuclear complex that activates the downstream FA protein, FANCD2. The activation of FANCD2 requires the FA proteins A, C, E, F, and G, and is regulated by the ATM checkpoint kinase. The downstream targets of the FA pathway include BRCA1, BRCA2, and the RAD5 1 protein. The role of the FA proteins in DNA repair is not yet clear, but it is likely that the FA proteins are involved in the repair of DNA crosslinks.

Adiponectin is an adipocyte-specific protein, which is exclusively present in the plasma as oligomers (trimers, hexamers, and HMW forms). Plasma levels of adiponectin are inversely correlated with obesity and insulin resistance. Adiponectin exerts its insulin-sensitizing and anti-atherosclerotic actions through its receptors in muscle and liver. The adiponectin receptors are structurally distinct from those of other cytokines. The globular form of adiponectin is able to activate the AMPK pathway in muscle cells. The activation of AMPK by adiponectin leads to an increase in fatty acid oxidation and glucose uptake. The hexameric and HMW forms of adiponectin bind to the cell-surface receptors, activating the AMPK pathway in muscle cells. The trimeric form of adiponectin binds to the receptor, activating the tyrosine kinase-based insulin signaling pathway in muscle cells. The hexameric and HMW forms of adiponectin also activate the AMPK pathway in liver cells. The activation of AMPK by adiponectin leads to an increase in fatty acid oxidation and glucose uptake.

The Wnt family of secreted glycoproteins are secreted glycoproteins that regulate development and cell fate. Wnt signaling is involved in a variety of cellular processes including cell fate, cell adhesion, cell motility, and cell proliferation. The Wnt family of secreted glycoproteins binds to cell surface receptors Frizzled and LRP5 / 6. Wnt binding to Frizzled leads to the inhibition of glycogen synthase kinase-3 (GSK-3), which phosphorylates beta-catenin, targeting it for ubiquitination and proteosomal degradation. Wnt binding to Frizzled also activates the phosphoprotein Disheveled, which inhibits the APC tumor suppressor protein. APC acts as a scaffold protein to recruit beta-catenin to the axin complex, where beta-catenin is phosphorylated by GSK-3. Phosphorylation of beta-catenin targets it for ubiquitination and proteosomal degradation. Inhibition of GSK-3 by Wnt signaling leads to the accumulation of beta-catenin in the cytoplasm, where it can move to the nucleus and interact with members of the TCF / LEF family of transcription factors to activate transcription of Wnt responsive genes. Wnt signaling also regulates the subcellular localization of beta-catenin. Wnt signaling causes the accumulation of beta-catenin in the cytoplasm, but prevents its translocation to the nucleus. Wnt signaling also regulates the subcellular localization of GSK-3. Wnt signaling inhibits GSK-3 in the cytoplasm, but activates GSK-3 in the nucleus. Wnt signaling also regulates the subcellular localization of beta-catenin. Wnt signaling inhibits GSK-3 in the cytoplasm, but activates GSK-3 in the nucleus. Wnt signaling causes the accumulation of beta-catenin in the cytoplasm, but prevents its translocation to the nucleus. Wnt signaling also regulates the subcellular localization of APC. Wnt signaling inhibits GSK-3 in the cytoplasm, but activates GSK-3 in the nucleus. Wnt signaling also regulates the subcellular localization of APC. Wnt signaling causes the accumulation of beta-catenin in the cytoplasm, but prevents its translocation to the nucleus. APC is required for the cytoplasmic localization of beta-catenin, and APC is required for the nuclear localization of beta-catenin.

The interaction of leukocytes with the endothelium is a key step in the inflammatory response. The adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium is mediated by a family of cell adhesion molecules (CAMs). The endothelial cell adhesion molecules ICAM-1, VCAM-1 and MAdCAM-1 bind to leukocyte integrins LFA-1, Mac-1 and VLA-4. The interaction of PECAM-1 with the integrin VE-cadherin mediates the formation of endothelial cell junctions and also acts as an adhesion molecule for leukocytes. The interaction of P-Selectin with P-Selectin Glycoprotein on the leukocyte surface mediates the initial adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium. The rolling of leukocytes on the endothelium is mediated by the interaction of P- Selectin with its ligand PSGL-1. The rolling leukocytes are then activated by chemokines expressed by the endothelium to adhere firmly and migrate into the tissue.

Cutaneous melanoma is a significant health problem in the United States. The incidence of melanoma has been steadily increasing over the past several decades. The mortality rate from melanoma is high, with approximately 50% of patients dying from their disease. The incidence of melanoma is increasing at a faster rate than that of any other cancer. The identification of high-risk populations and early detection of melanoma are critical to reducing the morbidity and mortality associated with this disease. The incidence of melanoma is strongly associated with the number of acquired melanocytic nevi (AMN). Persons with more than 1 AMN are at increased risk for melanoma. The identification of individuals with a high risk of developing melanoma, such as those with a family history of melanoma or multiple atypical nevi, can be used to target prevention efforts. The identification of genes involved in melanoma susceptibility has provided important insights into the molecular pathogenesis of this disease. The CDKN2A gene encodes 2 tumor suppressor proteins, p16INK4A and p14ARF, that regulate the cell cycle and apoptotic pathways, respectively. Germline mutations in CDKN2A are found in approximately 20% of melanoma-prone families. The role of CDKN2A in sporadic melanoma is less clear. The role of CDK4 in melanoma is supported by the discovery of activating mutations in this gene in melanoma. The MC1R gene encodes a G-protein coupled receptor that regulates the production of melanin in melanocytes. MC1R variants are associated with red hair, pale skin, and blue eyes and are associated with increased melanoma risk. MC1R variants may also alter the response of melanocytes to ultraviolet radiation. The identification of high-risk individuals and the development of effective prevention strategies will help to reduce the incidence of melanoma.

The G2 / M DNA damage checkpoint prevents the cell from entering mitosis if the genome is damaged. The checkpoint kinase ATM (ataxia telangiectasia mutated) is activated by DNA damage and phosphorylates the checkpoint kinase Chk2. Phosphorylated Chk2 in turn phosphorylates Cdc2 5C, which then dephosphorylates and activates the cyclin dependent kinase Cdk1 / Cdc2. The activation of Cdk1 / Cdc2 causes the cell to arrest in G2 and to prepare for repair of the damaged DNA. The phosphatase Cdc2 5C is a key regulator of the G2 / M checkpoint. When phosphorylated by checkpoint kinases, Cdc2 5C is sequestered in the cytoplasm by 1 4-3-3 proteins, and is thus unable to activate Cdk1 / Cdc2. The activity of the ubiquitin ligase APC / C is required for the transition from G2 into mitosis. The APC / C is active from G2 until the completion of DNA repair, when it is inhibited by the checkpoint kinases Chk1 and Cds1. The APC / C inhibitor Emi2 is a target of the checkpoint kinases and is degraded in an APC / C-dependent manner. Emi2 prevents the activation of Cdk1 / Cdc2 until the damage is repaired.

The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a chloride channel that is mutated in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF). CFTR is expressed in the apical membrane of secretory epithelia, including the airways, intestine, and exocrine glands. The most common mutation in CFTR is a deletion of a single phenylalanine residue at position 5 0 8 (deltaF5 0 8). This mutation results in a protein that is improperly processed and rapidly degraded. The loss of CFTR function in secretory epithelia leads to the symptoms of CF. The second most common mutation is a single amino acid change, G5 1 2X, that results in a truncated protein that is not transported to the cell surface. The cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA) and protein kinase C (PKC) stimulate the activity of wild-type CFTR. The G5 5 1D- and deltaF5 0 8-CFTR are also activated by PKA and PKC, but are less responsive than wild-type CFTR. The G5 5 1D-CFTR is not activated by PKA. The G5 5 1D- and deltaF5 0 8-CFTR are also less responsive to ATP than wild-type CFTR. The NHERF family of PDZ scaffold proteins (Na + / H + exchanger regulatory factor 1, NHERF-1; E3KARP; ERM-binding phosphoprotein 5 0, EBP5 0) interact with the C-terminus of CFTR. The interaction of CFTR with NHERF-1 may be involved in the regulation of CFTR channel activity and the endocytosis of CFTR. The disruption of the interaction of CFTR with NHERF-1 may provide a therapeutic strategy for CF.

The cell cycle is a sequence of events that occur in a sequence of discrete regulatory phases known as the G1, S, G2 and M phases. The G1 phase is the resting phase and precedes the S, G2 and M phases. The G1 phase is the period of preparation for the cell to enter the rest of the cell cycle. The restriction point, or R point, is a key regulatory point in the cell cycle. The restriction point determines the restriction of the cell to enter S phase. The restriction point is located at the boundary between the G1 and S phases. The initiation of DNA synthesis is the critical event that marks the completion of the G1 phase. The restriction point is regulated by the retinoblastoma protein (Rb) and its family members, the cyclins and the cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs). The CDKs are a family of serine / threonine protein kinases that are activated by binding to regulatory subunits, cyclins. The activity of CDKs is negatively regulated by CDK inhibitors (CKIs). The CKIs are a group of proteins that inhibit the activity of CDKs. The activity of the CDKs is positively regulated by the cyclins and the transcription factor E2F. The activity of the CKIs is negatively regulated by the ubiquitin-mediated proteosome pathway. The ubiquitin-mediated proteosome pathway targets proteins for degradation by the proteosome. The destruction of the CKIs by the proteosome releases the inhibition of the CDKs. The E2F-Rb pathway is a key regulatory pathway that controls the progression of cells through the cell cycle. The Rb protein is a tumor suppressor that regulates the cell cycle by blocking the activity of the E2F transcription factor. The phosphorylation of Rb by the CDKs dissociates Rb from E2F, allowing it to activate genes required for DNA replication. The activity of the CDKs is also regulated by the CKIs. The activity of the CDKs is positively regulated by the cyclins and negatively regulated by the CKIs.

The cell cycle is regulated by a series of cyclin dependent kinases (Cdks) that are activated by binding to cyclins. The Cdks phosphorylate key substrates to regulate the cell cycle. The Cdks include Cdk2 / cyclin E and Cdk2 / cyclin A in the G1 to S phase transition, and Cdk2 / cyclin A in S phase and G2. The E2F family of transcription factors regulates genes involved in DNA replication and S phase progression. The Rb protein binds to E2F and represses transcription. Phosphorylation of Rb by the Cdks causes the release of E2F, and activation of E2F-regulated genes. The S phase cyclins, cyclin A and cyclin E, are required for S phase entry, and are required to maintain S phase. The ubiquitin ligase complex that targets the Cdks and the Rb protein for degradation is the anaphase promoting complex or cyclosome (APC / C). The APC / C is active from mitosis through G1, targeting proteins such as the cyclins for degradation by the ubiquitin pathway. The APC / C is inhibited by the early mitotic inhibitor 1 (Emi1) until the metaphase to anaphase transition. The APC / C also targets the S and M phase cyclins for degradation, preventing their accumulation until the following G1 phase. The APC / C is inhibited by the early mitotic checkpoint protein (Emi2) until the completion of mitosis.

The T cell receptor (TCR) complex is a multisubunit complex that is expressed on the surface of T cells and is involved in the recognition of foreign antigen bound to MHC-1 molecules on the surface of antigen-presenting cells (APCs). The TCR complex is composed of three polypeptide chains, alpha, beta, and gamma.
