A-ketoglutarate is a key metabolite that is converted to glutamate by the enzyme glutamate dehydrogenase. Glutamate is converted to glutamine by the enzyme glutamine synthetase. Glutamine is transported out of the cell and is converted back to glutamate by the enzyme glutamate synthase. Glutamate is converted to the amino acids aspartate and proline, which are important for protein synthesis and the osmotic regulation of cells, respectively. The enzyme glutamate dehydrogenase also plays a key role in regulating the flow of carbon through the TCA cycle. When the supply of amino acids is limited, glutamate dehydrogenase converts glutamate to a-ketoglutarate, which enters the TCA cycle to produce NADH and FADH2. When there is excess amino acids, glutamate dehydrogenase is inhibited, and glutamate dehydrogenase is converted to a-ketoglutarate, which enters the TCA cycle to produce NADH and FADH2. The transfer of electrons from NADH and FADH2 to oxygen is coupled to the pumping of protons across the inner mitochondrial membrane by the enzyme ATP synthase to produce ATP. The transfer of electrons from NADH to oxygen is coupled to the transfer of protons by the enzyme cytochrome c oxidase. The transfer of electrons from NADH to oxygen is not coupled to the transfer of protons by cytochrome c oxidase. The transfer of electrons from FADH2 to oxygen is coupled to the transfer of protons by cytochrome c oxidase.

The liver plays a central role in the metabolism of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats. The liver is also the major site for the synthesis of plasma proteins, including albumin, fibrinogen, transferrin, and alpha-antitrypsin. The liver also produces glucose for the brain and the red blood cells. The liver is also the major detoxifying organ of the body, metabolizing a variety of xenobiotics and drugs. The liver is also the major site for the biosynthesis of cholesterol and bile acids. The liver is composed of parenchymal cells (hepatocytes) and nonparenchymal cells (Kupffer cells, endothelial cells, and fat-storing cells). Hepatocytes account for approximately 8 0% of the liver weight and are responsible for most of the liver functions. The liver is a multifunctional organ, with a large capacity to metabolize a wide variety of compounds. The liver is also a major endocrine organ, producing a variety of hormones, such as insulin, growth hormone, and glucagon.

The extracellular matrix (ECM) is a complex network of macromolecules that provides structural support and regulates cellular functions. The ECM is secreted by cells and is deposited in the ECM. Integrins are cell surface receptors that bind to ECM proteins and transduce signals into the cell in response to the ECM. The interaction of integrins with the ECM regulates cell shape, migration, proliferation, and survival. The ECM also provides a scaffold for the deposition of other ECM components. The deposition of ECM components is regulated by growth factors and cytokines. The deposition of ECM components regulates the expression of integrins and other ECM components. The interaction of integrins with the ECM regulates the organization of the cytoskeleton and the formation of focal adhesions. Focal adhesions are macromolecular complexes that form at the ends of actin stress fibers and contain integrins, signaling molecules, and cytoskeletal proteins. Integrins transmit signals into the cell in response to the ECM through the activation of focal adhesion kinase (FAK) and the formation of focal adhesions. FAK is a tyrosine kinase that is activated by integrins and is involved in the regulation of cellular functions such as migration and proliferation. The interaction of integrins with the ECM also activates the small GTPase RhoA, which regulates the formation of stress fibers and focal adhesions. RhoA is regulated by the guanine nucleotide exchange factor (GEF), Lbc, and the GTPase activating protein (GAP), Rho-GAP. The interaction of integrins with the ECM also activates the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway. The activation of the MAPK pathway by integrins is mediated by the small GTPase Rac and the exchange factor Sos-1. The activation of Rac by integrins leads to the formation of lamellipodia and the activation of the MAPK pathway. The activation of Rac also leads to the activation of p130CAS, a component of focal adhesions. The activation of p130CAS by integrins leads to the formation of focal adhesions and the activation of the MAPK pathway. The interaction of integrins with the ECM also activates the c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) pathway. The activation of JNK by integrins is mediated by MEKK1 and is independent of the small GTPases Rac and Rho. The activation of JNK by integrins is required for the induction of apoptosis in response to the interaction of cells with the ECM.

The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a cAMP-regulated chloride channel that is expressed in epithelial cells. Mutations in the CFTR gene cause cystic fibrosis (CF). The most common mutation in CFTR is deletion of a phenylalanine residue at position 5 0 8 (deltaF5 0 8). This mutation results in misfolding of the protein and its retention in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). In the ER, CFTR is degraded by the proteasome. In addition, a small amount of CFTR reaches the plasma membrane, but it is rapidly removed from the cell surface by endocytosis and subsequent degradation in lysosomes. The absence of functional CFTR at the surface of epithelial cells leads to the dehydration of airway surface liquid (ASL) and mucus stasis, which are the hallmarks of CF. The dehydrated mucus in the airways leads to chronic infection and inflammation, which in turn causes progressive lung damage. The most common mutation in the gene encoding the beta-subunit of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC), which causes Liddle's syndrome, also results in dehydration of airway surface liquid.

The Eph family of receptor tyrosine kinases and their ligands, the ephrins, are involved in the development of the nervous system and the formation of topographic maps in the visual system. They are also involved in the development of the cardiovascular system and bone morphogenesis. The ephrins are membrane bound ligands that interact with the ephrins on adjacent cells. Eph receptors are also membrane bound, but their cytoplasmic domains lack catalytic activity. Instead, they interact with other signaling molecules through their cytoplasmic domains. The ephrins are also membrane bound, but are attached to the cell membrane by a GPI linkage in the case of the ephrins B class. The ephrins are attached to the plasma membrane by a transmembrane domain and a short cytoplasmic domain. The ephrins are divided into two classes, A and B. The A ephrins are bound by the A class Eph kinases and the B ephrins by the B class kinases. The ephrins are expressed on the surface of neurons and their expression is regulated in a topographic manner. The Eph kinases are expressed on the surface of adjacent cells and interact with the ephrins on the surface of the same cell. The interaction between the ephrins and the Eph kinases on the same cell results in a bidirectional signaling event. The Eph kinases are involved in the repulsion of axons during development of the nervous system. The interaction between the ephrins and the Eph kinases on the same cell results in the repulsion of the axons. The interaction between the ephrins and the Eph kinases on adjacent cells results in the activation of signaling pathways that alter the cytoskeleton and cell adhesion. The ephrins are also involved in the development of bone and blood vessels. The ephrins are expressed on the surface of bone cells and their expression is regulated in a spatial and temporal manner. The interaction between the ephrins and the Eph kinases on the surface of endothelial cells results in the activation of signaling pathways that alter cell adhesion and the permeability of the endothelial cells.

The inflammatory response is an essential component of host defense. The response is initiated by the recognition of invading organisms or their products by the innate immune system. Macrophages and neutrophils are the first line of defense against infection. Macrophages and neutrophils phagocytose foreign bodies and kill them by generating reactive oxygen species and by secreting proteases. Macrophages and neutrophils also secrete cytokines and chemokines that recruit and activate other immune cells. The proinflammatory cytokines IL-1 and TNF are the key mediators of the inflammatory response. The production of these cytokines is induced by microbial products through the activation of the transcription factor NF-kB. The activation of NF-kB is negatively regulated by IkB kinase (IKK) complex, which phosphorylates IkB and targets it for degradation by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. The activation of NF-kB is also negatively regulated by the I-kappa B kinase-associated protein A2 0. The activation of NF-kB is also negatively regulated by the caspase 8-dependent cleavage of the NF-kB p6 5 subunit. The activation of NF-kB is also negatively regulated by the I-kappa B kinase-associated protein A2 0. The activation of NF-kB is also negatively regulated by the caspase 8-dependent cleavage of the NF-kB p6 5 subunit. The activation of NF-kB is also negatively regulated by the caspase 8-dependent cleavage of the IL-1 receptor associated kinase 1 (IRAK-1). The cleavage of IRAK-1 by caspase 8 dissociates the IL-1 receptor accessory protein (AcP) from the receptor and is required for IL-1 signaling.

The gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) receptor is a ligand-gated ion channel that mediates fast inhibitory synaptic transmission in the brain. The GABA receptor is a pentamer, with each subunit contributing an integral transmembrane channel-forming domain. The five subunits are designated alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho. The most common form of the receptor is a pentamer of alpha, beta, gamma, and delta subunits. The gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor-associated protein (GABARAP) is a 1 7-kDa protein that binds to the intracellular domain of the GABA (A) receptor gamma2 subunit. GABARAP is localized in the Golgi apparatus and is transported to the plasma membrane. GABARAP may be involved in the sorting and / or trafficking of the GABA (A) receptor. The interaction of GABARAP with the GABA (A) receptor gamma2 subunit may be involved in the clustering of the GABA (A) receptor at synaptic junctions. The interaction of GABARAP with NSF (N-ethylmaleimide sensitive factor), a protein involved in membrane fusion, may also be involved in the clustering of the GABA (A) receptor. GABARAP is also involved in the trafficking of the water channel aquaporin-0 to the plasma membrane. GABARAP is also involved in the trafficking of the acetylcholine receptor to the neuromuscular junction. The interaction of GABARAP with the acetylcholine receptor may be involved in the targeting of the receptor to the synapse. The interaction of GABARAP with the N-ethylmaleimide sensitive factor (NSF) may also be involved in the trafficking of the acetylcholine receptor. Gephyrin is a postsynaptic target protein of the molybdenum cofactor (Moco) biosynthesis enzyme. Gephyrin is involved in the clustering of the GABA (A) receptor at inhibitory synapses. The interaction of gephyrin with the GABA (A) receptor may be involved in anchoring the receptor at the synapse.

Proteoglycans are a class of glycoproteins covalently modified with long polysaccharide chains consisting of repeating disaccharide units. The polysaccharide chains are attached to the protein core via a specific linkage region consisting of a serine or threonine residue and a glycosaminoglycan (GAG). The GAG chains can be modified by epimerization and sulfation at various positions. Proteoglycans are found in the extracellular matrix and on the cell surface and are involved in a variety of biological processes. The core proteins of the core proteins are encoded by a family of genes with similar structural organization. The protein core is followed by a signal peptide, a propeptide, a domain with several potential N-glycosylation sites, and the GAG attachment domain. The GAG chains are synthesized by a series of glycosyltransferases in the Golgi apparatus. The chain polymerization is initiated by the transfer of a xylose residue to a serine residue. Chondroitin sulfate is the most common GAG, and its polymerization is catalyzed by the bifunctional enzyme chondroitin synthase. Chondroitin polymerization is terminated by the addition of a sulfate group to the N-acetyl-galactosamine residue. The polymerization of heparan sulfate and heparin requires the addition of N-acetylglucosamine residues. The polymerization of dermatan sulfate requires the addition of glucuronic acid residues. Chondroitin and heparan sulfate chains are further modified by epimerization and sulfation.

The Cbl gene encodes a protein of 80kDa that is recognized as an important component of tyrosine kinase-mediated signaling pathways. Cbl contains a tyrosine kinase-binding (TKB) domain, a C30-RING finger domain, and a proline-rich region. The TKB domain interacts with activated tyrosine kinases, such as the EGF receptor, PDGF receptor, and c-Kit, through recognition of phosphorylated tyrosine residues. The C30-RING finger domain functions as an E3 ubiquitin ligase that mediates the attachment of ubiquitin to protein substrates. The proline-rich region interacts with several SH3-containing proteins, including Crk, Nck, and the Src family kinases. The Cbl protein is phosphorylated on several tyrosine residues by activated tyrosine kinases, and these phosphorylated tyrosines serve as binding sites for other signaling molecules, including the Crk, Nck, and Src family kinases. The Cbl protein also interacts with the p8 5 regulatory subunit of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) through its proline-rich region and with the Cbl-associated protein (CAP) through its C-terminal Cbl-TKB domain. Cbl-mediated recruitment of PI3K to activated tyrosine kinases may provide a mechanism for the positive regulation of tyrosine kinase-mediated signaling pathways by Cbl.

Methionine is an essential amino acid derived from dietary protein. In bacteria, archaea and plants, methionine is synthesized from aspartate. In animals, methionine is synthesized from homocysteine in a process that requires vitamin B. In bacteria and archaea, methionine is synthesized from ATP and inorganic sulfur in a process called the transsulfuration pathway. In plants, methionine is synthesized from serine in a pathway called the sulfonation pathway. In animals, methionine is derived from homocysteine in a process called the transmethylation pathway. In bacteria, archaea and plants, cysteine is derived from serine in a process called the sulfuration pathway. In animals, cysteine is derived from methionine in a process called the transulfuration pathway. In this pathway, homocysteine is condensed with serine to form cystathionine, which is then cleaved to form cysteine and a-ketobutyrate. Cysteine is activated with ATP to form thiocystine, which is condensed with N-acetylcystine to form taurine and pyruvate. In animals, taurine is derived from cysteine in a reaction catalyzed by cysteine sulfinic acid decarboxylase. Taurine is synthesized from serine in a reaction catalyzed by cysteinesulfinic acid decarboxylase.

Platelet Derived Growth Factor (PDGF) is a mitogen for cells of mesenchymal origin. The PDGF dimer is composed of A and B chains that combine to form AA, AB and BB dimers. The PDGF receptor is a heterodimer of alpha and beta chains. Binding of PDGF to the receptor causes receptor dimerization and activation of the tyrosine kinase domain of the receptor. Activation of the receptor tyrosine kinase leads to phosphorylation of a number of cellular substrates including phospholipase C-gamma 1, Shc, and the 417Grb-2 complex. These substrates lead to the activation of several signaling pathways including the MAP kinase pathway, the PI-3 kinase pathway and the JAK / STAT pathway. The activation of these pathways leads to changes in cellular structure and gene expression that contribute to cellular proliferation and differentiation.

Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) is a mesenchymal-derived cytokine that stimulates proliferation of epithelial cells and morphogenesis of epithelial cells. HGF is a mitogen for a variety of cells, including hepatocytes, and stimulates cell motility and morphogenesis in a variety of cell types. HGF exerts its biological effects through binding to its receptor, the tyrosine kinase encoded by the c-met proto-oncogene. HGF and c-Met are expressed in many different cell types, but HGF is primarily produced by mesenchymal cells and acts on epithelial cells through the c-Met receptor. Binding of HGF to c-Met activates several signaling pathways, including the ras / MAPK pathway, the PI3-kinase pathway, and the STAT pathway. HGF also induces tyrosine phosphorylation of paxillin, a focal adhesion protein, and induces association of paxillin with the c-Met receptor. HGF stimulates cell motility and morphogenesis through the ras / MAPK pathway and the PI3-kinase pathway. Paxillin phosphorylation and association with c-Met may be involved in the regulation of cell motility and morphogenesis by HGF.

The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a transmembrane receptor tyrosine kinase that is activated by the binding of epidermal growth factor (EGF) or transforming growth factor-alpha (TGF-alpha). The EGFR is involved in a variety of cellular processes including proliferation, differentiation, motility, and survival. Overexpression of the EGFR has been observed in a number of human cancers including those of the breast, lung, and colon. The EGFR is a member of the ErbB family of receptors that also includes ErbB-2 / neu, ErbB-3, and ErbB-4. Binding of ligand to the EGFR induces receptor dimerization and activation of the intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity of the receptor. The phosphorylated tyrosine residues on the activated receptor serve as docking sites for signaling molecules containing SH2 domains. The binding of signaling molecules to the activated receptor leads to the activation of downstream signaling pathways including the Ras-Raf-MAP kinase pathway, the PI3-K-Akt pathway, and the Stat pathway. These signaling pathways in turn regulate gene expression and cellular responses. The association of the EGFR with the protein tyrosine phosphatase 1B (PTP-1B) has been shown to negatively regulate EGFR signaling. The PTP-1B dephosphorylates the EGFR and down-regulates its signaling. The association of the EGFR with the protein tyrosine phosphatase Shp-2 has also been shown to down-regulate EGFR signaling. The association of the EGFR with the Grb-2 adaptor protein has been shown to activate the ras-dependent pathway. The association of the EGFR with the Cbl adaptor protein has been shown to down-regulate EGFR signaling. The association of the EGFR with the Grb-2 adaptor protein has been shown to activate the ras-dependent pathway.

The binding of EGF to its receptor activates the MAP kinase pathway and stimulates cell motility. The activation of the MAP kinase pathway by EGF is mediated by the small G protein Ras. The activation of Ras by EGF causes the activation of the kinase Raf, which in turn activates the kinase Mek, which in turn activates the kinase Erk. The activation of Erk causes the phosphorylation and activation of the protease calpain, which cleaves the focal adhesion protein talin, causing the release of the cell from the extracellular matrix and causing cell spreading. Talin is a component of focal adhesions, which anchor the cell to the extracellular matrix. Calpain cleaves talin at a site near its N-terminus, releasing a fragment that binds to actin and causes the cell to spread. Calpain is also involved in the cleavage of other focal adhesion proteins, including the integrin subunit beta 1, which is involved in cell adhesion, and the focal adhesion protein FAK, which is involved in signaling between the extracellular matrix and the cytoskeleton. Calpain is also involved in the cleavage of other signaling proteins, including the growth factor receptor bound protein 2 (Grb2), which is involved in signaling between the EGF receptor and the MAP kinase pathway, and the protein kinase Akt, which is involved in cell survival signaling. Calpain is also involved in the cleavage of the cytoskeletal protein alpha-spectrin, causing the breakdown of the cytoskeleton and causing cell retraction. The activation of calpain by EGF is mediated by the small G protein RhoA, which is activated by EGF and causes the activation of the kinase ROCK, which in turn activates calpain. The activation of RhoA by EGF is mediated by the G-protein Rho-GEF, which is activated by EGF and causes the activation of Rho. The activation of ROCK by EGF also causes the activation of the kinase PKN, which also activates calpain. The activation of calpain by EGF is also mediated by the kinase Akt, which phosphorylates and activates the kinase PKC-zeta, which in turn activates calpain. The activation of PKC-zeta by EGF also activates the kinase Pak1, which also activates calpain. The activation of calpain by EGF is involved in cell motility, but also causes the degradation of other proteins, including the growth factor receptor EGF-R, causing the down-regulation of EGF signaling.

The control of gene expression at the post-transcriptional level is a fundamental process in all organisms. The major mechanism of mRNA degradation in eukaryotes is initiated by deadenylation, which is the removal of the poly (A) tail by a complex of proteins. In the 5 '-to-3' mRNA decay pathway, decapping enzyme releases the 5 'cap structure, which is subsequently degraded by the 5' -to-3 'exoribonuclease. In the 3' -to-5 'mRNA decay pathway, the exosome degrades the mRNA from the 3' to the 5 'end.

Eosinophils are leukocytes that are involved in inflammatory responses and are found in high numbers in tissues affected by asthma and other allergic conditions. Eosinophils are recruited to tissues by a variety of chemokines and cytokines, including eotaxin, RANTES, and IL-5. The chemokine eotaxin is a potent chemoattractant for eosinophils and is found in high levels in the lungs of asthmatic patients. The chemokine receptor CCR3 is a receptor for eotaxin and is expressed on eosinophils. Binding of eotaxin to CCR3 leads to eosinophil chemotaxis, degranulation, and production of reactive oxygen species. The small GTPase RhoA is involved in the regulation of actin cytoskeleton reorganization and changes in cell shape that are involved in chemotaxis. RhoA is activated by the guanine exchange factors (GEFs), which are involved in the exchange of GDP for GTP on RhoA. The GEFs are regulated by a variety of factors, including phosphorylation by PKC and other kinases. The RhoA-specific GEF, GEF-H1, is activated by phosphorylation by p38 MAPK and this activation is inhibited by the protein kinase PKA. The RhoA-specific GAP, p19RhoGAP, is also regulated by phosphorylation by PKC and PKA. The activity of RhoA is also regulated by the guanine nucleotide dissociation inhibitors (GDIs). The GDI-RhoA complex is found in the cytosol and is inactive. When phosphorylated by PKC and PKA, the GDI dissociates from RhoA, allowing RhoA to be activated and move to the membrane. The activation of RhoA by phosphorylation by PKC and PKA is part of a feedback loop that further activates RhoA and further increases actin polymerization and cell shape changes. The activation of RhoA by GEF-H1 also activates the p38 MAPK pathway, providing another positive feedback loop. The activation of RhoA by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p19RhoGAP, which inactivates RhoA and terminates the signal. The activation of RhoA by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK, providing another positive feedback loop. The activation of RhoA by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK through the activation of p19RhoGAP. The activation of p38 MAPK by RhoA also leads to the activation of p19RhoGAP, providing another negative feedback loop. The activation of RhoA by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK through the activation of p38 MAPK kinase kinases (MAPKKK). The activation of p38 MAPK by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK kinase kinases (MAPKKKK), such as TAK-1. The activation of p38 MAPK by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK-dependent genes, such as p38 MAPK-dependent genes, such as IL-5. The activation of RhoA by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK through the activation of p38 MAPK kinase kinases (MAPKKK), such as TAK-1. The activation of RhoA by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK through the activation of p38 MAPK kinase kinases (MAPKKK), such as MEKK1. The activation of RhoA by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK through the activation of p38 MAPK kinase kinases (MAPKKK), such as MLK3. The activation of RhoA by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK through the activation of p38 MAPK kinase kinases (MAPKKK), such as TAK-1. The activation of RhoA by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK through the activation of p38 MAPK kinase kinases (MAPKKK), such as MEKK1. The activation of RhoA by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK through the activation of p38 MAPK kinase kinases (MAPKKK), such as TAK-1. The activation of RhoA by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK through the activation of p38 MAPK kinase kinases (MAPKKK), such as MLK3. The activation of RhoA by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK through the activation of p38 MAPK kinase kinases (MAPKKK), such as TAK-1. The activation of RhoA by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK through the activation of p38 MAPK kinase kinases (MAPKKK), such as TAK-1. The activation of p38 MAPK by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK-dependent genes, such as IL-5. The activation of RhoA by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK through the activation of p38 MAPK kinase kinases (MAPKKK), such as MEKK1. The activation of p38 MAPK by GEF-H1 also leads to the activation of p38 MAPK-dependent genes, such as IL-5.

Cyclin-dependent kinase 5 (cdk5) is a protein kinase that is highly expressed in the brain. It is activated by the cleavage of its activator p3 5 to p2 5. The cleavage of p3 5 to p2 5 is mediated by the calcium-dependent protease calpain. The p2 5 / cdk5 kinase is highly toxic to neurons and its activity is elevated in the brains of patients with Alzheimer's disease. The activation of cdk5 by p2 5 leads to hyperphosphorylation of tau, aberrant activation of the protease, calpain, and cleavage of the amyloid precursor protein (APP) to produce the amyloid beta peptide (Abeta). The amyloid beta peptide (Abeta) is toxic to neurons and can lead to activation of calpain and cleavage of p3 5 to p2 5. The activation of cdk5 by p2 5 and the subsequent phosphorylation of tau and APP lead to a series of events that result in the formation of neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques in the brains of patients with Alzheimer's disease.

The immune system is a network of cells and molecules that respond to each other to protect the body from infection and to regulate the response to environmental antigens. The antigen-specific immune response is mediated by T cells that recognize antigens presented by specialized antigen-presenting cells, the dendritic cells. The antigen-presenting cells are located in tissues throughout the body and are found in the skin, lung, and intestine. Dendritic cells are a heterogeneous population of cells that are found in low numbers in the blood and lymphoid tissues, but are abundant in the tissues where they patrol the body. The antigen-presenting cells take up antigens from tissues and migrate to the lymphoid tissues to induce T cell activation. The activation of T cells requires two signals. The first signal is provided by the interaction of the T cell receptor with antigen presented by MHC on the surface of an antigen-presenting cell. The second signal is provided by cytokines produced by activated antigen-presenting cells that stimulate T cell proliferation and differentiation. The cytokines that stimulate T cell activation include IL-1, IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, TNF-alpha, and IFN-gamma. The cytokines stimulate the proliferation and differentiation of T cells into Th1 and Th2 cells. Th1 cells produce IL-2, IFN-gamma, and TNF-alpha and are involved in cell-mediated immune responses. Th2 cells produce IL-4, IL-5, and IL-6 and are involved in the humoral immune response. The balance of Th1 and Th2 cells determines the type of immune response. The chemokine receptors are G-protein coupled receptors that are expressed on the surface of leukocytes and are involved in the migration of leukocytes to tissues and the immune response. The chemokine receptors CCR1, CCR2, CCR3, CCR4, CCR5, and CXCR4 are involved in the migration of leukocytes to tissues. The CCR5 receptor is used by the HIV virus to enter cells and is the receptor for the chemokine macrophage inflammatory protein-1 (MIP-1) and MIP-1 beta. The CCR2 receptor is used by the chemokine MCP-1 to attract monocytes to tissues. The CCR3 receptor is used by the eosinophil chemoattractant eotaxin to attract eosinophils to tissues.

Leukocytes play a key role in inflammation and wound healing. They are recruited to sites of inflammation by a variety of chemokines, including the CXC chemokine ligand 1 2 (CXCL1 2). The binding of CXCL1 2 to its receptor CXCR4 activates a signaling pathway that leads to actin polymerization and the subsequent migration of the cell. The signaling pathway that leads to actin polymerization is not well understood. In this study, the tyrosine kinase LYN was found to be involved in the signaling pathway that leads to actin polymerization and cell migration. The activation of LYN by CXCL1 2 leads to the activation of the small GTPase RAC, which in turn activates the kinase PAK1. PAK1 phosphorylates the actin-binding protein Cofilin, which leads to the formation of actin fibers and the migration of the cell. The activation of LYN by CXCL1 2 is also involved in the activation of the transcription factor NF-kB, which leads to the production of inflammatory cytokines. The activation of LYN by CXCL1 2 may also play a role in the metastasis of cancer cells. The activation of LYN by CXCL1 2 may also play a role in the development of autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis.

The phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) / AKT pathway is a key regulator of cell survival, proliferation and growth. The PI3K / AKT pathway is activated by many different growth factors and is a key mediator of cell survival. The PI3K / AKT pathway is negatively regulated by the tumor suppressor gene PTEN. The PTEN gene is mutated in a large fraction of prostate cancers, suggesting that activation of the PI3K / AKT pathway contributes to prostate cancer development. The p53 tumor suppressor gene is also mutated in a large fraction of prostate cancers. The p53 tumor suppressor gene is involved in the regulation of the cell cycle and induction of apoptosis. The activation of the PI3K / AKT pathway inhibits apoptosis, contributing to the development of cancer. The p53 tumor suppressor gene is also involved in the regulation of transcription. The p53 tumor suppressor protein binds to the transcription factor E2F-1 and inhibits transcription of genes involved in cell cycle progression and apoptosis.

Peroxisomes are ubiquitous organelles involved in a variety of metabolic processes, including fatty acid alpha- and beta-oxidation, biosynthesis of ether lipids, and detoxification of reactive oxygen species (ROS). Peroxisomes are essential for human health, as demonstrated by the existence of a group of inherited peroxisomal disorders (PDs), which are caused by a defect in peroxisome biogenesis or peroxisomal metabolism. PDs are characterized by a broad spectrum of clinical symptoms, including severe mental retardation, liver dysfunction, and peroxisome biogenesis defects. Peroxisomes are formed and proliferated by a complex and coordinated process called peroxisome biogenesis. Peroxisomes are derived from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane, and the membrane proteins PEX3 and PEX19 are the key factors for the formation of peroxisomes. PEX3 is a receptor for peroxisomal membrane proteins (PMPs), and PEX19 is an escort protein that chaperones PMPs to the peroxisomal membrane. After the formation of the peroxisomal membrane, peroxisomal matrix proteins are translocated into the peroxisomal matrix by a peroxisomal targeting signal 1 (PTS1) -dependent or -independent pathway. Peroxisomes are highly dynamic organelles, and their proliferation is regulated by a complex interplay of PEX genes and PEX proteins.

Hypoxia is a common feature of the tumor microenvironment. Hypoxia-inducible factor 1 (HIF-1) is a transcription factor that plays a key role in cellular and systemic adaptation to hypoxia. HIF-1 is a heterodimer consisting of alpha and beta subunits. The HIF-1 alpha subunit is rapidly degraded under normoxic conditions, but is stabilized and activated under hypoxic conditions. HIF-1 activates the transcription of genes involved in erythropoiesis, glucose metabolism, and vascularization. HIF-1 is also activated by the hypoxia-mimetic agent desferroxamine. HIF-1 activation by genetic alterations in cancer may contribute to the development and progression of many human cancers.

The innate immune system is the first line of defense against invading microorganisms. It is comprised of a variety of cells and molecules that act in concert to recognize and respond to microbial pathogens. The Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are a class of pattern recognition receptors that recognize microbial products and activate innate immune responses. TLRs are expressed on antigen-presenting cells such as macrophages and dendritic cells and respond to microbial components such as lipopolysaccharides (LPS), lipoproteins, and peptidoglycans. Upon recognition of microbial components, TLRs activate signaling pathways that lead to the production of proinflammatory cytokines and costimulatory molecules. These cytokines and costimulatory molecules promote activation of adaptive immune responses.

The MAPK pathway is a highly conserved module of kinases that transmits signals from the cell surface to the nucleus in response to a variety of stimuli. The MAPK module consists of a MAPK kinase kinase (MAPKKK), a MAPKK or MEK, and a MAPK. The MAPKKKs are the primary level of regulation of the MAPK module. The MAPKKKs are themselves regulated by phosphorylation and / or by association with other proteins. The MAPKKKs that activate the JNK and p3 8 pathways include MEKK1, MEKK4, and ASK1. These kinases are activated by the small GTPases Rac and / or Cdc4 2. The JNK and p3 8 pathways are also activated by the MAPKK kinases (MAPKKs) MKK4 and MKK7, and MKK3 and MKK6, respectively. The JNK and p3 8 pathways are involved in the regulation of gene expression, apoptosis, and inflammation.

Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is the most common type of thyroid cancer. The genetic alterations associated with PTC include RET / PTC rearrangements and activating mutations of the RAS and BRAF genes. The RET / PTC rearrangements result in ligand-independent activation of RET kinase. The RAS and BRAF mutations lead to constitutive activation of the downstream signaling pathways. The BRAF mutation is the most common genetic alteration in PTC and is found in about one-half of all cases. The presence of these genetic alterations is associated with more aggressive tumor behavior and a reduced disease-specific survival.

Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the development of benign tumors in multiple organ systems. The disease is caused by mutations in either the TSC1 or TSC2 gene. The TSC1 and TSC2 gene products form a complex that acts as a GTPase activating protein (GAP) for the small G-protein Rheb. The activity of the TSC complex is inhibited by Akt-mediated phosphorylation of TSC2, which leads to the accumulation of active Rheb and the subsequent activation of mTOR and S6K. The regulation of p4EBP-1and pS6K by mTOR also contributes to the activation of cell growth.

Insulin like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) is a potent mitogen that stimulates proliferation and differentiation of many cell types. In skeletal muscle IGF-1 stimulates differentiation and inhibits proliferation. The mitogenic effects of IGF-1 are mediated by the MAP kinase pathway and the PI3 kinase pathway. The differentiation effects of IGF-1 are mediated by the PI3 kinase pathway. The downstream targets of PI3 kinase that stimulate differentiation are not known. One target of PI3 kinase that may be involved in differentiation is the transcription factor NFAT. The calcineurin pathway also appears to be involved in IGF-1 signaling. Calcineurin is a calcium activated phosphatase that is involved in muscle differentiation. Calcineurin is activated by an increase in intracellular calcium and is inhibited by the binding of the 14-3-3 proteins. Calcineurin dephosphorylates NFAT transcription factors, causing them to translocate to the nucleus and activate genes containing NFAT response elements. IGF-1 activates calcineurin and stimulates NFAT transcriptional activity. The activation of calcineurin by IGF-1 is mediated by the calcium / calmodulin dependent protein phosphatase, PP2B. The activation of calcineurin by IGF-1 is required for IGF-1 to stimulate differentiation. The inhibition of calcineurin by cyclosporin A or by expression of a 14-3-3 protein blocks the ability of IGF-1 to stimulate differentiation. The inhibition of calcineurin by cyclosporin A also blocks the ability of IGF-1 to stimulate hypertrophy. The inhibition of calcineurin by cyclosporin A does not block the ability of IGF-1 to stimulate proliferation. The inhibition of calcineurin by cyclosporin A also does not block the activation of MAP kinase by IGF-1. The 5HT3 receptor is a ligand-gated ion channel that is activated by the neurotransmitter serotonin (5-HT). The 5HT3 receptor is expressed in a variety of tissues, including the sensory neurons of the gastrointestinal tract, where it is involved in the nausea and vomiting caused by chemotherapy and radiation therapy. The 5HT3 receptor is also expressed in the spinal cord where it may play a role in the processing of pain signals. The 5HT3 receptor is also expressed in a variety of cancer cells, where it may play a role in the development of chemotherapy-induced emesis. The 5HT3 receptor is also expressed in the retina where it may play a role in the processing of light. The 5HT3 receptor is a member of the Cys-loop ligand-gated ion channel gene family that includes the nicotinic acetylcholine, GABAA, and glycine receptors. The 5HT3 receptor is a pentamer, with each subunit containing an intracellular N-terminal domain, four transmembrane domains, and a large extracellular domain. The structure of the 5HT3 receptor has not been determined, but the structure of the acetylcholine receptor, which is also a member of the Cys-loop gene family, has been determined in three dimensions. The acetylcholine receptor is a member of the pentameric ligand-gated ion channel gene family that includes the 5HT3 receptor. The acetylcholine receptor is activated by the neurotransmitter acetylcholine, which binds in the extracellular domain at the interface of two adjacent subunits. The 5HT3 receptor is activated by the neurotransmitter serotonin, which binds in the transmembrane region. The 5HT3 receptor is expressed in neurons as well as in some cancer cells. The expression of the 5HT3 receptor in neurons may play a role in the processing of pain signals. The expression of the 5HT3 receptor in cancer cells may play a role in chemotherapy-induced emesis.

The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a transmembrane receptor tyrosine kinase that is activated by binding of its ligands, the epidermal growth factor (EGF) family of growth factors. The EGFR is involved in the regulation of a variety of cellular processes, including proliferation, differentiation, and motility. Overexpression of the EGFR has been observed in a number of human cancers and is associated with a more aggressive tumor phenotype and a poor prognosis. The EGFR is a member of the ErbB family of receptor tyrosine kinases, which also includes ErbB-2 (HER2 / neu), ErbB-3 (HER3), and ErbB-4 (HER4). The ErbB receptors are formed by the association of two subunits, with the ErbB-1 / EGFR being the preferred binding partner. Binding of ligand to the extracellular domain of the receptor induces receptor dimerization and activation of the intrinsic tyrosine kinase. The phosphorylated tyrosine residues in the cytoplasmic domain serve as binding sites for a variety of signaling molecules containing SH2 or PTB domains. These molecules include the SHC adaptor protein, the Grb2 adaptor protein, phospholipase C-gamma, the protein tyrosine phosphatase SHP-2, the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI-3K), and the protein tyrosine kinase Src. The recruitment of these signaling molecules to the plasma membrane leads to the activation of a number of signaling pathways, including the MAP kinase pathway, the PI-3K pathway, and the JAK / STAT pathway. These pathways in turn activate a number of transcription factors, including the AP-1 and STAT transcription factors. Activation of these transcription factors leads to changes in gene expression that contribute to the biological responses to EGF.

HGF / SF is a mitogen for many cell types and a morphogen for epithelial cells. The biological effects of HGF / SF are mediated by the MET receptor tyrosine kinase. HGF / SF is a paracrine growth factor, secreted by mesenchymal cells, that acts on MET-expressing epithelial cells. HGF / SF is a multifunctional factor, also involved in morphogenesis and cell motility. HGF / SF is a ligand for MET and induces receptor dimerization and activation of the tyrosine kinase. Downstream signaling of MET includes RAS / MAPK, PI3 kinase and PLC pathways.

Peroxisomes are essential organelles involved in a variety of metabolic processes in eukaryotic cells. They are involved in the beta-oxidation of fatty acids, biosynthesis of ether lipids, pipecolic acid and D-amino acids, biosynthesis of nitric oxide, detoxification of reactive oxygen species, and glyoxylate detoxification. Peroxisomes are also involved in glyoxylate metabolism, which allows the organism to use both C2 and C2 compounds as a source of carbon and energy. The biogenesis of peroxisomes is a complex process and requires the action of at least 3 1 peroxins.

The binding of agonist to GPCRs leads to the activation of heterotrimeric G proteins, which in turn activate a variety of signaling pathways. The activation of G proteins by GPCRs leads to the dissociation of the alpha and beta gamma subunits. The alpha subunits of the G proteins can activate a variety of signaling pathways, including the PLCbeta / PKC and the MAPK cascades. The beta gamma subunits of G proteins activate the tyrosine kinase Src and the small G protein Ras. The activation of Src and Ras leads to the activation of the Raf-1 / MEK / ERK kinase cascade and ultimately to the regulation of transcription factors. The beta gamma subunits of G proteins also activate the MAP kinase cascade, although the mechanism is not yet known. The activation of the MAP kinase cascade by GPCRs is a transient response, lasting only a few minutes. The attenuation of the MAP kinase cascade is due in part to the activation of a tyrosine phosphatase, SHP-2, that dephosphorylates and inactivates the kinases in the cascade. The activation of the MAP kinase cascade by GPCRs is also attenuated by the induction of a protein, arrestin, that binds to the activated GPCR and blocks further G protein activation. The activation of the MAP kinase cascade by GPCRs leads to the regulation of transcription factors such as AP-1 and CREB. The activation of the MAP kinase cascade by GPCRs is also attenuated by the induction of a protein, arrestin, that binds to the activated GPCR and blocks further G protein activation. The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a transmembrane glycoprotein that binds epidermal growth factor (EGF) and transforming growth factor-alpha (TGF-alpha). The EGFR is frequently over-expressed in a variety of human cancers and is associated with a poor prognosis. The EGFR is a member of a family of closely related receptors (HERs) that also includes HER2 / neu. Binding of EGF or TGF-alpha to the EGFR leads to receptor dimerization, autophosphorylation of the receptor, and activation of downstream signaling pathways. These pathways include the ras-raf-MAPK kinase (MEK) -MAP kinase pathway, the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway, and the STAT pathway. These pathways regulate cellular proliferation, differentiation, and motility.

Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a heart muscle disease characterized by dilation and impaired contraction of the left ventricle that results in progressive heart failure and sudden cardiac death. Familial DCM is an autosomal dominant disease with an estimated prevalence of 1: 25 0 0. and is caused by mutations in at least 1 1 different genes. The first gene identified to be associated with familial DCM was the gene encoding beta-myosin heavy chain (beta-MHC). Since then, mutations in the genes encoding for cardiac troponin T (TNNTI), cardiac troponin C (TNNC1), tropomyosin (TPM1), alpha-tropomyosin (TPM2), and dystrophin (DMD) have been identified. The mutations in these genes lead to a reduced force generation and / or a reduced response to calcium. In addition, mutations in the genes encoding for the cytoskeletal proteins dystrophin (DMD) and the Z-disk protein alpha-actin (ACTC) have been associated with DCM. The cytoskeletal proteins dystrophin and alpha-actin are part of a complex of proteins that stabilizes the sarcomere and transmits force from the myofilaments to the extracellular matrix. The loss of this force transmission leads to dilation of the left ventricle.

The immune system consists of two major components, the innate and adaptive immune systems. The innate immune system consists of natural killer (NK) cells, macrophages, and granulocytes. The innate immune system is the first line of defense against invading pathogens and is non-specific. The adaptive immune system consists of B cells, T cells, and antigen-specific (or MHC-restricted) cells. B cells produce antigen-specific antibodies. T cells are classified into two types, T helper cells (Th) and T cytotoxic cells (Tc). Th cells are involved in the activation of B cells and macrophages, whereas Tc cells are responsible for direct killing of infected cells. Upon activation, B cells proliferate and differentiate into antibody-secreting plasma cells. Th cells are further subdivided into Th1 and Th2 cells, depending on their cytokine production profile. Th1 cells produce pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as IL-2, IFN-gamma, and TNF-alpha, whereas Th2 cells produce IL-4, IL-5, and IL-10. Macrophages and granulocytes phagocytose and kill invading microorganisms. Macrophages also activate the complement system and secrete pro-inflammatory cytokines. Cytotoxic T cells kill infected cells by two mechanisms: the direct killing of the target cell by cytotoxic granules and Fas ligand-mediated apoptosis. Cytotoxic T cells are activated by interaction of the T cell receptor (TCR) with antigen-MHC-I complex on the target cell. B cells produce antigen-specific antibodies that bind to the antigen on the surface of an infected cell, and then the antibody-antigen complex is recognized by the TCR on the cytotoxic T cell.

The biosynthesis of bile acids from cholesterol starts with the formation of cholic acid from 7-dehydrocholesterol. Cholic acid is then modified by hydroxylation at C-6 and C-2 4, and oxidation at C-7and C-3before it is conjugated with taurine or glycine. The glycine and taurine conjugates of cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid are the major bile acids in humans. < / FREETEXT > < / ABSTRACT > ▃

Insulin binding to its receptor stimulates autophosphorylation of the receptor and recruitment of IRS1, IRS2 and Shc. These proteins activate the Ras / Raf / MEK / ERK pathway and the PI 3-kinase / Akt pathway. The Ras / Raf / MEK / ERK pathway leads to activation of ELK-1 and SRF and induction of c-fos. The PI 3-kinase / Akt pathway leads to activation of mTOR and its downstream targets, including p4EBP-1 and pS6K, which leads to increased translation of mRNAs with a 5 '-oligopyrimidine tract.

The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a member of the ErbB family of receptor tyrosine kinases that also includes ErbB2, ErbB3 and ErbB4. The ErbB receptors are activated by ligands of the EGF family, including EGF, transforming growth factor-alpha (TGFA), heparin-binding EGF (HB-EGF), amphiregulin (AR), betacellulin (BTC) and epiregulin (EPR). The ligands are produced as transmembrane precursors that are cleaved to release the soluble factors. The soluble factors bind to the ErbB receptors and induce receptor dimerization and activation. The ligands are classified as either high-affinity (EGF, TGFA, AR, BTC) or low-affinity (HB-EGF, EPR). The ErbB receptors are non-covalently associated dimers formed from a combination of two of the four receptors. The most common dimer is the EGFR / ErbB2 heterodimer. The ErbB receptors contain an extracellular ligand-binding domain, a transmembrane domain, an intracellular tyrosine kinase domain and a cytoplasmic tail with autophosphorylation sites. The binding of ligand to the extracellular domain induces a conformational change in the receptor that allows the dimerization of the receptor. The dimerization induces the activation of the intracellular tyrosine kinase domain and autophosphorylation of the tyrosine residues in the cytoplasmic tail. The binding of ligands to the ErbB receptors induces a number of different cellular responses including proliferation, differentiation and migration. The cellular responses are determined by the specific tyrosine residues that are phosphorylated and the proteins that bind to these residues. The cellular responses are transient in the case of the EGFR and the ErbBs, with receptor activation and phosphorylation rapidly followed by receptor down-regulation and dephosphorylation. The cellular responses are more sustained in the case of the EGF receptor. The cellular responses are determined by the specific tyrosine residues that are phosphorylated and the proteins that bind to these residues. The cellular responses are transient in the case of the EGF receptor and the ErbBs, with receptor activation and phosphorylation rapidly followed by receptor down-regulation and dephosphorylation. The cellular responses are more sustained in the case of the EGF receptor. The cellular responses are determined by the specific tyrosine residues that are phosphorylated and the proteins that bind these residues. The cellular responses are transient in the case of the EGF receptor and the ErbBs, with receptor activation and phosphorylation rapidly followed by receptor down-regulation and dephosphorylation. The immune system is made up of cells that communicate with each other to defend the body against infection and other harmful agents. The body's immune system can be divided into two broad categories: innate and adaptive. The innate immune system responds to infection by a variety of mechanisms, including the release of cytokines and inflammatory factors, the activation of macrophages and natural killer (NK) cells, and the stimulation of neutrophils and eosinophils. The adaptive immune system responds to infection and other forms of stress by generating antigen-specific immune responses. The adaptive immune system is comprised of two distinct types of cells, lymphocytes and antibodies. B cells produce antibodies, which are composed of two chains, one of which is the heavy chain and one of which is the light chain. The heavy chain contains the antigen-binding site, while the light chain is used to form the antibody's effector functions. B cells differentiate into plasma cells that secrete antibodies, and into memory B cells that can respond rapidly to future infections. T cells are lymphocytes that respond to antigen by proliferating and differentiating into effector cells with different functions. Naive T cells differentiate into two types of cells, Th1 and Th2 cells, based on their cytokine expression profiles. Th1 cells express the cytokine interferon-g (IFN-g) and are involved in cellular immunity, while Th2 cells express the cytokines IL-4, IL-5 and IL-6 and are involved in humoral immunity. The differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 and Th2 cells is influenced by the cytokines IL-1 2 and IL-4, respectively. Cytotoxic T cells (CTLs) are lymphocytes that respond to infection by killing infected cells. CTLs are a heterogeneous population, with some cells expressing the CD4 antigen and other cells expressing the CD8 antigen.

Blood coagulation is a physiological process that leads to the formation of a clot to stop bleeding. The clotting cascade is initiated by tissue injury, activation of the clotting cascade, and formation of a clot. The clotting cascade is a series of enzymatic reactions that lead to the formation of a clot. The clotting cascade begins with the activation of prothrombin by the tissue factor (TF) -factor VIIa complex. The TF-factor VIIa complex activates factor X, which in turn activates prothrombin. The prothrombin activation fragment (F1 + 2) is released from prothrombin and is a marker of prothrombin activation. The clotting cascade is completed when thrombin cleaves fibrinogen to form fibrin monomers. The fibrin monomers polymerize to form a clot. The clotting cascade is regulated by a variety of factors. Antithrombin III (AT-III) is the most important physiologic inhibitor of thrombin. Antithrombin III inhibits the activity of thrombin by forming a complex with thrombin. The activity of AT-III is enhanced by heparin. Antithrombin III deficiency can result in thrombosis. Congenital AT-III deficiency is usually inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. Congenital AT-III deficiency is usually associated with a mild to moderate bleeding tendency. Congenital protein C deficiency is also associated with a mild bleeding tendency. Protein C is a cofactor in the inactivation of thrombin and factor Va by activated protein C. Protein C deficiency is usually inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. Protein C deficiency is usually associated with a severe bleeding tendency. Congenital fibrinogen deficiency is usually associated with a mild to moderate bleeding tendency. Congenital dysfibrinogenemia is an inherited disorder of fibrinogen that is characterized by a normal level of fibrinogen but an abnormal fibrinogen molecule. Congenital dysfibrinogenemia is usually inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. Congenital afibrinogenemia is an autosomal recessive disorder of fibrinogen. Congenital dysfibrinogenemia is an autosomal dominant disorder of fibrinogen. Congenital afibrinogenemia is an autosomal recessive disorder of fibrinogen.

The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a member of the ErbB family of receptor tyrosine kinases. The EGFR is activated by the peptide growth factors EGF and transforming growth factor-alpha (TGF-alpha). The EGFR is widely expressed in normal tissues and its activation has been implicated in the regulation of cellular proliferation, differentiation, migration, and apoptosis. Overexpression of the EGFR has been observed in a variety of human cancers and has been associated with a more aggressive tumor phenotype. The EGFR is a heterodimer consisting of an extracellular ligand-binding domain, a single transmembrane domain, and an intracellular domain containing a tyrosine kinase domain. Binding of EGF or TGF-alpha to the extracellular domain of the EGFR induces receptor dimerization and activation of the tyrosine kinase domain. The EGFR is internalized upon ligand binding and is subsequently degraded in the lysosome. Activation of the EGFR also leads to the activation of several signaling pathways, including the ras-raf-MEK-MAPK pathway, the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase pathway, and the Jak / Stat pathway. The ras-raf-MEK-MAPK pathway is activated by the binding of growth factors to the EGFR and leads to the activation of transcription factors such as AP-1 and ELK-1. Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase activation by the EGFR leads to the activation of protein kinase B (AKT) and the mTOR pathway. STAT proteins are transcription factors that are activated by tyrosine kinases, including the EGFR. The Jak / Stat pathway is activated by the EGFR and leads to the activation of STAT-1 and STAT-3. The activation of these pathways by the EGFR contributes to the proliferative and antiapoptotic effects of EGFR activation.

The Wnt family of secreted glycoproteins are secreted morphogens that regulate cell fate and proliferation during development. Wnt signaling is involved in many aspects of embryonic development, including cell fate specification in the central nervous system, the patterning of the mesoderm and endoderm, and the development of the limbs. Wnt signaling is also involved in stem cell proliferation and tissue regeneration in the adult. Wnt signaling is blocked by the action of secreted Frizzled-related proteins (sFRPs), which bind Wnt proteins and block Wnt signaling. Wnt signaling is also blocked by Dickkopf (Dkk) proteins, which bind to the Wnt co-receptor LRP 5 / 6 and block Wnt signaling. Wnt signaling is blocked by the action of the Axin complex, which includes the tumor suppressor protein APC, the protein kinases GSK-3-beta and CKI-alpha, and the protein phosphatases PP2A and PP1. Binding of Wnt to Frizzled leads to the recruitment of Disheveled to the plasma membrane and the subsequent stabilization of beta-catenin. Stabilized beta-catenin is transported into the nucleus, where it associates with TCF / LEF family transcription factors to activate gene expression. Wnt signaling is blocked by the action of the Wnt antagonists Dkk and sFRP. Wnt signaling is also blocked by the action of the Wnt inhibitory factor (WIF). WIF is secreted by the Wnt-receiving cell and binds to Wnt, blocking its interaction with the Frizzled receptor.

Bladder cancer is the fourth most common malignancy in the United States and is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. The disease is characterized by a high recurrence rate and a propensity for progression to invasive and metastatic disease. The standard treatment for non-muscle invasive bladder cancer is transurethral resection followed by intravesical chemotherapy or immunotherapy. For muscle invasive bladder cancer, radical cystectomy with regional lymph node dissection is the standard treatment. However, approximately 5 0% of patients with muscle invasive bladder cancer develop metastatic disease, with a median survival of approximately 1 2 months. The 5-year survival rate for metastatic bladder cancer is less than 5%. The development of effective systemic therapy for advanced bladder cancer has been challenging. The identification of molecular targets and the development of novel therapeutic agents are expected to improve the treatment of this disease. This review will focus on the molecular pathogenesis of bladder cancer and the potential molecular targets for the treatment of this disease. < / FREETEXT > < / ABSTRACT > ▃

The ATM gene is mutated in the rare cancer syndrome, AT, which is characterized by hypersensitivity to ionizing radiation and predisposition to cancer. The ATM protein is a member of a family of PI-3 kinases that includes DNA-PK, ATR and hSMG1. ATM is a protein kinase that is activated by ionizing radiation and phosphorylates proteins involved in cell cycle control and DNA repair. ATM phosphorylates BRCA1, Chk2, and p5 3 in response to ionizing radiation. Phosphorylation of Chk2 and BRCA1 by ATM leads to cell cycle arrest at the G1 / S and G2 / M checkpoints, respectively. Phosphorylation of p5 3 by ATM leads to increased transcription of the cyclin dependent kinase inhibitor p2 1, which mediates cell cycle arrest at the G1 checkpoint. Other ATM substrates include the DNA repair proteins NBS1 and the DNA-PK catalytic subunit. ATM also phosphorylates the histone variant H2AX in response to ionizing radiation, which may contribute to the recruitment of ATM and other factors to sites of DNA damage. The role of ATM in DNA repair is supported by the observation that AT cells are defective in repair of DNA double-strand breaks. Other ATM substrates include the transcription factor NF-kB, the c-Abl tyrosine kinase, and the DNA repair protein Rad5 0. ATM-dependent phosphorylation of c-Abl leads to activation of downstream signaling pathways that promote cell survival. ATM-dependent phosphorylation of Rad5 0 may be involved in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks by homologous recombination.
