The activation of the MAPK pathway by CCR5 may also play a role in other cellular responses that are induced by other chemokine receptors, such as the induction of chemotaxis. The activation of the MAPK pathway by CCR5 may also play a role in other cellular responses that are induced by other chemokine receptors, such as the induction of actin polymerization. The activation of the MAPK pathway by CCR5 may also play a role in other cellular responses that are induced by other chemokine receptors, such as the induction of chemotaxis. The activation of the MAPK pathway by CCR5 may also play a role in other cellular responses that are induced by other chemokine receptors, such as the induction of apoptosis. The activation of the MAPK pathway by CCR5 may also play a role in other cellular responses that are induced by other chemokine receptors, such as the induction of chemotaxis. The activation of the MAPK pathway by CCR5 may also play a role in other cellular responses that are induced by other chemokine receptors, such as the induction of transcription.

Fas (APO-1or CD9 5) is a cell surface receptor that induces apoptosis when bound by Fas ligand (FasL). The Fas-FasL interaction is involved in the regulation of immune responses, and defects in this interaction can lead to autoimmune disease. Binding of FasL to Fas activates the apoptotic signaling cascade through the caspase pathway. The Fas-induced apoptotic signal is transmitted through the adaptor protein FADD (Fas-associated via death domain), which binds to the intracellular domain of Fas and recruits the initiator caspase, caspase-8 (FLICE). Caspase-8 activation occurs through autocatalysis and cleavage, and then activates downstream caspases, such as caspase-3, -6 and-7. Caspase-3 activation leads to the cleavage of a variety of cellular substrates, resulting in cellular disassembly. The Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) pathway is also activated by Fas signaling, and may contribute to apoptosis through the upregulation of Fas expression. The p21-activated kinase (PAK2) is also activated by Fas signaling, and may contribute to apoptosis through the phosphorylation of downstream targets.

The transcription factor NF-kB is a key regulator of apoptosis and inflammation. The activation of NF-kB is involved in the cellular response to stress, cytokines, bacterial products, and viral infection. The activation of NF-kB is inhibited by its association with the inhibitor I-kB. The phosphorylation of I-kB by the I-kB kinase (IKK) complex leads to the ubiquitination and subsequent degradation of I-kB by the proteosome. The degradation of I-kB allows NF-kB to translocate to the nucleus and activate transcription of genes involved in inflammation and apoptosis. The activation of NF-kB by the HTLV-1 Tax protein is involved in the cellular transformation of T cells by HTLV-1. Tax activates NF-kB by three different mechanisms. First, Tax interacts with the IKK complex and activates its kinase activity. Second, Tax interacts with the I-kB kinase complex and causes the dissociation of the IKK complex. Third, Tax interacts with the CBP / p300 coactivator and causes its dissociation from NF-kB. The activation of NF-kB by Tax is involved in the cellular transformation of T cells by HTLV-1.

RET encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) that is activated by its ligand, glial cell line-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF). The RET receptor is expressed in neurons and in the kidney. Germline mutations in RET cause multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN 2A) and 2B (MEN 2B). MEN 2A is characterized by the development of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytoma (PHEO), and hyperparathyroidism (HPT). MEN2B is characterized by the presence of mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and PHEO. Somatic mutations in RET are found in > 5 0% of sporadic MTC. The most common mutation in MEN 2A and sporadic MTC is an in-frame duplication of one amino acid in codon 6 1 8 (TPM3). This mutation leads to constitutive dimerization and activation of RET. The MEN 2B mutation is a single base pair change in codon 9 1 8 (ATG1> ACG). This mutation results in a RET protein with a > 1 0 0-fold increase in kinase activity. Constitutive activation of RET leads to uncontrolled proliferation of cells. The MET oncogene is also a receptor tyrosine kinase that is activated by hepatocyte growth factor (HGF). The MET mutation that causes the germ line mutation in hereditary papillary renal carcinoma (HPRC) is also a constitutively active kinase. The MET mutation in HPRC leads to increased HGF binding and prolonged signaling. The constitutive activation of MET in HPRC leads to the development of multiple renal tumors.

The E2F family of transcription factors plays a key role in regulating the progression of cells from G1 to S phase of the cell cycle. The E2F family of proteins includes eight different genes that are divided into two groups based on sequence homology and functional similarity. The first group includes E2F1, E2F2 and E2F3a. These three genes encode proteins that act as transcriptional activators and are involved in the regulation of genes involved in DNA synthesis and cell cycle progression. E2F3b and E2F3c are transcriptional repressors that oppose the action of the activators. The second group includes E2F4, E2F5 and E2F6. These three genes encode proteins that act as transcriptional repressors and are involved in the regulation of genes involved in differentiation. E2F7 and E2F8 are the newest members of the E2F family. E2F7 and E2F8 are transcriptional activators that appear to play a role in the control of cell proliferation during development.

Rac GTPases are members of the Rho family of small G proteins that regulate the actin cytoskeleton. They are involved in a variety of cellular functions, including cell motility, membrane ruffling, cell cycle progression, and gene transcription. Rac proteins cycle between GTP- and GDP-bound states, with the GDP-bound form being the inactive form. Guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs) activate Rac by promoting the exchange of GDP for GTP. GAPs inactivate Rac by stimulating the hydrolysis of bound GTP to GDP. Guanine nucleotide dissociation inhibitors (GDIs) bind to the GDP-bound form of Rac and keep it in the cytosol. Guanine nucleotide dissociation inhibitors also inhibit the dissociation of GDP from Rac, keeping Rac in the inactive state in the absence of extracellular stimuli. Several GEFs and GAPs for Rac have been identified, but the regulation of these factors is not well understood. One of the best characterized Rac GEFs is Vav, which is activated by tyrosine phosphorylation. Another Rac GEF is Tiam-1, which is activated by the Rac-related protein Tiam-1. Another Rac GAP is p120GAP. Several Rac effectors have been identified. One of the first Rac effectors to be identified was PAK, a serine / threonine kinase. PAK interacts with Rac through a CRIB domain and phosphorylates downstream targets. One of the targets of PAK is p21, a Ras-related protein that stimulates Rac GEF activity. Another Rac effector is the lipid kinase phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI 3-kinase). Rac also activates the MAP kinase pathways, including the JNK and ERK pathways. Rac also interacts with other small G proteins, such as Cdc 4 2 and Rho. Rac may also interact with other proteins to regulate its activity.

The JAK / STAT pathway is a major signaling pathway used by cytokines to transmit signals from the cell surface to the nucleus. The JAK / STAT pathway is used by a wide variety of cytokines and growth factors to transmit signals from the cell surface to the nucleus. The JAK / STAT pathway is used by a number of cytokines including IL-6, IL-1 0, LIF, CNTF, OSM, and IFN-gamma. The JAK proteins are a family of cytoplasmic tyrosine kinases that are activated by cytokine receptors. Binding of cytokine to its receptor activates the JAK kinases, which in turn phosphorylate and activate the STAT proteins. Activated STAT proteins dimerize and translocate to the nucleus where they activate transcription of target genes. The SOCS proteins are a family of proteins that act as cytokine inducible negative regulators of the JAK / STAT pathway. The SOCS proteins are induced by cytokine signaling and then bind to the JAK kinases or activated STATs to inhibit further signaling.

Bradykinin (BK) is a nonapeptide formed by the enzymatic degradation of high molecular weight kininogen. BK is a potent vasodilator and a potent stimulator of permeability in the microcirculation. The BK receptor is a G-protein coupled receptor that is coupled to phospholipase C and inositol phosphate formation. The vascular endothelial cell BK receptor is a heterodimer consisting of the B1and B2Rs. The B1R is coupled to Gq / 1 1 and activation of phospholipase C, whereas the B2R is coupled to Gi / o and inhibition of adenylyl cyclase. The B2R is also coupled to phospholipase A2. The B2R is also coupled to the tyrosine kinase Src and the mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway. The B1R is coupled to Gq / 1 1 and activation of phospholipase C. The B1R and B2R are widely distributed in the body and are involved in a variety of physiological processes. The B1R is constitutively expressed in the lung, brain, and kidney. The B2R is constitutively expressed in the lung and is induced in the kidney and other tissues by inflammatory stimuli. The B2R is also expressed in the brain. The B1R is involved in the regulation of blood pressure and sodium homeostasis, whereas the B2R is involved in the inflammatory response. The B1R is involved in the regulation of vascular permeability and edema formation in the lung.

DNA mismatch repair (MMR) is a highly conserved DNA repair mechanism that corrects DNA replication errors, including insertion-deletion mismatches and some forms of DNA damage. MMR corrects DNA mismatches generated during DNA replication to maintain genomic stability. MMR also recognizes and repairs some forms of DNA damage, including O 6 -methylguanine (O 6 -MeG) generated by SN1 alkylating agents. Defects in MMR increase mutation rates and are associated with cancer predisposition in humans. In Escherichia coli, MMR is initiated by MutS, which recognizes and binds to mismatches. MutL activates the MutH endonuclease, which incises the unmethylated daughter strand at hemimethylated d (GATC) sites. UvrD helicase and exonuclease I nick the gap, and DNA polymerase III and DNA ligase complete repair. In eukaryotes, MMR is initiated by MutSα (MSH2-MSH6) or MutSβ (MSH2-MSH3), which bind to mismatches. MutLα (MLH1-PMS2) or MutLβ (MLH1-PMS1) activates the UvrD helicase and exonuclease I to repair the mismatch. In addition to MMR, MutS and MutL homologs play important roles in other DNA repair pathways and in genome stability through their interactions with other factors.

The innate immune system provides the first line of defense against microbial pathogens. Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are the pattern recognition receptors that recognize microbial components and activate innate immune responses. Mammalian TLRs are expressed in various cell types including macrophages, dendritic cells, and fibroblasts. They are characterized by an extracellular domain containing leucine-rich repeats, a transmembrane domain, and a cytoplasmic domain. TLRs are expressed on the cell surface or in intracellular compartments. Upon ligand recognition, TLRs recruit an adaptor protein MyD8 8 through the TIR domain. MyD8 8 in turn activates a set of downstream signaling molecules, including interleukin-1 receptor-associated kinase (IRAK), TNF receptor-associated factor (TRAF) -6, and nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-kB). These signaling events lead to induction of proinflammatory cytokines and type I interferons. IRAK-4 is a negative regulator of TLR signaling. Mice deficient in IRAK-4 are hyper-responsive to TLR ligands and exhibit increased susceptibility to infection.

B cell receptor (BCR) activation is essential for the maturation and survival of B cells. BCR activation initiates a complex signaling cascade that leads to the activation of B cells. The BCR complex is composed of immunoglobulin (Ig) and Ig-alpha / Ig-beta heterodimer. The Ig-alpha / Ig-beta heterodimer is associated with the heterodimer of Igalpha and Igbeta. The cytoplasmic domain of Ig-alpha contains two tyrosine residues that are phosphorylated upon BCR activation. The phosphorylation of these tyrosines creates binding sites for the SH2 domain-containing signaling molecules. The tyrosine kinase Lyn is the first kinase to be activated upon BCR activation. Lyn phosphorylates the Ig-alpha / Ig-beta heterodimer, which in turn recruits and activates the tyrosine kinase Syk. The activation of Syk leads to the activation of downstream pathways, including the phospholipase C-gamma 2 (PLC-gamma 2) pathway, the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway, and the NF-AT pathway.

The cAMP-dependent protein kinase A (PKA) pathway is a key signaling pathway that is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including differentiation, proliferation, and apoptosis. The PKA pathway is activated by a variety of extracellular signals, including neurotransmitters, hormones, and growth factors. The binding of these ligands to their respective cell surface receptors results in the activation of adenylate cyclase, which synthesizes cAMP from ATP. The intracellular concentration of cAMP is regulated by the opposing actions of adenylate cyclase and phosphodiesterases. The binding of cAMP to the regulatory subunits of PKA results in the release of the catalytic subunits, which are then free to phosphorylate downstream targets. The PKA holoenzyme is a tetramer consisting of two regulatory subunits and two catalytic subunits. There are four regulatory subunits (RIalpha, RIbeta, RIIalpha, and RIIbeta) and four catalytic subunits (Calpha, Cbeta, Cgamma, and Prkx). The PKA regulatory subunits bind four molecules of cAMP, whereas the catalytic subunits have no regulatory function on their own. The PKA regulatory subunits are encoded by two genes, Prkar1a and Prkar1b, and the PKA catalytic subunits are encoded by three genes, Prkaca, Prkacb, and Prkx. cAMP binds to the regulatory subunits, causing a conformational change that releases the catalytic subunits. The catalytic subunits are then free to phosphorylate downstream targets. The PKA catalytic subunits are encoded by three genes, Prkaca, Prkacb, and Prkx. cAMP response element binding protein (CREB) is a transcription factor that is activated by PKA. Phosphorylation of CREB by PKA results in the binding of CREB to the cAMP-response element (CRE), which in turn activates the transcription of genes containing the CRE. The PKA regulatory subunit RIIbeta has been shown to be a tumor suppressor gene, and loss of this gene leads to the formation of tumors in a variety of tissues. The PKA catalytic subunit Calpha has been shown to be a proto-oncogene. The Prkar1a gene encodes a PKA regulatory subunit that inhibits the activity of the PKA catalytic subunits. Loss of this gene results in increased PKA activity and increased cellular proliferation. The Prkar1b gene encodes a PKA regulatory subunit that is less sensitive to inhibition by PKA regulatory subunits. Loss of this gene also results in increased cellular proliferation, but this effect is independent of PKA activity. The E1a gene of adenovirus encodes a protein that binds to the p300 family of PKA regulatory subunits and inhibits their ability to inhibit PKA activity. The E1a protein of adenovirus also binds to the CBP / p300 transcriptional coactivators and stimulates the activity of CREB. The interaction of adenovirus E1a with the p300 transcriptional coactivators may provide a useful tool for studying the role of these coactivators in transcriptional regulation.

The protein translocation channel in the inner membrane of the mammalian endoplasmic reticulum is formed by the heterotrimeric complex Sec6 1alpha-Sec61beta. The channel is the primary route for the transport of proteins into the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). The channel is gated by a lateral gate formed by the membrane protein Sec61. The translocation channel is a component of the protein-conducting membrane-bound Sec complex. The Sec complex is a highly conserved protein transport machinery found in bacteria, archaea and eukaryotes. The Sec complex is associated with the translocon, a protein-conducting channel in the membrane of the ER. The translocon is formed by the heterotrimeric membrane protein Sec6 1alpha-Sec61beta-Sec12beta. The translocon is the main channel for the passive transport of proteins into the ER. The transport of proteins into the ER is coupled to their posttranslational translocation. Proteins that have not yet acquired their correct three-dimensional structure are transported into the ER via the so-called cotranslational translocation pathway. Proteins are targeted to the translocon via the signal recognition particle (SRP) and its receptor (SR). The SRP-ribosome-nascent chain complex is recognized by the SRP receptor and the ribosome is transferred to the membrane-bound translocon. The ribosome-bound signal sequence is recognized by the docking complex Sec2221beta, the docking complex Sec2221beta is a heterodimer of the membrane proteins Sec2221beta and Sec2222beta. The ribosome-bound nascent chain is then transferred to the translocation channel. The channel is formed by the trimeric complex Sec6 1alpha-Sec61beta-Sec12beta.

Nerve Growth Factor (NGF) is a neurotrophic factor that promotes the survival and differentiation of neurons. NGF binds to TrkA, a receptor tyrosine kinase, and activates signaling pathways that regulate neuronal survival and differentiation. The NGF / TrkA signaling pathway also plays a role in the development and function of other tissues and cells.

Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain. GABA is released from presynaptic terminals and binds to GABA (A) receptors on the surface of the postsynaptic neuron. The GABA (A) receptor is a ligand-gated chloride ion channel that is activated by GABA. GABA (A) receptors are pentamers and are classified into three different subunit types: alpha, beta, and gamma. The GABA (A) receptor is a major target of many clinically important drugs, including benzodiazepines, barbiturates, and general anesthetics. GABA (A) receptors are also the site of action of many drugs of abuse, including ethanol. GABA (A) receptors are also targets of drugs that are anxiogenic or cause memory impairment, such as the anxiogenic drug diazepam and the general anesthetic etomidate. The activity of GABA (A) receptors is regulated by a number of proteins, including GABA (A) receptor-associated proteins (GABARAPs). GABARAPs interact with the intracellular domain of the GABA (A) receptor and may regulate the number of receptors on the cell surface. The GABARAP family of proteins includes GABARAP, Golgi-associated ATPase enhancer of 1 8kDa (GATE1 8), and light chain 3 (LC3II) of microtubule-associated proteins 1 and 2. GABARAP and GATE1 8 are involved in intracellular vesicle transport and may be involved in the transport of GABA (A) receptors to the cell surface. The interaction of GABARAP with the GABA (A) receptor is regulated by the small ubiquitin-like modifier (SUMO) protein. GABARAP is covalently modified by SUMO, and the modification of GABARAP by SUMO is required for the interaction of GABARAP with the GABA (A) receptor. GABARAP is also modified by ubiquitin, but the functional significance of this modification is not known. GABARAP is also involved in the transport of GABAA receptors to the cell surface in neurons. The transport of GABA (A) receptors to the cell surface in neurons may be regulated by phosphorylation of GABARAP by the protein kinase casein kinase II (CK2). The transport of GABA (A) receptors to the cell surface in neurons may be regulated by phosphorylation of GABARAP by CK2. The transport of GABA (A) receptors to the cell surface in neurons may be regulated by phosphorylation of GABARAP by CK2. The transport of GABA (A) receptors to the cell surface in neurons may be regulated by phosphorylation of GABARAP by CK2. The transport of GABA (A) receptors to the cell surface in neurons may be regulated by phosphorylation of GABARAP by CK2.

The AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) is a heterotrimeric enzyme complex that is activated by increased AMP / ATP ratio in cells. Once activated, AMPK phosphorylates and thereby inactivates acetyl-CoA carboxylase (ACC), the rate-limiting enzyme in fatty acid biosynthesis. It also phosphorylates and stimulates the activity of the glucose transporter GLUT4, leading to increased glucose uptake into cells and increased glycogen storage. In addition, AMPK phosphorylates and thereby inactivates HMG-CoA reductase, the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol biosynthesis. These effects of AMPK activation are consistent with the observed increase in fatty acid oxidation and a decrease in fatty acid synthesis in response to AMPK activation. In addition, AMPK activation increases glucose uptake and glycogen synthesis in skeletal muscle. These effects of AMPK activation are consistent with the observed increase in glucose uptake and glycogen synthesis in response to AMPK activation in skeletal muscle. The anti-diabetic drug metformin activates AMPK in liver and skeletal muscle, and this may contribute to the glucose-lowering effects of metformin.

The G1 to S phase transition of the cell cycle is a critical regulatory checkpoint that must be carefully controlled to prevent unscheduled cell proliferation. The G1 to S phase transition is regulated by the cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs), which are in turn regulated by the CDK inhibitors (CKIs). The CKI proteins include the INK4 family (p16, p15, p18, and p19) and the Cip / Kip family (p16, p18, and p19). The INK4 family of inhibitors specifically inhibit the CDK4 and CDK6 kinases, while the Cip / Kip family of inhibitors inhibit the activities of the cyclin D1, cyclin E, and CDK2 kinases. The INK4 and Cip / Kip families of CKIs are all regulated by the Rb tumor suppressor gene. The Rb gene is regulated transcriptionally by the E2F transcription factors, and the Rb protein binds to the E2F transcription factors and represses their transcriptional activity. When the Rb gene is mutated or deleted, the E2F factors become constitutively active, inducing the transcription of genes involved in cell cycle progression and DNA replication. The INK4 and Cip / Kip families of CKIs are regulated at the level of transcription. The p16 and p19 proteins are induced by and are required for growth arrest induced by the p53 tumor suppressor gene. The p18 and p15 proteins are induced by the activated Ras oncogene, and these proteins inhibit the formation of the cyclin D-CDK4 and CDK6 complexes, thereby inhibiting cell cycle progression. The Ras oncogene also induces the expression of the p21 protein, which inhibits the formation of the cyclin E-CDK2 complex, further inhibiting cell cycle progression.

Cell cycle progression through the G1 phase is regulated by the cyclin D-cdk4 / 6 complex, which phosphorylates the retinoblastoma protein (Rb), releasing the transcription factor E2F-1. E2F-1 induces the expression of genes required for S-phase entry, including cyclin E, which activates cdk2 and p53. The induction of p53 by E2F-1 also contributes to the induction of p53 by E2F-1. The activation of p53 by E2F-1 leads to a positive feedback loop that reinforces the activation of E2F-1 and p53. The induction of p53 by E2F-1 is required for the S-phase entry and cell cycle progression.

The mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway is a highly conserved signaling cascade that is involved in the regulation of cell proliferation, differentiation and survival. The MAPK pathway is activated by growth factor receptors and by the small G protein Ras. Growth factor receptors activate the small G protein RAS, which activates the RAF / MEK / ERK kinase cascade. The BRAF gene is mutated in a high percentage of melanomas, and these mutations result in the constitutive activation of the MAPK pathway. The BRAF mutation is an early event in melanomagenesis, as it is found in dysplastic nevi. The NRAS mutation is found in both primary and metastatic melanomas, suggesting that it is an early event in melanomagenesis. The CDKN2A gene encodes two proteins, p16INK4A and p14ARF, that regulate the cell cycle and apoptosis. The p16INK4A protein inhibits the cell cycle by blocking the action of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs). The p14ARF protein binds to MDM2, a ubiquitin ligase that targets p5 3 for degradation, and stabilizes p5 3. Mutations in the CDKN2A gene are found in a high percentage of melanomas, and these mutations lead to the loss of p16INK4A and p14ARF. The activation of the MAPK pathway by the BRAF mutation and the loss of p16INK4A and p14ARF allow the cell cycle to progress unchecked.

The cadherin-catenin complex is a key mediator of cell-cell adhesion. The cadherin-catenin complex is localized at adherens junctions, where it interacts with the actin cytoskeleton. The cadherin-catenin complex is linked to the actin cytoskeleton through alpha-catenin. The cadherin-catenin complex is linked to the extracellular matrix through integrins. The cadherin-catenin complex is also linked to the APC tumor suppressor protein. The APC tumor suppressor protein is linked to beta-catenin through the scaffold protein axin. The APC tumor suppressor protein is linked to beta-catenin through the scaffold protein conductin. The scaffold protein axin also interacts with the protein kinase GSK-3. The scaffold protein axin also interacts with the protein kinase GSK-3. The scaffold protein axin is part of a multiprotein complex that targets beta-catenin for phosphorylation and degradation by the proteosome. The phosphorylation of beta-catenin by GSK-3 targets it for ubiquitination and degradation by the proteosome. The phosphorylation of beta-catenin by GSK-3 is inhibited by Wnt signaling. Wnt signaling inhibits the phosphorylation of beta-catenin by GSK-3, stabilizing beta-catenin and allowing it to translocate to the nucleus. In the nucleus, beta-catenin interacts with the TCF / LEF transcription factors to activate genes involved in cell proliferation and differentiation. CTNND1 (catenin delta 1) is a member of the catenin gene family. CTNND1 is localized to chromosome 1q4 2. 3. CTNND1 encodes for delta-catenin, a member of the catenin gene family. CTNND1 is expressed in the developing brain and is upregulated in the adult brain. CTNND1 is upregulated in some cancers, including melanoma, breast, and prostate. The delta-catenin protein is localized to the cytoplasm and the nucleus. CTNND1 interacts with the cadherin-catenin complex and may play a role in cell-cell adhesion.

Inflammation is a protective response to harmful stimuli such as infection. The inflammatory response is initiated by the release of inflammatory cytokines such as IL-1 and TNF from activated macrophages. The inflammatory cytokines activate endothelial cells, which express adhesion molecules such as E-selectin, P-selectin, and VCAM-1. These adhesion molecules mediate the attachment of leukocytes to the activated endothelium and their subsequent migration into the tissue. The migration of leukocytes into the tissue is regulated by chemokines such as IL-8 and CXCL-1. The activation of endothelial cells by cytokines also leads to the production of kinins, a group of peptides that cause vasodilation and increase vascular permeability. Kinins are released from kininogen by the protease activity of plasma kallikrein. Kininogen is cleaved by plasma kallikrein and factor XII to release bradykinin, a peptide that causes the pain of the inflammatory response. The release of bradykinin also activates the release of the hypotensive hormone vasopressin. The release of bradykinin by the inflammatory response may also act as a feedback mechanism to increase the inflammatory response.

The chemokine receptor CCR5 is expressed on macrophages and T cells and is involved in the immune response to infection. The chemokine RANTES (regulated on activation normal T cell expressed and secreted) binds to CCR5 and activates signaling pathways that lead to chemotaxis, actin reorganization, and other cellular responses. The signaling pathways downstream of CCR5 include the small G proteins Rac and Rho, the p38 MAP kinase pathway, and the small G protein kinase PAK. The p38 MAP kinase pathway is involved in actin reorganization and is activated by CCR5 through both the small G proteins Rac and Rho and the small G protein kinase PAK. The small G protein kinase PAK is involved in the regulation of p38 and is activated by Rac and Cdc4 2. The chemokine receptor CCR5 also activates the small G protein RhoA, which is involved in cytoskeletal reorganization and is involved in cell migration. The activation of RhoA by CCR5 is independent of the p38 pathway and is mediated by the small G protein Rac. The activation of Rac and RhoA by CCR5 is independent of phospholipase C and calcium flux, but is dependent on the G protein subunit alpha q. The activation of Rac and RhoA by CCR5 is involved in cellular responses such as actin reorganization and chemotaxis.

Interleukin-1 8 (IL-18) is a cytokine that induces the production of interferon-gamma (IFNgamma) and other cytokines and is a key mediator of inflammation. IL-18 is a 1 8kDa protein that is cleaved to a 70 amino acid form that is secreted. IL-18 signals through a cell-surface receptor that is distinct from the IL-1receptor and signals through a pathway that includes the kinases map kinase 8 and map kinase 26, the transcription factor STAT-4, and the transcription factor IRF-1. IL-18 signals through the IL-1receptor-like complex and the Jak / Stat pathway used by IL-12. IL-18 also induces the expression of the IL-1receptor antagonist (IL-1RA), which competes with IL-18 for the IL-1receptor. IL-18 is an important mediator of inflammation and is a therapeutic target for the treatment of inflammatory diseases.

Natural killer (NK) cells are lymphocytes of the innate immune system that are involved in the recognition and lysis of cells that display abnormal expression of MHC-I or display some otherwise normal self-molecules. NK cells do not express antigen receptors of the immunoglobulin gene family but do express a variety of receptors that are involved in the regulation of NK cell activation. These receptors include activating receptors that trigger NK cell cytotoxicity, such as the receptors for MHC-I-specific or -non-specific killer cell immunoglobulin-like receptors (KIRs), the activating lectin-like receptors (e.g., NKG2D), and the CD9 4-NKG2A heterodimer. Inhibitory receptors that are specific for MHC-I molecules, such as the killer cell lectin-like receptor (KLR) -1or the leukocyte Ig-like receptor (LIR) -1, block NK cell activation. Activating and inhibitory receptors are often co-expressed on the same cell, and the balance of signals from these receptors determines the activation or inhibition of the cell. NK cell activation is triggered by engagement of activating receptors and is inhibited by engagement of MHC-I-specific inhibitory receptors. NK cell cytotoxicity is triggered by the release of perforin and granzyme B, which leads to the formation of pores in the membrane of the targeted cell and the activation of caspases.

Taste perception is a complex process that involves the interaction of many molecules. The sense of taste is mediated by taste receptors located in the oral cavity. These receptors are stimulated by tastants, which are molecules that elicit a taste, and result in the activation of specific signaling pathways that lead to the perception of a taste. The transduction pathways activated by taste receptors are diverse and include the activation of ion channels, second messenger pathways, and the release of neurotransmitters. The transduction pathways activated by sweet, umami, and bitter compounds converge on the activation of gustducin, a G protein alpha subunit that is specific to taste cells. The activation of gustducin leads to the inhibition of the TRPM5 ion channel and the subsequent inhibition of the sweet, umami, and bitter transduction pathways. The activation of these transduction pathways by tastants is also modulated by the presence of other signaling molecules. The activation of the tastant receptors by amino acids is modulated by the binding of glutamate to the mGluR4 receptor. The activation of the tastant receptors by sour compounds is modulated by the presence of bicarbonate ions. The transduction pathways activated by the tastant receptors by acids are not yet known.

Hypoxia is a common feature of solid tumors. Hypoxia-inducible factor-1 (HIF-1) is a transcription factor that plays a key role in cellular and systemic responses to hypoxia. HIF-1 is a heterodimer consisting of HIF-1alpha and ARNT (aryl hydrocarbon receptor nuclear translocator) subunits. HIF-1 binds to a hypoxia-responsive element (HRE) in the promoters of many genes, increasing their expression in hypoxia. HIF-1 is also stabilized by the hypoxia mimetic agent desferrioxamine (DFX). HIF-1 is degraded in the presence of oxygen by the proteosome, but in the absence of oxygen HIF-1 is stabilized. HIF-1 is regulated by oxygen through post-translational hydroxylation of specific proline residues in HIF-1 by a family of prolyl hydroxylases (PHDs). The von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor protein (VHL) targets hydroxylated HIF-1 for degradation by the proteosome. The hydroxylation of HIF-1 by PHDs requires oxygen, iron, and 2-oxoglutarate. HIF-1 is also regulated by nitric oxide (NO). NO stabilizes HIF-1 through a mechanism that does not require the VHL protein. HIF-1 induces the expression of genes involved in angiogenesis, erythropoiesis, and vasomotor control. HIF-1 may play a role in tumor growth by stimulating angiogenesis and by increasing oxygen delivery to the tumor. HIF-1 may also play a role in the response of the body to hypoxia.

Breast cancer is the most common malignancy in women and the second leading cause of cancer death in American women. The 5year survival rate for breast cancer patients is 9 0% for patients with localized disease, but only 2 3% for patients with metastatic disease. The metastatic spread of breast cancer cells is a complex process that involves multiple steps, including local invasion, intravasation, circulation, extravasation, and growth at a distant site. The extracellular matrix (ECM) is a complex network of macromolecules that provides structural support and regulates cell behavior. The degradation of the ECM by tumor cells is essential for tumor cell invasion and metastasis. Cathepsin D is a lysosomal aspartic protease that degrades the ECM and is associated with tumor progression and metastasis. Cathepsin D is overexpressed in breast cancer cells and is secreted into the extracellular space. Secreted cathepsin D activates the protease meprin, a metalloprotease, and the protease MMP-2, a member of the matrix metalloproteinase (MMP) family. Meprin and MMP-2 degrade ECM components and basement membranes, allowing tumor cells to invade local tissues and metastasize. Cathepsin D also activates the protease plasmin, which in turn activates MMP-2. Meprin and MMP-2 are upregulated in breast tumors and are associated with tumor progression and metastasis. The interaction of breast tumor cells with the ECM is also regulated by cell adhesion molecules. E-cadherin is a transmembrane protein that mediates calcium-dependent cell-cell adhesion. Loss of E-cadherin expression is associated with tumor progression and metastasis. The transcription factor snail represses E-cadherin expression, increasing tumor cell motility and invasiveness. The transcription factor twist represses the expression of the tight junction protein occludin, increasing tumor cell motility and invasiveness. The expression of the metastasis-associated protein 1gene (MTA1) is associated with tumor metastasis. MTA1 interacts with the histone deacetylase (HDAC) complex to repress the transcription of estrogen receptor-alpha (ER-alpha), a key regulator of breast cancer progression. Loss of ER-alpha expression in breast cancer cells results in a loss of estrogen-dependent growth and a shift to estrogen-independent growth mediated by the growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase HER2. The HER2 pathway activates the transcription of the gene encoding the protease cathepsin D, which in turn activates meprin and MMP-2. The activation of meprin and MMP-2 by cathepsin D and HER2 leads to degradation of the ECM and increased tumor cell motility and metastasis.

Insulin like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) is a polypeptide hormone that has a variety of effects on growth and development. IGF-1 binds to the IGF-1 receptor and stimulates the tyrosine kinase activity of the receptor. The IGF-1 receptor activates several signaling pathways including the ras / p180GAP / MAPK pathway, the PI3 kinase pathway and the JAK / STAT pathway. The ras / p180GAP / MAPK pathway is activated by the binding of growth factors to their receptors and leads to the phosphorylation and activation of Raf1. Raf1 phosphorylates and activates MEK1, which in turn phosphorylates and activates ERK1 and ERK2. The PI3 kinase pathway is activated by growth factor receptors and leads to the phosphorylation and activation of Akt / PKB. Akt / PKB is a serine / threonine kinase that has been shown to play a role in cell survival. The JAK / STAT pathway is activated by growth factor receptors and leads to the phosphorylation and activation of STAT transcription factors.

The Krebs cycle is a central pathway of aerobic metabolism that produces NADH and FADH2 to drive the electron transport chain and produce energy in the form of a proton gradient. The cycle is also a major source of cellular precursors, such as 2-oxoglutarate, which is used as a precursor for amino acids and other compounds. The cycle begins with acetyl-CoA, which is converted to pyruvate by pyruvate dehydrogenase. Pyruvate is converted to acetyl-CoA by the action of pyruvate carboxylase, which also acts as a regulatory enzyme. Acetyl-CoA is converted to succinyl-CoA by the combined action of the pyruvate dehydrogenase and the alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complexes. Squalene is converted to isoprene by the addition of two molecules of farnesyl pyrophosphate. The next step in the cycle is the conversion of isocitrate to cis-aconitate by the enzyme aconitase. The next four steps are the same as those in the classical Krebs cycle, but with different enzymes. Succinyl-CoA is converted to fumarate by the sequential addition of the remaining three-carbon compounds of acetyl-CoA. The cycle ends with the conversion of carbon dioxide to the one-carbon compound, which is released as carbon dioxide.

The cell cycle is a series of coordinated events that lead to the duplication of cellular DNA and the subsequent division of the cell into two daughter cells. The cell cycle is regulated by a complex network of proteins that include cyclins, cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs), and CDK inhibitors (CKIs). The cyclin-CDK complex is inactive until it is phosphorylated by the CDK activating kinase (CAK) at threonine 1 60 and by the cyclin-dependent kinase 2 (CDK2) at threonine 161. Once activated, the cyclin-CDK complex phosphorylates downstream targets that lead to the G1 to S phase transition. The G1 to S phase transition is also regulated by the retinoblastoma protein (Rb). When unphosphorylated, Rb binds to E2F transcription factors and represses transcription of genes involved in DNA synthesis. Phosphorylation of Rb by the cyclin-CDK complex releases E2F, allowing transcription of genes involved in S phase progression. The G2 to M phase transition is regulated by the cyclin-dependent kinase CDK1 (CDC2). The activity of CDK1 is regulated by the checkpoint kinase CHK1 and WEE1 kinases. When activated, CHK1 and WEE1 phosphorylate and inhibit CDK1. DNA damage activates the ATM and ATR kinases, which in turn activate CHK1 and WEE1. Activated CHK1 and WEE1 phosphorylate and inhibit CDK1, halting the cell cycle and providing more time for the DNA repair machinery to correct the damage. Defects in the DNA damage checkpoint can lead to genomic instability and cancer.

The Notch signaling pathway is a highly conserved mechanism of intercellular communication that plays a key role in development. The Notch receptor is a single-pass transmembrane protein. The ligands Delta and Jagged / Serrate are transmembrane proteins. Binding of the ligand to the Notch receptor induces two proteolytic cleavages that release the Notch intracellular domain (NICD). NICD translocates to the nucleus and forms a complex with the DNA-binding protein CSL (CBF1, Su (H), Lag-1) and other transcriptional activators or co-activators. The NICD-CSL complex activates transcription of Notch target genes, including those involved in cell fate decisions. The first step in Notch signaling is ligand binding. The Rho GTPases are a subfamily of the Ras superfamily of small GTPases that includes the Ras, Rac, and Cdc-4 proteins. The Rho GTPases regulate a variety of cellular functions, including the formation of actin stress fibers, the formation of focal adhesions, and the regulation of cell motility. The Rho GTPases are active when bound to GTP and inactive when bound to GDP. The conversion of the GDP-bound form to the GTP-bound form is regulated by three classes of proteins: Guanine Exchange Factors (GEFs) that catalyze the release of GDP and the association of GTP; GTPase Activating Proteins (GAPs) that stimulate the intrinsic GTPase activity of the Rho protein; and Guanine Dissociation Inhibitors (GDIs) that bind to the inactive Rho-GDP complex and inhibit the release of GDP and the association of GTP. The Dbl family of GEFs are the largest class of Rho GEFs, with more than 8 0 members in the human genome. The Dbl family GEFs contain a catalytic Dbl homology (DH) domain and an adjacent pleckstrin homology (PH) domain. The Dbl family GEFs are regulated by a variety of mechanisms, including the interaction of the PH domain with phosphoinositides, phosphorylation by protein kinases, and interaction with other proteins. The Dbl family GEFs are further regulated by the presence or absence of additional domains. The Dbl family GEFs are further divided into two broad groups: those that act on only one Rho GTPase (e.g., Vav, Dbl, Lfc, and Vav-2) and those that act on more than one Rho GTPase (e.g., Ect2, Tiam1, and TrioGEF). The downstream signaling pathways of the Rho GTPases are not well characterized, but appear to be specific for each Rho GTPase. For example, the Rho-associated coiled-coil containing protein kinase (ROCK) is a downstream effector of Rho and regulates the formation of actin stress fibers and focal adhesions. ROCK also phosphorylates and activates LIMK, which phosphorylates and inactivates cofilin, an actin-depolymerizing protein. The Dia1 and Dia2 proteins are Rho-activated kinases that regulate the formation of actin filaments and focal adhesions. The p140 isoform of myosin II is also regulated by the Rho GTPases. The ERM proteins (Ezrin, Radixin, and Moesin) are involved in the formation of actin-membrane interactions and are regulated by the Rho GTPases. The p140 isoform of myosin II is involved in the formation of actin stress fibers and focal adhesions. The interaction of integrins with the extracellular matrix activates signaling pathways that lead to the activation of the Rho GTPases and the formation of focal adhesions and actin stress fibers. The Rho GTPases also play a role in cell motility. The formation of lamellipodia and filopodia is involved in the extension of the cell membrane and the formation of the leading edge of a cell, while the formation of focal adhesions and actin stress fibers is involved in the retraction of the cell and the formation of the trailing edge of a cell. The Rho GTPases are involved in cell motility through their regulation of the actin cytoskeleton. The activation of Rac and Cdc4 2 stimulate the formation of lamellipodia and filopodia, while the activation of Rho stimulates the formation of stress fibers and focal adhesions. The interaction of integrins with the extracellular matrix activates signaling pathways that lead to the activation of Rac and Cdc4 2, which stimulate the formation of lamellipodia and filopodia, while the interaction of integrins with the extracellular matrix activates pathways that activate Rho, which stimulates the formation of stress fibers and focal adhesions. The interaction of cells with the extracellular matrix also activates signaling pathways that activate FAK and paxillin, which are involved in the formation of focal adhesions. Apoptosis is a genetically controlled form of cell death that plays a key role in the removal of damaged cells and the regulation of cell numbers. Two major pathways of apoptosis have been identified: the extrinsic (receptor-mediated) pathway and the intrinsic (mitochondria-mediated) pathway. The extrinsic pathway is triggered by the binding of ligands to cell surface receptors of the tumor necrosis factor receptor (TNFR) family, such as Fas / APO1, and involves the activation of caspase-8. Caspase-8 activates caspase-3, -6 and -7, which directly cleave cellular proteins and cause the morphological changes associated with apoptosis. The intrinsic pathway is triggered by a variety of stimuli, including DNA damage, oxidative stress, and growth factor withdrawal, and leads to the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria. Cytochrome c interacts with Apaf-1 and caspase-9 to form the apoptosome, which activates caspase-9. Caspase-9 activates caspase-3, -6 and -7. The cleavage of cellular substrates by caspases leads to the morphological changes associated with apoptosis.

The dopamine D2 receptor is a G-protein coupled receptor that inhibits adenylyl cyclase and reduces cAMP levels. The cAMP pathway is involved in a variety of physiological processes including learning and memory. The dopamine D2 receptor is expressed in medium spiny neurons of the striatum where it inhibits the activity of the protein kinase A (PKA) pathway. The PKA pathway is involved in the phosphorylation of DARPP-32, a protein that inhibits the activity of the protein phosphatase PP-1. The inhibition of PP-1 by DARPP-32 results in an increase in the phosphorylation of a variety of substrates including the ion channel GluR1 and the dopamine D1 receptor. The inhibition of the PKA pathway by the dopamine D2 receptor also results in a decrease in the phosphorylation of CREB and a decrease in the expression of CRE-regulated genes. The dopamine D2 receptor also inhibits the activity of the phospholipase C pathway. The inhibition of phospholipase C by the dopamine D2 receptor is mediated by the pertussis toxin-sensitive G-protein Go. The inhibition of phospholipase C by the dopamine D2 receptor results in a decrease in the levels of IP3 and diacylglycerol and a decrease in the activation of protein kinase C. The inhibition of the phospholipase C pathway by the dopamine D2 receptor also results in a decrease in the phosphorylation of the GluR1 AMPA receptor subunit.

The immune system is comprised of cells that respond to infection and inflammation. Neutrophils are a key component of the immune system, and are recruited to sites of infection and inflammation by a variety of signals. One of the signals that recruits neutrophils to sites of inflammation is the interaction of the chemokine IL-8 with its receptor. IL-8 is a member of a family of chemokines that includes Gro-alpha, Gro-beta, and NAP-2. The IL-8 receptor is a G-protein coupled receptor, and is expressed on the surface of neutrophils. The interaction of IL-8 with its receptor causes the release of calcium from intracellular stores, and the activation of the neutrophil. The activation of the neutrophil causes the release of reactive oxygen species, the destruction of bacteria, and the formation of a neutrophil extracellular trap (NET). The NET is a web of DNA that is released from the activated neutrophil, and acts as a trap for bacteria. The interaction of IL-8 with its receptor also causes the chemotaxis of neutrophils to the site of inflammation. The interaction of IL-8 with its receptor is also involved in the activation of other cell types, including T cells and endothelial cells. The interaction of IL-8 with its receptor also causes the down regulation of the receptor, helping to turn off the response to IL-8. The interaction of IL-8 with its receptor is a key step in the immune response to infection and inflammation. The interaction of IL-8 with its receptor is a good target for the development of drugs to treat inflammatory conditions.

The regulation of the activity of DARPP-32 is complex and involves multiple signaling pathways. The phosphorylation of DARPP-32 at Thr75by PKA results in a conversion of DARPP-32 from an inhibitor of protein phosphatase-1 (PP1) to an inhibitor of protein phosphatase-2A (PP2A). The inhibition of PP2A by DARPP-32 results in the activation of the cdk5 / p35 kinase and subsequent phosphorylation of a number of downstream targets including the neurofilaments, the transcription factor, histone H3, and the microtubule associated protein, tau. The phosphorylation of DARPP-32 at Thr75by PKA also results in the inhibition of the dopamine and cAMP-regulated phosphoprotein, Mr = 32, 0 0 0 (DARPP-3 2), a potent inhibitor of PKA. The phosphorylation of DARPP-32 at Thr75by Cdk5 / p35 results in a reversal of the inhibition of PKA and the subsequent activation of PKA.

The innate immune system is the first line of defense against invading pathogens. It is activated by detecting conserved molecular patterns present in microbes, known as pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs), but not in the host cells. Viral nucleic acids are recognized by two classes of pattern recognition receptors (PRRs), Toll-like receptors (TLRs) and cytoplasmic RNA helicases, including RIG-I, MDA5 and LGP2. Upon recognition of viral nucleic acids, these receptors trigger signaling cascades that lead to the production of type I interferon (IFN) and other cytokines. Secreted IFN induces an antiviral state in infected cells and in neighboring cells through the JAK-STAT pathway, leading to the expression of a large set of genes with antiviral functions.

Leukocyte adhesion to the vascular endothelium is a key step in the inflammatory response. During inflammation, leukocytes are recruited from the bloodstream into tissues in response to inflammatory signals. The initial step in this process is the rolling of leukocytes on the vascular endothelium. This is mediated by the interaction of selectins on the leukocyte surface with P- and E-selectin on the vascular endothelium. After rolling, leukocytes are activated and adhere to the endothelium via integrins. This step is mediated by the interaction of lymphocyte function-associated antigen 1 (LFA-1) on the leukocyte with intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1) on the vascular endothelium. Other adhesion molecules such as PECAM-1 and VLA-4 also play a role in this step. After adhesion, leukocytes leave the vasculature and enter tissues. This step is mediated by PECAM-1 and PECAM-1 dependent signaling.

Interleukin-7 (IL-7) is a cytokine that is required for the development and function of T cells. The IL-7 receptor is composed of two polypeptide chains, the alpha chain (CD12 7) that is specific for IL-7 and the beta chain (CD25) that is shared with IL-2 and IL-1 5. The CD25 chain is unique to the IL-7 receptor and is required for signaling by IL-7. The activation of the JAK / STAT pathway by IL-7 is similar to that of IL-2 and IL-1 5. The JAK / STAT pathway includes activation of the JAK kinases, phosphorylation of the IL-7Ralpha chain, phosphorylation of the beta chain, activation of the STAT transcription factors, and induction of gene expression. The JAK kinases phosphorylate the IL-7Ralpha chain and the beta chain. The JAK kinases also phosphorylate the STAT transcription factors, STAT5a and STAT5b, that are activated by IL-7. The activation of the JAK / STAT pathway by IL-7 is similar to that of IL-2 and IL-1 5. The src family kinase, Lck, associates with the CD25 chain of the IL-7 receptor and is required for activation of the JAK kinases and the STAT transcription factors. The activation of Lck also leads to phosphorylation of the IL-7Ralpha chain and may contribute to the activation of the JAK / STAT pathway. The activation of Lck also leads to phosphorylation of the p300protein and the PI3 kinase pathway. The PI3 kinase pathway may contribute to the activation of the JAK / STAT pathway by IL-7. The activation of Lck and the PI3 kinase pathway may also contribute to the survival and proliferation of T cells by IL-7.

The transcription factor NFAT is a key regulator of cytokine gene expression in T cells. The activity of NFAT is regulated by the phosphatase calcineurin, which dephosphorylates NFAT, causing it to translocate from the cytoplasm to the nucleus and activate transcription. The activity of calcineurin is regulated by calcium, which is increased by the TCR. The activity of calcineurin is also regulated by the kinases GSK-3 and PKA, and by the phosphatase calcineurin itself. Calcineurin dephosphorylates NFAT, causing it to translocate to the nucleus and activate transcription. The transcription factor Sp1 also regulates cytokine gene expression in T cells, and interacts with NFAT to activate transcription synergistically. The interaction of NFAT and Sp1 is mediated by the transcription factor Sp3, which also interacts with NFAT. The interaction of NFAT and Sp1 is regulated by the kinase PKA, and by the phosphatase calcineurin. The interaction of NFAT and Sp1 is also regulated by the kinase PKC. The interaction of NFAT and Sp1 is also regulated by calmodulin. The interaction of NFAT and Sp1 is a key regulatory mechanism in T cells, and may also play a role in other cell types where these transcription factors are expressed.

Mucins are heavily glycosylated proteins that are secreted by epithelial cells. They are involved in a number of important functions including lubrication, protection from harmful agents, and cell signalling. The trefoil factor (TFF) family of peptides are small secreted proteins that are up-regulated in mucosal injury and repair. They are involved in mucosal restitution and repair and are potential therapeutic agents in the treatment of mucosal injury. The trefoil factors are characterized by the presence of three conserved cysteine residues that form intramolecular disulphide bonds. The three trefoil factors (pS2, spasmolytic polypeptide; TFF1, trefoil factor 1; TFF2, trefoil factor 2) are expressed in the gastrointestinal tract and are up-regulated in mucosal injury. TFF1 and TFF2 knockout mice have abnormal mucosal healing and TFF1 is down-regulated in gastric cancer. The trefoil factors are secreted onto the mucosal surface as a disulphide-linked dimer. The trefoil factors are mitogenic for a number of epithelial cell types and may act as motogens. The trefoil factors may also act as motogens in the gastrointestinal tract by stimulating the restitution of the epithelium. The trefoil factors may also act as mucosal protective agents by increasing the resistance of the epithelium to damage. The mechanism of action of the trefoil factors is not yet clear, but may involve activation of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR). The trefoil factors may act as EGFR ligands, activating the EGFR and downstream signalling pathways. The trefoil factors may also activate the EGFR by a mechanism involving the induction of the EGFR ligand heparin-binding EGF-like growth factor (HB-EGF). The trefoil factors may also act as motogens by inducing the expression of HB-EGF. The trefoil factors may also act as mucosal protective agents by inducing mucin secretion. The trefoil factors may also act as motogens by inducing the expression of mucin genes.

The inflammatory response is a complex series of events that involves the recruitment of leukocytes to the site of inflammation, their activation, and their subsequent migration to the site of inflammation. The initial step in this cascade is the rapid recruitment of leukocytes from the blood to the site of inflammation. This is accomplished by the rolling of leukocytes along the vascular endothelium, mediated by the interaction of the leukocyte adhesion molecule, P-selectin, with its ligand, P-selectin Glycoprotein, on the endothelium. Upon activation, leukocytes express a variety of adhesion molecules, including Mac-1 (alphaMbeta2, CD11b / CD1 8), LFA-1 (alphaLbeta2, CD11a / CD1 8), and VLA-4 (alpha4beta1, CD14b1 / CD18), that mediate their firm adhesion to endothelium and subsequent migration of leukocytes into the inflamed tissue. This cascade of events is tightly regulated by a variety of inflammatory mediators, including cytokines, chemokines, and lipid mediators.

The transcription factor NF-kB is involved in the regulation of many genes involved in the immune response, cell growth and apoptosis. The NF-kB family of transcription factors is formed by dimerization of the products of the NFKB1 (p5 0), NFKB2 (p5 2), RELA (p6 5), and REL (c-Rel) genes. The p5 0 and p5 2 proteins are synthesized from the NFKB1 and NFKB2 genes, respectively, and lack a transcriptional activation domain. The other two proteins, p6 5 and c-Rel, contain a transcriptional activation domain and are responsible for the transcriptional activity of the NF-kB complex. In the inactive state, NF-kB is retained in the cytoplasm by association with an inhibitor protein, I-kB. In response to a variety of stimuli, including mitogens, cytokines, and bacterial products, I-kB is phosphorylated by I-kB kinase (IKK), ubiquitinated and degraded by the proteosome, releasing NF-kB to translocate to the nucleus and activate transcription. The activation of NF-kB by bacterial products such as LPS is important in the innate immune response. The activation of NF-kB by cytokines such as TNF-alpha is involved in the inflammatory response. The activation of NF-kB by bacterial products such as LPS is important in the innate immune response. The activation of NF-kB by bacterial products such as LPS is important in the innate immune response. The actions of thyroid hormone are mediated by two receptors, TR alpha and TR beta, which bind to thyroid hormone response elements (TREs) in the promoter regions of target genes. TR can repress transcription in the absence of ligand, but is activated by thyroid hormone. The unliganded TR represses transcription by recruiting corepressors, including NCoR and SMRT, to the promoter region of the target gene. Upon binding of ligand, the corepressors are released and a coactivator complex is recruited, including p160, CBP / p300, and the Swi / Snf family of chromatin remodeling factors. The coactivators in turn interact with the basal transcriptional machinery to activate transcription. The balance of corepressors and coactivators bound to TR is influenced by the presence or absence of ligand, and by the phosphorylation state of the receptor.

The immune system consists of several different cell types, including lymphocytes, macrophages, and natural killer cells. Macrophages and lymphocytes respond to infection by secreting cytokines that alert the body and stimulate the immune system to respond more effectively. The first line of defense against infection is the innate immune system, which responds to the presence of infection without prior exposure. Macrophages and natural killer cells are part of the innate immune system and respond to infection by secreting cytokines that alert the body and stimulate the adaptive immune system. The adaptive immune system is activated only after the initial infection has been eliminated by the innate immune system. The adaptive immune system is slower and more specific in its response to infection. T cells and B cells respond to infection by secreting specific types of cytokines that stimulate the immune system to respond more effectively. Cytokines are small proteins secreted by other cells that act in a paracrine or autocrine manner to regulate the immune response. The innate immune system responds to infection with the secretion of cytokines, including IL-1, IL-6, and TNF, that stimulate the inflammatory response and activate macrophages and natural killer cells. B cells and T cells respond to infection with the secretion of antibodies and T cells secrete cytokines that stimulate the differentiation of B cells into antibody-secreting plasma cells. The adaptive immune system is activated only after the innate immune system has been activated by infection. The adaptive immune system is slower and more specific in its response to infection. T cells and B cells respond to infection with the secretion of cytokines, including IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, IL-10, IL-13, and TNF, that stimulate the differentiation of B cells into antibody-secreting plasma cells and T cells into helper T cells that stimulate the differentiation of B cells and other immune cells. The coordinated response of the innate and adaptive immune systems provides a more rapid and effective response to infection than the innate immune system alone.

The Wnt signaling pathway plays a key role in development and is also involved in the formation of some cancers. Secreted Wnt proteins bind to Frizzled receptors and activate the Wnt / frizzled pathway. Frizzled proteins are G-protein coupled receptors and activate heterotrimeric G proteins. G-protein activation leads to the activation of phospholipase C, which cleaves phosphatidylinositol 4, 5-bisphosphate into diacylglycerol and inositol 1, 4, 5-trisphosphate. The increase in inositol 1, 4, 5-trisphosphate activates calcium release from intracellular stores. Wnt also activates the small G protein Rho, which activates the kinase PKN. Wnt activation of the JNK pathway is also G-protein dependent. Wnt activation of the JNK pathway is blocked by expression of the axin tumor suppressor, which binds to the protein kinase CK1delta and GSK-3. GSK-3 is part of a multiprotein complex that phosphorylates beta-catenin, targeting it for degradation by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. Activation of Wnt signaling by Wnt leads to the inhibition of GSK-3, which leads to the accumulation of beta-catenin in the nucleus. Beta-catenin forms a complex with the transcription factors of the TCF / LEF family and activates the transcription of Wnt target genes. The transcription factor NFAT is another target of GSK-3 phosphorylation. NFAT is a transcription factor that is activated by the calcium-dependent phosphatase calcineurin. Wnt signaling also regulates the expression of NFAT.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that affects primarily the cerebral cortex and hippocampus. The two major pathological hallmarks of AD are senile plaques (SPs) and neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs). SPs are extracellular deposits of amyloid-beta (Abeta), a peptide derived from the amyloid-beta precursor protein (APP) by beta- and gamma-secretase cleavage. NFTs are intracellular aggregates of hyperphosphorylated tau. The amyloid cascade hypothesis states that Abeta plays a central role in the pathogenesis of AD. According to this hypothesis, the Abeta-induced neurotoxicity is mediated by the formation of amyloid plaques, which leads to the accumulation of tau proteins, which in turn causes synaptic dysfunction and neuronal loss. Recent studies have revealed that Abeta can be produced in neurons and that intraneuronal Abeta may be more toxic than extracellular Abeta. In addition, Abeta may also be involved in the pathogenesis of other neurodegenerative disorders, such as Parkinson's disease (PD) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Chemokine receptors are a family of G-protein coupled receptors that respond to chemotactic cytokines and are expressed on leukocytes, endothelial cells, and neurons. The ligands for these receptors are small proteins that are released by activated cells and act as chemoattractants to direct cell migration. The ligands include the chemokine Stromal Cell Derived Factor-1 (SDF-1) and the chemokine Macrophage Inflammatory Protein-3 (MIP-3). The chemokine receptors CXCR4 and CCR5 are used by HIV to gain entry into cells. The interaction of HIV with chemokine receptors activates signaling pathways that lead to cellular activation and possibly viral replication. The chemokine receptors CXCR4 and CCR5 are also used by the T-tropic strains of HIV to infect cells. The interaction of HIV with chemokine receptors activates signaling pathways that lead to cellular activation and possibly viral replication.

Glycogen is a branched polymer of glucose residues that serves as a major source of glucose in animals. In muscle, glycogen is rapidly degraded to glucose-1-phosphate and glucose upon exercise. The glucose-1-phosphate is released into the blood and is taken up by other tissues to be converted to glucose. The breakdown of glycogen in muscle is catalyzed by glycogen phosphorylase, which is activated by phosphorylation of a conserved Seryl residue. The enzyme is also allosterically activated by AMP and inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate. The breakdown of glycogen in liver is catalyzed by a different set of enzymes. In this case, the glucose residues are released as glucose-1-phosphate, which is converted to glucose by hexokinase. The glucose-1-phosphate is converted to glucose by phosphoglucomutase. The glucose-1-phosphate is also converted to glucose-6-phosphate by phosphoglucomutase. The glucose-6-phosphate is converted to glucose by glucose-6-phosphatase. The liver enzyme for glucose-6-phosphatase is also present in kidney and intestine. The liver enzyme for glycogen phosphorylase is also present in skeletal muscle, where it catalyzes the release of glucose from glycogen. The enzyme is activated by phosphorylation of a Seryl residue, and is inhibited by glucose-1-phosphate.

Blood coagulation is a series of proteolytic reactions that result in the formation of a clot at the site of vascular injury. The coagulation cascade can be divided into three phases: the extrinsic activation phase, the intrinsic activation phase, and the final common pathway. The extrinsic activation phase begins with the formation of a tissue factor (TF) -factor VIIa (FVII) complex in response to vascular injury. The TF-FVIIa complex activates factor X (FX), which is in turn activated by factor Xa (FXa). The TF-FVIIa complex also activates factor V (FV). The activated factors X and V form a complex that activates prothrombin. The intrinsic activation phase is triggered by the release of the platelet membrane-associated factors. alpha-Granulins are a class of proteins that are rich in tyrosine residues. The alpha-granules of platelets contain several factors that are released during platelet activation. These factors include ADP, epinephrine, serotonin, and PDGF. The release of these factors from the alpha-granules causes the activation of the coagulation cascade. The final common pathway is initiated by the activation of the tissue factor (TF) -factor VIIa complex. The TF-VIIa complex activates factors IX and X, which form a complex that activates prothrombin.

The RAS family of small GTPases are key regulators of cellular proliferation, differentiation, and survival. Activating mutations in RAS genes are found in approximately one-third of all human cancers. The RAS proteins are molecular on / off switches that cycle between an inactive GDP-bound state and an active GTP-bound state. In the active state, RAS interacts with a variety of downstream effectors to transmit the signal. The RAS-activated kinases RAF, PI3K, and RalGDS are involved in the mitogenic pathway, while the RAS-activated kinases RALGDS, TBK1, and RIN1 are involved in the survival pathway. The importance of RAS in cancer has led to the development of inhibitors that block the interaction of RAS with its effectors. One such inhibitor, Farnesyltransferase inhibitor R1 1 5 7 7 7, is in phase I clinical trials.

The immune system is comprised of a variety of cells, each of which plays a specific role in the immune response. T cells are key players in the immune response, and are responsible for coordinating the response to foreign antigens through the recognition of specific antigens presented by antigen-presenting cells. T cells are also involved in the recognition of self antigens, and are called self-reactive T cells. T cells are classified into two types based on the antigen they recognize. Helper T cells respond to antigens presented by MHC II molecules, while cytotoxic T cells respond to antigens presented by MHC I molecules. Helper T cells produce cytokines that stimulate other cells in the immune system, while cytotoxic T cells directly kill cells that present the specific antigen. Naive T cells are activated by antigen-presenting cells to proliferate and differentiate into effector cells. The activation of helper T cells requires the interaction of the T cell receptor with antigen-MHC complex, and the interaction of costimulatory molecules on the antigen-presenting cell with T cell receptors on the T cell. Cytotoxic T cell activation also requires the interaction of the T cell receptor with antigen-MHC, but in addition requires the interaction of costimulatory molecules on the antigen-presenting cell with T cell receptors on the T cell. Cytotoxic T cell activation also requires the interaction of cytokines produced by helper T cells with the antigen-presenting cell and the T cell. Cytotoxic T cells are also involved in the direct killing of cells that present specific antigens, and are called cytotoxic T cells. The differentiation of helper T cells into memory cells requires the interaction of the T cell receptor with antigen-MHC, and the interaction of costimulatory molecules with T cell receptors on the T cell. The interaction of cytokines produced by helper T cells with antigen-presenting cells and the T cell also plays a role in the differentiation of T cells into memory cells.

The gamma-aminobutyric acid type A (GABA (A)) receptor is a ligand-gated ion channel that mediates inhibitory neurotransmission in the brain. The GABA (A) receptor is a member of the cys-loop family of receptors that also includes the receptors for acetylcholine, serotonin, and glycine. Each subunit has a large amino-terminal extracellular domain, four transmembrane domains (M1-M4), a large second intracellular loop, a small extracellular loop, and a carboxy-terminal domain. The GABA (A) receptor is a pentamer, with five subunits surrounding a central pore. Each subunit has a unique pattern of expression in the brain and specific functional properties. The GABA (A) receptor is a major target of the general anesthetic propofol. The receptor is also the site of action of the drugs barbiturates and benzodiazepines. The genes for the subunits of the GABA (A) receptor have been identified and mapped to chromosomes 2q3 7 for the alpha subunits, 5q3 2 for the beta subunits, 2q3 2-.3 for the gamma subunits, and 4p1 5 for the delta subunit. The GABA (A) receptor is a major target of the action of the general anesthetic propofol. Mutations in the GABA (A) receptor have been identified in patients with generalized epilepsy with febrile seizures.

The initiation of DNA replication in eukaryotes is a highly conserved process that takes place once per cell cycle and is strictly regulated. The first step in the initiation of DNA replication is the formation of a pre-replication complex (pre-RC) at each replication origin. The formation of the pre-RC requires the binding of the origin recognition complex (ORC), cdc6, cdt1 and the mini-chromosome maintenance complex (Mcm) to chromatin in G1 phase. The binding of the pre-RC to chromatin is prevented by the binding of the cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) -cyclin complex to ORC, cdc6 and cdt1. At the G1 / S transition, the activation of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) and the Dbf4-dependent kinase (DDK) leads to the conversion of the pre-RC to a pre-initiation complex (pre-IC). The binding of the mini-chromosome maintenance complex (Mcm) to chromatin and the activation of the replication fork helicase (Cdc4 5 and the GINS complex) are the next steps in the initiation of DNA replication.

Inflammation is a response to harmful stimuli, such as bacteria, viruses, and irritants, and is essential for the elimination of these agents. The inflammatory response is initiated by the activation of resident tissue macrophages and the recruitment of circulating leukocytes to the site of inflammation. Macrophages are the first responders to tissue injury and infection, and are activated by cytokines, such as interferon-gamma (IFNgamma), tumor necrosis factor (TNF), and interleukin-1 (IL-1), to produce inflammatory mediators, including prostaglandins, leukotrienes, and reactive oxygen species. Macrophages also produce IL-8, a chemokine that attracts neutrophils to the site of inflammation. Neutrophils are the first responders to infection and are activated by IL-8 and other chemokines to migrate to the site of infection. Activated macrophages and neutrophils secrete additional inflammatory mediators, including prostaglandins, leukotrienes, and reactive oxygen species, that amplify the inflammatory response. The inflammatory response is tightly regulated to prevent damage to normal tissues, and cytokines play a key role in this regulation. For example, IL-1 0 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that inhibits the production of IL-1, TNF, and other pro-inflammatory cytokines. The inflammatory response is also regulated by anti-inflammatory cytokines, such as IL-4 and IL-13. IL-4 and IL-13 induce the expression of the anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10, which in turn inhibits the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines. The balance of pro- and anti-inflammatory cytokines is essential for the regulation of inflammation, and disruption of this balance can lead to disease. For example, a disruption of the IL-10 / IL-1 0 balance can lead to autoimmune disease, and a disruption of the IL-4 / IL-1 3 balance can lead to asthma.

The mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) cascade is a highly conserved signaling module that is used by various extracellular stimuli to regulate a variety of cellular responses, including cell proliferation, differentiation, motility, and survival. The core module consists of a MAPK kinase kinase (MAPKKK), an MAPK kinase (MAPKK), and a MAPK. The MAPKKKs include Raf, MEKK, and mixed lineage kinase (MLK) families. The MAPKKs include p38 kinase (p44 and p38) and c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) kinase (p46 and p36) families. The MAPKs include extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK), p38 kinase (p38), and JNK. Growth factors and cytokines activate receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) or cytokine receptors, which recruit and activate the small G proteins RAS and RAC. These small G proteins activate several downstream effectors, including the p21RAS-RAF-MEK-ERK kinase cascade and the p13RAS-RAC-MEKK1-p38 kinase cascade. The activation of these kinases ultimately leads to the phosphorylation and activation of various transcription factors, including ELK, ATF2, SRF, and STATs.

The epidermal growth factor (EGF) receptor is a member of the ErbB family of receptor tyrosine kinases. The EGF receptor is activated by binding of its ligand, EGF. The EGF receptor is involved in cellular proliferation, differentiation, and motility. The EGF receptor is overexpressed in a variety of cancers, including breast, lung, and prostate cancer. The EGF receptor is also involved in the development of drug resistance in cancer cells. The EGF receptor activates several signaling pathways, including the Ras-Raf-MAP kinase pathway, the PI-3 kinase pathway, and the Jak-Stat pathway. The EGF receptor activates the MAP kinase pathway through the Shc / Grb2 / Sos-1 pathway and the p70-S6 kinase pathway. The PI-3 kinase pathway is activated by the recruitment of Grb-2 and SOS to the plasma membrane by the EGF receptor and the subsequent activation of Ras and PI-3 kinase. The Jak-Stat pathway is activated by the phosphorylation of the EGF receptor and the recruitment of the Shp-2 tyrosine phosphatase and Stat transcription factors. The EGF receptor activates the AP-1 transcription factor through the MAP kinase pathway and the p70-S6 kinase pathway. The Ets family of transcription factors are targets of the MAP kinase pathway and are involved in the regulation of genes involved in cellular proliferation and differentiation.

The Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP) is a key regulator of actin cytoskeletal structure and dynamics. WASP is a member of the WASP family of proteins, which also includes N-WASP, WAVE1, WAVE2 and WAVE3. The WASP family members are characterized by the presence of a C-terminal verprolin-homology, central acidic (VCA) region that binds to the Arp2 / 3 complex and actin monomers, and a N-terminal verprolin-homology domain (V) and a WASP-homology (WH1) domain that binds to other proteins. The Arp2 / 3 complex is a seven protein complex that nucleates actin polymerization and is involved in the formation of branched actin networks. The WASP family proteins are regulated by a variety of factors, including the Rho family of small GTPases, phosphoinositides, and phosphorylation. The activity of WASP is stimulated by binding of Cdc4 2-GTP to the GBD, which relieves an intramolecular autoinhibitory interaction between the N-terminal WH1 domain and the VCA region. The phosphorylation of WASP by the tyrosine kinase Abl also stimulates its activity. The activity of N-WASP is regulated by its binding partners, including the adaptor protein Nck, which relieves an autoinhibitory interaction between the VCA and GBD domains. The activity of WAVE1 and WAVE2 is regulated by their binding to the adaptor proteins PIR1 2 1 and Abi1. The activity of WAVE3 is regulated by its binding to the adaptor protein HSPC3 0 0. The activity of the WASP family proteins is also regulated by their subcellular localization. The localization of WASP to the leading edge of migrating cells is regulated by the adaptor protein NckAP1, while the localization of N-WASP to filopodia is regulated by phosphoinositides. The localization of WAVE1 and WAVE2 to lamellipodia and membrane ruffles is regulated by the adaptor proteins PIR1 2 1 and Abi1. The localization of WAVE3 to the perinuclear region of the cell is regulated by its binding to HSPC3 0 0. The activity of the WASP family proteins is also regulated by their binding partners. The interaction of WASP with the adaptor protein Nck relieves an autoinhibitory interaction between the GBD and VCA regions. The interaction of N-WASP with the adaptor protein Grb2 relieves an autoinhibitory interaction between the GBD and VCA regions. The interaction of WAVE1 with PIR1 2 1 relieves an autoinhibitory interaction between the VCA and WH1 regions. The interaction of WAVE2 with Abi1 relieves an autoinhibitory interaction between the VCA and WH1 regions. The interaction of WAVE3 with HSPC3 0 0 relieves an autoinhibitory interaction between the VCA and WH1 regions.
