The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a transmembrane protein with an intracellular tyrosine kinase domain and an extracellular ligand-binding domain. Binding of ligand (EGF or transforming growth factor-alpha) to the extracellular domain of EGFR induces receptor dimerization and activation of the tyrosine kinase domain, resulting in the recruitment of signaling proteins to the receptor and the initiation of downstream signaling pathways. These pathways include the RAS / RAF / mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase (MEK) / extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) kinase (ERK) pathway, the phosphoinositide-3-kinase (PI3K) / AKT pathway, and the JAK / STAT pathway. EGFR overexpression and / or mutation is associated with the pathogenesis of many human cancers.

Interleukin-6 (IL-6) is a cytokine that signals through a receptor complex that includes the ligand-binding subunit (gp8 0) and the signal transducing subunit (gp1 3 0). The IL-6 receptor is widely expressed on cells of the hematopoietic system, hepatocytes, neurons, and other cell types. The IL-6 receptor is a member of the hematopoietin receptor family, which includes the receptors for IL-3, IL-5, and GM-CSF. The IL-6 receptor is a heterodimer, with gp1 3 0 being the signal transducing subunit. The IL-6 receptor does not have intrinsic kinase activity, but associates with JAK kinases that are activated by the receptor upon ligand binding. The JAKs phosphorylate the receptor and the associated gp1 3 0, creating binding sites for signaling molecules like STAT3. STAT3 is activated by phosphorylation on tyrosine and is then able to dimerize and translocate to the nucleus to activate transcription. The JAK / STAT pathway is a major signaling pathway used by many cytokines. The JAKs and STATs are also activated by other signaling pathways, including the EGF receptor and Ras. The JAKs phosphorylate and activate each other and the STATs. The JAKs and STATs are also activated by other signaling pathways, including the EGF receptor and Ras. The JAKs and STATs are also activated by other signaling pathways, including the IL-6 receptor and Ras. The JAKs and STATs are also activated by other signaling pathways, including the IL-6 receptor and Ras. The JAKs and STATs are also activated by other signaling pathways, including the IL-6 receptor and Ras. The JAKs and STATs are also activated by other signaling pathways, including the IL-6 receptor and Ras. The JAKs and STATs are also activated by other signaling pathways, including the IL-6 receptor and Ras. The JAKs and STATs are also activated by other signaling pathways, including the IL-6 receptor and Ras. The JAKs and STATs are also activated by other signaling pathways, including the IL-6 receptor and Ras. The JAKs and STATs are also activated by other signaling pathways, including the IL-6 receptor and Ras. The JAKs and STATs are also activated by other signaling pathways, including the IL-6 receptor and Ras. The JAKs and STATs are also activated by other signaling pathways, including the IL-6 receptor and Ras. The JAKs and STATs are also activated by other signaling pathways, including the IL-6 receptor and Ras.

The Janus kinase / signal transducers and activators of transcription (JAK / STAT) pathway is a key mediator of cytokine signaling. Cytokines bind to their cognate receptors, activating receptor-associated JAK kinases, which in turn phosphorylate and activate the STAT transcription factors. Activated STATs translocate to the nucleus and activate transcription of cytokine-responsive genes.

Platelet Derived Growth Factor (PDGF) is a dimeric protein that is released by platelets and that acts as a mitogen for cells of mesenchymal origin. The active form of PDGF is a dimer of A and / or B chains. Each PDGF dimer binds to two different cell surface receptors, PDGFR-alpha and PDGFR-beta. PDGFR-alpha binds to the A chain dimer and PDGFR-beta binds to the B chain dimer. Binding of PDGF to its receptor induces receptor dimerization and activation of the receptor tyrosine kinase activity. The activated receptor tyrosine kinase phosphorylates a number of cellular proteins including the PDGFR-alpha and PDGFR-beta themselves. The phosphorylated receptor and other substrates bind to SH2 containing signaling proteins, such as GRB2 and the 8 5kDa subunit of PI3 kinase. Other signaling proteins include the Shc proteins, which bind to the activated PDGFR-beta and activate the RAS / MAP kinase pathway. STAT-5 is also activated by the PDGFR-beta receptor and may contribute to the mitogenic response. Other signaling pathways activated by PDGFR-beta include the PI3 kinase pathway and the PLCgamma pathway. PDGFR-alpha is not activated by the PDGFR-beta dimer, but can form active signaling complexes with PDGFR-beta. The PDGFR-alpha / PDGFR-beta receptor complexes may play a role in the development of certain cell types.

The interaction of integrins with the extracellular matrix (ECM) is critical for the regulation of cell adhesion, spreading, migration and proliferation. Integrins are a family of cell surface receptors that mediate cell-ECM interactions. The interaction of integrins with the extracellular matrix is required for cell adhesion and is involved in the regulation of cell shape, migration, proliferation and differentiation. The binding of ECM ligands to integrins induces the formation of focal adhesions, which are specialized regions of the plasma membrane involved in the transduction of signals between the extracellular matrix and the cytoplasm. The formation of focal adhesions is regulated by the small GTPase RhoA, which is activated by integrin-mediated cell adhesion. The activation of RhoA leads to the formation of actin stress fibers and focal adhesions. The Crk-associated exchange factor (GEF) C3G is involved in the integrin-mediated activation of RhoA. The Crk-associated protein (CrkL) is involved in the activation of C3G by integrins. CrkL is also involved in the formation of focal adhesions. Paxillin is a focal adhesion protein that is involved in the regulation of cell migration and spreading. Paxillin is also involved in the regulation of cell spreading by regulating the activity of RhoA. The CrkL-mediated activation of RhoA is also involved in the regulation of cell spreading by paxillin. The interaction of integrins with the extracellular matrix is also involved in the regulation of cell proliferation. The interaction of integrins with the extracellular matrix induces the activation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway. The CrkL-mediated activation of RhoA also contributes to the integrin-mediated activation of the MAPK pathway.

The CD4 0 receptor is expressed on B cells and other cells and is activated by its ligand, CD40L. The interaction of CD40 and CD40L plays an important role in the regulation of the immune response. The interaction of CD40L with CD40 activates B cells and macrophages and is involved in the development of T helper cells. The interaction of CD40 with CD40L also plays a role in autoimmune diseases such as lupus. The interaction of CD40 with CD40L also plays a role in the interaction of B cells with T cells during the process of T cell activation. The interaction of CD40 with CD40L also plays a role in the interaction of cytotoxic T cells with target cells. The interaction of CD40 with CD40L also plays a role in the interaction of T cells with other T cells.

IL-7 is a cytokine that is produced by stromal cells in the bone marrow and stimulates the proliferation and differentiation of B and T cells. The receptor for IL-7 is a heterodimer of the IL-7Rα chain and the γc chain shared with IL-2, IL-4, IL-9 and IL-15. The IL-7Rα chain is also a component of the receptor for thymic stromal lymphopoietin (TSLP). Binding of IL-7 to the receptor activates JAK kinases and the downstream STAT transcription factors. The JAK / STAT pathway is also activated by TSLP. The IL-7 receptor is expressed early in B cell development and is required for normal B cell development. Mice lacking IL-7 or the IL-7Rα chain have very few B cells and die of infection by bacteria. IL-7 is also required for the survival of naïve T cells. The ability of IL-7 to stimulate the proliferation and differentiation of lymphocytes makes it an important therapeutic agent in the treatment of cancer and HIV infection.

Granzyme A is a protease that is released from cytotoxic T cells into the target cell's cytoplasm to induce apoptosis. The mechanism of action of granzyme A is not completely understood, but it appears to activate the caspase cascade. Granzyme A cleaves Bid, a Bcl-2 family member, to release cytochrome c and activate caspase-9. Caspase-9 activates caspase-8, which cleaves and activates caspase-3. Granzyme A also cleaves the transcription factor AP-1 to inhibit transcription of anti-apoptotic genes.

The immune system is composed of a variety of cell types, including macrophages, natural killer (NK) cells, neutrophils, and eosinophils. Macrophages and NK cells are part of the innate immune system, and are involved in the first line of defense against infection. Neutrophils and eosinophils are part of the adaptive immune system and are recruited to the site of infection to fight off pathogens. The recruitment of immune cells to the site of infection is regulated by a variety of chemokines and cytokines. The chemokines are a class of small secreted proteins that are involved in the recruitment of immune cells to the site of infection. The chemokines are further classified into different groups based on the presence of specific amino acid sequences, or chemokine receptors. The chemokine receptor is a G-protein coupled receptor that is activated by chemokines. The chemokine receptor is expressed on the surface of immune cells and is involved in the activation of the immune response. The chemokine receptor is activated by the chemokine, and the activation of the chemokine receptor leads to the migration of immune cells to the site of infection. The chemokine receptor CXCR1 is expressed on the surface of neutrophils and is activated by IL-8. The chemokine receptor CXCR2 is expressed on neutrophils, eosinophils, and monocytes and is activated by IL-8, Gro-α, Gro-β, and NAP-2. The chemokine receptor CCR2 is expressed on macrophages and is activated by MCP-1 and MCP-3. The chemokine receptor CCR5 is expressed on macrophages and is activated by RANTES, MIP-1α, and MIP-1β. The chemokine receptor CXCR4 is expressed on T cells and is activated by SDF-1. The activation of the chemokine receptor leads to the activation of the G-protein signaling pathway, which leads to the migration of immune cells to the site of infection. The chemokine receptor CCR7 is expressed on T cells and is activated by the chemokine SLC. The activation of the chemokine receptor leads to the activation of the integrin LFA-1, which leads to the firm adhesion of immune cells to each other and the endothelium. The activation of LFA-1 also leads to the activation of the integrin Mac-1, which leads to the binding of macrophages to the endothelium and the migration of immune cells to the site of infection.

The ATM gene is mutated in the cancer-prone disorder ataxia telangiectasia. The ATM protein kinase is a key regulator of the cellular response to DNA damage. It phosphorylates and activates the tumor suppressor protein p53, and also phosphorylates and activates the chk1 and chk2 protein kinases that regulate the cell cycle. The p53 tumor suppressor protein is involved in the regulation of cell cycle progression and apoptosis in response to DNA damage. The BRCA1 protein is involved in the regulation of DNA repair and cell cycle progression. The ABL tyrosine kinase is involved in the regulation of cell growth and apoptosis. The NFkB transcription factor is involved in the regulation of immune and inflammatory responses.

Peroxisome proliferators-activated receptors (PPARs) are a family of nuclear hormone receptors that include PPARα, PPARβ / delta, and PPARγ. PPARs are activated by fatty acids and fatty acid derivatives and are involved in lipid metabolism. They are also involved in glucose metabolism and inflammation. The activation of PPARs by their ligands inhibits the proliferation of tumor cells and induces apoptosis in some tumor cells. The activation of PPARγ by its ligands inhibits the growth of breast cancer cells. The inhibition of tumor cell growth by PPARγ ligands is associated with the induction of apoptosis and cell cycle arrest. The inhibition of tumor cell growth by PPARγ ligands is associated with the induction of the expression of the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor p2 1WAF1 / CIP1 and the inhibition of the expression of the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl-2. The inhibition of tumor cell growth by PPARγ ligands is also associated with the inhibition of angiogenesis. The inhibition of angiogenesis by PPARγ ligands is associated with the inhibition of the expression of the angiogenic factor VEGF. The inhibition of angiogenesis by PPARγ ligands is also associated with the inhibition of the expression of the matrix metalloproteinases MMP-2 and MMP-9. The inhibition of tumor cell growth by PPARγ ligands is also associated with the inhibition of the expression of the estrogen receptor. The inhibition of tumor cell growth by PPARγ ligands is associated with the inhibition of the expression of the estrogen receptor. The inhibition of tumor cell growth by PPARγ ligands is also associated with the inhibition of the expression of cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2). The inhibition of tumor cell growth by PPARγ ligands is also associated with the inhibition of the expression of the estrogen receptor.

The mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway is a highly conserved signaling module that transmits extracellular signals to intracellular responses. The pathway is activated by a variety of stimuli, including growth factors, cytokines, and cellular stress, and is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including proliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis. The MAPK pathway is a three-kinase module in which the MAPK kinase kinase (MAPKKK) phosphorylates and activates the MAPK kinase (MAPKK), which in turn phosphorylates and activates the MAPK. The three-kinase module is the core of the pathway and is composed of a MAPKKK, a MAPKK, and a MAPK. The MAPKKK phosphorylates and activates the MAPKK, which in turn phosphorylates and activates the MAPK. The three-kinase module is highly conserved from yeast to man and is used by all eukaryotic cells to convey signals from the cell surface to the nucleus. The MAPKKK in the pathway is Raf, a family of kinases that includes A-Raf, B-Raf, and c-Raf-1. The MAPKK is MEK, which phosphorylates and activates the MAPK, also known as Erk. The MAPKK is MKK, which phosphorylates and activates the MAPK Erk-1 and Erk-2. The Erk kinases are a family of kinases that includes p38, Erk2, and p68. The p38 kinases are activated by the p44 kinases, which are activated by the Rho family of GTPases. The Rho family of GTPases includes Rac, Rho, and Cdc-4. Rac and Rho activate the p38 kinases, while Cdc-4 activates the p68 kinases. The p38 and p68 kinases phosphorylate downstream targets, including Map kinase activated protein kinase 2 (MAPKAPK2), p38 kinase, and MSK-1. The MAPKAPK phosphorylates and activates the transcription factor CREB, which is involved in the stress response. The MSK-1 phosphorylates and activates the transcription factor MSK-1. The p38 kinases also phosphorylate and activate the myosin light chain phosphatase, which is involved in cytoskeletal changes. The p38 and p68 kinases also phosphorylate and activate the transcription factor Elk-1, which is involved in the cellular response to growth factors.

Presenilin 1 (PS1) is a multi-spanning membrane protein that is involved in the processing of amyloid precursor protein (APP). Mutations in PS1 are associated with early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease (FAD). PS1 is also involved in the processing of other proteins, including the Notch receptor. Presenilin 1 is part of a high molecular weight complex that cleaves transmembrane proteins within the transmembrane domain. The gamma-secretase cleavage of APP and Notch releases a cytoplasmic fragment that may enter the nucleus and participate in transcriptional regulation. Presenilin 1 is also involved in the Wnt signaling pathway, a pathway that is important in development and that may also be involved in the development of Alzheimer's disease.

TNF is a cytokine that induces apoptosis when bound to its receptor. The TNF receptor is a member of the TNF receptor gene family. The TNF receptor contains an intracellular death domain that is essential for signaling apoptosis. The adaptor protein FADD (Fas-associated via death domain) binds to the death domain of the receptor and recruits caspase-8 to the receptor. Caspase-8 is then activated and induces apoptosis through two pathways. One pathway involves the activation of caspase-3 and cleavage of cellular proteins. The second pathway involves the cleavage of Bid, a member of the Bcl-2 gene family, and the subsequent activation of the mitochondrial apoptotic pathway.

The Notch signaling pathway is an evolutionarily conserved, intercellular signaling mechanism essential for proper embryonic development in a variety of organisms. The Notch receptor is a single-pass transmembrane protein that is activated by interaction with a Delta or Jagged / Serrate family ligand expressed on an adjacent cell. This interaction leads to the proteolytic release of the Notch intracellular domain (NICD), which translocates to the nucleus and forms a transcriptional activation complex with the CSL family of DNA binding proteins and coactivators. The NICD-CSL complex activates the transcription of genes containing CSL-binding sites, including members of the Hes and Hey families of basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) transcription factors. Notch signaling is also negatively regulated by the Hes and Hey repressors, which are induced by Notch signaling and interact with the CSL proteins to block transcription. Presenilin is involved in the proteolytic processing of Notch and is required for Notch signaling. Mutations in Presenilin that lead to altered gamma-secretase activity and increased beta-amyloid production may contribute to Alzheimer's disease by altering Notch signaling.

TNF is a cytokine that induces apoptosis in a variety of cell types. The cytotoxic effects of TNF are mediated by two cell surface receptors, TNFR1 and TNFR2. TNFR1 is expressed in most cell types, while TNFR2 is expressed primarily in immune cells. The cytotoxic effects of TNF are mediated by TNFR1 through the activation of two distinct signaling pathways. One pathway involves the recruitment of the adapter protein TRADD to the cytoplasmic domain of TNFR1. TRADD in turn recruits the protein FADD and caspase-8 to form a death-inducing signaling complex. The formation of this complex results in the activation of caspase-8 and the subsequent cleavage of downstream caspases and the execution of apoptosis. The second pathway involves the activation of the transcription factor NF-kB through the TRAF2-NIK-MEKK1-IKK pathway. NF-kB activation can block apoptosis induced by TNF through induction of the anti-apoptotic genes such as IAP and Bcl2.

The T cell differentiation protein (TCF) family of transcription factors plays a key role in the regulation of T cell proliferation and differentiation. The TCF family includes four members, LEF1, TCF7, TCF7L1 and TCF7L2. The TCF proteins bind to the DNA as a heterodimer with members of the lymphoid enhancer factor (LEF) family of transcription factors. LEF1 is expressed in lymphoid tissues and TCF7 is expressed in the brain, liver and kidney. LEF1 and TCF7 are expressed in T cells and are involved in the regulation of T cell proliferation and differentiation. LEF1 is involved in the regulation of T cell proliferation and differentiation by interacting with the Wnt signaling pathway and the T cell receptor (TCR). LEF1 is involved in the Wnt signaling pathway by interacting with beta-catenin. Wnt signaling stabilizes beta-catenin, which enters the nucleus and interacts with LEF1 to activate transcription of Wnt-responsive genes. LEF1 is also involved in the regulation of T cell proliferation and differentiation by interacting with the TCR. T cell activation induces the expression of TCF7, which interacts with the TCR to repress T cell proliferation. T cell activation also induces the expression of LEF1, which interacts with the TCR to activate T cell proliferation. The interaction of LEF1 with the TCR and beta-catenin is regulated by the phosphorylation of LEF1 by protein kinase C (PKC). The interaction of LEF1 with the TCR and beta-catenin is also regulated by the phosphorylation of TCF7 by protein kinase A (PKA). The interaction of LEF1 and TCF7 with the TCR and beta-catenin is regulated by the phosphorylation of LEF1 and TCF7 by protein kinase A (PKA) and protein kinase C (PKC). The interaction of LEF1 and TCF7 with the TCR and Wnt signaling pathways plays a key role in the regulation of T cell proliferation and differentiation.

The interferon-inducible protein IFI1 6 is a member of the HIN-2 0 0 family of IFN-inducible genes. The HIN-2 0 0 family includes a group of genes with homology in their first two exons, encoding a highly conserved 2 0 0 amino acid domain. The HIN-2 0 0 family includes a group of proteins with either a 2 0 0 amino acid domain or a more complex structure. The HIN-2 0 0 family includes p2 0 4, MNDA, AIM2, IFIX, AIM2 4, AIM2 4-like, and HIN1 0. The HIN-2 0 0 proteins are involved in a variety of cellular processes, including apoptosis, cell cycle regulation, differentiation, and DNA repair. The HIN-2 0 0 proteins are involved in a variety of cellular processes, including apoptosis, cell cycle regulation, differentiation, and DNA repair. The AIM2 protein is an intracellular pattern recognition receptor that recognizes DNA from intracellular pathogens and activates the inflammasome. The AIM2 protein contains a PYRIN domain and a HIN domain and activates caspase-1 through the adaptor protein ASC. The AIM2 protein is also involved in the DNA damage response. The IFI1 6 protein is a nuclear protein that binds to proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) and represses transcription of E2F-regulated genes. IFI1 6 also interacts with the tumor suppressor protein p53 and induces p53-dependent apoptosis. The p53 tumor suppressor protein plays a role in DNA damage-induced apoptosis. The HIN-2 0 0 proteins are involved in a variety of cellular processes, including apoptosis, cell cycle regulation, differentiation, and DNA repair. The AIM2 protein is an intracellular pattern recognition receptor that recognizes DNA from intracellular pathogens and activates the inflammasome. The IFI1 6 protein is a nuclear protein that interacts with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) and represses transcription of E2F-regulated genes. The IFI1 6 also interacts with the tumor suppressor p53 and induces p53-dependent apoptosis.

Interleukin 18 (IL-18) is a member of the IL-1 cytokine family that induces interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma) secretion by activated T cells. IL-18 is produced by macrophages in response to microbial products and inflammatory stimuli. IL-18 binds to a receptor complex consisting of IL-18Ralpha and IL-18Rbeta that is distinct from the IL-1R1 receptor complex used by IL-1beta and IL-1RA. IL-18 signals through the JAK / STAT pathway to induce IFN-gamma and through the map kinase pathway to induce other cytokines. The map kinase pathway is activated by IL-18 through a TRAF6-dependent pathway that leads to activation of map kinase and the transcription factor ELK-1. The JAK / STAT pathway is activated by IL-18 through the recruitment of JAK kinases to the IL-18Ralpha receptor complex and the phosphorylation of STAT transcription factors.

The immune system is a complex network of cells and soluble factors that protect against invading pathogens and that also plays a role in the recognition and elimination of malignant cells. T cells are a key component of the adaptive immune system and are required for the immune response to foreign antigens. T cells are classified into two major groups, T helper cells and cytotoxic T cells, based on their function. T helper cells are required for the immune response to extracellular pathogens, such as bacteria and viruses, and produce the cytokines IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, IL-1 0 and IL-1 2. Cytotoxic T cells are required for the immune response to intracellular pathogens, such as parasites and viruses, and produce the cytokines IFN-gamma and TNF-alpha. Cytotoxic T cells are also involved in the recognition and elimination of malignant cells. T cell activation requires two signals. The first signal is provided by the binding of the T cell receptor (TCR) to antigen presented by MHC-I on the surface of an antigen-presenting cell. The second signal is provided by costimulatory molecules that bind to counter receptors on the T cell and activate the T cell. Cytotoxic T cell activation requires the interaction of CD2 8 with B7. 1 (CD8 0) and B7. 2 (CD8 6) on the antigen-presenting cell with the T cell receptor associated protein kinase, CD28-associated kinase. Cytotoxic T cell activation also requires the interaction of the T cell receptor with the costimulatory molecule ICOS with its ligand B7h. CD4 + T cells can be subdivided into two major subsets based on their function: Th1 cells that produce IL-2, IFN-gamma and TNF-alpha and Th2 cells that produce IL-4, IL-5, IL-6 and IL-13. Th1 cells are involved in the response to extracellular pathogens, while Th2 cells are involved in the response to intracellular pathogens. The differentiation of Th1 and Th2 cells is influenced by the cytokine environment in which the T cells are activated. The differentiation of Th1 and Th2 cells is influenced by the cytokine environment in which the T cells are activated. Th1 cells are induced by IL-12 and inhibited by IL-4. Th2 cells are induced by IL-4 and inhibited by IFN-gamma.

The proteasome is a large protein complex responsible for the degradation of intracellular proteins. It is responsible for the degradation of abnormal or damaged proteins, as well as the normal turnover of proteins involved in cell cycle control, signal transduction, antigen presentation, and apoptosis. The proteasome is a multi-subunit protein complex consisting of a proteolytic core particle (20S proteasome) and a regulatory particle that controls the activity of the core particle. The core particle is composed of four rings stacked on top of each other. The two outer rings each contain 17alpha subunits, and the two inner rings each contain 14beta subunits. The beta subunits contain the proteolytic active sites, while the alpha subunits form the outer rings that regulate the activity of the core particle. The core particle is activated by proteins that bind to the regulatory particle and that are usually tagged with ubiquitin. The regulatory particle is formed from two or three complexes called PA7 0 0, PA8 0 0, and PA5 0 0. The PA7 0 0 complex is responsible for the recognition, unfolding, and translocation of proteins to the core particle. The PA8 0 0 and PA5 0 0 complexes are required for the activation of the core particle. The PA7 0 0 and PA8 0 0 complexes are also required for the degradation of ubiquitin-tagged proteins.

The kappa opioid receptor (KOR) is activated by the endogenous peptide ligand dynorphin and a variety of synthetic ligands. The receptor is coupled to pertussis-sensitive Gi / o proteins to inhibit adenylyl cyclase and the release of intracellular calcium. The activation of the KOR also results in the activation of the MAP kinase pathway and the transcription factor AP-1. The activation of the MAP kinase pathway and the transcription factor AP-1 by the KOR is mediated by the small G protein ras and the downstream kinases map kinase and p38. The activation of the MAP kinase pathway and the transcription factor AP-1 by the KOR may play a role in the development of tolerance to the analgesic effects of dynorphin and the development of physical dependence to the synthetic KOR agonists.

Neuropeptide signaling is a major mechanism of intercellular communication in the brain. Neuropeptides are a diverse class of signaling molecules, including neuropeptides (e.g., enkephalins, substance P, and bradykinin) and neuropeptides (e.g., oxytocin, vasopressin, and acetylcholine). Neuropeptides are widely expressed in the nervous system and act as neurotransmitters, neuromodulators, and neurohormones. Neuropeptides are released from nerve terminals and act on receptors on the same or neighboring cells. Neuropeptide receptors are G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), which are found on both neurons and glial cells. Neuropeptide receptors are classified into four groups based on their coupling to G proteins. GPCRs coupled to Gs stimulate adenylyl cyclase and increase intracellular cAMP levels. GPCRs coupled to Gi and Go inhibit adenylyl cyclase and decrease cAMP levels. GPCRs coupled to Gq stimulate phospholipase C, which cleaves phosphatidylinositol bisphosphate into inositol trisphosphate and diacylglycerol. Inositol trisphosphate binds to receptors in the endoplasmic reticulum to release Ca2 + into the cytosol. Ca2 + is an important second messenger that regulates a variety of cellular processes. Neuropeptide receptors are coupled to Gq, which activates phospholipase C and increases intracellular Ca2 + levels. Neuropeptide receptors coupled to Gi inhibit adenylyl cyclase and decrease cAMP levels.

Interleukin-2 (IL-2) is a cytokine that stimulates the growth and activation of T cells. The IL-2 receptor is a heterodimer of alpha and beta chains. The IL-2 receptor beta chain is also used by the IL-4 receptor. The IL-2 receptor alpha chain is shared by the IL-7 receptor and the IL-9 receptor. The IL-2 receptor beta chain is also shared by the IL-15 receptor. The IL-2 receptor beta chain is associated with the gamma chain, also called the common gamma chain, which is shared by the IL-4 and IL-7 receptors. The IL-2 receptor beta chain is associated with the tyrosine kinases JAK1 and JAK3. The IL-2 receptor alpha chain is not associated with a kinase, but is required for high affinity binding of IL-2. The IL-2 receptor gamma chain is associated with the kinases JAK1 and JAK3. The activation of the IL-2 receptor leads to the activation of several signaling pathways, including the MAP kinase pathway, the STAT pathway, and the PI3 kinase pathway. The MAP kinase pathway is activated by the phosphorylation and activation of Shc, which binds Grb2 and the exchange factor Sos-1. The activation of the MAP kinase pathway leads to the phosphorylation and activation of the kinases raf, MEK, and MAP kinase. The STAT pathway is activated by the phosphorylation and activation of the kinases JAK1 and JAK3, which phosphorylate and activate the transcription factors STAT5 and STAT3. The PI3 kinase pathway is activated by the phosphorylation and activation of the kinase AKT. The activation of these signaling pathways leads to the activation of transcription of genes involved in the growth and activation of T cells.

The release of calcium from intracellular stores is a key component of cellular signaling. The ryanodine receptor (RyR) is a calcium release channel in the sarcoplasmic reticulum that releases calcium in response to various stimuli. The skeletal muscle isoform of the RyR (RyR1) is activated by the binding of calcium to calmodulin, whereas the cardiac muscle isoform (RyR2) is activated by the binding of calsequestrin. The skeletal muscle isoform of the channel is also activated by the calcium-sensing protein, Casq1. The skeletal muscle isoform of the channel is also regulated by the protein kinase C (PKC) pathway. The skeletal muscle isoform of the channel is also regulated by the protein kinase A (PKA) pathway. PKA activation of the skeletal muscle isoform of the channel increases the sensitivity of the channel to calcium, increasing the response of the channel to small changes in calcium. The skeletal muscle isoform of the channel is also regulated by the phosphoprotein phosphatase PP1. The skeletal muscle isoform of the channel is also regulated by phosphorylation by PKC. PKC activation of the skeletal muscle isoform of the channel increases the response of the channel to small changes in calcium. The skeletal muscle isoform of the channel is also regulated by the src kinase. The src kinase phosphorylates the channel on tyrosine residues, increasing the sensitivity of the channel to calcium. The skeletal muscle isoform of the channel is also regulated by the protein phosphatase PP1. PP1 dephosphorylates the channel, decreasing the sensitivity of the channel to calcium. The skeletal muscle isoform of the channel is also regulated by nitric oxide (NO). NO activates soluble guanylate cyclase in skeletal muscle, increasing the production of cyclic GMP. Cyclic GMP then activates cGMP-dependent protein kinase (PKG), which phosphorylates the skeletal muscle isoform of the channel. Phosphorylation of the channel by PKG increases the sensitivity of the channel to calcium.

The T cell receptor complex (TCR) is a multi-subunit complex that is expressed on the surface of T cells and is responsible for the recognition of foreign antigens presented by MHC molecules. The TCR complex is composed of two polypeptide chains, the alpha and beta chains of the TCR that are non-covalently associated with two copies each of the CD3 gamma, delta, epsilon, and zeta chains. The CD3 complex is associated with the TCR complex during its biosynthesis in the ER and is transported to the cell surface with the TCR. The TCR complex is maintained in a low affinity state in the absence of antigen and is only induced to bind antigen when a T cell encounters antigen bound to MHC on the surface of an antigen-presenting cell. Upon binding antigen, the TCR complex is phosphorylated on the tyrosine residues of the CD3 and TCR subunits by the Src family kinases Lck and Fyn. The activation of Lck and Fyn leads to the phosphorylation of additional substrates and the initiation of downstream signaling pathways. The activation of Lck and Fyn is believed to be induced by the binding of the TCR to MHC-antigen complexes and the subsequent phosphorylation of the CD3 and TCR subunits by Lck and Fyn.

Nerve Growth Factor (NGF) is a member of the neurotrophin family that promotes the survival and growth of specific neuronal populations. NGF exerts its effects through binding to TrkA, a member of the trk family of tyrosine kinase receptors. Binding of NGF to TrkA activates several signaling pathways including the Ras-Raf-Mek-Erk pathway and the PI-3 kinase pathway. These pathways in turn activate transcription factors such as AP-1 and ELK-1 that regulate gene expression.

The insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) is a transmembrane receptor tyrosine kinase that shares homology with the insulin receptor. It is widely expressed in many cell types and mediates the mitogenic and antiapoptotic effects of its ligand IGF-1. The IGF-1R is widely expressed in many cell types and mediates the mitogenic and antiapoptotic effects of its ligand IGF-1. The IGF-1R is involved in transformation and transformation by a variety of oncogenes. The IGF-1R is involved in transformation and transformation by a variety of oncogenes. The IGF-1R is involved in transformation by SV4 0, v-src, bcr-abl, and H-ras. The IGF-1R is also involved in transformation by adenovirus and human papillomavirus. The IGF-1R is involved in transformation by neu and erbB-2. The IGF-1R is involved in transformation by SV4 0, v-src, bcr-abl, and H-ras. The IGF-1R is also involved in transformation by adenovirus and human papillomavirus. The IGF-1R is overexpressed in many human tumors, including breast, prostate, and colon cancer. The overexpression of the IGF-1R may contribute to transformation by increasing the mitogenic response to IGF-1. The antiapoptotic effect of IGF-1 through the IGF-1R may also contribute to transformation.

The T cell receptor (TCR) complex is a multimeric receptor expressed on the surface of T cells that plays a key role in the immune response. The TCR is composed of two noncovalently associated subunits, the alpha and beta chains that bind to the antigen-binding site, and three additional subunits, gamma, delta, and epsilon, that are required for efficient expression and maturation of the receptor. The TCR complex is expressed on the cell surface in two forms, a mature form found on the surface of all T cells and a more immature form found on the surface of only a subset of T cells, the T-cell blasts. The mature form of the TCR is composed of alphabeta2epsilongamma delta epsilon 2zeta 2mu 1lambda2mu 1lambda2mu 1lambda2mu 1zeta 2. The immature form of the TCR is composed of alphabeta2epsilongamma delta 2zeta 2mu 1lambda2mu 1lambda2mu 1lambda2mu 1zeta 2mu 1. The mature TCR complex is responsible for the recognition of specific antigens in the form of peptides bound to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) proteins by T cells. The alphabeta2epsilon gamma delta 2zeta 2mu 1lambda2mu 1lambda2mu 1epsilon 2 structure of the TCR complex is required for efficient expression of the receptor on the cell surface. The three subunits that form the TCR complex are encoded by separate genes and are expressed as separate polypeptides that are assembled in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). The three subunits that form the CD3 complex are encoded by a single gene and are expressed as a single polypeptide. The CD3 complex is required for efficient expression of the TCR complex on the cell surface. The zeta chain is required for efficient expression of the TCR complex on the cell surface and is required for efficient signaling by the TCR complex. The CD3 complex is also required for efficient expression of the TCR complex. The gamma and delta chains are required for efficient expression of the TCR alpha and beta chains. The CD3 complex is also required for efficient signaling by the TCR complex. The CD3 complex is required for efficient expression of the TCR complex on the cell surface and for efficient signaling by the TCR complex. The CD24 subunit is required for efficient expression of the TCR complex on the cell surface and is required for efficient signaling by the TCR complex. The CD24 subunit is also required for efficient expression of the TCR complex. The CD24 subunit is also required for efficient signaling by the TCR complex.

The CD79 gene encodes a protein with three immunoglobulin-like domains, a transmembrane domain, and a cytoplasmic tail. The CD79 protein is expressed in a limited set of cells including B cells, T cells, and NK cells. The CD79 protein is associated with the BCR in B cells and the TCR in T cells. The CD79 protein is tyrosine phosphorylated upon BCR ligation and TCR ligation. The CD79 protein is required for normal T cell development and B cell development. The tyrosine phosphorylation of the CD79 protein is mediated by the Src family kinase Lck and the Syk family kinase Zap-7 0. The CD79 protein is required for the activation of the MAP kinase pathway by the BCR and TCR. The CD79 protein also associates with the Vav protein and may activate the Vav protein by recruiting a protein tyrosine phosphatase. The CD79 protein is required for normal T cell development and B cell development.

The ATM gene is mutated in the genetic disorder ataxia-telangiectasia (AT). AT patients are sensitive to ionizing radiation and are at increased risk for the development of cancer. The ATM protein is a protein kinase that phosphorylates itself and other proteins in response to DNA damage. ATM phosphorylates the tumor suppressor protein p60 RB, and the checkpoint kinase chk1 in response to DNA damage. ATM also phosphorylates the breast cancer susceptibility gene product, BRCA1, in response to DNA damage. The breast cancer susceptibility gene BRCA1 is involved in DNA repair and cell cycle checkpoint control. The role of ATM in cell cycle checkpoint control and DNA repair may be responsible for the increased cancer risk observed in AT patients.

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that results from the destruction of the thyroid gland by self-reactive T cells. The disease is characterized by the presence of thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase antibodies, thyroid autoantibodies, and lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid. The etiology of Hashimoto's thyroiditis is not known, but it is believed that genetic factors and environmental factors, such as dietary iodine, may play a role. Environmental factors may trigger autoimmune responses by inducing the expression of self-antigens on the surface of thyrocytes. The expression of self-antigens may be induced by interferon-gamma, a cytokine secreted by Th1 cells. The presence of self-reactive T cells in the thyroid may be due to defects in the mechanisms that normally prevent the activation of self-reactive T cells. Self-reactive T cells may be activated by self-antigens presented by antigen-presenting cells in the absence of regulatory signals provided by regulatory T cells.

DNA mismatch repair (MMR) corrects DNA mismatches generated during DNA replication. MMR also plays an important role in maintaining genomic stability by preventing mutations from being passed on to the next generation. Defects in MMR genes are associated with genome-wide instability and predisposition to certain types of cancer. The Escherichia coli MMR system is well characterized and consists of five proteins that are required for MMR. MutS recognizes the mismatch and then interacts with MutL to form a MutS-MutL-mismatch ternary complex. The MutH endonuclease is activated in the ternary complex and incises the unmethylated daughter strand on the nearest side to the mismatch. UvrD helicase and exonuclease I (ExoI) are recruited to the mismatch-containing region and remove the error-containing strand. DNA polymerase III and DNA ligase complete the repair. In contrast to E. coli MMR, eukaryotic MMR requires additional factors to carry out the repair. Human MMR is a more complex system involving at least seven different proteins. The human MutS homologs MSH2-MSH6 and MSH2-MSH3 are the central components of the MMR machinery. Human MutL homologs include MLH1-PMS2, MLH1-PMS1, and MLH3-PMS1. The exonuclease 1 (EXO1) is also involved in eukaryotic MMR. RPA and RFC are required for the assembly of the human MMR system.

Cell-cell adhesion is fundamental to the function of all cells in the body. Cell-cell adhesion is mediated by a variety of adhesive molecules that are classified into two major groups: the immunoglobulin superfamily and the integrin superfamily. The immunoglobulin superfamily includes classical cadherins, nectins, protocadherins, and pentraxins. Integrins consist of noncovalently associated alpha and beta subunits. Cell-cell adhesion is essential for the maintenance of tissue architecture and is involved in a wide variety of biological processes, including cell migration, differentiation, and activation.

The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a transmembrane glycoprotein with tyrosine kinase activity. It is involved in the regulation of cell proliferation and differentiation. The EGFR is over-expressed in many types of cancer and is associated with a poor prognosis. The EGFR is activated by binding of its natural ligand, epidermal growth factor (EGF), or transforming growth factor-alpha (TGF-alpha). Binding of EGF or TGF-alpha to the receptor induces receptor dimerization and autophosphorylation of tyrosine residues in the cytoplasmic domain of the receptor. These phosphotyrosine residues serve as binding sites for cytoplasmic signaling proteins containing src homology 2 (SH2) or phosphotyrosine binding (PTB) domains. The adaptor protein GRB2 binds to the receptor via an interaction between GRB2 and the adaptor protein SHC. GRB2 in turn interacts with the guanine nucleotide exchange factor Sos-1, activating the ras / MAPK pathway. The ras / MAPK pathway leads to activation of transcription factors such as c-Myc and ELK-1. Phospholipase C-gamma (PLC-gamma) also plays a role in the EGFR signaling pathway. PLC-gamma catalyzes the hydrolysis of phosphatidylinositol-4, 5-bisphosphate (PIP2) to produce the second messengers IP3 and DAG. IP3 binds to its receptor on the endoplasmic reticulum, releasing calcium ions into the cytoplasm. DAG activates protein kinase C (PKC), which can also activate the ras / MAPK pathway. JAK / STAT signaling also appears to play a role in EGFR signaling.

The CD40 receptor is a member of the TNF receptor gene family and is expressed on the surface of B cells and activated T cells. The ligand for CD40 is CD154, also known as CD15 0. The interaction of CD40 and CD154 is involved in a variety of immune responses, including B cell activation, T cell activation, and Ig class switching. The interaction of CD40 and CD154 also plays a role in the pathogenesis of autoimmune disorders such as lupus. The cytoplasmic domain of CD40 does not have intrinsic kinase activity but associates with TNF receptor associated factors (TRAFs). The TRAF proteins are a family of adaptor proteins that mediate signaling by members of the TNF receptor gene family. The TRAF proteins bind to the CD40 cytoplasmic domain through a conserved TRAF binding motif. The TRAF proteins also interact with other signaling molecules, including members of the TGF-beta receptor family, suggesting that the TRAF proteins may be involved in the signaling of multiple receptors. The TRAF proteins are involved in signaling by CD40 and other TNF receptor family members through several different pathways. The TRAF proteins are involved in the activation of NF-kB and MAP kinase pathways by CD40 and other TNF receptor family members. The TRAF proteins also interact with members of the I-TRAF family of proteins that inhibit TRAF-mediated signaling. The I-TRAF proteins may play a role in the regulation of immune responses.

Cryptosporidium parvum is a protozoan parasite that causes severe diarrheal disease in humans and other animals. The life cycle of C. parvum is complex and includes two stages, the extracellular oocyst and the intracellular trophozoite. The oocyst is resistant to environmental extremes and can survive for years in the environment. The infection of C. parvum begins with the ingestion of contaminated food or water by a susceptible host. The oocyst is passed through the stomach to the small intestine, where it is sporulated and released as infectious sporozoites. The sporozoites are actively invasive and invade the intestinal epithelial cells (IECs). Intracellular development of C. parvum takes approximately 2 4 h. The invaded IECs form a parasitophorous vacuole (PV), which is derived from the host cell membrane and contains the parasite's membranous organelles. The PV membrane is disrupted, and the parasite replicates within a membranous structure derived from the host cell membrane, the vacuole. The parasite then exits the PV and multiples by endodyogeny, forming thousands of merozoites that are released into the intestinal lumen. The excreted-secreted antigens (ESA) of C. parvum are important for the interaction of the parasite with the host cell. The ESA are released from the parasite and are present in the intestinal lumen. The ESA are involved in the modification of the intestinal environment and the immune response.

Myocarditis is an inflammatory heart disease that can result from a variety of etiologies, including viral infection, autoimmune disorders, and toxic drug reactions. Viral myocarditis is caused by coxsackievirus B3 (CVB3), a single-stranded RNA virus, which can infect both cardiac myocytes and immune cells. CVB3 infection can lead to viral replication in myocytes, resulting in viral myocarditis. CVB3 can also infect macrophages and other antigen-presenting cells, causing the release of inflammatory cytokines and the subsequent activation of cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs). CTLs can directly kill virus-infected myocytes, but may also cause damage to uninfected myocytes through the release of perforin and granzyme. Viral infection can also trigger the production of interferons (IFNs), which can induce apoptosis in both virus-infected and uninfected cells. Viral myocarditis can progress to dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), a condition characterized by ventricular dilatation and impaired contractile function, in some patients. Viral myocarditis may be a key factor in the development of DCM.

Parkinson's disease (PD) is a progressive neurodegenerative movement disorder characterized by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Mutations in alpha-synuclein, UCHL1, and parkin are associated with early-onset PD. Mutations in PINK1, DJ1, and LRRK2 are associated with autosomal-dominant PD. Mutations in alpha-synuclein, UCHL1, and parkin are associated with autosomal-recessive PD. Mutations in parkin, PINK1, and DJ1 are associated with autosomal-recessive PD. These proteins may be involved in different pathways to cause PD. Parkin is an E3 ubiquitin ligase that may be involved in the ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS). Mutations in parkin may lead to a decrease in UPS function, which may result in the accumulation of toxic proteins and neuronal cell death. Pink1 is a mitochondrial kinase that may be involved in mitochondrial function and turnover. DJ1 is an oxidative stress response protein that may be involved in mitochondrial function. Mutations in these proteins may lead to mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress, which may cause dopaminergic neuronal death.

The cardiac isoform of the sarcoplasmic / endoplasmic reticulum Ca2 + -ATPase (SERCA2a) is essential for cardiac muscle relaxation. SERCA2a transports Ca2 + from the cytosol into the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR), an intracellular Ca2 + store, and is regulated by Ca2 + -calmodulin (CaM) and phospholamban (PLN). Ca2 + -CaM activates SERCA2a by inducing a conformational change in SERCA2a, which exposes its active site for Ca2 +. The inhibition of SERCA2a by PLN is relieved when Ca2 + dissociates from CaM.

The m2 muscarinic receptor (m2AChR) is a GPCR that is coupled to Gi / o-proteins and is involved in the inhibition of the release of neurotransmitters. The m2AChR is also involved in the regulation of cell growth and proliferation. The mitogenic effect of the m2AChR is mediated by the βγ subunits of Gi / o-proteins and the subsequent activation of the ras / MAP kinase pathway. The release of arachidonic acid by phospholipase C is also involved in the mitogenic effect of the m2AChR. The activation of the MAP kinase pathway by the m2AChR is mediated by the small G-protein ras and the raf-1 kinase. The activation of the ras / MAP kinase pathway by the m2AChR is also mediated by the tyrosine kinase src. The activation of the ras / MAP kinase pathway by the m2AChR is inhibited by the binding of arrestins to the activated receptor. The binding of arrestins to the activated receptor also leads to the activation of the MAP kinase pathway by a mechanism that does not involve arrestins.

The production of prostaglandins by the inducible enzyme cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) is a key component of the inflammatory response. The production of prostaglandins is regulated by the rate-limiting enzyme phospholipase A2 (PLA2), which catalyses the release of arachidonic acid from the sn-2 position of membrane phospholipids. The release of arachidonic acid is stimulated by a variety of inflammatory mediators, including the proinflammatory peptide bradykinin, the bacterial endotoxin lipopolysaccharide (LPS), and the proinflammatory cytokine interleukin-1Beta (IL-1Beta). The activation of PLA2 is regulated by the convergence of several signalling pathways, including the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) cascade, the Ca2 + signalling pathway and the protein kinase C (PKC) pathway. The activation of PLA2 by IL-1Beta and LPS is mediated by the MAPK pathway, whereas the activation of PLA2 by bradykinin is mediated by the Ca2 + signalling pathway. The activation of PLA2 by IL-1Beta and LPS is mediated by the small G-protein Ras, which activates phospholipase C (PLC), resulting in the production of IP3 and diacylglycerol (DAG). IP3 causes the release of Ca2 + from intracellular stores, whereas DAG activates PKC. The activation of PLA2 by bradykinin is mediated by the tyrosine phosphorylation of cytosolic PLA2 (cPLA2) by the nonreceptor tyrosine kinase Pyk2. The activation of cPLA2 by Pyk2 is independent of PKC and Ras. The activation of Pyk2 by IL-1Beta and LPS is mediated by the adaptor protein Shc, which binds to the cytoplasmic domain of the IL-1Beta receptor. The activation of Pyk2 by bradykinin is mediated by the small G-protein Rac1, which activates the tyrosine kinase Src. The activation of cPLA2 by IL-1Beta and LPS is also mediated by the serine / threonine kinase map kinase. The activation of cPLA2 by IL-1Beta and LPS is also mediated by the transcription factor NF-kB. The activation of cPLA2 by bradykinin is independent of the MAPK cascade and PKC. The activation of cPLA2 by bradykinin is mediated by the tyrosine phosphorylation of cPLA2 by the nonreceptor tyrosine kinase Fyn. The activation of cPLA2 by IL-1Beta and LPS is also independent of the transcription factor NF-kB. The activation of cPLA2 by bradykinin is also independent of the transcription factor AP-1.

The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a cAMP-regulated chloride channel that also functions as a regulator of other ion channels. The most common mutation in CF is a deletion of three nucleotides that results in the loss of a phenylalanine residue at position 5 0 8 (F5 0 8del). CFTR is a member of the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter gene family and functions as a chloride channel and also as a regulator of other ion channels. The absence of functional CFTR leads to abnormalities in the regulation of other ion channels, including the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) and the outwardly rectifying chloride channel (ORCC). The absence of CFTR also affects the mucus layer in the lungs, which becomes thick and sticky, increasing the susceptibility of individuals with CF to bacterial infection.

Hashimoto's thyroiditis (HT) is the most common autoimmune thyroid disease, with a prevalence of about 2% in the general population. HT is characterized by the presence of circulating thyroid autoantibodies (TAbs) directed against thyroid peroxidase (TPO), thyroglobulin (Tg) and / or the thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR). The presence of TAbs is a marker of autoimmune thyroid disease and is found in about 1 0% of women and 3% of men. HT is usually preceded by autoimmune thyroiditis (AIT), which is a chronic autoimmune disease with a fluctuating course. AIT is characterized by the presence of thyroid autoantibodies and / or thyroid dysfunction. AIT can be classified into two groups: AIT with thyroid-specific autoantibodies (TPO, Tg, TSHR) and AIT without thyroid-specific autoantibodies. AIT with thyroid-specific autoantibodies can be further subdivided into AIT with thyroid-specific autoantibodies and normal thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR) antibodies (AITD-IgG) and AIT with thyroid-specific autoantibodies and thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibodies (AITD-TSHR). AIT without thyroid-specific autoantibodies can be further subdivided into AITD-IgG-positive and AITD-IgG-negative AIT. AIT-IgG-positive AIT is characterized by the presence of thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibodies (AITD-TSHR) and normal thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels. AIT-IgG-negative AIT is characterized by the presence of thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibodies (AITD-TSHR) and normal TSH levels. AIT-IgG-positive AIT is associated with the presence of thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibodies (AITD-TSHR) and thyroid dysfunction. AIT-IgG-negative AIT is associated with the presence of thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibodies (AITD-TSHR) and normal thyroid-stimulating hormone levels. AIT-IgG-positive AIT is associated with the presence of thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibodies (AITD-TSHR) and thyroid dysfunction. AIT-TSHR-positive AIT is associated with the presence of thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibodies (AITD-TSHR) and thyroid dysfunction. AIT-TSHR-negative AIT is associated with the presence of thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibodies (AITD-TSHR) and normal thyroid-stimulating hormone levels.

Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) and Natural Killer (NK) cells are the major cellular effectors of immune responses. CTLs and NK cells are activated by recognition of specific antigens on target cells, such as virus-infected cells, and secrete perforin and granzyme proteins to induce apoptosis in the target cells. Perforin is a protein that is secreted by CTLs and NK cells to form pores in the membranes of the target cells. The perforin pores allow the entry of granzyme proteins into the target cells, which are normally localized in the cytoplasm. Granzyme proteins enter the target cell and are then released into the cytoplasm to activate caspases and induce apoptosis. Perforin and granzyme proteins also induce apoptosis by a caspase-independent mechanism that involves the translocation of the acidic nuclear phosphoprotein 32 (ANP3 2) from the nucleus to the cytoplasm and the subsequent degradation of nuclear DNA. The translocation of ANP3 2 is induced by granzyme B, which cleaves ANP3 2 at aspartic acid residues. The caspase-independent apoptosis induced by perforin and granzyme proteins is important for the elimination of virus-infected cells by CTLs and NK cells.

TNF is a potent inflammatory cytokine that induces a variety of cellular responses including apoptosis, inflammation, and the activation of T cells. The TNF receptor superfamily contains 2 0 members, many of which are activated by TNF. The receptors for TNF are characterized by an intracellular domain called the TRAF domain. Binding of TNF to its receptor recruits the TRAF domain to the receptor complex, activating downstream signaling pathways. The TRAF domain is a protein-protein interaction domain that interacts with other signaling proteins, including members of the MAP kinase family. The TRAF-interacting protein NIK (NF-kappaB-inducing kinase) is a MAP kinase kinase kinase that activates the c-Jun amino-terminal kinase (JNK) pathway, a member of the MAP kinase family. The TRAF-interacting protein TANK (I-TRAF) binds to the TRAF domain of TRAF proteins, blocking the interaction of NIK with the TRAF domain and inhibiting the activation of the JNK pathway. The activation of the NF-kappaB pathway by TNF does not appear to involve NIK or the MAP kinase kinases, but may involve the RIP kinase. The activation of NF-kappaB by TNF also does not appear to involve the TRAF proteins, but does involve TRAF2. TRAF2 is a protein-protein interaction domain that interacts with several different proteins, including RIP, NIK, and TANK. TRAF2 also acts as a ubiquitin ligase, adding K6 3-linked ubiquitin chains to itself and to other proteins. The ubiquitination of proteins by the TRAF proteins may play a role in their signaling function.

The development of B cells and T cells is regulated by a complex interplay of positive and negative signals provided by the antigen receptor and other costimulatory molecules. The positive signals provided by the antigen receptor are required for the initial stages of B and T cell development, but are not sufficient to induce further differentiation. The development of B cells and T cells is also regulated by a complex interplay of positive and negative signals provided by a variety of costimulatory molecules.
