The T cell receptor (TCR) is a cell surface protein complex that is expressed on all T cells and that is composed of alpha and beta subunits noncovalently associated with the invariant CD3 gamma, delta, epsilon, and zeta chains. The TCR recognizes specific peptide antigens bound to MHC molecules on the surface of other cells. The interaction of the TCR with peptide-MHC on the surface of an antigen-presenting cell stimulates T cell activation. The CD3 complex is required for T cell activation and is associated with the protein tyrosine kinase activity of the TCR-associated protein tyrosine kinase, Lck. The interaction of the TCR with peptide-MHC stimulates the phosphorylation of the CD3 complex and other proteins by Lck. The activation of Lck and the phosphorylation of other proteins by the TCR-Lck interaction are required for T cell activation. The interaction of the TCR with peptide-MHC stimulates the phosphorylation of the CD3 complex and other proteins by Lck. The activation of Lck and the phosphorylation of other proteins by the TCR-Lck interaction are required for T cell activation. The interaction of the TCR with peptide-MHC stimulates the phosphorylation of the CD3 complex and other proteins by Lck. The interaction of the TCR with peptide-MHC stimulates the phosphorylation of the CD3 complex and other proteins by Lck. The activation of Lck and the phosphorylation of other proteins by the TCR-Lck interaction are required for T cell activation.

Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a heart muscle disease characterised by dilatation and impaired function of the left or both ventricles. The disease is characterised by progressive heart failure and sudden cardiac death. Familial DCM is caused by mutations in genes encoding for structural and functional proteins of the cardiomyocyte. The most common cause of familial DCM is mutations in the gene encoding for the cardiac isoform of beta-myosin heavy chain (beta-MHC). In mice, a point mutation in beta-MHC (Arg4 0 3Gln) has been shown to cause a phenotype similar to human DCM. In the heart of mice carrying the Arg4 0 3Gln mutation, the left ventricular (LV) wall is thin and the LV chamber is dilated. The mutation leads to a reduction in the ATPase activity of myosin and a decrease in the velocity of actin filament sliding. The decrease in the velocity of actin filament sliding is accompanied by a shift in the position of the thin-filament-regulatory-troponin complex. This shift is caused by a reduction in the Ca2 + sensitivity of the thin-filament-regulatory-troponin complex. The shift in the position of the thin-filament-regulatory-troponin complex is also caused by a reduction in the Ca2 + affinity of the regulatory troponin complex. The shift in the position of the thin-filament-regulatory-troponin complex is accompanied by a reduction in the Ca2 + sensitivity of the force development. The reduction in the Ca2 + sensitivity of the force development is also observed in human heart failure. The reduction in the Ca2 + sensitivity of the force development is expected to depress the response of the heart to increases in intracellular Ca2 + concentration. This may lead to a reduced force development and a reduced response of the heart to increases in intracellular Ca2 + concentration.

Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is an autoimmune disease in which the insulin-producing beta cells of the pancreas are selectively destroyed by the immune system. Environmental factors, such as viral infections, may trigger the autoimmune response, but genetic factors are also important. The first genetic evidence for the importance of genetic factors in type I diabetes was the discovery that the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) region on chromosome 6p2 1 is associated with type I diabetes. The HLA-DQ and HLA-DR genes are involved in the presentation of self-antigens to the immune system. The presence of certain HLA-DQ and HLA-DR alleles increases the risk of developing type I diabetes, while the absence of these alleles protects against the disease. Environmental factors, such as viral infections, may trigger the autoimmune response, but genetic factors are also important. The identification of the genes involved in type I diabetes will help to understand the pathogenesis of the disease and may lead to the development of new therapies.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that serves to form a selective barrier between the organism and the environment. The intestinal epithelium is a rapidly renewing tissue and its maintenance is dependent upon the proliferation and differentiation of epithelial cells. The intestinal epithelium is organized into two distinct cell types, the absorptive villus cells and the secretory crypt cells. The villus cells are responsible for the absorption of nutrients and water, while the crypt cells are involved in the secretion of water and electrolytes. The differentiation of epithelial cells is accompanied by changes in the expression of cytoskeletal proteins. In undifferentiated cells, actin filaments are abundant and form a cortical structure beneath the plasma membrane. As cells differentiate, they lose their actin cytoskeleton and become more specialized. In the villus cells, actin filaments are replaced by intermediate filaments, which are composed of keratins. In addition to the cytoskeletal proteins, intestinal epithelial cells express a variety of cell adhesion molecules, such as cadherins, integrins, and occludins. The expression of these molecules is also regulated during cell differentiation.

The cell cycle is a highly regulated process that ensures the accurate duplication and segregation of genetic material. The cell cycle is divided into four phases: G1, S, G2 and M, with the intervening gaps designated as gaps 1 and 2 (G1 and G2). The G1 phase is the gap between the duplication of DNA and the initiation of DNA replication. The S phase is the period of DNA replication and the G2 phase is the gap between the S phase and the initiation of mitosis. The cell cycle is regulated by a variety of factors, including the presence of growth factors and the availability of nutrients. The presence of growth factors activates signaling pathways that stimulate cell cycle progression. The presence of nutrients such as glucose and amino acids is required for cell cycle progression. The presence of growth factors and nutrients stimulate the production of ATP, which is required for cell growth. The production of ATP also stimulates the production of GTP, which is required for the activation of Ras and Rho. Ras and Rho activate the Raf / MEK / Erk and PI3K / Akt pathways, respectively, which stimulate cell cycle progression. The presence of growth factors and nutrients also stimulates the uptake of amino acids, which are used to produce new proteins. The completion of cell cycle progression is required for the production of a daughter cell with a complete set of chromosomes. The presence of DNA damage or the absence of nutrients activates checkpoints that prevent cell cycle progression. The DNA damage checkpoint is activated by the presence of DNA damage and halts the cell cycle to allow time for DNA repair. The absence of nutrients activates the metabolic checkpoint, which halts the cell cycle to prevent the production of cells with damaged DNA. The metabolic checkpoint is activated by the absence of glucose and other nutrients. The metabolic checkpoint is activated by the absence of glucose and other nutrients and halts the cell cycle to prevent the production of cells with damaged DNA.

The selectin family of adhesion molecules includes E-selectin (also known as ELAM-1, CD6 2E, sELAM-1, and LECAM-1), P-selectin (also known as CD6 2P, GMP-1 4 0, and PADGEM), and L-selectin (also known as LAM-1 and LECAM-2). These molecules are involved in the initial steps of the inflammatory response, including leukocyte rolling, adhesion, and migration. Selectins are type I transmembrane glycoproteins with an extracellular domain that contains an amino terminal lectin domain, a fibronectin type II domain, and a complement-like domain. The lectin domain binds to carbohydrate ligands on the surface of other cells. P-selectin is expressed on the surface of activated platelets and endothelial cells. It is involved in the initial stages of inflammation and thrombosis. L-selectin is expressed on the surface of leukocytes and binds to ligands on the surface of activated endothelial cells. E-selectin is expressed on the surface of inflamed endothelial cells and leukocytes and is involved in the later stages of inflammation. The selectin family members are similar in structure and function, but have distinct expression patterns and different ligands.

Cell motility is a fundamental feature of many biological processes, including embryonic development, immune responses, and wound healing. Cell motility is also involved in the spread of cancer cells and in the spread of bacteria and parasites. Cell motility is driven by the formation of actin-based structures, such as filopodia and lamellipodia, which are formed by the polymerization of actin filaments. The formation of actin-based structures is regulated by the Rho family of small GTPases, including Rac, Rho, and Cdc42. Rac and Cdc42 induce the formation of lamellipodia, while Rho induces the formation of stress fibers and focal adhesions. Cdc42 is activated by the Dbl family of oncogenes, which includes Dbl, Vav, and Vav-2. Cdc42 activates Cdc42 by causing Cdc42 to release GDP, allowing it to reassociate with GTP. Cdc42 activates Cdc42 by causing Cdc42 to release its bound GDP. Cdc42 activates the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP) family of proteins, including N-WASP and WASP-family verprolin-homologous protein (WAVE). Cdc42 activates N-WASP by causing N-WASP to change its conformation, exposing a binding site for the Arp2 / 3 complex. The Arp2 / 3 complex is a seven-protein complex that nucleates the formation of actin filaments and that is involved in the formation of actin-based structures. The Arp2 / 3 complex is a heterodimer of Arp2 and Arp3. Arp2 and Arp3 form a Y-shaped structure with a central region and three verprolin-like repeats at each end. The Arp2 / 3 complex is a constitutive dimer in solution, but upon binding to N-WASP or WAVE, Arp2 / 3 is activated and it binds to the side of an actin filament. The formation of an actin network by the Arp2 / 3 complex creates a branched actin filament network that pushes out the membrane of a cell and creates lamellipodia. Cdc42 and the WASP family of proteins are involved in other actin-based structures, such as filopodia. The formation of filopodia is induced by the formation of bundles of actin filaments by Cdc42 and the formation of filopodia is dependent on the formation of actin bundles by Cdc42.

Interleukin 3 (IL-3) is a cytokine that stimulates the growth and differentiation of cells of the myeloid lineage. The IL-3 receptor is a heterodimer, consisting of an alpha subunit (IL-3Ra) and a beta subunit (IL-3Rb). The beta subunit is shared with IL-5 and GM-CSF. Binding of IL-3 to its receptor causes receptor dimerization, activation of JAK kinases, and phosphorylation of the beta subunit. The phosphorylated beta subunit recruits and activates the tyrosine kinase src. The activated src phosphorylates Shc, which in turn activates the ras-MAP kinase pathway. The ras-MAP kinase pathway leads to activation of transcription factors such as AP-1 and Egr-1. The JAK-STAT pathway leads to activation of other transcription factors such as STAT5. The ras-MAP kinase pathway and STAT pathways appear to be independent of one another.

p53 is a transcription factor that regulates cell cycle progression and apoptosis in response to DNA damage. The p53 gene is mutated in a variety of human tumors, suggesting that p53 plays a role in tumor suppression. The p53 protein is stabilized and activated in response to DNA damage by the ATM kinase. Activated p53 induces transcription of genes involved in cell cycle arrest and apoptosis, including the CDK inhibitor p2 1CIP1, the DNA repair enzyme DNA-PK, and the proapoptotic protein Bax. In addition, p53 induces transcription of the gene encoding the p53 inducible protein (PIG), a protein with a putative oxidoreductase activity. PIG interacts with the tumor suppressor ARF, and induces p53-dependent apoptosis in the absence of DNA damage.

ADP-ribosylation factors (ARFs) are 2 0-kDa guanine nucleotide-binding proteins that are required for the ADP-ribosyltransferase activity of the cholera toxin A subunit and the ADP-ribosyltransferase activity of the Bordetella pertussis toxin. ARFs are also involved in intracellular vesicle transport. There are at least three different forms of ARF in mammalian cells, ARFA, B and C, which are encoded by separate genes. The three forms share about 9 0% amino acid sequence identity, but differ in their amino-terminal sequences. The amino-terminal 2 1aa of ARFA is replaced by a different sequence in the other two forms. The activation of ARFs by GTP is an essential step in the action of these proteins. The activation of ARFs by GTP is followed by their inactivation through the hydrolysis of bound GTP to GDP. ARF1GAP is an ARF GTPase-activating protein that catalyzes the very rapid and specific hydrolysis of bound GTP to GDP. The activity of ARF1GAP is stimulated by the Golgi-associated coatomer protein complex I (COPI). The coatomer is a protein complex that is involved in vesicle formation at the Golgi complex. The stimulation of ARF1GAP by COPI suggests that the GAP activity of ARF1GAP is involved in the disassembly of COPI.

Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) are nuclear hormone receptors that are activated by fatty acids and eicosanoids. There are three subtypes of PPAR, PPAR alpha, PPAR beta, and PPAR gamma. PPAR alpha is expressed in tissues with high-energy demand such as liver, skeletal muscle, and heart. PPAR beta / delta is ubiquitously expressed, while PPAR gamma is expressed in adipose tissue. PPAR gamma is also expressed in macrophages and is involved in adipocyte differentiation. PPAR forms a heterodimer with the retinoid X receptor (RXR) and binds to peroxisome proliferator response elements (PPREs) in the promoter region of target genes. The activity of PPAR is regulated by various factors including phosphorylation, ligand binding, and interaction with other proteins. The activity of PPAR is also regulated by the cellular concentration of its ligand, which is regulated by the activity of fatty acid oxidation and triglyceride synthesis pathways. The activity of PPAR is also regulated by the cellular concentration of its binding protein, the PPAR-gamma coactivator-1 (PGC-1). PGC-1 is a coactivator for many transcription factors involved in energy metabolism. The activity of PGC-1 is also regulated by phosphorylation and acetylation. The activity of PGC-1 is also regulated by the cellular concentration of its own ligand, which is regulated by the activity of fatty acid oxidation and triglyceride synthesis pathways. The activity of PGC-1 is also regulated by the cellular concentration of its own ligand. The activity of PPAR is also regulated by the cellular concentration of its binding protein, the PPAR-gamma coactivator-2 (PGC-2). The activity of PGC-2 is also regulated by phosphorylation and acetylation. The activity of PGC-2 is also regulated by the cellular concentration of its own ligand.

The complement system is an important part of the innate immune system that provides a rapid response to invading pathogens. The complement system is comprised of more than thirty proteins that are activated in a cascade-like fashion to induce a response against foreign cells and pathogens. The first three components of the complement system, C3, C4, and C2, are activated by the classical pathway, an antibody-dependent response, while the lectin pathway is activated by the presence of carbohydrates on the surface of pathogens. The complement system is activated by three different pathways, each of which leads to the formation of a C3 convertase that cleaves the C3 complement protein. The C3 convertase cleaves additional C3 molecules to form the C5 convertase, which cleaves C5 to form the anaphylatoxin C5a and the membrane attack complex (MAC). The anaphylatoxin C5a is a potent inflammatory agent that recruits immune cells to the site of infection and stimulates the respiratory burst in neutrophils. The MAC causes lysis of foreign cells and the release of inflammatory cytokines. The complement system is activated by three different pathways. The classical pathway is activated by the binding of antibodies to foreign cells or antigens. The lectin pathway is activated by the presence of carbohydrates on the surface of pathogens. The alternative pathway is initiated by spontaneous hydrolysis of C3. The three pathways converge at the step that cleaves the C3 convertase. The C3 convertase cleaves additional C3 molecules to form the C5 convertase. The C5 convertase cleaves C5 to form the anaphylatoxin C5a and the MAC. The formation of the MAC on the surface of pathogens causes lysis of the cell and release of inflammatory cytokines. The formation of the MAC also lyses red blood cells causing a condition called hemolytic anemia. The complement system is activated by three different pathways each of which leads to the formation of a C3 convertase. The three pathways converge at the step that cleaves the C3 convertase. The classical pathway is activated by the binding of antibodies to foreign cells or antigens. The lectin pathway is activated by the presence of carbohydrates on the surface of pathogens. The alternative pathway is initiated by the spontaneous hydrolysis of C3.

The Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is an X-linked immunodeficiency disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections. The gene defective in WAS encodes a 5 0kD protein (WASP) that is expressed in hematopoietic cells. WASP is a member of a family of proteins that includes the gene product of the gene defective in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome-like disorder, X-linked thrombocytopenia (XLT). WASP is a member of a growing family of proteins that are involved in the regulation of the cytoskeleton. WASP interacts with the Arp2 / 3 complex, a complex of proteins that induces actin polymerization. The interaction of WASP with the Arp2 / 3 complex is regulated by the Rho family of GTPases. The interaction of WASP with the Arp2 / 3 complex induces actin polymerization and the formation of filopodia and lamellopodia. The interaction of WASP with the Rho family of GTPases is also involved in the regulation of the actin cytoskeleton. The interaction of WASP with the Arp2 / 3 complex is regulated by the binding of the GTPase CDC4 2 to the CRIB domain of WASP. The interaction of CDC4 2Hs with WASP induces actin polymerization and the formation of filopodia. The interaction of WASP with CDC4 2Hs and the Arp2 / 3 complex induces the formation of lamellipodia. The interaction of WASP with Rac-1 and the Arp2 / 3 complex induces the formation of filopodia. The interaction of WASP with the Rho GTPases and the Arp2 / 3 complex regulates the formation of the actin cytoskeleton and the formation of filopodia and lamellopodia.

Cytokines are small secreted proteins that are produced by many different cell types and that are involved in the regulation of the immune response, inflammation, hematopoiesis, metabolism, and other processes. They are produced by many different cell types and act in a paracrine or autocrine manner. They are also involved in intercellular communication and can act on cells that are not themselves a source of the cytokine. Cytokines are classified according to their receptor structure and the class of signaling molecules they activate. The four main groups are the IL-1R family, the IL-10 family, the TNF family, and the hematopoietic cytokine receptor family. The IL-10 family cytokines include IL-10, IL-19, and IL-22. The IL-10 family cytokines act through a receptor complex that includes the IL-10RA chain. The IL-10 and IL-19 receptors also include the IL-10RB chain. The IL-10 receptor complex is distinct from the other cytokine receptor complexes in that it does not bind IL-10 itself but requires the IL-111RA chain. The IL-10 receptor complex is also distinct from the IL-1RA / IL-10RB complex in that it does not recruit JAK kinases. The IL-10 receptor complex is also distinct from the IL-1RA / IL-10RB complex in that it does not recruit the STAT proteins. The IL-10 receptor complex is also distinct from the IL-1RA / IL-10RA complex in that it does not recruit PI3 kinase. The TNF family includes TNF-alpha, TNF-beta, and lymphotoxin (LT) alpha and beta. The TNF family cytokines act through a receptor complex that includes the TNF-R1, TNF-R2, or the LT-betaR. The hematopoietic cytokine receptor family includes erythropoietin (EPO), thrombopoietin (TPO), IL-3, IL-5, IL-12, IL-4, and IL-15. The EPO receptor is a member of the cytokine receptor family and is a homodimer. The TPO receptor is also a member of this family and forms a heterodimer with the TPO receptor. The other cytokines in this family act through a receptor complex that includes the common beta chain. The beta chain is shared by all of these cytokines. The JAK / STAT pathway is the major signaling pathway used by cytokines. The activation of STATs by cytokines is a rapid and transient process. The activation of the JAK / STAT pathway by cytokines is rapid and transient. The activation of the JAK / STAT pathway by cytokines is a rapid and transient process. The activation of the JAK / STAT pathway by cytokines is a rapid and transient process. The activation of the JAK / STAT pathway by cytokines is a rapid and transient process. The activation of the JAK / STAT pathway by cytokines is a rapid and transient process. The activation of the JAK / STAT pathway by cytokines is a rapid and transient process.

Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) is a major complication of allogeneic bone marrow transplantation (BMT). It is caused by the reaction of donor T cells against recipient tissues. The clinical manifestations of GVHD include skin, liver, and gastrointestinal tract. The pathogenesis of GVHD is complex and involves multiple factors. The initial step is recognition of host MHC molecules by donor T cells. The interaction of the T cell receptor with the MHC / peptide complex leads to T cell activation and proliferation. Activated donor T cells produce a variety of cytokines, including IL-2, IFNgamma, TNFalpha, and IL-10. These cytokines can induce apoptosis in host cells, including epithelial cells, and damage the intestinal mucosa. In addition, the Fas / FasL interaction may play a role in the apoptosis of host cells. The Fas / FasL interaction may also lead to the activation-induced cell death of donor T cells. The activation of cytotoxic T cells may be induced by the interaction of donor T cells with host MHC molecules and the subsequent release of perforin and granzyme B. The cytotoxic T cells may also induce apoptosis in target cells through the Fas / FasL interaction.

The calcium-dependent protease calpain is involved in the degradation of many proteins in the cell. Calpain is activated by calcium and is inhibited by calpastatin. Calpain cleaves proteins at a specific site, usually a few amino acids from a region of a protein that is rich in basic residues. Calpain is involved in a variety of cellular processes including apoptosis, cell migration, cell differentiation, and cell cycle progression. Calpain is activated by the calcium ion signal that is released during excitation of muscle cells. Calpain is also activated by oxidative stress and by the release of calcium from the mitochondria during apoptosis. Calpain activation is involved in the degradation of the dystrophin protein in muscle cells, causing the muscle cells to lose their ability to contract. The activation of calpain by oxidative stress may be involved in the aging process in many tissues. Calpain is involved in the degradation of the tau protein in Alzheimer's disease. Calpain is also involved in the cleavage of amyloid precursor protein to produce amyloid beta-peptide, which is involved in the formation of plaques in Alzheimer's disease. Calpain is involved in the cleavage of the huntingtin protein in Huntington's disease. Huntington's disease is a genetic disorder that affects the brain and causes the patients to become mentally ill. Calpain inhibitors may be useful in the treatment of these and other diseases involving the degradation of proteins.

The ATM gene is mutated in the cancer prone syndrome ataxia telangiectasia. The ATM protein is a member of a family of kinases that are involved in the cellular response to DNA damage. The ATM protein is activated by ionizing radiation and phosphorylates several proteins involved in cell cycle control and DNA repair. The ATM protein phosphorylates the tumor suppressor gene product p53, and the chk1 and chk2 protein kinases. The chk1 and chk2 kinases phosphorylate the p27 protein, which in turn phosphorylates the CDC2 protein phosphatase, causing the cell to arrest in G2. The phosphorylation of p53, chk1 and chk2 by ATM also activates the intra-S phase checkpoint. The ATM protein also phosphorylates the BRCA1 tumor suppressor gene product, which also plays a role in the cellular response to DNA damage. The ATM protein also phosphorylates the NFkB inhibitor, IkB, activating NFkB and increasing the expression of genes involved in the cellular response to DNA damage. The ATM protein also phosphorylates the c-Abl tyrosine kinase, activating it and increasing the cellular response to DNA damage.

The complement system is a major part of the humoral defense against infection. It consists of more than 3 0 proteins, including the opsonins C3b and C3b. the anaphylatoxins C3a and C5a, the membrane attack complex (MAC), and several regulatory proteins. The complement system is activated by three different pathways: the classical pathway, the alternative pathway, and the lectin pathway. The classical pathway is activated by the recognition of antigen-antibody complexes by antibodies. The lectin pathway is activated by the recognition of carbohydrate structures on bacteria by mannan-binding lectin (MBL) or by the recognition of carbohydrate structures on viruses by the pentraxins C-reactive protein (CRP) and pentraxin 1q (pentraxin-1). The alternative pathway is initiated by the spontaneous hydrolysis of C3 to C3 (H2O). C3 (H2O) binds to factor B, which is subsequently activated by factor D, resulting in the formation of the C3 convertase C3bBb. The amplification of the C3 convertase occurs through the cleavage of factor B by the convertases C3bBb and C3bBbt. The cleavage of C3 by the convertases leads to the formation of the C5 convertases C3bBbC3 and C3bBbC3bBbt. The formation of the MAC by C5b leads to the formation of a pore in the cell membrane, which allows the influx of water and ions. Opsonization of bacteria by C3b and the recognition of foreign cells by pentraxins and MBL leads to the formation of the membrane attack complex, which lyses the bacteria or the cells they are attacking.

Presenilin-1 (PS1) is the catalytic component of gamma-secretase, an enzyme that cleaves the amyloid precursor protein (APP) within the transmembrane domain to generate the amyloid-beta peptide (Abeta) that accumulates in the brains of patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD). Presenilin-1 is also involved in the cleavage of other type I transmembrane proteins, including the Notch receptor. Cleavage of Notch by gamma-secretase is required for Notch signaling, which regulates cell fate decisions during development. Presenilin-1 is also involved in the notch signaling pathway, but this role is independent of gamma-secretase activity. Presenilin-1 is also involved in the regulation of the cell cycle, apoptosis, and calcium release. Presenilin-1 is a multi-spanning membrane protein that is thought to be involved in the transport of proteins through membranes. The cleavage of APP and Notch by gamma-secretase requires prior cleavage of the substrate by a different protease, termed the alpha-secretase for APP and the beta-secretase for Notch. The cleavage of APP by gamma-secretase releases the amyloid-beta peptide (Abeta), which aggregates to form senile plaques in the brains of patients with AD. The cleavage of Notch by gamma-secretase releases an intracellular domain that moves into the nucleus and activates transcription. The role of amyloid-beta in the pathogenesis of AD is still a matter of debate, but there is evidence that the amyloid-beta peptide may be toxic to neurons and may also interfere with synaptic function.

The protease activated receptors (PAR) are a family of four G-protein coupled receptors activated by proteolytic cleavage of the N-terminus of the receptor by the serine protease thrombin. The PAR receptors are activated by tethered ligand peptides that are released upon receptor cleavage. The PAR-1 receptor is activated by the protease thrombin and also by the peptide SFLLRN. PAR-2 is activated by trypsin and by the peptide SLIGKV. PAR-3 is activated by trypsin and by the peptide TFRGAP. PAR-4 is activated by trypsin and by the peptide GMSIPQ. The tethered ligand peptides are cleaved and inactivated by the same proteases that activate the PAR receptors. The PAR receptors are widely expressed in the body and are involved in a variety of physiological and pathological processes. The PAR-1 receptor is involved in platelet activation and hemostasis and is also involved in inflammatory responses. PAR-2 is involved in inflammatory responses and is involved in pain signaling. PAR-3 is involved in platelet activation and hemostasis. PAR-4 is involved in platelet activation and is also involved in neuronal signaling. The PAR receptors are involved in a variety of pathological processes including inflammation, asthma, and neuronal signaling. The PAR receptors are activated by proteases that are secreted during tissue damage and inflammation. The PAR receptors are also activated by proteases secreted by platelets during blood clotting. The PAR receptors are involved in a variety of pathological processes including inflammation, asthma, and neuronal signaling. The PAR receptors are activated by proteases that are secreted during tissue damage and inflammation. The PAR receptors are also activated by proteases that are secreted by platelets during blood clotting. The PAR receptors are involved in a variety of pathological processes including inflammation, asthma, and neuronal signaling. The PAR receptors are involved in a variety of pathological processes including platelet activation and inflammation. The PAR receptors are also activated by proteases that are secreted during blood clotting. The PAR receptors are involved in a variety of pathological processes including platelet activation and inflammation. The PAR receptors are involved in a variety of pathological processes. The PAR receptors are activated by proteases that are secreted during tissue damage and inflammation. The PAR receptors are also activated by proteases that are secreted by platelets during blood clotting. The PAR receptors are involved in a variety of pathological processes including platelet activation and inflammation. The PAR receptors are also involved in neuronal signaling.

The release of Ca2 + from intracellular stores is a key event in the control of cellular function. The release of Ca2 + is triggered by the second messenger IP3, which is produced by the activation of phospholipase C (PL-C). The IP3 receptor (IP3R) is a ligand-gated channel that is located on the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane. The binding of IP3 to the IP3R leads to the release of Ca2 + from the ER into the cytoplasm. The depletion of ER Ca2 + stores activates the so-called Ca2 + release-activated Ca2 + (CRAC) channels, which are highly selective for Ca2 +. The CRAC channels are activated by depletion of ER Ca2 + stores and are responsible for the influx of extracellular Ca2 +. The influx of Ca2 + through CRAC channels is required for the refilling of the ER with Ca2 + and for the activation of various cellular responses. The activation of GPCRs leads to the production of the second messenger cAMP by the enzyme adenylyl cyclase (AC). The activity of AC is regulated by the alpha-subunit of the G protein. Gs activates the AC isoform V, VI, and VIII, whereas Gi inhibits AC isoform III. The activation of AC leads to the production of the second messenger cAMP. The cAMP-dependent protein kinase A (PKA) is a heterotetramer consisting of two regulatory subunits and two catalytic subunits. The regulatory subunits inhibit the activity of the catalytic subunits when they are bound to cAMP. The cAMP-dependent protein kinase A is involved in the regulation of a variety of cellular processes, including the secretion of hormones and neurotransmitters.

Base excision repair (BER) is the predominant mechanism for the repair of small base lesions in DNA, including the most common DNA lesion, 7, 8-dihydro-8-oxoguanine (8oxoG). BER is also responsible for the repair of 104 lesions per day caused by reactive oxygen species. BER can be separated into two subpathways based on the position of the lesion in the DNA. Lesions in the transcribed strand of genes are repaired by the so-called transcription-coupled repair (TCR) pathway. BER can also be separated into incision repair and gap-filling repair. For the repair of simple base lesions, DNA glycosylases initiate the first step of BER by hydrolyzing the N-glycosyl bond between the abnormal base and the deoxyribose. DNA glycosylases can be separated into two groups based on their substrate specificity. Monofunctional glycosylases hydrolyze the N-glycosyl bond without the cleavage of the phosphodiester backbone. Glycosylases with an associated AP lyase activity hydrolyze the N-glycosyl bond and cleave the DNA strand 5 'to the lesion. Glycosylases with an associated dRP lyase activity cleave the DNA strand 3' to the lesion and remove the deoxyribose phosphate (dRP) group that is generated during the hydrolysis of the N-glycosyl bond. BER is completed by the insertion of a new base, DNA synthesis, and ligation. For the repair of 8oxoG, 8-oxoguanine DNA glycosylase 1 (OGG1) excises the damaged base and the resulting abasic site is incised by AP endonuclease 1 (APE1). DNA polymerase beta (pol beta) then fills in the gap and DNA ligase III (LIG3) seals the nick. 8oxoG can pair with adenine, resulting in a GC to TA mutation. MYH (MUTYH) excises adenine from 8oxodGTP, preventing its incorporation into the genome during replication.

Bladder cancer is the fourth most common cancer in the United States, with an estimated 4 0, 8 8 0 new cases and 1 4, 5 8 0 deaths in 2 0 0 7. Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC) accounts for 7 5% of all cases, and 1 5% of patients with NMIBC develop muscle invasive bladder cancer (MIBC). The standard treatment for NMIBC is transurethral resection of the bladder tumor (TURBT) followed by intravesical chemotherapy or immunotherapy. Approximately 7 0% of patients with NMIBC develop recurrent disease, and 1 5% progress to MIBC. The 5-year survival rate for patients with NMIBC is approximately 9 0%, but only approximately 5 0% for patients with MIBC. The most common cause of death in patients with MIBC is metastasis. The molecular mechanisms underlying the development of bladder cancer are not well understood. Several genetic alterations have been identified in bladder cancer, including activating mutations in H-RAS, K-RAS, and B-RAF, and inactivating mutations in p53 and RB. Amplification of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene has also been observed in bladder cancer. These genetic alterations may lead to increased cell proliferation and decreased apoptosis, contributing to the development of bladder cancer. In addition to genetic alterations, epigenetic changes, such as promoter hypermethylation, may play an important role in the development of bladder cancer. Aberrant DNA methylation of promoter regions silences the expression of tumor suppressor genes. Hypermethylation of the E-cadherin gene has been observed in invasive bladder cancer and may contribute to the invasive phenotype. The inactivation of the p53 and retinoblastoma (Rb) genes by promoter hypermethylation may contribute to the development of bladder cancer. Aberrant DNA methylation of multiple genes has been observed in bladder cancer, suggesting that aberrant DNA methylation may play a role in the development of bladder cancer.

Interleukin 2 (IL2) is a cytokine that stimulates the growth and differentiation of T cells. IL2 binds to a receptor on the surface of T cells and activates a signaling pathway that leads to T cell proliferation. The IL2 receptor is a heterodimer with two chains, alpha and beta. The beta chain is the ligand binding subunit and is also the signaling subunit. The alpha chain does not bind IL2 by itself, but is required for high affinity binding of IL2 to the receptor. The IL2 receptor activates several different signaling pathways, including the JAK / STAT pathway and the MAPK pathway. The JAK / STAT pathway is activated by IL2 through the JAK kinases JAK1 and JAK3, which phosphorylate and activate the STAT transcription factors. The MAPK pathway is activated by IL2 through the Ras pathway, leading to activation of the MAP kinases Erk1 and Erk2. The Ras pathway also activates the transcription factor ELK-1, which is involved in the regulation of genes involved in T cell activation. The activation of these different pathways by IL2 through the IL2 receptor leads to T cell proliferation.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease characterized by the presence of distinct genetic abnormalities in hematopoietic progenitor cells that result in the aberrant expression of genes that are normally expressed in more restricted patterns. The molecular mechanisms that lead to AML are diverse and include chromosomal translocations that result in the generation of fusion genes that play a central role in leukemogenesis. These fusion genes encode chimeric proteins that deregulate proliferation and / or differentiation of hematopoietic cells and / or induce apoptosis. In addition, mutations that affect signal transduction pathways are frequently found in AML. These mutations include those in FLT3, RAS, KIT, and N / K-RAS, PTPN1 1, and PTPN1 1.

Neurotransmitters such as dopamine, serotonin, glutamate, GABA and acetylcholine are released from presynaptic neurons and bind to specific receptors on the surface of postsynaptic neurons. The receptors are coupled to G proteins and activate second messenger systems. The neurotransmitters dopamine, serotonin and acetylcholine activate G (s) proteins and stimulate the production of cAMP. The neurotransmitter glutamate activates G (q) proteins and stimulates the production of inositol phosphates. The activation of G (i) proteins inhibits the activity of adenylyl cyclase. The activation of G proteins by neurotransmitters can also lead to the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPKs). The MAPKs are a family of serine / threonine protein kinases that are involved in a variety of cellular processes such as proliferation, differentiation and apoptosis. The MAPKs are activated by a cascade of phosphorylation events. The MAPKs are activated by the phosphorylation of threonine and tyrosine residues by the upstream kinases MEK kinase (MEKK), MEK kinase (MEKK) and Raf. The phosphorylation of the MAPKs is then terminated by the dephosphorylation of these residues by phosphatases. The activation of the MAPKs by neurotransmitters can be blocked by inhibitors of the G proteins, MEK and protein kinase C.

Cell surface proteins can be attached to the cell membrane via a glycolipid structure called a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor. The GPI anchor is covalently attached to the C-terminus of proteins through a conserved structure, the GPI core structure. The biosynthesis of GPI anchors is a multistep process that starts with the attachment of N-acetylglucosaminyl (GlcNAc) to phosphatidylinositol (PI). GlcNAc is then modified by the addition of mannose (Man) residues, which are in turn modified by the addition of other sugars and phosphate residues. The GPI core structure is conserved in all eukaryotes. After the synthesis of the GPI precursor is completed, the GPI-anchor attachment site is recognized by a specific GPI-transamidase complex, which cleaves the C-terminus of the protein and replaces it with the preformed GPI. After the attachment of the GPI anchor, the GPI-anchored proteins are transported to the cell surface via the secretory pathway. In this review, we describe the biosynthesis of GPI anchors and the genes involved in this process.

The transcription factor NFAT is a key regulator of cytokine gene expression in T cells. The activity of NFAT is regulated by the calcium / calmodulin dependent phosphatase calcineurin. In the absence of calcium, NFAT is retained in the cytoplasm by association with the proteins 14-3-3. Upon antigen receptor stimulation, calcium is mobilized from intracellular stores and enters the cell. Calcineurin is activated by calcium and dephosphorylates NFAT, causing it to translocate to the nucleus. In the nucleus NFAT binds to the AP-1 site in the promoter of cytokine genes, and interacts with other transcription factors to activate transcription. The activity of NFAT is also regulated by phosphorylation. The kinase GSK-3 phosphorylates NFAT and causes it to be retained in the cytoplasm. The kinase p42-MAPK is also able to phosphorylate NFAT, causing it to be exported from the nucleus. The kinase PKC-theta is involved in the activation of NFAT by the T cell receptor, and is activated by the scaffold protein CARMA1.

ADP-ribosylation factors (ARFs) are 2 0-kDa guanine nucleotide-binding proteins that are members of the Ras GTPase superfamily. They are involved in intracellular vesicular transport and in the regulation of phospholipase D. The six known human ARF proteins (ARFA-1C, -1B, -1C1-2, -1C2, -1D1, -1D2) are encoded by different chromosomes and are classified into three groups based on sequence similarity: class I (ARFA-1C1, -1C2), class II (ARFA-1D1, -1D2), and class III (ARFA-1C1, -1D2). The three groups share 2 5-3 0% sequence identity and are structurally divided into an N-terminal domain containing the GTP-binding site, a middle domain containing a Sec7 domain, and a C-terminal domain containing the putative lipid modification site and the Rho-like GTPase-activating protein (GAP) domain. The Sec7 domain catalyzes the exchange of GDP for GTP in ARFs, and the Rho-like GAP domain stimulates the GTPase activity of ARFs. The PH domain is a lipid-binding domain that is involved in membrane recruitment of proteins containing PH domains. The cytohesins are a subfamily of guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs) for ARF proteins that also contain a PH domain, ankyrin repeats, and a conserved C-terminal domain that is similar to the product of the tumor suppressor gene p130. The cytohesins are found in all vertebrates and are expressed in a variety of tissues. The cytohesin-1 PH domain binds phosphatidylinositol-3, 4, 5-trisphosphate (PtdIns (3, 4, 5) P3), and this interaction is required for the efficient activation of the exchange activity of cytohesin-1 by PI (3, 4, 5) P3. The PH domain also contributes to the autoinhibition of cytohesin-1. The crystal structure of the Sec7 domain of cytohesin-1 in complex with GDP-bound ARF1GDP revealed the molecular basis for the specificity of the Sec7 domain for the ARF family of GTPases. The Sec7 domain forms a dimer with a 2-fold symmetry, and each monomer contributes one of the two nucleotide-binding sites. The structure of the complex also revealed the basis for the specificity of the cytohesin-1 Sec7 domain for the ARF GTPases. The PH domain of cytohesin-1 binds PtdIns (3, 4, 5) P3, and this interaction may help to recruit cytohesin-1 to the plasma membrane. The PH domain also contributes to the autoinhibition of cytohesin-1. The binding of PtdIns (3, 4, 5) P3 to the PH domain may induce a conformational change that exposes the binding site for the Sec7 domain. The crystal structure of the PH domain of cytohesin-3 in complex with Ins (1, 3, 4, 5) P4 revealed the molecular basis for the specific recognition of PtdIns (3, 4, 5) P3 by the PH domain of cytohesin-3. The crystal structure of the PH domain of cytohesin-2 in complex with Ins (1, 3, 4, 5) P4 revealed the molecular basis for the specific recognition of PtdIns (3, 4, 5) P3 by the PH domain of cytohesin-2. The PH domain of cytohesin-2 also contributes to the autoinhibition of cytohesin-2. The binding of PtdIns (3, 4, 5) P3 to the PH domain may induce a conformational change that exposes the binding site for the Sec7 domain.

The human papilloma virus (HPV) is a DNA virus that infects squamous epithelial cells and can cause cervical cancer. The E6 and E7 proteins encoded by HPV are the major viral oncoproteins that are required for cellular transformation. E6 binds to the tumor suppressor protein p5 3 and targets it for degradation. E6 also binds to the ubiquitin ligase E6AP, which targets proteins for degradation by the proteasome. E7 binds to the retinoblastoma protein (Rb) and disrupts the interaction of Rb with the transcription factor E2F-1, releasing the transcription factor E2F-1 to induce S phase and cellular proliferation. E6 and E7 also interact with the transcription factor AP-1, which may also contribute to cellular transformation. E6 and E7 also activate transcription of the hTERT gene, which encodes the catalytic subunit of telomerase, a ribonucleoprotein that adds multiple nucleotides to the ends of chromosomes and is required for cellular immortalization. E6 and E7 also activate the transcription of the cellular genes involved in DNA replication and repair, which may contribute to cellular transformation. E6 and E7 also activate the transcription factor AP-1, which may contribute to cellular transformation by inducing expression of genes involved in cell growth and proliferation. The ability of E6 and E7 to transform cells requires the expression of the cellular transcription factor AP-1. The activation of AP-1 by E6 and E7 may be mediated by the induction of c-Fos and c-Jun. The activation of AP-1 by E6 and E7 may also contribute to cellular immortalization by inducing expression of the catalytic subunit of telomerase, which is required for cellular immortalization.

The transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) superfamily consists of a large group of structurally related secreted cytokines that regulate a broad spectrum of cellular functions, including proliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis. TGF-beta is a potent inhibitor of epithelial cell growth and has been implicated as a tumor suppressor. TGF-beta signals through a heteromeric complex of type I and type II serine-threonine kinase receptors. Binding of TGF-beta to its receptor complex results in the phosphorylation and activation of the type I receptor kinase, which in turn activates the type II receptor kinase. The activated type I receptor phosphorylates receptor-associated SMAD proteins (R-SMADs), including SMAD2 and SMAD3. R-SMAD proteins bind to SMAD4 and the complex is then translocated to the nucleus, where it regulates transcription of target genes. Inhibitory SMADs (I-SMADs), including SMAD6 and SMAD7, antagonize the TGF-beta pathway by binding to activated type I receptors and preventing the phosphorylation of R-SMADs. SMAD6 and SMAD7 also interact with the E3 ubiquitin ligase SMURF-1, targeting them for degradation.

The renin-angiotensin system (RAS) is a key regulator of blood pressure and electrolyte homeostasis. Angiotensinogen is cleaved by renin to form angiotensin I, which is further cleaved by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) to form angiotensin II. Angiotensinogen and ACE are both synthesized in the liver, and are transported to the kidneys, where they are filtered by the glomeruli and then secreted into the tubular lumen. In the tubular lumen, angiotensinogen is cleaved by the protease cathepsin D, which is secreted by the tubular cells. The filtered angiotensinogen is then absorbed by the proximal tubular cells and cleaved by cathepsin D to form angiotensin I. This is then cleaved by ACE to form angiotensin II, which is secreted into the tubular lumen. Angiotensin II binds to its receptor in the tubular cells, stimulating the secretion of sodium and water into the tubular lumen. The increased water and sodium in the tubular lumen then pass into the bladder through the kidneys, increasing blood pressure. The importance of the RAS in blood pressure regulation is demonstrated by the fact that ACE inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor blockers are effective antihypertensive drugs.

The innate immune system is the first line of defense against invading pathogens. Viral infection is detected by host cells through recognition of viral nucleic acids by cellular pattern recognition receptors (PRRs), including Toll-like receptors (TLRs) and RIG-I-like receptors (RLRs). Upon recognition of viral nucleic acids, cellular signaling pathways are activated that lead to the production of type I interferon (IFN) and other cytokines, which in turn activate the expression of interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs), resulting in an antiviral state in infected cells and neighboring cells. This process is called the 'IFN amplification loop'.

The high affinity IgE receptor (Fc epsilon RI) is a key regulator of allergic responses. Cross-linking of Fc epsilon RI by antigen-antibody complexes on the surface of mast cells leads to the release of inflammatory mediators that cause allergic reactions. The activation of mast cells also leads to the production of cytokines that can affect the immune system in a variety of ways. The Fc epsilon RI is a member of the immunoglobulin gene superfamily and is comprised of an alpha chain that binds IgE with high affinity, a beta chain, and two gamma chains. The cytoplasmic domains of the subunits are not homologous, but they do contain a number of motifs that are involved in signal transduction. Upon aggregation of Fc epsilon RI, the tyrosine kinase Lyn (Src family kinase) is activated and phosphorylates the beta and gamma subunits. The phosphorylated tyrosine residues provide docking sites for the binding of the SH2 domains of the tyrosine phosphatase SHP-1 and the adaptor protein Shc. SHP-1 and Shc are involved in the down-regulation of signaling pathways. SHIP is a negative regulator of signaling that hydrolyzes the lipid second messenger PIP3 to PIP2 and thus inhibits the activation of PI3 kinase. The activation of PI3 kinase leads to the activation of the kinase Akt and the transcription factor NF-AT. The activation of NF-AT leads to the production of cytokines such as TNF-alpha and IL-4. The MAP kinase pathway is also involved in the activation of mast cells. The activation of MAP kinase pathways by Fc epsilon RI is dependent on the activity of Lyn. The activation of Lyn leads to the phosphorylation of the adaptor protein LAT and the subsequent activation of the Map kinase pathway. The Map kinase pathways are involved in the regulation of cytokine production by mast cells.

The phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) / AKT pathway is activated by a variety of growth factors and is involved in cell survival. The inhibitor of apoptosis protein (IAP) family of proteins binds to and inhibits caspases, the proteases that induce apoptosis. The PI3K / AKT pathway also activates the NF-kappaB pathway, which promotes cell survival. The PI3K / AKT pathway also phosphorylates the transcription factor FKHRL1, which induces expression of the IAP protein survivin. The heat shock protein 9 0 (HSP9 0) is involved in the folding of proteins and is required for the stability and activity of a number of proteins involved in cell proliferation and survival. The HSP9 0 inhibitor geldanamycin (GA) induces the degradation of several of these proteins, including AKT, and is cytotoxic to tumor cells. The activity of GA is enhanced by the glucose transporter 1 (GLUT1), which is required for GA uptake by tumor cells. The degradation of AKT by GA is blocked by glucose, indicating that the effect of GA is due to depletion of intracellular glucose. The degradation of AKT is also blocked by the proteasome inhibitor MG1 3 2, indicating that the degradation is mediated by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. The degradation of AKT by GA is specific, as other proteins that are dependent on HSP9 0 for stability are not affected. The degradation of AKT by GA is also specific for tumor cells, since normal cells do not degrade AKT in response to GA. The degradation of AKT by GA is blocked by the PI3K inhibitor LY2 9 4 0 0 2, indicating that the degradation is dependent on the PI3K pathway. The degradation of AKT by GA is blocked by the HSP9 0 inhibitor 1 7AAG, indicating that the degradation is dependent on the inhibition of HSP9 0 by 1 7AAG. The degradation of AKT by GA is also blocked by the GLUT1 inhibitor cytochalasin B, indicating that the degradation is dependent on glucose uptake. The degradation of AKT by GA is also blocked by the glycolysis inhibitor 2-deoxy-D-glucose (2-DG), indicating that the degradation is dependent on glycolysis. The degradation of AKT by GA is also blocked by the antioxidant N-acetyl-L-cysteine (NAC), indicating that reactive oxygen species (ROS) are involved in the degradation.
