The phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) / AKT pathway is a key regulator of cell survival and proliferation. The pathway is activated by growth factor receptors and by loss of tumor suppressors. AKT is a key downstream effector of PI3K. AKT phosphorylates a variety of substrates involved in cell survival and proliferation. Phosphorylation of the proapoptotic protein BAD by AKT inhibits its interaction with the antiapoptotic protein BCL-XL, thus promoting cell survival. AKT also phosphorylates the forkhead transcription factors FKHRL1 and FKHRL2, which induce the expression of proapoptotic genes. Another substrate of AKT is the MDM2 protein, which promotes the degradation of the tumor suppressor p53. Another substrate of AKT is p07, a cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor. The phosphorylation of p07 by AKT inhibits its growth inhibitory activity.

Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease with a poor prognosis. The majority of patients suffer from AML de novo, but a small percentage of patients suffer from AML following a myelodysplastic phase (MDS). The molecular pathogenesis of AML is complex and heterogeneous. Several different classes of mutations have been identified in AML, including mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinases FLT3 and c-Kit, mutations in the RAS genes, and mutations in the NPM1 gene. The most common cytogenetic abnormalities in AML are translocations involving the MLL gene at chromosome 1 1q2 3, which is involved in de novo AML as well as in therapy-related AML (t-AML), and the AML-associated genes AML1 / ETO and CBF1ME. The MLL gene is involved in the regulation of HOX genes, which are involved in embryonic development and haematopoiesis. The AML1 / ETO fusion protein interferes with the normal function of transcription factors involved in haematopoiesis.

Cytokines are soluble factors that are secreted by various cell types and act on other cells to regulate a broad spectrum of biological responses. Cytokines are classified into distinct groups on the basis of their structure and the receptors they bind. The hematopoietic cytokines are grouped into two major categories: the hematopoietin group, which includes erythropoietin (EPO), thrombopoietin (TPO), interleukin-3 (IL-3), interleukin-5 (IL-5), and granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF), and the IL-6 family, which includes IL-6, IL-11, IL-12, IL-13, LIF, and OSM. Cytokines exert their biological functions by binding to specific cell-surface receptors. The receptors for hematopoietins are members of the hematopoietin receptor family, whereas the IL-6 family receptors are members of the IL-6 receptor family. Binding of cytokines to their receptors leads to the activation of associated protein tyrosine kinases, the Janus kinases (JAKs), which in turn phosphorylate specific tyrosine residues on the receptor and / or associated proteins. The phosphorylated receptors then serve as docking sites for the recruitment and activation of downstream signaling molecules, including the signal transducers and activators of transcription (STATs). The JAK / STAT pathway is a major signaling pathway used by cytokines to transmit their biological effects. Other pathways activated by cytokines include the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway and the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway.

Blood coagulation is a series of biochemical reactions resulting in the formation of a clot at the site of vascular injury. The coagulation cascade is initiated by tissue factor (TF), which is expressed at low levels on the surface of cells in the absence of vascular injury. Tissue injury results in the exposure of the plasma proteins fibrinogen and prothrombin, which are in their soluble form in plasma. Thrombin is formed from prothrombin by the action of the prothrombinase complex, which is formed by the binding of factor Va to factor Xa and factor Va. The prothrombinase complex is activated by the TF-factor VIIa complex, which is formed by the binding of TF to factor VIIa. The activation of factor X by the TF-factor VIIa complex and factor Xa results in the formation of thrombin, which cleaves fibrinogen to fibrin monomers. The polymerization of these monomers leads to the formation of a clot.

B cells are the key players in adaptive immunity. They produce and secrete antibodies to fight against foreign antigens. They also present antigens to T cells to stimulate the immune response. The B cell receptor (BCR) is a multi-molecular complex that is composed of immunoglobulin (Ig) heavy (H) and light (L) chains, Ig-alpha and Ig-beta. The BCR is coupled to downstream signaling pathways through Ig-alpha and Ig-beta. The BCR is activated by binding of antigen to the Ig variable region, which triggers the phosphorylation of immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motifs (ITAMs) in Ig-alpha and Ig-beta by the Src family kinases Lyn and Fyn. The phosphorylated ITAMs recruit the tandem SH2-containing tyrosine kinase Syk, which in turn activates several downstream signaling pathways, including the phospholipase C (PLC) -gamma 2 pathway and the phosphoinositide-3-kinase (PI3K) -Akt pathway. These pathways lead to the activation of nuclear factor-AT (NFAT), nuclear factor-KB (NF-kB) and activator protein-1 (AP-1), which are important for B cell proliferation and differentiation.

The Fas receptor is a member of the tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily. Fas-induced apoptosis is involved in the regulation of the immune system and may play a role in autoimmune disease. The Fas receptor is expressed on a variety of cell types including lymphocytes, macrophages, and neurons. Binding of Fas ligand (FasL) on an adjacent cell activates the Fas receptor and initiates apoptosis. The Fas-FasL interaction is also involved in cytotoxic T cell-mediated lysis of virus-infected cells. The Fas-FasL interaction also plays a role in the rejection of transplanted tissue and may play a role in neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease. The Fas receptor is a 4 9-kDa type I integral membrane protein with a cytoplasmic domain homologous to that of the tumor necrosis factor receptor. The cytoplasmic domain contains a death domain that is required for apoptosis signaling by the Fas receptor. The Fas-associated death domain (FADD) is an adaptor protein that binds to the Fas death domain and is required for Fas-mediated apoptosis. FADD also contains a death effector domain that interacts with another adaptor protein, procaspase-8. Binding of FADD to the Fas receptor brings procaspase-8 into proximity, allowing its activation. Caspase-8 activates downstream caspases, including caspase-3, that cleave cellular targets and induce apoptosis. The Bcl-2 family of proteins includes both anti-apoptotic (Bcl-2, Bcl-xL, Bcl-w, A1, and Bfl-1) and pro-apoptotic (Bax, Bak, Bad, Bid, Bik, and Noxa) members. The Bcl-2 family members form a complex network of interactions that regulate apoptosis. The anti-apoptotic members of the Bcl-2 family interact with FADD and / or procaspase-8 to inhibit apoptosis. The pro-apoptotic Bcl-2 family members interact with the mitochondrial membrane to induce apoptosis. The Bcl-2 family also interacts with each other to regulate apoptosis. The mechanism by which the Bcl-2 family members regulate apoptosis is not yet clear, but may involve regulation of mitochondrial membrane permeability and release of cytochrome c.

The Wnt family of secreted glycoproteins plays a key role in embryonic development and adult tissue homeostasis. The Wnt pathway is involved in the control of cell proliferation, differentiation and apoptosis. Wnt proteins bind to the cell surface receptor Frizzled (Fz) and to the low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 5 (Lrp5) or Lrp6. This interaction leads to the recruitment of Disheveled (DSH) and the stabilization of beta-catenin. Beta-catenin translocates into the nucleus, where it associates with TCF / LEF family transcription factors and activates the transcription of target genes. Wnt / beta-catenin signaling is negatively regulated by a set of proteins, including Axin, APC, and the sodiophilic frizzled-related proteins (SFRPs). Wnt / beta-catenin signaling is also positively regulated by the planar cell polarity (PCP) pathway, which involves the small GTPases RhoA and Rac1 and the protein kinase JNK. Wnt / PCP signaling regulates the cytoskeleton and cell motility.

The peptide hormone angiotensin II (Ang II) is a key regulator of blood pressure and fluid homeostasis. Ang II exerts its effects through two receptors, AT1 and AT2. The AT1 receptor is coupled to Gq / 1 1, stimulating the inositol phosphate pathway and the release of intracellular calcium, and activating protein kinase C. The AT2 receptor is coupled to Gi / o and is negatively coupled to adenylyl cyclase. Ang II also activates MAP kinase pathways through both AT1 and AT2 receptors. The AT1 receptor activates the ras / raf / Mek / Erk pathway, while the AT2 receptor activates the p38 pathway. The AT1 receptor also activates the p38 pathway through the tyrosine kinase Pyk2 and the small G protein rac. Ang II also activates the p38 pathway through G-protein independent mechanisms involving reactive oxygen species and the epidermal growth factor receptor. Ang II induces hypertrophy of vascular smooth muscle cells and cardiac fibroblasts through the p38 pathway. Ang II also stimulates proliferation of many cell types through the ras / map kinase pathway. The p38 pathway may also be involved in Ang II induced apoptosis.

The nuclear factor-kappaB (NF-kB) family of transcription factors plays a key role in the regulation of immune and inflammatory responses. In most cells, NF-kB is retained in the cytoplasm by association with the inhibitor protein IkBa. Various stimuli, including inflammatory cytokines such as TNF and IL-1, viral infection, and the phorbol ester PMA activate the IKK kinase complex, which phosphorylates IkBa, targeting it for degradation by the ubiquitin-proteosome pathway. This results in the release and nuclear translocation of NF-kB, which then activates transcription of target genes. The activation of NF-kB by the T cell costimulatory receptor, CTLA-4, is independent of IKK activation, but requires the protein kinase MEKK1. MEKK1 activates the JNK pathway, which also leads to NF-kB activation.

Huntington's disease (HD) is an autosomal-dominant neurodegenerative disorder caused by a CAG repeat expansion in the HD gene IT1 5. The HD mutation results in a long stretch of polyglutamine (polyQ) near the N-terminus of the HD gene product, huntingtin (Htt). Mutant Htt (mHtt) is widely expressed throughout the body, but its toxicity is most pronounced in neurons. Mutant Htt (exp) is prone to cleavage by proteases, and the resulting N-terminal fragments are prone to misfolding and aggregation. The presence of expanded polyQ in Htt leads to a loss of normal Htt function. The loss of normal Htt function may be related to the role of Htt in vesicular transport. The gain of toxic function may be related to the aberrant protein-protein interactions of mHtt. The formation of aggregates may interfere with normal cellular functions. The accumulation of misfolded proteins in the cytosol and nucleus leads to proteasome and / or mitochondrial dysfunction, which in turn may cause more protein misfolding and aggregation. These events may then feed forward into more protein misfolding and aggregation, resulting in a self-propagating cycle of protein misfolding and aggregation.

Axon guidance is a crucial process in the formation of neuronal network. Axons are guided by attractive and repulsive guidance cues in their environment. Axons are attracted to their targets by attractive cues, such as netrins, and are repelled by repellent cues, such as ephrins. Axons are also guided by a variety of intermediate targets, such as growth cones. Axons are guided by ephrins and netrins expressed on the surface of guideposts. Ephrins and their receptors are divided into two classes, EphAs and EphBs, and ephrins and their receptors, EphRs. The Eph receptor tyrosine kinases (Ephs) are activated by ephrins. The Eph signaling pathway is complex and involves multiple downstream signaling cascades. The interaction of ephrins and Eph receptors can lead to two distinct signaling pathways. The contact-mediated forward signaling pathway involves the interaction of Eph receptors on the axonal surface with ephrins on the surface of the adjacent cells. This pathway is involved in the initial attraction of the growing axon. The contact-independent reverse signaling pathway involves the cleavage of the ephrins' cytoplasmic domain. This pathway is involved in the retraction of the growth cone.

Interleukin-7 (IL-7) is a cytokine that is produced by stromal cells in the bone marrow and is critical for the development and proliferation of B and T cells. The IL-7 receptor is expressed on immature B and T cells and the binding of IL-7 to the receptor activates several signaling pathways. One pathway activated by IL-7 is the PI3 kinase pathway. PI3 kinase activation by IL-7 leads to the activation of Akt and the inhibition of apoptosis. Another pathway activated by IL-7 is the JAK / STAT pathway. The JAK / STAT pathway is activated by IL-7 and leads to the activation of STAT5 and the induction of genes such as p300 and p21. The activation of p300 and p21 leads to the activation of NF-AT and the induction of genes such as cyclin D2. The activation of the JAK / STAT and PI3 kinase pathways by IL-7 leads to the induction of genes that lead to the proliferation and survival of B and T cells.

Glycolysis is a fundamental metabolic pathway that produces ATP and other essential metabolites. It consists of eleven reactions, each of which involves the transfer of a phosphate group from a high-energy phosphate compound to a low-energy phosphate compound. The phosphate group is either from a phosphate group donor (ATP) or from a proton (H +). The phosphate donors are ADP, NAD +, and Pi. The phosphate acceptors are carbohydrates, carboxylic acids, and alcohols. The reactions are shown in the lower part of glycolysis. The upper part of glycolysis converts glyceraldehyde-3P to glycerate-3P, which is then converted to phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP). Pyruvate is then formed from PEP and is reduced to form lactate. The conversion of glucose to pyruvate is catalyzed by the enzyme hexokinase. There are two forms of hexokinase, a constitutive form (HKII) and an inducible form (HKI). The inducible form is expressed at high levels in liver and kidney in response to a variety of stimuli, including hormones, diet, and exercise. The enzyme phosphofructo-kinase (PFK) catalyzes the committed step of glycolysis, the conversion of fructose-6P to fructose-1P. There are three forms of PFK, each of which is a homotetramer. The form expressed in bacteria and invertebrates is inhibited by ATP and activated by AMP. The form expressed in vertebrates is less sensitive to these effectors. The third form is expressed in muscle and is less sensitive to these effectors. The enzyme enolase catalyzes the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate. There are two forms of enolase, each of which is a homodimer. The muscle form of enolase is less sensitive to inhibition by ATP and inhibition by Pi. The final step of glycolysis is the conversion of pyruvate to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). There are two forms of LDH, each of which is a homodimer. One form is expressed constitutively (LDH-A), and the other form is expressed in muscle and is expressed at high levels during exercise (LDH-B).

The peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) are a class of nuclear hormone receptors that are activated by fatty acids and their derivatives. The PPAR family consists of three members, PPARalpha, PPARbeta / delta (also known as PPARbeta / delta), and PPARgamma. PPARalpha is expressed in the liver, kidney, heart, and brown adipose tissue, and is involved in the regulation of lipid metabolism. PPARbeta / delta is expressed in a broad range of tissues, and is involved in lipid metabolism and cellular differentiation. PPARgamma is expressed in adipose tissue and is involved in adipocyte differentiation. The three subtypes of PPAR bind to fatty acids and their derivatives as ligands. The binding of fatty acids and their derivatives to PPARs induces conformational changes in the receptor, and the activated PPAR forms a heterodimer with the retinoid X receptor (RXR). The PPAR / RXR heterodimer then binds to peroxisome proliferator response elements (PPREs) in the promoter regions of target genes, and regulates the expression of these genes. In addition to fatty acids and their derivatives, various synthetic compounds, including hypolipidemic drugs and prostaglandin J2, are ligands for PPARs. The expression of cytochrome P4 5 0 (CYP) genes is also regulated by PPARs. CYP2C9 is the major CYP enzyme involved in the metabolism of drugs, including warfarin. CYP2C9 is induced by all three PPAR subtypes through the direct binding of the PPAR / RXR heterodimer to a PPRE in the CYP2C9 gene. In addition to CYP2C9, CYP2C8 and CYP2E1 are also induced by PPARalpha ligands. In contrast, PPARbeta / delta represses the induction of CYP2C9, CYP2C8, and CYP2E1 by PPARalpha ligands. The repression of CYP2C9 and CYP2C8 by PPARbeta / delta is mediated by the activation of the NF-E2-related factor 2 (Nrf2) / antioxidant response element (ARE) pathway. PPARgamma represses the induction of CYP2C9, CYP2C8, and CYP2E1 by PPARalpha ligands. The repression is mediated by the inhibition of the PPARalpha-mediated activation of the CYP2C9 and CYP2C8 genes.

The T cell receptor (TCR) is a multisubunit complex that recognizes specific peptide antigens in the context of MHC molecules on the surface of other cells. The TCR is composed of two heterodimers, each containing one alpha and one beta chain. The alpha chain also associates with the CD28 co-receptor. The CD3 complex is associated with the TCR complex and is required for its expression and function. The zeta chains of the TCR complex contain immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motifs (ITAMs) that are phosphorylated by the Src family kinases Lck and Fyn upon TCR engagement. The phosphorylated ITAMs recruit the ZAP-7 0 protein tyrosine kinase to the receptor complex, which in turn phosphorylates downstream targets. The activation of T cells requires two signals. The first signal is provided by the interaction of the TCR with peptide antigen in the context of MHC. This interaction results in the phosphorylation of the TCR zeta chains by Lck and Fyn and the recruitment of ZAP-7 0 to the receptor complex. ZAP-7 0 phosphorylates downstream targets that activate the T cell. The second signal is provided by the interaction of the T cell co-receptor CD28 with the T cell surface molecule LFA-1. This interaction also activates Lck and Fyn and may result in the phosphorylation of the TCR zeta chains. The phosphorylation of the TCR zeta chains may be required for the full T cell activation.

Nerve growth factor (NGF) is a member of the neurotrophin family that regulates neuronal survival and differentiation. In addition to its well-established role in the development and maintenance of the nervous system, NGF has been implicated in a variety of other processes, including immune function, inflammation, and the pathogenesis of some neurodegenerative disorders. The biological effects of NGF are mediated by TrkA, a receptor tyrosine kinase. Upon NGF binding, TrkA is phosphorylated on tyrosine residues, activating several signaling cascades. The first pathway activated is the Ras / Raf / mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) cascade, which leads to the activation of the transcription factor CREB. Another pathway activated by NGF is the PI3-kinase / Akt pathway, which leads to the activation of the transcription factor NF-kappaB. Other pathways activated by NGF include the phospholipase C (PLC) -gamma pathway, which leads to the activation of PKC and the calcineurin / NFAT pathway.

Cytokines are soluble factors that are secreted by cells and act on other cells. Cytokines are classified into two groups: cytokines that are secreted by lymphocytes (cytokines that mediate cellular immunity) and cytokines that are secreted by nonlymphocytes (cytokines that mediate humoral immunity). Cytokines are involved in a wide variety of biological functions, including development and differentiation of cells, cell growth and proliferation, induction of apoptosis, and inflammation. Cytokines are produced by various types of cells and act on cells through specific receptors. Cytokines that are secreted by lymphocytes include interleukins (IL), interferons (IFN), growth factors (GF), and tumor necrosis factors (TNF). Cytokines that are secreted by nonlymphocytes include erythropoietin (EPO), thrombopoietin (TPO), prolactin (PRL), insulin-like growth factor (IGF), leptin, and interleukin 10 (IL-10). Cytokines act on cells through specific receptors. The receptors for cytokines are generally composed of two subunits. Some cytokines have two subunits in a complex, such as IL-2 and IL-10. Other cytokines have a single subunit, such as the interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma) receptor. The subunits of cytokine receptors are diverse in structure and are classified into two groups: the ligand-specific subunits and the subunits shared by several cytokines. The ligand-specific subunits are usually glycoproteins that bind cytokines with high affinity. The subunits of the shared receptors are transmembrane proteins that bind cytokines with lower affinity.

DNA damage activates checkpoint signaling pathways that block cell cycle progression to allow time for DNA repair to occur. The ATM kinase and the ATR kinase respond to DNA damage by activating downstream signaling pathways that block cell cycle progression and induce DNA repair. The ATM kinase is mutated in patients with the cancer-prone disease ataxia telangiectasia. The ATR kinase is related to ATM and is required for cell cycle checkpoint control in response to DNA damage. The ATR kinase is activated by DNA damage and by replication blocks. The ATR kinase phosphorylates the checkpoint kinases Chk1 and Chk2, which in turn phosphorylate and regulate downstream targets to block cell cycle progression and induce DNA repair. The breast cancer susceptibility gene product BRCA2 is also phosphorylated by the ATR kinase in response to DNA damage. The breast cancer susceptibility gene product BRCA1 is required for DNA repair and checkpoint control. The breast cancer susceptibility gene product p53 is involved in checkpoint control and DNA repair. The p53 protein interacts with the checkpoint kinase Chk1 and is required for the activation of Chk1 by ATR in response to DNA damage. The p53 gene is also mutated in patients with the cancer-prone disease Li-Fraumeni syndrome. The p53 protein interacts with the breast cancer susceptibility gene product BRCA1. The interaction of p53 with BRCA1 may regulate the DNA repair activity of BRCA1.

The progression of prostate cancer from an androgen-dependent state to an androgen-independent state is a major cause of prostate cancer mortality. The progression of androgen-independent prostate cancer is associated with the emergence of androgen-independent tumor cells, which no longer depend on androgen for growth and survival. The androgen-independent prostate cancer cells express high levels of the androgen receptor (AR) and are able to proliferate in the absence of androgen. The AR is a ligand-dependent transcription factor that is activated by androgen antagonists such as flutamide and bicalutamide. However, in androgen-independent prostate cancer cells, the AR is still required for the proliferation and survival of prostate cancer cells. The AR is also a phosphoprotein and undergoes phosphorylation by protein kinases, including protein kinase A, protein kinase C, and MAPK. Protein phosphorylation plays an important role in the regulation of AR activity. The AR is also regulated by protein phosphatases. Protein phosphatase 2A dephosphorylates the AR and inhibits its activity. Dephosphorylation of the AR by protein phosphatase 2A may contribute to the development of androgen-independent prostate cancer.

The mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) cascade is a highly conserved module of kinases that transmits signals from the cell surface to the nucleus in response to a variety of extracellular stimuli. The MAPK cascade is activated by growth factors, cytokines, and neurotransmitters, and is involved in a variety of cellular responses including proliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis. The MAPK cascade is initiated by activation of a transmembrane receptor tyrosine kinase, which leads to the activation of Ras and the Raf family of protein kinases. Activated Raf phosphorylates and activates Mek1 and Mek2, which in turn activate Erk1 and Erk2. The activated Erks translocate to the nucleus and activate transcription through phosphorylation of transcription factors such as Elk-1. The duration and strength of the signal is regulated by phosphatases and by the action of specific inactivators such as p27. The p27 protein is induced by the MAPK pathway and acts as a feedback inhibitor to attenuate the signal. The p27 protein binds to and inhibits the Mek1 and Mek2 kinases, and also induces the degradation of the Mek1 and Mek2 kinases. The p21 protein is a cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor that is induced by the MAPK pathway and acts as a checkpoint to prevent the cell from entering S phase if the pathway is not activated.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that affects multiple organ systems. The hallmark of SLE is the production of autoantibodies to nuclear antigens. The presence of these autoantibodies is a key feature of SLE. Autoantibodies are directed against nuclear proteins such as DNA, histones, and ribonucleoproteins (RNPs). The presence of these autoantibodies is associated with the formation of immune complexes that are deposited in tissues and cause organ damage.

The G2 / M checkpoint prevents the cell from entering mitosis (M phase) if the genome is damaged or the cell is incompletely replicated. The G2 / M checkpoint is activated by DNA damage and by incomplete DNA replication. The checkpoint prevents the activation of the M-phase promoting factor (MPF), which is a complex of cyclin-dependent kinase 1 (CDK1) and cyclin B. MPF is required for the transition from G2 to M phase. The activation of MPF is regulated by the opposing activities of the kinases, Wee1 and Cdc2 5. When MPF is active, it is phosphorylated and activated by the kinases Myt1 and Cdc25C. When MPF is inactive, it is dephosphorylated and the kinases are phosphorylated by the protein phosphatase PP2A. The activation of the DNA damage checkpoint inhibits the activation of MPF by blocking the degradation of cyclin B. In the absence of DNA damage, the ubiquitin ligase that targets cyclin B for degradation is activated by the APC. In the presence of DNA damage, the kinase Chk2 is activated by ATM and phosphorylates and activates the transcription factor p5 3. The activated p5 3 induces the expression of the protein Wip1, which dephosphorylates and deactivates the kinase Cdc2 5C. The dephosphorylation of Cdc2 5C by Wip1 prevents the activation of MPF by Cdc2 5C and the subsequent activation of MPF. The inhibition of the APC by Wip1 also prevents the degradation of cyclin B. The inhibition of MPF activation by the DNA damage checkpoint prevents the initiation of mitosis and allows time for the cell to repair the damaged DNA.

Sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) is a bioactive lipid messenger that is generated by the phosphorylation of sphingosine by sphingosine kinase (SPHK). S1P can be dephosphorylated to sphingosine by sphingosine phosphatases or it is N-acylated by sphingosine acyltransferase to form ceramide. S1P is a ligand for the Edg family of G-protein coupled receptors. S1P has been implicated in a variety of cellular processes including cell proliferation, survival, migration, and angiogenesis. The intracellular levels of S1P are regulated by the opposing actions of SPHK and the S1P lyase. SPHK1 is activated by a variety of growth factors and cytokines and is required for cell proliferation. S1P is degraded by S1P lyase, which cleaves the ethanolamine phosphate group to yield hexadecenal and phosphoethanolamine. The S1P lyase is induced by stress and is required for cell death. The S1P receptor is coupled to Gi and inhibits adenylate cyclase, but also activates other signaling pathways including Rac and the MAP kinases. The S1P receptor is required for S1P-induced cell migration. The S1P lyase is required for S1P-induced inhibition of angiogenesis.

The central nervous system (CNS) is an immune-privileged site, in part because of the presence of the blood-brain barrier (BBB), a specialized endothelial cell layer that restricts the passage of circulating cells and molecules into the brain parenchyma. The BBB is formed by tight junctions between the endothelial cells, which prevent the paracellular diffusion of hydrophilic molecules and restrict the movement of lipid-soluble molecules by passive diffusion. In addition, specialized transport systems located at the luminal and abluminal membranes of the endothelial cells regulate the entry and exit of nutrients and immune cells into the CNS. The presence of the BBB is a major factor in the immune-privileged status of the CNS. The expression of MHC-II and costimulatory molecules on the abluminal side of the BBB endothelium suggests that activated T cells in the circulation can gain access to the CNS parenchyma. Furthermore, the expression of adhesion molecules and costimulatory molecules on the abluminal side of the BBB endothelium may allow the migration of activated T cells into the CNS parenchyma.

The transcription factor NF-kB is a key regulator of apoptosis, inflammation, and immune responses. The activity of NF-kB is regulated by IkB kinase (IkB kinase), which phosphorylates IkBalpha, causing IkBalpha to be degraded by the proteosome. The degradation of IkBalpha allows NF-kB to translocate to the nucleus and activate transcription. The activation of NF-kB by TNF-alpha is mediated by the IkB kinase complex, which also phosphorylates IkB, including the activation of map kinase pathways. The map kinase pathway includes MEKK1, SEK1, and Rsk-2. The map kinase pathway also activates NF-kB by a mechanism independent of the IkB kinase complex. The transcription factor Sp1 is also involved in the activation of the HIV LTR. The activity of Sp1 is regulated by phosphorylation, and the activation of the HIV LTR by Sp1 is also mediated by the phosphorylation of Sp1. The activation of the HIV LTR by Sp1 and NF-kB is inhibited by the cellular kinase p53. The cellular kinase p53 is induced by a variety of stress signals, including the DNA damaging agent adriamycin, and activates the HIV LTR by phosphorylating Sp1 and inducing the activity of NF-kB. The activation of the HIV LTR by p53 may contribute to the activation of HIV by stress signals.

Base excision repair (BER) is the predominant pathway for the repair of small base lesions, such as the oxidation or alkylation of bases, in DNA. BER is initiated by lesion-specific DNA glycosylases that recognize and excise the damaged base, generating an abasic site. The abasic site is then cleaved by an AP endonuclease, and the resulting gap is filled by a DNA polymerase and sealed by a DNA ligase. BER is a multi-enzyme pathway, and in humans, there are at least three different DNA polymerases (pol beta, pol eta, and pol lambda) and at least two different DNA ligases (DNA ligase I and DNA ligase III) that participate in BER.

The Eph family of receptor tyrosine kinases and their membrane-bound ligands, the ephrins, are involved in a variety of developmental processes, including cell migration, axon guidance, and tissue boundary formation. Eph receptors are also involved in the regulation of cell adhesion and motility, and have been implicated in cancer progression. The ephrin ligands are also membrane bound, and interact with the extracellular matrix. The Eph-ephrin interaction is highly specific, and is dependent on the interaction of the extracellular domain of the Eph receptor with the extracellular domain of the ephrin ligand. The ephrins are also membrane bound, and interact with the extracellular matrix. The ephrins are divided into two groups, the A ephrins, which are tethered to the membrane by a glycosylphosphatidylinositol anchor, and the B ephrins, which are transmembrane proteins. The Eph receptors and ephrins are expressed in a variety of tissues, but are most highly expressed in the nervous system. The interaction of the Eph receptors and ephrins is bidirectional, with the Eph receptor signaling in both directions. The Eph receptors are tyrosine kinases, and their activation transduces a signal in both directions. In the forward direction, the Eph receptor phosphorylates its ligand, and the signal is transduced down the same pathway down the receptor. In the reverse direction, the phosphorylated Eph receptor also transduces a signal down the same pathway, by phosphorylating downstream targets. The Eph-ephrin interaction is highly specific, and is dependent on the interaction of the extracellular domain of the Eph receptor with the extracellular domain of the ephrin ligand. The Eph-ephrin interaction is also highly specific, and is dependent on the interaction of the extracellular domain of the Eph receptor with the extracellular domain of the ephrin ligand. The Eph-ephrin interaction is highly specific, and is dependent on the interaction of the extracellular domain of the Eph receptor with the extracellular domain of the ephrin ligand. The Eph-ephrin interaction is highly specific, and is dependent on the interaction of the extracellular domain of the Eph receptor with the extracellular domain of the ephrin ligand. The Eph-ephrin interaction is highly specific, and is dependent on the interaction of the extracellular domain of the Eph receptor with the extracellular domain of the ephrin ligand. The Eph-ephrin interaction is highly specific, and is dependent on the interaction of the extracellular domain of the Eph receptor with the extracellular domain of the ephrin ligand.

Coagulation factor V is a cofactor for the serine protease factor VIII. When activated by thrombin, factor V and factor VIII form a complex that activates factor X in the presence of calcium. The activation of factor X by the factor V-factor VIII complex is inhibited by antithrombin III, protein C, and protein S. The inhibition of the factor V-factor VIII complex by antithrombin III and protein C is enhanced by protein S. Protein C is activated by the thrombin-thrombomodulin complex. Activated protein C cleaves and inactivates factors Va and VIIIa. The inhibition of the factor V-factor VIII complex by protein C is enhanced by protein S. The inhibition of the factor V-factor VIII complex by antithrombin III is enhanced by heparin. The inhibition of the factor V-factor VIII complex by heparin is mediated by the high affinity binding of antithrombin III to the pentasaccharide sequence in heparin. The inhibition of factor X activation by the protein C system is also enhanced by the presence of thrombomodulin on the vascular endothelium. The inhibition of the factor V-factor VIII complex by the antithrombin III-heparin system is also enhanced by high molecular weight kininogen. The inhibition of the factor V-factor VIII complex by the protein C system is also enhanced by prekallikrein. The inhibition of the factor V-factor VIII complex by the antithrombin III-heparin system is also enhanced by high molecular weight kininogen. The inhibition of the factor V-factor VIII complex by the protein C system is also enhanced by the presence of activated platelets.

The release of the gonadotropins, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), is a key regulatory process in the endocrine system. The secretion of these hormones is stimulated by the hypothalamic decapeptide, gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). The secretion of the gonadotropins is pulsatile, with a pulse frequency that is dependent on the species and the physiological state of the animal. The frequency of the pulses is regulated by the level of GnRH in the portal circulation. The GnRH receptor is coupled to the Gq / 1 1 class of G proteins, which activate phospholipase C through the generation of the second messengers IP3 and DAG. IP3 binds to its receptor on the endoplasmic reticulum, releasing calcium from this organelle. The increase in intracellular calcium stimulates calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II (CaMKII), which in turn activates the voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs). The increase in intracellular calcium also activates calmodulin-dependent phosphodiesterase (PDE1), which hydrolyzes cAMP to 5 '-AMP. The increase in cAMP activates the cAMP-dependent protein kinase A (PKA), which activates the transcription of the glycoprotein hormone alpha-subunit (alphaSU) gene. The activation of the cAMP-dependent protein kinase A (PKA) also stimulates the expression of the LH beta-subunit gene. The activation of the extracellular signal-regulated kinase 1 / 2 (ERK1 / 2) pathway is also involved in the regulation of the alphaSU and LH beta-subunit genes.

The mu opioid receptor (MOP) is a member of the G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) gene family. It is activated by the endogenous opioid peptides enkephalins and endorphins, as well as the synthetic opiate drugs morphine and heroin. The endogenous ligands are cleaved from larger precursors and act at the receptor to produce their physiological effects. The receptor is expressed in the central nervous system and the periphery by neurons in the spinal cord and brain stem to produce analgesia and other physiological effects. The receptor is also found in many other tissues, including immune cells, where it may produce other physiological effects. The MOP receptor is a G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) that activates the Gi / o family of G proteins to produce its physiological effects. The receptor is phosphorylated by GPCR kinases (GRKs) in response to agonist binding, recruiting arrestins to the receptor to terminate further G protein activation. The receptor-arrestin complex internalizes, and the arrestin can interact with signaling molecules, including the MAP kinase pathways, to produce other receptor effects. The receptor can also desensitize without internalization, desensitize and internalize with different GRKs, and desensitize with different GRKs in different cell types. The receptor is also regulated by other GPCRs, including the delta opioid receptor (DOP), which can act as a phosphorylation-dependent and -independent regulator of the receptor. The receptor can also be regulated by other GPCRs, including the kappa opioid receptor (KOP), which can act as a phosphorylation-independent regulator of the receptor. The regulation of the MOP receptor by multiple factors produces the complex regulation of the receptor that produces the physiological effects of the endogenous ligands and the drugs that act at the receptor.

The calpain family of calcium-dependent intracellular cysteine proteases is comprised of two large subunits (8 0kDa and 2 8kDa) and two small subunits (30kDa and 18kDa). The large subunits contain the protease domain and the small subunits are involved in the regulation of the activity of the large subunits. Calpain is activated by calcium and inhibited by calpastatin. The large subunits of calpain are involved in a variety of cellular functions including cell motility, cell adhesion, signal transduction, cell cycle progression and apoptosis. Calpain is activated by the release of the 30kDa subunit from the large subunit. The release of the 30kDa subunit exposes the active site of the large subunit and allows autocatalysis to proceed. Calpain is inhibited by calpastatin, the endogenous inhibitor. The large subunits of calpain are encoded by nine different genes. The tissue distribution of the different calpains is regulated by the different large subunits. The small subunits are encoded by two genes, m- and micro-calpain. The expression of the two small subunits is regulated independently. The large subunit of mu-calpain is encoded by the CAPN1 gene and the large subunit of m-calpain is encoded by the CAPN2 gene. The expression of the small subunit is regulated independently for mu-calpain and m-calpain. The expression of the mu-calpain small subunit is regulated by the CAPN4 gene. The expression of the m-calpain small subunit is regulated by the CAPN2 gene. The expression of the two small subunits is regulated independently. The regulation of the expression of the different calpain large and small subunits is complex. The expression of the different large and small subunits is regulated by different promoters and enhancers. The expression of the large subunits is regulated by the same promoter and the same enhancer. The expression of the small subunits is regulated by different promoters and different enhancers. The expression of the large and small subunits is regulated differently during development. The expression of the large subunits is high in undifferentiated cells and decreases as cells differentiate. The expression of the small subunits is high in differentiated cells. The expression of the large subunits is regulated by the same promoter and enhancer as the expression of the small subunits. The expression of the small subunits is regulated differently during development. The expression of the mu-calpain small subunit is regulated by the CAPN4 gene. The expression of the micro-calpain small subunit is regulated by the CAPN2 gene.

Myocarditis is a disease of the heart muscle that results from various causes, including viral infection. Viral myocarditis is the most common cause of heart failure in young adults. Myocarditis can be caused by direct cytopathic effects of the virus, or by an autoimmune response to viral antigens. Viral myocarditis is associated with a high incidence of sudden death and heart failure. Myocarditis is characterized by myocardial inflammation and injury. Viral infection can result in direct cytopathic effects, such as necrosis and apoptosis, or indirect effects, such as the induction of an autoimmune response. Viral infection can also result in the activation of self-antigen-presenting cells, such as macrophages and dendritic cells, which leads to the activation of self-reactive T cells. Activated self-reactive T cells can cause direct myocardial injury or can be cytotoxic to cardiomyocytes through the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines. Viral infection can also result in the activation of self-antigen-presenting cells, such as macrophages and dendritic cells, which leads to the activation of self-reactive T cells. Activated self-reactive T cells can cause direct myocardial injury or can be cytotoxic to cardiomyocytes through the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines.

The hallmark of allergic disease is the infiltration of tissues by inflammatory cells, particularly eosinophils, activated Th2 cells and mast cells. The hallmark of allergic inflammation is the presence of Th2 cells, which produce IL-4, IL-5 and IL-9. IL-5 and IL-9 are key cytokines that stimulate the growth and differentiation of eosinophils. Mast cells are central to the allergic response, secreting a variety of inflammatory mediators, including histamine, leukotrienes, and prostaglandins. The activation of mast cells also leads to the release of cytokines, chemokines, and lipid mediators. The activation of eosinophils leads to the release of toxic granules, causing tissue damage and obstruction of the airway. The activation of eosinophils also leads to the release of cytokines and chemokines, stimulating the activation of other inflammatory cells.

The renin-angiotensin system (RAS) is a key regulator of blood pressure and volume homeostasis. Angiotensis II (Ang II), the active component of the RAS, is formed from the precursor angiotensinogen by the actions of renin and ACE. Ang II is a potent vasoconstrictor and a key regulator of blood pressure. The RAS is present in the heart and vasculature and is upregulated in heart failure. The cardiac RAS is activated in heart failure and may contribute to the progression of heart failure. Ang II increases collagen synthesis and deposition in the heart and may contribute to cardiac fibrosis and diastolic dysfunction. ACE inhibitors block the formation of Ang II and block the actions of Ang II. ACE inhibitors are an important treatment for heart failure and have been shown to reduce morbidity and mortality in heart failure patients. The cardioprotective effects of ACE inhibitors may be due in part to their effects on the cardiac RAS.

Cell adhesion to the extracellular matrix (ECM) through integrins activates intracellular signaling pathways that regulate cell survival, proliferation, and motility. The integrin cytoplasmic domain binds to the cytoskeleton and to a number of signaling molecules, including the focal adhesion kinase (FAK), paxillin, and Src. FAK is a key component of integrin signaling and is activated by phosphorylation on tyrosine residues in response to integrin engagement. FAK activation leads to the phosphorylation and activation of Src, which phosphorylates additional targets, including other components of focal adhesions. Paxillin is a target of FAK and Src and is involved in the regulation of cell motility. The adaptor protein Crk is recruited to FAK and paxillin and is phosphorylated by FAK and Src. Crk can associate with the guanine nucleotide exchange factor DOCK1 8 0, which activates Rac, a small G protein that regulates the formation of lamellipodia and other actin-based structures. Paxillin also binds to the CrkL adaptor protein, which can activate the Ras pathway. Paxillin phosphorylation also leads to the recruitment of Csk, a kinase that phosphorylates Src and other substrates, to the complex. The phosphorylation of FAK, paxillin, and other targets by integrin signaling pathways may regulate cell survival, proliferation, and motility.

DNA mismatch repair (MMR) is a highly conserved DNA repair mechanism that removes base-base mismatches and insertion-deletion loops (IDLs) generated during DNA replication. MMR corrects DNA mismatches generated during DNA replication, thereby preventing mutations from being passed on to the next generation. Defects in MMR are associated with cancer in humans. The MMR pathway is composed of at least seven MMR proteins (MLH1, MSH2, MSH3, MSH6, PMS1, and PMS2) in humans. MutS heterodimers (MSH2-MSH6 and MSH2-MSH3) specifically bind to mismatches and recruit MutL heterodimers (MLH1-PMS2 and MLH1-PMS1) to the mismatch site. The exonuclease 1 (EXO1) is then recruited to the mismatch site by the MutS / MutL complex, excising the newly synthesized DNA strand containing the mismatch. The nicked strand is then resynthesized by DNA polymerases and ligases.

Apoptosis is a genetically programmed cell death pathway that is important for the removal of unwanted cells. Caspases are a family of cysteine proteases that play a central role in apoptosis. Caspases are initially expressed as proenzymes that are activated by proteolytic cleavage. Caspases are classified into two groups: the initiator caspases (caspase-8, -9, and -1 0) that are activated by a diverse array of apoptotic signals, and the effector caspases (caspase-3, -6, and -7) that are directly activated by the initiator caspases. Apoptotic signaling pathways can be triggered by either the death receptor pathway or the mitochondrial pathway. In the death receptor pathway, binding of ligands to death receptors such as Fas leads to the recruitment of initiator caspases such as caspase-8. Caspase-8 is activated through oligomerization and subsequent auto-cleavage. Activated caspase-8 cleaves and activates caspase-3, -6, and-7, which in turn cleave cellular substrates, leading to cell death. In the mitochondrial pathway, apoptotic signals such as DNA damage activate the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria. Cytochrome c activates caspase-9, which in turn activates caspase-3, -6, and-7. Caspase-3 and-7 cleave cellular substrates, leading to cell death. Caspase-8 and -9 are activated by the initiator caspase-2 and caspase-1 0, respectively. Caspase-8 and -9 activate caspase-3 through cleavage of Bid. The cleavage of DFFA-4 by caspase-3 removes its inhibitory effect on DFFA-6 / caspase-ase5, leading to activation of DFFA-6 / caspase-ase6 and-7. The cleavage of nuclear lamins by caspase-3 causes nuclear condensation, while the cleavage of DNA fragmentation factor (DFFA) by caspase-3 and-7 causes DNA fragmentation.

The receptor tyrosine kinase KIT is activated by its ligand SCF (also known as steel factor) and plays a key role in the development of hematopoietic cells, germ cells and melanocytes. The importance of KIT in hematopoiesis has been demonstrated by the phenotype of mice lacking KIT (W / W mice) and by the effect of KIT antagonists on normal hematopoiesis. Mice lacking KIT (W / W) are sterile and have few or no germ cells. W / W mice also have a marked reduction in the number of hematopoietic cells, with the most dramatic reduction in the hematopoietic stem cells. The number of hematopoietic stem cells in W / W mice is reduced by more than 1 0 0-fold. The defect in the hematopoietic stem cells in W / W mice can be corrected by transplantation of bone marrow cells from normal mice. The hematopoietic defect in W / W mice can be partially corrected by administration of SCF. The effect of SCF on hematopoiesis is likely mediated through its receptor KIT. Mice lacking KIT (W / W) die at an early stage of development. The defect in the development of melanocytes and germ cells in W / W mice is also reversed by the transplantation of normal bone marrow cells. The effect of KIT on hematopoiesis is mediated through its downstream signaling pathways. The tyrosine kinase activity of KIT is essential for its signaling function. The activation of KIT leads to the phosphorylation of several tyrosine residues in the cytoplasmic domain of KIT. These phosphorylated tyrosines serve as docking sites for signaling molecules containing src homology 2 (SH2) or phosphotyrosine binding (PTB) domains. The adaptor protein Shc binds to phosphorylated tyrosine (Y) 7 1 9 of KIT and recruits Grb2 / Sos-1 complex to activate Ras / MAPK pathway. The binding of PI3 kinase to phosphorylated tyrosine (Y) 5 6 7 of KIT leads to the activation of PI3 kinase / AKT pathway. The adaptor protein APS binds to phosphorylated tyrosine (Y) 7 0 3 of KIT and may also recruit PI3 kinase to activate AKT pathway. The phosphorylation of tyrosine (Y) 9 3 6 of KIT recruits the protein tyrosine phosphatase Shp2 to activate ras / MAPK pathway. The activation of PI3 kinase / AKT pathway may also contribute to the activation of transcription factors such as CREB and STAT5 by KIT. The activation of STAT5 by KIT may contribute to the survival of hematopoietic cells.

Cell-matrix interactions are critical for cell migration and tissue morphogenesis. Cells at the leading edge of a migrating cell migrate by extending their leading edge in the form of lamellipodia and filopodia. The formation of these structures is dependent on the interaction of cells with the extracellular matrix (ECM) through integrins. The ECM is a complex mixture of macromolecules, including collagen, laminin, and fibronectin, that provides structural support and signals to cells. Integrins are a family of cell surface receptors that mediate cell-ECM interactions. The interaction of cells with the ECM initiates a signaling cascade that results in cytoskeletal reorganization and the formation of lamellipodia and filopodia. The interaction of cells with the ECM also results in the formation of focal adhesions, which are points of cell-ECM contact that contain integrins, cytoskeletal proteins, and signaling molecules. The interaction of cells with the ECM also results in the activation of the ras family of small GTPases, including ras, rac, and rho, which regulate cytoskeletal reorganization and cell migration. The interaction of cells with the ECM also activates the calcium-dependent protease calpain, which cleaves cytoskeletal and signaling proteins to regulate cell migration. Calpain is a calcium-dependent protease that is involved in cytoskeletal reorganization and cell migration. Calpain is a heterodimer, consisting of a large catalytic subunit (8 0kDa) and a small regulatory subunit (3 0kDa). Calpain is involved in the formation of lamellipodia and filopodia, and in the formation of focal adhesions. Calpain cleaves spectrin, which is a component of the cytoskeleton, and talin, which is involved in focal adhesion formation. The interaction of cells with the ECM also activates the small GTPase rho, which regulates the formation of lamellipodia and filopodia. Calpain is also involved in the activation of the ras family of small GTPases, including ras, rac, and rho. Calpain cleaves the GDP-bound inactive form of rho to the GTP-bound active form. Calpain also cleaves and activates raf, a component of the ras signaling pathway. The interaction of cells with the ECM also activates the calcium-dependent protease calpain. The interaction of cells with the ECM results in the release of calcium from intracellular stores. The release of calcium activates calpain, which cleaves cytoskeletal and signaling proteins to regulate cell migration.

The innate immune system is the first line of defense against invading pathogens. The innate immune system is comprised of several cell types including macrophages, neutrophils, and natural killer (NK) cells. Macrophages and neutrophils respond to microbial infection by producing inflammatory cytokines such as TNF-alpha, IL-1, IL-6, and IL-8. Macrophages and neutrophils also phagocytose and kill invading microbes. Natural killer (NK) cells are lymphocytes that provide a first line of defense against viral infection and cancer. NK cells are also involved in the inflammatory response. NK cells are activated by IL-2 and IL-1 2 to produce IFN-gamma, a cytokine that activates macrophages and stimulates their cytotoxic activity. NK cells also produce TNF-alpha and other cytokines that stimulate the inflammatory response. The innate immune response is initiated by the recognition of pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) by pattern recognition receptors (PRRs). PAMPs are conserved molecular motifs unique to microorganisms. Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are a class of PRRs that recognize PAMPs. TLR2 is activated by bacterial lipoproteins, TLR4 is activated by bacterial lipopolysaccharide (LPS), and TLR9 is activated by bacterial DNA. The innate immune response is also stimulated by endogenous molecules released during tissue injury and inflammation, known as damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs). DAMPs include heat shock proteins, extracellular matrix components, and high-mobility group box 1 protein (HMGB1). The signaling pathways activated by PAMPs and DAMPs are similar to those activated by cytokines. Activation of TLRs leads to the recruitment of the adaptor proteins MyD8 8 and TRIF, which activate the transcription factors NF-kB and AP-1. NF-kB and AP-1 induce the expression of inflammatory cytokines and chemokines. Activation of the interferon response by TLR9 also involves the adaptor protein MyD8 8. Secreted cytokines and chemokines activate macrophages and other immune cells to amplify the innate immune response. DAMPs also activate the endothelium to induce the expression of adhesion molecules that promote the recruitment of immune cells to the site of inflammation. The innate immune response is essential for the subsequent development of an effective adaptive immune response. The inflammatory cytokines produced by innate immune cells activate B cells and T cells to produce antigen-specific antibodies and cytotoxic T cells, respectively. The activation of the adaptive immune response is essential for the clearance of microbial infection and the prevention of autoimmune disease.

The inflammatory response is a complex process involving the interaction of many different cell types. Macrophages are one of the cell types involved in the inflammatory response and are activated by a variety of signals, including bacterial products such as LPS. LPS activates macrophages through the Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4). The activation of macrophages by LPS leads to the production of cytokines such as TNF-alpha, IL-1 and IL-6 that stimulate the immune system and lead to the fever associated with infection. The activation of macrophages by LPS also leads to the production of nitric oxide, a reactive molecule that can be toxic to cells. The production of these inflammatory cytokines and nitric oxide by macrophages is regulated by the transcription factor NF-kB. In unstimulated cells NF-kB is bound to the inhibitor IkB in the cytoplasm. LPS activates the kinase NIK (NF-kB inducing kinase) that phosphorylates IkB leading to the degradation of IkB and the translocation of NF-kB to the nucleus. NF-kB activates the transcription of many genes involved in the inflammatory response including IL-1, IL-6 and TNF-alpha. The activation of NF-kB by NIK also leads to the activation of the kinase MEKK1, which phosphorylates and activates the kinase MKK3. MKK3 in turn activates the kinase p38, also involved in the inflammatory response. The activation of p38 by NIK and MEKK1 leads to the activation of the kinase p65 and the transcription factor ATF2. ATF2 activates the transcription of the gene for interferon-beta, a cytokine that activates the immune response. The activation of NF-kB and the production of cytokines and nitric oxide by macrophages are important steps in the inflammatory response. The activation of NF-kB and the production of cytokines and nitric oxide by macrophages are important steps in the inflammatory response. The activation of NF-kB and the production of cytokines and nitric oxide by macrophages are important steps in the inflammatory response. The activation of NF-kB and the production of cytokines and nitric oxide by macrophages are important steps in the inflammatory response. The activation of NF-kB and the production of cytokines and nitric oxide by macrophages are important steps in the inflammatory response. The activation of NF-kB and the production of cytokines and nitric oxide by macrophages are important steps in the inflammatory response. The activation of NF-kB and the production of cytokines and nitric oxide by macrophages are also important steps in the activation of the immune system. The activation of NF-kB and the production of cytokines and nitric oxide by macrophages are also important steps in the activation of the immune system. The activation of NF-kB and the production of cytokines and nitric oxide by macrophages are important steps in the inflammatory response. The activation of NF-kB and the production of cytokines and nitric oxide by macrophages are also important steps in the activation of the immune system. The activation of NF-kB and the production of cytokines and nitric oxide by macrophages are also important steps in the development of septic shock and septic shock. The activation of NF-kB and the production of cytokines and nitric oxide by macrophages are also important steps in the development of rheumatoid arthritis. The activation of NF-kB and the production of cytokines and nitric oxide by macrophages are also important steps in the development of atherosclerosis. The activation of NF-kB and the production of cytokines and nitric oxide by macrophages are also important steps in the development of osteoporosis.

The Fas receptor is a member of the tumor necrosis factor receptor gene family and transduces apoptotic signals in response to binding its ligand, Fas ligand (FasL). Fas-mediated apoptosis is important in the regulation of immune responses and may also play a role in the pathogenesis of autoimmune disease and cancer. Fas-mediated apoptosis is initiated by the binding of FasL to Fas, which initiates a signaling cascade that ultimately results in the activation of caspases and the apoptotic cell death. The Fas-mediated apoptotic signaling pathway is complex and involves multiple proteins. The Fas receptor contains an intracellular death domain that is required for signaling. The adaptor protein FADD binds to the Fas death domain and recruits caspase-8 to the receptor complex. Caspase-8 is then activated by dimerization and autocatalysis and in turn activates downstream caspases such as caspase-3. Caspase-3 activation leads to the cleavage of cellular substrates and the morphological and biochemical changes associated with apoptosis. The Fas-FADD-caspase-8 signaling pathway is negatively regulated by the cellular FLICE-inhibitory protein (c-FLIP). The expression of c-FLIP is regulated by the MAPK pathway and the level of c-FLIP determines the sensitivity of cells to Fas-mediated apoptosis. The Fas-mediated apoptotic pathway is also regulated by the Bcl-2 family of proteins. Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL are anti-apoptotic proteins that block Fas-mediated apoptosis by inhibiting the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria. The Bcl-2 family of proteins regulate apoptosis by controlling the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria. Bid is a Bcl-2 family protein that is activated by Fas and induces cytochrome c release. Activated Bid interacts with Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL to prevent them from blocking cytochrome c release. Cytochrome c release activates caspase-9, which in turn activates caspase-3.

Angiotensin II (Ang II) is a potent vasoconstrictor peptide that also has a growth promoting effect on vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMC). Ang II exerts its effects through two G-protein coupled receptors, the AT and AT receptors. The AT receptor mediates the majority of the known actions of Ang II, including vasoconstriction and proliferation of VSMC. The AT receptor is a vasodilator and growth inhibitor. The AT receptor is coupled to the G-protein, Gq, which activates phospholipase C, generating the second messengers inositol triphosphate and diacylglycerol. These second messengers trigger the release of intracellular calcium and activation of protein kinase C, respectively. In addition to the activation of protein kinase C, the activation of phospholipase C also stimulates the ras-dependent pathway through the activation of son-ras. The activation of ras-dependent pathway leads to the activation of the mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPK), including extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK), Jun amino-terminal kinase (JNK) and p3 8 MAPK. Ang II also activates other signaling pathways, including the JAK / STAT pathway, the phosphoinositol-3 kinase (PI3K) pathway and the Rho-dependent pathway. These pathways may also contribute to the growth promoting effect of Ang II.

Bladder cancer is the fourth most common cancer in the United States, with an estimated 7 5, 0 0 0 new cases diagnosed each year. The majority of bladder cancers are non-muscle invasive at presentation, but can progress to muscle-invasive disease, which is associated with a 5 0% mortality rate. The progression of non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer to muscle-invasive disease is associated with the activation of the Ras pathway, and the subsequent activation of the transcription factor E2F. The activation of Ras and E2F leads to the activation of genes involved in cell cycle progression and cell motility, and the inactivation of genes involved in apoptosis. The activation of Ras and E2F also leads to the loss of cell-cell adhesion, which may allow for the invasion of the basement membrane and stroma.

The T cell receptor (TCR) complex is responsible for the recognition of specific antigen in the context of MHC-II molecules by T cells. The TCR is a multisubunit complex consisting of the clonotypic TCRalphabeta heterodimer and three invariant chains (CD3-gamma, -delta, and -epsilon). The CD3 chains are responsible for the assembly, transport, and signaling of the TCR. The TCR is associated with the tyrosine kinases Lck and Fyn, which phosphorylate the immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motifs (ITAMs) in the CD3 chains, initiating a signaling cascade that leads to T cell activation. The CD4 and CD28 accessory molecules are involved in the regulation of T cell activation. The binding of the T cell receptor to MHC-II / peptide complex induces the activation of Lck, which phosphorylates Lck-Y5 0 5, leading to its inactivation and dissociation from the receptor. Lck is also involved in the activation of Fyn, which phosphorylates the CD3 chains and other substrates. The binding of Lck to CD4 or CD28 may increase Lck activity by increasing Lck concentration at the membrane, by increasing Lck phosphorylation of Lck-Y5 0 5, or by increasing Lck autophosphorylation.

The nuclear factor-kB (NF-kB) transcription factor regulates the expression of genes involved in inflammation, cell survival, and apoptosis. In the absence of inflammatory signals, NF-kB is retained in the cytoplasm by association with the inhibitor IkBa. Activation of NF-kB occurs through the IkB kinase (IKK) complex, which phosphorylates IkBa, targeting it for degradation by the proteasome. IkBa is a member of a family of inhibitors that includes IkBa, IkBb, and IkBg. The IKK complex is a multimeric protein kinase that includes IKKa, IKKb, and IKKg. The activation of NF-kB by inflammatory stimuli such as TNF and IL-1 is mediated through the MAP kinase pathway, which includes the kinases TAK1 and NIK, and the kinases MEKK1, MEKK3, and MEKK4. Once activated, NF-kB translocates to the nucleus and activates the transcription of a number of genes involved in inflammation, cell survival, and apoptosis.

Growth hormone (GH) is a peptide hormone secreted by the anterior pituitary gland that regulates growth and metabolism. The GH receptor is a member of the cytokine receptor gene family and signals through the JAK / STAT pathway. The JAK / STAT pathway is used by many cytokines to transmit their signals, including GH. The JAK kinases are associated with the cytoplasmic domain of the cytokine receptor and are activated by ligand binding to the receptor. The JAKs phosphorylate the receptor, creating binding sites for STAT transcription factors. The STATs are recruited to the phosphorylated receptor and are phosphorylated by the JAKs. The STATs then dimerize and translocate to the nucleus to regulate gene expression. The JAKs also activate the Ras / Map kinase pathway, leading to activation of the transcription factor, AP-1.

Inflammasome is a large protein complex that mediates innate immune response by activating caspase-1 and inducing the maturation of proinflammatory cytokines such as IL-1beta and IL-18. The inflammasome is formed by a sensor protein, an adaptor protein, and pro-caspase-1. The sensor protein includes NALP1, NALP3, Ipaf, and others. The sensor protein recognizes a specific molecule and triggers the assembly of the inflammasome. The assembly leads to the proximity-induced activation of caspase-1. Caspase-1 processes pro-IL-1beta and pro-IL-18 into their mature forms, which are secreted out of the cell. The NALP1 inflammasome is activated by the presence of extracellular ATP and intracellular muramyl dipeptide. The NALP3 inflammasome is activated by extracellular lipopolysaccharide and intracellular uric acid.

Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is a clonal disorder of pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells that progresses through distinct molecular and cytogenetic stages. The initial chronic phase (CP) is characterized by the presence of a Philadelphia (Ph) chromosome, which encodes the BCR-ABL fusion protein. Progression to the accelerated phase (AP) and blast crisis (BC) is associated with additional genetic abnormalities. The most common of these are mutations in the tumor suppressor gene p15. or in b2l. The development of imatinib mesylate (Gleevec), a selective inhibitor of BCR-ABL, has dramatically improved the treatment of CML. Imatinib is highly effective in patients with chronic-phase CML, but is less effective in patients with accelerated-phase or blast-phase CML. The development of resistance to imatinib has become a major clinical problem. Resistance can be caused by mutations in the BCR-ABL kinase domain that interfere with drug binding, or by increased expression of the drug efflux protein, P-glycoprotein.

The insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) receptor is a tyrosine kinase that is expressed in many cell types and is involved in the regulation of growth and differentiation. IGF-1 also stimulates proliferation of neuronal cells and protects neurons from apoptosis. In addition, IGF-1 has been shown to stimulate neurite outgrowth and regeneration. The downstream signaling pathways activated by the IGF-1 receptor are similar to those activated by the insulin receptor. The IGF-1 receptor is associated with the tyrosine phosphatase SHP-2 and activates the ras / raf / mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway. The src family of tyrosine kinases and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase are also involved in the activation of this pathway. The calcium / calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II pathway is also involved in the activation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway by IGF-1. The calcineurin / NFAT pathway is also activated by IGF-1. The calcineurin / NFAT pathway is involved in the regulation of the immune system and is also involved in neuronal differentiation. Calcineurin dephosphorylates NFAT, which then translocates to the nucleus and activates transcription. IGF-1 activates NFAT through the src family of tyrosine kinases and PI3 kinase. The calcineurin / NFAT pathway is also activated by depolarization of neurons through calcium influx through voltage-sensitive calcium channels. The calcineurin / NFAT pathway may play a role in the neuroprotective effects of IGF-1.

The BCR gene is involved in the Philadelphia chromosome translocation, which is associated with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). The translocation fuses the BCR gene with the ABL gene, creating a fusion gene that codes for a constitutively active abl tyrosine kinase. The BCR-abl protein transforms cells by activating multiple signaling pathways, including the Ras, JAK / Stat, and PI3K pathways. The JAK / Stat pathway is activated by BCR-abl through phosphorylation of the JAK kinases, which in turn phosphorylate and activate the Stat transcription factors. The PI3K pathway is also activated by BCR-abl, through phosphorylation of the adaptor protein GAB1. The activation of these pathways contributes to the transforming activity of BCR-abl. The Myc and Fos transcription factors are also activated by BCR-abl, contributing to the transforming activity of the fusion protein.

The immune system is comprised of many different cell types that communicate with each other through cell-cell signaling molecules called cytokines. One of the ways in which the immune system responds to infection is by activating macrophages and other cells to kill the infecting pathogen. The macrophage is activated by cytokines produced by the T helper cells that it interacts with. One of the cytokines that activates macrophages is IL-12. IL-12 is produced by T helper cells that have been activated by an antigen-presenting cell (APC). IL-12 activates macrophages by inducing them to express the cell-surface protein Fas (also called Apo1). Fas is a protein on the surface of the macrophage that induces the macrophage to kill other cells when it binds to Fas ligand on another cell. The interaction of Fas and Fas ligand induces apoptosis in the Fas-positive cell. The interaction of IL-12 with its receptor on the macrophage also activates the macrophage. The IL-12 receptor is a heterodimer of two proteins, IL-12Ralpha and CD28. The CD28 protein is a co-activator of the IL-12 receptor. The interaction of an APC with a T cell activates the T cell to produce IL-12. IL-12 activates the macrophage by inducing the expression of Fas on the macrophage. IL-12 also activates T cells by inducing the expression of the IL-2receptor. The T cell that produces IL-12 also produces IL-2. IL-2 activates T cells by inducing the expression of the IL-2receptor. The interaction of an APC with a T cell activates the T cell to produce IL-12. The T cell that produces IL-12 also produces IL-2. IL-12 and IL-2 activate macrophages by inducing the expression of Fas on the macrophage. The activation of macrophages by IL-12 and IL-2 is an example of a positive feedback loop in which the macrophage activates the T cell that produces IL-12, and the T cell that produces IL-12 activates the macrophage. The activation of macrophages by IL-12 and IL-2 is part of a feedback loop that maintains the immune response.

Skeletal muscle differentiation is a highly coordinated process involving the withdrawal of undifferentiated myoblasts from the cell cycle and the expression of muscle-specific genes. The myogenic regulatory factors (MRFs), MyoD, Myf5, myogenin and MRF4, are master regulators of myogenesis. These factors activate muscle-specific genes and repress the expression of genes associated with the cell cycle. The activity of the MRFs is regulated by a variety of signaling pathways, including the IGF-1 / PI3K / AKT pathway, which promotes differentiation. The activity of the MRFs is also regulated by the activity of histone deacetylases (HDACs). Phosphorylation of the MRFs by the cyclin-dependent kinase cdk2 / cyclinA or by the MAP kinase pathway inhibits their activity, while the activity of HDACs is inhibited by their association with the transcriptional coactivator CBP. The balance between the activities of the MRFs and HDACs is regulated by the extracellular environment. The IGF-1 / PI3K / AKT pathway promotes differentiation by inhibiting cdk2 and inducing the expression of the MRFs. The activity of the MRFs is also regulated by the interaction with other transcription factors. The transcriptional coactivator PGC-1 alpha interacts with the MRFs and promotes their activity. The interaction of PGC-1 alpha with the MRFs is inhibited by the interaction with the transcriptional corepressor HDAC5. The interaction of HDAC5 with the MRFs is inhibited by the activity of the CaMK pathway.

The cell cycle is a tightly regulated sequence of events that leads to the replication of genetic material and the division of cells. The G1 to S phase transition is a key regulatory point in the cell cycle. The G1 to S phase transition is regulated by the cyclin-dependent kinases (cdks). The activity of cdks is regulated by association with cyclins and phosphorylation by the cyclin-dependent kinases-kinases-4 and -6 (cdk4 and cdk6). The cdk-cyclin complexes phosphorylate the retinoblastoma protein (Rb), releasing the transcription factor E2F-1. The transcription of genes required for DNA replication and other S phase related events are activated by E2F-1. The activity of cdk4 and cdk6 is inhibited by the INK4 family of proteins (p1 6, p1 5, p1 8 and p19). The INK4 proteins are expressed in a cell cycle dependent manner, with the expression of p16 increasing as the cells progress from G1 to S phase. The activity of the p16 protein is inhibited by the binding of the INK4 proteins to D-type cyclins. The INK4 proteins are also regulated by phosphorylation by the p21-activated kinase (p21-AK). The phosphorylation of the INK4 proteins by p21-AK inhibits their inhibitory activity and allows the formation of active cdk4 and cdk6-cyclin D complexes. The activity of p21-AK is regulated by the p90RSK kinase. The activity of p90RSK is regulated by the p38 stress activated protein kinase. The activity of p38 is also regulated by the p21-activated kinase (p38-ask). The activity of the p38-ask is inhibited by the p21-activated phosphatase (p21-AP). The activity of the p21-AP is also regulated by the p21-activated kinase (p21-AK). The p21-AK is also regulated by the p90RSK kinase. The activity of the p21-AP is inhibited by the p21-activated phosphatase (p21-AP). The activity of the p21-AP is also inhibited by the p21-activated kinase (p21-AK). The activity of the p21-AK is inhibited by the p21-activated phosphatase (p21-AP). The activity of the p21-AP is also inhibited by the p21-activated kinase (p21-AK). The activity of the p21-AK is also inhibited by the p21-activated phosphatase (p21-AP). The activity of the p21-AP is also inhibited by the p21-activated phosphatase (p21-AP).

Insulin stimulates glucose uptake into muscle and adipose tissue by translocation of the GLUT4 glucose transporter from an intracellular pool to the plasma membrane. This process is initiated by binding of insulin to its receptor, which activates the insulin receptor tyrosine kinase. The activated receptor phosphorylates IRS-1 and IRS-2, which bind to the regulatory subunit of PI 3-kinase. PI 3-kinase activation leads to the activation of the protein kinase AKT and the small G protein RAC. Both AKT and RAC stimulate GLUT4 translocation. The transcription factor ELK-1 is also activated by AKT, and activates the GLUT4 promoter. The transcription factor AP-1 is also activated by insulin, and may contribute to GLUT4 gene transcription. The transcription factor SRF is also activated by insulin, but its role in GLUT4 gene transcription is not known.

The extrinsic apoptotic pathway is triggered by the binding of death receptors of the TNF receptor superfamily, including Fas, TNF-R1 and TNF-related apoptosis-inducing ligand (TRAIL) -R1, to their respective ligands. The binding of these receptors by their respective ligands results in the recruitment of the adaptor protein Fas-associated via death domain (FADD) and the subsequent recruitment and activation of caspase-8. Caspase-8 activation results in the cleavage of downstream caspases and the execution of apoptosis. This pathway is negatively regulated by cellular FLICE-inhibitory protein (c-FLIP).

Apoptosis is a genetically programmed cell death that plays an important role in development, tissue homeostasis, and the removal of virus-infected or mutated cells. Caspases are a class of cysteine proteases that play a central role in apoptosis. Caspases are synthesized as inactive precursors that are activated by proteolytic cleavage. Caspases exist as a family of related proteases, and each member of the caspase family has a distinct role in apoptosis. Caspases-1, -4, -5, and -1 2 are involved in the initiation phase of apoptosis, and are activated by a cascade of proteolytic cleavage. Caspases-2, -3, -6, and-7 are involved in the execution phase of apoptosis, and are activated by a different proteolytic cascade. Caspase-8 and-9 are involved in the extrinsic and intrinsic pathways of apoptosis, respectively. Caspase-3, -6, and-7 are the effector caspases that cleave a variety of cellular targets to cause the morphological changes associated with apoptosis. Caspases are also involved in other cellular processes such as inflammation. Caspases are activated by two main mechanisms. The first is the extrinsic pathway, in which caspases are activated by extracellular death receptors. The second is the intrinsic pathway, in which caspases are activated by mitochondria.
