The p34 kinase is activated by the small G protein ras, acting through Map kinase kinase 1 and 2 and map kinase kinase 3. The p34 kinase is also activated by p53, acting through Map kinase kinase 6. The p34 kinase is involved in the regulation of a number of cellular processes, including cell cycle progression, differentiation, and apoptosis. The p34 kinase is also involved in the regulation of a number of cellular processes, including cell cycle progression, differentiation, and apoptosis. The p34 kinase is activated by cellular stress, acting through Map kinase kinase 3. The p34 kinase is also activated by cytokines, acting through Map kinase kinase 4.

The kappa-opioid receptor is a member of the G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) gene family. The kappa-opioid receptor is activated by the endogenous opioid peptide, dynorphin, and by the synthetic opioid drug, morphine. The kappa-opioid receptor is widely expressed in the central nervous system and is involved in the regulation of pain, anxiety, and drug reward. The activation of the kappa-opioid receptor leads to the inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and the subsequent reduction of intracellular cAMP levels. The inhibition of adenylyl cyclase by the kappa-opioid receptor is mediated by the pertussis toxin-sensitive G-protein, Gi. The inhibition of adenylyl cyclase by the kappa-opioid receptor leads to the inhibition of the cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA) and the subsequent inhibition of the CREB-mediated gene transcription. The inhibition of CREB-mediated gene transcription by the kappa-opioid receptor may also involve the regulation of the phosphorylation of CREB by the PKA-dependent activation of the calcium-calmodulin-dependent protein kinase IV (CaMKIV). The inhibition of CREB-mediated gene transcription by the kappa-opioid receptor may also involve the regulation of the phosphorylation of CREB by the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway. The activation of the kappa-opioid receptor also leads to the activation of the MAPK pathway. The activation of the MAPK pathway by the kappa-opioid receptor involves the transactivation of the EGF receptor by the G-protein coupled receptor kinase 2 (GRK 2). The activation of the MAPK pathway by the kappa-opioid receptor leads to the phosphorylation and activation of the transcription factor Elk-1. The activation of Elk-1 by the kappa-opioid receptor may involve the regulation of the phosphorylation of CREB by the MAPK pathway.

Wnt signaling is an evolutionarily conserved pathway that plays a key role in development and tissue homeostasis. Wnt ligands are secreted glycoproteins that bind to Frizzled family receptors and activate several different signaling cascades. One of the best characterized Wnt pathways is the canonical Wnt pathway, in which the transcriptional co-activator beta-catenin is stabilized and enters the nucleus to activate transcription. In the absence of Wnt signaling, beta-catenin is phosphorylated by the kinase complex containing glycogen synthase kinase 3 (GSK-3), axin, and the tumor suppressor adenomatous polyposis coli (APC), and is targeted for degradation by the proteosome. In the nucleus, beta-catenin interacts with the TCF / LEF family of transcription factors to activate transcription of Wnt target genes. Wnt signaling is regulated by several secreted Wnt antagonists including secreted Frizzled-related proteins (sFRPs), Wnt inhibitory factor (WIF), Cerberus, and Dickkopf (DKK). Wnt signaling is also regulated by several intracellular components, including the APC family of proteins, beta-catenin, and axin. Mutations in components of the Wnt pathway are associated with several types of cancer.

The ubiquitin-proteasome pathway plays a key role in the degradation of most cellular proteins. Proteins are targeted for degradation by the proteasome through the covalent attachment of a chain of ubiquitin molecules. The proteasome is a large protein complex that degrades proteins linked by ubiquitin in a highly conserved pathway. The proteasome is found in the nucleus and cytoplasm and is composed of two multi-subunit complexes, a 20S core particle and a 19S regulatory particle. The 20S core particle is a barrel-shaped structure with a central proteolytic core. The core particle contains three proteolytic activities, one chymotrypsin-like, one trypsin-like and one peptidylglutamyl peptide-hydrolyzing activity. The 19S regulatory particle is a complex that binds to the 20S core particle and is required for the degradation of ubiquitin-protein conjugates by the proteasome. The 19S regulatory particle is composed of at least 1 3 different subunits and is required for the binding and unfolding of proteins prior to their entry into the 20S core particle. The addition of a 19S regulatory particle to the 20S core particle increases the proteolytic activity of the proteasome and allows for the degradation of proteins that are not efficiently degraded by the core particle alone. The 20S core particle is able to degrade intact proteins, proteins that are first modified by multiple ubiquitin molecules, and proteins that are first modified by a single ubiquitin. The 19S regulatory particle is required for the binding and unfolding of proteins prior to their entry into the 20S core particle. The 19S regulatory particle is also required for the degradation of ubiquitin-protein conjugates.

The ATM gene product is mutated in the cancer-prone disorder ataxia telangiectasia. ATM is a protein kinase that is activated by DNA damage and phosphorylates many targets, including the tumor suppressor protein p5 3. One of the targets of ATM is the Cdc2 5 phosphatase, which activates the cyclin-dependent kinases that drive the cell cycle from G1 to S phase. Phosphorylation of Cdc2 5 by ATM leads to its degradation, preventing the activation of the cyclin-dependent kinases and stopping the cell cycle. Another ATM substrate is the tumor suppressor protein p53, which is also involved in cell cycle control. When activated by DNA damage, p53 causes cells to arrest in G1 and G2, allowing time for DNA repair to occur. The importance of p53 in maintaining genomic integrity is demonstrated by the fact that it is mutated in a large fraction of tumors.

The cAMP-dependent protein kinase A (PKA) is a key regulator of cellular functions. The PKA holoenzyme is a tetramer consisting of two regulatory subunits and two catalytic subunits. The regulatory subunits are bound by cAMP and the catalytic subunits are released to phosphorylate downstream targets. The PKA is targeted to specific subcellular locations through association with A-kinase anchoring proteins (AKAPs). AKAPs are a family of structurally diverse proteins that bind to the regulatory subunit of PKA and target the PKA holoenzyme to specific subcellular locations. AKAPs are involved in a variety of cellular functions including regulation of ion channels, cell shape and motility, and regulation of gene expression. The PKA is anchored to the outer mitochondrial membrane by the AKAP AKAP1 8delta. The PKA anchored at the outer mitochondrial membrane phosphorylates the mitochondrial protein p21. The phosphorylation of p21 regulates the release of cytochrome c and the induction of apoptosis.

The ets family of transcription factors is characterized by the presence of a highly conserved DNA binding domain, the ETS domain. The ets family includes more than a hundred members in vertebrates. The ets genes are involved in a variety of developmental processes and are involved in the regulation of cellular proliferation, differentiation and apoptosis. The Ets-1 gene is involved in cellular transformation by various viruses and in the formation of some types of cancer. Ets-1 is a downstream target of Ras signaling and is involved in the regulation of cellular proliferation by Ras. Ets-1 also interacts with the Rb tumor suppressor protein and represses transcription of genes involved in cellular transformation. Ets-1 also interacts with CBP / p300 and CBP / p300 interacts with Ets-1 to repress transcription. The p300 / CBP complex is involved in transcriptional activation by a variety of transcription factors. The interaction of Ets-1 with CBP / p300 may play a role in the regulation of cellular proliferation. The ets factor PU.1 is involved in the regulation of myeloid and B cell development. The interaction of PU.1 with the transcription factor GATA-1 plays a role in the regulation of myeloid specific genes. The interaction of PU.1 and GATA-1 may also play a role in the regulation of B cell development. The interaction of PU.1 and GATA-1 may also play a role in the regulation of the beta-globin gene during erythroid differentiation. The interaction of PU.1 and GATA-1 may also play a role in the regulation of other genes involved in myeloid and B cell development. The interaction of PU.1 and GATA-1 may also play a role in the regulation of other genes involved in myeloid and B cell development. The interaction of PU.1 and GATA-1 may also play a role in the regulation of other genes involved in myeloid and B cell development. The interaction of PU.1 and GATA-1 may also play a role in the regulation of other genes involved in myeloid and B cell development. The interaction of PU.1 and GATA-1 may also play a role in the regulation of other genes involved in myeloid and B cell development.

Calcium / Calmodulin-dependent protein kinases (CaMKs) are a family of serine / threonine protein kinases that are activated by calcium and the calcium-binding protein calmodulin (CaM). CaMKs are involved in a variety of cellular functions including gene transcription, neuronal activity, learning and memory, and muscle contraction. There are many different forms of CaMK, including CaMKI, CaMKII, CaMKIV, and CaMK-Gr. CaMKs are activated by different mechanisms. CaMKI and CaMK-Gr are activated by CaMK kinase, which is itself activated by CaMKK. CaMKII and CaMKIV are activated by CaM kinase kinase, which is activated by the CaM kinase pathway. CaMKs are involved in a variety of signaling pathways. For example, CaMKII is involved in the NMDA receptor pathway and is involved in learning and memory. CaMKI is involved in the CREB pathway and is involved in learning and memory. CaMK-Gr is involved in the cAMP pathway and is involved in learning and memory. The CaMK family is part of a larger group of kinases called the CaM kinases. The CaM kinases are activated by calcium through the binding of calcium to calmodulin, and are themselves regulated by phosphorylation. The CaM kinases are regulated by CaM kinase kinase and CaM kinase kinase. CaM kinase kinase is activated by the MAP kinase pathway and is involved in learning and memory. The CaM kinases are also regulated by autophosphorylation. The CaM kinases are inhibited by the CaMK inhibitor protein, CaMKI-K, which is activated by CaM kinase kinase.

The calcium / calmodulin-dependent protein kinases (CaMKs) are a group of multifunctional serine / threonine kinases that are activated by binding calcium and the regulatory protein calmodulin. CaMKI, CaMKII and CaMKIV are activated by increases in intracellular calcium that occur in response to a variety of stimuli. CaMKI is activated by calcium and calmodulin, but is not regulated by phosphorylation. CaMKI is expressed in brain and other tissues, and is activated by the CaMKK (CaMK kinase). CaMKII is a kinase that is activated by calcium and calmodulin, and is autophosphorylated. CaMKII is autophosphorylated at three sites, and is a calcium-dependent kinase. CaMKIV is activated by calcium and calmodulin, but is not regulated by phosphorylation. CaMKK phosphorylates and activates CaMKIV. The CaMKs regulate a variety of cellular processes in response to calcium signals, including gene transcription, neurotransmitter release, and neuronal plasticity. The CaMKs are also involved in learning and memory processes in animals. The CaMKs are also involved in the regulation of cell cycle progression and apoptosis. The CaMKs are involved in the regulation of the MAP kinase pathways, including the Erk and JNK pathways. The CaMKs also regulate the CREB transcription factor, and CREB-mediated gene transcription. The CREB transcription factor is involved in learning and memory processes in animals, and is also involved in cell survival. The CaMKs are also involved in the regulation of cell cycle progression and apoptosis. The CaMKs are involved in the regulation of cell cycle progression, and the CaMKs regulate the cell cycle through the phosphorylation of the tumor suppressor protein p27kip. The CaMKs also regulate apoptosis through the phosphorylation of the Bcl-2 anti-apoptotic protein. The phosphorylation of Bcl-2 by the CaMKs inhibits its anti-apoptotic activity. The phosphorylation of Bcl-2 by the CaMKs also activates the anti-apoptotic activity of Bcl-2. The phosphorylation of Bcl-2 by the CaMKs also activates the anti-apoptotic activity of Bcl-2. The phosphorylation of Bcl-2 by the CaMKs also activates the calcium-induced cytochrome c release and caspase activation. The phosphorylation of Bcl-2 by the CaMKs also activates the anti-apoptotic activity of Bcl-2 in cells that are treated with staurosporine to induce apoptosis. The activation of the CaMKs by calcium also activates the JNK stress-activated protein kinase pathway. The JNK pathway is involved in apoptosis induced by calcium, and the activation of the JNK pathway by the CaMKs may be involved in the activation of apoptosis by calcium. The CaMKs also regulate other cellular processes in addition to gene transcription, including microtubule dynamics and cell cycle progression. The CaMKs are involved in microtubule dynamics through the phosphorylation of microtubule-associated proteins. The phosphorylation of microtubule-associated proteins by the CaMKs increases their association with microtubules, and may increase microtubule stability. The CaMKs also regulate cell cycle progression through the phosphorylation of the cell cycle regulator protein Cdc2 5C. The phosphorylation of Cdc2 5C by the CaMKs activates the phosphatase activity of Cdc2 5C, and activates the cell cycle kinase Cdc2. The activation of Cdc2 by the CaMKs may be involved in the regulation of cell cycle progression by calcium. The regulation of microtubule dynamics and cell cycle progression by the CaMKs may also be involved in other cellular processes regulated by calcium, such as cell motility and cell division.

Interleukin-1 2 (IL-1 2) is a cytokine that plays a key role in the development of Th1 cells, which are involved in cell-mediated immunity. IL-1 2 is produced by antigen-presenting cells, such as macrophages and B cells, in response to stimulation by microbial products such as LPS. IL-1 2 stimulates the production of interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma) by T cells and natural killer (NK) cells, and induces the expression of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) and adhesion molecules on antigen-presenting cells. IFN-gamma produced by Th1 cells in response to IL-1 2 stimulates the expression of MHC and adhesion molecules on antigen-presenting cells, and enhances their antigen-presenting activity. IL-1 2 also stimulates the proliferation and cytotoxic activity of Th1 cells. IL-1 2 is produced primarily by activated macrophages and B cells, and its production is induced by stimulation with lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and other microbial products. IL-1 2 is a heterodimer, composed of p3 5 and p4 0 subunits. The IL-1 2 receptor is a heterodimer, composed of IL-1 2 receptor beta1 (IL-1 2Rbeta1) and IL-1 2 receptor beta2 (IL-1 2Rbeta2) subunits. IL-1 2Rbeta1 is a component of the receptor for IL-2 3, a cytokine that shares some of the activities of IL-1 2. IL-1 2Rbeta2 is a component of the receptor for IL-2, a cytokine that plays a key role in the differentiation of Th2 cells. IL-2 and IL-4 stimulate the proliferation and cytotoxic activity of Th2 cells.

The growth hormone (GH) -insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) axis plays a key role in growth and metabolism. IGF-1 is a potent mitogen and anti-apoptotic factor. The GH receptor (GHR) is a cytokine receptor that activates several signaling pathways, including the JAK / STAT, MAPK, and PI3 kinase pathways. The PI3 kinase pathway is activated by binding of the GH receptor-associated kinase JAK2 to the 100 kDa regulatory subunit of PI3 kinase. PI3 kinase phosphorylates phosphoinositides to produce the second messengers PIP3 and PIP2. PIP3 activates the kinase AKT, also known as protein kinase B. AKT phosphorylates and inactivates the tumor suppressor protein, p190RhoGAP, which in its unphosphorylated form inhibits the activity of the Rho family GTPases Rac and Cdc-4. PIP3 also activates the kinase PDK1, which activates AKT. AKT phosphorylates and inactivates the forkhead transcription factor FKHR-L1, which regulates genes involved in apoptosis, cell cycle progression, and metabolism. AKT also phosphorylates and activates the kinase IKK, which phosphorylates and activates the transcription factor NF-kB. NF-kB regulates the expression of genes involved in inflammation, cell proliferation, and apoptosis. The transcription factor FKHR-L1 also regulates genes involved in metabolism. The transcription factor FKHR-L1 is regulated by phosphorylation, and phosphorylation by AKT causes FKHR-L1 to be retained in the cytoplasm, preventing activation of genes involved in metabolism. The transcription factor FKHR-L1 is also regulated by the kinase IkB kinase, which phosphorylates and inactivates FKHR-L1 in the absence of growth factor signaling.

Apoptosis or programmed cell death is a genetically controlled process that eliminates unwanted or harmful cells. Apoptosis is induced by two major pathways, the extrinsic and intrinsic pathways. The extrinsic pathway is triggered by extracellular signals, such as Fas ligand, TNF-alpha, TNF-related apoptosis-inducing ligand (TRAIL), and TNF-alpha, and mediated by death receptors, such as Fas, TNF-R1, and TRAIL-R1. The intrinsic pathway is triggered by various intracellular stimuli, including growth factor withdrawal, DNA damage, and ER stress, and is mediated by mitochondria. Mitochondria play a central role in apoptosis and are regulated by the Bcl-2 family proteins. The antiapoptotic Bcl-2 family proteins, such as Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL, prevent the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria by inhibiting the release of cytochrome c and other proapoptotic factors from mitochondria. The proapoptotic Bcl-2 family proteins, such as Bax and Bak, induce the release of cytochrome c and other proapoptotic factors from mitochondria. Cytochrome c, Apaf-1, and caspase-9 form the apoptosome, which activates caspase-3 and other caspases. Caspase-3 cleaves various cellular proteins, leading to the morphological and biochemical changes associated with apoptosis.

The N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor is a ligand-gated ion channel that is activated by the neurotransmitter glutamate. The NMDA receptor is a key mediator of excitatory neurotransmission in the central nervous system (CNS) and is involved in a variety of physiological processes including learning and memory. The NMDA receptor is a multi-subunit complex that requires the binding of glutamate, glycine, and two cations (Na +, K +, and Ca 2 +) for channel opening. The NR1 subunit is the essential component of the channel and is required by the other subunits for functional expression. The NR2 subunits (NR2A-2D) determine the properties of the receptor. The binding of glutamate to the NR1 subunit causes a conformational change in the receptor that allows the channel to open. The influx of cations through the NMDA receptor causes membrane depolarization, which in turn activates voltage-gated calcium channels. The influx of calcium through the NMDA receptor can activate a variety of calcium-dependent signaling pathways. The binding of glutamate to the NMDA receptor also activates a slow, voltage-independent form of desensitization. The binding of glutamate to the NMDA receptor also causes the removal of the channel from a high-affinity, magnesium-dependent state to a lower-affinity, magnesium-independent state. This process is regulated by nitric oxide (NO), which activates soluble guanylyl cyclase and increases cGMP levels. The increase in cGMP activates cGMP-dependent protein kinase (PKG), which phosphorylates the NR1 subunit at a serine residue. This phosphorylation decreases the affinity of the receptor for magnesium and increases the probability of channel opening. The activation of the NMDA receptor also causes the influx of calcium through voltage-gated calcium channels. The influx of calcium activates a variety of signaling pathways. The influx of calcium also activates calcium-dependent proteases, calpains, which cleave the NMDA receptor. The cleavage of the NMDA receptor increases the open time of the channel and may also increase the number of channels in the plasma membrane. The activation of the NMDA receptor also causes the influx of sodium, which depolarizes the membrane and activates voltage-gated calcium channels. The activation of the NMDA receptor also causes the influx of potassium, which hyperpolarizes the membrane and may also activate voltage-gated calcium channels. The activation of the NMDA receptor also causes the influx of zinc, which may act as a negative modulator of the NMDA receptor. Zinc is a potent inhibitor of the NMDA receptor at low micromolar concentrations. The influx of zinc through the NMDA receptor is regulated by the membrane zinc concentration. The membrane zinc concentration is regulated by the membrane zinc transporter-3 (ZnT3). The influx of zinc through the NMDA receptor is also regulated by metallothioneins. The influx of zinc through the NMDA receptor is also regulated by nitric oxide. The influx of zinc through the NMDA receptor is also regulated by the redox state of the cell. The oxidation of cysteine residues in the extracellular domain of the NMDA receptor by reactive oxygen species (ROS) inactivates the receptor. The inactivation of the NMDA receptor by ROS is reversed by the zinc-dependent formation of a disulfide bond between two cysteine residues. The influx of zinc through the NMDA receptor also activates the tyrosine phosphatase STEP. The activation of STEP by zinc causes the dephosphorylation and inactivation of ERK1 / 2. The dephosphorylation of ERK1 / 2 activates the transcription of immediate early genes (IEG).

Fibrinogen is a 3 4 0 kD plasma glycoprotein that is cleaved by thrombin to form fibrin monomers that polymerize to form the fibrin clot. The fibrin clot is a scaffold for the clotting factors and platelets that form the blood clot. The fibrin clot is a temporary structure that seals off a vessel or organ and is degraded by plasmin to release the cellular components of the clot. Plasmin is a serine protease that is produced by the liver and secreted into the blood to degrade fibrin. Plasmin is inhibited by the serpin family E member plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 (PAI1). Plasmin is also inhibited by alpha2-antiplasmin, a serum glycoprotein produced by the liver. Plasmin cleaves fibrinogen to form fibrin monomers that polymerize to form the fibrin clot. The fibrin clot is degraded by plasmin and the clotting factors to release the cellular components of the clot.

Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the growth of benign tumors in multiple organ systems. The disease is caused by mutations in either the TSC1 or TSC2 gene. The gene products, hamartin and tuberin, form a complex that regulates the mTOR pathway. The mTOR pathway regulates translation and cell growth. The mTOR pathway is also involved in the regulation of autophagy. Autophagy is a cellular process that clears damaged proteins and organelles. The inhibition of autophagy by the mTOR pathway may contribute to the formation of tumors in TSC patients. The mTOR inhibitor rapamycin has been shown to inhibit the growth of tumors in TSC patients. The mTOR inhibitor CCI-779 has been shown to inhibit the growth of renal tumors in a TSC mouse model. Interleukin 3 (IL-3) is a cytokine that stimulates the growth and differentiation of hematopoietic cells. The IL-3 receptor is a heterodimer consisting of an alpha subunit (IL-3Ra) and a beta common subunit (IL-5Ra). Binding of IL-3 to the IL-3Ra subunit activates the beta common subunit, which in turn activates several signaling pathways. One pathway activated by IL-3 is the JAK / STAT pathway. The JAK kinases are activated by IL-3 and phosphorylate the beta common subunit, which in turn activates the STAT transcription factors. Another pathway activated by IL-3 is the MAP kinase pathway. IL-3 activates the MAP kinases Erk1 and Erk2, which phosphorylate and activate the transcription factor Elk-1. The activation of Elk-1 by the MAP kinase pathway may contribute to the proliferative response of hematopoietic cells to IL-3.

Interleukin 3 (IL-3) is a cytokine that stimulates the proliferation and differentiation of hematopoietic cells. The IL-3 receptor is a heterodimer consisting of an alpha chain and a beta chain. The beta chain is shared with the IL-5 receptor and the GM-CSF receptor. The beta chain is also a component of the receptors for IL-2, IL-5 and IL-7. The alpha chain is unique to the IL-3 receptor. Binding of IL-3 to the receptor activates the JAK / Stat pathway, the Ras / Map kinase pathway and the PI3 kinase pathway. The JAK kinases are a family of tyrosine kinases that are activated by cytokines and growth factors. The JAK kinases phosphorylate the receptor and the Stat transcription factors. The Map kinases are a family of kinases that are activated by growth factors and cytokines and that activate transcription factors. The PI3 kinase pathway is activated by growth factors and cytokines and activates the Akt kinase and the mTOR kinase.

Cytotoxic T cells (CTLs) are a key component of the immune system that kill virus-infected cells and tumor cells. CTLs kill target cells by two main mechanisms: the release of perforin and granzyme proteins to induce apoptosis in the target cell, and the interaction of Fas ligand on the surface of the CTL with Fas on the target cell. Perforin and granzyme induce apoptosis in the target cell by activating caspases, a class of proteases that cleave other proteins to induce cell death. The caspases are a family of cysteine proteases that include caspase-2, -3, -4, -5, -6, -7, -8, -9, and -1 0. The caspases are initially inactive proenzymes that are activated in a proteolytic cascade. Perforin and granzyme induce apoptosis in the target cell by activating caspase-8, a protease that cleaves and activates caspase-3. Caspase-3 in turn cleaves and activates other caspases, including caspase-10, another caspase that is involved in the apoptotic response to Fas. The Jun / AP-1 transcription factor is also activated by perforin and granzyme to induce expression of the Fas ligand gene, which in turn induces apoptosis in the target cell. The Rho GTPases are a family of proteins that regulate the actin cytoskeleton and other cellular processes. The Rho GDP dissociation inhibitor beta (ARHGDIB) is a negative regulator of the Rho GTPases. CTLs induce apoptosis in target cells by activating ARHGDIB, which inhibits the activity of the Rho GTPases, and so prevents the formation of the actin stress fibers that are required for cell survival. The activation of ARHGDIB by CTLs may be a mechanism to prevent the formation of actin stress fibers in the target cell, and so to allow the induction of apoptosis.

The attachment of proteins to the cell membrane by a glycolipid anchor is a common feature of eukaryotes. The glycolipid anchor is called a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor. In mammals, GPI anchors are attached to more than 1 5 0 proteins. The anchor is attached to the C-terminus of the protein through a series of reactions that are conserved in all eukaryotes. The first step in anchor biosynthesis is the transfer of N-acetylglucosaminyl (GlcNAc) from UDP-GlcNAc to phosphatidylinositol (PI), to form GlcNAc-PI. The second step is the addition of phosphoethanolamine (EtN) to the C-1 position of the inositol ring, to form Man-1EtN-1PI. In mammals, this step is catalyzed by glucosaminyl phosphatidylinositol (GPI) N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase (GPI-GlcNAc transferase). In yeast, the first step is different, and the second step is catalyzed by a different enzyme. In mammals, the third step is the addition of fatty acids to the 2-position of the inositol ring, to form Man-1GlcN-PI. In yeast, the third step is not performed, and the anchor is not lipid-modified. In mammals, the fourth step is the addition of a phosphoethanolamine (EtN) to the C-2 position of the inositol ring, to form Man-1GlcN-1PI. In yeast, the fourth step is not performed, and the anchor is not lipid-modified. In mammals, the fourth step is catalyzed by a membrane-bound enzyme, GPI-anchor biosynthesis class C (PIG-C). In yeast, the fourth step is catalyzed by GPI-anchor biosynthesis class E (PIG-E). In mammals, the fourth step is catalyzed by a soluble enzyme, GPI-anchor biosynthesis class D (PIG-D). In yeast, the fifth step is the addition of a fatty acid to the 6-position of the Man residue. In mammals, the addition of a fatty acid is not required, and the anchor is not lipid-modified. In yeast, the sixth step is the addition of a side-branch oligosaccharide to the Man-1GlcN-1PI. In mammals, the side-branch oligosaccharide is not required.

The cell cycle is a highly regulated process that ensures that each daughter cell receives a complete set of chromosomes prior to cell division. The transition from G1 to S phase is regulated by the activity of the cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs), a family of serine / threonine kinases that are activated by association with cyclins. The CDKs are negatively regulated by CDK inhibitors (CKIs). The CDK inhibitors are expressed throughout the cell cycle, but their expression is induced by the tumor suppressor protein, p16INK4a. The p16INK4a protein forms a complex with CDK4 and CDK6, inhibiting their kinase activity and blocking progression through the G1 phase of the cell cycle. The CDK inhibitors also block the phosphorylation of the retinoblastoma protein (Rb) by the CDKs, preventing the release of E2F transcription factors that induce genes required for S phase progression. The CDK inhibitors are also involved in other cellular processes, such as the response to DNA damage.

The transition from G2 to M phase of the cell cycle is controlled by the maturation promoting factor (MPF), a heterodimer of the cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) Cdc2 and the cyclin B regulatory subunit. The activation of MPF is regulated by the dual-specificity phosphatase Cdc2 5C and the phosphatase Cdc2-activating phosphatase 2. MPF is maintained in an inactive state by phosphorylation on Thr1 4 and Tyr1 5 by Myt1 and WEE1 kinases and is activated by dephosphorylation of these residues by the phosphatase Cdc2 5C. The activation of MPF is triggered by the accumulation of cyclin B, which is regulated by the APC / C ubiquitin ligase. The maturation-promoting factor is inhibited by the kinase Wee1 and Myt1 and by the kinase PKA. The activity of MPF is regulated by the phosphorylation state of Cdc2 and by the binding of the protein kinase PKA to the regulatory subunit. The maturation-promoting factor is activated by the Mos-MEK-MAPK pathway and inhibited by the PKA pathway.

Inflammation is a protective response to harmful stimuli such as infection or tissue injury. If inflammation persists, it can damage tissues and organs. The inflammatory response is initiated by the activation of macrophages and other cells by inflammatory stimuli such as lipopolysaccharide (LPS). Activated macrophages release reactive oxygen species (ROS) and reactive nitrogen species (RNS) that cause tissue damage. ROS and RNS activate the transcription factor NF-kB, which induces the expression of genes involved in inflammation and apoptosis. The glutathione (GSH) antioxidant system is also induced by NF-kB to protect cells from oxidative stress. The xdh gene encodes the enzyme xanthine dehydrogenase (XDH), which produces ROS and RNS when activated. The xdh gene is also induced by NF-kB to produce more XDH. The induction of xdh and glutathione synthesis by NF-kB and xdh by NF-kB may be a positive feedback loop to protect cells from oxidative stress. The induction of xdh by NF-kB may also be involved in the pathogenesis of gout.

Cadherins are a family of transmembrane glycoproteins that mediate homophilic cell-cell adhesion. The cytoplasmic domain of cadherins binds to catenins, which in turn bind to actin filaments. The cadherin-catenin complex is linked to the actin cytoskeleton through alpha-catenin. The catenins are a family of proteins that includes beta-catenin, gamma-catenin, p0 0 7 1, and plakoglobin. The cadherin-catenin complex is involved in a variety of cellular functions including cell-cell adhesion, cell migration, and signaling. The activity of the cadherin-catenin complex is regulated by phosphorylation of the catenins. Cascades are substrates of the tyrosine kinase Src and the serine / threonine kinase GSK-3. Phosphorylation of beta-catenin by GSK-3 leads to its dissociation from the cadherin complex and its subsequent degradation in the proteasome. Cascades also interact with the cytoplasmic tail of the amyloid precursor protein (APP). The interaction of APP with cadherins may regulate cell-cell adhesion and neurite outgrowth. The interaction of APP with cadherins may also play a role in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease.

The transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) family of secreted proteins regulates cellular proliferation, differentiation and apoptosis. TGF-beta binds to type II and type I serine-threonine kinase receptors, activating the type II receptor kinase. The type I receptor phosphorylates the receptor-activated SMADs (R-SMADs), SMAD1, SMAD2, SMAD3, SMAD5 and SMAD8. The R-SMADs are bound by the co-SMAD, SMAD4, and the complex is translocated to the nucleus, where it regulates transcription. The SMADs interact with other transcription factors, including the forkhead transcription factor, FKHR, and the homeobox transcription factors, HOX and MEIS. SMADs also interact with other signaling pathways, including the Wnt / beta-catenin pathway. Crosstalk between the TGF-beta and Wnt / beta-catenin pathways may be important in cancer progression.

The immune system is composed of cells that respond to specific antigens in the context of MHC molecules. The T cell receptor recognizes specific antigens presented by MHC molecules on the surface of antigen presenting cells. The T cell receptor is a complex of proteins that includes the CD3 subunits gamma, delta, epsilon, and zeta. The T cell receptor is expressed on the surface of T cells only when the CD3 subunits are present. The T cell receptor is responsible for the recognition of specific antigens and the activation of T cells. The T cell receptor is also responsible for the activation of cytotoxic T cells that kill cells that present specific antigens on their surface. The activation of T cells is also regulated by the interaction of the T cell receptor with the CD28 molecule on the surface of antigen presenting cells. The CD28 molecule is a co-stimulatory molecule that is expressed on the surface of antigen presenting cells and is involved in the activation of T cells. The interaction of the T cell receptor with the CD28 molecule is inhibited by the interaction of the Fas ligand on the T cell with the Fas receptor on the antigen presenting cell. The interaction of the Fas receptor with the Fas ligand induces apoptosis in the antigen presenting cell. The regulation of T cell activation by the interaction of the T cell receptor with the CD28 molecule and the Fas-Fas ligand interaction plays an important role in the regulation of the immune response.

The calpain family of calcium-dependent intracellular proteases is involved in a variety of cellular functions, including signal transduction, cell motility, cell adhesion, cell cycle progression, apoptosis, and differentiation. The calpains are a family of intracellular cysteine proteases that are activated by calcium. The ubiquitous calpains (mu-calpain and m-calpain) are heterodimers consisting of a large catalytic 8 0kDa subunit and a small 30kDa regulatory subunit. The regulatory subunit is encoded by the p30 gene and is expressed as two splice variants, MD2and MD2t. The p30gene also encodes the p23 protein, which is involved in the regulation of the calpains. Calpastatin is a specific calpain inhibitor. Calpastatin is a large (20 0kDa), widely expressed, and highly conserved protein. Calpastatin is a specific calpain inhibitor and does not inhibit other cysteine proteases. Calpastatin has a calpain inhibitory domain (130amino acids), a penta-EF-hand calcium binding domain (4EF-hand domain), and a protease inhibitory domain. Calpain activity is regulated by two mechanisms. One is the direct binding of calcium to the p23domain and the other is the binding of the p30domain to the p28 domain. The p30domain is also involved in the binding of calpastatin. The p30domain is encoded by the p30 gene. The p28 domain is encoded by the p23 gene. The p23 protein is a calpain inhibitor. The p28 domain is also involved in the binding of calpastatin. The p23 protein is a precursor of the p20 inhibitory domain. The p23 protein is cleaved by calpain to release the p20 inhibitory domain. The p20 domain is encoded by the p30gene. The p23 protein is also called 4F2HC. The p20 domain is a domain that is conserved in the EF-hand family of calcium binding proteins. The EF-hand motif consists of two helix-loop-helix structures, each containing a conserved calcium binding loop. The p23 protein is localized in the cytoplasm and is associated with the cytoskeleton. Calpain activity is regulated by the binding of calpastatin to the p20 domain. The p23 protein is localized in the cytoskeleton. The p23 protein is phosphorylated by several protein kinases, including protein kinase C, protein kinase A, and protein kinase G. The phosphorylation of p23 protein by protein kinase C inhibits the inhibitory activity of calpastatin.

The cAMP-dependent protein kinase A (PKA) is a key regulator of cellular responses to hormones and neurotransmitters. The PKA holoenzyme is a tetramer consisting of two regulatory subunits bound to two catalytic subunits. Binding of cAMP to the regulatory subunits causes the release of the catalytic subunits, which then phosphorylate downstream targets. The specificity of PKA signaling is achieved through the targeting of the kinase to specific subcellular locations through the interaction of the regulatory subunits with A-kinase anchoring proteins (AKAPs). AKAPs are a family of structurally diverse proteins that coordinate the targeting, activation and inhibition of PKA and other signaling molecules. AKAP9 5 is a large multifunctional protein that binds to the condensin I complex and the PKA regulatory subunit (RII). The PKA regulatory subunit bound to AKAP9 5 is responsible for targeting the PKA holoenzyme to the condensin I complex. The condensin I complex is a key regulator of chromosome condensation during mitosis. The binding of PKA to AKAP9 5 may regulate the activity of the condensin I complex during mitosis.

The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a cAMP-regulated chloride channel that is defective in cystic fibrosis. The CFTR protein contains a regulatory domain that inhibits the channel's activity in the absence of cAMP. Binding of the regulatory domain to the channel's channel domain inhibits channel activity. Phosphorylation of the regulatory domain by PKA relieves this inhibition. The CFTR channel is also regulated by protein kinase C (PKC), and by ATP binding and hydrolysis. The NHERF family of PDZ scaffold proteins (NHERF1, NHERF2, and CAP7 0) interact with the regulatory domain of CFTR and regulate its activity. NHERF proteins bind to the regulatory domain of CFTR and also interact with other proteins involved in the regulation of CFTR. NHERF1 and NHERF2 interact with the ezrin-radixin-moesin (ERM) family of cytoskeletal proteins that interact with the actin cytoskeleton. The interaction of NHERF proteins with the ERM proteins may anchor CFTR to the cytoskeleton and may also affect channel regulation. CAP7 0 interacts with the regulatory domain of CFTR and may act as a chaperone for CFTR folding. The interaction of NHERF proteins with the regulatory domain of CFTR may also affect the interaction of other proteins with CFTR. The interaction of CFTR with the ERM proteins may also affect channel regulation. The interaction of the PDZ scaffold proteins with the regulatory domain of CFTR may also affect the interaction of other PDZ scaffold proteins with CFTR.

Interleukin-1 2 (IL-1 2) is a cytokine that stimulates the proliferation of T helper cells and is a key factor in the immune response. IL-1 2 is produced by antigen presenting cells in response to stimulation by microbial products, and stimulates the proliferation of T helper cells and the production of other cytokines. The response of T cells to IL-1 2 is regulated by the state of cellular activation and the state of cellular differentiation. The response of T cells to IL-1 2 is inhibited by interferon-gamma, a cytokine produced by T cells that is stimulated by IL-1 2. Interferon-gamma inhibits the proliferation of T cells in response to IL-1 2 and inhibits the production of other cytokines stimulated by IL-1 2. Interferon-gamma inhibits the response of T cells to IL-1 2 by blocking the expression of genes involved in the response of T cells to IL-1 2. Interferon-gamma inhibits the expression of the IL-1 2 receptor beta 1 chain, which is required for the response of T cells to IL-1 2. Interferon-gamma also inhibits the expression of the Janus kinase JAK2, which is required for the response of T cells to IL-1 2. The inhibition of JAK2 by interferon-gamma may also contribute to the inhibition of the response of T cells to IL-1 2. The inhibition of the response of T cells to IL-1 2 by interferon-gamma may be an important mechanism by which the immune response is regulated.

Apoptosis is a genetically controlled process of cell death that is essential for proper development and tissue homeostasis. Caspases are a family of cysteine proteases that are critical mediators of apoptosis. Caspases are synthesized as inactive precursors that are activated by proteolytic cleavage. Caspases are activated through two main pathways: the extrinsic pathway, triggered by death receptors, and the intrinsic pathway, triggered by a variety of cellular stresses. The extrinsic pathway is initiated by the binding of specific ligands to cell surface receptors, such as FAS, and the TNF receptor family. The intrinsic pathway is triggered by a variety of cellular stresses, including DNA damage, growth factor withdrawal, and ER stress. Both pathways activate the initiator caspase-8, which in turn activates caspase-3, -6 and-7. Caspase-3, -6 and-7 then induce the cleavage of cellular substrates, leading to cell death.

Nucleotide excision repair (NER) is a highly conserved mechanism that is responsible for the removal of a wide variety of DNA lesions including those induced by UV light. Defects in NER are associated with the human disease xeroderma pigmentosum (XP), which is characterized by extreme sun sensitivity and a > 1 0 0 0-fold elevated incidence of skin cancer. In humans, there are at least eight genes (XPA through XPG) that are specifically involved in the repair of helix-distorting lesions by NER. These genes encode proteins that are involved in different steps of the repair process. The first step is the recognition of the lesion by the XPC-hHr2 3B complex. The next step is the formation of an open complex by the cooperative action of the XPB and the XPD helicases. The XPG protein then makes a 5 'incision, followed by the incision by the ERCC1-XPF complex at the 3' side of the lesion. The repair synthesis step is then completed by the action of DNA polymerases delta and epsilon and by the sealing of the DNA strand by DNA ligase I.

The pentose phosphate pathway is a major source of reducing equivalents and nucleotides in many organisms. It is found in bacteria, archaea, and plants, but is not found in animals. It involves the oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway in which glucose-6P is converted to ribulose-5P, which is then isomerized to xylulose-5P. In the non-oxidative phase, ribose-5P and xylulose-5P are interconverted to ribulose-5P and ribulose-6P, which are converted to the nucleotides R5P and xylulose-5P, respectively. Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) is an essential compound in the biosynthesis of purine and pyrimidine nucleotides. In the non-oxidative phase, ribose-5P and xylulose-5P are converted to R5P and xylulose-5P, respectively. In addition to these reactions, the reversible reaction of fructose-6P with glyceraldehyde-3P and pyruvate is also involved in the non-oxidative phase.

The progesterone receptor (PR) is a member of the steroid hormone receptor gene family. It is a ligand-dependent transcription factor that regulates gene expression. The human PR gene is located on chromosome 1 1q2 2-2 3 and is composed of nine coding exons. The PR protein is translated from two different mRNAs that are generated by the use of two different translational start sites in exon 2A. the PR-B protein contains an additional 1 6 4 amino acids at its amino terminus that are absent in the PR-A protein. The PR-A and PR-B proteins are identical in their DNA- and ligand-binding domains, but they differ in their amino and carboxyl terminal domains. The PR-A protein does not bind progestin and functions as a transcriptional repressor of PR-B and other steroid hormone receptors. The PR-B protein is both a transcriptional activator and repressor of gene transcription. The ratio of PR-B to PR-A varies between tissues and changes during development. In the absence of progestin, the PR-A: PR-B ratio is high in the uterus and low in the mammary gland. Binding of progestin to the PR-B causes a conformational change in the receptor that leads to its dimerization, translocation to the nucleus, and binding to progesterone response elements (PREs) or to a progesterone response element half-site (PRE-HS) in the regulatory region of progesterone target genes. The PR-B also interacts with other transcription factors such as Sp1 and c-jun to regulate gene transcription. The transcriptional activity of the PR-B is regulated by phosphorylation in response to progestins. The phosphorylation of the PR-B is mediated by multiple kinases including MAPK, cdk2 and p38. The phosphorylation of the PR-B is associated with its increased transcriptional activity. The regulation of gene expression by the PR is essential for normal reproductive function. The PR is the molecular target for the progestin component of oral contraceptives and for some of the progestational effects of hormone replacement therapy. The PR is also the molecular target for the anti-cancer drugs used in the treatment of breast cancer and endometriosis.

Leukocyte recruitment to sites of inflammation is a multistep process that requires the sequential interaction of various adhesion molecules expressed on the surfaces of leukocytes and endothelial cells. During the initial step of this process, P- and E-selectins expressed on activated platelets and endothelial cells bind to their ligands, P- and E-selectins' ligands (PSGL-1 and PECAM), respectively, and initiate transient interactions between leukocytes and the vascular endothelium. This interaction triggers the activation of leukocyte integrins, LFA-1 and Mac-1, and their subsequent firm adhesion to the endothelium. Leukocyte integrins bind to their ligands, ICAM-1 and VCAM-1, and strengthen their interactions with each other. Finally, leukocytes move across the endothelium and migrate into the surrounding tissues in response to a variety of chemokines.

The high affinity receptor for immunoglobulin E (Fc epsilon RI) is the central mediator of allergic responses. Cross-linking Fc epsilon RI on mast cells by antigen results in the release of preformed granules and the synthesis and release of lipid mediators and cytokines. The release of these mediators causes a rapid inflammatory response and vasodilation. The activation of Fc epsilon RI also induces a state of transcriptional activation in the mast cell. This leads to the expression of a variety of proteins that are involved in the inflammatory response. The signaling pathways that lead to degranulation and transcriptional activation are distinct, but both require activation of the MAP kinase pathways. Degranulation is dependent on the activation of phospholipase C and the release of calcium from intracellular stores. The activation of protein kinase C is also required. Transcriptional activation is dependent on the activation of the Map kinase pathways and the transcription factors NF-AT, NF-IL-6 and AP-1.

The interferon-beta (IFNB) gene is induced by a variety of stimuli, including virus infection, double-stranded RNA, and lipopolysaccharide. The IFNB gene product is secreted and binds to a cell surface receptor to induce a cellular antiviral state. The IFNB promoter contains binding sites for a number of transcription factors, including IRF1, IRF2, NF-kB, and AP-1. The induction of the IFNB gene by these factors is amplified by positive feedback mechanisms involving the transcription factors themselves and other transcription factors. The IFNB gene is also induced by the cytokine interferon alpha (IFNA), and the two genes are coordinately induced by many stimuli. The IFNB gene is also induced by the cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF), but the IFNB gene is not induced by lipopolysaccharide (LPS), a potent inducer of the IFNA gene. The IFNB gene is also induced by the cytokines interleukin 1 (IL-1) and interleukin 6 (IL-6), but these genes are not coordinately induced with the IFNB gene. The IFNB gene is also induced by the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, but the IFNB gene is not induced by the chemotherapeutic agent cisplatin. The IFNB gene is not induced by the anti-cancer drug 5-fluorouracil, indicating that the induction of the IFNB gene is not a general response to DNA damage. The IFNB gene is also induced by heat shock, but the induction by heat shock is transient and does not lead to the accumulation of high levels of IFNB mRNA. The IFNB gene is also induced by hypoxia, but the induction is transient and does not lead to the accumulation of high levels of IFNB mRNA. The IFNB gene is also induced by exercise, but the induction is transient and does not lead to the accumulation of high levels of IFNB mRNA. The IFNB gene is not induced by the stress of osmotic stress. The IFNB gene is also not induced by osmotic stress.

The insulin receptor (INSR) is a member of the receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) gene family. The INSR is activated by binding of insulin or insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). The INSR is expressed in many tissues, including skeletal muscle, liver, adipose tissue, and the brain. The INSR is a key regulator of glucose metabolism and is a major target for the treatment of type II diabetes. The INSR is a disulfide-linked heterodimer consisting of two extracellular alpha subunits and two transmembrane beta subunits. The INSR beta subunit contains the tyrosine kinase domain and the INSR alpha subunit is required for INSR expression and plasma membrane targeting. The INSR is activated by binding of insulin or IGF-1, resulting in receptor dimerization, autophosphorylation, and activation of the receptor kinase. The INSR activates several signaling pathways, including the Ras-Raf-MEK-ERK kinase pathway, the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway, and the JAK-STAT pathway. The Ras-Raf-MEK-ERK kinase pathway is activated by both the Ras-dependent and Ras-independent mechanisms. The Ras-independent pathway is activated by Grb-2 and the tyrosine kinase c-Src. The Ras-dependent pathway is activated by the association of Grb-2 with the IRS-1 adaptor protein. The PI3K pathway is activated by the binding of the adaptor protein IRS-1 to the regulatory subunit of PI3K. The JAK-STAT pathway is activated by the tyrosine phosphorylation of the INSR beta subunit and the subsequent binding of JAK kinases to the INSR beta subunit. The activation of these signaling pathways by the INSR contributes to the regulation of glucose metabolism by insulin.

The calcium-activated protease calpain is a heterodimer consisting of a large 8 0kDa catalytic subunit and a small 30kDa regulatory subunit. Calpain is activated by calcium and results in the limited proteolysis of a variety of intracellular proteins. The activity of calpain is regulated by the reversible binding of the small regulatory subunit to the large catalytic subunit. The binding of calcium to the EF hand motifs of the regulatory subunit causes a conformational change in the enzyme that exposes a new surface for protein-protein interactions. Calpain has been implicated in a variety of cellular processes including apoptosis, cell motility, and signal transduction. The activity of calpain is regulated by the reversible binding of the small regulatory subunit to the large catalytic subunit. Calpastatin is the only known inhibitor of calpain. Calpastatin is a large, specific inhibitor of calpain. Calpastatin is a large protein with eight inhibitory domains that are each homologous to the calpain large subunit inhibitory sequence. The inhibitory domains are arranged in tandem and are separated by short, protease sensitive, sequences. The inhibitory domains are separated by large, protease resistant sequences. The protease sensitive sequences are cleaved by calpain to release the active inhibitory domains. Calpastatin is an effective inhibitor of calpain in vitro, but is not required for calpain activity in vivo. Calpastatin is localized to the cytosol and is not associated with the plasma membrane, mitochondria, or nucleus. Calpastatin is not a substrate of calpain. The activity of calpain is also regulated by the interaction of the regulatory subunit with caldopathy inhibitor. The interaction of the regulatory subunit with the catalytic subunit is regulated by calmodulin. Calmodulin binds to the regulatory subunit in the absence of calcium and is displaced by calcium binding. Calpain also interacts with a variety of other proteins through its non-catalytic subunit.

The release of arachidonic acid from membrane phospholipids by phospholipase A2 (PLA2) is the rate-limiting step in the biosynthesis of eicosanoids. Eicosanoids are lipid mediators that play a key role in many physiological and pathological processes. The first step in the biosynthesis of eicosanoids is the release of arachidonic acid from membrane phospholipids by PLA2. There are two major groups of PLA2, secretory PLA2 (sPLA2) and cytosolic PLA2 (cPLA2). sPLA2 is extracellular and is activated by interaction with membrane phospholipids or by a variety of agents including calcium ions. cPLA2 is a cytoplasmic enzyme that is present in an inactive form in the cytosol. The activity of cPLA2 is regulated by intracellular calcium concentration and phosphorylation. The activity of cPLA2 is also regulated by the concentration of free fatty acids, particularly arachidonic acid. Once activated, cPLA2 translocates to the membrane where it cleaves membrane phospholipids, releasing arachidonic acid. The release of arachidonic acid by cPLA2 is the rate-limiting step in the biosynthesis of eicosanoids.

The B cell antigen receptor (BCR) is a transmembrane protein complex that plays a critical role in the development and function of B cells. The BCR is composed of two immunoglobulin chains (Ig-alpha and Ig-beta) associated with two Ig-gamma and Ig-delta chains. The cytoplasmic portion of the Ig-alpha and Ig-beta chains contains immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motifs (ITAMs) that are required for BCR signaling. The binding of antigen by the BCR initiates a signaling cascade that leads to the activation of nuclear factor-AT (NF-AT), nuclear factor-kB (NF-kB), and activator protein-1 (AP-1). The activation of these transcription factors ultimately results in the transcriptional activation of a variety of genes involved in B cell proliferation and differentiation.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by the production of autoantibodies to self-antigens. The production of autoantibodies is thought to be caused by the loss of tolerance to self-antigens, which are presented in the form of apoptotic cells or nuclear debris, in the context of an abnormal cytokine environment. The presence of autoantibodies is associated with the formation of immune complexes that are deposited in the glomeruli of the kidney, causing glomerulonephritis. The presence of immune complexes in the circulation causes the activation of complement and the recruitment of inflammatory cells, which leads to tissue damage.

The chemokine receptor CXCR4 is activated by its ligand SDF-1 / CXCL1 2. This chemokine is expressed by bone marrow stromal cells and is also found in the brain, lung, liver, and small intestine. The SDF-1 / CXCL1 2 ligand is also expressed in these tissues. The interaction of SDF-1 / CXCL1 2 with CXCR4 plays a role in the development of the nervous system and the development of the heart. The interaction of SDF-1 / CXCL1 2 with CXCR4 also plays a role in HIV infection. The interaction of SDF-1 / CXCL1 2 with CXCR4 also plays a role in the retention of lymphocytes in the bone marrow. The interaction of SDF-1 / CXCL1 2 with CXCR4 activates a variety of signaling pathways in lymphocytes. The activation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway, calcium flux, and the activation of protein kinase C are all involved in CXCR4 signaling. The activation of these signaling pathways leads to the activation of transcription factors such as AP-1 and NF-AT. The activation of these transcription factors leads to the activation of genes such as the IL-2 gene. The activation of CXCR4 also leads to the activation of focal adhesion kinase and the small G-protein Rac. These signaling pathways lead to the activation of cytoskeletal changes and changes in cell shape. The activation of CXCR4 also leads to the activation of PI3 kinase and the AKT pathway. The activation of PI3 kinase and AKT leads to the inhibition of apoptosis in lymphocytes.

The regulation of gene expression by steroid hormones is a complex process that involves the interaction of steroid hormone receptors with a variety of transcription factors. The interaction of steroid hormone receptors with transcription factors is influenced by the cell and promoter context as well as by the presence of other transcription factors. The interaction of steroid hormone receptors with transcription factors can be either positive or negative, depending on the promoter context and the transcription factors involved. The interaction of steroid hormone receptors with transcription factors can be direct or indirect. In the direct interaction, the steroid hormone receptor binds to a specific DNA response element and then interacts with and influences the activity of a transcription factor. In the indirect interaction, the steroid hormone receptor interacts with another transcription factor and then interacts with the transcription factor to alter its activity. The interaction of steroid hormone receptors with transcription factors can be influenced by the phosphorylation state of the transcription factor. The interaction of steroid hormone receptors with transcription factors can also be influenced by the cell cycle. The interaction of steroid hormone receptors with transcription factors can also be influenced by the presence of other proteins.

Bile acids are a class of steroid carboxylic acids that are synthesized from cholesterol in the liver. Bile acids are conjugated with taurine or glycine before secretion into the intestine. In the intestine, bile acids are conjugated with taurine or glycine before being secreted into the intestine. Bile acids are amphipathic molecules that are essential for the digestion and absorption of dietary fats and sterols. Bile acids are also signaling molecules that regulate metabolism and homeostasis of glucose and lipids. Bile acids activate the nuclear receptor FXR to induce the expression of the bile acid efflux pump BSEP and the ileal bile acid binding protein (IBABP). FXR also induces the expression of the short heterodimer partner SHP, which in turn represses the expression of CYP7A1, the rate-limiting enzyme in bile acid biosynthesis. Bile acids also activate the nuclear receptor LXR to induce the expression of the cholesterol transporter ABCA1 and the cholesterol ester transfer protein CETP. ABCA1 mediates the efflux of cellular cholesterol to lipid-poor apolipoprotein AI (ApoAI) to form nascent high-density lipoprotein (HDL) particles, which are the first step in the reverse cholesterol transport pathway. CETP catalyzes the transfer of cholesterol ester from HDL to triglyceride-rich lipoproteins for the formation of HDL3. Bile acids also activate the G-protein coupled receptor TGR5, which increases energy expenditure by increasing energy expenditure and reducing food intake. TGR5 is expressed in the enterochromaffin cells of the intestine, where it stimulates the release of serotonin, which activates brown adipose tissue to increase energy expenditure. Bile acids also activate the nuclear receptor PXR, which induces the expression of cytochrome P4 5 0 enzymes involved in the metabolism of bile acids and xenobiotics. The activation of PXR by bile acids may also protect against the toxicity of bile acids.

The mTOR pathway is a key regulator of cell growth and proliferation. mTOR is a serine / threonine kinase that exists in two distinct protein complexes, mTORC1 and mTORC2. mTORC1 is composed of mTOR, mLST8, PRAS4 0 and raptor and is sensitive to the macrolide rapamycin. Growth factors activate the class I PI3-kinase pathway, which in turn activates AKT. AKT phosphorylates TSC2, a GTPase activating protein (GAP) for the small G protein Rheb. Phosphorylation of TSC2 by AKT inhibits the GAP activity of TSC2 towards Rheb, leading to an accumulation of active Rheb-GTP and activation of mTOR. Activated mTOR phosphorylates the 4EBP-1 and S6K1 kinases, which regulate protein translation. The mTORC2 complex is composed of mTOR, mLST8, rictor, Sin1 and protor. It is insensitive to rapamycin and does not appear to regulate the phosphorylation of 4EBP-1 or S6K1.

The D1 dopamine receptor is coupled to Gs and activates adenylyl cyclase, increasing cAMP levels. The cAMP-activated protein kinase A (PKA) phosphorylates DARPP-3 2, a protein phosphatase inhibitor, at Thr75. pThr75DARPP inhibits the protein phosphatase 1 (PP1), resulting in an increase in the phosphorylation of proteins that are substrates of PKA, including CREB. The phosphorylation of DARPP-3 2 at Thr75also inhibits PKA by an auto-inhibition mechanism. The phosphorylation of CREB at Ser1 33by PKA leads to the transcription of genes containing CRE sequences. The activation of PKA also leads to the activation of the MAP kinase pathway, resulting in the phosphorylation of CREB at Ser180. pSer180CREB activates the transcription of genes containing the CRE sequence. The D2 dopamine receptor is coupled to Gi / o and inhibits adenylyl cyclase. The activation of the D2 dopamine receptor also leads to the inhibition of the MAP kinase pathway and CREB phosphorylation. The regulation of DARPP-3 2 by dopamine through the D1 and D2 receptors provides a mechanism for the integration of dopamine and glutamate signals in the striatum.

gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain. The inhibitory action of GABA is mediated by GABA-gated chloride channels (GABA (A) Rs). The GABA (A) Rs are macromolecular complexes that are composed of five subunits arranged coaxially around the chloride ion channel. Each subunit has a molecular mass of between 4 0 and 5 0 kDa and is encoded by a separate gene. The GABA (A) R is a member of a gene superfamily that includes the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors and the glycine receptors. Each subunit has four transmembrane domains (M1-M4) and an extended cytoplasmic loop between M3 and M4. The GABA (A) R is a heteropentamer with multiple subunits. In the brain, the majority of GABA (A) Rs are composed of 2alpha1beta1gamma2 subunits. The GABA (A) R is the site of action of many commonly used sedative-hypnotic drugs, such as benzodiazepines, barbiturates, and general anesthetics. The GABA (A) R is also the site of action of many drugs that are abused by humans, such as the benzodiazepines, ethanol, and the barbiturates. The GABA (A) R is a chloride channel that opens in response to GABA binding. The binding of GABA opens the chloride channel, which allows chloride ions to flow down their electrochemical gradient down their electrochemical gradient into the cell. The chloride ions flow down their electrochemical gradient down their electrochemical gradient into the cell, causing the cell to hyperpolarize. The binding of GABA to the GABA (A) R opens the chloride channel, which allows chloride ions to flow down their electrochemical gradient down their own electrochemical gradient into the cell. The binding of GABA to the GABA (A) R hyperpolarizes the neuron, reducing the probability of an action potential being generated. GABA (A) Rs are modulated by a variety of drugs, including benzodiazepines, barbiturates, and general anesthetics. Benzodiazepines are anxiolytic drugs that are used as analgesics and as sedatives. They bind to a site on the GABA (A) R that is distinct from the GABA binding site. Benzodiazepines increase the affinity of the GABA (A) R for GABA and increase the chloride current elicited by GABA. Barbiturates and general anesthetics also enhance the response of the GABA (A) R to GABA. Barbiturates are used as anesthetics and as anticonvulsants. General anesthetics are used to provide general anesthesia. They are used as a general depressant to produce unconsciousness and amnesia. GABA (A) Rs are also targets of several drugs of abuse, including the benzodiazepines, ethanol, and the inhalants. The GABA (A) R is the site of action of many drugs of abuse, including the benzodiazepines, ethanol, and the inhalants. Benzodiazepines are anxiolytic drugs that are used as analgesics and as sedatives. They bind to a site on the GABA (A) R that is distinct from the GABA binding site. Benzodiazepines increase the affinity of the GABA (A) R for GABA and increase the chloride current elicited by GABA. Barbiturates and general anesthetics also enhance the response of the GABA (A) R to GABA. Barbiturates and general anesthetics increase the chloride current elicited by GABA. General anesthetics are used as general anesthetics. They are used as general anesthetics to produce unconsciousness and as analgesics to provide general analgesia. Ethanol is an alcoholic drug that is used as a general anesthetic. Like benzodiazepines, ethanol increases the response of the GABA (A) R to GABA. Inhalants are volatile compounds that are commonly used as a general anesthetic. They bind to a site on the GABA (A) R that is distinct from the GABA binding site. The chloride current elicited by GABA is increased by inhalants. The chloride current is increased by inhalants. The chloride current is increased by inhalants.

The transcription factor CREB (cAMP response element binding protein) is activated by a variety of extracellular signals, including neurotransmitters, hormones, and growth factors. Phosphorylation of CREB at a single site, serine-1 3 3, is required for transcriptional activation. The CREB kinase cascade includes the kinases PKA, CAMKII, and CAMKIV. The CREB kinase cascade is triggered by the activation of cell surface receptors, including the beta-adrenergic receptor, glutamate receptors, and the tyrosine kinase growth factor receptors. The CREB kinase cascade is triggered by the activation of a variety of G-proteins, including Gs, Gi, and Gq. The CREB kinase cascade is triggered by the activation of a variety of G-proteins, including Gs, Gi, and Gq. The CREB kinase cascade is triggered by the activation of a variety of G-proteins, including Gs, Gi, and Gq. The CREB kinase cascade is triggered by the activation of a variety of G-proteins, including Gs, Gi, and Gq. The CREB kinase cascade is triggered by the activation of a variety of G-proteins, including Gs, Gi, and Gq. The CREB kinase cascade is triggered by the activation of a variety of G-proteins, including Gs, Gi, and Gq. The CREB kinase cascade is triggered by the activation of a variety of G-proteins, including Gs, Gi, and Gq. The CREB kinase cascade is triggered by the activation of a variety of G-proteins, including Gs, Gi, and Gq. The CREB kinase cascade is triggered by the activation of a variety of G-proteins, including Gs, Gi, and Gq.

Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) is a major complication of allogeneic bone marrow transplantation (BMT). GVHD is caused by the attack of donor T cells against host tissues, leading to tissue damage and impaired function of vital organs. GVHD is a multi-factorial disease, and is initiated by the recognition of host MHC molecules by donor T cells. The activation of donor T cells is followed by the release of inflammatory cytokines, such as IL-2, TNF and IFN-gamma. These cytokines activate host cells and induce apoptosis of intestinal epithelial cells. The activation of cytotoxic T cells and the release of perforin and granzyme B by cytotoxic T cells induce apoptosis of target cells. The recognition of host MHC molecules by donor T cells also leads to the activation of host APCs. The activation of host APCs results in the presentation of host MHC-bound peptides to donor T cells, which then proliferate and differentiate into effector cells. The activation of donor T cells is also influenced by the presence of TGF-beta and IL-1 0.

Cross-linking of the high affinity IgE receptor (Fc epsilon RI) on mast cells by multivalent antigen activates multiple signaling pathways that lead to the release of inflammatory mediators and the subsequent development of an allergic response. Fc epsilon RI aggregation results in the activation of Lyn, Fyn, and Syk tyrosine kinases, which phosphorylate multiple substrates, including the adaptor proteins LAT and SLP-7 6. The LAT / SLP-7 6 complex activates the phospholipase C-gamma pathway, which leads to the release of intracellular calcium and the activation of the calcium-dependent protein kinases, calcineurin, and the nuclear factor of activated T cells (NFAT). The calcium flux also activates the protein kinase C pathway, which leads to the activation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway and the production of cytokines. The MAPK pathway is activated by a series of phosphorylation events that are mediated by the adaptor proteins Shc, Grb2, and Sos-1. The activation of the transcription factors AP-1 and NF-AT by the MAPK pathway leads to the production of cytokines.

Insulin like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) is a potent mitogen that stimulates proliferation of many cell types. IGF-1 binds to a receptor tyrosine kinase (IGF-1R) that is closely related in structure to the insulin receptor. Binding of IGF-1 to IGF-1R stimulates proliferation of many cell types, including cells of the nervous system. IGF-1 also has important effects on differentiation of many cell types. The mitogenic effects of IGF-1 are mediated by the Ras / Raf / MAP kinase pathway and the PI 3-kinase pathway. Both pathways converge on the cell cycle machinery to stimulate progression through the G1 phase of the cell cycle. The Ras / Raf / MAP kinase pathway stimulates expression of cyclin D1, which activates the cyclin-dependent kinases CDK4 and CDK6. These kinases phosphorylate the retinoblastoma protein (Rb), releasing the transcription factor E2F, which stimulates entry into S phase. The PI 3-kinase pathway also stimulates progression through G1, but does not appear to stimulate cyclin D1 expression. The PI 3-kinase pathway stimulates phosphorylation of the protein kinase AKT, which activates the transcription factor NF-AT. The convergence of these two pathways on the cell cycle machinery may contribute to the ability of IGF-1 to stimulate proliferation of many cell types.

TNF-alpha is a cytokine that induces apoptosis in some cells and activates the transcription factor NF-kB in others. The TNF-alpha receptor family includes the 5 5kDa TNF-alpha receptor (TNFR1) and the TNF-alpha receptor 2 (TNFR2). The cytoplasmic domain of TNFR1 contains a death domain that is required for TNF-induced apoptosis and NF-kB activation. The TNF-alpha receptor associated death domain (TRADD) protein is recruited to the receptor upon TNF-alpha binding and recruits the receptor-interacting protein RIP and the TNF-R1 associated factor 2 (TRAF2). RIP and TRAF2 activate NF-kB and JNK signaling pathways. The kinase NIK (NF-kB inducing kinase) is required for NF-kB activation by TNF-alpha and by the lymphotoxin-beta receptor, but not by IL-1R1. The kinase activity of NIK is required for NF-kB activation by NIK and TNF-alpha. The TRAF proteins are E3 ubiquitin ligases that may recruit other factors to the TNF-R1 signaling complex. The TRAF-2 associated protein TANK (TRAF-interacting protein) inhibits NF-kB activation by TNF-alpha and TRAF2.

The extracellular matrix (ECM) is a complex mixture of structural and functional macromolecules that provide a structural scaffold and a means of transmitting signals between cells. The ECM is a complex three-dimensional network composed of many different macromolecules, including glycoproteins, proteoglycans, and fibrillar collagen. The major components of the ECM are collagen, laminin, and proteoglycans. The major constituents of the basement membrane are collagen IV, laminin, and proteoglycans. The ECM is closely associated with the plasma membrane and provides a structural scaffold for cells and tissues. Cells adhere to the ECM through transmembrane receptors of the integrin family. Integrins are a family of heterodimeric transmembrane glycoproteins that consist of noncovalently bound alpha- and beta-subunits. There are 1 8 alpha- and 8 beta-subunits that form at least 2 4 different heterodimers with distinct ligand specificities and cellular expression patterns. Integrins transmit signals from the ECM through the cytoskeleton to the cytoplasm and the nucleus. The interaction of ECM components with cell surface receptors is important for cell migration, proliferation, differentiation, and survival.

The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a transmembrane receptor tyrosine kinase that is activated by a variety of growth factors, including EGF, transforming growth factor-alpha (TGF-alpha), and heparin binding EGF. The binding of growth factors to the extracellular domain of the receptor induces dimerization and activation of the cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase domain, resulting in phosphorylation of specific tyrosine residues in the cytoplasmic tail. These phosphorylated tyrosine residues serve as binding sites for signaling molecules containing Src homology 2 (SH2) or phosphotyrosine binding (PTB) domains. The binding of signaling molecules to the activated EGFR activates a number of signaling pathways, including the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway, the phosphoinositol 3-kinase (PI3-K) pathway, and the JAK / STAT pathway. These signaling pathways ultimately regulate cellular proliferation, differentiation, and motility.

B cell receptor (BCR) activation is essential for B cell development and function. BCR activation initiates a cascade of protein phosphorylation events that lead to transcriptional regulation. The first step in BCR signaling is the activation of Src-family protein tyrosine kinases (PTKs), primarily Lyn and Fyn. Src-family PTKs phosphorylate the BCR and provide binding sites for the recruitment of Syk and the Tec-family kinase Btk. The phosphorylation of downstream substrates by Syk and Btk leads to the activation of phospholipase C-gamma 2 (PLC-gamma 2) and the subsequent release of intracellular calcium. The activation of PLC-gamma 2 also leads to the activation of protein kinase C (PKC) and the Ras pathway. The Ras pathway leads to the activation of the transcription factors NF-AT, AP-1 and NF-kB, which in turn activate the transcription of genes involved in B cell activation and proliferation. The activation of NF-AT and NF-kB is dependent on calcium release and the activation of PKC. The activation of AP-1 is dependent on both the Ras pathway and the calcium pathway. The activation of the Tec-family kinase Bmx is also involved in BCR signaling. The activation of Bmx leads to the phosphorylation of PLC-gamma 2 and the subsequent activation of calcium release and the Ras pathway.

The AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) is a highly conserved, ubiquitously expressed serine / threonine protein kinase, which is activated by cellular stresses that increase the AMP: ATP ratio, such as glucose deprivation, heat shock, hypoxia, and exercise. Once activated, AMPK acts as a metabolic checkpoint, switching on ATP-generating pathways (such as glycolysis and fatty acid oxidation) and switching off ATP-consuming processes (such as gluconeogenesis and fatty acid synthesis). The kinase is a heterotrimer, with a catalytic alpha subunit and regulatory beta and gamma subunits. Binding of AMP to the gamma subunit causes a conformational change that allows phosphorylation of the alpha subunit by the upstream kinase, LKB1. This phosphorylation event activates the kinase and also creates a docking site for 34-kDa-protein-phosphatase-2CD (PP2Calpha), which dephosphorylates the AMPK alpha subunit, leading to its inactivation. The identification of the AMPK pathway as a metabolic checkpoint has generated considerable interest in the therapeutic potential of AMPK activators for the treatment of metabolic disorders such as type 2 diabetes. The identification of the mitochondrial protein, Cbp48, as an upstream activator of AMPK has provided a new potential target for drugs that activate AMPK.

The protease-activated receptors (PARs) are a family of four G-protein coupled receptors that are activated by proteolytic unmasking of a tethered ligand domain. The tethered ligand domain is specific for each PAR and activates the receptor independent of receptor cleavage. The tethered ligand domain is generated by a protease that is co-expressed with the PAR and can activate the receptor in an autocrine or paracrine fashion. The tethered ligand can also diffuse from the activating surface and activate PARs on cells that are not in immediate proximity to the activating protease. The PAR family includes the thrombin receptor (PAR-1), the coagulation factor receptors (PAR-3 and PAR-4) and the protease-activated receptor for trypsin (PAR-2). PARs are widely expressed in a variety of tissues and cells and are activated by a variety of proteases that are present in the extracellular environment.
