The PAR-1 receptor is activated by thrombin, the coagulation factor VIIa-tissue factor complex and activated protein C. The PAR-2 receptor is activated by trypsin and factor Xa. The PAR-3 receptor is activated by the trypsin-like protease coagulation factors Xa and IXa. The PAR-4 receptor is activated by trypsin and factor Xa. PAR-1 and PAR-3 are cleaved and activated by proteases that are found in the circulation and are associated with the vascular wall. PAR-2 is activated by trypsin and factor Xa and is found in the gut and lungs. PAR-1 and PAR-3 are important in hemostasis and thrombosis. PAR-1 is activated by thrombin and plays a key role in platelet activation and aggregation. PAR-1 is also important in the vascular response to thrombin. PAR-3 is activated by trypsin and plays a role in the vascular response to trypsin. PAR-3 is also involved in platelet activation. PAR-2 is activated by trypsin and factor Xa and plays a key role in the initial activation of platelets by these proteases. PAR-2 is also involved in the vascular response to trypsin. PAR-4 is activated by trypsin and factor Xa and plays a role in the vascular response to these proteases. The activation of PARs by proteases in the vascular environment may play an important role in vascular inflammation and injury. The activation of PARs by proteases in the extracellular environment may also play a role in the activation of PARs on cells that are not in immediate proximity to proteases. The activation of PARs on platelets may play a role in the development of arterial thrombosis in the setting of atherosclerosis.

Growth hormone (GH) is a peptide hormone secreted by the anterior pituitary gland that regulates growth and metabolism. The actions of GH are mediated by the GH receptor (GHR), a member of the cytokine receptor gene family. Binding of GH to GHR activates JAK2, a tyrosine kinase, and other signaling pathways. The JAK / STAT pathway is one of the signaling pathways activated by GHR. JAK2 phosphorylates and activates STAT-1, STAT-3 and STAT-5. These transcription factors translocate to the nucleus and regulate gene expression. Another pathway activated by JAK2 is the Ras / Raf / MEK / ERK pathway. Ras activates Raf, which activates MEK, which in turn activates ERK. The activation of ERK by GH is rapid and transient, and is not inhibited by the expression of a dominant negative Ras. The activation of ERK by GH is independent of the activation of JAK kinases or STAT transcription factors. The role of ERK in the regulation of gene expression by GH is not yet known. Another pathway activated by JAK2 is the PI3-kinase pathway. PI3-kinase is activated by JAK2 and phosphorylates AKT. AKT is a serine / threonine kinase that regulates many cellular processes including metabolism, proliferation and apoptosis. AKT phosphorylates and inhibits the pro-apoptotic protein Bad. Phosphorylation of Bad by AKT prevents Bad from forming heterodimers with Bcl-xL and Bcl-2, and allows them to induce cytochrome c release and apoptosis. AKT also phosphorylates and activates eNOS, increasing NO production. AKT activation by GH may also contribute to the anti-apoptotic actions of GH.

The kappa-opioid receptor (KOR) is a G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) that is activated by the endogenous peptide ligand, dynorphin. Dynorphin is derived from prodynorphin and is cleaved by the enzyme prohormone convertase (PC) 1 / 3 to release the endogenous ligand, dynorphin. The activation of KOR by dynorphin leads to the inhibition of pain and other physiological responses. The activation of KOR also produces some of the dysphoric effects of opioids such as a state of dysphoria. The dysphoric effects of KOR activation are mediated by the activation of the extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) pathway and inhibition of cAMP production. The activation of ERK by KOR also leads to the activation of the transcription factor CREB and the expression of the immediate early gene, c-fos. The activation of ERK by KOR is mediated by the G-protein Go, the beta-arrestin scaffolding protein, and the protein kinase C (PKC) -dependent activation of the small G-protein, ras. The activation of the ERK pathway by KOR may contribute to the dysphoric effects of KOR activation.

The insulin-like growth factor 1 receptor (IGF-1R) is a tyrosine kinase receptor that is structurally similar to the insulin receptor (IR). IGF-1R is activated by IGF-1 and IGF-2, and is involved in the regulation of cell growth and differentiation. IGF-1R is over-expressed in many types of cancer and is associated with poor prognosis. The IGF-1R pathway is an attractive target for cancer therapy. The IGF-1R pathway is similar to the insulin receptor (IR) pathway in that both receptors are tyrosine kinases and both pathways activate the PI3K / AKT pathway and the MAPK pathway. Both pathways regulate protein synthesis and cell growth. The mTOR pathway is involved in the regulation of protein synthesis and is activated by both IGF-1R and IR. The PI3K / AKT pathway inhibits GSK-3, which phosphorylates eIF2B, increasing the activity of eIF2B and increasing the rate of translation. The mTOR pathway also regulates protein synthesis through phosphorylation of ribosomal protein S6 kinase (S6K) and 4E-BP. The MAPK pathway also regulates protein synthesis through phosphorylation of ribosomal protein S6 kinase and 4E-BP. The IGF-1R pathway also activates the RAS / RAF / MEK / MAPK pathway, which also regulates protein synthesis. The activation of these pathways by IGF-1R and IR increases the translation of proteins involved in cell growth and proliferation.

The Krebs cycle is a central metabolic pathway that provides NADH and FADH2 for the respiratory chain and also provides precursors for the biosynthesis of amino acids, fatty acids, and some other important metabolites. The cycle begins with the carboxylation of pyruvate to form oxaloacetate. This reaction is catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase. The next step is the transfer of a CO2 molecule from oxaloacetate to the CoA derivative of acetyl-CoA to form the thioester of succinyl-CoA. This reaction is catalyzed by succinyl-CoA synthetase. The next step is the transfer of a CO2 molecule from succinyl-CoA to fumarate to form succinate. This reaction is catalyzed by succinate-CoA ligase. The next step is the transfer of a CO2 molecule from succinyl-CoA to a-ketoglutarate to form the condensation product of alpha-ketoglutarate and succinyl-CoA. This reaction is catalyzed by alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from succinyl-CoA to a-ketoglutarate to form isocitrate and the transfer of a CO2 molecule from isocitrate to a-ketoglutarate to form a-ketoadipate. These two reactions are catalyzed by isocitrate dehydrogenase and alpha-ketoadipate hydrolase. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from a-ketoglutarate to a-ketoadipate to form alpha-ketoadipate. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from a-ketoadipate to pyruvate to form oxaloacetate. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from oxaloacetate to pyruvate to form malate. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from malate to pyruvate to form pyruvate. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from pyruvate to a-ketoglutarate to form alanine. The next step is the transfer of a CO2 molecule from alanine to pyruvate to form pyruvate and then to a-ketoglutarate to form oxaloacetate. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from pyruvate to a-ketoglutarate to form isocitrate. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from isocitrate to pyruvate to form alpha-ketoglutarate. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from alpha-ketoglutarate to pyruvate to form alanine. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from pyruvate to a-ketoglutarate to form glutamate and then to a-ketoadipate. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from pyruvate to a-ketoglutarate to form aspartate and then to alanine. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from aspartate to pyruvate to form alanine. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from pyruvate to a-ketoglutarate to form oxaloacetate. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from oxaloacetate to pyruvate to form malate. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from aspartate to pyruvate to form alanine. The next two steps are the transfer of a CO2 molecule from alanine to pyruvate to form aspartate.

The immune system is composed of two major parts, the innate and the adaptive immune systems. The innate immune system provides the first line of defense against invading pathogens. Innate immune cells include natural killer (NK) cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells (DCs). Macrophages and DCs phagocytose and digest foreign pathogens. Macrophages and DCs secrete cytokines and chemokines to activate the adaptive immune system. Macrophages and DCs present antigen to T cells and stimulate their proliferation and differentiation. Naive T cells are classified into two types, helper T cells (Th) and cytotoxic T cells (Tc). Th cells produce cytokines that regulate the type and function of subsequent immune responses, while Tc cells directly kill infected cells. The adaptive immune system is antigen-specific and is generated through the rearrangement of genes encoding the antigen-specific receptors of B and T cells. B cells produce antibodies that provide humoral immunity by binding to antigens and activating complement proteins. T cells recognize antigen in the context of MHC molecules and stimulate further proliferation and differentiation of B and T cells.

The proteasome is a large protein complex that degrades proteins in an ATP-dependent manner. It is found in all cells and is responsible for the degradation of abnormal proteins and the processing of proteins involved in many cellular functions. The proteasome is a cylindrical structure with a molecular weight of about 10 0000 00Da. It is composed of two multi-subunit rings stacked on each other to form a 26S structure. The outer ring is composed of 6subunits (PA700) and the inner ring of 14 subunits (PA280). The PA280 ring contains the proteolytic activity, which is carried out by three different proteases, trypsin-like, chymotrypsin-like and peptidylglutamyl-peptide-hydrolyzing (PGPH) activities. The PA700 ring contains the ubiquitin receptors that bind to ubiquitin-tagged proteins and the PA280 ring contains the ATPases that unfold the proteins and feed them into the catalytic center of the 20S particle. The PA280 ring is also called the PA700 ring because of its size and structure. The PA700 ring is called PA700 if not stated otherwise. The PA280 ring is called PA700 because of its apparent molecular weight. The PA280 ring is called PA700 if not stated otherwise. The PA280 ring is also called PA200 because of its apparent molecular weight. The PA200 ring is called PA200 if not stated otherwise. The PA200 ring is called PA200 if not stated otherwise. The PA200 ring is also called PA2100 because of its apparent molecular weight. The PA200 ring is called PA200 if not stated otherwise. The PA200 ring is called PA2100 if not stated otherwise. The PA200 ring is called PA21000 if not stated otherwise. The PA200 ring is called PA200 if not stated otherwise. The PA200 ring is called PA21000 if not stated otherwise.

Leukocyte adhesion to the endothelium is a key event in inflammation and is mediated by a family of cell adhesion molecules called selectins. The selectin family includes the peripheral node addressin (PNAd), also called the homing receptor for lymphocytes (HHR), and the more recently identified L-selectin, also called MEL-1 4. The PNAd is a mucin on the surface of high endothelial venules (HEVs) in lymphoid tissues that binds to the integrin lymphocyte homing receptor (LHR), also called integrin alpha4beta7, expressed on the surface of lymphocytes. The interaction of PNAd and LHR mediates the homing of lymphocytes from the blood to lymphoid tissues. The interaction of L-selectin and its ligand on the endothelium of blood vessels in nonlymphoid tissues mediates the initial rolling of leukocytes on the endothelium prior to firm adhesion and extravasation. The interaction of L-selectin with its ligand is regulated by several different mechanisms, including the expression of different forms of the ligand, the presence of different carbohydrate structures on the ligand, and the binding of calcium ions to the lectin domain of L-selectin.

Insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) is a potent mitogen that stimulates cell proliferation and differentiation. IGF-1 binds to the IGF-1 receptor (IGF-1R), a tyrosine kinase receptor, and activates several signaling pathways, including the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway and the phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway. The activation of the MAPK pathway by IGF-1 is Ras-dependent and leads to the phosphorylation of ERK1 and ERK2. The activation of the PI3K pathway by IGF-1 leads to the phosphorylation of AKT and GSK-3. The activation of both pathways is required for IGF-1 induced proliferation. The activation of the MAPK pathway by IGF-1 also leads to the phosphorylation of CREB and the activation of transcription. The activation of the PI3K pathway by IGF-1 leads to the phosphorylation of AKT and GSK-3, and the phosphorylation of FKHRL1 and FKHRL1. The phosphorylation of FKHRL1 and FKHRL1 by AKT leads to their retention in the cytoplasm and the inhibition of transcription. The inhibition of GSK-3 by AKT also contributes to the activation of transcription by beta-catenin. The inhibition of GSK-3 by AKT also contributes to the activation of transcription by beta-catenin.

TNF-alpha is a cytokine that can induce apoptosis in a variety of cell types. TNF-alpha induces apoptosis through two different pathways. The first pathway is dependent on the activation of the transcription factor NF-kB and involves the induction of the expression of the gene encoding the protease caspase 8. Caspase 8 in turn activates caspase 3, a protease that induces apoptosis. The second pathway is independent of NF-kB and caspase 8 and does not involve caspase 3. This pathway involves the translocation of the apoptosis inducing factor (AIF) from mitochondria to the nucleus where it induces apoptosis. The activation of NF-kB by TNF-alpha is blocked by ceramide, a lipid second messenger generated by the action of neutral sphingomyelinase. The activation of NF-kB by TNF-alpha is also blocked by the protein kinase C (PKC) activator phorbol 1 2-myristate 1 3-acetate (PMA). The inhibition of NF-kB activation by ceramide and PMA may be due to the activation of the protein kinase A (PKA) pathway by ceramide and the activation of the MAPK pathway by PMA.

Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a heart muscle disease that is characterized by progressive dilation and impaired contractile function of the left ventricle. The hallmark of DCM is dilatation of the left ventricle with normal or slightly increased wall thickness. The prognosis is poor, with a high incidence of sudden cardiac death. Familial forms of DCM are recognized in approximately 3 0% of patients with DCM. Genetic studies have revealed that mutations in at least 1 1 genes are responsible for familial DCM. These genes encode cytoskeletal / Z-disc proteins (actin, tropomyosin, desmin), a cytoskeletal / nuclear protein (Titin), a sarcomere protein (myosin), a calcium-handling protein (phospholamban), an energy metabolism protein (creatine kinase), an ion channel (sodium / potassium-transporting ATPase), and an extracellular matrix protein (laminin). The mutant proteins are thought to be responsible for the development of DCM through various mechanisms, including abnormal force generation, abnormal force transmission, abnormal force decay, abnormal intracellular calcium, abnormal calcium handling, and / or abnormal stretch response.

The Janus kinase (JAK) / signal transducers and activators of transcription (STAT) pathway is a key component of cytokine signaling. Cytokines bind to their cognate receptors and activate JAK kinases, which in turn phosphorylate and activate STAT transcription factors. The JAK / STAT pathway is conserved from insects to mammals and is involved in development, differentiation and proliferation of a variety of cell types. Constitutive activation of the JAK / STAT pathway has been implicated in a variety of human cancers.

The T cell receptor (TCR) is a multi-subunit complex that recognizes peptide antigens in the context of MHC molecules. The TCR is essential for the development and function of T cells. Engagement of the TCR by antigen-MHC complexes initiates a cascade of signaling events that lead to T cell activation and proliferation. The TCR complex is composed of two distinct families of proteins, the TCR-alpha and -beta chains and the CD3-gamma, -delta, -epsilon and -zeta chains. The CD3 chains are required for the expression of the TCR on the cell surface and are responsible for the signal transduction function of the TCR. The TCR-alpha and -beta chains are not required for TCR expression or signal transduction, but are required for the recognition of antigen. The CD3 chains are required for the initiation of signaling by the TCR and are responsible for the signal transduction function of the TCR. The CD3 chains associate with several other proteins to form the complete TCR complex. Upon TCR engagement by antigen-MHC, the src kinases Lck and Fyn phosphorylate the immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motifs (ITAMs) in the CD3 chains. Phosphorylation of the ITAMs creates docking sites for the tyrosine kinase ZAP7 0, which is activated by Lck and Fyn. Recruitment of ZAP7 0 to the TCR results in the phosphorylation and activation of downstream targets. The Tec family kinase Itk is also recruited to the TCR and may contribute to the activation of ZAP7 0. The downstream targets of ZAP7 0 include the adaptor protein LAT and the tyrosine kinase Sos-1. The activation of LAT and Sos-1 leads to the activation of the Ras pathway and the downstream kinases Erk and JNK. The activation of the transcription factors NFAT, AP-1 and NF-kB leads to the transcriptional activation of genes involved in T cell activation and proliferation.

The Hedgehog (Hh) family of secreted signaling proteins plays a key role in development of many different organ systems in both vertebrates and invertebrates. In vertebrates, Hh signaling is required for the development of the brain, the axial skeleton, the skin, and the lungs. Hh signaling is also involved in the development of several types of cancer. The protein ligands of Hh family bind to Patched (Ptc), a twelve-pass transmembrane protein, and to Smoothened (Smo), a seven-pass transmembrane protein. Binding of Hh to Ptc relieves Ptc-mediated inhibition of Smo, which in turn activates a signal transduction pathway that includes the Gli family of transcription factors.

The cell cycle is a sequence of events that includes DNA replication and mitosis. The G1 phase is the period of the cell cycle when cells prepare to enter S phase. The G2 phase is a period of preparation for mitosis. The M phase is the period of cell division. The transition from one phase to another is controlled by cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs). CDKs are a family of serine / threonine protein kinases that are activated by binding to a cyclin subunit. The activity of CDKs is regulated positively by cyclins and negatively by CDK inhibitors (CDKIs). The activity of CDKs is also regulated by phosphorylation and dephosphorylation. The activity of CDKs is required for the progression of the cell cycle from one phase to another. The transition from one phase to another is controlled by the concerted action of CDKs and CDKIs. The activity of CDKs is required for the progression of the cell cycle from one phase to another. The activity of CDKs is required for the G1 / S transition and the G2 / M transition. The activity of CDKs is also required for the progression of mitosis. The activity of CDKs is inhibited by CDKIs. CDKIs are a group of proteins that inhibit the activity of CDKs. There are two families of CDKIs: the INK4 family and the Kip / Cip family. The INK4 family of CDKIs includes p16INK4a, p15INK4b, p15INK4c and p103CDKIs are negative regulators of the cell cycle that include p15INK4b, p17Kip1, p27Kip1 and p21Cip1. The Kip / Cip family of CDKIs includes p300Kip1, p105Kip2, p27Kip1 and p132Kip1. p16INK4a is the first CDKI discovered. The p16INK4a / CDKI is a tumor suppressor gene that is frequently inactivated in human cancers.

Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) accounts for approximately 8 0% of all lung cancers. The most common histologic subtype of NSCLC is adenocarcinoma. Smoking is the most important risk factor for lung cancer. Adenocarcinomas are more common in smokers than in nonsmokers. Adenocarcinoma is more common in women than in men. Adenocarcinoma is more common in nonsmokers than in smokers. Adenocarcinomas are more common in women than in men. The incidence of adenocarcinoma has been increasing over the past several decades, particularly among women. The discovery of specific molecular changes in lung cancer has led to the development of new drugs that target these changes. These new drugs have improved the treatment of lung cancer and have the potential to further improve outcomes. The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a cell-surface receptor with an intracellular tyrosine kinase domain. Binding of ligand to the receptor leads to receptor dimerization and activation of downstream signaling pathways that promote cell proliferation and inhibit apoptosis. Activating mutations in the tyrosine kinase domain of the EGFR gene lead to ligand-independent activation of the receptor and downstream signaling. These mutations are more common in women, nonsmokers, and patients with adenocarcinoma. EGFR mutations are associated with a higher response rate to the EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors gefitinib and erlotinib than to standard chemotherapy. EGFR mutations are also associated with a longer progression-free survival and overall survival. The presence of EGFR mutations may be a useful predictor of response to these agents. KRAS mutations are associated with resistance to EGFR inhibitors. BRAF mutations are rare in NSCLC and are associated with a more aggressive clinical course. KRAS mutations are mutually exclusive of EGFR mutations. The anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) is a receptor tyrosine kinase that is normally expressed in the brain. Chromosomal translocations involving ALK lead to the formation of fusion proteins that have constitutive kinase activity. The echinoderm microtubule-associated protein-like 4 (EML4) gene has been identified as a fusion partner of ALK in NSCLC. The presence of EML4-ALK fusion proteins may identify a new molecular subset of NSCLC.

Lysosomes are membrane-delimited organelles in animal cells that contain more than 60 hydrolases involved in the degradation of macromolecules entering the cell via endocytosis, phagocytosis, or autophagy. The enzymes are packaged into membrane-bounded vesicles called lysosomes by a process that requires the action of the small GTPase Rab7. Lysosomes are acidified by the vacuolar-type ATPase (v-ATPase), which is a multisubunit protein complex. The proton gradient established by v-ATPase is used to drive the transport of other molecules into the lysosome lumen. The low pH is essential for the activity of lysosomal hydrolases and also for the maturation of lysosomal proteins. The formation of lysosomes is a multistep process that requires the participation of the clathrin-dependent and -independent pathways.

Interleukin-6 (IL-6) is a cytokine that plays a role in inflammation, the immune response, and hematopoiesis. IL-6 signals through a receptor complex that includes the IL-6 receptor alpha chain (IL-6Ralpha) and the signal transducing protein gp1 3 0. The cytoplasmic domain of gp1 3 0 is required for signaling, and contains a number of tyrosine residues that are phosphorylated upon IL-6 treatment. The tyrosine phosphorylation of gp1 3 0 leads to the activation of several signaling pathways, including the JAK / STAT pathway, the Ras / MAPK pathway, and the PI3 kinase pathway.

The induction of apoptosis by cytotoxic T cells is essential for the immune system to eliminate virus-infected cells. Cytotoxic T cells (CTLs) induce apoptosis in target cells by two distinct pathways. The first pathway is triggered by the interaction of the Fas ligand on the surface of the CTL with its receptor on the surface of the target cell. The second pathway is triggered by the perforin / granzyme proteins that are released from the CTL into the target cell's cytoplasm. Perforin forms a pore in the membrane of the target cell, allowing the granzyme proteases to enter the target cell. Granzyme A and B are the two major proteases released by CTLs. Granzyme A cleaves the caspase-3 protease, which leads to the degradation of cellular proteins and the induction of apoptosis. Granzyme B cleaves caspase-3, but also cleaves other caspases and other cellular proteins. The cleavage of caspase-3 by Granzyme B is an important step in the induction of apoptosis by CTLs. The induction of apoptosis by the perforin / granzyme pathway is essential for the immune system to eliminate virus-infected cells. The perforin / granzyme pathway is also used by other immune cells to kill target cells. The failure of the perforin-dependent immune response can lead to the uncontrolled growth of virus-infected cells and the development of autoimmune diseases.

Prion diseases are a group of neurodegenerative disorders that include Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), Gerstmann-Straüssler-Scheinker syndrome (GSS) and Kuru. The infectious agent responsible for prion diseases is thought to be PrPSc, an abnormal form of the prion protein (PrPC). The conversion of PrPC to PrPSc is a posttranslational process that occurs after PrPC has been synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). In sporadic CJD, the conversion of PrPC to PrPSc occurs spontaneously. In genetic CJD, GSS and familial CJD, mutations in the PRNP gene lead to an increased conversion of PrPC to PrPSc. The conversion of PrPC to PrPSc may lead to neuronal death through several different mechanisms. One possibility is that PrPSc accumulates in the ER, triggering an ER stress response. Another possibility is that PrPSc accumulates in lipid rafts, altering signal transduction pathways. A third possibility is that PrPSc may act as a template to convert normal PrPC to PrPSc, leading to a self-propagating process.

The immune system consists of two major cell types, the lymphocytes and the macrophages. Each type of cell responds to signals from the other cell type. Macrophages respond to bacterial products like LPS by secreting cytokines like IL-1 and IL-6. These cytokines stimulate the proliferation and differentiation of B cells and T cells. T cells respond to bacterial products like LPS by secreting IL-2 and IL-4. T cells also respond to antigen presented by MHC-II on the surface of antigen presenting cells (APCs). T cells respond to antigen presented by MHC-II by secreting IL-2 and other cytokines that stimulate the proliferation and differentiation of B cells. T cells also secrete a protein called CTLA-4 that binds to the same ligand as CD2 8 and blocks the costimulatory signal.

Protein ubiquitination plays an important role in a variety of biological processes, including protein degradation, cell cycle regulation, signal transduction, DNA repair, transcription, membrane trafficking, etc. The ubiquitination process is carried out by a cascade of reactions involving three classes of enzymes: ubiquitin activating enzyme (E1), ubiquitin conjugating enzyme (E2), and ubiquitin ligase (E3). E1 activates ubiquitin in an ATP-dependent manner and then transfers it to the active-site cysteine of a conjugating enzyme (E2). An E3 recognizes specific protein substrates and brings them into proximity with the E2 enzyme, which catalyzes the formation of an isopeptide bond between the C-terminal glycine of ubiquitin and the amino group of a lysine residue of the substrate protein. There are two major types of E3s: HECT (homologous to E6-AP C terminus) -type E3s and RING (really interesting new gene) -finger-type E3s. HECT-type E3s have a conserved cysteine residue that forms a thioester intermediate with ubiquitin during the reaction. They then transfer the ubiquitin to the substrate they are bound to, whereas the RING-finger-type E3s do not form a thioester intermediate. They function as scaffolds to bring the E2 and the substrate together and facilitate the transfer of ubiquitin from the E2 to the substrate.

The innate immune system provides the first line of defense against invading microorganisms. Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are pattern-recognition receptors that recognize conserved microbial structures called pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs). The signaling pathways activated by TLRs are similar to those induced by the T-cell receptor (TCR), and are dependent on the adaptor protein myeloid differentiation primary-response gene 8 8 (MyD8 8). The MyD8 8-dependent pathway leads to the activation of NF-kB and the production of proinflammatory cytokines, whereas the MyD8 8-independent pathway leads to the activation of interferon regulatory factor (IRF) and the production of interferon-alpha (IFN-alpha) and IFN-beta.

The actions of the peptide hormone, atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP), are mediated by a guanylyl cyclase-linked receptor (NPR-A) and a receptor with guanylate cyclase activity (NPR-C). The NPR-A receptor is found on the surface of essentially all cell types, whereas the NPR-C receptor is found in high density in the kidney, heart and adrenal medulla. The NPR-C receptor is also found in low density on platelets and in high density on adrenal cortical cells. ANP is released from atrial myocytes in response to increased blood volume, and acts to reduce blood pressure by a combination of diuretic, natriuretic and vasodilator actions. The major action of ANP is to reduce the volume of extracellular fluid by acting through the NPR-A receptor on the renal collecting duct to increase water and sodium excretion. The natriuretic response is mediated by cyclic GMP, which stimulates the opening of potassium and chloride channels, and the closure of the renal cortical Na + channel. The vasodilator actions of ANP are mediated by cyclic GMP and the subsequent activation of nitric oxide synthase and the production of cGMP in the vascular endothelium. The subsequent release of nitric oxide and activation of soluble guanylate cyclase in vascular smooth muscle cells leads to the formation of cGMP and the subsequent relaxation of vascular smooth muscle.

The cadherins are a family of calcium-dependent cell adhesion molecules that mediate cell-cell adhesion in a variety of cell types. The classical cadherins are involved in cell-cell adhesion in epithelial cells, neurons, and leukocytes. The classical cadherins are a family of transmembrane glycoproteins that mediate cell-cell adhesion by binding to the extracellular domain of another cadherin on an opposing cell. The intracellular domain of the cadherins interacts with a complex of proteins that link the cadherins to the cytoskeleton. The cadherins are a family of adhesion molecules that mediate cell-cell adhesion in a variety of cell types. The classical cadherins are involved in cell-cell adhesion in epithelial cells, neurons, and leukocytes. Allergy is an immune response to an antigen that causes an individual to become sensitized to that antigen. The response is mediated by IgE antibodies that bind to antigen on mast cells and other cells. The antigen is taken up by the cells and presented to T cells in the context of MHC class II molecules. The T cell receptor recognizes the complex of antigen, MHC class II, and a peptide derived from the antigen. The T cell response is regulated by cytokines produced by other cells in the immune system. IL-4 and IL-5 are important in the development of eosinophils. IL-3 and GM-CSF stimulate the proliferation of eosinophils.

Nerve growth factor (NGF) is a member of the neurotrophin family of growth factors that promotes neuronal survival and growth. NGF is expressed in the skin and is released by keratinocytes to act on neurons in the skin. NGF binds to TrkA, a receptor tyrosine kinase, on the surface of sensory neurons and activates signaling pathways that promote neuronal survival and growth. NGF also binds to the p75 neurotrophin receptor (p75NTR), a member of the tumor necrosis factor receptor gene family, and this binding can either enhance or inhibit NGF signaling. Binding of NGF to TrkA activates the Ras / Map kinase pathway and the PI3 kinase pathway to promote neuronal survival and growth. NGF binding to p75NTR can activate the Map kinase pathway and PI3 kinase pathway to promote neuronal survival and growth. NGF also induces the expression of p75NTR and TrkA through a positive feedback loop. The p75NTR can also be activated by the p75NTR-signaling molecule B-cell activating factor (BAFF) to promote neuronal survival and growth. NGF also activates the Map kinase pathway and PI3 kinase pathway to promote neuronal differentiation. NGF signaling through TrkA and p75NTR can also activate the JAK / Stat pathway to promote neuronal survival and growth.

The estrogen receptor (ER) is a member of the steroid hormone receptor gene family that includes the glucocorticoid, progesterone, androgen, and mineralocorticoid receptors. The ER is a ligand-dependent transcription factor that regulates the expression of target genes in a cell- and tissue-specific manner. The estrogen receptor is expressed in two forms, ERalpha and ERbeta, which are encoded by distinct genes. The two receptors share 9 7% homology in their DNA binding domains and 5 9% in their ligand binding domains. The estrogen receptor is expressed in a variety of tissues including the uterus, ovaries, bone, and the breast. The estrogen receptor is activated by binding to estrogen, which induces a conformational change in the receptor that allows it to bind to estrogen response elements (EREs) in the promoter regions of estrogen-responsive genes. The estrogen receptor can also regulate gene expression through a non-classical mechanism that does not involve direct binding to DNA. The estrogen receptor can interact with other transcription factors such as AP-1 and Sp1 to regulate gene expression. The estrogen receptor can also regulate gene expression through a protein-protein interaction with other signaling pathways. The interaction of the estrogen receptor with the c-Src tyrosine kinase and the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway has been well studied. The estrogen receptor can interact with c-Src through the MAPK scaffolding protein, MNAR. The interaction of the estrogen receptor with MNAR allows estrogen to activate c-Src and the MAPK pathway in a rapid, non-nuclear estrogen receptor-dependent manner. The interaction of the estrogen receptor with Shc and the activation of the MAPK pathway also occurs through Shc. The interaction of the estrogen receptor with the MAPK pathway also occurs through Shc. The interaction of the estrogen receptor with Shc allows estrogen to activate the MAPK pathway in a non-nuclear estrogen receptor-dependent manner. The interaction of the estrogen receptor with the MAPK pathway also occurs through Shc. The interaction of the estrogen receptor with Shc also allows estrogen to activate the phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) pathway. The interaction of the estrogen receptor with Shc and the activation of the MAPK and PI3K pathways allows estrogen to regulate cellular proliferation and survival. The interaction of the estrogen receptor with MNAR also allows estrogen to regulate cellular proliferation and survival. The interaction of the estrogen receptor with MNAR also allows estrogen to activate the MAPK pathway. The interaction of the estrogen receptor with Shc and MNAR also allows estrogen to regulate cellular proliferation and survival. The interaction of the estrogen receptor with MNAR also allows estrogen to regulate the expression of some estrogen-responsive genes in a non-nuclear estrogen receptor-dependent manner. The interaction of the estrogen receptor with Shc and MNAR also allows estrogen to regulate cellular proliferation and survival.

The PML nuclear bodies (PML-NBs) are discrete nuclear substructures that are disrupted in acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) by the PML-RARalpha fusion protein. PML-NBs are associated with a variety of cellular processes including apoptosis, transcriptional regulation, DNA repair and cell cycle control. The PML protein is a key component of PML-NBs and is essential for the formation of PML-NBs. The p53 tumor suppressor protein is another key component of PML-NBs. The PML-RARalpha fusion protein disrupts the formation of PML-NBs and sequesters p53 in the fusion protein-containing nuclear bodies. The disruption of PML-NBs and the sequestration of p53 by the PML-RARalpha fusion protein may contribute to the pathogenesis of APL. The Fas ligand (FasL) is a member of the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) family. Fas is a cell surface receptor that induces apoptosis in cells that are triggered to express Fas ligand. The Fas-FasL interaction plays an important role in the immune system by inducing apoptosis in activated T cells and cytotoxic T cells. PML-NBs are associated with the Fas apoptotic pathway. PML-NBs may regulate Fas-mediated apoptosis by controlling the expression of Fas and / or by regulating the Fas-mediated apoptotic signaling pathway. The Fas-mediated apoptosis is also regulated by the p53 tumor suppressor protein. The PML-RARalpha fusion protein represses the expression of p53 and represses Fas-mediated apoptosis. The disruption of PML-NBs and the sequestration of p53 by the PML-RARalpha fusion protein may contribute to the pathogenesis of APL.

The ATM gene encodes a protein kinase that is mutated in the cancer-prone disorder ataxia telangiectasia (AT). ATM is activated by ionizing radiation and other DNA damaging agents, and initiates a signal transduction pathway that leads to cell cycle arrest and DNA repair or apoptosis. ATM phosphorylates and activates chk1 and chk2, which phosphorylate and inactivate the p21 protein, allowing progression through the cell cycle. ATM also phosphorylates and activates the tumor suppressor gene product p5 3, which induces cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in response to DNA damage. ATM also phosphorylates and activates the tumor suppressor gene product BRCA1, which is involved in DNA repair and checkpoint control. The importance of ATM in maintaining genomic integrity is demonstrated by the high incidence of cancer in AT patients and the early onset of cancer in AT patients who are homozygous for ATM mutations. The breast cancer susceptibility gene BRCA1 encodes a nuclear phosphoprotein that is involved in DNA repair and transcriptional regulation. BRCA1 interacts with the ATM kinase and may be a target of ATM phosphorylation. The abl oncogene is involved in cellular transformation and is mutated in some leukemias and breast cancer. The p53 gene product is a tumor suppressor that mediates growth arrest and apoptosis in response to DNA damage. The p53 protein interacts with the ATM kinase and may be a target of ATM phosphorylation. The NFkB transcription factor regulates genes involved in inflammation and immune response, including the expression of cytokines such as TNF-alpha. The NFkB complex is held in the cytoplasm by binding of the IkB inhibitory proteins. Activation of NFkB involves phosphorylation of IkB by the IKb kinase, leading to its ubiquitination and degradation by the proteosome, and subsequent translocation to the nucleus.

The transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) family of cytokines regulates cellular proliferation and differentiation. TGF-beta inhibits the growth of many cell types, including B and T lymphocytes. TGF-beta also induces apoptosis in some cell types. TGF-beta signals through a complex of serine-threonine kinases, including the type II TGF-beta receptor (TbetaR-II), which phosphorylates and activates the type I TGF-beta receptor (TbetaR-I). The activated TbetaR-I phosphorylates the transcription factors SMAD2 and SMAD3, which then associate with the common mediator SMAD4. Phosphorylated SMAD2 and SMAD3 associate with the co-activator CBP / p3 0 0 and other transcriptional regulators to activate transcription. The SMAD proteins are structurally related to Drosophila MAD (mothers against decapentaplegic) and are involved in signaling by other members of the TGF-beta family, including activins, nodals and bone morphogenetic proteins. The SMAD proteins are also involved in signaling by other pathways, including the interferon-response pathway and the Wnt pathway. SMADs are phosphorylated and activated by receptors for these other pathways, but they also interact with other signaling pathways. The SMADs regulate transcription by interacting with other transcription factors, including the homeodomain proteins of the Hox gene family, the paired box proteins involved in development of the midbrain and hindbrain, and the forkhead transcription factor FKHR-L1 involved in development of the liver. SMADs also interact with other transcription factors, including the Ets family transcription factor EGR-1, the bHLH transcription factor Mad, and the NFAT family of transcription factors. The interaction of SMADs with other transcription factors provides a mechanism for integrating different signaling pathways.

The transcription factor NF-kB is a key regulator of genes involved in inflammation, apoptosis, cell survival, and the immune response. In the absence of a stimulus, NF-kB is retained in the cytoplasm by association with the inhibitor IkB. Various stimuli, including inflammatory cytokines, activate the IkB kinase (IKK) complex, which phosphorylates IkB, leading to its degradation by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. NF-kB is then free to translocate into the nucleus and activate transcription. The TRAF family of proteins are involved in the activation of NF-kB by TNF and other members of the TNF receptor gene family. TRAF2 and TRAF6 are involved in the activation of NF-kB by TNF and other members of the TNF receptor gene family, while TRAF1 is not involved in this pathway. The TRAF proteins themselves are involved in the activation of NF-kB by other receptors, including the CD4 0 receptor, and also in the activation of other signaling pathways. The activation of NF-kB by TNF and other members of the TNF receptor gene family is blocked by the protein kinase RIP, a member of the IRAK family of proteins. RIP interacts with the TRAF proteins involved in NF-kB activation by TNF receptors, but also interacts with the kinase domain of RIP to activate NF-kB. The kinase activity of RIP is required for NF-kB activation, but the target of RIP kinase activity in this pathway is not yet known. The protein kinase MEKK1 is also involved in NF-kB activation by TNF, but MEKK1 does not appear to interact with the TRAF proteins involved in NF-kB activation by TNF. MEKK1 activates the MAP kinase kinase kinase MKK3, which activates the kinase p38, leading to the activation of NF-kB. MEKK1 also activates the JNK kinase MKK4, which activates JNK, and MKK4 is involved in NF-kB activation by TNF. The protein kinase Tpl-2 also activates NF-kB, but does not appear to activate the JNK pathway. The activation of NF-kB by TNF and other members of the TNF receptor gene family is a key component of the inflammatory response, and is blocked by the TNF receptor family member osteoprotegerin, which acts as an inhibitor of bone resorption. The inhibition of bone resorption by osteoprotegerin may be due in part to the inhibition of the activation of NF-kB by TNF.

Base excision repair (BER) is the predominant pathway for the repair of small base lesions in DNA. BER is initiated by the lesion-specific DNA glycosylase, which recognizes and excises the damaged base. The resulting apurinic / apyrimidinic (AP) site is recognized and incised by an AP endonuclease, creating a single-strand break with 3 '-hydroxyl and 5' -dRP termini. The repair of the 5 '-blocking group is then completed by the sequential actions of DNA polymerase and DNA ligase. BER can also be sub-classified as short-patch BER (repair in one nucleotide) or long-patch BER (repair in 2-1 3 nucleotides). DNA polymerase beta (pol beta) is the major DNA polymerase involved in short-patch BER. DNA ligase I (or DNA ligase III) is then recruited by pol beta and seals the nick. DNA glycosylases that recognize and remove larger lesions, such as N-methyl purine DNA glycosylase (MPG), are involved in long-patch BER. PCNA and FEN-1 are required for the strand displacement synthesis and the formation of the ligatable nick.

The heart is a highly vascularized organ with a constant blood supply. The heart is composed of four chambers, the atria and ventricles, which are separated by septa that contain the conduction system. The ventricles are the largest chambers of the heart and are responsible for pumping blood throughout the body. The atria are the smallest chambers, and are responsible for the production of the majority of the cardiac output. The heart is a complex organ with multiple functions. The ventricles pump blood throughout the body, while the atria are responsible for the production of the cardiac impulse. The conduction system is responsible for the coordination of the heart's contraction and the maintenance of the heart rate. The heart is also responsible for the production of the pressure that pumps blood throughout the body. The heart is a complex organ with multiple functions. Blood coagulation or clotting is a series of biochemical reactions that leads to the formation of a clot at the site of vascular injury. The clotting cascade begins with the activation of prothrombin by the enzyme thrombin. The activation of prothrombin is initiated by the interaction of the clotting factors with the tissue factor (TF), a protein in the vascular wall exposed to the blood stream in response to vascular injury. The activation of prothrombin by the TF-factor VIIa complex is enhanced by the presence of the coagulation factors V and X and the coagulation factors VII, VIII, and IX. The activation of prothrombin by the TF-factor VIIa complex is inhibited by the protein C pathway. The protein C pathway is a negative feedback system for the regulation of blood coagulation. The protein C zymogen is activated by the thrombin-thrombomodulin complex. The activated protein C (APC) in the presence of the protein S cofactor inhibits the activation of factors V and VIII by the TF-factor VIIa complex. The inhibition of the TF-factor VIIa complex by the protein C pathway is enhanced by heparin.

The binding of beta-arrestins to agonist-occupied GPCRs leads to the activation of Src and the subsequent phosphorylation of the ERK1 / 2 MAP kinases. This pathway is independent of G-protein activation and is mediated by beta-arrestin scaffolding of Src and the Raf1 kinase. The activation of ERK1 / 2 MAP kinases by the beta-arrestin-Src complex leads to the regulation of a variety of cellular responses, including gene transcription, cell proliferation, and chemotaxis.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that leads to the loss of neurons in the cerebral cortex and hippocampus. The two major pathological hallmarks of AD are senile plaques and neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs). Senile plaques are mainly composed of amyloid-beta (Abeta) peptides, which are derived from amyloid precursor protein (APP) by beta- and gamma-secretase cleavage. NFTs are composed of paired helical filaments (PHFs) that are abnormally hyperphosphorylated tau. The amyloid cascade hypothesis states that the deposition of amyloid-beta (Abeta) peptides in the brain is the primary event that triggers a pathogenic cascade that leads to neuronal death. The accumulation of Abeta peptides in the extracellular space may lead to neuronal death through several mechanisms, including the generation of free radicals, calcium (Ca2 +) dysregulation, and mitochondrial dysfunction. Ca2 + dyshomeostasis may be caused by either Abeta oligomers or Abeta fibrils. Abeta oligomers may enter the cell and interact with the membrane, forming cation channels. Alternatively, Abeta oligomers may bind to the prion protein (PrP C), which then interacts with the metabotropic glutamate receptor 5 (mGluR5) to trigger Ca2 + influx. Abeta fibrils may interact with PrP C and activate mGluR5, which leads to the activation of Fyn kinase and the subsequent phosphorylation of tau. Fyn may also contribute to the abnormal phosphorylation of tau by activating cyclin-dependent kinase 5 (cdk5). Hyperphosphorylation of tau may lead to destabilization of microtubules and inhibition of axonal transport. Mitochondria are essential for neuronal function and survival. They produce energy in the form of ATP through oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS), and they play a key role in Ca2 + homeostasis. Mitochondrial dysfunction may lead to the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and reactive nitrogen species (RNS), which may further damage mitochondria and other cellular components.

The attachment of a protein to the cell membrane via a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor. The anchor is attached to the C-terminus of proteins in the lumen of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) by a GPI transamidase complex. In yeast, the GPI anchor is synthesized on the cytoplasmic side of the ER membrane by a pathway involving at least 1 0 different gene products. The core GPI structure is conserved from protozoa to mammals. In mammals, the GPI structure is attached to proteins by the sequential addition of sugars, phosphoethanolamine, and fatty acids.

The BCR gene encodes a protein of approximately 2 1 0 kDa that is a critical component of the B cell receptor (BCR) complex. The BCR complex is found on the surface of all mature B cells and is involved in B cell activation and development. The BCR complex is composed of immunoglobulin (Ig) heavy and light chains, and two heterodimers of the Ig-alpha and Ig-beta proteins. The cytoplasmic domain of the BCR contains several tyrosine residues that are phosphorylated upon BCR ligation and that serve as binding sites for proteins containing SH2 domains. The tyrosine kinase Lyn phosphorylates the Ig-alpha and Ig-beta proteins, creating binding sites for the SH2 domains of the GRB2 and Sos-1 proteins. GRB2 and Sos-1 activate Ras, which in turn activates the Raf / MEK / ERK kinase cascade and leads to the activation of transcription factors such as ELK-1 and c-Jun. The transcription factor NF-AT is also activated by BCR ligation and contributes to the induction of genes such as the IL-2 gene. The tyrosine kinase Syk also contributes to BCR signaling, phosphorylating downstream targets including BLNK, PLCg, and the adaptor protein Vav. The tyrosine kinase Btk contributes to BCR signaling, as mutations in the human btk gene cause X-linked agammaglobulinemia, a disease in which the development of B cells is blocked at the pre-B cell stage. The adaptor protein Nck binds to the tyrosine phosphorylated BCR complex and may link BCR signaling to the actin cytoskeleton. The BCR also signals through the MAP kinase pathway, leading to the activation of the transcription factors ELK-1 and c-Jun. The serine / threonine kinase AKT also contributes to BCR signaling, phosphorylating the transcription factor FKHR-L1. The BCR activates a variety of signaling pathways, some of which are opposed by others. The balance of these opposing signals may determine the fate of the cell.

HGF / SF is a multifunctional cytokine that stimulates cell motility, morphogenesis, and proliferation in a variety of cell types. The biological activities of HGF are mediated by the c-Met receptor tyrosine kinase. HGF binding to c-Met induces receptor dimerization and activation of downstream signaling pathways including the MAPK pathway, PI-3 kinase pathway, and the Stat pathway. These signaling pathways ultimately regulate gene expression and cellular responses.

Translation is the process of protein synthesis from a mRNA molecule. It begins with the binding of a methionine-containing initiation factor (usually eIF1, eIF1A, and eIF2) to the 4 0S ribosomal subunit. The binding of the ternary complex (eIF2-GTP-Met-tRNA) then occurs, and the 6 0S subunit joins to form the 4 8S initiation complex. The binding of a 6 0S subunit to this complex then leads to the hydrolysis of the GTP bound to eIF2, releasing the factors and leaving the ribosome in the now-stable complex with an active site for elongation. The elongation cycle begins with the binding of a ternary complex to the ribosome, followed by GTP hydrolysis, and the release of the ternary complex. The next amino acid is then added, and the cycle repeats until the complete sequence of amino acids is reached.

The allergic response is initiated by the interaction of immunoglobulin E (IgE) with allergens. The binding of allergen to IgE on the cell surface of mast cells and basophils leads to the activation of these cells and the release of inflammatory mediators. Type I hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by IgE and mast cells. Type I hypersensitivity reactions are characterized by the immediate release of mediators from mast cells and basophils and are associated with the symptoms of hives, itching, and edema. Type I hypersensitivity reactions are initiated by the crosslinking of high-affinity IgE receptors (FcERI) on the surface of mast cells and basophils by allergens. Crosslinking of IgE-FcERI complexes leads to the activation of signaling pathways that result in the release of preformed mediators from intracellular granules and the de novo synthesis and release of lipid mediators, cytokines, and chemokines. The activation of mast cells and basophils by allergens leads to the release of preformed mediators that cause the early symptoms of type I hypersensitivity reactions. The activation of mast cells and basophils also leads to the production and release of lipid mediators, cytokines, and chemokines that contribute to the late phase and the progression of the allergic response. The late phase response is characterized by the infiltration of inflammatory cells, such as eosinophils, neutrophils, and lymphocytes, into tissues and the increased expression of adhesion molecules on the vascular endothelium. The late phase of the allergic response is often associated with the symptoms of hives, itching, and edema. The late phase response is believed to be mediated by the same mediators that cause the immediate response, but in a delayed manner.

The angiogenic process is a complex cascade of events that lead to the formation of new blood vessels. The angiogenic switch is a critical control point in the formation of new blood vessels and is regulated by a balance of pro- and anti-angiogenic factors. The angiogenic factors include vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), fibroblast growth factor (FGF), platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF), and others. The angiogenic inhibitors include thrombospondin-1 (TSP-1), angiostatin, and others. The angiogenic process is also regulated by hypoxia. The angiogenic factors stimulate endothelial cell proliferation, migration, and tube formation. The angiogenic inhibitors inhibit these processes. The angiogenic factors are upregulated by hypoxia and by oncogenes. The angiogenic factors are produced by tumor cells and by cells in the tumor stroma, including fibroblasts, macrophages, and mast cells. The angiogenic factors are upregulated by hypoxia and by oncogenes. The angiogenic factors stimulate angiogenesis by binding to their receptors on endothelial cells. The VEGF receptor is a tyrosine kinase receptor that signals through the ras / MAP kinase pathway to induce endothelial cell proliferation. The PDGF receptor is a tyrosine kinase and signals through the PI3 kinase pathway to induce endothelial cell proliferation and migration. The FGF receptor is a tyrosine kinase and signals through the ras / MAP kinase and PI3 kinase pathways to induce endothelial cell proliferation and migration. The angiogenic factors also induce the expression of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), which degrade the extracellular matrix and allow endothelial cell migration and tube formation. The angiogenic inhibitors inhibit endothelial cell proliferation and migration by binding to their receptors and blocking downstream signaling. The angiogenic factors are upregulated by hypoxia and by oncogenes. The angiogenic factors are upregulated by hypoxia and by oncogenes. The angiogenic inhibitors are downregulated by hypoxia and by oncogenes. The angiogenic factors are produced by tumor cells and by cells in the tumor stroma, including fibroblasts, macrophages, and mast cells. The angiogenic factors are upregulated by hypoxia and by oncogenes. The angiogenic inhibitors are downregulated by hypoxia and by oncogenes.

Epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) is a process by which polarized epithelial cells undergo a transition to a more motile mesenchymal phenotype. This process occurs during embryonic development and is also involved in tissue regeneration and cancer progression. During EMT, epithelial cells lose their polarity and cell-cell adhesion, and gain the ability to migrate and invade. The hallmark of EMT is the loss of E-cadherin expression and the subsequent translocation of beta-catenin from the cell membrane to the nucleus. The loss of E-cadherin expression is mediated by transcriptional repressors such as Snail, Slug and ZEB1. These transcriptional repressors bind to E-boxes in the E-cadherin promoter and recruit histone deacetylases and methylases to repress E-cadherin expression. The beta-catenin translocates to the nucleus and acts as a transcriptional coactivator with LEF / TCF family proteins to induce the expression of genes involved in cell motility and proliferation. Secreted factors such as TGF-beta and EGF induce EMT. TGF-beta induces EMT through the Smad pathway and also through the MAP kinase pathway. EGF induces EMT through the Ras / Rac / JNK pathway.

The conversion of glucose to glycogen is a key metabolic pathway that is regulated by multiple enzymes. The first step of this pathway is the phosphorylation of glucose by hexokinase (HK) to form glucose-6-phosphate (G6P). G6P is then converted to glucose-1-phosphate (G1P) by phosphoglucomutase (PGM), and finally to glucose-6-phosphate (G6P) by glucose-6-phosphate isomerase (GPI). The next step is the phosphorylation of G1P by phosphoglucomutase (PGM) to produce glucose-1, 6-bisphosphate (G6P), which is converted to glucose-6-phosphate (G6P) by phosphoglucomutase (PGM). The last step is the conversion of glucose-1, 6-bisphosphate (G6P) to glucose-6-phosphate (G6P) by glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD). G6P is converted to fructose-6-phosphate (F6P) by phosphofructokinase (PFK), and F6P is isomerized to fructose-1, 6-bisphosphate (F1, 6BP) by phosphofructokinase (PFK). F1, 6BP is isomerized to glucose-1, 6-bisphosphate (G1, 6BP) by triosephosphate isomerase (TPI). The next step is the conversion of glucose-1, 6-bisphosphate (G1, 6BP) to fructose-6-phosphate (F6P) by phosphofructokinase (PFK). The next step is the conversion of F6P to fructose-1, 6-bisphosphate (F1, 6BP) by phosphofructokinase (PFK). The next step is the conversion of F6P to fructose-1, 6-bisphosphate (F1, 6BP) by phosphofructokinase (PFK). The next step is the conversion of F1, 6BP to glucose-6-phosphate (G6P) by 6-phosphofructokinase (PFK). The next step is the conversion of G6P to glucose-1-phosphate (G1P) by glucose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase (UGT). The next step is the conversion of G1P to glucose-6-phosphate (G6P) by glucose-6-phosphate phosphatase (G6Pase). The next step is the conversion of G6P to fructose-1, 6-bisphosphate (F1, 6BP) by 6-phosphofructokinase (PFK). The next step is the conversion of F1, 6BP to fructose-1, 6-bisphosphate (F1, 6BP) by phosphofructokinase (PFK). The next step is the conversion of F1, 6BP to glucose-6-phosphate (G6P) by glucose-6-phosphate isomerase (GPI). The next step is the conversion of G6P to glucose by glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD). The next step is the conversion of G6P to fructose-6-phosphate (F6P) by glucose-6-phosphate isomerase (GPI). The next step is the conversion of F6P to fructose-1, 6-bisphosphate (F1, 6BP) by phosphofructokinase (PFK). The next step is the conversion of F6P to glucose-1-phosphate (G1P) by glucose-6-phosphate isomerase (GPI). The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a transmembrane tyrosine kinase receptor that is activated by binding of its ligand, epidermal growth factor (EGF) or transforming growth factor-alpha (TGF-alpha). Binding of ligand to the receptor leads to receptor dimerization, activation of the receptor tyrosine kinase, and autophosphorylation of the receptor and recruitment of signaling molecules to the activated receptor. These signaling molecules include the Ras / Raf / MEK / ERK kinase cascade and the PI3 kinase / Akt pathway. These pathways ultimately result in changes in gene expression that promote cell proliferation and inhibit apoptosis. Mutations in the EGFR gene or in genes that regulate its signaling have been identified in a subset of non-small cell lung cancers (NSCLC). NSCLC that overexpress EGFR are more likely to respond to EGFR inhibitors such as gefitinib or erlotinib. Mutations in the EGFR gene are associated with a higher response rate to gefitinib or erlotinib.

Cartilage is a specialized tissue that provides a favorable environment for the immobilization of the joints. The extracellular matrix (ECM) of cartilage consists primarily of collagen type II and proteoglycan aggregates of hyaluronan and link proteins. The chondrocytes are surrounded by a thin layer of type I collagen and are attached to each other by specialized cell-surface structures, the cell-matrix adhesions known as focal adhesions. These structures are primarily formed by integrins, heterodimeric transmembrane glycoproteins that bind to the ECM proteins. The binding of ECM proteins to integrins activates several signaling pathways, including the Ras-mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway, the phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI-3K) pathway and the RhoA-Rho-associated coiled-coil-containing protein kinase (ROCK) pathway. These pathways regulate chondrocyte proliferation and differentiation.

The amyloid beta peptide (A beta), a proteolytic fragment of amyloid precursor protein (APP), is the major component of senile plaques in the brains of patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD). APP is a type-1 integral membrane protein with a large extracellular domain, a single transmembrane domain, and a short cytoplasmic domain. APP is cleaved by two different proteases, the beta-secretase and the gamma-secretase, to release A beta. The beta-secretase cleavage occurs in the extracellular domain of APP and liberates a soluble fragment, sA beta, and a membrane-bound C-terminal fragment, C9 9. The gamma-secretase cleavage occurs within the membrane domain of C9 9 and releases A beta and a cytoplasmic fragment, APP intracellular domain. sA beta is the major component of senile plaques and is neurotoxic. The APP intracellular domain may also have a role in the pathogenesis of AD. The second cleavage of APP by gamma-secretase is thought to be involved in the regulation of the level of APP. The third cleavage of APP by gamma-secretase is the final step in the production of A beta. Mutations in APP or in presenilin-1 (PS-1), a component of the gamma-secretase complex, cause early-onset familial AD (FAD). Mutations in PS-1 increase the ratio of A beta4 2 to A beta4 0, the longer form of A beta that is more amyloidogenic and more prone to form amyloid deposits. The deposition of amyloid in senile plaques and the formation of neurofibrillary tangles are the two major pathological hallmarks of AD. The mucosal immune system is the first line of defense against invading pathogens. It consists of a single layer of epithelial cells that line the mucosal surfaces and a network of immune cells that are distributed in the lamina propria. The epithelial cells provide a physical barrier to the external environment and also act as antigen-presenting cells (APCs). The APCs, in concert with other cells of the immune system, induce antigen-specific immune responses. The APCs take up foreign antigens and present them to T cells in the lymphoid tissues. The activated T cells in turn activate other immune cells to produce immune responses.

The allergic response is a complex response involving the interaction of many different cell types. Antigen-presenting cells, or macrophages, are required for the activation of T cells in the allergic response. T cells activated by antigen-presenting cells produce a variety of cytokines that stimulate the response of other cell types. The cytokines produced by T cells include IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13, which stimulate the proliferation and activation of eosinophils, the cells that cause the tissue damage in allergic diseases. Eosinophils are involved in a variety of responses, including the immune response, inflammation, and parasitic infection. Eosinophils are also involved in the immune response through the production of cytokines such as IL-5. IL-5 stimulates the production of other cytokines, including IL-4 and interferon-gamma, that are involved in the allergic response. IL-5 also stimulates the production of eosinophils, which are involved in the immune response and inflammation. IL-5 is produced by activated T cells and other cell types. The interaction of IL-5 with its receptor on eosinophils stimulates eosinophil proliferation and activation.

The Hedgehog (Hh) family of secreted signaling proteins plays a critical role in development of many different organ systems in vertebrates. The Hh signal is transduced by binding to Patched (Ptc), a twelve-transmembrane protein, releasing the inhibition of Smoothened (Smo). Hh signaling is involved in the development of the central nervous system, the development of the face, the limb, the myotome, and the lungs. Mutations in components of the Hh pathway have been implicated in several human congenital malformations.

Hypoxia is a reduction in tissue oxygen tension that can occur in a number of settings, including development, ischemia, and cancer. Cells respond to hypoxia by increasing the expression of genes involved in oxygen delivery and metabolism, and decreasing the expression of genes involved in proliferation and growth. The hypoxia-inducible factor-1 (HIF-1) is a transcription factor that plays a key role in the cellular response to hypoxia. HIF-1 is a heterodimer consisting of HIF-1alpha and ARNT subunits. HIF-1 is stabilized and activated by hypoxia, and activates transcription of genes containing hypoxia response elements (HREs). HIF-1 is also activated by the oncogene product p53, and the tumor suppressor p300. HIF-1 activates transcription of genes involved in oxygen delivery, such as erythropoietin (EPO), vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), and glycolytic enzymes. HIF-1 also activates genes involved in proliferation and growth, such as p53 and p300. p53 and p300activate genes such as MDM2, which targets p53 for degradation, and CDKN1A, which encodes the cell cycle inhibitor p15. p53 and HIF-1 also activate genes such as BNIP3, which induces apoptosis in response to hypoxia. HIF-1 also represses transcription of genes such as those encoding transferrin receptor (TfR) and heme oxygenase (HO-1).

Eph receptors are a family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) that are activated by their membrane-bound ligands, ephrins. Eph receptors and ephrins are involved in a variety of developmental processes, including cell migration, axon guidance, and tissue boundary formation. The Eph family is divided into two groups, A and B, based on sequence homology and ligand binding. Eph receptors are single pass transmembrane proteins with an extracellular domain that binds ephrins and an intracellular tyrosine kinase domain. The ephrins are also single-pass transmembrane proteins, with an extracellular domain that binds Eph receptors and an intracellular domain that contains a conserved cytoplasmic tail. The ephrins are divided into two groups, A and B, based on sequence homology and binding affinity. The A-ephrins are expressed on the surface of adjacent cells and bind the Eph receptors with high affinity. The interaction between Eph receptors and ephrins is bidirectional, with both the receptor and ligand having signaling activity. Apoptosis is a genetically controlled cellular suicide mechanism that removes damaged or unwanted cells. The Bcl-2 family of proteins regulates apoptosis through the mitochondrial pathway. Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL promote cell survival, whereas Bax and Bad promote apoptosis. Bad is phosphorylated by AKT, which leads to its inactivation and retention in the cytosol. Bad interacts with Bcl-xL and Bcl-2 to block their anti-apoptotic function. When dephosphorylated, Bad interacts with Bcl-xL and Bcl-2 to induce apoptosis. The activity of Bax and Bid are regulated by phosphorylation / dephosphorylation. Bax is phosphorylated by AKT and this phosphorylation inhibits its pro-apoptotic activity. Bid is dephosphorylated by a protease activated during apoptosis, and this promotes its pro-apoptotic activity. Other Bcl-2 family members are not regulated by phosphorylation. The tumor suppressor protein p53 is also a regulator of apoptosis. p53 is a transcription factor that induces apoptosis in response to DNA damage. The mechanism by which p53 induces apoptosis is not clear, but it may act through the Bcl-2 family of proteins.

Calpain is a calcium-dependent neutral protease that is involved in a variety of cellular functions, including cell motility, adhesion, and apoptosis. The activity of calpain is regulated by calcium and by the inhibitory subunit calpastatin. The activation of calpain is associated with the cleavage of its regulatory subunit. The interleukin-2 receptor (IL-2R) is a key regulator of the immune response. The IL-2R is composed of three chains, alpha (CD25), beta (CDRB25) and gamma (CDGG25). The IL-2R is expressed on activated T cells and is essential for T cell proliferation in response to antigen stimulation. The IL-2R is also expressed on NK cells and some T cell lines. The IL-2R is a member of the cytokine receptor gene family and is related in structure to the IL-3 and IL-5 receptors. The IL-2R is distinct from the other cytokine receptors in that it does not themselves have a kinase domain. The IL-2R gamma chain is essential for IL-2 signaling and is also a component of the IL-3 and IL-5 receptors. The beta chain is also a component of the IL-3 and IL-5 receptors. The IL-2R alpha chain is not required for IL-2 signaling but is required for high affinity IL-2 binding. The beta chain is essential for IL-2 signaling and is also a component of the IL-3 and IL-5 receptors. The IL-2R activates several different signaling pathways including JAK / STAT, Ras / Map kinase and PI3 kinase. The JAK / STAT pathway is activated by IL-2 through the tyrosine phosphorylation of the beta chain and the activation of JAK1 and JAK3. The Map kinase pathway is also activated by IL-2 through the phosphorylation of Shc and the activation of map kinase. PI3 kinase is also activated by IL-2 and appears to play a role in the activation of the Ras / Map kinase pathway. The activation of these pathways leads to the activation of transcription factors such as AP-1 and NF- kappa B. The transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) superfamily consists of at least four closely related members, TGF-beta 1, TGF-beta 2, TGF-beta 3 and bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs), which are involved in a wide variety of biological processes, including cell proliferation, differentiation, apoptosis, migration and extracellular matrix formation. TGF-beta 1 is a potent growth inhibitor of many cell types, including epithelial cells. The TGF-beta 1 signaling pathway is complex and involves the activation of SMAD proteins, MAPK and Rho family GTPases.

DNA mismatch repair (MMR) is a highly conserved system that plays a critical role in maintaining genomic stability. MMR corrects DNA mismatches generated during replication and prevents mutations from becoming permanent in the genome. Defects in MMR are associated with genome-wide increases in mutation rates and predisposition to cancer. In Escherichia coli, MMR is initiated by the mismatch-activated MutS-MutL-ATP complex. This complex recruits and activates the MutH endonuclease, which nicks the unmethylated daughter strand at a hemimethylated GATC sequence. The nick in the unmethylated strand is then used as a signal to direct excision of the error-containing DNA strand by the UvrD, MutH, and exonuclease I proteins. DNA polymerase III and DNA ligase then resynthesize the repaired DNA molecule. In bacteria like E. coli, MMR is essential for viability. In humans, MMR is not essential, but defects in MMR are associated with genome-wide instability and predisposition to cancer. Human MMR proteins are highly conserved with E. coli MutS and MutL homologs. Human MMR proteins are similar in function and mechanism to their E. coli counterparts.

The Hedgehog (Hh) family of secreted signaling proteins plays a key role in embryonic development in animals. In humans, Hh homologs include Sonic Hedgehog (Shh), Indian Hedgehog (Ihh), and Desert Hedgehog (Dhh). Hh proteins are secreted molecules that bind to patched (Ptc), releasing smoothened (smo) to transduce a signal. Hh signaling is involved in the control of proliferation and differentiation of a variety of cell types, including neural precursors, and is also involved in the patterning of many tissues. Hh signaling is also involved in the development of some types of cancer.

Rac is a member of the Rho family of small GTPases that regulates actin cytoskeletal structure and cell motility. Rac is activated by growth factor receptors and transmits signals to stimulate cell motility through the formation of lamellipodia and membrane ruffles. Rac also stimulates the formation of focal adhesions and stress fibers. The formation of these structures is stimulated by Rac through the activation of the Arp2 / 3 complex and the formation of branched actin filaments. The EGFR is a member of the ErbB family of receptor tyrosine kinases that also includes HER2 / neu (also known as ErbB2), ErbB3 and ErbB4. The binding of ligands such as EGF, transforming growth factor-alpha (TGFA) and others to the extracellular domain of the receptor leads to the formation of receptor dimers and activation of the intracellular tyrosine kinase domain. This results in the phosphorylation of specific tyrosine residues in the cytoplasmic domain of the receptor and the subsequent activation of downstream signaling pathways that regulate cell proliferation, differentiation and survival. Overexpression of EGFR is associated with a number of human cancers, including those of the lung, breast, head and neck, and colon. The association of EGFR overexpression with poor prognosis in some cancers has led to the development of therapeutic agents that target the receptor or its signaling pathways.

Interleukin-1 (IL-1) is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that is released by macrophages in response to infection and injury. IL-1 signaling is mediated by a cell surface receptor that is a member of the TNF receptor gene family. The IL-1 receptor is a heterodimer, with a ligand binding chain (IL-1R1) and a signaling chain (IL-1RAcP). The IL-1 receptor is found on most cells in the body, but the downstream effects of IL-1 signaling are cell type specific. In most cells, IL-1 signaling leads to the activation of NFkB and the release of inflammatory cytokines. In some cells, such as neurons, IL-1 signaling leads to the activation of JNK and apoptosis. The downstream effects of IL-1 signaling are cell type specific and are determined by the presence of other signaling pathways in the cell.

Granzyme A is a protease released by cytotoxic T cells that induces apoptosis in target cells. Granzyme A cleaves Bid, a member of the Bcl-2 family, and activates the mitochondrial apoptotic pathway. Granzyme A also activates caspase-independent apoptosis by cleaving the nuclear protein SET. SET is a substrate of protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A), and SET cleavage by granzyme A activates PP2A, which dephosphorylates and activates CAD, a nuclease that cleaves DNA.

Viral infection of cells can be detected by the innate immune system through the recognition of viral nucleic acids by Toll-like receptors (TLRs). Viral infection of cells can also be detected by the adaptive immune system through the recognition of viral proteins by antigen-specific receptors expressed by T cells and B cells. The activation of T cells and B cells by antigen receptors is accompanied by the induction of interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma) production. IFN-gamma plays an important role in the activation of macrophages and the induction of apoptosis in virus-infected cells.

The T cell receptor (TCR) is a multi-subunit complex that is responsible for the recognition of specific antigens by T cells. The TCR is composed of two chains that are non-covalently associated: the clonotypic alpha or beta chain and the more ubiquitously expressed gamma or delta chain. The TCR-CD3 complex is expressed on the cell surface in three different forms: the TCR-CD3 complex is expressed on the surface of all T cells, the TCR-CD3 complex is expressed on the surface of all T cells, and the TCR-CD3 complex is not expressed on the cell surface. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease with respect to both clinical features and molecular pathogenesis. The molecular basis of AML is complex and heterogeneous, involving several classes of genetic alterations. These include mutations in transcription factors such as those in the RUNX1, PML, and GATA families, as well as NPM1 and c-KIT. In addition, mutations in signaling genes such as FLT3, RAS, and c-KIT, as well as in the tumor suppressor genes TP5 3 and WT1, have been identified. Mutations in NPM1 and FLT3 are associated with a normal karyotype, whereas other mutations are associated with an aberrant karyotype. The prognostic impact of these molecular abnormalities is being defined.

The nucleolus is a nuclear subcompartment involved in the biogenesis of ribosomes. The nucleolus is also involved in the maturation of other noncoding RNAs, including the U3 and U6 spliceosomal RNAs, the telomerase RNA, and the RNase P RNA.
