The activity of GATA-1 and IL-4 are regulated by the MAP kinase pathways through the transcription factor NFATC-1.

Taste perception begins with the interaction of tastants with membrane bound receptors on the apical surface of taste cells. The transduction pathway for umami, sweet, and bitter taste stimuli is well established and begins with the binding of ligand to a specific receptor, activation of a G-protein-coupled receptor, and activation of a downstream signaling pathway. In the case of umami and sweet taste, binding of glutamate or sugars to the metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR4) or the sweet receptor (T1R2 / T1R3) activates gustducin, which stimulates the activation of the G protein subunit, gustducin, and its associated effector, the membrane bound phosphodiesterase (PDE). Activation of PDE leads to the breakdown of the second messenger, cAMP, which inhibits the activity of the basolateral Na + / K + -ATPase, depolarizing the cell and increasing its intracellular concentration. The depolarization opens a variety of ion channels, including the transient receptor potential channel M5 (TRPM5), which allows cations to flow down their electrochemical gradients into the cell. The influx of cations depolarizes the cell and activates voltage-gated channels, triggering action potentials and the release of neurotransmitters such as serotonin and ATP. In the case of bitter taste, binding of tastant to the metabotropic taste receptor (T2R1 / T2R3) activates a G protein complex (gustducin / Galpha14), which stimulates the phosphodiesterase to produce a similar response. The downstream effects of bitter taste transduction are not well understood, but may involve the opening of ion channels or the inhibition of the Na + / K + -ATPase.

The mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) cascade is a highly conserved module that is used by cells to transduce a variety of extracellular signals into intracellular responses. The cascade begins with the activation of a MAPKKK (MAPKKK = MAP kinase kinase kinase kinase), which phosphorylates and activates a MAPKK (MAP kinase kinase), which in turn activates a MAPK (MAP kinase). There are four major groups of MAPKs: ERKs (extracellular signal-regulated kinases), JNKs (Jun N-terminal kinases), JNKs / SAPKs (stress-activated protein kinases), and p3 8MAPKs. Each group includes several members. The cascade terminates with the phosphorylation and activation of a MAPK by its corresponding MAPKK. The complexity of this system is increased by the existence of multiple isoforms of each component, as well as the existence of various scaffolds and adaptors that provide additional levels of regulation.

The cell cycle is a highly regulated process that ensures that the cell has enough nutrients and energy to replicate its DNA and then segregate its chromosomes and divide into two daughter cells. The cell cycle is also regulated by checkpoints that prevent the cell from entering into or exiting from the cell cycle if there is not sufficient time to repair DNA damage. If the cell cannot repair DNA damage, the cell undergoes apoptosis. The cell cycle is regulated by a group of proteins called cyclins that are expressed at specific times during the cell cycle. Cyclins bind to cyclin dependent kinases (CDKs) and activate the kinase activity of the cyclin-CDK complex. The cyclin-CDK complex phosphorylates and thereby regulates the activity of other proteins that control the cell cycle. One of the key targets of the cyclin-CDK complex is the RB protein, which is a tumor suppressor. When RB is phosphorylated by the cyclin-CDK complex, it no longer binds to and inhibits the activity of E2F, a transcription factor that regulates genes that control the G1 to S phase transition. Another key target of the cyclin-CDK complex is the p53 tumor suppressor, which is also an E2F target. When p53 is phosphorylated by the cyclin-CDK complex, it is stabilized and induces apoptosis. Another key regulator of the cell cycle is the tumor suppressor protein p53, which is mutated or deleted in many cancers. When p53 is not phosphorylated, it binds to MDM2, an E3 ubiquitin ligase that targets p53 for degradation by the proteosome. When phosphorylated by the cyclin-CDK complex, MDM2 no longer binds to p53, and p53 is stabilized and accumulates in the cell. Another key regulator of the cell cycle is the tumor suppressor protein RB. When unphosphorylated, RB binds to E2F and inhibits the activity of E2F. When phosphorylated by the cyclin-CDK complex, RB no longer binds to E2F and the activity of E2F is no longer inhibited. Another key regulator of the cell cycle is the tumor suppressor protein p53. When unphosphorylated, p53 binds to MDM2 and induces the proteosomal degradation of p53. When phosphorylated, p53 no longer binds to MDM2 and is stabilized and accumulates in the cell.

The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a receptor tyrosine kinase that is activated by binding of its ligand, epidermal growth factor (EGF). EGF binding to the receptor induces receptor dimerization and autophosphorylation of tyrosine residues in the cytoplasmic tail of the receptor. The phosphorylated tyrosines serve as binding sites for proteins containing Src homology 2 (SH2) domains, including the adaptor protein Shc, the Ras guanine nucleotide exchange factor Sos-1, and the protein tyrosine phosphatase SHP-2. Shc and Sos-1 activate the Ras / Raf / Mek / Erk pathway, leading to cell proliferation. SHP-2 dephosphorylates and activates the transcription factor Stat-3, leading to cell survival. The Cbl protein binds to the EGFR and targets it for ubiquitination and proteosomal degradation. The Cbl protein also binds to the tyrosine phosphatase SHP-2, and may regulate its activity.

TNF is a potent cytokine that can induce a variety of cellular responses including apoptosis, inflammation, and the regulation of cell proliferation. The cellular responses to TNF are mediated through two distinct cell surface receptors, TNFR1 and TNFR2. TNFR1 is expressed at high levels by most cells and binds both soluble and membrane-bound TNF. In contrast, TNFR2 is expressed at low levels by most cells and binds only membrane-bound TNF. The binding of TNF to its receptors induces the recruitment of several signaling molecules to the receptor complex. The adaptor protein TRADD is recruited to the receptor complex through the interaction of its death domain with the death domain of TNFR1. TRAF2 is also recruited to the receptor complex through the interaction of its TRAF domain with the death domain of TNFR1. TRAF2 is a member of a family of proteins that are involved in the transduction of signals from TNF receptors to downstream signaling pathways. The activation of the transcription factor NF-kB by TNF is one of the signaling pathways that is mediated by the TNF receptors. TRAF2 has been shown to play an important role in this pathway through its interaction with the I-kappa B kinase (IKK) complex. The activation of NF-kB by TNF is important for the regulation of cell proliferation and apoptosis. The activation of NF-kB by TNF is also involved in the regulation of the expression of genes involved in inflammation and the immune response. The activation of NF-kB by TNF also plays an important role in the inhibition of apoptosis induced by TNF. The activation of NF-kB by TNF also induces the expression of genes involved in the inhibition of apoptosis. The activation of NF-kB by TNF also induces the expression of genes involved in cell proliferation, such as the genes for the anti-apoptotic proteins Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL. The activation of NF-kB by TNF also induces the expression of genes involved in inflammation, such as the genes for the cytokines IL-1 and IL-6. The activation of NF-kB by TNF also induces the expression of genes involved in the regulation of cell proliferation, such as the genes for cyclin D1 and c-myc. The activation of NF-kB by TNF also induces the expression of genes involved in the regulation of apoptosis, cell proliferation, and inflammation. The activation of NF-kB by TNF plays an important role in the regulation of cell proliferation and apoptosis. The activation of NF-kB by TNF also plays an important role in the regulation of apoptosis. The activation of NF-kB by TNF inhibits apoptosis induced by TNF and other agents that induce apoptosis. The inhibition of apoptosis by NF-kB is mediated through the induction of the expression of genes involved in the inhibition of apoptosis, such as the genes for Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL. The activation of NF-kB by TNF also induces the expression of genes involved in cell proliferation, such as the genes for cyclin D1 and c-myc. The activation of NF-kB by TNF also induces the expression of genes involved in inflammation, such as the genes for IL-1 and IL-6. The activation of NF-kB by TNF also induces the expression of genes involved in the regulation of apoptosis, cell proliferation, and inflammation.

The ubiquitin-proteasome pathway (UPP) is a major mechanism for the degradation of intracellular proteins. Proteins are tagged with ubiquitin, a 7 6-amino acid peptide, before being degraded by the proteasome. The proteasome is a large, multi-subunit protease complex that degrades proteins in an ATP-dependent manner. The proteasome is composed of a two major components, a core particle (CP) and a regulatory particle (RP). The CP is a cylindrical structure with a central proteolytic core and the RP is a regulatory particle that binds to the ends of the core particle and is involved in the recognition, unfolding, and degradation of proteins. The RP is composed of PA70 0 (PA38) in eukaryotes and PA38 in prokaryotes. PA38 is a ring-shaped structure that binds to the ends of the CP and consists of two heptameric rings stacked upon each other. The PA28 regulatory complex is a heterodimer of PA29 and PA70 in eukaryotes and a homoheptamer in prokaryotes. PA28 binds to PA37and functions as the recognition factor for the proteasome and also as an activator of the CP. PA29 is an ATPase that opens the PA70 / PA38 complex to allow substrates to enter the core particle. PA34 is a non-ATPase regulatory subunit that is involved in the degradation of abnormal proteins and is found in a complex with PA28. PA28 and PA34 are replaced by PA10 when PA28 is activated. The ubiquitin-activating enzyme (E1), ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme (E2), and ubiquitin ligase (E3) enzymes are involved in the ubiquitination of proteins. The transfer of ubiquitin to proteins requires a three-step reaction. E1 activates ubiquitin by transferring its C-terminal glycine to a cysteine in an E1-ubiquitin complex. The activated ubiquitin is then transferred to the active site cysteine of an E2 enzyme. Finally, an E3 enzyme ligates ubiquitin to the protein that is to be degraded by the proteasome. The specificity of the ubiquitination process is determined by the E3 enzymes. The proteasome is a multi-protein complex that degrades ubiquitinated proteins. The proteasome is a threonine protease that degrades proteins in an ATP-dependent manner. The degradation of proteins by the proteasome is preceded by the removal of the ubiquitin by a deubiquitylating enzyme (DUB). The proteasome is composed of four rings stacked together to form a 20S core particle. The two inner rings are each composed of 14 subunits, two of which are beta-subunits that form the proteolytic core. The two outer rings are each composed of 14 subunits each. The core particle is a cylindrical structure with a central cavity. Proteins that are to be degraded are unfolded by PA28 and then translocated into the core particle by PA27. Once inside the core particle, the protein is rapidly degraded by the proteases.

Selectins are a family of adhesion molecules expressed on the surface of leukocytes that bind to carbohydrate ligands on the surface of endothelial cells. The selectins are involved in the initial interaction of leukocytes with the endothelium and are required for the rolling of leukocytes on the endothelium. P-selectin is expressed on the surface of activated platelets and is released upon platelet activation. P-selectin binds to sialyl Lewis (x) (sLe (x)), a carbohydrate ligand expressed on the surface of activated endothelial cells. E-selectin is expressed on the surface of cytokine activated endothelial cells and binds to the carbohydrate ligand sialyl Lewis (a) (sLe (a)). L-selectin is expressed on the surface of leukocytes and binds to sialyl Lewis (a) (sLe (a)). The interaction of selectins with their carbohydrate ligands mediates the rolling of leukocytes on the endothelium, a critical first step in the subsequent adhesion and migration of leukocytes to sites of inflammation. Selectins are also involved in other aspects of inflammation including leukocyte activation and migration to sites of inflammation. Selectins are also expressed on other cell types and may play a role in other aspects of inflammation.

The methionine cycle is a central pathway for the metabolism of methionine and related sulfur-containing amino acids. The methionine cycle begins with the absorption of methionine from the diet and its conversion to AdoMet by methionine adenosyltransferase (MAT). AdoMet is the methyl donor for a variety of reactions including methylation of DNA, RNA, proteins, and lipids. The transfer of a methyl group from AdoMet to a variety of acceptors is a reversible reaction and can be removed by the enzyme methionine sulfoxide reductase (MSR) to regenerate methionine and generate NADPH. The transfer of a methyl group from AdoMet to homocysteine (Hcy) is a reaction that is irreversible under normal physiological conditions. The transfer of a methyl group from AdoMet to Hcy is a reaction that is catalyzed by a number of methyltransferases. The transfer of a methyl group from AdoMet to DNA is catalyzed by DNA methyltransferases (DNMTs). The transfer of a methyl group from AdoMet to RNA is catalyzed by RNA methyltransferases (RNMTs). The transfer of a methyl group from AdoMet to proteins is catalyzed by protein methyltransferases (PMTs). The transfer of a methyl group from AdoMet to lipids is catalyzed by methyltransferases (MTases). The transfer of a methyl group from AdoMet to methionine is a reaction that is catalyzed by methionine adenosyltransferase (MAT). The transfer of a methyl group from AdoMet to homocysteine is a reaction that is catalyzed by methionine synthase (MS). The activity of MAT is regulated by methionine and AdoMet. AdoMet is synthesized from methionine and ATP by MAT. The concentration of AdoMet is regulated by methionine and by S-adenosylhomocysteine hydrolase (SAHH). The concentration of S-adenosylhomocysteine (AdoHcy) is regulated by S-adenosylmethionine synthetase (SAHS). The ratio of AdoMet / AdoHcy is an important indicator of the methylation status of a cell. The ratio of AdoMet / AdoHcy is high when methylation is extensive and low when methylation is limited. The activity of methionine synthase (MS) is also regulated by methionine and by vitamin B1 2. The activity of methionine synthase reductase (MSR) is regulated by the concentration of folate. The activity of betaine homocysteine methyltransferase (BHMT) is regulated by betaine.

Spliceosomes are large complexes that catalyze the excision of noncoding sequences (introns) from pre-mRNA and the ligation of exons in a process known as pre-mRNA splicing. Spliceosomes are ribonucleoprotein complexes consisting of five small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNPs) and many additional proteins. The snRNPs are the key components of spliceosomes and are responsible for the recognition of splice sites and the catalysis of the transesterification reactions. Spliceosomes assemble on the pre-mRNA in a stepwise manner. The spliceosome is a dynamic structure that changes its composition and conformation during the splicing reaction.

The renin-angiotensin system (RAS) is a key regulator of blood pressure and fluid homeostasis. Angiotensinogen is secreted into the circulation by the liver and is cleaved by the enzyme renin to form angiotensin I (AngI). AngI is further cleaved by the enzyme ACE to form the potent vasoconstrictor angiotensin II (AngII). AngII is a peptide that binds to two different receptors, AT1 and AT2, to exert its effects. The AT1 receptor is coupled to G proteins and activates a number of signaling pathways, including the production of inositol phosphates and calcium mobilization. The AT2 receptor is coupled to G proteins that inhibit adenylyl cyclase and activate MAP kinase. AngII also stimulates the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) by the endothelium and vascular smooth muscle cells. AngII also stimulates the synthesis and secretion of aldosterone by the adrenal cortex. The actions of AngII are attenuated by the ACE inhibitor captopril and the angiotensin receptor blocker losartan. The importance of the RAS in the regulation of blood pressure and cardiovascular function is demonstrated by the fact that blocking the actions of AngII with either losartan or ACE inhibitors lowers blood pressure and reduces cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.

The nuclear factor kappa B (NF-kB) transcription factor plays a central role in the regulation of genes involved in the immune and inflammatory responses, as well as in the regulation of apoptosis. NF-kB is activated by a variety of stimuli, including inflammatory cytokines such as TNF-alpha, IL-1 and IL-1rI, viral infection, and antigen receptor stimulation. In the classical pathway, NF-kB is kept inactive in the cytoplasm by association with the inhibitor protein, IkB. Stimuli that activate NF-kB lead to the phosphorylation and degradation of IkB, releasing NF-kB to translocate to the nucleus and bind to its cognate DNA sequence. In the nucleus, NF-kB interacts with a variety of coactivators and coregulators to regulate the transcription of a large number of genes. The transcriptional activity of NF-kB is regulated by post-translational modifications, including phosphorylation and acetylation. The transcriptional activity of NF-kB is also regulated by the inhibitor of NF-kB kinase (IKK) complex, which phosphorylates IkB and also the p6 5 subunit of NF-kB. The IKK complex is a multi-subunit complex that includes two kinases, IKK1 / IKKa and IKK2 / IKKb, and a regulatory subunit, IKKg. The IKK1 / IKKa subunit is a member of the MAP kinase family, whereas IKK2 / IKKb is a member of the casein kinase I family. The IKK1 / IKKa subunit is constitutively associated with NF-kB, while the IKK2 / IKKb subunit is recruited to NF-kB by interaction with the IKK1 / IKKa subunit. The IKK1 / IKKa subunit phosphorylates IkB, targeting it for degradation by the ubiquitin-proteosome pathway, releasing NF-kB to translocate to the nucleus and activate transcription. The IKK2 / IKKb subunit phosphorylates the transcriptional activation domain of NF-kB, increasing its transcriptional activity. The transcriptional activity of NF-kB is also regulated by the interaction with other proteins. The transcriptional repressor I-kB is phosphorylated by IKK2 / IKKb, targeting it for degradation. The transcriptional coactivator CBP / 3 0 is also phosphorylated by IKK2 / IKKb, increasing its transcriptional activity. The transcriptional repressor p300 is also phosphorylated by IKK2 / IKKb, targeting it for degradation. The regulation of NF-kB by phosphorylation is a complex process involving the interaction of multiple kinases and transcription factors.

The Tax protein of HTLV-1 is a key factor in the development of adult T-cell leukemia (ATL). Tax interacts with a variety of cellular factors and modulates their functions. Tax interacts with p53, a tumor suppressor, and induces its degradation through the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. Tax also interacts with the tumor suppressor gene product p53, and induces its degradation. Tax also interacts with the CBP / p3 0 0 transcriptional coactivators, and represses their transcriptional activities. Tax also interacts with the CREB transcription factor, and activates the transcription of the viral promoter through the viral CRE (vCRE). Tax also interacts with the CREB-binding protein (CBP), and represses the CBP-mediated transcriptional activation of cellular genes. Tax represses the transcriptional activation of the MHC-1 gene by the transcription factor NF-kB. Tax also interacts with the I-mfa family of transcriptional repressors, and represses their transcriptional activities. Tax also interacts with the tumor suppressor gene product WT1, and represses its transcriptional activity.

Type II allergic reactions are mediated by immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibodies that bind to specific antigens. Antigen-specific IgE antibodies are produced by B cells in response to exposure to allergens. Crosslinking of IgE bound to the high affinity IgE receptor (FcepsilonRI) on the surface of mast cells and basophils by allergens leads to the release of inflammatory mediators, such as histamine, that cause the symptoms of allergy. Cross-linking of IgE bound to FcepsilonRI on T cells by allergens on antigen-presenting cells (APC) can lead to the activation of T cells.

The innate immune system is the first line of defense against invading pathogens. Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are pattern recognition receptors that recognize conserved microbial components and activate innate immune responses. The intracellular domain of TLRs recruits the adaptor protein myeloid differentiation factor 8 8 (MyD8 8), which leads to activation of NF-kB and MAPK pathways and production of proinflammatory cytokines. The cytoplasmic domain of TLR2 and TLR4 also recruits the adaptor protein TIRAP / Mal (MyD8 8 adaptor-like protein), which mediates activation of NF-kB and MAPK pathways but not the production of proinflammatory cytokines. Instead, TIRAP / Mal mediates activation of the transcription factor IRF-1 and the production of type I interferon in response to LPS.

The death receptor Fas (also called APO1, CD9 5, or TNFRSF6) is a member of the TNF receptor gene family. Fas is expressed on the surface of a variety of cells, including B cells, T cells, monocytes, and some tumor cells. Fas-mediated apoptosis is involved in the regulation of immune responses, elimination of virus-infected cells, and the maintenance of immune tolerance. The Fas-Fas ligand interaction induces the recruitment of the adaptor protein FADD (Fas-associated death domain protein) to the cytoplasmic domain of Fas. FADD in turn recruits caspase-8 through its death effector domain (DED). The formation of the death-inducing signaling complex (DISC) leads to the activation of caspase-8, which in turn activates caspase-3 and other downstream caspases, leading to apoptosis. The Bcl-2 family of proteins regulates apoptosis by controlling mitochondrial membrane permeability. The anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 family members, such as Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL, localize to the mitochondrial membrane and prevent the release of cytochrome c and other mitochondrial factors into the cytoplasm. The Bcl-2 family includes both anti-apoptotic and pro-apoptotic proteins. The anti-apoptotic proteins, Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL, localize to the mitochondrial membrane and prevent the release of cytochrome c. The pro-apoptotic proteins Bax, Bok, and Bad, which are localized in the cytosol, translocate to the mitochondrial membrane and induce the release of cytochrome c. Cytochrome c in the cytoplasm binds to apoptotic protease activating factor-1 (Apaf-1) and triggers the oligomerization of Apaf-1. The resulting activated Apaf-1 promotes the activation of caspase-9 and the subsequent caspase cascade.

Cardiac hypertrophy is an adaptive response of the heart to increased mechanical stress or increased neurohormonal stimuli. It is initially an adaptive response that serves to maintain cardiac output, but prolonged hypertrophy can lead to heart failure. The transition from adaptive to pathological cardiac hypertrophy is accompanied by a fetal gene program, in which the adult cardiac genes are re-expressed. This fetal gene program is thought to be detrimental and contributes to the deterioration of cardiac function. The transition from adaptive to pathological cardiac hypertrophy is accompanied by an increase in intracellular calcium concentration. Calcium / calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II (CaMKII) is a calcium-sensing enzyme that is activated by increased intracellular calcium. CaMKII in turn activates the nuclear factor of activated T cells (NFAT) family of transcription factors. CaMKII-dependent activation of NFAT induces the fetal gene program and cardiac hypertrophy. The activity of CaMKII is regulated by the endogenous inhibitor protein, calmesin. The activity of calmesin is regulated by the oxidation of methionine residues. The oxidation of methionine residues in calmesin by reactive oxygen species (ROS) activates CaMKII and induces cardiac hypertrophy. The activation of CaMKII by ROS is not dependent on calcium, but rather on the oxidation of methionine residues in calmesin. The activation of CaMKII by ROS is blocked by the antioxidant N-acetylcysteine, indicating that ROS are upstream of CaMKII. The activation of CaMKII by ROS is not dependent on calmodulin. The activation of CaMKII by ROS is not dependent on calcium, but rather on the oxidation of methionine residues in calmesin. The activation of CaMKII by ROS is not dependent on calcium, but rather on the oxidation of methionine residues in calmesin. The activation of CaMKII by ROS is not dependent on calcium, but rather on the oxidation of methionine residues in calmesin. The activation of CaMKII by ROS is not dependent on calmodulin. The activation of CaMKII by ROS is not dependent on calcium, but rather on the oxidation of methionine residues in calmesin. The activation of CaMKII by ROS is not dependent on calmodulin. The activation of CaMKII by ROS is not dependent on calcium, but rather on the oxidation of methionine residues in calmesin. The activation of CaMKII by ROS is not dependent on calmodulin. The activation of CaMKII by ROS is not dependent on calcium, but rather on the oxidation of methionine residues in calmesin. The activation of CaMKII by ROS is not dependent on calmodulin. The activation of CaMKII by ROS is not dependent on calcium, but rather on the oxidation of methionine residues in calmesin. The activation of CaMKII by ROS is not dependent on calmodulin.

Insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) is a potent mitogen for many cell types. IGF-1 signals through the IGF-1 receptor, a member of the tyrosine kinase receptor gene family. Binding of IGF-1 to the IGF-1 receptor leads to receptor autophosphorylation and activation of downstream signaling pathways. IGF-1 signaling is involved in normal development and growth, and IGF-1 signaling is also involved in the proliferation of transformed cells. IGF-1 signaling activates the Ras / Raf / MEK / ERK pathway, and also activates the PI-3 kinase pathway. Both of these pathways lead to the activation of the transcription factor AP-1, which is involved in the regulation of cell proliferation and differentiation. IGF-1 also activates the transcription factor ELK-1, which is involved in the regulation of cell proliferation and differentiation. The activation of ELK-1 by IGF-1 is independent of the MEK / ERK pathway, but does require PI-3 kinase activity. The transcription factor STAT5 is activated by the IGF-1 receptor and is involved in the regulation of cell proliferation and differentiation. The activation of STAT5 by the IGF-1 receptor is independent of the Ras / Raf / MEK / ERK pathway, but requires PI-3 kinase activity. The activation of STAT5 by the IGF-1 receptor is involved in the regulation of cell proliferation and differentiation.

The recruitment of leukocytes to sites of inflammation is a key component of the inflammatory response. Infiltration of leukocytes into tissues is a hallmark of inflammatory responses, such as in arthritis. The process of leukocyte recruitment is complex and involves the sequential interaction of leukocytes with the endothelium of the blood vessel wall, their subsequent diapedesis through the endothelium of the blood vessel wall, and their subsequent migration into the extracellular matrix of the tissue. The multistep model of leukocyte recruitment has been used to describe the sequence of events involved in the recruitment of leukocytes to inflammatory sites. The first step in the recruitment of leukocytes is the adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium of the blood vessel wall. This is mediated by the interaction of the leukocyte integrin LFA-1 (lymphocyte function-associated antigen-1) with its endothelial ligand ICAM-1 (intercellular adhesion molecule-1). The binding of LFA-1 to ICAM-1 is regulated by chemokines such as IL-8. The rolling of leukocytes along the endothelium is mediated by the interaction of the selectin family of adhesion molecules with their ligands on the endothelium. The selectin-mediated rolling of leukocytes is followed by their activation and firm adhesion by the interaction of the integrin LFA-1 with ICAM-1. The firm adhesion of leukocytes is followed by their transendothelial migration. The chemokine receptor CCR5 is involved in this process. The migration of leukocytes from the blood stream into the extracellular matrix of tissues is also a key step in the inflammatory response. The chemokine receptor CCR5 is involved in this process.

The invasion of intestinal epithelial cells by enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) and enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) is a key feature of these pathogens. The ability of these pathogens to adhere to and invade the intestinal epithelium is essential for disease. EPEC and EHEC are closely related pathogens that are able to cause disease by attaching and effacing (A / E) lesion formation on intestinal epithelial cells. The genes required for A / E lesion formation are located on a 3 5-kb pathogenicity island termed the locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE). The LEE-encoded proteins include intimin, Tir, EspA, EspD, and EspB. Tir is an integral membrane protein that is inserted into the plasma membrane and that is translocated into the host cell by the LEE-encoded type III secretion system. Tir is subsequently tyrosine phosphorylated by a host cell kinase, and this phosphorylation is required for the formation of actin pedestals. Intimin is a surface protein that mediates the intimate attachment of EPEC and EHEC to the host cell. The formation of A / E lesions is associated with the localized destruction of the brush border microvilli. In addition to their role in pathogenesis, intimin and Tir are also involved in the regulation of intestinal epithelial cell differentiation.

The HTLV-1 virus causes adult T-cell leukemia (ATL) after a long latent period. The virus encodes a regulatory protein, Tax, that activates transcription from the viral long terminal repeat (LTR) and from many cellular promoters. Tax also induces cellular transformation. The cellular targets of Tax include p53, a tumor suppressor, and the tumor suppressor p16INK4a. The activation of NF-kB by Tax contributes to cellular transformation. The activation of the JAK / STAT pathway by Tax contributes to cellular transformation.

Gap junctions are clusters of intercellular channels that allow direct communication between cells. Each gap junction channel is formed by docking of two hemichannels, each containing six connexin subunits. Each hemichannel is a hexamer of a connexin subunit. Each hemichannel is located in the plasma membrane of an adjacent cell. Each hemichannel is connected to the junctional compartment of the cell by a cytoplasmic channel. Each hemichannel is gated by transjunctional voltage (Vj) and by the transjunctional conductance (Gj). The gating of each hemichannel is determined by the relative transjunctional voltage and the transjunctional conductance. The opening of each hemichannel causes the flow of ions and small molecules between the two cells. Gap junctions are involved in a variety of physiological processes, including cell growth and differentiation, electrical coupling, metabolic transport, and control of tissue homeostasis. Gap junctional intercellular communication (GJIC) is regulated by a variety of factors, including phosphorylation, intracellular calcium, pH, redox state, transjunctional voltage, and membrane lipids.

The metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) are G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) that modulate a variety of physiological processes, including learning and memory, nociception, and neuronal development. The mGluRs are divided into three groups based on sequence homology, G-protein coupling, and pharmacological profile: group I (mGluR1 and mGluR5), group II (mGluR2 and mGluR3), and group III (mGluR4, mGluR6, mGluR7, and mGluR8). The mGluRs are expressed throughout the central nervous system (CNS), with group I mGluRs primarily expressed on the postsynaptic membrane, and group II and group III mGluRs expressed on both presynaptic and postsynaptic membranes. Upon glutamate binding, the mGluRs activate G-proteins, resulting in the activation of phospholipase C (PLC) and subsequent release of IP3 and diacylglycerol (DAG). IP3 binds to its receptor on the ER membrane, causing the release of calcium into the cytosol. DAG activates protein kinase C (PKC) through the production of the second messenger DAG. The mGluRs also activate the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway, including the Ras / Raf / MEK / ERK and the phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) / Akt pathways. The mGluRs are involved in a variety of neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, anxiety, and drug abuse. The mGluRs are also potential drug targets for the treatment of these disorders.

TNF is a cytokine that induces apoptosis in a variety of cell types. The cytotoxic effects of TNF are mediated by two distinct cell surface receptors, TNFR1 and TNFR2. Binding of TNF to TNFR1 leads to the recruitment of the adaptor protein TRADD and the subsequent recruitment of the protein kinases RIP, TRAF2 and FADD. RIP and TRAF2 are involved in the activation of NF-kappaB and JNK signaling pathways, while FADD is required for the recruitment and activation of caspase-8. Caspase-8 activation results in the proteolytic processing and activation of caspase-3, which in turn cleaves cellular substrates, triggering DNA fragmentation and other cellular changes associated with apoptosis. Caspase-8 also cleaves Bid, a Bcl-2 family protein, to form tBid, which translocates to mitochondria and induces the release of cytochrome c. Cytochrome c activates Apaf-1, which in turn activates caspase-9, which then activates caspase-3 and other downstream caspases. The activation of JNK and NF-kappaB by TNF is mediated by TRAF2 and RIP, respectively. NF-kappaB activation inhibits apoptosis by inducing the expression of genes that block the mitochondrial release of cytochrome c.

PML is a tumor suppressor protein that is involved in apoptosis and transcriptional regulation. PML is a component of nuclear bodies, which are dynamic structures associated with the nuclear matrix. PML nuclear bodies are involved in transcriptional regulation and apoptosis. PML nuclear bodies are disrupted in acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) by the expression of the PML-RAR alpha fusion protein, resulting in a loss of PML tumor suppressor activity. PML nuclear bodies are also disrupted in cells infected with the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). The EBV latent membrane protein 1 (LMP1) is expressed in EBV associated B cell lymphomas and disrupts PML nuclear bodies. PML nuclear bodies are also disrupted in cells expressing the E6 protein of the human papillomavirus (HPV). The disruption of PML nuclear bodies by these viral proteins may contribute to the development of EBV associated lymphomas and HPV associated cancers.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic, systemic, inflammatory autoimmune disease characterized by the formation of circulating autoantibodies against nuclear antigens. The formation of autoantibodies is the hallmark of SLE. The production of autoantibodies is a result of the breakdown of self-tolerance. The production of autoantibodies is under the control of multiple mechanisms. The production of autoantibodies against nuclear antigens is the result of the loss of self-tolerance. The breakdown of self-tolerance is caused by genetic factors and environmental factors. The genetic factors include the presence of certain genes that increase the risk of developing SLE and the presence of certain genes that decrease the threshold for the induction of autoimmunity. Environmental factors include infections, ultraviolet light, drugs, and smoking. The production of autoantibodies is also under the control of other mechanisms. The production of autoantibodies is the result of the interaction of multiple mechanisms.

Apoptosis is a genetically controlled process of cellular self-destruction that plays a key role in development and tissue homeostasis. The intrinsic or mitochondrial pathway of apoptosis is activated by a variety of cellular stresses, including DNA damage, growth factor withdrawal, and ER stress. These stresses activate the multidomain proapoptotic proteins Bax and Bak, which induce the release of cytochrome c from the mitochondria into the cytosol. Cytochrome c in the cytosol binds to Apaf-1, a caspase recruitment domain (CARD) -containing protein, and recruits caspase-9 into a complex termed the apoptosome. Caspase-9 then activates the rest of the caspase cascade, which leads to the proteolytic degradation of cellular substrates and cell death. IAP proteins bind to the caspase-inhibitory domain of the proapoptotic Bcl-2 family proteins and inhibit apoptosis. IAP proteins also bind to Smac / DIABLO, a protein released from the mitochondria that antagonizes IAP proteins and promotes apoptosis.

The cell cycle is driven by the activity of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) and their regulators, cyclins. CDKs are a family of serine / threonine protein kinases that are activated by binding to regulatory cyclins. The activity of CDKs is negatively regulated by CDK inhibitors (CKIs). CDKs are themselves regulated by phosphorylation, and dephosphorylation. CDK activity is required for the G1 / S and G2 / M transitions. The G1 / S transition is promoted by the activity of cyclin E-CDK2 and cyclin A-CDK2. The activation of cyclin E-CDK2 is negatively regulated by the CKI p16Ink4. The activation of cyclin A-CDK2 is negatively regulated by the CKI p27Kip1. The G2 / M transition is promoted by the activation of cyclin B-CDK1. The activity of cyclin B-CDK1 is negatively regulated by the phosphatase CDC2 5C. The activity of CDKs is also regulated by their abundance. The levels of cyclins are regulated by the ubiquitin-dependent proteolytic pathway. The destruction of p16Ink4 and p27Kip1 by the ubiquitin-dependent proteolytic pathway allows the activation of cyclin E-CDK2 and cyclin A-CDK2, respectively. The levels of cyclins are also regulated by the ubiquitin-dependent proteolytic pathway. The destruction of cyclin A is promoted by the phosphorylation of cyclin A by CDK1. The destruction of cyclin B is promoted by the phosphorylation of cyclin B. The activation of cyclin B-CDK1 is negatively regulated by the phosphatase CDC2 5C. The activity of CDKs is also regulated by their phosphorylation. The phosphorylation of CDKs by the CDK-activating kinase (CAK) is required for CDK activation. The CDK-counteracting phosphatases, protein phosphatases 1and 2A (PP1 and PP2A), are required for CDK inactivation. The activity of PP1 and PP2A is negatively regulated by the kinase WEE1 and the kinase CDC2 5C. The activity of PP2A is also negatively regulated by the kinase CDC25R1.

The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a member of the ErbB family of receptor tyrosine kinases. The binding of EGF-like growth factors to the extracellular domain of the receptor leads to receptor dimerization and activation of its intracellular tyrosine kinase domain. This in turn leads to the phosphorylation of various cellular substrates and initiation of signaling cascades that regulate cell proliferation and differentiation. Aberrant signaling by EGFR or its ligands has been implicated in the development and progression of a variety of human cancers. The EGFR gene is frequently amplified or rearranged in tumor cells, and high levels of EGFR expression have been associated with a more aggressive tumor phenotype and resistance to therapy. EGFR inhibitors are currently being tested in clinical trials as potential cancer therapies.

The complement system is an important part of the immune system that helps to identify and destroy invading pathogens. The complement system is composed of more than thirty different proteins and protein fragments that work in a cascade of proteolytic activation to form a proteolytic cascade that lyses cells and helps to opsonize and clear pathogens. The complement system is activated by three different pathways, the classical pathway, the lectin pathway, and the alternative pathway. Each pathway begins with the recognition of an infection by a pattern recognition molecule, such as the C1 protein in the classical pathway, or mannose-binding lectin in the lectin pathway. This recognition leads to the activation of the complement cascade through a series of proteolytic reactions. The classical pathway is initiated by the recognition of foreign antigen by the C1 complex, which is a complex of the proteins C1q, C1r, and C1s. The recognition of antigen by C1 leads to the activation of C1s, which cleaves C4 and C2 to form C4bC2a. The C4bC2a complex binds to the activating surface and cleaves additional C3 molecules to form the C3 convertase. The C3 convertase cleaves additional C3 molecules to form the C3 convertase, C3bBbC3b. The cleavage of C3 by C3 convertase creates a new C3 convertase that cleaves more C3, forming a positive feedback loop that quickly increases the number of C3 convertases. The C5 convertase cleaves C5 to form the anaphylatoxin C5a, which recruits phagocytes to the site of infection, and the membrane attack complex (MAC), which lyses cells. The lectin pathway is initiated by the recognition of carbohydrate patterns on the surface of bacteria by mannan-binding lectin (MBL). The recognition of carbohydrate by MBL leads to the activation of the protease MASP-2, which cleaves C4 and C2 to form the C3 convertase. The alternative pathway is initiated by spontaneous hydrolysis of C3, which leads to the formation of C3 (H2O), a C3 fragment that can form a C3 convertase without the need for a recognition molecule or a pattern recognition molecule. The C3 convertase formed by the alternative pathway cleaves additional C3 to form more C3 convertase. The three pathways converge on the cleavage of C5, which is the critical step in the formation of the MAC and the subsequent lysis of cells.

The T cell receptor (TCR) is a complex of two polypeptides, alpha and beta, that is expressed on the cell surface in association with three other proteins, CD3. The TCR is responsible for the recognition of foreign antigens in the form of peptides bound to MHC molecules on the surface of cells. The activation of T cells requires the engagement of the TCR with antigen-MHC complexes on an antigen-presenting cell, a process that is facilitated by the presence of costimulatory molecules such as B7. The engagement of the TCR by antigen-MHC complexes stimulates a cascade of signaling events that ultimately lead to T cell proliferation and the expression of genes involved in T cell effector functions. The TCR is associated with the src family protein tyrosine kinases Lck and Fyn, and the p36 family of proteins. The p36 family of proteins includes LAT, SLP-7 6 and FYB. The src kinases phosphorylate LAT and SLP-7 6, which in turn associate with the Tec family kinases Itk and Rlk. The Tec kinases activate PLC-gamma and the subsequent production of IP3 and DAG. IP3 leads to the release of calcium from intracellular stores and the activation of the calcium-dependent transcription factor NFAT. DAG activates the Ras / Raf / MEK / MAP kinase pathway and also the protein kinase C (PKC) pathway. The activation of the Ras / Raf / MEK / MAP kinase pathway is independent of PKC activation. The activation of T cells requires costimulatory signals provided by the interaction of CD2 8 with its ligands on the surface of antigen-presenting cells. The interaction of the T cell costimulatory molecule CTLA-4 with B7. 1 or B7. 2 inhibits T cell activation.

Trefoil factors are small, secreted proteins with a unique trefoil structure. They are normally expressed in the gastrointestinal tract, but are also found in other tissues. Trefoil factors are up-regulated in response to mucosal damage and are thought to play a role in mucosal healing. They are also involved in mucosal protection and repair. The trefoil factor family has three members in mammals, TFF1, TFF2 and TFF3. TFF1 and TFF2 are expressed in the stomach, while TFF3 is expressed in the small and large intestine. TFF1 and TFF2 are involved in mucosal protection and repair, while TFF3 is involved in mucosal protection and repair in the intestine. Trefoil factors are also involved in tumor suppression. The trefoil factors are synthesized as precursors that are cleaved to the mature form. TFF1 and TFF2 are found in mucous granules in the gastric epithelium. TFF3 is secreted into the mucus layer of the intestine. The trefoil factors are not glycosylated, but are secreted via the constitutive secretory pathway. The trefoil factors are not cleaved from the mucous granules and are not degraded in the gastric lumen. The trefoil factors are not protease inhibitors, but act as intramolecular or intermolecular cross-linkers to form a network of mucin polymers. The trefoil factors also stimulate cell migration and proliferation. The trefoil factors are involved in mucosal protection and repair. The trefoil factors are also involved in tumor suppression. The trefoil factors are not cleaved from the mucous granules and are not degraded in the gastric lumen. The trefoil factors are not cleaved from the mucous granules and are not degraded in the gastric lumen. The trefoil factors are not cleaved from the mucous granules and are not degraded in the gastric lumen. The trefoil factors are not cleaved from the mucous granules and are not degraded in the gastric lumen. The trefoil factors are not cleaved from the mucous granules and are not degraded in the gastric lumen. The trefoil factors are not cleaved from the mucous granules and are not degraded in the gastric lumen. The trefoil factors are not cleaved from the mucous granules and are not degraded in the gastric lumen. The trefoil factors are not cleaved from the mucous granules and are not degraded in the gastric lumen. The trefoil factors are not cleaved from the mucous granules and are not degraded in the gastric lumen. The trefoil factors are not cleaved from the mucous granules and are not degraded in the gastric lumen. The trefoil factors are not cleaved from the mucous granules and are not degraded in the gastric lumen.

T cells are key regulators of the immune system and respond to foreign antigens in the form of peptides bound to MHC proteins on the surface of antigen-presenting cells. T cells are activated by the interaction of the T cell receptor with the antigen-MHC complex. The T cell receptor is a multi-subunit complex that includes a clonotypic alpha chain and a clonotypic beta or gamma chain associated with the CD3 complex. The clonotypic alpha and beta chains are responsible for binding the antigen-MHC complex and the CD3 complex transmits the activation signal to the T cell. The CD3 complex is composed of three dimers (gamma epsilon, delta epsilon, and zeta zeta) and is associated with the T cell receptor. The zeta chain is a key component of the T cell receptor complex and is required for the expression of the T cell receptor on the cell surface. The activation of the T cell receptor results in the tyrosine phosphorylation of several cellular proteins and the activation of downstream signaling pathways. The protein tyrosine phosphatase CD4 5 dephosphorylates the T cell receptor and other proteins involved in T cell activation to maintain T cell receptor signaling in the absence of antigen.

Autoimmune thyroid disease (AITD) is a complex organ-specific autoimmune disorder in which autoantibodies to thyroid peroxidase (TPO), thyroglobulin (Tg) and / or the TSH receptor (TSHR) are produced in genetically susceptible individuals. AITD is characterized by two phases: the initiation phase, in which self-reactive T cells are activated by self-antigen in the context of self-MHC-II molecules, and the effector phase, in which self-reactive B cells and T cells are expanded and differentiate into autoantibody-secreting plasma cells. The effector phase is characterized by the secretion of thyroid-reactive autoantibodies, which in the case of TPO and Tg leads to the production of thyroid autoantibodies that bind to and damage the thyroid. The destruction of the thyroid gland by thyroid autoantibodies leads to hypothyroidism. Graves' disease is characterized by the presence of thyroid-stimulating antibodies that stimulate the thyroid to produce excessive amounts of thyroid hormone, resulting in hyperthyroidism.

Mucins are large O-glycoproteins that are heavily O-glycosylated and are found on cell surfaces and in body fluids. Mucin O-glycans are synthesized by the stepwise transfer of monosaccharides to the serine or threonine residues of a polypeptide. The first monosaccharide to be added is N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc), which is then extended with monosaccharides that are specific for each of the different monosaccharides that may be found in O-glycans. The O-glycans of most mucins are branched and heterogeneous. Mucin O-glycans are important for many biological functions, including protection of epithelial cells from harmful agents, immune surveillance, and inflammation. Mucin O-glycans are synthesized by a process that is similar to the biosynthesis of other complex carbohydrates, with the addition of monosaccharides being catalyzed by a family of specific glycosyltransferases.

Cell-matrix and cell-cell adhesions are essential for many biological processes, including morphogenesis, cell motility, cell proliferation, differentiation, and cell survival. At the cell-matrix adhesions, the integrin family of adhesion receptors mediates the interaction of cells with the extracellular matrix (ECM). Integrins are heterodimeric transmembrane proteins consisting of noncovalently associated subunits, alpha and beta. The binding of ECM ligands to the extracellular domains of integrins triggers the formation of focal adhesions, which are large protein complexes that link the actin cytoskeleton to the plasma membrane. The formation of focal adhesions is regulated by the small GTPases of the Rho family, Rho, Rac, and Cdc 4 2, which are activated by various signaling pathways. The activation of Rho induces the formation of contractile actin-based structures, such as stress fibers and focal adhesions, whereas Rac and Cdc 4 2 induce the formation of lamellipodia and membrane ruffles, respectively. On the other hand, the inactivation of Rho induces the dissolution of focal adhesions. The integrin-mediated cell-cell adhesions are also called adherens junctions, and are mediated by E-cadherin. The cytoplasmic domain of E-cadherin interacts with beta-catenin, which in turn binds alpha-catenin. Alpha-catenin is an actin-binding protein that may link the cadherin-catenin complex to the actin cytoskeleton. The tyrosine kinase activity of the receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) for growth factors, such as the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), is required for the formation of adherens junctions. The phosphorylation of beta-catenin by RTKs dissociates beta-catenin from E-cadherin, thereby destabilizing adherens junctions.

Tight junctions (TJs) are multiprotein structures that regulate the passage of ions and macromolecules between adjacent cells. They are essential for the maintenance of cell polarity and tissue integrity. They are formed by the association of transmembrane proteins, the occludins and the claudins, with cytoplasmic proteins, such as ZO-1, ZO-2 and cingulin. The cytoplasmic proteins are involved in the assembly of TJs and in the regulation of their function. The assembly of TJs is a highly dynamic process that is regulated by the cell cycle and by growth factors. The disassembly of TJs is associated with increased permeability and is triggered by tyrosine phosphorylation of ZO-1. The phosphorylation of ZO-1 and cingulin is mediated by Src and EGFR. The reassembly of TJs is a slower process that requires protein synthesis and dephosphorylation.

The transcription factor NFAT is a key regulator of cytokine gene expression in T cells. In resting T cells, NFAT is phosphorylated and retained in the cytoplasm by binding to the cytoplasmic 14-3-3 protein. Activation of T cells by antigen results in the influx of calcium ions through the T cell receptor (TCR) and the release of calcium from intracellular stores. This leads to the activation of the phosphatase calcineurin, which dephosphorylates NFAT, causing it to migrate into the nucleus and activate transcription. The activity of NFAT is regulated by a number of kinases, including GSK-3, which phosphorylates NFAT and promotes its binding to 14-3-3. Other kinases, including PKA, phosphorylate NFAT and cause it to be retained in the cytoplasm. The activity of PKA is regulated by the G-protein subunit alpha s (Gs), which stimulates the production of cAMP by adenylate cyclase. The production of cAMP activates PKA, which phosphorylates NFAT and causes it to be retained in the cytoplasm. The activity of NFAT is also regulated by the phosphatase calcineurin, which dephosphorylates NFAT and causes it to migrate into the nucleus. The activity of calcineurin is regulated by the calcium-binding protein calmodulin, which activates calcineurin when bound calcium levels rise in response to TCR activation.

The Wnt signaling pathway is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including cell proliferation, differentiation and motility. Wnt proteins are secreted glycoproteins that bind to Frizzled receptors and low-density lipoprotein receptor-related proteins 5 and 6 (LRP5 / 6). This binding results in the stabilization of beta-catenin, which accumulates in the cytoplasm and is then translocated to the nucleus. In the nucleus, beta-catenin interacts with the TCF / LEF family of transcription factors, resulting in the activation of Wnt target genes. Wnt signaling is involved in the genesis of a variety of human cancers. Mutations in APC or beta-catenin are associated with colon cancer, and mutations in beta-catenin are associated with melanoma. Wnt signaling is also involved in the development of other tissues, such as the central nervous system.

Chemokines are small chemoattractant proteins that direct cell migration in both physiological and pathological processes. They are classified into four groups on the basis of their amino acid sequences. Chemokine receptors are G protein-coupled receptors and are expressed on the surface of leukocytes. Chemokine receptors are classified into four groups on the basis of their structure and ligand specificity. The chemokine receptor group includes chemokine receptors that are specific for a single chemokine group. The chemokine receptor group that binds multiple chemokines includes the chemokine receptor group that binds multiple chemokines. The chemokine receptor group that does not bind chemokines includes the chemokine receptor CCR5.

The immune system is comprised of a variety of cell types that work together to protect the body from invading pathogens and to respond to internal threats. B cells produce antibodies, T cells are the cells responsible for cellular immunity, and macrophages are the cells responsible for phagocytosis and the response to infection. B cells express antibodies that bind to and inactivate specific foreign antigens. T cells respond to specific antigens in the context of other proteins on the surface of antigen-presenting cells, usually a macrophage or B cell. The T cell receptor recognizes specific antigens in the context of MHC proteins on the antigen-presenting cell. Macrophages and B cells are activated by the presence of antigen, and T cells are activated by the interaction of antigen-presenting cells with T cell receptors and costimulatory molecules.

Interleukin 2 (IL-2) is a cytokine that stimulates the growth and differentiation of T cells. The IL-2 receptor is a heterodimer of alpha and beta chains. The alpha chain is also a receptor for IL-4 and IL-1 3. The beta chain is shared by IL-2, IL-4 and IL-1 5. The beta chain is associated with the JAK family of tyrosine kinases and the STAT family of transcription factors. The JAK kinases are activated by phosphorylation by the IL-2 receptor and phosphorylate the beta chain and STAT-5. STAT-5 is phosphorylated on tyrosine by the JAK kinases and translocates to the nucleus where it activates transcription of genes including the IL-2 receptor alpha chain and the IL-2 receptor gamma chain. The JAK kinases are also involved in the activation of the Ras / Map kinase pathway by IL-2. The Map kinase pathway is activated by the JAK kinases and leads to the activation of the transcription factors ELK-1 and AP-1. The JAK kinases are also involved in other signaling pathways activated by IL-2.

The dystrophin-glycoprotein complex (DGC) is a multimeric complex that links the extracellular matrix to the actin cytoskeleton. The DGC is required for the stability of the sarcolemma during muscle contraction and is also involved in signaling pathways that regulate gene expression and cell survival. The absence of the DGC in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) leads to membrane instability and muscle cell death. The loss of the DGC also affects the expression of other muscle proteins, including the acetylcholine receptor (AchR). The absence of the dystrophin protein in DMD results in the loss of the entire DGC from the sarcolemma. The loss of the DGC in DMD also affects the expression of other muscle proteins, including the AchR. The loss of the DGC in DMD also affects the expression of other muscle proteins, including the acetylcholine receptor (AchR). The loss of the DGC in DMD also affects the expression of other muscle proteins, including the acetylcholine receptor (AchR). The loss of the DGC in DMD results in the loss of the entire DGC from the sarcolemma. The loss of the DGC in DMD also affects the expression of other muscle proteins, including the acetylcholine receptor (AchR). The loss of the DGC in DMD also affects the expression of other muscle proteins, including the acetylcholine receptor (AchR). The loss of the DGC in DMD also affects the expression of other muscle proteins, including the dystrophin-associated protein alpha-dystrobrevin.

The protease-activated receptors (PARs) are a family of G-protein coupled receptors that are activated by proteolytic cleavage of their amino-terminal extracellular domain by the protease thrombin. The tethered peptide ligand that is unmasked by cleavage binds to and activates the receptor and thus the PAR is now considered a receptor for a protease. Four members of the PAR family have been identified and are activated by different proteases. The PAR-1 receptor is activated by thrombin, the PAR-2 receptor by trypsin, the PAR-3 by trypsin-like proteases such as tryptase and the PAR-4 by factor Xa. The tethered ligand sequence that activates the PAR-1, PAR-3 and PAR-4 receptors is SFLLRN, GYPGQV and SLIGRL, respectively. PAR-2 is activated by a tethered ligand sequence of GYPGQV. The cleavage of PARs by proteases results in activation of G-proteins and downstream signaling pathways including the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway. The PAR-1 and PAR-2 receptors are widely expressed in a variety of tissues and cells and are involved in a number of physiological and pathological processes including platelet activation, inflammation, and possibly cancer. The PAR-3 receptor is expressed in the central nervous system and may play a role in neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimers disease. The PAR-4 receptor is expressed in the intestinal epithelium and may play a role in inflammatory bowel disease.

Type I diabetes mellitus (IDDM) is an autoimmune disease that results from the destruction of insulin-producing beta cells by self-reactive T cells. The genetic basis of IDDM is complex, with both environmental and genetic factors contributing to disease susceptibility. Environmental factors include diet, infections, and stress. Genetic factors include the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) and the insulin gene. The MHC is the most important genetic region in humans and mice. In humans, the MHC class II molecule encoded by the HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 gene is associated with increased risk of IDDM. The insulin gene is also associated with IDDM in some populations. The pathogenesis of IDDM is thought to result from the destruction of beta cells by self-reactive T cells. Environmental factors may act by increasing the presentation of autoantigens by antigen-presenting cells, or by inducing T cell activation. In NOD mice, a model of IDDM, the disease is dependent on both CD4 + and CD8 + T cells. CD4 + T cells are required for the activation of beta cell-specific CD8 + T cells. These T cells induce the expression of Fas ligand on beta cells, resulting in beta cell death by apoptosis. In addition to T cells, macrophages and dendritic cells may be involved in the activation of beta cell-specific T cells. Macrophages and dendritic cells are professional antigen-presenting cells that activate T cells. Macrophages and dendritic cells may also be involved in the activation of beta cell-specific T cells.

Apoptosis is a genetically controlled form of cell death that is induced by a variety of stimuli and is essential for normal development and tissue homeostasis. The apoptotic program is executed by a family of cysteine proteases, the caspases, that are activated by two distinct proteolytic pathways. The first pathway is triggered by members of the TNF receptor gene family and results in the activation of caspase-8. Caspase-8 in turn activates caspase-3, -6 and / or-7. The second pathway is triggered by the Bcl-2 family of proteins and results in the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria. Cytochrome c interacts with Apaf-1 to activate caspase-9. Caspase-9 activates caspase-3, -6 and / or-7. The caspases are a class of cysteine proteases with conserved sequence motifs that include an amino-terminal death domain (DD), involved in protein-protein interactions, and a carboxy-terminal catalytic domain. Caspases are separated into two groups based on their requirement for activation: the initiator caspases (caspases-2, -8, -9, -1 0) that are activated by oligomerization and the downstream caspases (caspases-3, -6, -7) that are activated by the initiator caspases. Caspases are expressed as inactive zymogens and are activated by proteolytic cleavage. Caspases in the initiator group are activated by proximity-induced dimerization, while the downstream caspases are activated by proteolytic cleavage of the inactive zymogen. Caspases-8 and -9 are activated by the adaptor protein FADD (FAS-associated death domain protein), which is recruited to the receptor-signaling complex by the Fas-ligand or other death receptors. Caspase-8 cleaves and activates caspase-3, -6 and -7. Caspase-3 in turn cleaves a number of cellular substrates, including the nuclear enzyme DFF-4 5, which is required for chromatin condensation and the enzyme lamin-B, which is required for nuclear fragmentation during apoptosis. Caspase-3 also cleaves Bid, a Bcl-2 family member, which translocates to mitochondria and induces the release of cytochrome c. Cytochrome c activates caspase-9, which in turn activates caspase-3. Caspases-1 and -4 are activated by the inflammatory cytokines, IL-1beta and IL-18, respectively, and are involved in the inflammatory response. Caspases-2 and-8 are involved in the mitochondrial pathway of apoptosis, but their activation is not required for apoptosis. Caspases-3, -6 and-7 are involved in the execution of apoptosis.

The amino acid methionine is an essential amino acid for animals and is synthesized from aspartate in bacteria, plants, and fungi. The enzyme methionine synthase (MS) catalyzes the reaction. converting tetrahydrofolate (THF) with methionine and homocysteine to THF and methionine. The methyl group of methionine is donated to the methyl group of dUMP in DNA for methylation. The enzyme MS is a key enzyme in one-carbon metabolism. The enzyme glycine N-methyltransferase (GNMT) catalyzes the irreversible methylation of glycine to form sarcosine. Sarcosine is excreted in the urine of humans and other animals. Sarcosine is a methyl donor in the synthesis of creatine, which is used as an energy buffer in muscles.

Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) is an autoimmune disease in which the insulin-producing beta cells are destroyed by self-reactive T cells. The disease is associated with the presence of islet-cell autoantibodies that recognize beta-cell antigens. The disease is genetically complex, with the inheritance of multiple susceptibility genes. The autoimmune response is T-helper 1 (Th1) -cell-mediated, with the secretion of interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma) and the cytotoxic action of CD8 + T cells. The major genetic determinant of T1DM is the MHC class II molecule, HLA-DQB1 * 0 3 0 2. Other MHC genes, such as HLA-DRB1, -DQA1, and -DQB1, are also associated with T1DM. Environmental factors, such as viral infections, may trigger the autoimmune process. Viral infections may activate self-reactive T cells by molecular mimicry, in which self-proteins are recognized by T cells that are specific for viral proteins. Viral infections may also induce the expression of heat shock proteins (Hsps), which are also self-antigens, in beta cells. Viral infections may also induce the expression of stress proteins, such as glucose-regulated proteins (Grps), in beta cells. Grps are induced by a variety of environmental stresses, including viral infections. Viral infection may also induce the expression of stress proteins in beta cells. The induction of Hsps and Grps may result in the formation of abnormal proteins in beta cells, which are then targeted by the immune system.

The retinoic acid receptor (RAR) is a member of the steroid hormone receptor gene family. It binds to retinoic acid (RA) and regulates the expression of genes involved in cell growth and differentiation. The RAR is a ligand-dependent transcription factor that binds to RA response elements in the promoter regions of target genes. The RAR is found in two forms, RAR alpha and RAR beta. The RAR is found in a complex with a number of proteins that regulate its activity. One of these proteins is the nuclear receptor corepressor (N-CoR). N-CoR binds to the RAR in the absence of ligand and represses transcription. Upon binding of RA to the RAR, the N-CoR is dissociated and the RAR is able to activate transcription. Another protein that binds to the RAR is the transcriptional coactivator protein SRC-1. Binding of RA to the RAR causes the dissociation of the N-CoR and the recruitment of SRC-1 to the RAR. SRC-1 binds to the thyroid hormone receptor (TR) and other steroid hormone receptors and increases the transcriptional activity of these receptors. The binding of RA to the RAR causes a conformational change in the RAR that allows the binding of SRC-1. The binding of SRC-1 to the RAR causes a conformational change in the RAR that allows the binding of CBP / pCIP to the RAR. CBP / pCIP is a histone acetylase that relaxes the chromatin structure and allows the transcriptional machinery to access the DNA. The binding of RA to the RAR causes the dissociation of N-CoR and the recruitment of SRC-1 and CBP / pCIP to the RAR. The binding of RA to the RAR causes a conformational change in the RAR that allows the binding of CBP / pCIP and causes the dissociation of N-CoR. The binding of CBP / pCIP to the RAR causes a conformational change that allows the binding of SRC-1.

The chemokine IL-8 is a member of the C-X-C family of chemotactic cytokines that induce the migration of neutrophils, eosinophils, and monocytes to sites of inflammation. IL-8 is secreted by airway epithelial cells in response to inflammatory stimuli, including bacterial products, cytokines, and environmental irritants. IL-8 is a potent chemoattractant for neutrophils and is a key mediator of inflammation. IL-8 is a member of the CXC chemokine family that also includes IP-1 0, ENA-7 8, and GRO-alpha. The CXC chemokines are distinguished from the C-X-C chemokines by the presence of a conserved glutamic acid-leucine (EL) motif adjacent to the N-terminus that is absent in the C-X-C chemokines. The ELR motif is essential for the angiogenic activity of IL-8. The receptor for IL-8 is a G-protein coupled receptor that signals through the MAP kinase and NF-kB pathways to activate transcription of genes involved in inflammation and chemotaxis. The receptor for IL-8 is a heterodimer of CXCR1 and CXCR2. The affinity of CXCR2 for IL-8 is greater than CXCR1, but the expression level of CXCR2 is much higher than CXCR1 in neutrophils. The expression of CXCR1 and CXCR2 on neutrophils is regulated by inflammatory stimuli. IL-8 is a key mediator of inflammation and is a therapeutic target for the treatment of inflammatory conditions.

Protein phosphorylation plays a key role in the control of translation. Eukaryotic initiation factor 2 (eIF-2) is a key translation factor that regulates the initiation of protein synthesis. Phosphorylation of eIF-2 by protein kinases inhibits eIF-2 and protein synthesis. Protein phosphatase-1 (PP1) and protein phosphatase-2A (PP2A) are involved in the dephosphorylation of eIF-2 and the reversal of the inhibition of protein synthesis. The activity of eIF-2 is regulated by phosphorylation of a specific subunit, eIF-2 alpha. eIF-2 alpha kinase (PKR) is activated by double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) and phosphorylates eIF-2 alpha. PKR is also activated by hemin deficiency, a condition that occurs during cellular stress. Activated PKR phosphorylates eIF-2 alpha, inhibiting eIF-2 and protein synthesis. PP1 and PP2A are involved in the dephosphorylation of eIF-2 alpha. PP1 dephosphorylates eIF-2 alpha and activates eIF-2 and protein synthesis. PP2A dephosphorylates eIF-2 alpha and inactivates eIF-2 and protein synthesis.

Insulin resistance is a common feature of type II diabetes. The development of insulin resistance is associated with a decrease in the ability of insulin to stimulate glucose uptake into skeletal muscle. Skeletal muscle accounts for more than half of insulin-stimulated glucose uptake. Insulin stimulates glucose uptake into skeletal muscle by increasing the translocation of the glucose transporter GLUT4 from an intracellular pool to the plasma membrane. The development of insulin resistance is associated with defects in insulin signaling. The insulin receptor tyrosine kinase pathway plays a key role in insulin signaling. Binding of insulin to its receptor activates the receptor tyrosine kinase, which phosphorylates downstream substrates including the insulin receptor substrates (IRS). Tyrosine-phosphorylated IRS proteins bind to and activate the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway. PI3K phosphorylates the lipid phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PI 4,5 P2), which in turn activates the serine / threonine kinase AKT. AKT phosphorylates and activates the Rab-GAP protein AS1 6 0, which inhibits GLUT4 translocation. AKT also phosphorylates and inhibits the forkhead transcription factor FKHRL1, which promotes GLUT4 translocation. Another substrate of the insulin receptor tyrosine kinase is Shc, which activates the Ras-dependent mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway. The Ras-dependent MAPK pathway also contributes to the stimulation of glucose uptake by insulin. The serine / threonine kinase mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin) is a downstream target of the PI3K pathway and a key regulator of protein synthesis. Rapamycin, an inhibitor of mTOR, blocks the stimulation of protein synthesis by insulin and other growth factors. Rapamycin also blocks the stimulation of glucose uptake by insulin, indicating that mTOR is involved in insulin signaling.

The Eph family of receptor tyrosine kinases and their ligands, ephrins, are involved in the guidance of neuronal and vascular development. The ephrins are tethered to the cell surface by a GPI anchor, but can also be cleaved and released as soluble factors. The Eph receptors are tethered to the cell surface by a transmembrane domain, and are therefore able to transduce signals in both directions across the plasma membrane. The ephrins are tethered to the extracellular matrix or other cells by a second membrane-spanning domain. The Eph receptors and ephrins are involved in the guidance of neuronal and vascular development. The ephrins and Eph receptors are involved in the guidance of neuronal and vascular development. The ephrins and Eph receptors are involved in the guidance of neuronal and vascular development. The ephrins and Eph receptors are involved in the guidance of neuronal and vascular development.
