The rolling of leukocytes along the vascular endothelium is an essential step in the inflammatory response. This process is mediated by the interaction of the leukocyte adhesion molecule LFA-1 (lymphocyte function-associated antigen-1) with its endothelial counter-receptor ICAM-1 (intercellular adhesion molecule-1). The rolling leukocytes are then activated to adhere to the endothelium and migrate into the tissue in a process known as firm adhesion. The firm adhesion of leukocytes is mediated by the interaction of Mac-1 (macrophage-1 antigen) with its endothelial counter-receptor, ICAM-1. The rolling and firm adhesion of leukocytes is mediated by a series of adhesion molecules on the surface of the leukocytes and the vascular endothelium. The interaction of the selectins with their counter-receptors on the vascular endothelium initiates the rolling of leukocytes along the endothelium. The interaction of LFA-1 and ICAM-1 mediates the rolling of leukocytes. The firm adhesion of leukocytes is mediated by the interaction of Mac-1 with ICAM-1. The interaction of P-selectin on the vascular endothelium with its ligand on the leukocyte, PSGL-1, is also involved in the rolling of leukocytes. The rolling of leukocytes along the vascular endothelium is followed by their firm adhesion and migration into the tissue. The interaction of LFA-1 and ICAM-1 is required for the firm adhesion of leukocytes. The interaction of Mac-1 and ICAM-1 is required for the migration of leukocytes into the tissue. The interaction of LFA-1 and ICAM-1 is inhibited by the interaction of PSGL-1 with P-selectin.

DNA mismatch repair (MMR) is a highly conserved mechanism that removes base-pair mismatches and insertion-deletion loops (IDLs) generated during DNA replication. MMR corrects replication errors that escape DNA polymerases proofreading activity. MMR also plays a role in other DNA transactions, including DNA damage signaling and recombination. Defects in MMR genes are associated with genome instability and predisposition to certain types of cancer. MMR proteins are classified into three groups: 1) MutS homologs (MSH), 2) MutL homologs (MLH), and 3) exonuclease I (EXOI). MSH2 and MSH6 (hMutS) form a heterodimer that recognizes mismatches and recruits MLH1 and PMS2 (hMutLα) to the mismatch. MLH1 and PMS2 form a heterodimer that is also recruited by MSH proteins. The recruitment of these complexes by the MSH complex activates the exonucleolytic activity of EXOI, which excises the error-containing strand and then uses the intact strand as a template for repair synthesis. After repair synthesis, the single-stranded gap is filled by DNA polymerase and DNA ligase.

The Krebs cycle is a central metabolic pathway that produces NADH and FADH for use in oxidative phosphorylation. The Krebs cycle also produces precursors for amino acids, fatty acids and other metabolites. The cycle begins with the conversion of acetyl-CoA to citrate by acetyl-CoA carboxylase. Citrate is converted to isocitrate by citrate synthase. Isocitrate is converted to alpha-ketoglutarate by isocitrate dehydrogenase. The Krebs cycle then proceeds through a series of reactions to convert alpha-ketoglutarate to succinyl-CoA, which is then converted to fumarate by a series of reactions. Fumarate is converted to malate by malate dehydrogenase. Finally, malate is converted to pyruvate by the enzyme malic enzyme. The pyruvate is converted to acetyl-CoA by pyruvate dehydrogenase. The acetyl-CoA is converted to citrate by citrate synthase. The cycle continues with the conversion of acetyl-CoA to the Krebs cycle intermediate, alpha-ketoglutarate. The cycle ends with the conversion of succinyl-CoA to succinate by succinyl-CoA synthetase. Succinate is converted to fumarate by fumarate hydratase. The cycle ends with the conversion of malate to pyruvate by malic enzyme. The cycle is completed with the conversion of NADH to NAD + by the electron transport chain. The cycle is completed in four steps each cycle. The cycle begins with acetyl-CoA, which is converted to citrate by acetyl-CoA carboxylase. The next cycle step is the conversion of isocitrate to alpha-ketoglutarate by isocitrate dehydrogenase. The next cycle step is the conversion of alpha-ketoglutarate to succinate by succinyl-CoA synthetase. The next step is the conversion of fumarate to malate by fumarate hydratase. The next step is the conversion of malate to pyruvate by malic enzyme. The cycle ends with the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA by pyruvate dehydrogenase. The cycle is completed with the conversion of NADH to NAD + by the electron transport chain. The cycle completes each cycle by converting NADH to NAD +. The cycle ends with the conversion of pyruvate to succinyl-CoA by succinyl-CoA synthetase. The cycle completes each cycle by converting succinyl-CoA to succinate by succinyl-CoA synthetase.

The sense of taste is initiated by the perception of a tastant by taste receptor cells (TRCs). TRCs are classified into two types, bitter-sensitive (type II) and umami-sensitive (type III) TRCs. Bitter-sensitive TRCs respond to a variety of bitter compounds, including toxins, whereas umami-sensitive TRCs respond to monosodium glutamate (MSG) and MSG-containing foods. Bitter and umami taste are detected by membrane-bound taste receptors, T2Rs and mGluRs, respectively. Bitter taste receptors are GPCRs coupled to gustducin, a G protein alpha-subunit, which activates the downstream signaling cascade. Umami taste receptors are GPCRs that are coupled to the G protein, Gq. Downstream signaling by mGluRs leads to the activation of phospholipase C (PLC), which cleaves phosphatidylinositol 4, 5-bisphosphate to produce inositol 1, 4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). IP3 binds to receptors in the endoplasmic reticulum to release calcium (Ca2 +) from this organelle. Ca2 + then flows into the cytosol through IP3 receptors and / or the calcium release-activated calcium channel (CRAC). Ca2 + is an important second messenger that regulates a variety of cellular functions. Ca2 + influx through CRAC channels activates the Na + / Ca2 + exchanger, which exports Na + and imports Ca2 +. The resulting increase in intracellular Ca2 + activates the Ca2 + -activated chloride channel, which depolarizes the plasma membrane and opens the transduction channels of the TRC. TRC depolarization activates the transduction channels in primary afferent fibers, which convey the taste signal to the brain.

The ets family of transcription factors is defined by the presence of a conserved DNA binding domain, the ETS domain, that recognizes a core sequence 5 '-GGAA / T-3'. The ets family is comprised of more than 3 0 genes in mammals and is involved in a variety of developmental processes and cellular functions. The ets-family genes are further divided into subfamilies based on the similarity of the ETS domain and the non-conserved flanking sequences. The ets- subfamily genes include PU.1, Spi-1 / PU.1, Erg, Fli-1, Ets2, Elf-1, NERF, Tle-1, Tal-1, and Er8 1. The ets-family genes are involved in a variety of cellular processes including differentiation, proliferation, apoptosis, and transformation. The activity of the ets-family genes is regulated by a variety of mechanisms including autoregulation, post-translational modification, and interaction with other transcription factors. The interaction of ets-family genes with other transcription factors is often cooperative and leads to the activation or repression of target genes. The cooperative interactions between ets-family genes and other transcription factors are often mediated by the recruitment of coactivators or corepressors to the target promoters. The coactivators include CBP / p30 0, p300-CBP associated factor, and p160 / SRC-1. Corepressors include mSin3A, N-CoR, and SMRT. The recruitment of coactivators or corepressors by transcription factors often involves the use of a LxxL motif to interact with a hydrophobic cleft on the surface of the transcription factor. The LxxL motif is found in a variety of transcription factors including the ets-family genes Fli-1, Ets2, and PU.1. The LxxL motif is also found in the corepressor NCoR and SMRT. The interaction of the ets-family genes with coactivators and corepressors is often regulated by post-translational modification of the transcription factors. The interaction of PU.1 with CBP / p30 0 is negatively regulated by phosphorylation of threonine-5 7 2 by the kinase p38. The interaction of PU.1 with p160 / SRC-1 is also negatively regulated by phosphorylation of threonine-5 7 2. The interaction of PU.1 with corepressors mSin3A and N-CoR is positively regulated by phosphorylation of threonine-5 7 2 by p38. The interaction of PU.1 with Ets-2 is negatively regulated by phosphorylation of threonine-2 1 2 by Erk2. The interaction of Fli-1 with CBP / p30 0 is negatively regulated by phosphorylation of threonine-3 5 by casein kinase II. The interaction of Ets2 with CBP / p30 0 is negatively regulated by phosphorylation of threonine-3 8 and threonine-3 9 by p38. The interaction of Elf-1 with CBP / p30 0 is negatively regulated by phosphorylation of threonine-3 8 by p38. The interaction of Tel with CBP / p30 0 is negatively regulated by phosphorylation of threonine-2 1. The interaction of NERF with CBP / p30 0 is negatively regulated by phosphorylation of threonine-2 0. The interaction of Tal-1 with CBP / p30 0 is negatively regulated by phosphorylation of threonine-2 0. The interaction of Er8 1 with CBP / p30 0 is negatively regulated by phosphorylation of threonine-2 1. The interaction of Ets-2 with p30 0 is negatively regulated by phosphorylation of threonine-2 1 2 by p38. The interaction of PU.1 with p30 0 is negatively regulated by phosphorylation of threonine-2 1 8 by p38.

Calpain is a calcium-dependent protease that is involved in a variety of cellular functions, including cell motility and adhesion. Calpain is a heterodimer, consisting of a large catalytic subunit (8 0kDa) and a small regulatory subunit (30kDa). The large subunit contains the protease active site, and the small subunit is involved in calcium binding and membrane localization. Calpain is activated by calcium binding to the regulatory subunit, and is inhibited by the binding of calpastatin to the large subunit. Calpain cleaves a variety of substrates, including cytoskeletal proteins, cell adhesion molecules, and signaling proteins. Calpain activity is regulated by phosphorylation, and by the presence of other proteins that interact with calpain. The large subunit of calpain is encoded by a single gene, CAPN1, which is alternatively spliced to produce four different isoforms. The small subunit is encoded by a separate gene, CAPN2. Calpain is localized in the cytosol in a quiescent state, but is recruited to the plasma membrane and cytoskeleton by calcium binding. Membrane localization of calpain is mediated by interaction with the cytoskeletal protein spectrin, and by interaction with the membrane protein talin. Talin is involved in cell adhesion and integrin signaling, and calpain cleaves talin to regulate cell adhesion. The calpain substrate beta-catenin is involved in cell adhesion, and cleavage of beta-catenin by calpain disrupts cell adhesion. Paxillin is another cytoskeletal protein involved in cell adhesion that is cleaved by calpain. Calpain also cleaves the focal adhesion kinase (FAK), disrupting focal adhesions and cell motility. Calpain also cleaves Rac and Rho, two small GTPases involved in cell motility, to regulate cell motility. Calpain activity is inhibited by the binding of calpastatin to the large subunit of calpain, and by the binding of the small subunit to the regulatory subunit. The binding of the regulatory subunit to the small subunit is inhibited by the binding of the inhibitory domain of calpastatin to the large subunit. The activity of calpain is also regulated by phosphorylation. Phosphorylation of the regulatory subunit of calpain by protein kinase C inhibits calpain activity. The activity of calpain is also regulated by the calcium binding protein 36kDa (36k). The 36kDa protein is a calcium binding protein that is localized to the membrane and cytoskeleton, and is involved in the regulation of calpain activity. The activity of 36kDa is inhibited by the binding of calpastatin to the large subunit of calpain, and is activated by the binding of 36kDa to the small subunit.

The activation of macrophages by bacterial products such as lipopolysaccharide (LPS) is essential for the innate immune response to infection. LPS activates macrophages through a receptor complex containing Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) and the CD1 4 coreceptor. LPS binding to the receptor complex activates multiple signal transduction pathways, including the NF-kappaB and AP-1 transcription factors, which lead to the expression of genes involved in inflammation and immune responses.

Vasopressin (AVP) is a nonapeptide hormone that regulates water homeostasis by increasing water intake and decreasing water excretion in the kidneys and the colon. AVP is released into the circulation by the pituitary in response to increased plasma osmolality or decreased blood volume. In the kidney, AVP binds to V2 receptors in the collecting duct cells, increasing cAMP levels and activating the protein kinase A (PKA) pathway. This in turn leads to phosphorylation of the water channel aquaporin-2 (AQP2) and its insertion into the apical plasma membrane, increasing water permeability and promoting water excretion into the urinary bladder. In addition to this short-term regulation, AVP also regulates AQP2 expression at the transcriptional level. In the kidney, long-term exposure to high levels of AVP results in increased AQP2 expression and the development of water-imbalance disorders such as diabetes insipidus. In the rat inner medullary collecting duct (IMCD), AVP increases AQP2 expression by increasing the half-life of AQP2 mRNA. In addition to AQP2, AVP also regulates the expression of other proteins involved in water transport, including the Na + / K + -ATPase and the Na + / H + exchanger.

Cardiac muscle contraction is triggered by the influx of extracellular calcium ions (Ca (2 +)) through voltage-gated L-type Ca (2 +) channels (LCCs) in the sarcolemmal (SL) membrane. The resulting increase in intracellular Ca (2 +) (Ca (2 +)) triggers the release of Ca (2 +) from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) via the ryanodine receptor (RyR) Ca (2 +) release channels (CRSs). The Ca (2 +) that activates the contractile proteins is mainly derived from the release of SR Ca (2 +). This is called the Ca (2 +) -induced Ca (2 +) release mechanism. The Ca (2 +) that activates the contractile proteins is pumped out of the cell by the SR Ca (2 +) -ATPase (SERCA) and the Na (+) / Ca (2 +) exchanger (NCX). The amount of Ca (2 +) that enters the cell via the LCC is determined by the balance between Ca (2 +) influx through the LCC and Ca (2 +) removal via the SERCA and NCX. The Ca (2 +) that enters the cell is buffered by intracellular Ca (2 +) -binding proteins and is returned to the extracellular space via the NCX. The Ca (2 +) that enters the cell via the LCC is also pumped out of the cell by the SERCA in a manner that depends on the preceding Ca (2 +) removal rate. This is known as the Ca (2 +) -induced Ca (2 +) release mechanism. The Ca (2 +) that enters the cell via the NCX is pumped out of the cell by the same mechanism.

The vitamin D receptor (VDR) is a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily that functions as a ligand-dependent transcription factor. The VDR binds to the vitamin D response element (VDRE) in the promoter region of target genes and regulates their transcription in a ligand-dependent manner. The ligand-dependent transcriptional activity of the VDR is regulated by a variety of coregulators. The SWI / SNF complex is one of the best characterized coregulators. The SWI / SNF complex uses the energy of ATP to alter the structure of chromatin and facilitate the binding of transcription factors to nucleosomal DNA. The SWI / SNF complex is composed of at least nine subunits, including BRG1 or hBRM as the ATPase subunit. The SWI / SNF complex interacts with a large number of transcription factors and coregulators to regulate their transcriptional activity. The p300 subunit interacts directly with the VDR and is required for the transcriptional activity of the VDR. The histone acetylase (HAT) activity of coactivators also plays an important role in transcriptional regulation. The p300 subunit interacts directly with CBP and p300-CBP interaction is required for the transcriptional activity of the VDR. The coactivators such as SRC-1 and CBP / p300 also possess histone acetylase activity. The vitamin D receptor-interacting protein (DRIP) complex is another coactivator complex that interacts with the VDR. The DRIP complex interacts with the basal transcriptional machinery and functions as a bridge between transcription factors and the RNA polymerase II.

Angiotensin II (Ang II) is a peptide hormone that plays a key role in the regulation of blood pressure and sodium homeostasis. Ang II is formed from the cleavage of the inactive decapeptide angiotensin I (Ang I) by the enzyme renin. Ang II is a potent vasoconstrictor that increases blood pressure by increasing vascular resistance. Ang II also has a number of other actions including the regulation of aldosterone secretion by the adrenal gland, sodium retention by the kidneys, and the regulation of sodium balance in the heart and brain. Ang II is formed in the heart and blood vessels from the conversion of circulating inactive AGT by the enzyme ACE. ACE is a zinc peptidase that is anchored to the cell surface by a glycosyl-phosphatidylinositol (GPI) linkage. ACE is found in high concentrations in the lungs and at lower concentrations in the kidneys, heart, and blood vessels. Ang II is formed in the heart and blood vessels from the cleavage of circulating AGT by ACE. ACE inhibitors block the formation of Ang II and are used to treat hypertension and heart failure. ACE is also found in the testes and may play a role in the regulation of fertility. Ang II is a substrate for the enzyme chymase, which is found in high concentrations in the heart and in the lungs. ACE inhibitors do not cross the blood brain barrier and do not affect brain function. The ACE gene has been mapped to chromosome 1 7q2 3. 3 and is a single copy gene. The ACE gene has been cloned and sequenced and found to contain 2 6 exons. The ACE gene is regulated by two promoters and by alternative splicing of the ACE mRNA. The kidney and lungs are the main sites of ACE synthesis. The kidney is the main site of degradation of Ang II. ACE inhibitors block the degradation of Ang II in the circulation but do not cross the blood brain barrier and do not affect brain function. The second enzyme involved in the formation of Ang II is chymase. Chymase is a serine protease that is found in high concentrations in the heart and in the heart valves. Chymase is a zinc protease that is not inhibited by ACE inhibitors. Chymase is not inhibited by the ACE inhibitor chymostatin. Ang II is not formed from AGT by chymase. The heart and blood vessels are the main sites of Ang II formation from AGT by chymase. ACE inhibitors do not cross the blood brain barrier and do not affect brain function.

Bladder cancer is the fourth most common malignancy in men in the United States. Approximately 7 5% of bladder cancers are transitional cell carcinomas (TCC). The majority of bladder cancers are superficial, papillary tumors that are treated by transurethral resection. Approximately 3 0% of patients with superficial bladder cancer will develop muscle invasive disease. The 5-year survival rate for patients with muscle invasive bladder cancer is less than 5 0%. The molecular pathogenesis of bladder cancer is complex and involves the activation of oncogenes and inactivation of tumor suppressor genes. The most common genetic alterations in bladder cancer are in the p53, RAS, RB, and EGF receptor pathways.

Insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) is a polypeptide hormone with structural and functional similarities to insulin. IGF-1 binds to the IGF-1 receptor (IGF-1R), a tyrosine kinase receptor, and activates multiple signaling pathways that regulate cellular proliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis. IGF-1 is an important mediator of growth and development, and is also implicated in the development of cancer. IGF-1R is widely expressed in many tissues, and its expression is increased in many cancers. IGF-1R signaling activates the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway, which leads to activation of AKT and mTOR. AKT phosphorylates and inhibits the activity of the forkhead transcription factor FKHRL1, which regulates expression of the cell cycle inhibitor p2 7Kip1. mTOR also regulates translation by phosphorylating the translation initiation factor 4E binding protein (4E-BP) and the 7 0 kDa ribosomal protein S6 kinase (p70S6K). Phosphorylation of 4E-BP releases the initiation factor 4E (eIF-4E), which binds to eIF-4G to form the eIF-4F complex that binds to the 5 'cap of mRNA and facilitates translation initiation. eIF-4F also binds to the poly (A) binding protein (PABP), which interacts with the poly (A) tail of mRNA and facilitates ribosome scanning and translation initiation. AKT also phosphorylates and inhibits glycogen synthase kinase 3 (GSK-3), which phosphorylates and activates eIF4B. Phosphorylation of eIF4B and p70S6K increases the translation of mRNAs with a complex 5' cap.

Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) and the structurally related pituitary adenylate cyclase-activating polypeptide (PACAP) are neuropeptides widely expressed in the nervous system and in peripheral tissues. They exert a broad spectrum of biological actions, including regulation of hormone secretion, neuronal transmission, immune functions, and cell proliferation. The biological actions of VIP and PACAP are mediated by the interaction with specific receptors, VPAC and PAC, which are coupled to Gs and Gq / 1 1 proteins, respectively. The activation of these G proteins stimulates the adenylate cyclase and the phospholipase C pathways. Both pathways lead to the activation of protein kinase A and C, which in turn activate several transcription factors, including CREB, NF-AT, and NF-kB. VIP and PACAP exert a potent growth-regulatory activity, inhibiting the proliferation of normal and transformed cells. The growth-inhibitory activity of VIP and PACAP is mediated by the activation of the p35-15 kinase and the subsequent induction of the p190-1 4 2 / RB-0 5 0 / RB-0 2 0 tumor suppressor gene. The induction of RB-0 5 0 / RB-0 2 0 leads to the inhibition of cyclin-dependent kinases and the consequent cell cycle arrest.

The cell cycle is a series of events that result in the duplication of DNA and the partitioning of chromosomes between the two daughter cells. The cell cycle is regulated by a series of checkpoints that prevent the cell from progressing through the cycle if conditions are not right. The G1 / S checkpoint prevents the cell from entering S phase if conditions are not right. The G2 / M checkpoint prevents the cell from entering mitosis if conditions are not right. The intra-S phase checkpoint prevents the cell from entering S phase if conditions are not right. The G2 / M transition is regulated by the activation of the cyclin dependent kinase Cdc2. The activity of Cdc2 is regulated by the phosphorylation of tyrosine 1 5 by the kinases Wee1 and Mik1. The activation of the checkpoint kinases Chk1 and Chk2 in response to DNA damage results in the phosphorylation and inhibition of Cdc2 5C, the phosphatase that dephosphorylates Cdc2. The activation of the DNA damage checkpoint also results in the inhibition of the transcription of a number of genes involved in DNA replication, including cyclin A and Cdc25A. The inhibition of cyclin A transcription results in the inhibition of the activation of the cyclin E-cdk2 complex, which is required for the G1 / S transition. The inhibition of Cdc25A transcription results in the inhibition of the activation of the checkpoint kinase chk1, which is required for the activation of the G2 / M checkpoint.

The dystrophin-glycoprotein complex (DGC) is a multi-subunit protein complex that links the cytoskeleton to the extracellular matrix. The core complex consists of the dystrophins (Dys), the dystroglycans (Dg), and the sarcoglycans (SG). The sarcoglycans form a complex with sarcospan (SSPN), sarcospan-sarcotrim (SGCA-D), and caveolin-3 (CAV3). The sarcoglycans are associated with the dystrophin complex through sarcospan. The DGC is expressed in skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscle. Defects in the DGC are associated with the muscle disease Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) and the muscle disease Limb Girdle Muscular Dystrophy (LGMD). The sarcoglycans are a part of the DGC and are expressed in skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscle. The sarcoglycans are a family of four transmembrane proteins (SCAP-SCLAV). SCAP is a single transmembrane protein that is expressed in skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscle. SCAP is associated with the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and is required for the stable expression of SCAP and the sarcoglycans in the plasma membrane. SCAP is also required for the stable expression of the other members of the DGC, the dystrophins and the dystroglycans. The sarcoglycans are members of the tetraspanin family of proteins. The tetraspanins are a group of membrane proteins that are associated with the plasma membrane and are involved in a variety of cellular processes. The tetraspanins are characterized by four transmembrane domains and are involved in cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions. The tetraspanin CD3 7 is associated with the B cell receptor complex and is involved in B cell activation. The tetraspanin CD1 5 1 is associated with the integrin alpha1beta1integrin and is involved in the regulation of cell motility and cell signaling. The association of the sarcoglycans with the DGC may be involved in the stabilization of the sarcoglycans in the plasma membrane. The dystroglycans are a family of high molecular weight glycoproteins that are expressed in a variety of tissues including brain, skeletal muscle, heart, and lung. The dystroglycans are part of the DGC. The dystroglycans are a family of three proteins that are expressed in a variety of tissues. The dystroglycans are a family of three proteins that are expressed in a variety of tissues. The dystroglycans are a family of three proteins that are expressed in a variety of tissues.
