The NF-kB transcription factor regulates expression of genes involved in inflammation, apoptosis, cell proliferation, and differentiation. The NF-kB family is formed from five subunits, p5 0, p5 2, p6 5, c-Rel, and RelB. The p5 0 and p5 2 subunits are generated by the proteolytic processing of the larger precursors, p1 0 5 and p1 0 0. The precursor proteins contain an N-terminal dimerization domain, a C-terminal DNA binding domain, and a regulatory domain that contains the site of proteolytic processing. The precursor proteins are retained in the cytoplasm by an inhibitory complex that contains an ankyrin repeat region and a C-terminal leucine-rich repeat. The inhibitory complex is disrupted by various stimuli, including the phosphorylation of IkB by the IkB kinase (IKK1 and IKK2). The dissociation of the inhibitory complex allows the NF-kB subunits to translocate to the nucleus and bind to specific DNA sequences. The IkB kinase complex is a multi-subunit complex that includes the kinases IKK1 and IKK2, and the regulatory subunit NEMO / IKKgamma. The activation of NF-kB by a variety of stimuli, including TNF-alpha, IL-1, LPS, and T cell receptor activation, requires the phosphorylation of IkB by the IKKs. The IKK complex is also involved in the activation of NF-kB by the Tax protein of HTLV-1, and the Epstein Barr virus BNLF2a protein. The activation of NF-kB by Tax requires the phosphorylation of the IKK complex, but does not require the degradation of IkB. The activation of NF-kB by BNLF2a does not require the phosphorylation of the IKK complex, but does require the phosphorylation of IkB. The activation of NF-kB by Tax also does not require the phosphorylation of IkB, but does require the degradation of IkB. The activation of NF-kB by Tax requires the IKK complex, but does not require the phosphorylation of IkB. The activation of NF-kB by BNLF2a does not require the phosphorylation of IkB, but does require the degradation of IkB.

Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) are a key component of the immune system that kills cells that have been infected with foreign pathogens or that have undergone malignant transformation. CTLs kill cells by two main mechanisms: the first is through the release of granules that contain perforin and granzyme proteins that induce apoptosis in the targeted cell. The second mechanism is through the interaction of Fas ligand on the CTL with Fas on the target cell, activating the apoptotic pathway. The Fas-mediated pathway is used by CTLs to kill cells that are virus infected or that have undergone malignant transformation. The interaction of CTLs with their targets leads to the release of perforin from the CTL into the intercellular space between the two cells. Perforin forms pores in the membrane of the targeted cell, allowing granzymes to enter the cell and activate apoptotic pathways. The interaction of CTLs with their targets also activates the transcription factor NF-AT, which induces the expression of FasL on the target cell, allowing the CTL to kill additional target cells.

The innate immune response is the first line of defense against invading pathogens. The innate immune response is triggered by the recognition of pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) by pattern recognition receptors (PRRs). The Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are a class of PRRs that recognize PAMPs and play a key role in the innate immune response. Upon recognition of PAMPs, TLRs activate signaling pathways that lead to the production of inflammatory cytokines and interferons. The downstream signaling pathways activated by TLRs are highly conserved and are similar in all cell types. The first TLR signaling pathway identified was the MyD8 8-dependent pathway. In this pathway, the Toll / IL-1R domain-containing adaptor protein (TIRAP) is recruited to the plasma membrane by the activated TLR. TIRAP then recruits the IL-1 receptor-associated kinase (IRAK) to the receptor. IRAK is then phosphorylated and dissociates from the receptor complex. IRAK then interacts with TRAF6, a ubiquitin ligase that activates the transcription factor NF-kB. TRAF6 also activates the MAP kinase pathway, leading to the activation of AP-1 and the production of inflammatory cytokines. In addition to the MyD8 8-dependent pathway, several other pathways have been identified that activate NF-kB and MAPKs. These pathways are dependent on the specific TLR and the ligand recognized by the receptor. For example, in response to LPS, TLR4 activates the MyD8 8-independent pathway through the adaptor TRIF. TRIF activates the transcription factor IRF-3, leading to the production of interferon.

Cutaneous melanoma is the most serious form of skin cancer, accounting for approximately 4% of all cancer deaths. The incidence of melanoma has been on the increase for the past 3 0 years, with a peak incidence in the 54years of age. The prognosis for patients with metastatic melanoma is poor, with a 5-year survival rate of less than 1 5%. The molecular pathogenesis of melanoma is complex and heterogeneous. The majority of melanomas arise from the clonal expansion of melanocytes with the acquisition of one or more mutations. These mutations include those in the genes for the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 2A (CDKN2A), the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 2B (CDKN2B), and the v-kit Hardy-Zuckerman 4feline sarcoma viral oncogene homolog (KIT). Other genes that have been implicated in melanoma pathogenesis include the phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN), the p53 tumor suppressor, the melanocortin 1 receptor (MC1R), the glutathione S-transferases (GSTs), and the micro-opthalmia-associated transcription factor (MITF). The majority of melanomas are sporadic, with an estimated 8 0% of cases arising from the combination of environmental and genetic factors. The role of the environment in melanoma pathogenesis is supported by the fact that the incidence of melanoma is increasing at a greater rate than any other cancer. The role of genetic factors is supported by the fact that familial melanoma accounts for only 1-5% of all melanoma cases. The inheritance of melanoma susceptibility genes is complex, with multiple genes involved and an array of phenotypes. The role of genetics in melanoma susceptibility is supported by the fact that familial melanoma accounts for only 1-5% of all melanoma cases. The RAB proteins are a family of small GTPases that regulate intracellular membrane traffic. They are involved in the formation of vesicles from the donor membrane, their movement along the cytoskeleton, and their fusion with the acceptor membrane. The RAB proteins are activated by exchange of bound GDP for GTP and are deactivated by hydrolysis of bound GTP to GDP. The RAB proteins are regulated by a variety of proteins that stimulate or inhibit the exchange of GDP for GTP. The exchange factors include the GDS family and the SEC7domain family. The GAPs include the RABGAP family and the TBC family. The GAPs inactivate the RAB proteins by stimulating their own GTP hydrolysis. The GDP dissociation inhibitors (GDIs) inhibit the activation of the RAB proteins by inhibiting the dissociation of GDP from the RAB proteins. The GDI proteins bind to the RAB proteins in the cytosol and keep them in the inactive, GDP-bound form. The RAB proteins are transported to their target membranes where they are activated by the exchange of GDP for GTP and are inactivated by the hydrolysis of bound GTP to GDP. The target membranes include the plasma membrane, the Golgi complex, and the endoplasmic reticulum. The RAB proteins are inactivated on the target membrane by the action of the RAB-GAPs. The RAB-GAPs include the RN-tre family, the ALX family, and the GAP1 family. The GEFs include the SEC7domain family and the GDS family. The GAPs and GDIs inhibit the activation of the RAB proteins on the target membrane. The target membranes include the plasma membrane, the Golgi complex, and the endoplasmic reticulum.

Blood coagulation is a series of reactions that result in the formation of a clot at the site of a wound or rupture of a blood vessel. The clotting factors in the clotting cascade are serine proteases. The clotting cascade begins with the activation of prothrombin by the enzyme thrombin. Thrombin cleaves fibrinogen to form fibrin, the major protein in blood clots. The fibrin clot is a mesh-like structure that protects the wound from bleeding. The clotting cascade is completed when activated factor XIII cross-links the fibrin fibers to form a clot. The clotting cascade is regulated by a variety of proteins that either activate or inhibit the cascade. The prothrombin activating complex is a complex of factors V, VII, and X and a phospholipid surface. The prothrombin activating complex is activated by tissue factor, a membrane bound protein that is expressed by damaged cells. The prothrombin activating complex is inhibited by tissue factor pathway inhibitor (TFPI), a plasma protein that is released into the blood by the damaged cells. The prothrombin activating complex is also inhibited by antithrombin III, another plasma protein that is activated by thrombin. The clotting cascade is also inhibited by heparin, a negatively charged polysaccharide that binds to antithrombin III. Antithrombin III and heparin bind to thrombin and block the interaction of thrombin with other proteins in the clotting cascade. The prothrombin activating complex is also inhibited by heparin cofactor II, a plasma protein that is closely related in sequence to antithrombin III. The prothrombin activating complex is also inhibited by the serpin protease nexin-1 (PN-1). PN-1 is a secreted protein that is activated by thrombin to form an inactive complex with thrombin. The activated form of PN-1 also inhibits factors IXa and Xa in the clotting cascade. The clotting cascade is also inhibited by the fibrinolytic system. The fibrinolytic system is a cascade of enzymes that lyses clots. The initial step in the fibrinolytic system is the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin by tissue-type plasminogen activator (tPA) or urokinase-type plasminogen activator (uPA). Plasmin then digests fibrin clots and other proteins in clots. The inhibition of the clotting cascade by heparin is due to the binding of heparin to thrombin and the subsequent inhibition of the thrombin by heparin cofactor II.

Interleukin-1 2 (IL-1 2) is a key cytokine in cell-mediated immune response. IL-1 2 induces the differentiation of Th1 cells from naive T cells and stimulates the proliferation and activation of Th1 cells. The activity of IL-1 2 is regulated by IL-1 8, another key cytokine in cell-mediated immune response. IL-1 8 is a member of the IL-1 family and shares a receptor with IL-1beta. IL-1 8 is produced by macrophages and stimulates the production of IL-1 2 by macrophages and other cells. IL-1 2 and IL-1 8 induce the differentiation of Th1 cells from naive T cells and stimulate the proliferation and activation of Th1 cells. The activity of IL-1 2 is regulated by IL-10, an anti-inflammatory cytokine. IL-10 inhibits the production of IL-1 2 and IL-18 and the activity of Th1 cells. The activity of IL-10 is regulated by IL-12 and IL-18.

The MYC transcription factor is a key regulator of cell proliferation and growth. MYC stimulates cell cycle progression by inducing the expression of genes involved in cell cycle progression, including cyclin D1 and the cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) Cdk4 and Cdk6. MYC also stimulates ribosomal RNA (rRNA) synthesis by RNA polymerase I (Pol I), and this contributes to cell growth in addition to cell cycle progression. The induction of rRNA synthesis by MYC contributes to the ability of MYC to stimulate cell growth. MYC also stimulates the expression of genes involved in the synthesis and assembly of ribosomes, including ribosomal RNA (rRNA), transfer RNA (tRNA), and ribosomal proteins (rDNAs, RPSs, and RPLs). The coordinate induction of these genes by MYC contributes to the increase in ribosome biogenesis that occurs during cell growth. The induction of rRNA synthesis by MYC contributes to the coordinate increase in rRNA, tRNA, and ribosomal protein gene expression. The induction of rRNA synthesis by MYC contributes to the increase in ribosome biogenesis that occurs during cell growth. The induction of rRNA synthesis by MYC contributes to MYC's ability to stimulate cell growth.

The cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA) is a key component of the cAMP signaling pathway. It is activated by the binding of cAMP to the regulatory subunit of PKA, releasing the catalytic subunit to phosphorylate downstream targets. The catalytic subunit of PKA phosphorylates a variety of substrates including ion channels, transcription factors, and other kinases. The PKA regulatory subunit is encoded by four genes (Prkar1a, Prkar1b, Prkar2a, and Prkar2b) that produce four different isoforms (RIalpha, RIbeta, RIIα, and RIIbeta) that are expressed in a tissue-specific manner. cAMP signaling is terminated by the action of cyclic nucleotide phosphodiesterases (PDEs) that hydrolyze cAMP to 5 '-AMP. There are 1 1 families of PDEs, each with different regulatory properties and tissue distributions.

Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) are nuclear hormone receptors that regulate lipid metabolism and energy homeostasis. They are activated by fatty acids and their derivatives. The three PPAR subtypes (alpha, beta / delta, and gamma) have distinct expression patterns and biological functions. PPAR alpha is a key regulator of lipid metabolism in liver and skeletal muscle. It controls the expression of genes involved in fatty acid oxidation and transport. PPAR beta / delta is involved in lipid metabolism in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue. PPAR gamma is a key regulator of lipid metabolism in adipose tissue. It controls the differentiation and lipid storage of adipocytes.

The intercalated disc is a specialized region of the cardiomyocyte that mechanically couples neighboring myocytes. It is a key structure that transmits mechanical forces generated by the sarcomere to the extracellular matrix, and distributes these forces to the rest of the cell to regulate cellular function. The intercalated disc is a highly organized structure with a complex network of proteins that provide structural integrity and electrical coupling. Disruption of this structure can lead to heart failure.

Hypoxia is a common feature of rapidly growing tumors and is associated with poor prognosis. Cells respond to hypoxia by increasing the expression of genes that allow the cell to survive and proliferate in low oxygen. One of the genes induced by hypoxia is that for vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). VEGF is a secreted protein that stimulates angiogenesis by inducing the growth of new blood vessels. The induction of VEGF by hypoxia is mediated by a hypoxia-response element (HRE) in the VEGF promoter. Binding of the transcription factor HIF-1 to the HRE is required for VEGF induction by hypoxia. HIF-1 is a heterodimer of two subunits, HIF-1alpha and ARNT. ARNT is a member of the bHLH-PAS family of transcription factors that also includes Arnt. HIF-1 is degraded rapidly under normoxic conditions, but is stabilized under hypoxic conditions. The HIF-1alpha subunit is hydroxylated by a family of 2-oxoglutarate-dependent dioxygenases that include FIH-1. The hydroxylation of HIF-1alpha targets it for ubiquitination and degradation by the proteasome. The hydroxylases are oxygen-dependent, suggesting that they are part of the cellular oxygen sensing mechanism. HIF-1 activates the transcription of a number of other genes involved in response to hypoxia, including those for glycolytic enzymes, transferrin, and erythropoietin. ARNT is also required for HIF-1-dependent transcription, but is not itself regulated by hypoxia. HIF-1 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cancer and ischemic diseases.

Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) are nuclear hormone receptors that are activated by fatty acids and their derivatives. PPAR is a heterodimer with the retinoid X receptor (RXR). The binding of ligands to the PPAR-RXR heterodimer induces a conformational change in the receptor, which leads to the release of corepressors and the recruitment of coactivators. The coactivators then interact with the basal transcriptional machinery and other transcription factors to regulate gene transcription. The PPAR-RXR heterodimer regulates lipid metabolism and inflammation. PPAR-RXR also regulates cell differentiation and proliferation. The ligands for PPAR include fatty acids and eicosanoids. The expression of PPAR is tissue-specific. PPARa is expressed in skeletal muscle, brown adipose tissue, heart, liver, and macrophages. PPARb is expressed in brown adipose tissue, heart, liver, and macrophages. PPARg is expressed in adipose tissue and macrophages. The expression of PPARg is induced during adipocyte differentiation.

Peroxisomes are essential organelles that play a crucial role in redox signaling, lipid metabolism and reactive oxygen species (ROS) detoxification. They are involved in lipid metabolism through beta-oxidation of fatty acids and biosynthesis of ether lipids and bile acids. In addition, they are involved in the detoxification of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and reactive nitrogen species (RNS). The biogenesis of peroxisomes is a complex process that requires the coordinated action of more than 5 0 proteins. Defects in peroxisomal biogenesis or function result in severe inherited peroxisomal disorders.

Interleukin-1 2 is a cytokine that stimulates T cells to produce interferon-gamma and other cytokines. It also stimulates the proliferation of T cells. The mechanism of action of IL-1 2 is to stimulate the T cell to produce interferon-gamma, which stimulates the production of nitric oxide by macrophages. The production of nitric oxide inhibits the growth of many different types of cells, including cancer cells. The mechanism of action of IL-1 2 is to stimulate the T cell to produce interferon-gamma, which stimulates the production of nitric oxide by macrophages. The inhibition of cancer cell growth by nitric oxide is indirect. The macrophages inhibit the growth of the cancer cells by producing reactive nitrogen intermediates that damage the cancer cells. The mechanism of action of IL-1 2 is to stimulate the T cell to produce interferon-gamma, which stimulates the production of nitric oxide by the macrophages. The T cell receptor (TCR) complex is composed of an alpha, beta, and gamma chain in a 1: 1: 1 ratio and a delta chain in a 1: 1 ratio. The TCR complex is associated with the CD3 complex, which is composed of the gamma, delta, epsilon, and mu chains. The TCR complex recognizes specific peptide antigens in the context of self-MHC molecules and is required for the activation of T cells. The activation of T cells requires two signals. The first signal is the recognition of antigen by the TCR complex and the second signal is the interaction of costimulatory molecules on the T cell with their ligands on the antigen-presenting cell. The binding of antigen by the TCR complex induces a conformational change in the TCR complex that results in the activation of src family kinases and the phosphorylation of tyrosine residues in the immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motifs (ITAMs) in the cytoplasmic domains of the CD3 chains. The phosphorylation of the ITAMs recruits and activates the ZAP7 0 kinase, which in turn activates the downstream signaling pathways. The activation of src kinases and the phosphorylation of the ITAMs are required for the initiation of T cell activation, but do not appear to be sufficient for T cell activation. The activation of protein kinase A (PKA) by the T cell receptor complex is required for the full activation of T cells. The activation of PKA by the TCR complex is not required for the initiation of T cell activation, but is required for the full activation of T cells. The activation of PKA by the TCR complex is not required for the phosphorylation of the TCR complex or the activation of src kinases, but is required for the full activation of src kinases and the downstream signaling pathways. The activation of PKA by the TCR complex is not required for the binding of T cells to antigen-presenting cells, but is required for the full activation of T cells.

The calcium-activated protease calpain cleaves a variety of cellular proteins, including the cytoskeletal protein spectrin. The cleavage of spectrin by calpain produces a breakdown product that is a marker of calpain activation. The activation of calpain by calcium influx into neurons may be involved in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease. Amyloid beta protein (A beta), which accumulates in the brains of patients with Alzheimer's disease, may cause calcium influx into neurons, activating calpain and causing the cleavage of cellular proteins. The cleavage of the amyloid precursor protein (APP) by calpain may be involved in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease. The activation of calpain by amyloid beta protein may also lead to tau hyperphosphorylation, another factor in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease. The activation of calpain by amyloid beta protein may also lead to the cleavage of the regulatory subunit of calcineurin, a calcium-dependent protein phosphatase. Calpain activation may also play a role in the toxicity of the prion protein.

Endocytosis is the process by which cells internalize extracellular molecules and their ligands by forming vesicles and delivering them to lysosomes for degradation. Endocytosis is also involved in the uptake of nutrients and lipids into cells. There are two major pathways of endocytosis: clathrin-dependent endocytosis (CDE) and clathrin-independent endocytosis (CIE). CDE is the uptake of ligands bound to their receptors by forming clathrin-coated vesicles (CCVs). The formation of CCVs requires the assembly of clathrin and adaptor protein 2 (AP2), clathrin adaptors, dynamin, and lipids at the plasma membrane. Some CIE pathways are characterized by the formation of GPI-anchored proteins (GPI-APs) -enriched early endosomal compartments (GEECs), caveolae, macropinosomes, and lipid rafts. These pathways do not require clathrin or AP2. They require actin filaments and lipid rafts.

Oxidative stress is a condition in which there is an imbalance between the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and the ability of cells to detoxify them. ROS are oxygen-containing molecules with high reactivity. ROS include the superoxide anion (O2 -), hydroxyl radical (OH), and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). ROS are produced as by-products of aerobic metabolism and are also produced as part of the immune response. ROS can damage cellular macromolecules such as DNA, lipids, and proteins. The lung is continuously exposed to environmental oxygen and is therefore particularly susceptible to oxidative stress. ROS are produced in the lung by a variety of sources, including the mitochondrial electron transport chain, inflammatory cells, and environmental pollutants. ROS can damage the lung epithelium, causing barrier dysfunction and allowing the passage of inflammatory cells into the lung. ROS can also damage the lung endothelium, causing barrier dysfunction and allowing the passage of inflammatory cells into the lung. ROS can also activate inflammatory cells, such as macrophages, neutrophils, and mast cells, that produce ROS themselves. ROS can also activate signaling pathways that lead to the production of inflammatory mediators. ROS can activate the transcription factor NF-kB, which regulates the expression of genes involved in inflammation. ROS can also activate the transcription factor Nrf2, which regulates the expression of antioxidant genes. Nrf2 is activated by oxidative stress and translocates to the nucleus to activate the expression of antioxidant genes. Nrf2 activation may be protective against oxidative stress, but prolonged activation of Nrf2 may lead to the production of excessive ROS and chronic inflammation. ROS can also activate the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathways, including the extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK), Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK), and p3 8 pathways. These pathways are involved in the regulation of cell growth, differentiation, and apoptosis. ROS can also activate the transcription factor activator protein-1 (AP-1), which regulates the expression of genes involved in inflammation and apoptosis. ROS can also activate the transcription factor NF-kB, which regulates the expression of genes involved in inflammation and apoptosis. NF-kB activation can also lead to the production of inflammatory mediators such as TNF-alpha and IL-1. ROS can also activate the transcription factor activator protein-1 (AP-1), which regulates the expression of genes involved in inflammation and apoptosis. ROS can also activate the tyrosine kinase c-Src, which can activate NF-kB and AP-1. ROS can also activate the protease caspase-3, which can activate NF-kB and AP-1. ROS can also activate the kinase p38, which can activate NF-kB and AP-1. ROS can also activate the transcription factor Egr-1, which can regulate the expression of genes involved in inflammation and apoptosis. Egr-1 is activated by ROS through the activation of p38 and JNK. Egr-1 can also be activated by growth factors and cytokines, including PDGF, EGF, and TGF-beta. Egr-1 is a nuclear transcription factor that regulates the expression of genes involved in inflammation and apoptosis.

The progestin and adipoQ receptor (PAQR) family is a group of putative 7TM receptors that are structurally related to G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR). The PAQR family is comprised of 7TM receptors PAQR1-7. The PAQRs are structurally related to the AdipoQ receptor family, which includes PAQR5, PAQR6 and PAQR7. PAQRs are widely expressed in a variety of tissues and are coupled to intracellular cAMP signaling pathways. The PAQR family is structurally related to the neuropeptide Y (NPY) family of receptors, which includes the NPY Y1, Y2, Y4, and Y5 receptors. The NPY receptors are coupled to the Gi / o family of G-proteins and are coupled to inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and stimulation of phospholipase C. The PAQR family is structurally related to the ghrelin receptor, which is coupled to the Gq family of G-proteins. The PAQR family is structurally related to the somatostatin receptor family, which includes the sst1, sst2, sst3, and sst5 receptors. The PAQR family is structurally related to the urotensin II receptor, which is coupled to the Gq family of G-proteins. The PAQR family is structurally related to the orphan receptors GPR3, GPR6, and GPR1 2. The PAQR family is structurally related to the putative pheromone receptors, GPR2 1 and GPR2 7. The putative pheromone receptors are structurally related to the adhesion GPCRs, which are also 7TM receptors. The adhesion GPCR subfamily is large and phylogenetically ancient, and is found in all metazoan genomes sequenced to date. The adhesion GPCR subfamily is found in all metazoan genomes sequenced to date, but is absent from the genomes of fungi and choanoflagellates. The adhesion GPCR subfamily is phylogenetically ancient, with representatives in the genomes of the sponge Suberites domuncula, the ctenophore Mnemiopsis leidyi, the placozoan Trichoplax adhaerens, the echinoderm Strongylocentrotus purpuratus, the urochordate Ciona savignyi, the cephalochordate Branchiostoma floridae, and the jellyfish Hydractinia echinata. The adhesion GPCR subfamily is phylogenetically ancient, with representatives in the genomes of the sponge Suberites domuncula, the ctenophore Mnemiopsis leidyi, the placozoan Trichoplax adhaerens, the echinoderm Strongylocentrotus purpuratus, the urochordate Ciona savignyi, the cephalochordate Branchiostoma floridae, and the jellyfish Hydractinia echinata. The adhesion GPCR subfamily is phylogenetically ancient, with representatives in the genomes of the sponge Suberites domuncularis, the ctenophore Mnemiopsis leidyi, the placozoan Trichoplax adhaerens, the echinoderm Strongylocentrotus purpuratus, the urochordate Ciona savignyi, the cephalochordate Branchiostoma floridae, and the jellyfish Hydractinia echinata. The putative pheromone receptors are structurally related to the neuropeptide Y (NPY) family of receptors, which are also 7TM receptors. The putative pheromone receptors are structurally related to the urotensin II receptor, which is also a 7TM receptor. The urotensin II receptor is coupled to Gq and is coupled to the intracellular calcium release pathway.

The glutamate ionotropic receptor NMDA type (GRIN1) is a ligand-gated ion channel that is activated by the neurotransmitter glutamate. The GRIN1 protein is a tetramer consisting of two NR1 and two NR2 subunits (A-D). The NR2 subunits determine the type of ion channel that is formed and the subcellular localization of the receptor. The NR2 subunits are also targets for phosphorylation by a variety of protein kinases including PKA, PKC, PKG, and CAMKII. The NR2 subunits are phosphorylated at multiple sites, and the phosphorylation state of the NR2 subunits can alter the properties of the receptor.

The complement system is a group of more than thirty plasma proteins that are part of the immune response to infection. When activated, complement proteins recruit and opsonize bacteria, recruit and activate phagocytes, and directly lyse bacteria. The complement system is activated by three different pathways: the classical pathway, the lectin-mediated pathway, and the alternative pathway. In the classical pathway, antibodies bound to the surface of bacteria activate the complement cascade. In the lectin-mediated pathway, mannose-binding lectin (MBL) binds to carbohydrates on the surface of bacteria activating the complement cascade. In the alternative pathway, spontaneous activation of complement occurs without the presence of antibodies. In all three pathways, a series of proteolytic reactions lead to the formation of a pore in the bacterial membrane that allows the complement proteins to lyse the bacteria.

The interferon (IFN) family of cytokines includes at least 1 3 distinct members that are involved in both innate and adaptive immune responses. The type I IFNs, IFN-alpha and IFN-beta, are induced by viral infection and are involved in the early innate response to viral infection. The type II IFN, IFN-gamma, is induced by cytokines such as IL-2 and is involved in the adaptive immune response. The type III IFN, IFN-lambda, is induced by viral infection and is involved in the innate immune response. The IFN-alpha and -beta proteins bind to a cell surface receptor and signal through the JAK / STAT pathway to induce expression of interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs). The ISGs encode proteins that inhibit viral replication and other processes involved in viral infection. The JAK / STAT pathway is also activated by IFN-gamma, but the JAK kinases involved in this pathway are different from those involved in the IFN-alpha / beta response. The IFN-gamma receptor activates JAK kinases and the STAT transcription factors to induce expression of ISGs. The IFN-alpha / beta receptor also activates the JAK / STAT pathway, but the receptor does not contain JAK kinases. The IFN-alpha / beta receptor also activates the NF-kB transcription factor, and like the JAK / STAT pathway, NF-kB is involved in the immune response to viral infection. The NF-kB pathway is activated by many different stimuli, including cytokines, bacterial products, and viral infection. The IFN-alpha / beta receptor and the JAK / STAT pathway also activate NF-kB, but the role of NF-kB in the IFN response is not clear. The IFN-gamma receptor activates JAK kinases and the STAT transcription factors, but does not activate NF-kB. The IFN-alpha / beta and IFN-gamma receptors activate distinct JAK kinases and STAT transcription factors, but both pathways activate NF-kB. The IFN-alpha / beta and IFN-gamma receptors activate distinct pathways, but both pathways activate NF-kB. The role of NF-kB in the IFN response is not clear. Some studies indicate that NF-kB is involved in the IFN response, while other studies indicate that NF-kB is not involved.

The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a receptor tyrosine kinase that is over-expressed in many different types of cancer. It is a key regulator of cell proliferation and survival and is a target for cancer therapy. The ligand for EGFR is EGF, which is released from cells and binds to EGFR on the cell surface. The binding of EGF to EGFR activates the receptor and causes the receptor to dimerize. The two receptors in the dimer are activated by each other, and each receptor has an active site that phosphorylates other proteins in the cell. One of the targets of EGFR is GRB2, which binds to EGFR and activates the MAP kinase pathway. Another target of EGFR is p21-activated kinase (PAK2). PAK2 is involved in the regulation of the actin cytoskeleton and is activated by EGFR. The activation of PAK2 by EGFR may contribute to the role of EGFR in cell migration and metastasis.

Base excision repair (BER) is the predominant mechanism for the repair of small base lesions such as the alkylated bases and oxidized bases. BER is initiated by a lesion-specific DNA glycosylase that recognizes and excises the base lesion, generating an apurinic / apyrimidinic (AP) site. In the next step, an AP endonuclease (APE1 in human) incises the DNA 5 'to the AP site, generating a single-nucleotide gap with a 5' -deoxyribose phosphate (dRP) residue. In short-patch BER, DNA polymerase (pol) beta removes the dRP and fills in the single nucleotide gap, followed by DNA ligase (Lig) I or Lig III (x-ray repair cross-complementing 1 (XRCC1) and x-ray repair cross-complementing 2 (XRCC2)) -mediated ligation. In long-patch BER, DNA pol delta / epsilon and DNA ligase (Lig) I or Lig III are involved. In single-strand break repair (SSBR), DNA damage is detected and processed by the BER proteins, and the ends are then processed to generate 3 '-OH and 5' -P termini, which are then restored to intact DNA by DNA pol lambda or pol beta.

Aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption in the distal nephron by increasing the activity of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC). ENaC is a member of the ENaC / degenerin family of ion channels. ENaC is expressed in the apical membrane of tight epithelia, such as the distal nephron, lung, and colon. ENaC is formed by three homologous subunits (alpha, beta, and gamma) that combine to form a channel with 2alpha1beta1gamma1subunit stoichiometry. ENaC is a limiting step in sodium absorption in tight epithelia and is regulated by a variety of factors, including serum sodium, vasopressin, and aldosterone. Aldosterone acts through the mineralocorticoid receptor (MR), a member of the steroid hormone receptor gene family, to increase sodium transport. Aldosterone binds to MR in the cytoplasm, causing translocation of the MR-ligand complex to the nucleus. In the nucleus, the MR binds to specific hormone response elements in the regulatory region of ENaC genes, increasing transcription. In addition to transcriptional regulation, aldosterone increases ENaC activity by a rapid, nontranscriptional mechanism. This nontranscriptional mechanism does not require MR or the nucleus. Aldosterone increases the open probability of ENaC channels in the apical membrane by a kinase-dependent mechanism. The kinase SGK1, which is transcriptionally induced by aldosterone, phosphorylates the E3 ubiquitin ligase Nedd4-2, causing Nedd4-2 to bind more tightly to ENaC, resulting in increased ubiquitination and proteosomal degradation of ENaC. The nontranscriptional effect of aldosterone does not require SGK1. The rapid effect of aldosterone on ENaC is independent of SGK1 and Nedd4-2.

Protein phosphorylation is a key mechanism of regulating protein activity. Protein kinases are enzymes that transfer a phosphate group from ATP or GTP to specific serine, threonine, or tyrosine residues in other proteins. The eukaryotic protein kinase PKR is an interferon-induced protein kinase that plays a key role in the anti-viral response. PKR is activated by binding to dsRNA, a by-product of viral replication, and then phosphorylates the alpha subunit of the initiation factor eIF2, inhibiting protein synthesis and viral replication. In addition to its role in the anti-viral response, PKR also plays a role in other cellular processes such as cell growth and differentiation. PKR is activated by a variety of cellular stresses, including oxidative stress, heat shock, and amino acid starvation. These stresses activate PKR through a mechanism that does not involve dsRNA binding. Instead, these stresses activate PKR by inducing autophosphorylation of PKR at multiple sites. Once activated, PKR phosphorylates the alpha subunit of eIF2, inhibiting the formation of the ternary complex (eIF2-GTP-Met-tRNAi) and blocking translation.

The retinoic acid receptor (RAR) is a member of the steroid hormone receptor gene family and is activated by its ligand all-trans retinoic acid (RA). RAR forms a heterodimer with the retinoid X receptor (RXR) and binds to RA response elements (RAREs) in the promoter region of RA-responsive genes. The transcriptional activity of RAR is regulated by a variety of coactivators and corepressors. The coactivators include CBP / p300, SRC-1, p160, CBP / p160 / RAC3, ACTR, and p / CIP. The corepressors include N-CoR, SMRT, and Alien. The binding of coactivators or corepressors to RAR is ligand-dependent. The coactivators and corepressors bind to the activation function-2 (AF-2) domain of RAR through a conserved LxxLL motif. The binding of coactivators to RAR is inhibited by the corepressors in the absence of ligand. Binding of RA to RAR induces a conformational change that dissociates the corepressors and allows the binding of coactivators. The coactivators and corepressors are recruited to the promoter region of the RA-responsive genes through interaction with other transcription factors. The coactivators and corepressors also play a role in the repression of RA-responsive genes by other transcription factors. The binding of corepressors to RAR is inhibited by the transcription factor YY1. The binding of YY1 to RAR is inhibited by the transcription factor NF-Y, which binds to the same site as YY1 in the RA-responsive promoter.

Nerve growth factor (NGF) is a member of the neurotrophin family of growth factors that are required for the development and survival of specific populations of neurons. NGF binds to TrkA, a member of the trk family of receptor tyrosine kinases, to initiate signaling. NGF-TrkA signaling activates several signaling pathways, including the Ras / mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway, phospholipase C-gamma (PLC-gamma), and the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3-K) pathway. The activation of these pathways leads to the induction of neuronal survival and differentiation.

The interferon (IFN) family of cytokines includes several members that are involved in antiviral responses. One of the key actions of type I IFNs is the induction of an antiviral state in cells. The antiviral state induced by type I IFNs is mediated by the transcriptional activation of a set of genes known as the interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs). The products of these genes inhibit viral replication at various steps. One of the key transcription factors involved in the induction of ISGs is the interferon regulatory factor 3 (IRF-3). In the absence of IFN signaling, IRF-3 is maintained in an inactive state in the cytoplasm. Viral infection or treatment with type I IFNs activates the JAK / STAT signaling pathway, leading to the phosphorylation and activation of IRF-3. Activated IRF-3 translocates into the nucleus and binds to the ISRE (IFN-stimulated response element) in the promoter of ISGs, leading to their transcriptional activation. Another key transcription factor involved in the induction of ISGs is NF-kB. NF-kB is maintained in an inactive state in the cytoplasm by association with IkB. Viral infection or treatment with type I IFNs activates the IKK kinase complex, which phosphorylates IkB, leading to its degradation and the release of NF-kB. NF-kB then translocates into the nucleus and binds to the NF-kB site in the promoter of ISGs, leading to their transcriptional activation. The IRF-3 and NF-kB transcription factors cooperate to induce the full set of ISGs.

The immune system is a complex network of cells and molecules that protects the body against invading organisms and aberrant cells. The antigen-specific immune response is initiated when foreign antigen is recognized by T cells. The T cell receptor recognizes antigen in the context of MHC molecules on the surface of antigen-presenting cells. The T cell response is regulated by a variety of costimulatory signals provided by other cells in the immune system. The interaction of T cells with antigen-presenting cells is enhanced by the interaction of the CD40 molecule on the T cell with its ligand, CD137 on the antigen-presenting cell. The CD80 / 1heterodimer on the T cell interacts with the CD8alpha / 1heterodimer on the antigen-presenting cell to provide a costimulatory signal. The interaction of CD40 with CD137 is enhanced by the interaction of CD40 with the B cell costimulatory molecule, CD54. The interaction of CD80 / 1with CD8alpha / 1is enhanced by the interaction of CD8alpha / 1with intercellular adhesion molecule 1 (ICAM-1). The interaction of CD40 with CD137 is enhanced by the interaction of CD40 with the T cell costimulatory molecule, CD28.

N-linked glycans are attached to asparagine residues of polypeptide chains via an amide bond. N-glycans are classified into four groups: high-mannose, hybrid, complex and neutral glycans. The biosynthesis of N-glycans starts with the transfer of N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) from UDP-GlcNAc to the lipid precursor, dolichol-P, to form GlcNAc-PP-GlcNAc. This GlcNAc can be transferred several times to a growing polypeptide chain, and the resulting Man5GlcNAc structure is then extended by the addition of mannose, galactose, and N-acetylglucosamine to form the core structure, Man3GlcNAc. The addition of glucose residues by the enzyme ER glucosyltransferase (ERGT) represents the first sign of the formation of a complex N-glycan. If the glycan is to be further modified, the mannose residues are extended by the addition of fucoses and N-acetylglucosamine residues by a series of glycosyltransferases. The last three steps in the assembly of a complex N-glycan are catalyzed by a membrane-bound enzyme complex, the N-acetylglucosaminyltransferases (ALG).

The chemokine receptors are a family of G-protein coupled receptors that bind to chemoattractant ligands and are expressed on leukocytes. They are involved in leukocyte trafficking and activation. The chemokine receptors CCR5 and CXCR4 are used by HIV-1 as coreceptors along with CD4 for viral entry into cells. The CCR5 receptor is used by macrophage tropic HIV-1 strains, while the CXCR4 receptor is used by T-cell tropic HIV-1 strains. The expression of CCR5 and CXCR4 is regulated by cytokines and other factors. The expression of CCR5 is induced by interferon-gamma and other factors that activate macrophages, while the expression of CXCR4 is induced by cytokines that activate T cells. CCR5 and CXCR4 are also involved in the migration of leukocytes in normal immune responses.

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) is the key regulator of reproduction in all vertebrates. It is synthesized in the hypothalamus and secreted into the hypophyseal portal circulation, which then travels to the anterior pituitary to stimulate the synthesis and secretion of the gonadotropins, luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). The two forms of GnRH, chicken GnRH I and GnRH II, are found in most vertebrates. In mammals, GnRH I is the major form, whereas in nonmammalian vertebrates, GnRH II is the major form. The GnRH receptor belongs to the 7TM receptor gene family and is coupled to Gq / 1 1, which activates phospholipase C. The resulting second messengers are IP3 and DAG, which mobilize intracellular calcium, and activate protein kinase C. These second messengers are essential for GnRH receptor signaling. The activation of the MAPK cascade by the receptor also requires the activation of PKC. The activation of the PKC pathway is calcium dependent, whereas the activation of the Ras / Raf / MEK / ERK pathway is calcium independent. The GnRH receptor is also coupled to the Gs / AC / cAMP pathway, which is involved in the regulation of the synthesis of the gonadotropins. The activation of the Gs / AC / cAMP pathway is also involved in the regulation of the synthesis of the gonadotropins.

The main transduction pathway for olfaction is through activation of a cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase A (PKA) cascade in the cilia of olfactory receptor neurons (ORNs). The main excitatory stimulus is binding of odorants to a receptor coupled to a Gs protein. Activation of the Gs protein stimulates adenylyl cyclase (AC), which converts ATP to cAMP. The elevated intracellular cAMP activates a cyclic-nucleotide-gated (CNG) channel, leading to influx of Na + and Ca + +, and a small depolarization. The depolarization opens a transduction channel, which is permeable to Na +, Ca + +, and less permeable to K +. The increase in intracellular Ca + + activates a Cl − channel, increasing the Cl − concentration in the cilia, which further depolarizes the cell. The Ca + + also activates a Ca + + -activated Cl − channel, which may further depolarize the cell. The Ca + + also activates a Ca + + -calmodulin-dependent kinase (CaM kinase), which may modulate the activity of other proteins. The activation of the kinase cascade may also modulate the activity of the CNG channel.

Neurotrophins are a family of trophic factors that support the survival and differentiation of specific neuronal populations. The neurotrophins include nerve growth factor (NGF), brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), neurotrophin-3 (NT-3), and neurotrophin-4 (NT-4). Neurotrophin binding to Trk tyrosine kinase receptors activates several signaling pathways, including the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway and the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway. The PI3K pathway is activated by binding of neurotrophins to Trk receptors, and leads to the phosphorylation and activation of Akt. The activation of Akt by neurotrophins leads to the phosphorylation and inactivation of the pro-apoptotic protein Bad. The phosphorylation of Bad by Akt leads to the formation of a complex between Bad and the survival factor Bcl-xL, preventing the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria and blocking apoptosis. The activation of the MAPK pathway by Trk receptors leads to the phosphorylation of the transcription factor CREB, which can lead to the activation of genes involved in neuronal survival.

Telomeres are specialized structures at the ends of chromosomes that consist of short, tandemly repeated DNA sequences and associated proteins. Telomerase is a ribonucleoprotein enzyme that adds de novo telomeric repeats to the ends of chromosomes using an RNA template. Telomerase activity is low or undetectable in most human somatic cells, but is activated in germ cells and in most cancer cells. Telomerase activity is repressed in most human somatic cells, and this repression is one mechanism by which cells achieve the limited proliferative capacity that characterizes normal human cells in culture. Telomerase activity is repressed in most human cells in culture due to the progressive shortening of telomeres with each round of cell division. When telomeres become critically short, a checkpoint in the cell cycle is activated that leads to cell death by apoptosis or a senescence program. Telomerase activity is repressed in most human cells in culture due to the progressive shortening of telomeres with each round of cell division. When telomeres become critically short, a checkpoint in the cell cycle is activated that leads to cell death by apoptosis or a senescence program. Telomerase activity is repressed in most human cells in culture due to the progressive shortening of telomeres with each round of cell division. Telomerase activity is activated in most human cancer cells, and this activation is one mechanism by which cancer cells achieve the unlimited proliferative capacity that characterizes cancer cells. Telomerase activity is repressed in most human cells in culture due to the progressive shortening of telomeres with each round of cell division. When telomeres become critically short, a checkpoint in the cell cycle is activated that leads to cell death by apoptosis or a senescence program. Telomerase activity is repressed in most human cells in culture due to the progressive shortening of telomeres with each round of cell division. Telomerase activity is repressed in most human cells in culture due to the progressive shortening of telomeres.

The peptide hormone endothelin-1 (ET-1) is a potent vasoconstrictor that is also mitogenic and pro-fibrotic. ET-1 is secreted by endothelial cells and binds to two G-protein coupled receptors, ETAR and ETBR, expressed in many cell types. Binding of ET-1 to ETAR stimulates phospholipase C, which cleaves phosphatidylinositol to generate inositol trisphosphate and diacylglycerol. Inositol trisphosphate stimulates release of calcium from intracellular stores, and diacylglycerol activates protein kinase C (PKC). PKC activation also stimulates the Raf-Mek-Erk pathway, leading to activation of the transcription factor AP-1. PKC also activates the Map kinase pathway, leading to activation of the transcription factor NF-kB. Activation of AP-1 and NF-kB stimulates transcription of genes involved in cell proliferation and inflammation. Activation of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) stimulates cell proliferation through multiple pathways, including activation of ras and the Map kinase pathway. ET-1 also stimulates proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMC) through activation of the EGFR. ET-1 also stimulates proliferation of fibroblasts and epithelial cells through activation of the EGFR. ET-1 also stimulates production of extracellular matrix proteins by fibroblasts and other cell types. The proliferative and pro-fibrotic actions of ET-1 may contribute to the pathogenesis of cardiovascular and renal diseases. ET receptor antagonists are being developed as potential therapeutic agents.

Growth hormone (GH) is a peptide hormone that regulates growth and metabolism. The GH receptor (GHR) is a member of the cytokine receptor gene family. Binding of GH to the GHR activates the JAK / STAT pathway, the MAPK pathway, and the PI3 kinase pathway. These pathways in turn regulate gene expression.

The cell cycle is a highly coordinated sequence of events that includes DNA replication and cell division. The G1 to S phase transition is a key regulatory checkpoint in the cell cycle. This transition is regulated by the concerted action of the cyclin-dependent kinases (cdks) and their associated regulatory subunits, the cyclins. The activity of the cdks is regulated by the association of the cyclins with the cdk inhibitors. The cdk-cyclin complexes phosphorylate specific proteins that regulate the G1 to S phase transition. The phosphorylation of the Rb protein by the cdk4-cyclin D and cdk6-cyclin D complexes releases the inhibition of the E2F transcription factors that are required for progression into S phase. The cdk2-cyclin E complex also phosphorylates the Rb protein, and the phosphorylation of the histone H1 protein by the cdk2-cyclin A complex completes the release of the E2F transcriptional activation. The cyclin-cdk inhibitors, such as p16INK4a, p15Ink4b, and p27Kip1, inhibit the phosphorylation of the cdk substrates and act as tumor suppressors. The p16INK4a-cdk4-p60Rb pathway is frequently disrupted in human cancer. The p15Ink4b-p90Rsk pathway is also frequently disrupted in cancer. The p27Kip1 protein inhibits the formation of the cdk2-cyclin E and cdk2-cyclin A complexes and acts as a tumor suppressor. The TGF-beta signaling pathway plays a key role in regulating the cell cycle. Binding of TGF-beta to its receptor activates the receptor-associated Smad proteins, p23 and p37. The activated Smads translocate to the nucleus and interact with other transcription factors to regulate the expression of cell cycle inhibitors, such as p15Ink4b and p27Kip1.

The cell cycle is a highly regulated process that ensures that DNA is replicated only once per cell cycle and that the cell cycle is separated into four phases: G1, S, G2 and M. The G1 phase is the period of preparation for DNA replication and the restriction point is the point at which the cell no longer responds to growth factors. The restriction point is just one point in the cell cycle. When the cell cycle is paused at the restriction point, the cell is no longer able to enter S phase and DNA replication does not occur. The restriction point is regulated by the cyclin dependent kinases (CDKs). The CDKs are a family of proteins that are activated by the binding of a cyclin subunit and are involved in the regulation of the cell cycle. The CDKs are activated by the phosphorylation of threonine 1 6 1 by the CDK activating kinase (CAK). The CDKs are negatively regulated by the CDK inhibitors (CDKIs). The CDKIs are a family of proteins that are involved in the regulation of the cell cycle and are classified into two groups: the INK4 inhibitors (p1 5, p1 6, p1 8 and p1 9) and the KIP / Cip inhibitors (p2 1, p2 7 and p5 7). The INK4 inhibitors specifically inhibit the CDK4 and CDK6 kinases that phosphorylate the Rb protein to release the transcription factor E2F-1. E2F-1 is involved in the transcription of genes involved in DNA replication and progression through the cell cycle. The KIP / Cip inhibitors inhibit the activity of CDK2 and CDK1, which are involved in the transition from G1 to S phase. The CDKIs are regulated by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. The phosphorylation of the CDKIs by the CDKs targets them for ubiquitin-mediated degradation. The ubiquitination of the CDKIs is carried out by an SCF complex that includes the proteins Cul1, Skp1, Roc1 and CD34. The ubiquitination of the CDKIs by the SCF complex targets them for degradation by the 2 6S proteasome. The degradation of the CDKIs by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway allows the CDKs to phosphorylate the Rb protein and release the transcription factor E2F-1. E2F-1 then activates the transcription of genes involved in DNA replication and progression through the cell cycle. The ubiquitin-proteasome pathway also plays a role in the DNA damage checkpoint. The phosphorylation of the CDKI p21 by the checkpoint kinase ATM stabilizes p21 and prevents the activation of CDKs and the cell cycle progression in response to DNA damage.

Nerve growth factor (NGF) is a neurotrophin that promotes the survival and differentiation of specific neuronal populations. NGF binds to TrkA, a receptor tyrosine kinase, to initiate signaling. NGF binding to TrkA activates Ras / Map kinase signaling and also phospholipase C-gamma 1 (PLC-gamma 1). The Map kinase pathway includes activation of p38 and p21, which regulate transcription. The p38 pathway includes induction of c-fos and Egr-1, and the p21 pathway includes induction of Egr-1. The Map kinase pathway also includes activation of the transcription factor SRF. NGF also activates the AKT pathway, which regulates the forkhead transcription factor FKHRL1. NGF also activates the small G protein Rac1, which regulates the JNK pathway. NGF also activates PI3 kinase, which activates p44 / 42 and regulates other pathways.

The sense of taste is mediated by specialized receptors located in the taste bud that respond to a variety of taste stimuli. Taste receptors are found on both the apical and basolateral membranes of taste cells. On the apical surface of taste cells, there are ion channels that transduce taste stimuli into electrical signals. These include amiloride-sensitive Na + channels for salt, acid-sensing ion channels (ASICs) for sour, and the two pore-domain K + channels (Kcn2s) for bitter and sweet. On the basolateral membrane, taste cells are stimulated by taste-detecting G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs). These GPCRs include the heterodimer taste 1 receptor (T1R) for sweet and umami, and the heterodimer taste 2 receptor (T2R) for bitter and sweet. In addition to these GPCRs, taste cells express a variety of taste signal transduction elements including PLCbeta2, which produces IP3 and diacylglycerol, which in turn activate a transient increase in intracellular Ca2 +. This Ca2 + signal activates the TRPM5 channel, which is required for the transduction of all taste qualities.

Sonic hedgehog (Shh) is a secreted protein that plays a key role in the development of many tissues. In the developing cerebellum, Shh secreted by the Purkinje cells acts on the granule cell precursors (GCPs) in the external granule cell layer (EGL) to stimulate their proliferation. The proliferating GCPs then migrate into the internal granule cell layer (IGL) and differentiate. Shh signaling is also involved in the proliferation of other cell types, including neural precursors in the developing retina and the developing brain. The Shh receptor is a transmembrane protein called Patched (Ptc). In the absence of Shh, Ptc inhibits the activity of Smoothened (Smo), a G-protein coupled receptor. Smo then activates several signaling pathways, including the Gli family of transcription factors. The role of Shh signaling in cancer has been the focus of considerable recent research. Mutations in the Shh receptor Ptc or in the Shh signaling pathway components Smo or Sufu have been found in a large fraction of human cancers, including basal cell carcinomas, meduloblastoma, and some forms of pancreatic cancer. The discovery that Shh signaling is involved in cancer has led to the development of drugs that block the Shh pathway and are being tested as anti-cancer agents.

The T-cell receptor (TCR) complex is a multimeric complex that is expressed on the surface of all T cells and is responsible for the recognition of specific antigens in the form of peptides bound to MHC molecules on the surface of antigen-presenting cells (APCs). The TCR complex is composed of five subunits, alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and epsilon. The CD3 complex is composed of three heterodimers, gamma, delta, epsilon, and zeta. The TCR complex is responsible for the recognition of specific antigens in the form of peptides bound to MHC molecules, and the activation of T cells. The interaction of the TCR with the MHC / peptide complex is the key event in the activation of T cells. The interaction of the T-cell receptor with MHC / peptide is a two-step process. The first step is the interaction of the T-cell receptor with MHC / peptide. The T-cell receptor binds to the MHC / peptide complex in a peptide-specific manner, but the affinity of the interaction is low. The second step is the interaction of the T-cell receptor with the CD4 or CD8 coreceptor. The coreceptor increases the affinity of the interaction of the T-cell receptor with MHC / peptide and increases the specificity of the interaction. The coreceptor is responsible for increasing the sensitivity of T cells and is also involved in the regulation of T-cell activation. The coreceptor is not required for T-cell activation, but increases the sensitivity of T-cell activation. The coreceptor is not required for the binding of the T-cell receptor to MHC / peptide, but is required for the activation of T cells by T cells. The coreceptor is required for the interaction of the T-cell receptor with the tyrosine kinase Lck. Lck is a member of the src family of tyrosine kinases that are involved in signal transduction pathways. Lck phosphorylates the tyrosine residues in the immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motifs (ITAMs) in the CD3 subunits of the T-cell receptor complex. The phosphorylation of the ITAMs increases the affinity of the T-cell receptor for the tyrosine kinase Zap-7 0, which is associated with the T-cell receptor complex. Lck also phosphorylates the coreceptor CD8beta, which is required for the coreceptor activity. The activation of Lck and Zap-7 0 by the coreceptor increases the number of T-cell receptors that bind MHC / peptide and increases the sensitivity of T cells to antigen. The interaction of the T-cell receptor with the coreceptor CD8beta also regulates the specificity of T-cell activation. T cells that do not express CD8beta are anergic to antigen and do not respond to antigen presented by MHC-I molecules. The interaction of the T-cell receptor with the coreceptor CD8beta is required for the interaction of the T-cell receptor with the Lck kinase. The interaction of the T-cell receptor with the coreceptor CD8beta also regulates the specificity of T-cell activation. T cells that do not express CD8beta are anergic to antigen and do not respond to antigen presented by MHC-I molecules. T cells that do not express CD8beta are anergic to antigen and do not respond to antigen presented by MHC-I molecules. The interaction of the T-cell receptor with the coreceptor CD8beta also regulates the specificity of T-cell activation.
